headline: End-of-Summer Business Reading: Dreamers and the Defiant
abstract: Summer’s almost gone, but in these last warm days you might reach into a few books on some of the people and creations that shape the economy.
lead_paragraph: With just a week left before the unofficial end of what has been a relentless summer of business news — the fate of Greece, the economic woes of China and the market roller coaster in the United States — hopefully you might find the time to read a book.

headline: U.S. Open 2015: Stars Take a Beating on a Topsy-Turvy Day
abstract: Serena Williams was the lone top-10 player who remained in the top half of the women’s draw. Kei Nishikori fell in the men’s bracket. Other first-round victims included Ana Ivanovic and Carla Suárez Navarro.
lead_paragraph: Amid a flurry of first-round upsets, Kei Nishikori had multiple chances — two, to be specific — to sidestep disaster at the United States Open on Monday.

headline: 6 Players Get Probation in Sayreville, N.J., Football Hazing Case
abstract: Four teenagers pleaded guilty, and two others were convicted on lesser charges, in a case that shocked and divided the town last fall.
lead_paragraph: Six of the seven teenagers charged with sexually abusing teammates in a football hazing scandal at the high school in Sayreville, N.J., last fall were sentenced to probation and 50 hours each of community service, a prosecutor said on Monday.

headline: Clash Erupts During Raid by Israelis in West Bank
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A raid that appeared to be aimed at arresting people suspected as Palestinian militants turned into an armed confrontation in the Jenin refugee camp.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Israeli soldiers clashed with Palestinian gunmen in one of the West Bank’s toughest refugee camps overnight Tuesday, as a raid that appeared to be aimed at arresting people suspected as Palestinian militants turned into an armed confrontation.

headline: Supreme Court Says Kentucky Clerk Must Let Gay Couples Marry
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The new case from Kentucky, Davis v. Miller, was the court’s first opportunity to consider whether government officials may refuse to recognize same-sex marriages on religious grounds.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday refused to allow a county clerk in Kentucky who objects to same-sex marriage on religious grounds to continue to deny marriage licenses to all couples, gay or straight.

headline: Japan Nears Test Flight for Long-Delayed Regional Passenger Jet
abstract: Japan’s first commercial airliner in half a century — the Mitsubishi Regional Jet — will take its first test flight in October.
lead_paragraph: After several years of delays, Japan’s first commercial airliner in about half a century is scheduled for its first test flight — an hourlong ride out of Nagoya Airport.

headline: California Defends Its Review Process in Appeal to Preserve Death Penalty
abstract: A federal appeals panel on Monday heard the state’s argument against a 2014 ruling that could bring a reprieve to all the inmates on death row in California.
lead_paragraph: California on Monday asked a federal appeals panel to overturn a 2014 court ruling that — unless it is reversed — could bring a reprieve to the more than 740 inmates on death row in the state.

headline: TV Dinners in a Netflix World
abstract: Big food companies like Nestlé are sinking money into revitalizing their frozen offerings, after upstarts have taken supermarket freezer space with more innovative foods.
lead_paragraph: SOLON, Ohio — The pizza arrived, mozzarella melting on a red crushed tomato blanket dotted with brilliant green spinach aboard a crispy, irregularly shaped crust dusted here and there with ash.

headline: Insights, and Redactions, in Latest Release of Hillary Clinton’s Emails
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The 4,368 documents released by the State Department on Monday contain insights into Hillary Rodham Clinton’s circle and underscore her acute interest in remaining current on political developments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chelsea Clinton warned her parents that international relief efforts in Haiti were a disaster and that major changes were needed in a memo released on Monday that offered a rare window into her role in America’s most prominent political family.

headline: A Wild Month on Wall St. Ends Quietly
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'United States Economy', 'Nasdaq Composite Index', 'Interest Rates', 'Dow Jones Stock Average']
abstract: August’s turbulence interrupted an unusually long period of tranquillity, but some analysts found reasons to believe that the markets may have found a bottom.
lead_paragraph: For several years, parking one’s savings in the United States stock market seemed like a no-brainer. Not only did stocks steadily climb — giving investors far better returns than they could get from their bank accounts — the ride up was smooth.

headline: Nelson Shanks, Who Painted the Prominent, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Shanks, known for his portraits of political leaders and figures in the arts, this year revealed that he had included a visual reference to the Monica Lewinsky affair in a portrait of Bill Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Nelson Shanks, a painter known for his portraits of political leaders and prominent figures in the arts, who earlier this year revealed that he had included a visual reference to the Monica Lewinsky affair in his portrait of Bill Clinton for the National Portrait Gallery, died on Friday at his home in Bucks County, Pa. He was 77.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Episode 7 Recap: The Trouble With Steve Murphy
abstract: The show’s main American character is one of its weaknesses.
lead_paragraph: Read all of our “Narcos” recaps.

headline: 244 Immigrants With Criminal Records Face Deportation in California
abstract: Federal authorities arrested 244 unauthorized immigrants who had previously been convicted of crimes, including violent felonies and sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — More than 240 immigrants with criminal records who are living in the United States illegally were taken into custody last week during a four-day sweep across Southern California, immigration authorities said Monday.

headline: Most Nations Miss a Goal for Women in Leadership
abstract: Despite a pledge made by world leaders to have women make up at least 30 percent of their national legislatures, most of the world’s parliaments remain largely male.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The corridors of the United Nations hummed on Monday as hundreds of men, in polished wingtips and natty ties, arrived here for the annual conclave of lawmakers from around the world.

headline: Wayne W. Dyer, Prolific Author of Self-Help Books, Dies at 75
abstract: Dr. Dyer, author of the best-selling “Your Erroneous Zones” and more than two dozen books, was a popular lecturer and talk-show guest.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Wayne W. Dyer, whose best-selling 1976 book decrying the vice of blame and preaching the virtue of self-reliance, “Your Erroneous Zones,” propelled him to a prolific multimedia career of advice-giving and spiritual counseling, died over the weekend in Maui, Hawaii. He was 75.

headline: Murder Rates Rising Sharply in Many U.S. Cities
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Urban Areas', 'Gangs', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Cities across the nation are seeing a startling rise in murders this year, and few places have witnessed a shift as precipitous as Milwaukee.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Cities across the nation are seeing a startling rise in murders after years of declines, and few places have witnessed a shift as precipitous as this city. With the summer not yet over, 104 people have been killed this year — after 86 homicides in all of 2014.

headline: Making American Men’s Game Great Again: Ideas?
abstract: Perhaps with an asterisk, Tommy Haas, who lost his opener Monday, was the most credentialed American in the men’s field at this U.S. Open, despite being ranked 506th.
lead_paragraph: On Tommy Haas’s Twitter page, in an Aug. 22 posting to his roughly 157,000 followers, he wrote: “Make America great again. Thoughts? Suggestions?”

headline: An Escalating Migrant Crisis and an Intensifying Search for Solutions
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The crisis has exposed vulnerabilities in the European Union’s open border policy, a fundamental tenet of the continental union.
lead_paragraph: A mounting migrant crisis has forced members of the European Union to search for new ways to adequately house, feed and effectively screen thousands of people seeking asylum. The recent influx of migrants, mostly from the Middle East and Northern Africa, has overwhelmed some countries and exposed vulnerabilities in the continental bloc’s open-border policy.

headline: Taxis of Yesterday and Today
abstract: From the Darracq to the Nissan NV200, a brief history of automobile models that have served as New York City taxis.
lead_paragraph: From the Darracq to the Nissan NV200, a brief history of automobile models that have served as New York City taxis.

headline: Tomorrow Arrives for New York City’s Yellow Cab Standard
abstract: Starting Tuesday, most cab owners will be required to switch to the Nissan NV200, known as the Taxi of Tomorrow, when they retire their cabs.
lead_paragraph: The boxy yellow vehicle is a survivor. It won a competition to redesign New York City’s taxi. It endured a pothole-marred course in Arizona meant to replicate the city’s rugged streets. And it prevailed in a legal battle and overcame the election of a new mayor who had been a vocal opponent.

headline: An Analyst’s Seamless Injection Into ESPN’s Rotation
abstract: Jessica Mendoza showed she belongs in the network’s regular mix of baseball game analysts, with a smart, understated stint in place of Curt Schilling.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Mendoza showed Sunday night that she belongs in ESPN’s regular rotation of baseball game analysts, with a smart, understated stint in place of Curt Schilling.

headline: 1993 Murder Conviction Vacated; Brooklyn Prosecutor Says Evidence Was Withheld
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'District Attorneys', 'Supreme Courts (State)']
abstract: District Attorney Kenneth P. Thompson admitted that his office had concealed a material-witness order as Ruddy Quezada, who was released after 24 years, sought to have his conviction reversed.
lead_paragraph: A man who had served 24 years on a murder conviction was released on Monday, after the Brooklyn district attorney admitted his office had withheld key evidence in the case against the man, Ruddy Quezada.

headline: As Crowds for Bernie Sanders Grow, the Biggest Impact Comes in Iowa
abstract: It is Mr. Sanders’s footprint in Iowa, that most critical of early states, where that expansion matters most.
lead_paragraph: BOONE, Iowa — The first person Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont met when he climbed out of a Dodge Journey here on a recent Saturday morning was Caleb Humphrey. It was for good reason.

headline: Top Officials With New York City Police Are Angered by Escapes
abstract: After a shoplifting suspect fled custody, becoming at least the fourth person to escape from the police this summer, Commissioner William J. Bratton said he would not tolerate such carelessness.
lead_paragraph: The woman, arrested after she was accused of skipping out on her bill at a restaurant and shoplifting, was taken to the hospital. She had told the police that she was pregnant and feeling ill.

abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, August 31, 2015.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: 3,000 Miles From Denali, Ohio Fumes Over Renaming of Mount McKinley
abstract: The renaming created rare unity between Republican and Democratic Buckeyes against President Obama, and even rarer agreement from members of both parties in Alaska praising him.
lead_paragraph: To be clear, President William McKinley has one of the largest grave sites of any former American president, so perhaps a mountaintop was a bit superfluous.

headline: Serena Williams Coasts Through First Round at U.S. Open
abstract: Williams, seeking to complete a Grand Slam, won 32 of 37 points and all eight games against Vitalia Diatchenko, who retired with an injury.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams spent about an hour on a practice court in the late afternoon on Monday in preparation for her first-round match of the U.S. Open. She pounded groundstrokes and serves, smashed some overheads, punched home a few volleys and even chased a handful of drop shots.

headline: Europe Must Reform Its Deadly Asylum Policies
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Border Barriers', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Editorials', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The European Union’s failed policies cannot escape blame for the suffering of thousands of people seeking to escape these crises.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of hundreds of thousands of refugees from war-torn regions of Africa and the Middle East, as well as economic migrants from Africa and Asia, is testing the European Union as no other recent crisis has. As the human toll mounts — more than 2,500 have died so far this year — so does the moral pressure on Europe to act. On Friday, after 71 people were found suffocated in a truck in Austria and 150 others drowned off the coast of Libya, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said he was “horrified and heartbroken at the latest loss of lives.”

headline: Expert Says Manuscript Is Not Harper Lee’s Third Novel
abstract: Recently discovered pages are from an earlier version of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” a rare books expert has concluded.
lead_paragraph: A rare books expert who reviewed recently discovered manuscript pages by Harper Lee has concluded that they are from an early version of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” and not a possible third novel by the author.

headline: White House Sidesteps Hubbub About Obama’s Future Role at Columbia
abstract: A passing comment by Columbia University’s president touched off a flurry of expectations that President Obama would affiliate with his alma mater after he leaves office, but the White House said no decisions had been made.
lead_paragraph: A passing comment by the president of Columbia University on Monday touched off a flurry of expectations that President Obama would affiliate with the university, his alma mater, after he leaves office, but the White House said no decisions had been made.

headline: U.S. Tennis Association’s New Executive Waits Patiently for American Boys to Fill a Void
abstract: Martin Blackman, the U.S.T.A.’s new general manager of player development, wants to temper the expectations the public places on players.
lead_paragraph: The shirt Andy Roddick was wearing when he won the 2003 United States Open was cool, so cool, with one sleeve black and the other white, and diagonal lines across the chest, and some more diagonals across the back, that Tommy Paul remembers wanting to do anything to get it.

headline: Help From Above
abstract: Michael Torch breathes life into his theme.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Just to mix it up a little, we’re going to begin with the constructor’s notes today.

headline: At U.S. Open Match, a Sea of Bills Blue
abstract: Fans rallied around the qualifier Jessica Pegula, the 21-year-old daughter of the Bills’ and Sabres' owner Terry Pegula, as she captured her first victory in the main draw of a Grand Slam event.
lead_paragraph: It is not often that N.F.L. apparel provides a clue of a spectator’s allegiance to a tennis player. But as play at the U.S. Open began Monday morning on Court 7, several fans in Buffalo Bills attire rallied around the 21-year-old qualifier Jessica Pegula as she sought her first victory in the main draw of a Grand Slam event.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Episode 8 Recap: It Doesn’t Have to End This Way
abstract: “Narcos” excels at piecing together historical moments, but it has trouble with intimacy.
lead_paragraph: Read all of our “Narcos” recaps.

headline: Mets’ Efficiency Pays Off in Latest Win Over Phils
abstract: Bartolo Colon pitched eight scoreless innings, and Michael Conforto and Curtis Granderson hit home runs.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Conforto, the Mets’ rookie left fielder, dug into the batter’s box in the fifth inning, he calmly processed the situation. The Mets were locked in a scoreless tie with the Philadelphia Phillies. The rookie Jerad Eickhoff had held the Mets to one hit, a single to Conforto, who punched a 1-2 pitch into right field in his first at-bat.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Aide on Homeless Is Resigning Amid Crisis
abstract: Lilliam Barrios-Paoli, the deputy mayor overseeing the city’s response to the homelessness crisis, will leave at the end of September to become the volunteer chairwoman of the board of the Health and Hospitals Corporation.
lead_paragraph: At a time when New York has taken emergency measures to help homeless residents, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Monday night that the deputy mayor overseeing the city’s response to the crisis will resign at the end of September.

headline: Explosion at Chinese Chemical Plant Is Said to Kill at Least 1
abstract: The blast occurred in Shandong Province on Monday night, according to a report in the Chinese news media, and the fire was put out by early Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — An explosion at a chemical plant in Shandong Province late Monday night killed at least one person, according to a Chinese news media report.

headline: Missed Opportunities Haunt the Yankees on a Frustrating Night in Boston
abstract: With Mark Teixeira headed back to New York for tests on his injured shin, the Yankees loaded the bases four times but scored only three runs.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — With the Yankees trailing by a run and down to their final out, but with the bases loaded, the crack of Didi Gregorius’s bat gave rise to hope in the visitors’ dugout as the ball soared toward deep right field.

headline: 1945: Tokio Ruin Bares Toll of Bombers
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Tokyo, pulverized by Allied bombing, reeled from the shock of surrender in 1945.
lead_paragraph: April 18, 1942, marked the first air raid on Tokyo by the United States. Strikes continued until August 15, 1945, when Emperor Hirohito announced Japan’s surrender, which was made official on Sept. 2.

keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']

headline: Rafael Nadal, Reinvigorated, Subdues a Rising Star
abstract: Nadal, the eighth seed and a two-time U.S. Open champion, coasted through the first two sets, but 18-year-old Borna Coric refused to go quietly.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Nadal is still a long way from reclaiming the form that once made him the most feared player on the ATP Tour, but with a solid victory against a talented young player, he moved into the second round of the United States Open.

headline: What’s On TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:05 A.M. (FLIX) MR. HOLLAND’S OPUS (1995) An idealistic composer (Richard Dreyfuss, above with Alicia Witt) takes a teaching job that becomes his true opus. “Mr. Dreyfuss’s taste for grandstanding could easily sink a tale of simple virtues, especially one about a music teacher who is often seen marching, dancing, conducting or otherwise registering emotions aimed at the bleacher seats,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “But in ‘Mr. Holland’s Opus,’ Mr. Dreyfuss gives a warm and really touching performance. He’s firmly in control of the film’s comic moments and just as comfortable delivering the film’s calculatingly Capraesque payoff: a good cry.”

headline: Teenage Motherhood in France
abstract: Vivane Dalles labored to find the money — and outside interest — to pursue an intensive project on teenage mothers in France.
lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — When Viviane Dalles decided to explore the dramatic increase in teenage pregnancy in France’s Nord-Pas-de-Calais region, she knew it would be difficult. Few publications were interested in the topic, while parents and their daughters were reluctant to grant permission.

headline: Obama to Call for More Icebreakers in Arctic as U.S. Seeks Foothold
abstract: The Coast Guard has the equivalent of just two “fully functional” heavy icebreakers, according to the White House, while Russia has 41.
lead_paragraph: SEWARD, Alaska — President Obama on Tuesday proposed speeding the acquisition and building of new Coast Guard icebreakers that can operate year round in the nation’s polar regions, part of an effort to close the gap between the United States and other nations, especially Russia, in a global competition to gain a foothold in the rapidly changing Arctic.

headline: When Bosses Schedule Hours That Just Don’t Work
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Overtime', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Some companies are starting to change their dubious policies, but unpredictable scheduling is still widespread.
lead_paragraph: Gap announced last week that it would soon end the practice of on-call scheduling, which requires workers to call in before a shift to see if they are needed. By the beginning of next year, the company’s five brands — Athleta, Banana Republic, Gap, Intermix and Old Navy — will give employees at least 10 to 14 days’ notice of their schedules.

headline: Hillary Clinton, the Great Defender
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: She has been playing defense most of her political career, and that’s given her strengths. But that mind-set also hurts her.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has obviously had a bad summer. She’s losing in New Hampshire to Bernie Sanders, even among women. She’s barely leading him in Iowa. In a Quinnipiac poll of potential general election matchups, she’s beating Donald Trump by only four points, 45 to 41, and she’s beating Marco Rubio by only one point.

lead_paragraph: China’s effort to prop up its stock market has taken a dangerous turn. Officials are arresting people whom they accuse of spreading rumors about the market and the unrelated industrial explosions in Tianjin that killed scores of people last month.

headline: Putting Donald Trump on the Couch
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Want to understand what motivates him? It’s worth looking at his lifelong fear of becoming a sucker.
lead_paragraph: AS surprising as Donald J. Trump’s political ascendance may be, it is not unprecedented. He is the latest in a long line of demagogues that have appeared throughout American history to point accusing fingers at blacks, foreigners, Masons, Jews, socialists, central bankers and others. What’s more mysterious are the roots of his vast insecurity — his compulsive need to trumpet his wealth, his smarts, his popularity. What is he compensating for?

headline: Baylor, Football and the Rape Case of Sam Ukwuachu
abstract: The university didn’t let on about the accusation for nearly two years, but with its player’s conviction, it’s suddenly indignant and taking action.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 21, a Baylor University football player named Sam Ukwuachu was sentenced to six months in the county jail and 10 years’ probation for sexually assaulting a freshman soccer player two years ago.

abstract: Should the age of a presidential candidate matter?

headline: Marissa Mayer of Yahoo Says She’s Pregnant With Twins
abstract: Ms. Mayer said Monday that her twins were due in December and that she planned to work throughout her pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, and her husband, Zachary Bogue, are expecting twin daughters, according to an announcement she made on Yahoo’s Tumblr.

headline: Between Iraq and a Hawk Base
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: G.O.P. presidential candidates are struggling to craft a foreign policy that can please the gung-ho and win in 2016 — without overpromising military force.
lead_paragraph: The first sign that the Republican Party’s 17 presidential candidates might have trouble explaining what a conservative foreign policy should look like — beyond simply saying that it should not look like Barack Obama’s — emerged on May 10. That’s when the Fox News host Megyn Kelly asked Jeb Bush a rather predictable question about the Iraq war: ‘‘Knowing what we know now, would you have authorized the invasion?’’

headline: The Politics of Distraction
keywords: ['English Language', 'United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: In American political life, “shiny objects" has become a useful metaphor for the stories — and people — that divert us from the important questions.
lead_paragraph: We begin, as many discussions about politics today should, with an analogy to pro wrestling. Consider the ‘‘foreign object’’ routine: One combatant produces a concealed item, usually from under his tights — a pointed stick or some hand-size tool of menace — and proceeds to jab his opponent with it. He perpetrates this atrocity in full view of everybody except the referee, who remains oblivious because a complicit third party (perhaps a tag-team partner or a manager) is distracting him.

headline: ‘Did You Ever Have a Family’ by Bill Clegg
abstract: In the wake of a tragedy, the affected reckon with complicated pasts.
lead_paragraph: Catastrophe and misfortune are a novelist’s friends, dramatic devices that provide a plot and let characters demonstrate their range. Tragedies tunnel through life, and the suspense comes from seeing how these spaces will be filled. This is what excites us about books that begin with a sorrowful bang. Grief is sad — we know that — but what now? How will these particular characters respond? What else do you have to give us?

headline: Instagram Exerts a Force in Beauty Trends
abstract: “Contouring,” “baking” and eyebrows on “fleek” are makeup trends popularized on social media by @Belladelune and @heidimakeupartist, among others.
lead_paragraph: In days, New York Fashion Week will inspire a burst of beauty trends. But are the runways still the best place to source fresh ideas?

headline: Should Schools Give Students ‘Body’ Report Cards?
abstract: Have you ever received a letter or report card from your school telling you your B.M.I., or body mass index?
lead_paragraph: In an effort to fight childhood obesity, more schools are keeping track of their students’ weight and sending reports home to update students and families.

headline: An Unanswered Call for Help at Rikers Island
abstract: Carlos Mercado, 45, who was diabetic, died after 15 hours at the New York jail complex. His family’s lawyers say surveillance video shows that guards repeatedly ignored his pleas for help.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, reports of brutality and neglect at the Rikers Island jail complex have become routine. And while the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio has been working to improve conditions at New York City jails, the death of Carlos Mercado shows that the problems of the past could haunt the city for years to come.

headline: Foraging for Fashion
abstract: A bounty of warm-weather looks at the Union Square Greenmarket.
lead_paragraph: Summer was in full bloom at the Union Square Greenmarket last week. There was a bounty of ripe tomatoes, sweet corn and smartly dressed shoppers, who took a break from their grocery shopping to discuss their warm-weather looks.

headline: ‘The Girl in the Spider’s Web’ by David Lagercrantz
abstract: This continuation of Stieg Larsson’s Millennium series features artificial intelligence and code breaking and suitably icy bad guys.
lead_paragraph: There are many ways to continue a series after its author’s death. One is to wait a long time, until the original material has achieved classic status, and then find an established heavyweight willing to step up, like a great actor taking on his third King Lear. Examples would be John Banville reviving Raymond Chandler’s Philip Marlowe, or Jill Paton Walsh giving us more of Dorothy L. Sayers’s Lord Peter Wimsey. As readers we approach such attempts cautiously, with style points and degrees of difficulty in mind, as if we were judges at an Olympic diving competition, and therefore, however good the execution may be, these books will always remain to some extent interesting curiosities.

headline: Popcast: 2015 MTV Video Music Awards
abstract: The night belonged to those who shocked without needing to perform.
lead_paragraph: At the 2015 MTV Video Music Awards on Sunday night, it was the most theatrically transgressive of times, and the most honestly transgressive of times. Miley Cyrus, pop’s enfant terrible, hosted the event, but she was hardly the most shocking part of the night’s festivities, despite her best efforts. Those included outfits that looked like they had been drawn with a thin pencil, rather than cut from actual fabric (to say nothing of the moment Ms. Cyrus seemingly wore nothing at all); jokes that poked fun at her extreme persona, with little effect; and the surprise announcement of a new album, which she released just after the show.

headline: Gravity

Neat.

headline: What Should Obama Do Next on Iran?
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Now that the deal is done, it’s time to get tough on Iran.
lead_paragraph: As Congress returns to Washington after Labor Day, the vote on the Iran nuclear deal will be its most important since the decision to go to war in Iraq in 2003. While Republicans dominated the debate in July, Democrats regained lost ground in recent weeks with a flurry of endorsements in both houses of Congress. I testified in favor of the agreement before four congressional committees, and talked with many members individually during July and August. It now appears almost certain that President Obama has the votes to prevail in Congress.

headline: Two Exciting New Fall Shows for Richard Long
abstract: An upcoming retrospective and exhibition of new work give a wandering land artist his moment in the sun.
lead_paragraph: The trailblazing British artist Richard Long, renowned for his large-scale creations made using stone, driftwood and, in some cases, nothing more than his own footprints, is being celebrated in two exhibitions this fall. In the 70-year-old’s hometown of Bristol, the retrospective at the Arnolfini Gallery, ‘‘Richard Long: Time and Space,’’ features a number of his trademark mud murals and dry-stone sculptures. And in New York, at Sperone Westwater, ‘‘Crescent to Cross’’ will include a striking photograph of ‘‘Aconcagua Circle,’’ a ring of jagged rocks that the Turner Prize winner constructed during a 17-day trek in the Andes in 2012, as well as a new drawing created from red clay mud.

headline: 1940: Pilot Is Saved by Cup of Tea
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A British pilot escapes death in 1940.
lead_paragraph: AN AIRDROME IN SOUTHEAST ENGLAND — A cup of tea saved a young British Hurricane pilot from Nazi vengeance here today [Sept. 1] when three Messerschmitt Jaguars, painted with British markings which fooled ground defenses, swept in and bombed his machine in a corner of the field. A few minutes earlier the pilot had landed to have an oil leak plugged after shooting down a Dornier 117 into marshland near the coast. He had intended to wait in the cockpit while the mechanics worked on his plane, but instead accepted the commanding officer’s offer of a cup of tea. It probably saved him from death or serious injury. — New York Herald Tribune, September 2, 1940

headline: Alexander Sokurov: Russia as Allegory for Art and Life
abstract: The veteran director Alexander Sokurov raises questions about history and homeland in his new film, “Francofonia.’‘
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Alexander Sokurov’s 2002 film “Russian Ark,” a single 90-minute unedited Steadicam shot that weaves through the State Hermitage Museum here, is an elliptical meditation on art, power and nostalgia. In his latest film, “Francofonia,” which will debut in competition at the Venice International Film Festival on Friday, this Russian director turned his camera on the Louvre for a reflection on cultural patrimony during wartime and Russia’s vexed relationship with Europe.

headline: 1965: Rusk Letter Admits Spying
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The U.S. confirms a botched C.I.A. operation in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An embarrassed State Department conceded today [Sept. 1] that Secretary of State Dean Rusk had apologized to the government of Singapore in 1961 over a Central Intelligence Agency operation that went bad. Only yesterday, the State Department had firmly denied an accusation by Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew in Singapore that an American CIA agent had been arrested in 1960 for trying to buy state secrets in Singapore. Mr. Lee said that he asked $33 million in foreign aid from the United States in return for his government’s silence and the release of the agent, but that he was offered only $3 million and turned it down as an ‘‘insult.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 2, 1965

lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — A newly demure Janet Jackson started her “Unbreakable World Tour” at Rogers Arena here on Monday night. She was dressed in white and covered, like her dancers and musicians, from shoulders to shoes. And she avoided one big subset of her songwriting: her salacious, sometimes kinky whispers. That left Ms. Jackson, 49, to play the many other, less titillating roles that have given her major hits and made her an enduring influence across pop and R&B.

headline: Jesse Kamm’s Laid-Back Approach to Life — and Looks

lead_paragraph: This year, the Los Angeles-based designer Jesse Kamm — whose languid, Annie Hallish separates are cult items among the creative class on both coasts — celebrates 10 years in business. It’s no small feat considering she is the company’s sole employee and refuses to collaborate with big brands as a matter of principle. Instead, the former model has slowly built a following for her signature silhouettes — including dramatically high-waisted, perpetually sold-out sailor pants, which are being reissued in early September in new colors to commemorate the line’s anniversary. (A video celebrating the pants in all their splendor debuts here.)

headline: The Healing Power of Hugs
abstract: Should therapists embrace their patients?
lead_paragraph: One day several years ago, I spontaneously hugged a patient of mine, Gretchen. It was during a moment in which her despair and distress were so intense that it seemed cruel on a human level not to reach out my arms to her, in the event that she might derive some relief or comfort from an embrace. She hugged me for dear life.

lead_paragraph: In summer and early fall, when local sweet peppers are truly sweet and have great depth of flavor, there’s nothing I like better than a comforting stew of peppers: a simple mix of onion, garlic, peppers, tomatoes and basil cooked slowly in olive oil.

headline: The End of the Republican Party?
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Third-Party Politics (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The G.O.P. isn’t going to die, but it’s ripe for transformation.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column on Trump ended with a rather dire forecast: That if the G.O.P. fails to adapt to some of the crucial reasons for his success, “the pressure the Donald has tapped will continue to build — and when it bursts, the G.O.P. as we know it may go with it.” Erick Erickson, in part of a longer series of posts, invokes my column while making an even grimmer forecast: That the Republican Party is “dying,” that what we’re watching is the “beginning of the end.” And Ben Domenech, in yesterday’s edition of The Transom, writes the following:

headline: The Fantastic Man Editors on Their Five Favorite Magazines
abstract: Jop van Bennekom and Gert Jonkers, the Dutch duo also behind The Gentlewoman and Butt, share their all-time favorite publications.
lead_paragraph: Jop van Bennekom and Gert Jonkers, the Dutch duo also behind The Gentlewoman and Butt, share their all-time favorite publications.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 10 | Finding Freedom and Self-Love Through Running
abstract: Our top winner is Audrey L, who wrote about finding freedom and self-love through running. We also selected five runners-up and 10 honorable mentions.
lead_paragraph: For 10 weeks this summer we asked students the question, “What interested you most in The Times this week?” Below, we announce our favorite responses for the 10th and final week of our Sixth Annual Summer Reading Contest.

headline: Fung Tu Keeps Cooking, Even With Gas Shut Off
abstract: Since July 9, the Chinese restaurant on the Lower East Side has gotten by without its main source of fuel, using butane and shortening its menu.
lead_paragraph: The gas went out at Fung Tu on July 9, a Thursday, the busiest night of the week for a Manhattan restaurant in summer.

headline: The Neverending Fight to Save Social Security
keywords: ['Disability Insurance', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Retirement', 'Social Security (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans’ latest plan for unnecessary cuts to Social Security involves the disability fund.
lead_paragraph: A trial balloon now being inflated by Republicans in Congress needs to be popped before it gets any bigger.

headline: Stocks Dive as Worries About Asia Reverberate
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index closed down nearly 3 percent and the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 469 points as turbulence continued.
lead_paragraph: Keep the seatbelts on.

headline: Review: Chrissie Hynde’s ‘Reckless’ Details a Rocker’s Life
abstract: Ms. Hynde’s memoir is full of facts and anecdotes, but is also noteworthy for what it leaves out.
lead_paragraph: Way to go, Akron, Ohio, for giving the world Chrissie Hynde, a malcontent for the ages — or, at a minimum, for the post-punk era — with a look to match: kohl-rimmed eyes, a low hedgerow of bangs, the best sneer since Elvis’s.

headline: Serena Williams’s Links to a Pioneer Keep Growing Clearer
abstract: Each viewing of the documentary “Althea” solidifies the notion that Williams is her generation’s Althea Gibson, and vice versa.
lead_paragraph: As Serena Williams left the interview room Monday evening and walked down a long corridor, I asked her if she had seen the Althea Gibson documentary that is making the rounds.

headline: Is Everyone Qualified to Be a Critic?
abstract: Adam Kirsch and Charles McGrath discuss what it takes to pass judgment on the arts.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Adam Kirsch and Charles McGrath discuss what it takes to pass judgment on the arts.

headline: Undercover Activist James O’Keefe Plans to Step Up Political Stalking
abstract: Project Veritas Action, a research group that uses undercover investigators, warned that it was stepping up its stalking of campaigns this election cycle to uncover wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: Campaign rallies are crawling with hidden cameras these days as opposition researchers from rivals, activist groups or political action committees spare no expense in hopes of finding a gaffe or, ideally, signs of unlawfulness.

headline: Saucy in Brooklyn Isn’t Just for Catering
abstract: Przemek Adolf is opening a place that dabbles in sustainability; Joe Bastianich has revived his Milan restaurant; Aldea and Kappo Masa are reopening; and more.
lead_paragraph: Saucy Przemek Adolf started with savory jams and chutneys four years ago. They quickly became the platform for his catering company, Saucy by Nature. And now he has a restaurant, Saucy. “It’s been a bit of a ride,” he said. He figured that having a restaurant in tandem with a catering company would permit him to reduce waste by using surplus ingredients, distributing leftovers and composting. Though he’s not going to the extremes of sustainability like the experiment this year by Dan Barber of Blue Hill, serving carrot peelings and fish-head tartare, he said he would dabble in it, and turn radish leaves into pesto. The restaurant is fast casual, with counter service for soups, salads and sandwiches to eat in or take out at lunchtime, and heartier fare, like Moroccan chicken, for dinner: 884 Fulton Street (Washington Street), Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, saucybynature.com.

headline: Robert Rodriguez, Film Director and El Rey Founder, on Creating a Hispanic Network
abstract: “People could enjoy these stories all over the world, but Hispanics could see themselves reflected in different ways — as heroes, as lead characters.”
lead_paragraph: Back when he was participating in clinical drug trials to help raise the original $7,000 budget for his 1993 breakthrough film “El Mariachi,” Robert Rodriguez never dreamed he would one day be running his own cable channel. Now he’s the founder and chairman of the El Rey Network, an outlet he started in 2013 specializing in the grindhouse fare he favors as the director of movies like “Sin City” and “Machete.” “Usually as a filmmaker, all you can do is make product, and you have to go find a distributor,” Mr. Rodriguez said. “When you are the distributor, you have a direct pipeline into homes, and you can try things you wouldn’t get to do otherwise. You can build a network from the ground up.” El Rey now reaches 40 million households in the United States and is available on such services as DirecTV, Dish Network and Sling TV.

headline: Obama Nears Needed Votes on Iran Nuclear Deal
abstract: Bob Casey and Chris Coons, both Democrats, say they will back the accord, all but clinching victory for the agreement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama all but clinched victory for his Iran nuclear deal on Tuesday, as two Democratic senators threw crucial support behind the landmark accord.

headline: Big Leaps for Parental Leave, if Workers Actually Take It
keywords: ['Family Leaves', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Women and Girls', 'Paid Time Off', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Some companies are offering more generous paid leave, but the message from the top is ambiguous, as Marissa Mayer’s recent announcement highlights.
lead_paragraph: Some corners of corporate America have a new message for new parents: Put down that laptop and pick up your baby instead.

headline: Police Clear ‘You Stink’ Protesters From Minister’s Offices in Beirut
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Demonstrators protesting a garbage pileup and political dysfunction, had occupied the offices of Lebanon’s environment minister on Tuesday, declaring that they would stay until he resigned.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Demonstrators from the “You Stink” movement, protesting a garbage pileup and political dysfunction, occupied the offices of Lebanon’s environment minister in downtown Beirut on Tuesday, declaring that they would stay until he resigned.

headline: Donald Trump’s Shaky Grasp on Immigration
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Economy', 'Foreign Workers']
abstract: That border wall already exists, but demographics and other factors have significantly shrunk the population of Mexicans who want to cross it.
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump was reaching adulthood in the mid-1960s, the United States was a less diverse place. By 1970, the share of the population born overseas had shrunk to 4.7 percent, the slimmest on record. Only about 0.4 percent of the population had been born in Mexico.

headline: The Triumph of Backward-Looking Economics
abstract: Tobin was right.
lead_paragraph: We don’t get to do many controlled experiments in economics, so history is mainly what we have to go on. Unfortunately, many people who imagine that they know how the economy works go with what they think they heard about history, not with what actually happened. And I’m not just talking about the great unwashed; quite a few well-known economists seem not to have heard about FRED, or at least haven’t picked up the habit of doing a quick scan of the actual data before making assertions about facts.

headline: In Asheville, a Fall Tour That Includes Farms and Wine
abstract: Artisans and agriculture are the focus of a tour package offered by innkeepers in Asheville, N.C.
lead_paragraph: In response to guests asking innkeepers in the Asheville, N.C., area what to do beyond exploring the Blue Ridge Parkway, the Asheville Bed & Breakfast Association has created a Fall Farms and Artisans Tour Package that takes visitors along the roads less traveled. The 16 inns have partnered with three western North Carolina farms, a vineyard and five artisans in the 200-year-old farming community of Sandy Mush in Leicester, situated amid rolling hills 20 minutes northwest of Asheville.

headline: In West Bank, Speculation Abounds Over Mahmoud Abbas’s Plans
abstract: Mahmoud Abbas, the aging Palestinian president, may be paving the way for his exit from political life — or he may be trying to consolidate power by crippling all his rivals.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Mahmoud Abbas, the aging Palestinian president, may be paving the way for his exit from political life — or he may be trying to consolidate power by crippling all his rivals.

headline: Bad Ideas Down Under
abstract: Call me Bruce.
lead_paragraph: I’m heading off to Sydney, for the Festival of Dangerous Ideas. Blogging will be limited due to travel, plus blood rushing to my head from standing upside down when I get there.

headline: Inside Amazon: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: The reporters Jodi Kantor and David Streitfeld provided insight into their reporting on Amazon and its fast-paced, sometimes punishing, culture.
lead_paragraph: Last January, when we began interviewing Amazon veterans about what it is like to work at the company, we realized that we were stepping into a heated private debate.

headline: Pope Francis Eases Path to Absolution for Abortion
abstract: All Roman Catholic priests may offer absolution in the coming year to women who had abortions and want to return to the good graces of the church.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis announced Tuesday that all Roman Catholic priests would be empowered to offer absolution for the “sin of abortion” during the church’s Holy Year of Mercy, which begins in December.

headline: Idris Elba, Called ‘Too Street’ to Play James Bond, Gets an Apology
abstract: The novelist Anthony Horowitz had said Adrian Lester would be a better choice.
lead_paragraph: To fans, Idris Elba would make the perfect James Bond. They’ve been clamoring for years to cast the actor as the smooth action hero. So when the author of a forthcoming Bond novel dismissed Mr. Elba as “too street” for the part, the backlash was immediate, and now comes the apology.

headline: Shakespeare Gets Hip-Hop Treatment With App
abstract: Royal Shakespeare Company has created “RE: Shakespeare,” an app with Samsung that remixes Shakespeare through a hip-hop lens.
lead_paragraph: Eminem called himself a “modern-day Shakespeare” in 2001. Now the Royal Shakespeare Company is trying to further bridge the gap between rap and the writer: They’ve created an app with Samsung, “RE: Shakespeare,” which remixes Shakespeare through a hip-hop lens.

headline: Review: ‘The Black Panthers’ Captures a Militant Movement’s Soul and Swagger
abstract: Stanley Nelson’s new documentary chronicles the organization’s rise and turbulent times.
lead_paragraph: The beginning of “The Black Panthers,” Stanley Nelson’s excellent new documentary, includes a television news report on tensions between black citizens and the police in American cities. If not for the fuzzy, monochrome images and the voice-over’s unironic use of the word “Negroes,” the clip could have been broadcast last week, instead of almost 50 years ago. And if Mr. Nelson doesn’t strain to establish the present-day relevance of the story he has to tell, it’s partly because he doesn’t have to. The problems of poverty, police brutality and economic plunder that gave birth to the Panthers are with us still.

headline: Same-Sex Couple Confronts Kentucky Clerk
abstract: Kim Davis, the clerk of Rowan County, Ky., turned away David Ermold and David Moore, who were seeking a marriage license. Ms. Davis said she was acting “under God’s authority.”
lead_paragraph: Kim Davis, the clerk of Rowan County, Ky., turned away David Ermold and David Moore, who were seeking a marriage license. Ms. Davis said she was acting “under God’s authority.”

keywords: ['Constitution (US)', 'Constitutional Amendments', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: As a county clerk, Kim Davis is required to issue marriage licenses to anyone who may legally get married, which includes same-sex couples.
lead_paragraph: Apparently, you can appeal a Supreme Court ruling to a higher authority.

headline: Fox Lake Police Open Manhunt for 3 Shooting Suspects
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: The police opened a manhunt in Fox Lake, Ill., using helicopters, dogs and heavily armed assault teams. Local reports said the officer had died.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — With helicopters buzzing overhead and police dogs searching on the ground, the authorities in northern Illinois conducted a sprawling manhunt Tuesday evening for three people suspected in the fatal shooting of a Fox Lake police lieutenant that morning.

headline: At Auschwitz, a Summer Precaution Is a Grim Reminder to Some
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Social Media']
abstract: Critics said overhead sprinklers at the entrance to the death camp’s memorial and museum were reminiscent of the showers the Nazis used to gas Jews in World War II.
lead_paragraph: It was intended to provide relief from the extreme summer heat in Poland. But instead, a suspended hose that sprays visitors to Auschwitz with a fine mist is reminding some of the concentration camp’s grim history.

headline: Pope Asks Bullied Girl to Sing for Him
abstract: After learning that Valerie Herrera, 17, used music to cope with being bullied for a rare skin condition, Pope Francis said he would like to hear her sing. “Be courageous,” he added with a smile.
lead_paragraph: After learning that Valerie Herrera, 17, used music to cope with being bullied for a rare skin condition, Pope Francis said he would like to hear her sing. “Be courageous,” he added with a smile.

headline: British Employers Who Skirt ‘Living Wage’ Will Face Tough Fines, Cameron Says
abstract: With the minimum wage set to rise to £7.20 an hour in April, from £6.50, Prime Minister David Cameron said companies must conform or face fines.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the push for higher minimum pay builds momentum on both sides of the Atlantic, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain on Tuesday threatened companies with tough fines if they fail to pay what he called a “national living wage.”

headline: Real Madrid and Manchester United Trade Jabs After Transfer Fails
abstract: The proposed deal, which would have sent goalkeeper David de Gea to Madrid, failed when an exchange of paperwork missed a midnight deadline.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Major soccer transfers almost always involve secretive talks among clubs, players and their agents haggling over large sums of money. The outcome is ultimately made public if a deal is reached, but often in trite statements in which the buying club welcomes the arrival of a top player while the seller thanks him for his contribution. Rarely is there a mention of exactly how much cash was exchanged.

headline: Phillips and Sotheby’s Announce Strategic Moves
abstract: Phillips has appointed Hugues Joffre its new worldwide head of 20th century art, and Sotheby’s said it was opening its first office in India.
lead_paragraph: Phillips and Sotheby’s auction houses are taking steps to strengthen their businesses.

headline: Marco Rubio Faults Donald Trump on ‘Make America Great Again’ Slogan
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, one of the many Republicans challenging Mr. Trump for the party’s presidential nomination, thinks Mr. Trump misses the point with his slogan, “Make America Great Again.”
lead_paragraph: CARSON CITY, Nev. — The slogan is now synonymous with Donald J. Trump’s campaign: “Make America Great Again.” It is embroidered on the hats he sells for $25 and often seen printed on homemade T-shirts and signs at his rallies across the country.

headline: Uber Rolls Into Martha’s Vineyard and Finds Some Resistance
abstract: Operating in quaint vacation spots like Martha’s Vineyard is a new thing for Uber, but not all the locals appreciate the advancement into their communities.

headline: Missouri Teenagers Protest a Transgender Student’s Use of the Girls’ Bathroom
abstract: More than 100 students at Hillsboro High School staged a walkout after a transgender student was allowed to use the girls’ facilities.
lead_paragraph: A transgender high school student in Missouri is facing backlash from her peers after requesting to use the girls’ bathrooms and locker room.

headline: Menstruation Innovation: Lessons from India
keywords: ['Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Menstruation', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: When it comes to addressing menstrual health and hygiene, much of the ingenuity and innovation has been spearheaded in the developing world, particularly India.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, a wave of period-positivity has captured headlines – from Kiran Gandhi’s bold free-bleeding run of the London Marathon, to the successful repeal of Canada’s national “tampon tax.” Donald Trump catapulted menstruation smack into the middle of  the Republican presidential debate when he ridiculed Megyn Kelly’s inquiry about his prior sexist rants, telling CNN she had “blood coming out of her wherever.”

headline: Mr. Obama’s Urgent Arctic Message
abstract: The president’s trip to Alaska drove his point home that there’s no time to waste on climate change.
lead_paragraph: A presidential trip has enormous power to focus attention on a place and an issue, and President Obama’s trip to Alaska has been minutely choreographed with visits to glaciers, threatened Inuit villages and the like to provide a stunning and alarming context to his message on the urgent need to address climate change.

headline: Five Poets Receive Lucrative Fellowships
abstract: The Poetry Foundation and Poetry magazine announced the winners on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Five poets received unusually lucrative good news on Tuesday, as the Poetry Foundation and Poetry magazine announced the recipients of the 2015 Ruth Lilly and Dorothy Sargent Rosenberg Poetry Fellowships.

headline: The Black Panthers in Pictures
abstract: Images from the documentary “The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution.”
lead_paragraph: Images from the documentary “The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution.”

headline: Readers Recommend Where to Go Around Lake Michigan
abstract: Readers pointed out some of their favorite spots around the huge Great Lake.
lead_paragraph: One of our recent articles, “A Tour of Lake Michigan, My Inland Sea,” about the writer Rich Cohen’s travels around the lake, inspired more than 290 comments on nytimes.com/travel. Mr. Cohen, who grew up in Glencoe, Ill., about a mile from the shore, made stops in Chicago; Benton Harbor, Mich.; Ludington, Mich.; Mackinac Island and Milwaukee; just to name a few.

headline: Los Angeles to Be U.S. Bidder to Host 2024 Olympics
abstract: After a week of delays over concerns about potential costs, a City Council vote paved the way for Los Angeles to throw itself into a contest that some cities have grown increasingly hesitant to enter.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Eight months after finishing as the runner-up to Boston, Los Angeles has officially been chosen as the United States candidate for the 2024 Olympics, city officials announced Tuesday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Hungary and Elsewhere
abstract: Hungary and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Hungary and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: U.S. Remains the ‘Great Satan,’ Hard-Liners in Iran Say
abstract: Denunciations by a top general and a cleric signaled a struggle over domestic influence because of the nuclear deal with six world powers, including the United States.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Flexing their muscles, some of the toughest anti-American voices in Iran said on Tuesday that the United States remains their country’s top enemy, guilty of “uncountable” crimes. Their remarks hinted at a developing struggle over domestic influence because of the nuclear deal with world powers.

headline: A Recipe From the Newly Relaunched Aldea
abstract: Chef George Mendes reboots the menu at his Iberian-inspired restaurant to include dishes like veal sweetbreads with piquillo pepper and sunchoke.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 24, the chef George Mendes’s ultramodern, Iberian-inspired restaurant, Aldea, shut its doors for 10 days. Six years after its opening (and five years after receiving its first Michelin star), the time had come, he explains, for some long-awaited updates. “The relaunch itself has probably been on my mind for the past year and a half to two years,” he says. “I wanted to take this on full force — what started out as a need for wear-and-tear renovations became an opportunity, in the summer months, to close down, do a complete renovation from head to tail, make changes at the bar and revisit the menu.”

headline: September 1, 2015 — Pictures of the Day

lead_paragraph: Photos from Hungary, India, Ukraine and Cuba.

headline: Building for Future, Ithaca Remakes Town Square
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Pedestrian Malls']

lead_paragraph: ITHACA, N.Y. — On Saturday, as Ithaca celebrated the official opening of its newly designed outdoor pedestrian mall, the Commons, Mayor Svante Myrick strolled through the crowd on the plaza, collecting congratulations every few feet.

lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, R.I. — At summer carnivals like the Washington County Fair recently held here, migrant laborers spend long days running the Whip, the Orbiter, the Polar Express and other popular rides.

keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Search Engines', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google is quickly becoming the company government regulators around the world love to investigate.

headline: Review: ‘Big Blue Live’ Searches for Marine Life
abstract: PBS turns its cameras on Monterey Bay in California, hoping to catch glimpses of otters, sea lions and even whales while highlighting efforts to save species from extinction.
lead_paragraph: “Big Blue Half-Live” might have been a more accurate title, and only the humpback whales seem to have gotten the memo for the initial East Coast broadcast, but at least give PBS credit for trying something different.

headline: A Fellow Outsider, Ben Carson Rivals Donald Trump in Polls, if Not in Pomp
abstract: Like Donald J. Trump, Mr. Carson, a retired neurosurgeon, has never held elected office, but polls suggest that voters are responding to his low-key style.
lead_paragraph: The spotlight rarely found Ben Carson this summer. While other presidential candidates shot flaming arrows at rivals and sometimes the news media, the soft-spoken Mr. Carson seemed to struggle to be noticed. “Well, thank you,” he told moderators in the first Republican debate. “I wasn’t sure if I would get to speak again.”

headline: Maria on ‘Sesame Street,’ Sonia Manzano, Tells of Her Own Childhood
abstract: Retiring after 44 years as a beloved figure on a beloved children’s show, Ms. Manzano has a memoir out and a children’s book to come.
lead_paragraph: Talking to Sonia Manzano feels like catching up with an old friend.

headline: Explaining the Strange, Stinky Appeal of the ‘Corpse Flower’

lead_paragraph: A little more than a week after crowds at the Denver Botanic Gardens welcomed the smelly bloom of its resident titan arum, known as the corpse flower, another of the flowers failed to give visitors at the Chicago Botanic Garden a similar, smelly show.

headline: In ‘Black Mass,’ Whitey Bulger Acquires a Glimmer of Humanity
abstract: In this film starring Johnny Depp as a coldblooded killer, Scott Cooper found that tinge by incorporating the death of Mr. Bulger’s young son.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Books about the unsavory alliance between the Boston mobster James (Whitey) Bulger and a corrupt F.B.I., including the best-selling “Black Mass,” serve up one horrific detail after another: a man stabbed 38 times with an ice pick, drive-by machine gun shootings, a young woman who is strangled with bare hands, the digging up of rotting corpses.

keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']

headline: Uber Rebuffed by Judge in Ruling on Drivers’ Suit
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: A lawsuit challenging the ride-hailing service’s designation of drivers as contract workers, not employees, will be heard as a class action.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge granted class-action status on Tuesday to a lawsuit that questions the employment classification of Uber drivers, paving the way for a legal challenge that could strike at the heart of the ride-hailing company’s business model.

headline: Kathleen Hanna Revisits Her Riot Grrrl Past
abstract: This month, Bikini Kill will release a new, remastered version of its first demo cassette from 1991. T exclusively debuts a track, "Ocean Song."
lead_paragraph: When the riot grrrl pioneer Kathleen Hanna recently dug up some of her earliest work — the first demo cassette she recorded in 1991 with her band Bikini Kill, which has been remastered and is being reissued this month as “Revolution Girl Style Now” — she was a little nervous. “I thought I was going to hate it. I thought I was going to be like, ‘Oh, God, this is so embarrassing,’” she says with a laugh. “These were the first songs we ever wrote; and that tape was made primarily to send to promoters, to try to get shows. It wasn’t even made as a product that we were trying to sell in stores.”

headline: Donald Trump Meets With Javier Palomarez, Head of U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce
abstract: Donald J. Trump took a step to try to smooth things over with Hispanics by inviting Javier Palomarez, president of the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, to his Manhattan office.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has been ruffling feathers with Hispanics with his tough talk on immigration, but on Tuesday the Republican presidential candidate took a step to try to smooth things over.

headline: CNN Alters Debate Criteria, Which Could Help Carly Fiorina
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The change in criteria effectively helps candidates who have moved up in the polls since the first debate — chiefly Carly Fiorina.
lead_paragraph: CNN announced on Tuesday that it would amend the criteria for picking candidates for the next Republican debate, scheduled for Sept. 16. The move followed criticism from supporters of Carly Fiorina and others that she was being unfairly excluded.

headline: Rashomon on the West Bank: Israelis and Palestinians Debate Images of Soldier and Child
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Social Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: What happened in Nabi Saleh last Friday is not in doubt; but the meaning of a clash between protesters and a soldier remains hotly disputed.
lead_paragraph: Not much of what happened last Friday during a demonstration near the West Bank village of Nabi Saleh is in doubt. But in thousands of social media arguments since then, Israelis and Palestinians, and supporters of the two sides around the world, have interpreted one charged encounter in very different ways.

headline: Qaeda-Affiliated Group Overruns African Union Base in Somalia
abstract: The African Union Mission said it had regained control of the base from the Shabab, which has been staging hit-and-run attacks in and outside Somalia.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Fighters from the Shabab militant group overran an African Union military base in southern Somalia on Tuesday morning in an attack that included a suicide bombing and an intense firefight, witnesses and officials said.

headline: SFX Cancels One Tribe Festival, Citing Weak Ticket Sales
abstract: SFX Entertainment, a promoter of dance music events, is struggling with financial problems. The event outside Los Angeles was set for Sept. 25 and 26.
lead_paragraph: SFX Entertainment, the beleaguered promoter of dance music events, has canceled the One Tribe festival outside Los Angeles, the company’s first business casualty in the face of mounting financial problems in recent weeks.

headline: Representative Hakeem Jeffries Says He Will Vote for Iran Nuclear Deal
abstract: The Brooklyn Democrat known for his close ties with pro-Israel groups said the agreement was “imperfect” but was the “most preferable vehicle to prevent Iran from developing a nuclear weapon.”
lead_paragraph: Representative Hakeem Jeffries, the Brooklyn Democrat known for his close ties with pro-Israel advocacy groups, announced on Tuesday that he will vote in support of President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran.

headline: Review: ‘Creep,’ a Horror Film With the Look of Found Footage
abstract: The actor and director Mark Duplass stars as a man seeking to leave a legacy for his unborn child.
lead_paragraph: The actor and director Mark Duplass has come a long way from his mumblecore days, when he appeared in modest, low-budget movies like “Hannah Takes the Stairs,” often collaborating with his brother, Jay. Now he’s an indie stalwart, who helped create, and stars in, “Togetherness” on HBO. But he still has a taste for bare-bones filmmaking, as evidenced by “Creep,” a horror two-hander in which he stars, directed by Patrick Brice.

headline: Sony Altered ‘Concussion’ Film to Prevent N.F.L. Protests, Emails Show
abstract: In dozens of emails unearthed by hackers, Sony Pictures executives and others discussed altering the script and marketing the movie more as a whistle-blower story than as a condemnation of the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: When Sony Pictures Entertainment decided to make a movie focusing on the death and dementia professional football players have endured from repeated hits to the head — and the N.F.L.’s efforts toward a cover-up — it signed Will Smith to star as one of the first scientists to disclose the problem. It named the film bluntly, “Concussion.”

headline: Preparing for a Military Parade, China Deploys a Troop of Monkeys
abstract: Chinese news websites have recently featured monkeys trained to tear apart the nests of birds that might foul up the engines of fighter jets involved in a military parade on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese government has countless worries about mishaps that might besmirch its quest for a perfectly staged military parade.

headline: Review: ‘A Walk in the Woods,’ With Robert Redford, Is a Scenic Trek Spoiled
abstract: Mr. Redford stars with Nick Nolte in this film based on Bill Bryson’s 1998 chronicle of hiking the Appalachian Trail with an old friend.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene in “A Walk in the Woods,” a low-impact amble through hill, dale and cinematic nostalgia, when our two crusty trekkers face down a pair of bears. The men — Robert Redford and Nick Nolte — are slumbering in their tents when the bears descend and begin tearing into the hikers’ food, which they have failed to properly stash. The bears roar and the men thunder back, flapping uvulas and arms to chase off the animals. It’s a mildly funny scene, partly because of its light physical comedy and sight gaggery, although also because Mr. Nolte, his signature growl now often at sepulchral depths, has been doing a fair impression of a wild beast for years.

headline: Agency Reduces Estimate of Faulty Airbag Inflaters in the United States
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: An official at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said some vehicles had been counted twice or sold outside the United States.
lead_paragraph: A federal regulator said on Tuesday that it was still grappling with the size of the airbag crisis at Takata, the Japanese supplier, and that it expected to outline new steps in the recall process at a public meeting this fall.

headline: TV Producers of 2016 Oscars Are Selected
abstract: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences appointed Reginald Hudlin and David Hill to produce the ceremony, which is set for broadcast on Feb. 28.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The producers for the next Oscar ceremony will be Reginald Hudlin, a filmmaker schooled in urban comedy, and David Hill, a television producer with credits on “American Idol” and the 2011 World Series broadcast, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Tuesday.

headline: Kuwait: 26 Accused of Iran-Linked Plot
abstract: Authorities in Kuwait have charged 25 Kuwaitis and an Iranian with illicit arms possession and secretive contacts with Iran and its ally Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: The judicial authorities in Kuwait have charged 25 Kuwaitis and an Iranian with illicit arms possession and secretive contacts with Iran and its ally Hezbollah, the Shiite Lebanese militant group, Kuwait’s official news agency reported Tuesday. The agency quoted a statement by Dherar al-Asousi, the public prosecutor, as saying all 26 were implicated in what it described as a terrorist plot to destabilize the country. Twenty-three of the defendants have been arrested, the statement said. It did not name any but said all were accused of having illegally obtained “explosives, machine guns, firearms, ammunition and tapping devices.” Kuwait’s Sunni monarchy is a strong ally of Saudi Arabia, which regards Iran as its main regional rival.

headline: After a Killing, Body Cameras Are Expanded in San Antonio
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Cameras', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Latino activists, lawmakers and civil rights groups continued to question and condemn the shooting of a Hispanic man by sheriff’s deputies on Monday in San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — One day after a bystander’s cellphone video was released that appeared to show sheriff’s deputies fatally shooting a Hispanic man who had his hands raised in surrender, officials here voted Tuesday to finance additional body cameras for deputies in the field, as federal authorities said they had opened an investigation into whether the man’s civil rights had been violated.

headline: Preservationists Fight Bill Setting Time Limit on Landmarks Decisions in New York
abstract: The bill’s sponsors argue that it would bring much-needed responsibility and transparency to the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
lead_paragraph: What if Grand Central Terminal, the Empire State Building and the theater at Radio City Music Hall were not New York City landmarks?

headline: Can a Novelist Be Too Productive?: Q. & A. With Stephen King
abstract: The horror novelist responds to reader questions about writing and creativity based on his Sunday Review essay.
lead_paragraph: Stephen King took questions from readers about writing and creativity based on his Sunday Review essay, “Can a Novelist Be Too Productive?” Here are his responses.

headline: F.D.A. Warns 5 Producers of Powdered Caffeine
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said pure powdered caffeine is “potentially dangerous” and threatened to seize the product if it found violations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that it had sent warning letters to five producers of pure powdered caffeine, in what consumer advocates said was a long overdue move against the product and the industry that makes it.

headline: Ruling in Uber Case
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The ruling by Judge Edward M. Chen will allow a jury to decide whether Uber drivers should be considered employees or 1099 contract workers, named after a tax designation, which does not require the company to pay payroll taxes or apply minimum wage and overtime laws to the drivers.
lead_paragraph: The ruling by Judge Edward M. Chen will allow a jury to decide whether Uber drivers should be considered employees or 1099 contract workers, named after a tax designation, which does not require the company to pay payroll taxes or apply minimum wage and overtime laws to the drivers.

headline: A Lesson in Sincerity, Trump Style
abstract: A columnist’s run-in with Donald J. Trump nearly 18 years ago reveals something about how the presidential candidate has always acted.
lead_paragraph: “Please hold for Mr. Trump,” the voice said on the telephone.

headline: Paring His Bucket List, Obama Relishes Hiking at an Alaskan Glacier
abstract: President Obama is in legacy-building mode here in Alaska, where he has come to talk about the rapidly unfolding effects of climate change and the urgent need to address it.
lead_paragraph: KENAI FJORDS NATIONAL PARK, Alaska — President Obama hiked alone up a gravel path toward Exit Glacier, gazing at a mass of flowing ice as it melted into the plain below.

lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the editor in chief of Bloomberg News, John Micklethwait, outlined a slew of changes — some organizational, some visual, and some editorial — and the thinking behind them in a lengthy email to the staff.
