keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Social Media', 'International Relations']
abstract: Iceland’s prime minister has said a council of ministers would explore how the island nation could take in migrants.
lead_paragraph: Responding to a growing international crisis, thousands of Iceland’s residents have taken to social media to put pressure on their government to take in more migrants.

headline: With Technology, Avoiding Both Ads and the Blockers
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: Some predict that ad blockers will lead to an arms race among publishers, advertisers and consumers on how to outdo each other.
lead_paragraph: When Allrecipes unveiled a revamped website on Tuesday, it billed the move as part of a broader transformation into a social network for food lovers. Among other new capabilities available to them, the site’s millions of users can now follow other cooks and share what they have made on Facebook.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Episode 9 Recap: The Two Faces of Pablo Escobar
abstract: That guy sure has a temper.
lead_paragraph: Read all of our “Narcos” recaps.

headline: New York Attorney General Reaches Deal to End Litigation at Cooper Union
abstract: Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, is expected to announce a settlement Wednesday that would create an independent monitor of the college’s management and finances.
lead_paragraph: After a year of negotiations with warring parties at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, New York State’s attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, is expected on Wednesday to announce that his office has reached a settlement that would end litigation and create an independent monitor of the college’s management and finances.

headline: Kim Davis, a Local Fixture, and Now a National Symbol
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Kim Davis, the clerk of Rowan County, Ky., has drawn scorn and praise for her opposition to same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: MOREHEAD, Ky. — Before she ignited a firestorm over same-sex marriage, Kim Davis was known, for decades, as a woman behind the counter of a small county clerk’s office: a mild-mannered conduit for auto tag renewals, lien releases, land records and marriage certificates.

headline: Price of Crude Oil Tumbles After Soaring for 3 Days
abstract: As benchmark crude fell by nearly 8 percent, ConocoPhillips said it was cutting its global work force by 10 percent, or 1,800 jobs.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — After three days of spiking oil prices, a barrel of crude tumbled back nearly 8 percent on Tuesday, renewing despair in the oil patch. At the same time, ConocoPhillips announced it was cutting its global work force by 10 percent.

headline: President Otto Pérez Molina Is Stripped of Immunity in Guatemala
abstract: A 132-0 vote in Congress was the culmination of a tumultuous five months since prosecutors revealed the existence of a customs fraud ring.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Guatemala’s Congress voted on Tuesday to strip President Otto Pérez Molina of his immunity from prosecution, a unanimous decision that acknowledged the outpouring of citizen demands for an end to entrenched impunity.

headline: Donald Young Comes From Behind by Not Looking Back
abstract: Young, once considered the future of American tennis, trailed 11th-seeded Gilles Simon by two sets and dropped the first three games of the third before bouncing back for a victory.
lead_paragraph: Gone are the days when Donald Young was considered the future of American tennis. In the 12 years since he turned professional, at 14, Young has lost more matches than he has won. He has battled nerves, critics and opponents. He has become an unabashed reader of self-help books — and pretty much anything else that might help him deal with adversity.

headline: Roger Federer, an Old Hand With a New Move, Keeps Everyone Guessing
abstract: Federer is employing a new tactic in his return game — darting forward to the edge of the service line and taking the ball quickly with a half-volley — and his success has many observers buzzing.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams was working out on Practice Court 1 on Monday, and between shots she glanced over at Roger Federer on the adjacent court to see for herself.

headline: Historical Symbols in Midst of a ‘Purge Moment’
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Symbols', 'Names, Geographical', 'Names, Organizational', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: The fight over the name of a mountain or the treatment of a figure from history rests in large part on competing ownership of histories, peppered with contemporary political context.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 1861, Union soldiers who were camped out in the Senate chamber attacked the desk of Jefferson Davis with a bayonet. Eager to destroy the symbol connected to Davis, who had resigned from the Senate to become president of the Confederacy, they were halted by an aide who insisted that the desk belonged to the government and that the military was “sent here to protect, not destroy.”

headline: Many Paths to Finding Peace
abstract: Maha Rose in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, offers traditional therapies, such as yoga and meditation, but also unconventional ones, like crystal bowl sound baths and tarot card readings.
lead_paragraph: Maha Rose in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, offers traditional therapies, such as yoga and meditation, but also unconventional ones, like crystal bowl sound baths and tarot card readings.

headline: Free Your Mind
abstract: Kevin Christian and Brad Wilber offer a sizzling, hip, bluesy puzzle that will shake you out of your midweek blahs.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — This offering from Kevin Christian and Brad Wilber rocked me out of my midweek blahs. In my view, it’s a sassy, bluesy grid that was a lot of fun to solve. This puzzle is the solving equivalent of sipping your third Scotch in a dark blues club after midnight. All you know is that you’re having a good time and the band is playing all your favorites.

headline: After Playing Down a Homeless Crisis, Mayor de Blasio Changes His Tone
abstract: The resignation of Deputy Mayor Lilliam Barrios-Paoli came amid a scramble by Mayor Bill de Blasio’s team to solve a persistent problem.
lead_paragraph: In mid-July, facing a swelling public outcry over street homelessness in New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio suggested that residents’ eyes were deceiving them. “Homelessness is not going up, thank God,” he said.

headline: Jets Put Jace Amaro on Injured Reserve With Shoulder Injury
abstract: Amaro, a second-round draft pick in 2014 who was hurt in the preseason opener, has a torn labrum, costing the Jets a receiving threat at one of their weaker positions.
lead_paragraph: Jace Amaro was placed on injured reserve with a torn labrum in his shoulder, costing the Jets a receiving threat at one of their weaker positions.

headline: Azerbaijan: Journalist Critical of Leader Is Sentenced to 7 1/2 Years in Prison
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Tax Evasion', 'Embezzlement']
abstract: Khadija Ismayilova was sentenced Tuesday to 7 1/2 years in prison on charges including embezzlement and tax evasion.
lead_paragraph: Khadija Ismayilova, an Azerbaijani investigative journalist, was sentenced Tuesday to 7 1/2 years in prison on charges including embezzlement and tax evasion. The sentence was handed down by the Court on Grave Crimes in Baku, the capital. Ms. Ismayilova is a contributor to Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, which is funded by the United States, and is known for reports questioning the sources of wealth of Azerbaijan’s president, Ilham Aliyev, and his family. During the trial, Ms. Ismayilova, 39, who was arrested in December, said she was innocent and accused the government of “lies.” Isabel Santos of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe’s Parliamentary Assembly, said in a statement that “with every journalist, human rights defender and civil society leader it harasses or jails, Azerbaijan distances itself further and further from democratic values.”

headline: Clashes Over Draft Constitution Kill 5 in Nepal
abstract: Five members of an ethnic minority were killed by police gunfire during protests over the latest version of a draft constitution.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU — Violent protests over a draft of a new constitution broke out Tuesday in Nepal’s southern plains, the latest strife to imperil the new charter and draw accusations of police brutality from local leaders.

headline: Police and Pastors Seek to Curb Violence as Hartford’s Homicide Rate Soars
abstract: Only eight months into 2015, the city has logged 24 homicides, surpassing the total number reported during all of last year.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — On a sunny Sunday in August, the Salvation Army’s small North End congregation held its weekly worship service outside.

headline: Obama’s Alaska Tour Continues
abstract: On Tuesday, the president visited a melting glacier in the Kenai Mountains and bought some pastries at an Anchorage cafe.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the president visited a melting glacier in the Kenai Mountains and bought some pastries at an Anchorage cafe.

headline: Yankees’ Betances Escapes Trouble, and Pineda Picks Up 10th Win
abstract: Reliever Dellin Betances worked his way out of jams in the seventh and eighth innings, and Michael Pineda earned his third win in a row at Boston since he was ejected there last season.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — If many of his teammates had to be indoctrinated into the rich history between the Yankees and Red Sox, Dellin Betances, who grew up in Washington Heights, was steeped in it.

headline: New York City Reaches Deal With Bus Drivers Union on Safety Law
abstract: A law introduced by Bill de Blasio last year had resulted in the arrests of six bus drivers for injuring pedestrians or cyclists.
lead_paragraph: After clashing repeatedly this year over a new traffic safety law, Mayor Bill de Blasio and the city’s major bus drivers union came to a fragile truce this week.

headline: For Thousands of Exhausted Migrants, a Journey’s End in Munich
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: The men, women and children were met by the police who escorted them to their first step in Germany — registration with the bureaucracy.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — The journey for more than 2,000 migrants, who overcame border crossings, deprivation and erratic enforcement of European migration policies on a land route through southeastern Europe, ended Tuesday when the trains that had carried them from the Hungarian capital rolled into Munich’s vast main station.

headline: Mets’ Sudden Crowd Comes Up Empty
abstract: The Mets, whose recalled players have given the team a packed clubhouse, allowed the Phillies to score five runs in the third inning and eight runs in the sixth.
lead_paragraph: The Mets’ clubhouse resembled a traffic jam on the Grand Central Parkway on Tuesday.

headline: Blondell Cummings, Dancer of Life’s Everyday Details, Dies at 70
abstract: Ms. Cummings danced on prominent stages and created works that embraced multiple disciplines.
lead_paragraph: Blondell Cummings, a modern dancer and choreographer who mined quotidian experiences like washing, cooking and building to yield works celebrated for their rich characterizations and dramatic momentum, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 70.

headline: Nikolaus Lehnhoff, German Opera Director, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Lehnhoff staged “Salome” at the Metropolitan Opera in New York and Wagner’s “Ring” cycle in San Francisco in the 1980s, but was best known for his productions in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Nikolaus Lehnhoff, a German opera director who staged “Salome” at the Metropolitan Opera in New York and Wagner’s “Ring” cycle in San Francisco in the 1980s, but who was best known for his productions in Europe, died on Aug. 22 at his home in Berlin. He was 76.

headline: U.S. Stock Markets End Higher Though Global Concerns Linger
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Hang Seng Index (Hong Kong)', 'Nikkei Stock Average', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Some analysts said it was too early to tell whether the increases on Wednesday were a sign that stocks were close to bottoming out.
lead_paragraph: Stocks in the United States bounced back on Wednesday, a day after another sell-off on the global markets, even as worries about economic growth persisted.

headline: Fans, Lights and Andy Murray Beat Nick Kyrgios at U.S. Open
abstract: Kyrgios lived up to his volatile reputation in a four-set defeat in the first round under the lights at Arthur Ashe Stadium.
lead_paragraph: It did not take much to set off the volatile Australian Nick Kyrgios on Tuesday night at the U.S. Open. Troubled by the late-arriving fans, the positioning of the lights and the defensive range of Andy Murray, Kyrgios began to unravel. Quickly. It was precisely the sort of entertainment the crowd at Arthur Ashe Stadium was hoping to see.

headline: Noah Davis, 32, Artist and Founder of Underground Museum in Los Angeles, Dies
abstract: Mr. Davis founded the Underground Museum, which provides free art shows in a working-class neighborhood, in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Noah Davis, a painter and installation artist who founded the Underground Museum, an exhibition space in a working-class neighborhood of Los Angeles that provides free art shows, died on Saturday at his home in Ojai, Calif. He was 32.

headline: Puerto Rico Electric Utility Is Said to Be Near Debt Deal
abstract: The terms under consideration to restructure $5.7 billion in debt included a bond exchange, which would mean a permanent loss for participating bondholders.
lead_paragraph: With a deadline approaching Tuesday night, the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority was close to an agreement with a group of bondholders for a restructuring of up to $5.7 billion of debt, according to two people with knowledge of the talks. The terms under consideration included a bond exchange, which would mean a permanent loss for participating bondholders, along with measures to increase the likelihood that the bondholders would be repaid on the new debt, those people said. By improving the utility’s creditworthiness, Prepa’s borrowing costs would also go down. The total face value of Prepa’s outstanding debt is about $8.1 billion; of that, about $2.4 billion has been insured. The negotiations cover only the remaining $5.7 billion. Prepa and its bondholders have been in restructuring talks for more than a year, and during that time its creditors agreed not to take any legal action to enforce their claims. The agreement was scheduled to expire at midnight on Tuesday, but people with knowledge of the talks said they expected that a deal would be announced early Wednesday.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (TCM) BARRY LYNDON (1975) An Irish rogue (Ryan O’Neal, above right, with James Magee) gambles, fights and seduces his way to the apex of 18th-century British society in Stanley Kubrick’s adaptation of William Makepeace Thackeray’s first novel. His undoing comes at the hand of a widowed beauty (Marisa Berenson), whose high station gives her license to be boring. This comedy of manners “is so long and leisurely, so panoramic in its narrative scope, that it’s as much an environment as it is a conventional film,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “Its austerity of purpose defines it as a costume movie unlike any other you’ve seen.” The film is part of a tribute to the Oscar-winning composer Leonard Rosenman, starting at 8 with “A Man Called Horse.”

headline: Hedge Funds’ Wobbles Bolster Argument Against High Fees
abstract: Big names in hedge funds have taken a pounding from recent market turmoil, lending extra weight to decisions by Calpers and others to ditch them.
lead_paragraph: Recent hedge fund woes are adding fodder to fee fighters.

headline: Questions Raised About Vietnam War Photos
abstract: Images by North Vietnamese war photographers that were featured in a book and exhibit have been found to have been manipulated.
lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — During last year’s Visa pour l’Image festival here, dramatic images by North Vietnamese photographers of the war with the United States were exhibited with great fanfare. The show was presented by a veteran war photographer, Patrick Chauvel, and the festival’s director, Jean Francois Leroy, as an unprecedented view of the Vietnam wars told by the virtually unknown photographers.

headline: North Korea Denies Apologizing for Land Mine Blasts
abstract: “‘Regret' is nothing more than expressing sympathy,” the country said of its statement about the maiming of two soldiers in its recent deal with the South.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Wednesday accused South Korea of misreading the two countries’ recent agreement on easing border tensions, insisting that Pyongyang’s expression of “regret” over the wounding of two soldiers from the South was never meant as an apology.

abstract: No problem with writers writing too much. Yet they don’t have to publish it all.

abstract: A resident of Arverne by the Sea, Queens, wants the scales to tip from the few to the many.

headline: Venezuela’s Manufactured Border Crisis
abstract: The Venezuelan president has made up a crisis with two neighbors in an effort to rally support ahead of parliamentary elections.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela declared a state of emergency in areas that abut Colombia, shut down the border and ordered a mass roundup of Colombian immigrants. In a decree issued on Aug. 21, he warned that drug trafficking, contraband and rampant violence along the border made it necessary to suspend basic rights, such as public gatherings and demonstrations. After Venezuelan authorities evicted Colombians from their homes, some dwellings were marked with the letter D, meaning they would be demolished.

abstract: The Turkish ambassador says his country is doing “more than most” to address the turmoil in his region.

headline: Costly Hepatitis C Drugs for Everyone?
abstract: Competition and discounts are going a long way toward resolving the problem of expensive hepatitis C drugs.
lead_paragraph: New drugs to treat hepatitis C are tremendously effective — and tremendously costly — raising fears that the high prices might outstrip the ability of public and private insurers to pay. Fortunately, competitive market forces and hard-nosed bargaining by insurers for big discounts are going a long way toward resolving the problem.

headline: Giving Women a Role in Korean Peace Negotiations
abstract: Gloria Steinem and Christine Ahn, who were among a group of women crossing the DMZ in Korea, say “we’re still waiting” for a peace deal 62 years after the war.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Joe Biden Delusion
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The vice president commands enormous affection. That doesn’t mean he can win the Democratic presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Many politicians seem intent on holding themselves as far back from us as possible, on parceling themselves out in only the smallest and most controlled bits. Even as they implore us to love them and insist that we trust them, they’re stingy. Cagey. Coiled.

headline: Our Radical Islamic BFF, Saudi Arabia
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: The greatest purveyors of radical Islam aren’t the Iranians, as a general says. The Saudis win that title hands down.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Post ran a story last week about some 200 retired generals and admirals who sent a letter to Congress “urging lawmakers to reject the Iran nuclear agreement, which they say threatens national security.” There are legitimate arguments for and against this deal, but there was one argument expressed in this story that was so dangerously wrongheaded about the real threats to America from the Middle East, it needs to be called out.

headline: Was It Cancer? Getting the Diagnosis
abstract: I regularly do hot yoga and swim in a bay near my home in Sydney. What was this thing on my ovaries?
lead_paragraph: Sydney, Australia — I OFTEN wondered what it would be like to have a cancer growing inside your body. To suddenly discover you are carrying something that is eating you away, growing in an ugly, consuming mass in or around your bones or organs. To be blithely stepping through life, unaware that your insides are betraying you.

headline: What Donald Trump Understands About Republicans
abstract: Fifty years of Republican policies on race and immigration have readied the party for his candidacy.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s success is no surprise. The public and the press have focused on his defiant rejection of mannerly rhetoric, his putting into words of what others think privately. But the more important truth is that a half-century of Republican policies on race and immigration have made the party the home of an often angry and resentful white constituency — a constituency that is now politically mobilized in the face of demographic upheaval.

headline: Obama, Visiting Arctic, Will Pledge Aid to Alaskans Hit by Climate Change
abstract: He will step up government aid for Arctic communities whose shorelines and infrastructure are crumbling as warming seas melt their foundations.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — President Obama on Wednesday will pledge to step up government aid for Arctic communities whose shorelines and infrastructure are crumbling as warming seas melt their foundations, intensifying his administration’s effort to cope with the effects of climate change where they are being felt most acutely.

headline: What's the Greatest Threat to U.S. National Security?
abstract: The president says it's nuclear terrorism. The Pentagon says it's Russia. The F.B.I. says it's the Islamic State.

headline: Chinese Comedian Suing Baidu Over Biographical Entry
abstract: The Chinese comedian Xu Deliang is suing the Chinese Internet encyclopedia Baidu Baike, hoping to win removal of assertions that he never graduated from college and did not write his own material.

headline: The West Village: Bohemian Past, Lofty Prices
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Cobblestone streets and small cafes predominate in many areas of the West Village, where about 80 percent of the neighborhood has landmark status.
lead_paragraph: The West Village of Manhattan is a place “where the streets are so tiny, so isolated from the hubbub of the rest of the city, they have managed to stay trapped in a time warp,” said Barry Benepe, an architect and urban planner who has rented an apartment on Jane Street since 1971 and was a founder of the city’s Greenmarket movement in 1976. Landmark designations have helped to maintain the human scale, he said. About 80 percent of the West Village has landmark status, said Andrew Berman, the executive director of the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation.

headline: Bat Flipping Draws Shrugs in South Korea but Scorn in America
abstract: Hwang Jae-gyun, who plays in South Korea’s top baseball league, found himself prominent on websites and English-language social media after a home run.
lead_paragraph: DAEGU, South Korea — Hwang Jae-gyun, a third baseman for the Lotte Giants in South Korea’s top baseball league, received some curious text messages from his American teammates one morning in July. His name, they told him, was popping up on websites around the world. He was prominent on English-language social media websites.

headline: Stephen Colbert, the Late Night Hope
abstract: Mr. Colbert (the real one, not the character) has spent the summer preparing to assume command of “The Late Show.” Will he become the Letterman successor CBS needs him to be?
lead_paragraph: On a recent Monday night, Stephen Colbert was about as high atop the Ed Sullivan Theater as one can be, looking out over the 200 or so employees of his CBS “Late Show” who had gathered for a roof party as he stood on a staircase with a megaphone in hand.

headline: Are You a Hoarder or a Minimalist (or Somewhere in the Middle)?
abstract: Do you have low tolerance for clutter in your bedroom, your house or your life in general?
lead_paragraph: What do you do with all the physical things you collect along the way in life?

headline: ‘The Silo Effect,’ by Gillian Tett
abstract: A journalist takes an anthropological approach to the structure of organizations.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever worked for a large organization, you’ve probably had some version of the following experience: A project you’ve been working on for months is now going to be canceled because some other part of the organization was also working on a similar project, and apparently no one in your department even knew. Or: You find out some crucial piece of information or equipment you’ve been desperately searching for actually exists within your company, secretly hoarded by some rival internal faction that wanted to make sure no one else got to play with their proverbial toys.

headline: ‘$2.00 a Day,’ by Kathryn J. Edin and H. Luke Shaefer
abstract: A look at the rise of extreme poverty and how families survive in its grip.
lead_paragraph: From the late 1960s to the mid-1990s, a number of developments turned out to have profound effects on destitute families in the United States, which Kathryn J. Edin and H. Luke Shaefer’s “$2.00 a Day: Living on Almost Nothing in America” brings into sharp relief. Critics of welfare repeatedly argued that the increase of unwed mothers was mainly due to rising rates of welfare payments through Aid to Families With Dependent Children (A.F.D.C.). Even though the ­scientific ­evidence offered little support for this claim, the public’s outrage against the program, fueled by the “welfare queen” stereotype that Ronald Reagan peddled in stump speeches during his 1976 run for the presidency, led to calls for a major revamping of the welfare system.

headline: Passport Hints at a Uighur Link in Bangkok Bombing
abstract: The document indicates the man is from the far western Chinese region of Xinjiang, the authorities say, but they have not verified its authenticity.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The Thai police said on Wednesday that their main suspect in a deadly attack on a Bangkok shrine has a Chinese passport indicating that he is from the far western region of Xinjiang but that they had not yet verified whether the passport was authentic.

headline: Today in Politics: Obama Has One Vote Left to Court on Iran Deal
abstract: President Obama may be in the wilds of Alaska, but he is on the verge of a major foreign policy victory back home: The Senate is a vote short of making it impossible for opponents to block the nuclear deal with Iran.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning. In their arguments against the Iran nuclear deal, some Republican candidates have mocked President Obama for calling climate change the most serious threat facing the nation. It is worth noting then that the deal’s success might be assured while Mr. Obama is in the Arctic, warning of the effects of climate change.

headline: Can I Lie to My Father About Being Gay So He Will Pay for My College Education?
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Scholarships and Fellowships']
abstract: The ethicists consider whether a son’s need for financial support justifies concealing his sexual orientation.
lead_paragraph: I am a young gay man in college. My father generously pays for my tuition and rent. The problem is that he does not know I am gay. He has made it very clear that if I were, he would not only withdraw all financial support but also cast himself entirely out of my life. His suspicion arose in high school when he found love letters between me and another male student. I swore they were meaningless and have since been defending my heterosexuality. Questions about my sexuality are inevitable whenever I come home. My father has demanded I produce archives of all emails and text messages for him to review, although I have successfully refused these requests on the grounds that he has no claim to my adult communications. Is it ethical for me to continue accepting financial support for my education and my career that will come from it? Could I continue to lie to accept the support and one day disclose my sexuality and pay him back to absolve myself of any ethical wrongdoing? NAME WITHHELD

headline: The Propane-Fueled Endless Summer
abstract: Warmer months might be waning, but your grilling season can keep right on going.
lead_paragraph: There is something wistful about a Labor Day cookout — something ever-so-slightly melancholy about putting those burgers and brats on the grill one last time before summer’s end. For many, the holiday marks the start of what Spy magazine once called ‘‘anxiety season’’ — time to ‘‘overstuff the briefcase, to yearn for a new apartment, fret about the raise, lose patience, work harder, fidget, stew, anguish, roil.’’ In anxiety season, we think there is no longer room for warm-weather pleasures like cooking outside.

headline: The Misanthropic Genius of Joy Williams
abstract: The writer’s new story collection establishes her as one of the greatest chroniclers of humanity’s insignificance.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the writer Joy Williams’s favorite church needed to dispose of a few extra pews after a renovation. Williams attends the church only in April and October, when her frequent cross-country drives take her to Laramie, Wyo., but she wanted a pew anyway. She borrowed a trailer, got a friend to help her load the pew and drove a thousand miles, pulling it behind her enormous Bronco, her two German shepherds in the cab with her. Now the long, dark pew lives in her house in Tucson.

headline: China’s Military Parades: A Look Back

lead_paragraph: Although the military parade in Beijing on Thursday will be the first in China to honor the anniversary of the end of World War II, major military pageants have been staged in the capital before, to celebrate the founding of the People’s Republic on Oct. 1, 1949. The parades were an annual event through the 1950s, then moved mostly to five- or 10-year intervals. Here are some glimpses of notable National Day parades from years past.

headline: 1940: New York Teems With Visitors
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: New York draws Labor Day visitors in 1940.
lead_paragraph: The largest Labor Day week-end crowd that ever descended on New York City began to journey homeward last night [Sept. 2], choking transport facilities with its volume and leaving behind a happy but tired legion of hotel, theater and restaurant managers to recover from the pleasant pain of being swamped by so much business that they turned away thousands of customers. Railroad stations and bus terminals were jammed when the out-of-town visitors on their way home met the horde of New Yorkers returning from summer fun to fall business. Precisely how many out-of-town visitors swarmed into the city during the three-day holiday was anybody’s guess. Maj. Benjamin H. Namm, chairman of Mayor F.H. La Guardia’s Official World Fair Housing Bureau, set the figure at 2,500,000. — New York Herald Tribune, September 3, 1940

Mosby, the state’s attorney for Baltimore City, removed from the case on grounds of conflict of interest and prosecutorial misconduct.

headline: Coordinated Strategy Brings Obama Victory on Iran Nuclear Deal
abstract: A message from five world powers helped persuade many Democrats to back the accord, for which President Obama now has enough votes to survive Republican opposition.

The five world powers had no intention of returning to the negotiating table.

headline: 1965: Fighting in Kashmir
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Pakistan forces advance into Kashmir in 1965.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Pakistan forces supported by tanks and jet planes advanced still further into Indian-held Kashmir territory today [Sept. 2], Indian officials said. They also acknowledged for the first time that Pakistani forces had occupied the towns of Chamb and Deva, six to eight miles inside the Indian part of the state. But the officials here said an Indian counterattack had slowed the advance, allegedly involving 3,000 men and 70 tanks. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 3, 1965

headline: Will Germany Succumb to Hate?
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Discrimination', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Despite the rise of anti-refugee attacks, there is reason to hope that Germany will remain open and welcoming to migrants.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — AMID the staccato ping of news generated by Europe’s migration crisis, perhaps nothing is more jarring than what is playing out in Germany. The country, which expects up to a million refugees to arrive this year and whose chancellor has been the Continent’s most outspoken advocate for accepting refugees, has also experienced more than 200 attacks, mostly arson, on homes for asylum seekers during the first six months of the year, according to the Ministry of Homeland Affairs.

headline: Time-Worn Village in Moldova Springs Back to Life, Thanks to Port
abstract: In 1999, in exchange for ceding a stretch of contested road to Ukraine, landlocked Moldova received a strip of land along the Danube River.
lead_paragraph: GIURGIULESTI, Moldova — Like many rural villages throughout Europe, Giurgiulesti was shrinking. The young had left, seeking work and better futures, and they never came back. The old had stayed behind, tilling the fields and nurturing the grapes on backyard vines that they used to make wine.

headline: Iranian General Speaks of U.S. Enmity
abstract: The head of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, Maj. Gen. Mohammad Ali Jafari, referred to the United States as “the Great Satan” and said its hostility toward the Islamic Revolution had grown.
lead_paragraph: The head of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, Maj. Gen. Mohammad Ali Jafari, referred to the United States as “the Great Satan” and said its hostility toward the Islamic Revolution had grown.

headline: A Skyscraper-Size Pope
abstract: Amid the hustle and bustle, a mural of Pope Francis was painted on the side of a high-rise near Penn Station in Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Amid the hustle and bustle, a mural of Pope Francis was painted on the side of a high-rise near Penn Station in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Before the Pope’s Visit, a 180-Foot-Tall Francis Arrives in Midtown
abstract: Van Hecht-Nielsen and a team of three painters are creating possibly the largest hand-painted mural of Francis ever done, a project commissioned by the Diocese of Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday afternoon, Van Hecht-Nielsen had just finished painting the elbow of a 180-foot-tall Pope Francis overlooking Madison Square Garden, when he took a break for lunch.

headline: College Football’s Opening Week Evolves From Mismatches to Can’t-Miss Matches
abstract: A national “kickoff game” in 2008 led to the creation of other high-profile openers, which have turned the start of the season into a powerful national advertisement for the sport.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Eight years ago, Alabama Coach Nick Saban had a football program to resurrect. So when he was approached about beginning the 2008 season, his second at Alabama, with an August game against Clemson in the Georgia Dome, Saban agreed almost immediately.

headline: Prison Officials Join Movement to Curb Solitary Confinement
abstract: The Association of State Correctional Administrators said in a statement Wednesday that the policy of keeping inmates in solitary confinement needed to be limited or ended.
lead_paragraph: In a sign of how far the nation has moved from supporting solitary confinement for inmates, the leading organization for the nation’s prison and jail administrators on Wednesday called for sharply limiting or even ending its use for extended periods.

headline: A Trio of New Paris Tables
abstract: Three restaurants with open-air seating are just the place to sit, eat and watch the city — and the final days of summer — pass by.
lead_paragraph: In Paris, three new restaurants with open-air seating are just the place to get comfortable, share a meal and watch the city — and the final days of summer — pass by.

headline: Senator Voices Support for Iran Deal
abstract: Senator Chris Coons, a Democrat from Delaware, explained why he decided not to oppose a landmark accord on Iran’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: Senator Chris Coons, a Democrat from Delaware, explained why he decided not to oppose a landmark accord on Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: New York City Council Speaker Endorses Hillary Clinton for President
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Endorsements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Puerto Ricans', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Speaker Melissa Mark-Viverito lent her support to Mrs. Clinton’s campaign, saying it was time for all of the state’s Democrats to close ranks around her.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Melissa Mark-Viverito of the New York City Council endorsed Hillary Rodham Clinton for president on Wednesday, reinforcing Democratic support for Mrs. Clinton in her home state and possibly offering her a boost in Ms. Mark-Viverito’s native Puerto Rico.

headline: Paula Deen and a Train Hero Join ‘Dancing With the Stars’
abstract: “Dancing With the Stars” announces the full cast of its 21st season.
lead_paragraph: ABC announced the full cast of the 21st season of “Dancing With the Stars” on Wednesday morning, adding to the lineup Alek Skarlatos, a specialist in the Oregon National Guard who helped avert a train disaster in France, and the celebrity chef Paula Deen, whose reputation was stained after she admitted in 2013 to using racial slurs in the past.

headline: The Oregon Shakespeare Festival Focuses on Diversity
keywords: ['Theater', 'Oregon Shakespeare Festival', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The troupe has dedicated itself to community outreach and “color-conscious” casting.
lead_paragraph: ASHLAND, ORE. — A first-time visitor to the Oregon Shakespeare Festival might be struck by any number of things. The festival’s idyllic location in this small city surrounded by vistas of rolling hills. Or the splendid Tudor-style outdoor Elizabethan theater, just one of the three spaces where performances take place six days a week for more than seven months, for an impressive total of roughly 800 shows.

headline: John Gachot’s Back-to-School Lunchbox Doodles
abstract: The interior designer, who has worked with Marc Jacobs, Gucci and Boucheron, shares notes to tuck into kids’ lunches.
lead_paragraph: The interior designer, who has worked with Marc Jacobs, Gucci and Boucheron, shares notes to tuck into kids’ lunches.

headline: Back-to-School Lunchbox Notes From Marc Jacobs’s Interior Designer
abstract: John Gachot has been tucking illustrated notes in with his kids’ lunches for years; he shares 13 printable doodles exclusively with T.
lead_paragraph: The interior designer John Gachot has been responsible for decorating Marc Jacobs’s townhouse, the Tumblr founder David Karp’s Williamsburg apartment and the Smyth Hotel in Tribeca; he’s done interiors for the likes of Bottega Veneta, Gucci and Boucheron. He’s also a dedicated father: He and his wife and fellow designer, Christine, have two boys, Boris and Jackie, aged 13 and 8, who are very close despite wildly different personalities. “Where Boris is our mild-mannered peace, love and rock ‘n’ roll child, Jackie is a powerhouse of ambition and energy,” Gachot says. “He recently turned our kitchen stools into a sculpture called Jackefeller Center, and would get to work on time each day.”

headline: Jessica Raine, a Star of ‘Call the Midwife,’ on Returning to the ’50s With Agatha Christie
abstract: The actress, who portrayed Jenny Lee in “Midwife,” was told by a drama teacher that she should expect to be cast in modern roles.
lead_paragraph: In her final year at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London, Jessica Raine was told by a teacher that she had a modern face and should expect to be cast in modern roles. And sure enough, after graduation Ms. Raine portrayed a defiant goth and a drugged-out politician’s daughter in quick succession at the National Theater.

headline: Trump Campaign: Carnival Sideshow, yes. But also dangerous and irresponsible.
abstract: Times editorial page editor Andrew Rosenthal on Donald Trump
lead_paragraph: Times editorial page editor Andrew Rosenthal on Donald Trump

headline: Is Ben Carson Really the Anti-Trump?
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: We’re supposed to believe he’s more thoughtful, but the evidence suggests otherwise.
lead_paragraph: In this over-polled, over-long, over-crowded Republican presidential contest, the spin of the day is that Ben Carson, the former neurosurgeon who touts his scientific background but rejects science on little things like evolution and global warming, is challenging Donald Trump for the supposed lead in the alleged campaign.

headline: Kentucky Clerk Who Said ‘No’ to Gay Couples Won’t Be Alone in Court
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: Kim Davis, a county clerk, will be represented by Liberty Counsel, a nonprofit that has been aiding officials who refuse to recognize same-sex marriages.
lead_paragraph: MOREHEAD, Ky. — Of the local officials who refuse to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, Kim Davis, the clerk here in Rowan County, Ky., is the best known, at least for now.

headline: Backpack Makers Rethink a Student Staple
abstract: As the need to carry textbooks becomes less important, the backpack is being redesigned for electronics and the everyday needs of living on the go.
lead_paragraph: The inside of Alejandro Sarete’s backpack is jammed with the objects of a busy student life: smartphone, USB thumb drive, playing cards, lip balm. Cho Young-Uk’s shoulder bag is more minimalist in content: Lenovo laptop and adapter.

headline: Photographic Portraits From West Africa at the Met
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art presents nearly 80 pieces dating from the 1870s to the 1970s by photographers living and working in the region.
lead_paragraph: From the 1840s on, European photographers traveled all over the world looking for exotic subjects, and people in the places they visited enthusiastically adopted the new medium for themselves. West Africa was one such locale. “In and Out of the Studio: Photographic Portraits from West Africa,” now open at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, presents nearly 80 pieces dating from the 1870s to the 1970s by professional and amateur photographers living and working in a region bordered by Senegal and Mali in the northwest and Cameroon and Gabon in the southeast.

headline: Executive at Struggling Rovio, Maker of Angry Birds, Pushes Silver Lining
abstract: Rovio, the Finnish gaming company behind the Angry Birds franchise, has faced cutthroat competition from upstart rivals in the increasingly competitive world of online gaming.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — The signs are still not looking good for the maker of Angry Birds.

headline: Annie Gosfield, Scoring the Music of Machines
abstract: Ms. Gosfield, whose compositions feature vacuums, industrial noise and shortwave radios, is drawn to alternative sonic sources.
lead_paragraph: One of the composer Annie Gosfield’s favorite mementos is a faded pink ticket for a 1980 show by Planet Z, a rock band she played keyboards with, at the Hong Kong Cafe in downtown Los Angeles. The small living room in the East Village apartment where she has lived since arriving in New York in 1992 is crammed with other souvenirs of her eclectic life: a shelf with hat blocks next to shelves of records, a shortwave radio, a guitar, an old desktop computer and the small desk where she works.

headline: Jeanine Durning in Constant Motion at the Chocolate Factory
abstract: Her latest work, “To Being,” helps this venue celebrate its 10th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Jeanine Durning’s work, a labyrinth of accumulation featuring looping, half-finished thoughts and precise, nuanced movement, drives its own beat. In the solo “inging,” a 2010 piece based on unscripted speaking, her task is to talk. It’s a relentless practice in which language, more than movement, becomes the choreography. In her latest work, “To Being,” she shifts her focus from the voice to the body to explore the precariousness of a dancer moving ceaselessly in performance. Her underlying question: “How can we give more when all we feel is that we’ve met our limit?” The work, which also includes the dancers Julian Barnett and Molly Poerstel and sound by Tian Rotteveel, delves even more deeply into her research practice known as “nonstopping,” which means moving but never arriving. The Chocolate Factory, however, has arrived: This treasured performance space celebrates its 10th anniversary with the premiere of “To Being” (Sept. 9-19) and the reprisal of “inging” (Sept. 23-26).

headline: Jeb Bush’s Dig at Donald Trump Requires a Show of Hands
abstract: Jeb Bush is telling people about his rival’s hygiene rituals, such as what Donald J. Trump wrote in a 1997 book: “I happen to be a clean hands freak. I feel much better after I thoroughly wash my hands, which I do as much as possible.”
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida made his offensive against Donald J. Trump more personal on Wednesday, highlighting his fear of germs as another reason that Republicans should reconsider their summer fling with the billionaire tycoon.

headline: Hans Werner Henze’s ‘Kammermusik 1958’ Gets a New Staging
abstract: The composer described this chamber piece, to be presented at St. Peter’s, as an encounter between Germany and Greece imagined by a mad poet.
lead_paragraph: The German composer Hans Werner Henze, who died at 86 in 2012, wrote richly scored, emotive orchestral, chamber and vocal works that often proved a stark contrast to the avant-garde music of his contemporaries. He wrote “Kammermusik 1958,” a 12-movement chamber piece for tenor, guitar and eight instruments, during a visit to Greece that year. Set to texts by the poet Friedrich Hölderlin, the work was dedicated to Benjamin Britten; the guitarist Julian Bream and the tenor Peter Pears performed at the premiere.

headline: Masked Gunmen Kidnap 17 Turkish Workers in Baghdad
abstract: The abduction of 17 Turkish workers and their Iraqi translator from a construction site was seen by officials as the work of a criminal gang, not Islamic State militants.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — In the early morning darkness on Wednesday, masked gunmen in military uniforms rolled up in more than a dozen black sport utility vehicles to a construction site on the edge of Baghdad, subdued the guards, and roused 17 Turkish workers and their Iraqi translator from sleep and kidnapped them.

headline: Kerry Warns Against No Vote on Iran Deal
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry, in a speech in Philadelphia on Tuesday, warned of the consequences if the United States walks away unilaterally from the Iran nuclear deal.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry, in a speech in Philadelphia on Tuesday, warned of the consequences if the United States walks away unilaterally from the Iran nuclear deal.

headline: Comfortable at Plate, Jackie Bradley Jr. Eases Boston’s Concerns
abstract: Bradley, hitting .438 in his last 20 games, is finally turning into the hitter Boston expected when it let Jacoby Ellsbury leave as a free agent in 2013.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Jackie Bradley Jr. has a voice as gentle as an evening breeze and barely more audible. The problem was that for much of the last three seasons, his bat was just as quiet.

headline: 36 Hours in Rio
abstract: Rio has a new cosmopolitan edge, with a reinvigorated downtown, recently opened museums and a diverse cuisine that ranges from Amazonian to old-school European.
lead_paragraph: Rio has a new cosmopolitan edge, with a reinvigorated downtown, recently opened museums and a diverse cuisine that ranges from Amazonian to old-school European.

headline: Baltimore Protests for Freddie Gray Case
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Demonstrators gathered outside the Baltimore City Courthouse, where six police officers were facing charges in the arrest and death of Freddie Gray.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators gathered outside the Baltimore City Courthouse, where six police officers were facing charges in the arrest and death of Freddie Gray.

headline: Idris Elba Responds to Author, and Lets ‘the Street’ Do the Talking
abstract: The actor lets us know what he thinks of a novelist’s opinion that he wasn’t suave enough to play James Bond.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, after an interview with the novelist Anthony Horowitz was published in which he shared his belief that Idris Elba was “too street” to take over as James Bond, seemingly the entire Internet let the author know he was wrong. Mr. Horowitz, the latest in a line of writers to pen 007 books, quickly decided that the actor was in fact suave enough for the role and issued an apology.

headline: 36 Hours in Rio de Janeiro
abstract: A new Rio is taking shape, with the Summer Olympics around the corner, and palpable energy is flowing to downtown areas.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Rio de Janeiro has evoked a distant fantasyland of skimpy bathing suits and Carnival spectacle wedged between the sea and a riotous upheaval of tropical mountains. All this, under the outstretched arms of Christ the Redeemer, the sculpture with the most jaw-dropping view on Earth — if only soapstone jaws could drop. But the 2010s have given Rio a chance to add a cosmopolitan edge as host of last year’s World Cup and next year’s Summer Olympics, twice making it the center of the world. The new Rio is taking shape in fits and starts: The downtown port area is in the midst of an impressive overhaul of public works, exhumed historic sites and new museums. And with it, energy has been flowing toward more central, bustling neighborhoods, away from the traditional South Zone destinations of Copacabana and Ipanema — though their beaches still give a party on the sand like no other. And with the dollar at its strongest in over a decade against the troubled Brazilian real, traditionally pricey Rio is still exuberant, but no longer exorbitant.

headline: Basketball Break
abstract: One apparel company’s version of a team lunch.
lead_paragraph: One apparel company’s version of a team lunch.

headline: Police and Migrants Clash in Budapest
abstract: The police in Budapest tried to stop migrants leaving the city’s main train station on Wednesday, which led to a large demonstration.
lead_paragraph: The police in Budapest tried to stop migrants leaving the city’s main train station on Wednesday, which led to a large demonstration.

headline: For One Apparel Brand, Staying Fit Is Just Part of the Job
abstract: The Outdoor Voices crew has adopted certain endorphin-pumping office practices, which they share with T.
lead_paragraph: Once a month, while the weather still permits, the staff at the recreational activewear line Outdoor Voices has a different kind of team lunch: a friendly game of basketball, or “Friday dribble dribble,” as they call it. Around 1 p.m., they lace up and walk past Canal Street’s own lineup — countless vendors, hawking handbags and tchotchkes — to Grand Canal Court, about eight minutes away. Tyler Haney, the company’s 26-year-old founder and C.E.O., grew up in Boulder, Colo., where, she says, “casual activity is baked into everything you do.” Fittingly, the brand’s key tenet, “Doing Things,” embodies a relaxed approach to fitness; and through its signature array of crop tops, leggings, sweats and shorts in subdued hues, Outdoor Voices seeks to close the gap between your gym life and... every other aspect of your life.

headline: Switzerland Investigates Fund Executives in Malaysian Scandal
abstract: The Attorney General’s Office said it had begun an inquiry into two executives of an investment fund at the center of a scandal in which Malaysia’s prime minister is suspected of misconduct.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Swiss authorities said on Wednesday that they had started a criminal investigation of two executives of a Malaysian state investment fund at the center of a corruption scandal that has led to calls for Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia to resign.

headline: Just a Book? No, More Like a Trusty Companion
abstract: “Mystery Train” may be the best book ever written about rock music. Which isn’t far from saying it may be the best book ever written about being alive.
lead_paragraph: The book I wish I could read again for the first time — and the book, I’ve long felt, I most wish I had written — is “Mystery Train: Images of America in Rock ’n’ Roll Music,” by Greil Marcus.

headline: Sharing Economy Goes Hyperlocal With a Growing Market for Household Items
abstract: An earlier flood of similar start-ups fell by the wayside, but experts say poor timing may have been to blame. Smartphone apps may change the equation this time.
lead_paragraph: When vandals broke into Stephanie Ciancio’s Land Cruiser in 2014 and stole her car stereo, she did not have the time and money to replace it. It was particularly vexing for Ms. Ciancio, a 34-year-old San Francisco resident, because she had been planning to take a four-day road trip to Fern Canyon, Calif., over the long July 4 weekend, and the idea of making the eight-hour drive without music was depressing.

keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Epidemics', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton released plans for an initiative to combat the escalating drug epidemic that she says has swept through rural America and is a top concern of many she has encountered on the campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday released plans for a $10 billion initiative to combat the escalating drug epidemic that she says has swept through rural America and has emerged as a regular concern among voters she has met in the early nominating states.

headline: Short Sleepers May Catch More Colds
abstract: Short sleepers who get less than five to six hours of sleep a night are more likely to get sick after exposure to the common cold virus, new research shows.
lead_paragraph: Want to avoid catching a cold this winter? Start by getting more than six hours of sleep a night.

headline: Copy Roger Federer? He Has No Shot
abstract: When David Waldstein knew he would write about Federer’s new strategy on second-serve returns, he had to try it for himself.
lead_paragraph: It was not until I was given this assignment that I realized the embarrassing truth: I am actually trying to be Roger Federer. This would be fine if I were still a child; back then, I tried to be Julius Erving. But really, I should be past this.

headline: Julie Kent Has New Roles at American Ballet Theater
abstract: Ms. Kent, the former American Ballet Theater principal who retired in June, will be artistic director of the summer intensive programs and will teach and coach the studio company and at the school.
lead_paragraph: Julie Kent, the star ballerina who retired as a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater in June, is taking on several new roles with the company, including as the artistic director of its summer intensive programs for young dancers.

headline: Solitary Confinement Is Cruel and All Too Common
abstract: If California, the worst offender, can reform its use of solitary, there is hope for the rest of the country.
lead_paragraph: If mass incarceration is one of modern America’s deepest pathologies, solitary confinement is the concentrated version of it: far too many people locked up for far too long for no good reason, at no clear benefit to anyone.

headline: From Gaza to East Harlem: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Reporter Nicholas Casey writes about how surprisingly well he blended in with the subjects of his recent piece about a block in East Harlem.

lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Thursday was supposed to be an occasion for Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, to take a victory lap.

lead_paragraph: Answers to questions about the case of a Kentucky clerk who has refused to issue marriage licenses to any couples, gay or straight.

headline: San Quentin Prison Scrambles After Outbreak of Legionnaires’ Disease
abstract: California corrections officials face problems trying to manage an outbreak of a disease at a prison where the plumbing system has been shut down.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The thick walls of San Quentin State Prison contain thousands of criminals housed deep within a rambling complex on the edge of San Francisco Bay. But since last week, when the first of six prisoners tested positive for Legionnaires’ disease, those ramparts seem to have also turned the prison into a petri dish.

headline: Bernie Sanders Said to Be Close to Signing Fund-Raising Deal With Democratic Party
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders is on the verge of signing a joint fund-raising agreement with the Democratic National Committee, his aides said, a week after Hillary Rodham Clinton entered such an arrangement with the party.

abstract: The end of the two-year contract has spawned something perhaps more nefarious — endlessly bewildering options. We waded through them and found the best bets.
lead_paragraph: THE American wireless industry is increasingly redefining the word “simple” in the same way that the food industry rendered the word “natural” absurd.

headline: La Monnaie, in Brussels, Names New Music Director
abstract: The French conductor Alain Altinoglu will become the music director of the Théâtre Royal de la Monnaie in Brussels, the theater said.
lead_paragraph: The French conductor Alain Altinoglu, whose career has taken off in recent years with well-received performances at many of the world’s leading opera houses, will become music director of the Théâtre Royal de la Monnaie in Brussels in January, the theater said Wednesday.

headline: ‘The Daily Show’ Announces Three New Correspondents
abstract: Ronny Chieng, Roy Wood Jr. and Desi Lydic will join the Comedy Central news satire.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Noah won’t be the only person at “The Daily Show” asking veteran staff members how to set up a voice-mail box or where to find the nearest bathroom.

abstract: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan unveils a special chair ahead of the papal Mass at Madison Square Garden in New York this month.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan unveils a special chair ahead of the papal Mass at Madison Square Garden in New York this month.

headline: Hillary Clinton Uses G.O.P.’s Words to Aid Her Arguments
abstract: Again and again in her political career, Mrs. Clinton has been given political cover by Republicans who cannot stop themselves from overreaching.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton falters, and Republicans ride to her rescue.

headline: London Theater Journal: Rehab and Resistance
abstract: A review of Duncan Macmillan’s new play “People, Places and Things.”
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of Duncan Macmillan’s “People, Places and Things,” a portrait of a skeptic in the church of Alcoholics Anonymous, I began to think that I had misjudged it. At that point, the scene had shifted from the rehab center, where most of the work is set, to the childhood home of the show’s central figure for the expected day of reckoning with Mom and Dad.

headline: Fool’s Gold Concert to Feature the Energy of Meek Mill and More
abstract: This event at the intersection of dance and hip-hop will include D. J.s and artists like Post Malone at Brooklyn Live at the Inlet.
lead_paragraph: Since its 2010 debut in a SoHo parking lot, the Fool’s Gold Presents Day Off party has been an annual barometer of the fertile space where hip-hop meets dance music, a space where Fool’s Gold, the label, thrives and innovates. This year’s lineup emphasizes high energy, radiating from the vanquished hip-hop warrior Meek Mill, looking for redemption; the fiercely rumbling grime don Skepta; the saucy, wavy, trippy rapper Post Malone; the polyglot club bounce D.J.-producer Brenmar; the punchy updater of ’90s R&B Bosco; and many more. All of it will be interwoven with D.J. sets by the Fool’s Gold label founders A-Trak and Nick Catchdubs, masters of this domain and of its many copycats, too. (4 p.m., Monday, Brooklyn Live at the Inlet, foolsgoldrecs.com.)

headline: ‘Arthur & George’ Makes Sherlock Holmes’s Creator the Detective
abstract: This adaptation of Julian Barnes’s factual novel unveils Sir Arthur Conan Doyle’s personal life.
lead_paragraph: In the time it took to puff on his pipe, Sherlock Holmes would have discerned everything: the eavesdropper at the private club as well as his name, political persuasion and place of birth — all from the dust on his shoes. But Sir Arthur Conan Doyle? Shockingly oblivious, a detractor declares in “Arthur & George” (Sundays on PBS). “If you pursue your interest in the Edalji case, you’ll be judged by his high standards, and judged harshly,” the man chides Holmes’s creator. “But if you fall short, as you are bound to do, you’ll taint not only yourself but the world’s favorite consulting detective.”

headline: ‘Apu Trilogy’ Screens at BAM Cinématek
abstract: Satyajit Ray’s triptych masterpiece, about a son from a rural Bengal family, has been restored.
lead_paragraph: “Everyone has their reasons” is the immortal line from Jean Renoir’s masterpiece “The Rules of the Game.” A similar openhearted humanity characterizes the films of the Indian auteur Satyajit Ray, and never more so than in “The Apu Trilogy,” at BAM Cinématek in Brooklyn from Wednesday through Saturday.

headline: Wedding Gifts That Give Back

lead_paragraph: Some presents for bridal couples provide assistance for those in need around the world.

headline: A Nursery for Newborn Stars in the Prawn Nebula
abstract: The Prawn Nebula is 6,000 light-years from Earth and home to bright clusters of newborn stars.
lead_paragraph: A telescope at La Silla Observatory in Chile has captured three clusters of bright newborn stars in the Prawn Nebula, a dense concentration of ionized gas and dust. Just a few million years old, the stars glow in ultraviolet light, illuminating the nebula’s gas clouds as well. The young stars form from the remnants of old stars that died in supernova explosions. The nebula is about 6,000 light-years from Earth, in the constellation Scorpius.

headline: William Buchina’s “Time to Speak a Human Language”
abstract: The artist will show new paintings at Garis & Hahn starting next week.
lead_paragraph: The artist will show new paintings at Garis & Hahn starting next week.

headline: Meticulously Assembled Paintings That Find Grace in the Gesture
abstract: Starting next week, Garis & Hahn will show new works by the artist William Buchina, who layers images from dozens of sources to create his paintings.
lead_paragraph: The artist William Buchina is no snob: athletes in motion interest him no more than the fans who cheer or mope on the Jumbotron. The things that fascinate Buchina, he says, are “the contortions of the body, the look on the face, the strain of the muscles” in human movement. And the people he depicts are often cropped or abstracted to just that — the jutting of a jaw, the torque of a torso. Each painting in “Time to Speak a Human Language,” a new solo exhibition comprising nearly a dozen new works on canvas along with some older pieces, features images from many distinct sources. Buchina reworks these images, often altering, layering or abstracting them beyond recognition.

headline: Review: ‘Miley Cyrus & Her Dead Petz’ Puts Faith in the Weird
abstract: This pop star’s experimental new album is long and slack, stretching many of its 23 songs out of meager ideas.
lead_paragraph: MILEY CYRUS

headline: Spielberg’s DreamWorks Studio Expected to End Distribution Pact With Disney
abstract: The amicable departure will probably occur next summer, after the July release of “The BFG,” according to people briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Steven Spielberg’s DreamWorks Studios, a company that has survived more scrapes than Indiana Jones, is about to try another perilous leap.

headline: Stephen Colbert and J.J. Abrams Team Up for Montclair Film Festival
abstract: The two will appear in a “Celebrity Nerd-Off!”
lead_paragraph: Stephen Colbert may be the sort of fantasy-narrative geek who can quote at length from “The Lord of the Rings” and occasionally invoke it in just the right way to make Jon Stewart feel warm and fuzzy. But this incoming “Late Show” host is no scruffy-looking nerf herder when it comes to his worship of the “Star Wars” franchise, either, having featured its creator, George Lucas, on “The Colbert Report” and hosted him in conversation at the Tribeca Film Festival in May.

headline: Understanding Mac OS X Disk Permissions, and How to Repair Them

lead_paragraph: LIZZ WRIGHT

headline: Universal Music Posts Strong Results, and Streaming Is a Bright Spot
abstract: Universal, whose results were reported as part of its parent company Vivendi, had $2.6 billion in revenue for the first half of the year and $255 million in earnings.
lead_paragraph: In another sign of the growing importance of online streaming to the music business, the Universal Music Group had increased revenue and earnings for the first half of 2015, largely because of the popularity of streaming and subscription outlets like Spotify and Deezer.

headline: War Crimes Trial Opens for Bosco Ntaganda, Congolese Rebel Leader
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Mr. Ntaganda appeared at the International Criminal Court, accused of terrorizing and killing civilians in the Ituri region of the Democratic Republic of Congo.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Bosco Ntaganda is not the first person accused of war crimes to appear voluntarily before the International Criminal Court, but the former Congolese rebel commander and once powerful crime boss is the first to do so after turning himself in at an American Embassy.

headline: For the Former OHWOW Gallery’s First Outing, a Provocative Show
abstract: The “youth-cultural experiment” OHWOW has been rebranded Moran Bondaroff; its inaugural show features sculptures by Nick van Woert that confront institutional violence.
lead_paragraph: The artist Nick van Woert culls inspiration from the past, frequently remixing artifacts and evoking history to build his art. His latest, “Just Dropped in to See What Condition My Condition Was In,” on view starting next Saturday at Moran Bondaroff, the just-rebranded L.A. gallery formerly known as OHWOW, borrows its title from a well-known 1968 Kenny Rogers hit.

headline: Classical Playlist: Matt Haimovitz, Avalon String Quartet and Eighth Blackbird
abstract: A Times critic shares what she’s been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: “Orbit”: Music for Solo Cello (1945-2014) Matt Haimovitz, cello(Pentatone)In this fascinating three-disc survey of music for solo cello written since the end of World War II, this ferociously talented cellist brings his megawatt sound and uncommon expressive gifts to a vast variety of styles, often with surprising results. Mr. Haimovitz finds sensuality in Pierre Boulez, Baroque stringency in Philip Glass and Verdian drama in Salvatore Sciarrino. By turns heartwarming, scary, playful and groovy, this recording reveals worlds inside a single instrument. The ghost of Bach is never far away, of course, but the specter Mr. Haimovitz conjures most vividly is that of Jimi Hendrix, whose rendition of “The Spar-Spangled Banner” he imitates in all its subversive brilliance.

headline: Satanists, Vegans and Atheists Seek Equal Opportunity in Little Rock
keywords: ['Atheism', 'Hinduism', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Religion and Belief', 'Religion-State Relations', 'State Legislatures', 'Supreme Courts (State)', 'Veganism']
abstract: Now that the Arkansas state government has approved a Ten Commandments monument at the Capitol, proposals for other monuments are flowing in.
lead_paragraph: What atheists, vegans, Hindus and Satanic cultists have in common lately is an eye for the statehouse grounds of Arkansas. The groups have separately proposed public displays of their own spiritual values in Little Rock now that the state government has approved a Ten Commandments memorial for the Capitol grounds.

lead_paragraph: The esteemed baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky, who canceled all his performances this summer to receive treatment for a brain tumor, plans to return to the stage this month for three performances of Verdi’s “Il Trovatore” at the Metropolitan Opera, the company said Wednesday.

headline: Review: Pianist Soheil Nasseri Puts a New Touch on Classical Standards
abstract: Mr. Nasseri’s knack for turning ordinary ingredients into enlightening programs was on display at a recital at Merkin Concert Hall.
lead_paragraph: Soheil Nasseri, a pianist known for his unorthodox programming choices, performed a recital made up of early-19th-century standards on Tuesday at Merkin Concert Hall. The lineup included such chestnuts as Schubert’s Sonata in G (D. 894), a Chopin Ballade and Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony.

headline: A New Video From an André Saraiva-Approved Musical Duo

The pair — who grew up in downtown Manhattan and attended PS 3 on Hudson Street — would toy with guitar riffs and songwriting in their free time together, recording the results on their phones and playing small local venues or friends’ art shows.

lead_paragraph: It’s September, but you still have a few days to savor summer. Lisa Perry is having a giant sale at her summer pop-up in SoHo through Sunday with deals of up to 80 percent off on space age bits like a suede lunar dress ($461, originally $1,595). Everything must go so Ms. Perry can transform the space for her spring fashion show on Sept. 9. At 154 Prince Street.

headline: The National Music Museum, an Unlikely Eden in South Dakota
abstract: Despite obstacles of geography and money, this university museum has amassed an astonishing world-class collection.
lead_paragraph: As you walk toward the cello believed to be the oldest in the world, the nearly 500-year-old instrument has its back turned to you. But the discourtesy grows forgivable on approach: The Amati “King” cello’s rear side is its most seductive feature, with richly colored paintings — crowns, winged putti, columns, fleurs-de-lis, Justice hoisting a sword — that take on glowing depth beneath the varnish.

headline: Nikki Haley Says Black Lives Matter Movement Is Endangering Black Lives
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Indian-Americans', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']

lead_paragraph: Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina, who won accolades for swiftly moving to remove the Confederate flag from the grounds of the state capitol after the June massacre of nine black churchgoers, sharply criticized the Black Lives Matter movement on Wednesday.

lead_paragraph: Two of the biggest names in cabaret — Michael Feinstein and 54 Below — are joining forces. The Midtown Manhattan supper club, nicknamed “Broadway’s living room,” in the basement of the former disco Studio 54, will be renamed Feinstein’s/54 Below. And Mr. Feinstein, the singer and pianist known as the ambassador of the Great American Songbook, will play his first engagement there, Dec. 20-30. Thereafter, he will appear twice annually.

Trump from mounting an independent campaign for president, the Republican National Committee on Wednesday asked each of the party’s presidential candidates to sign a statement vowing not to run as a third-party candidate.

headline: Review: ‘Thunderbitch’ Features Brittany Howard of Alabama Shakes
abstract: This side project finds Ms. Howard in typically volcanic form, in deep devotion to rootsy rock ’n’ roll.
lead_paragraph: “I’m a wild child!” Brittany Howard shouts on the debut album by Thunderbitch, and she leaves no doubt about it. Thunderbitch is where Ms. Howard, who leads Alabama Shakes, gets to blow off steam playing rock ’n’ roll, whooping and hollering with no pressure to innovate or make big statements. It has self-explanatory song titles like “I Just Wanna Rock n Roll,” “Leather Jacket” and “Eastside Party,” and the music reaches back to Chuck Berry and the Rolling Stones, charged with late-1960s adrenaline. It’s a joy to hear.

headline: Fast Feet Take the Day (or Night)

headline: ‘Time Out of Mind’ and ‘Shelter’: Next in Line at Cinema’s Soup Kitchen
abstract: Two new features are just the latest to examine issues of poverty, a time-honored theme in movies.
lead_paragraph: It’s a curious fact that one of the most popular characters in motion-picture history is homeless: Charlie Chaplin’s Little Tramp. Although Chaplin’s creation took on a life of his own, he set the tone for the complex interplay between art and authenticity in the depiction of homelessness. In the decades since, the portrayals have been a decidedly mixed bag (or bindle).

headline: ‘Seventeen’ and ‘Cooley High’: No Easy A’s, but Powerful Lessons
abstract: Michael Schultz’s “Cooley High” (1975) and Joel DeMott and Jeff Kreines’s documentary “Seventeen” (1982) look at young Midwestern lives in the city and the suburbs.
lead_paragraph: “Life is nothing but high school,” Kurt Vonnegut once told an interviewer. “Class officers, cheerleaders and all.” To which, Joel DeMott and Jeff Kreines, the makers of the once-banned, now-classic made-for-TV documentary “Seventeen” (1982), out on DVD from Icarus Films, might add: substance abuse, racial tension, problematic romantic relationships and issues with authority.

headline: Fall’s Geek Chic Look
abstract: A quirky mix of colors, prints and textures, pulled together in a way that makes perverse sense.
lead_paragraph: Call it geek chic, “Royal Tenenbaums” redux or Bedford Avenue granny (as Style.com did), this fall’s eccentric back-to-school look will soften the blow of summer coming to an end. The look, seen on the runways at Miu Miu and Gucci, among others, is a quirky mix of colors, prints and textures, pulled together in a way that somehow makes perverse sense. It’s a youthfully naïve approach to dressing that feels fresh and fun. Here, some options to mix and clash (and don’t forget the clunky specs).

lead_paragraph: Almost 15 years have passed since I warned about media “balance” that involved systematically abdicating the journalistic duty of informing readers about simple matters of fact. As I said way back when,

headline: Gaza: U.N. Issues Warning About Living Conditions
abstract: A United Nations agency has warned that Gaza may become uninhabitable by 2020 if current political and economic trends continue.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations agency has warned that Gaza may become uninhabitable by 2020 if current political and economic trends continue. The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development said in a statement released late Tuesday that eight years of effective bans on most exports, three major conflicts and tight restrictions on materials entering Gaza had “shattered its ability to export and produce for the domestic market, ravaged its already debilitated infrastructure, left no time for reconstruction and economic recovery, and accelerated the de-development” of the Gaza Strip. According to the agency, “Gaza’s 1.8 million inhabitants rely on coastal aquifers as their main source of freshwater, yet 95 percent of this water is not safe to drink.” Moreover, the unemployment rate exceeds 40 percent, and more than two-thirds of Gazans do not have reliable access to adequate supplies of food. A United Nations report in 2012 contained similar warnings, but it appears that widespread destruction caused by last summer’s conflict between Israel and Palestinian militants may have accelerated those trends. Israel and Egypt heavily restricted the movement of people and goods into Gaza after the militant Hamas group seized power of the territory in 2007.

headline: Police Officers and Other New York City Agencies Visit Homeless Encampments
keywords: ['Homeless Persons', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Group Homes and Supportive Housing']
abstract: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton discusses the measures the city has taken to address a rise in homelessness.
lead_paragraph: As police officers, mental health workers, lawyers and others visit homeless encampments in New York as part of a City Hall initiative, a prime mission will be determining how people wound up on the streets.

headline: A Vacation That Ended With the Legion of Honor

headline: California: Coal Dropped From Public Pension Funds
abstract: California lawmakers passed a bill on Wednesday that will force the state’s public employee pension funds to drop investments in coal.
lead_paragraph: California lawmakers passed a bill on Wednesday that will force the state’s public employee pension funds to drop investments in coal. The bill, passed by the Assembly on a vote of 43 to 27, will now go to the desk of Gov. Jerry Brown. The Senate president pro tempore, Kevin de León, the bill’s sponsor, noted that stocks in the battered coal industry were losing value and said they were “inconsistent with our values as a state on the forefront of efforts to address global climate change.” The two funds, known as CalPERS and CalSTRS, manage nearly $500 billion in assets. A spokeswoman for Mr. Brown, Deborah Hoffman, said the governor had until Oct. 11 to act. “Given the serious challenge of climate change,” she said, “this bill deserves careful consideration.”
