headline: Michigan: Backlog of Sex Assault Kits Almost Gone
abstract: Six years after more than 11,000 untested evidence kits from sexual assault investigations were discovered in a Detroit police warehouse, that backlog has been nearly eliminated.
lead_paragraph: Six years after more than 11,000 untested evidence kits from sexual assault investigations were discovered in a Detroit police warehouse, that backlog has been nearly eliminated, producing thousands of potential leads in criminal cases, Michigan officials said Wednesday. More than 10,000 of the kits have undergone testing for DNA and other evidence, an effort that has cost the state millions of dollars. So far, 21 convictions have resulted from the evidence. But officials warned that the work of investigating and prosecuting cases still had years to go and would cost millions more. At a news conference with Gov. Rick Snyder, state and local officials said the tests had produced 2,616 matches with DNA samples in the F.B.I.’s national database, with evidence of 477 serial rapists and links to crimes in 39 states and the District of Columbia. An investigation by Michigan State University researchers, funded by the Justice Department, pointed to a chronic lack of resources, rapid turnover in the department and a sense of triage in a high-crime city as contributing to sexual assault cases’ not being treated seriously enough.

headline: What’s On TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Fuse) ALMOST FAMOUS (2000) The director Cameron Crowe looks back on his career as a teenage music journalist in this coming-of-age story about his fictionalized alter ego, William Miller (Patrick Fugit), a 15-year-old from San Diego who makes a fairy-tale ascent from nerdy schoolboy to Rolling Stone reporter. Frances McDormand plays William’s protective mother, a college professor; Zooey Deschanel, his rebellious older sister; Philip Seymour Hoffman, the critic Lester Bangs; and Billy Crudup, Russell Hammond, the lead guitarist of the band Stillwater, to whom William is drawn. And Kate Hudson (above right with Mr. Fugit) is Penny Lane, the ringleader of a troupe of groupies who call themselves the Band-Aids. “We don’t have intercourse,” she says. “We inspire the music.” Mr. Crowe “may be the least cynical director working in Hollywood today,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Of course, rock ’n’ roll is not always about being nice.”

headline: Judges Standing Upside-Down
abstract: Conservative judges used to do what they could to keep the courthouse doors closed. Now they’re trying to pry them open.
lead_paragraph: Something funny is happening on the way to the courthouse — and I don’t mean county clerks refusing to issue licenses for same-sex marriages. For decades, judicial conservatism has been defined at least in part as strict observance of the elements that make a case justiciable in federal court: a live controversy and a plaintiff with a concrete problem — as opposed to a general grievance — that can be fixed by a favorable ruling. I first learned about the doctrine of standing back when progressive law professors wrung their hands over how flagrantly justices like William H. Rehnquist were invoking standing and other jurisdictional barriers in order to close courthouse doors to meritorious lawsuits.

headline: Timothy Snyder’s ‘Black Earth’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Timothy Snyder argues for a new interpretation of the Holocaust that looks at concerns over food and other resources.
lead_paragraph: More than 70 years after the Holocaust, there is no sign of research on it abating. Instead, over the past few decades, historians have been extending their inquiries. Investigators who once understood the wartime massacres as a unique historical episode that mainly concerned Germans and Jews and was driven principally by ideology have increasingly produced comparative studies of regions and states, turning their attention to other victims and to what Eastern European archives are able to tell us about the dynamics of persecution and mass murder; economic issues; and the motivations of perpetrators, bystanders, women, religious and political leaders, neutrals, rescuers and others. So voluminous is this scholarly outpouring that few are able to keep up with it, although some historians continue to grapple with the subject as a whole. Notwithstanding all this effort, Timothy Snyder, a Yale University specialist in Eastern Europe, contends in “Black Earth” that our understanding of the Holocaust has failed us. We have misunderstood its lessons.

headline: ‘The Hotel Years,’ by Joseph Roth
abstract: A selection of Joseph Roth’s journalism, produced between the wars in Europe’s hubs and outposts.
lead_paragraph: Reading the 64 essays by Joseph Roth anthologized in “The Hotel Years” — dazzling, elegiac, mordant and harrowingly oracular by turn — is like roaming through the Grand Budapest Hotel and discovering that it’s merged with the Overlook, the establishment from “The Shining.” There are so many fantastic scenes, indelible characters and exquisite lines to marvel at. Yet the cumulative vision is one of ­horror.

lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Another allegation of sexual abuse has been filed in the Central African Republic against a member of the French military force, the United Nations human rights chief, Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, said on Thursday, bringing new attention to a year-old scandal over abuse of children by peacekeepers.

headline: Touring 109 Bars in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula
abstract: What started out as a father-and-son bar crawl in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula turned out to have a lot more meaning.
lead_paragraph: There aren’t too many perfect days in Sault Ste. Marie.

headline: Is the Blue-Collar Shirt Still Blue Collar?
abstract: As the chambray shirt has evolved into a staple of casual style, its workingman’s identity has become a slippery social construct.
lead_paragraph: A work shirt is a dress shirt with a job to do. Accordingly, it is designed with buttonholes on its double pockets, stitched with an emphasis on strength and constructed from a sturdy material like khaki or covert or, most classically, a cotton called chambray. You can have a chambray shirt in any color you want, and if that color is blue, you also have a social construct and a rhetorical device: The shirt’s blue collar is a mass-­produced idea as durable and versatile as the garment itself. With blue-­collar identity now more a matter of cultural style than of occupational history, the term is perfectly slippery, such that the assertions that Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has ‘‘blue-­collar appeal’’ and an ‘‘anti-­union agenda’’ are not fundamentally incompatible. The phrase ‘‘blue collar’’ has flourished precisely because it is concrete in its imagery and vague in its connotations, vividly conjuring a labor-­class scene while sidestepping such a nasty word as ‘‘class.’’

headline: Alton Brown Has Had It With Foodies
abstract: The TV personality on the pornification of cuisine, cooking as an act of self-reliance and why loving food isn’t enough to make you a star.
lead_paragraph: Ten or so years ago, you said that food in this country was like what sex was in the ’70s: our last decadent act. Are we out of the ’70s yet? I think we’ve moved into the ’80s. The decadence is being replaced by a potentially appropriate austerity. The orgy of the unfamiliar and new has given way to something more focused and thoughtful.

headline: There’s More to Cremona Than Violins
abstract: The birthplace of Stradivarius is a must-visit for music lovers, but it’s also a perfect overnight side trip from Milan.
lead_paragraph: Cremona is a small, pretty, well-kept, bourgeois, mercantile city in the fertile Po Valley of Italy. There is no local wine region. There is no city university. There are no grandiose must-see sights. The chef Mario Batali once wrote that Cremona is “famous for its quiet, pious belief in commerce and order.”

headline: Michigan State: Fifth in the Nation, Yet Still Second Fiddle to Michigan
abstract: The Spartans have always felt unappreciated in the shadow of the Wolverines, but with four double-digit victory totals in five years, Michigan State seems to have reason to complain.
lead_paragraph: EAST LANSING, Mich. — After its come-from-behind win over Baylor in the Cotton Bowl in January, Michigan State’s football team, as tradition dictates, was presented with commemorative rings. The walnut-size mementos celebrated the 42-41 victory as well as the team’s 11-2 record. But one small section of each ring’s limited real estate displayed something else: the score of a blowout over a team that wound up 5-7.

headline: Why Fund-Raising Is Important, Even if You Are Trump
abstract: Money raised in political campaigns sends many signals. Here’s some advice on how to read them.
lead_paragraph: “I’m using my own money,” Donald Trump declared when he announced he was running for president. “I’m not using the lobbyists. I’m not using donors.” And of course, he added, “I’m really rich.”

headline: Otto Pérez Molina of Guatemala Is Jailed Hours After Resigning Presidency
abstract: The decision to detain Mr. Pérez Molina is unprecedented in Guatemalan history and was a stunning conclusion to a day of swift change in the nation.
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — Just hours after tendering his resignation as president of Guatemala, Otto Pérez Molina was sent to jail to await the conclusion of a hearing examining his role in a multimillion-dollar customs fraud case that has shaken the nation and sent reverberations throughout the region.

abstract: While President Obama celebrates the success of his strategy to secure enough votes to put the Iran nuclear agreement in place, the head of the Republican National Committee was seemingly engaging in some strategy of his own, calling for all 17 candidates to make a promise meant to ease concerns about one candidate’s intentions.

It was then, on live television, that President Xi Jinping stepped forward to announce that the Chinese military, on proud display to mark 70 years since the end of World War II, would lose more than a 10th of its personnel.

headline: The Swedish Museum That BabyBjörn Built
abstract: The cultural center Artipelag speaks to the founders’ deep ties to the area as well as their focus on the arts.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — Fourteen miles east of Sweden’s capital, amid the piney woods and rocky outcroppings of the Stockholm archipelago, an 8-by-11-foot photograph of the North Atlantic Ocean as viewed from space greets visitors to one of Scandinavia’s most ambitious new arts institutions. The picture, digitally constructed by the German photographer Andreas Gursky from multiple satellite images, suggests vastness, emptiness, power and fragility. It also reverses our customary perspective on the world, with an immense expanse of midnight-blue ocean occupying almost the entirety of the frame while familiar land masses — Newfoundland, Labrador, Greenland, Iceland, the coast of West Africa, the Caribbean islands — are relegated to a fringe around the edges. A similar desire to change our outlook animates the photography show this image introduces, as well as the space that’s hosting it.

headline: Highlights of China’s Victory Day Parade
abstract: China held a military parade featuring some 12,000 troops in Beijing on Thursday to commemorate 70 years since the end of World War II.
lead_paragraph: China held a military parade featuring some 12,000 troops in Beijing on Thursday to commemorate 70 years since the end of World War II.

headline: Inside the Mind of a Japanese Master Plant Stylist
abstract: Satoshi Kawamoto, who will set up shop inside Freemans Sporting Club’s Tokyo outpost this fall, shares his green thumb secrets.
lead_paragraph: You could say it’s growing season for Satoshi Kawamoto, the Japanese plant artist and creative director behind lush installations for brands like Filson, Gant Rugger and Mr Porter. In March, he relocated the New York outpost of his Green Fingers empire (five locations in Tokyo, two in Yokohama) from the East Village to a larger — but still modest — location on the Lower East Side. At a glance, the storefront reads like a plant nursery; but it’s also a boutique, and not just of botanicals. Unruly houseplants and tiny, prim succulents grow among clothes, accessories, lighting (some flea-market-sourced and some designed by Kawamoto himself) and Japanese-made housewares – all for sale. “People who are not interested in plants but who are interested in looking for plates, handbags or clothes — may end up buying plants,” he explains of the renewed interest in foliage as a home accent, among people who subscribe to a certain (Brooklynized) aesthetic. And on the flip side, “people who are looking for plants may end up buying some beautiful vintage clothes.”

headline: 1915: German Admiral Resigns
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The German Minister of Marine, Von Tirpitz, resigns for health reasons in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — According to a despatch from Amsterdam, Grand Admiral von Tirpitz, the German Minister of Marine, has handed in his resignation [Sept. 3] and will be succeeded by Admiral von Pohl. The Berlin report that Von Tirpitz is taking a prolonged holiday ‘‘for his health’’ is regarded in New York, says a cablegram to the ‘‘Daily Chronicle,’’ as an indication that there is a break in the relations of that illustrious sailor with the Kaiser. America is naturally elated over Germany’s ‘‘climb-down,’’ which is generally declared to be a triumph for the President’s diplomacy. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 4, 1915

headline: Twyla Tharp’s Troupe Prepares for a Milestone Tour
abstract: As Ms. Tharp works on the tour, which highlights two new works, she is aware that “the dancers are at the heart of the whole matter.”

headline: Lucas Hnath’s ‘The Christians’ Tackles a Schism Among the Flock
abstract: The playwright Lucas Hnath’s “The Christians,” coming to Playwrights Horizons, had its genesis in Mr. Hnath’s evangelical upbringing.
lead_paragraph: Lucas Hnath grew up in an evangelical church. His mother became a minister, and he thought he might do the same. Instead, he became a playwright, and now he’s written a knowing script about congregational tremors set off by a doctrinal dispute inside a megachurch.

headline: Texas Abortion Providers Ask Supreme Court to Reverse Ruling on Clinics
abstract: Should the Supreme Court agree to hear the case, it could issue its first major abortion ruling since 2007 before its next term ends in June.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Abortion providers in Texas asked the Supreme Court on Wednesday to reverse an appeals court ruling that would leave the state with 10 abortion clinics, down from more than 40. Should the court agree to hear the case, as appears likely, it could issue its first major abortion ruling since 2007 before its next term ends in June.

keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Human Trafficking', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Smuggling']
abstract: The case of a young boy’s doomed journey has landed as a political bombshell across the Middle East and Europe.

Instead, they showed up with a 15-foot rubber raft that flipped in high waves, dumping Mr. Kurdi, his wife and their two small sons into the sea.

headline: The Timeless Allure of the Art of Knots
abstract: One elegiac tome — researched, written and illustrated entirely by one man — has left an impact on Jody Rosen.
lead_paragraph: Last year, I wrote an article for T about, of all things, knots. To report the piece, I traveled to the Museum of Knots and Sailors’ Ropework in Ipswich, England. I also spent hours leafing though ‘‘The Ashley Book of Knots,’’ a doorstop reference work published in 1944. A year later, I’m still reading it. It’s an unusual thing: a how-to guide that’s also an eccentric literary classic.

That figure, unequaled in baseball history, is so striking that it underscores everything about the Los Angeles Dodgers. Yet to focus too much on it is to miss the beauty of the pursuit. Nothing is preordained.

headline: 1965: Russia Won’t Trade Exhibitions
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Russia refuses to trade exhibitions with the U.S. in 1965.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia has called off a planned exchange of exhibitions with the United States, apparently because of tension over Vietnam, U.S. officials said today [Sept. 3]. They said the Soviet Union had asked for an American hand-tools exhibition and a Soviet space-achievement display to be ‘‘suspended under present circumstances.’’ American officials disclosed yesterday that Russia had withdrawn an invitation for the American musical ‘‘Hello Dolly’’ to stage a five-week run here in October. The cancellations are seen by the Americans as first direct results of a tougher public posture by Russia over Vietnam. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 4, 1965

headline: Numbering of Migrants by Czechs Brings Outcry

headline: This Was to Be the Year of Bigger Wage Gains. It’s Not.
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Inflation (Economics)']
abstract: Shadow workers, people who are sort of but not really in the labor force, may be holding wage growth back.
lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate is low by any historical standard at 5.1 percent. Businesses are complaining of worker shortages in industries like health care, construction and trucking. Household-name companies like Walmart and McDonald’s have announced increases to their pay for low-wage workers.

headline: A Song Inspired by a Bizarre Love Triangle
abstract: Unknown Mortal Orchestra’s “Can’t Keep Checking My Phone” was influenced by frontman Ruban Nielson’s unorthodox romance.
lead_paragraph: The initial concept for the psych-rock trio Unknown Mortal Orchestra’s third full-length album, “Multi-Love,” began with the title. “When I first wrote down the term ‘multi-love,’ I didn’t really know what it meant or why it resonated with me,” frontman Ruban Nielson explains. “But the meaning of it became more complex as the year went on.” Nielson set out to make a “happy record” — a seemingly painless undertaking. But when an unlikely friendship blossomed with a young woman on the road, it evolved into a love triangle between Nielson, his wife and “Woman X” — and complications set in.

headline: Legion of Tech Volunteers Lead a Charge for Bernie Sanders
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media']
abstract: A group of software developers and designers, product managers and more have used their prowess to create apps and other tools to help the candidate.
lead_paragraph: Dawn crept into Daniela Perdomo’s Brooklyn apartment, her bleary eyes still focused on her bright computer screen. The founder of a nearly three-year-old communications start-up, she had been up all night again, orchestrating the work of more than 100 other developers, web designers, researchers and writers.

headline: 1991 Suspension of Reggie Langhorne Plays Into Tom Brady Decision
abstract: Bill Belichick was a rookie head coach when he disciplined receiver Reggie Langhorne for not hustling. When the penalty was reduced, it established a precedent invoked Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Reggie Langhorne, who retired from the N.F.L. more than 20 years ago, was on a golf course Thursday afternoon when he learned that he was making news in the league again.

headline: Chailly to Leave Leipzig Orchestra Early
abstract: Riccardo Chailly, the acclaimed music director of the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra, will step down from that position in June, several years ahead of schedule.
lead_paragraph: The recent game of musical chairs among the world’s top conductors is continuing: Riccardo Chailly plans to step down as music director of the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra in June, several years ahead of schedule, the orchestra announced on Thursday.

headline: Biden Again Expresses Uncertainty About 2016
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said he was unsure whether he had the “emotional energy” for a run, telling an audience, “I can’t look you straight in the eye and say now, ‘I know I can do it.’”
lead_paragraph: DAVIE, Fla. — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Thursday night that he was unsure whether he and his family had the “emotional energy” for a presidential bid, telling an audience at an Atlanta synagogue that “I can’t look you straight in the eye and say now, ‘I know I can do it.’”

headline: Hakeem Jeffries for New York Mayor? Some Democrats Say Yes, but He Hesitates
abstract: Mr. Jeffries, a second-term congressman, has emerged as a powerful magnet for Mayor Bill de Blasio’s opponents and possibly, if Mr. Jeffries changes his mind, a genuine threat to his re-election.
lead_paragraph: The calls have come in a steady stream: from political donors, community leaders and members of the clergy, urging Representative Hakeem Jeffries to consider running against Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York.

headline: Problems With Supreme Court’s Ruling on Fees
abstract: A recent opinion suggests that the Supreme Court does not really understand the dynamics of large Chapter 11 cases.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a situation where a client refuses to pay a lawyer’s bill, claiming that the bill is too high or the quality of the work was poor. The normal rule is that the lawyer eats the cost of defending the bill, even if the lawyer eventually prevails against the client.

headline: In Paris, a Famed Department Store Goes ‘Brooklyn’
abstract: Le Bon Marché themes its fall installation around the borough, featuring Catbird jewelry, Mast Brothers chocolate and “le kale.”
lead_paragraph: They call it “Le Brook-leen,” and for the French, or Parisians at least, it is an exotic land far, far away. But there is something je ne sais quoi about Brooklyn that seduces the French — that intellectual approach to life and style, which, at its core, perhaps, is as français as Sartre and Beauvoir. So beginning this week, the Left Bank department store Le Bon Marché Rive Gauche will spotlight Brooklyn as its annual autumn cultural theme — a focus running throughout the store and its sister gourmet grocery, La Grande Epicerie. Items from more than 100 different Brooklyn purveyors will be for sale, including Catbird jewelry, Kinfolk men’s wear and Mast Brothers chocolates. The store’s commitment to the Brooklyn aesthetic is so complete as to border on caricature — they’ll even hawk Lynn & Lawrence woolen beanies and Ball mason jars (which happen to be made in Indiana).

headline: Father of Drowned Syrian Boys Speaks About Loss
abstract: Abdullah Kurdi, the father of Aylan, 3, and Galip, 5, who both drowned attempting to flee from Syria, tells the story of their harrowing journey and the moment he lost his family.
lead_paragraph: Abdullah Kurdi, the father of Aylan, 3, and Galip, 5, who both drowned attempting to flee from Syria, tells the story of their harrowing journey and the moment he lost his family.

abstract: Kim Davis of Rowan County rejected a proposal that would have allowed her deputies to grant same-sex marriage licenses. Had she consented, a federal judge would have considered releasing her from jail.
lead_paragraph: ASHLAND, Ky. — A Kentucky county clerk who has become a symbol of religious opposition to same-sex marriage  was jailed Thursday after defying a federal court order to issue licenses to gay couples.

headline: Analysis Confirms Plane Debris Came From Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: Investigators said a serial number inside the wing piece that was found in July corresponded with records of the company that supplied the part for the disappeared plane.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French prosecutors said on Thursday that further analysis of a piece of an airplane wing that washed up on a remote Indian Ocean island had allowed investigators here to determine “with certitude” that it came from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared in March 2014 with 239 people on board.

headline: In Britain, Top Artists Sell Affordable Work Straight From Their Cars
abstract: The 11th annual Art Car Boot Sale, which took place in the British town of Margate this weekend, may soon head to New York.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, the British artists Tracey Emin, Sir Peter Blake, Keith Coventry, Matt Collishaw, Polly Morgan and Jeremy Deller convened to raise money for charity. But it was a scene unlike any they tend to participate in: instead of the usual blue-chip auction, they took part in Vauxhall’s annual Art Car Boot Fair, selling special editions of their works from stalls and the trunks of their cars. “What makes this kind of event exceptional is that you are selling affordable art from different people at different points in their careers,” Emin told T as she took a brief break from selling her work, which included signed posters and limited editions of her drawings that ranged from £50-£500. “And that makes it accessible to the public.”

headline: Prosecutors to Seek Death Penalty for Dylann Roof in Charleston Shootings
abstract: Mr. Roof, 21, was charged with the racially motivated murders of nine people at a church in Charleston, S.C., on June 17.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — After what she described as intense and emotional discussions with family members and survivors, one of the state’s top prosecutors said Thursday that she would seek the death penalty for Dylann S. Roof, who is charged with committing racially motivated murder against nine members of a storied church here.

headline: A New Name and Height for Mount McKinley
abstract: The United States Geological Survey announced that the official height of Denali, the mountain formerly known as Mount McKinley, is now 20,310 feet.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the tallest mountain in North America not only was renamed, but also lost a bit of stature — 10 feet. The United States Geological Survey announced Wednesday that the official height of Denali, the Alaskan mountain formerly known as Mount McKinley, is 20,310 feet. Previously, it was listed at 20,320 feet.

headline: Study Reveals Consistent Predator-Prey Pattern
abstract: An analysis of animals from more than 1,500 locations worldwide found that the number of predators do not increase as rapidly as the number of prey does.
lead_paragraph: Predators may depend on prey for food, but an increase in the number of prey animals does not bring a proportional increase in the number of predators, a new study has found.

abstract: Letgo, which operates a smartphone-focused market for secondhand goods, has raised $100 million in financing.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The world of online marketplaces may already seem crowded with the likes of Amazon.com and the Alibaba Group.

headline: A West Village Space That’s Part Store, Part Light Installation
abstract: For the second New York location of FEIT, brothers Josh and Tull Price sought to design a store that reflects the message behind their brand.
lead_paragraph: When the brothers Tull and Josh Price set out to design the second New York store for their shoe brand, Feit, they had a goal in mind: to, as Tull puts it, “push the boundaries of what a retail space could look and feel like.” The result is just that: a stark, cleanly geometric space — that feels simultaneously industrial and natural — opening in the West Village this week.

headline: Slave Trade Video Game Developer Alters Scene After Outcry
abstract: Critics had condemned the game, Playing History: Slave Trade, on Twitter, saying that it trivialized slavery, specifically a level in which players were required to stack black slaves on top of one another.
lead_paragraph: After facing mounting criticism on social media, a Danish video game developer has excised a scene from an educational game that depicts the 18th-century slave trade.

headline: Witty Photos That Play With Centuries-Old Artistic Tradition
abstract: The photographer Thorsten Brinkmann creates portraits and still lifes that echo noble, aristocratic techniques — with an absurdist twist.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Thorsten Brinkmann’s portraits marry the traditional with the absurd: His subjects stand in regal poses, wearing thrift-store fabric scraps, plus vases or cloth-covered wastepaper baskets over their heads that render them genderless and ageless. Brinkmann often poses for the portraits himself; wearing a cape made of a pleated skirt or masking his face with a broken flower pot, he provides a witty take on the gestures of European aristocrats.

keywords: ['Beauty Salons', 'Nails (Body Part)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries']

keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Global Warming', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Organized Labor', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Weather', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']

headline: College Football Kickoff: A Primer on the Playoff System

Marc Tracy takes a quick look at what all the teams are playing for: a chance to be a part of the College Football Playoff at the end of the season.

headline: Migrant Children in Need Raise Questions at Home
abstract: Some parents worry about holding our children’s hands as we cross the street; others as they cross an ocean.
lead_paragraph: Summer vacation is almost officially over. By the Tuesday after Labor Day, even the last of the public schools will have started their calendars. The holdout preschools should finally start easing their young charges into classroom life by mid-September; soon, the ordinary ritual of family life — the constructing of the house of cards that is child care and car pool, the setting aside the work email for homework help, the parent-teacher conferences, the calls from the school nurse — should be in full swing.

headline: For Philippe Parreno, a Big Honor and an Even Bigger Year
abstract: The installation artist will be celebrated at Sculpture Center’s annual gala in November — and is currently pursuing projects all over the world.
lead_paragraph: The artist Philippe Parreno has never been to the Rainbow Room, where he’ll be honored this year at Sculpture Center’s annual gala on Nov. 4. In fact, it’s not even clear whether he’s heard of the landmarked Art Deco event space, which has at some point hosted almost every philanthropic endeavor in New York from its 65th floor vantage point — a world away from the nonprofit’s gritty Long Island City location. Parreno Googles the Rainbow Room and asks, laughing, “Can I come in a T-shirt, or do I have to get a tie?”

keywords: ['Endorsements', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Reality Television', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Trump’s pledge not to run as a third-party candidate has no legal significance, and it likely has no intellectual significance, either.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump made a big show today out of the latest in the series of meaningless gestures and self-promotional stunts that make up his political career. He signed a piece of paper saying that if he doesn’t win the Republican nominating contest, he will endorse the winner and will not mount a third-party run.

headline: Chef Michael White Closes Summer by Opening Vaucluse

keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The principle of Pashtunwali, a code of conduct that stresses fairness and gives guest privileges even to enemies, is being lost after decades of war.

A few days ago he and a friend shot 13 of them to death, mostly while they slept, he and the police said.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Is the coming “Suffragette” a political movie? At first glance, it looks period and foreign, the story of Britain’s early feminist movement, with Carey Mulligan in the lead role. On second glance, it could resonate in a presidential contest that finds a woman within reaching distance of the presidency. Maybe?

headline: No Judge of Character
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Waiters and Waitresses', 'Discrimination', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Internships']
abstract: Plus: when you don’t want to hear a server’s specials; a wedding riles a family’s emotions; and an intern impresses supervisors but not co-workers.
lead_paragraph: I was in a deli, and a man may have cut in front of me in line. When asked if he had, I said: “I don’t argue over such things. He can go ahead.” The man replied: “You don’t argue over such things? That’s why you’re fat.” I said, “You’ll end up in a courtroom.” He replied: “Good! I’m a lawyer.” I said, “Well, I am a judge.” The conversation devolved until he accused me of racism. Apparently, he was Hispanic; I hadn’t noticed. But when did it become O.K. to pick on someone’s physical imperfections but not sexual orientation or race?

lead_paragraph: Senator Cory A. Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, endorsed President Obama’s nuclear agreement with Iran on Thursday, padding support for the accord, which already has enough votes in the Senate to thwart a Republican-backed resolution of disapproval.

headline: Fighting the Tank Car Invasion
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Explosions (Accidental)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Railroads', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Tankers of combustible crude oil have overtaken railways in recent years, but one community is pushing back.
lead_paragraph: It seemed to happen overnight for people living along the commercial rail lines from North Dakota to New York and beyond.  Instead of sleepy Amtrak passenger trains or a string of relatively harmless boxcars, the railways have been overtaken in the last year or so by thousands of matte black tank cars. These bullet-shaped tankers are mostly filled with Bakken crude oil, a combustible substance that has been responsible for numerous explosions and 47 deaths in recent years.

headline: Review: ‘Dragon Blade’ Features Jackie Chan, Romans and a Lot of Mayhem
abstract: This eyeball-popping extravaganza features Jackie Chan, John Cusack, Adrien Brody and lots of horse-riding extras.
lead_paragraph: All fighting, all grimacing — though sometimes all smiling, weeping and singing — “Dragon Blade” is the kind of nutsy maximalist entertainment that isn’t content merely to tap a handful of influences. Instead, it stuffs an entire encyclopedia of dicey ideas (visual, narrative, political) into a blender to create a wacky, eyeball-popping and -glazing extravaganza that suggests a Cecil B. DeMille Bible epic, a Chinese military parade and a Busby Berkeley musical, at times all at once. And while it can be tough to find the human pulse amid the spectacle noise, Jackie Chan, John Cusack, Adrien Brody and a trillion horse-riding extras are also part of the very big picture.

headline: Review: Capturing Frida Kahlo Through a Series of Portraits
abstract: “Mirror, Mirror,” at Throckmorton Fine Art, includes 40 images of Kahlo taken by more than a dozen photographers.
lead_paragraph: FRIDA KAHLO

headline: Review: In ‘La Jaula de Oro,’ Riding the Rails to Reach New Lives
abstract: Diego Quemada-Diez’s film follows three Guatemalan teenagers as they make their way through Mexico to the United States border.
lead_paragraph: In the opening moments of “La Jaula de Oro,” three impoverished Guatemalan teenagers prepare to make the perilous journey north in hopes of slipping across the United States border into the land of opportunity. There, one boy exclaims wishfully, “everything is much better.” In a ramshackle public lavatory, Sara (Karen Martínez), the lone girl of the three, chops off her hair, tapes her breasts, and dons a T-shirt and baseball cap to pose as a boy named Osvaldo.

headline: Outside Courthouse, Kim Davis Is Seen as a Villain and a Hero
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Supporters of same-sex marriage chanted “love wins,” while supporters of Kim Davis worried about religious freedom.
lead_paragraph: Outside a federal courthouse in Ashland, Ky., on Thursday, dozens of people gathered in two cacophonous groups to debate what both sides felt was history in the making, but for different reasons.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, Sept. 6 to 13, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Hedge Funds Faced a Test in August, and Faltered
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Mutual Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Hedge funds aim to reap high returns while countering volatility in stocks, but during the global turmoil in August, many just extended their history of underperformance.
lead_paragraph: A surge in volatility. Plunging global stock markets. A surprise Chinese currency devaluation.

headline: ‘Sesame Street’ When It Started
abstract: As “Sesame Street” heads to HBO, a look at the debut of this pioneering children’s show on PBS; a “working men’s parade” in 1882.
lead_paragraph: 46 YEARS AGO

headline: Review: At Bargemusic, a Surprise Competition With Live Bluegrass
abstract: Musicians performing contemporary works at the Fulton Ferry Landing found it a challenge to hold their own.
lead_paragraph: An element of surprise is built into any performance during Bargemusic’s Here and Now Labor Day festival. This four-day celebration of contemporary music takes a catholic approach to styles and instrumentation, and with virtually every work a New York or world premiere, there’s no telling what you’ll hear.

headline: Review: ‘Donald Blumberg Photographs,’ Observing America on the Streets and From the Sofa
abstract: Mr. Blumberg began his career shooting on the streets of New York, but by the late 1960s he was preferring to shoot the television in his living room.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — There’s real life, and there’s media; there are the spaces outside we inhabit together, and there is the screen we gaze at alone. Yet the photographs of Donald Blumberg, subject of a large retrospective at the Yale University Art Gallery here, make the distinction between reality and image feel overdrawn. Mr. Blumberg began his career shooting on the streets of New York, but by the late 1960s he had turned his lens away from real spaces, preferring to shoot the television in his living room. As the nearly 200 images here attest, the gap between one and the other is smaller than you’d think. Outside or inside, photographing or rephotographing, Mr. Blumberg observes an America in transition and in crisis, via a medium whose assumed veracity he never stopped questioning.

abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Sept. 6 to 13, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: Charenée Wade Performs Gil Scott-Heron Works
abstract: Ms. Wade, a jazz singer, drew from her album of Scott-Heron covers for her concert at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola.
lead_paragraph: The defining act of alchemy on “Offering: The Music of Gil Scott-Heron and Brian Jackson” (Motéma), a persuasive new album by the jazz singer Charenée Wade, is her version of “Song of the Wind.” In its original incarnation, released in 1977, the tune has a funk-reggae lilt and an obbligato of tropical birdsong, played on a synthesizer. Ms. Wade sings it with a graver air, slow and brooding and serious.

headline: Pérez Art Museum Miami Names Franklin Sirmans as New Director
abstract: Mr. Sirmans is currently the department head and curator of contemporary art at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Aspen has a growing reputation among South Florida’s art world heavies as the perfect spot to escape the summer’s ceaseless humidity — call it a Rocky Mountain answer to the Hamptons. Turns out it’s also a good place to pick a new museum director.

headline: China Shows Off Its Military
abstract: China staged a military parade in Beijing on the 70th anniversary of Japan’s defeat in World War II.
lead_paragraph: China staged a military parade in Beijing on the 70th anniversary of Japan’s defeat in World War II.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Sept. 6 to 13, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Dirty Weekend,’ Neil LaBute’s Tale of an Unexpected Layover
abstract: Matthew Broderick and Alice Eve play colleagues stranded in Albuquerque who try to piece together what happened the last time one of them was there.
lead_paragraph: The comedy of sexual identity “Dirty Weekend” might not be the kind of thing you’d expect to see from the director and playwright Neil LaBute. Despite a reputation for slashing at the jugular, Mr. LaBute has done the equivalent of rolling over and letting his belly be rubbed with this tale of an especially eventful layover in Albuquerque.

headline: In ‘A Sinner in Mecca,’ a Gay Director Ponders His Sexuality and Islamic Faith
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: In this documentary, Parvez Sharma considers the contradiction with his religion while on a pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: There is no doubting the courage and conviction of the New York documentarian Parvez Sharma. In “A Jihad for Love,” from 2008, he interviewed devout gay Muslims worldwide. In “A Sinner in Mecca,” Mr. Sharma, who is also gay and Muslim, takes viewers on his 2011 hajj, or pilgrimage, to Islam’s most sacred sites. The journey is fraught with risks: In Saudi Arabia, being gay can mean execution, public lashings or imprisonment. And yet Mr. Sharma has created a swirling, fascinating travelogue and a stirring celebration of devotion.

headline: ‘Treasures and Talismans,’ at the Cloisters, Puts Rings on a Pedestal
abstract: This exhibition, from a private collector’s trove, focuses primarily on rings as jewelry and as a field of study.
lead_paragraph: Why do people wear rings on their fingers? For personal adornment, of course, but as often as not because of the social meanings they bear and communicate. Perhaps the world’s oldest form of jewelry, rings symbolize love, betrothal and marriage. They represent the wearer’s status, group affiliation and ancestry. They express religious, superstitious and moral beliefs. They may be trophies, memorials and, as in the case of the signet ring, a device for sealing and authenticating letters and documents.

headline: Migrant Smuggling in Europe Is Now Worth ‘Billions’
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Human Trafficking', 'Smuggling', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: As thousands pour out of Afghanistan and the Middle East, the business of smuggling them into the European Union has grown larger than the illicit trade in drugs and weapons.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — With thousands of migrants pouring out of Afghanistan and the Middle East, the business of smuggling them across the Balkans into the European Union has grown even larger than the illicit trade in drugs and weapons, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Previewing New Jersey’s Fall Theater Schedule
abstract: The New Jersey fall theater schedule includes new works by the critically acclaimed playwrights Joe DiPietro, Jennifer Haley and Ken Ludwig.
lead_paragraph: Social media cannot be blamed entirely for the world’s obsessive fascination with the latest thing.

headline: Becoming a Vampire, or Almost Anything Else, in Live Action Role Playing
abstract: Live-action role play is coming to Westchester County, with enthusiastic LARPers playing children of the night and other characters in defined but unscripted settings.
lead_paragraph: In late July, nearly 60 men and women from around the country pitched their tents in the campground at Croton Point Park in Croton-on-Hudson. They had come to inhabit the World of Darkness as players in the game “Vampire: The Masquerade.” From Friday till Sunday, they enacted their individual roles as members of a complex society of vampires — and participants in a LARP.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: In ‘Bedroom Farce,’ Love and Other Jokes
abstract: A production of an early Alan Ayckbourn comedy at the Westport Country Playhouse delivers big laughs and a few insights.
lead_paragraph: Once you’ve heard Freddie Mercury’s voice belting out Queen’s “Crazy Little Thing Called Love” a few times in the Westport Country Playhouse, you’ll have caught the splendid sense of glee that the theater is selling with its production of Alan Ayckbourn’s “Bedroom Farce.”

headline: Review: ‘Saturday Night Fever: The Musical’ at Gateway Is Old but New
abstract: The adaptation of “Saturday Night Fever: The Musical” in Bellport hews to the popular 1977 film but adds three more songs.
lead_paragraph: The stage version of “Saturday Night Fever” now at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport is not the same adaptation that opened on Broadway in 1999. Ben Brantley called that earlier musical based on the hit 1977 film “dreary,” and most other critics agreed. Nevertheless, it ran for 501 performances.

headline: BB-8 Droid Offers Hint of Coming Crush of ‘Star Wars’ Toys
abstract: The BB-8, a small, round robot that rolls along at the touch of a smartphone, is one of hundreds of toys related to the next “Star Wars” film.
lead_paragraph: One of the first toys to emerge from a tightly held cache of merchandise tied to the next “Star Wars” movie is already the target of a viral crush online: It’s the BB-8 droid, a small, round robot that rolls along the floor at the touch of a smartphone.

headline: Gerry Hayden, Who Took Farm-to-Table Dining to Long Island, Dies at 50
abstract: Mr. Hayden worked at noted Manhattan restaurants before promoting New American cuisine at his and his wife’s North Fork Table and Inn in Southold.
lead_paragraph: Gerry Hayden, a chef who brought a refined style of farm-to-table dining to the East End of Long Island with his restaurant the North Fork Table and Inn, died on Wednesday at his home in Southold, N.Y. He was 50.

headline: Bounding Across Space and Time, via DVD
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)']
abstract: When you miss the dance, there are these DVDs.
lead_paragraph: Alastair Macaulay

headline: The Top Tennis Player in the World Started Here
abstract: Long before he found his way to the top of the sport, where did Novak Djokovic learn to swing a racket? We visit the childhood courts of some of the world’s tennis greats.
lead_paragraph: Long before he found his way to the top of the sport, where did Novak Djokovic learn to swing a racket? We visit the childhood courts of some of the world’s tennis greats.

headline: Lining Up (Early) for Boutique Pastries in Connecticut
abstract: The owners of three bakeries have found their niches by catering to different kinds of sweets lovers.
lead_paragraph: At 7:49 on a recent Sunday morning, six people had already lined up in the sweltering heat outside Hen & Heifer, a small pastry shop near the Guilford Town Green. The doors would not open until 8 a.m.

headline: Review: Finca Offers Tapas, Though Not Strictly From Spain
abstract: Finca, with an executive chef from Argentina, holds to the theme of small plates while diverging from traditional dishes.
lead_paragraph: Finca, in downtown Ridgewood, is a prime example of how the Spanish tapas trend has inspired small plates at restaurants not exclusively dedicated to the cuisine of Spain. The choices here feature more general Mediterranean — and some Latin-American — influences.

headline: Sotheby’s to Auction A. Alfred Taubman’s $500 Million Trove
abstract: Mr. Taubman, who died in April, once owned the auction house that will now sell off his estate. It could break records.
lead_paragraph: The chairman’s art collection is coming to Sotheby’s.

headline: Review: Momi Ramen in East Hampton Defies Expectations
abstract: Hot soup in hot weather is a combination drawing crowds in a beach community.
lead_paragraph: If you were to make a list of the things you were least likely to want to eat after a day at the beach, a big steaming bowl of ramen noodles would probably be near the top. Anita Chen, owner and manager of Momi Ramen in East Hampton, however, would beg to differ. After several members of Ms. Chen’s family opened the original Momi Ramen in downtown Miami in 2012 to much acclaim, she said, she was inspired to try her luck in another coastal community. Judging by the crowds this summer at the new branch, which opened in June, Ms. Chen’s counterintuitive thinking has paid off.

headline: A Review of Appétit Bistro in Port Chester, N.Y.
abstract: Appétit Bistro in Port Chester has a menu that can throw one off at first, but it soon returns to its Francophile roots.
lead_paragraph: At the north end of Willett Avenue in Port Chester, Appétit Bistro shares a strip mall with the Nail Palace, the Super Primo Grocery and an Irish pub known for its karaoke night. From arm’s length, the name and the setting do little to set a diner’s heart aflutter, but close up, the sparkling plate-glass facade and two exuberant coleus plants (along with a flurry of five-star reviews on Yelp) raise an expectation or two.

headline: 2015 U.S. Open: As Favorites Are Upended, Many Players Are Wobbly
abstract: In the longest women’s match in Open history, Johanna Konta overcame Garbiñe Muguruza, 7-6 (4), 6-7 (4), 6-2, and saunalike conditions took a toll on others.
lead_paragraph: As her second-round match against Garbiñe Muguruza on a sweat-soaked Thursday afternoon dragged on, Johanna Konta caught herself glancing at the courtside clock.

headline: The Eerie Mating Sound
abstract: A male Attwater’s prairie chicken emits its signature cry during the courtship process.
lead_paragraph: A male Attwater’s prairie chicken emits its signature cry during the courtship process.

headline: A Stained-Glass Artist Enjoys a Renaissance
abstract: Robert Pinart’s windows, which have appeared in places as prominent as the National Cathedral in Washington, are being tracked down by two Brooklyn historians.
lead_paragraph: Last month the stained-glass artist Robert Pinart revisited two windows he designed that had been installed in the 1980s at the New City Jewish Center in Rockland County, N.Y.

headline: ‘The Jemima Code’ Spotlights Forgotten Black Cooks
abstract: Toni Tipton-Martin’s new book unearths the role of African-Americans in America’s culinary history.
lead_paragraph: When the food writer Toni Tipton-Martin lectures about her private collection of recipe books by African-Americans, she said, the back stories have brought audiences to tears. They reveal the lives of maltreated slaves who served meals with European and African culinary roots to plantation owners, and they expose 20th-century white chefs who won acclaim for recipes developed by black colleagues, whom they never properly credited.

headline: Christie’s Puts Chinese Pedestals on the Auction Block
abstract: More than 100 display stands, made mostly in the 18th and 19th centuries, are being sold by an unnamed consignor.
lead_paragraph: An unnamed consignor to a Christie’s sale in New York on Sept. 17 had stocked his home with empty pedestals.

headline: Scenes From Judge Diment’s Courtroom
abstract: In Bowdon, Ga., Richard A. Diment, a municipal court judge, told traffic violators that they had to immediately pay down fines in his courtroom, or go to jail.
lead_paragraph: In Bowdon, Ga., Richard A. Diment, a municipal court judge, told traffic violators that they had to immediately pay down fines in his courtroom, or go to jail.

headline: Times Square Topless Woman Is Arrested; 2 Others Are Assaulted, Police Say
abstract: A seminude painted woman and her boyfriend were arrested on drug and prostitution charges, while a businessman was accused of attacking two other women.
lead_paragraph: A topless woman, painted on her torso and soliciting tips for photographs in Times Square, was arrested Wednesday night by undercover officers along with her boyfriend on drug and prostitution charges. Two other topless women with painted torsos were attacked by a visitor from North Carolina who accused them of robbing him, the police said.

headline: Legal Questions Aside, Much Remains Unanswered in the Tom Brady Case
abstract: Thursday was a good day for the Patriots, but the overturning of Brady’s suspension did not deal with the issues of sportsmanship and what Brady knew.
lead_paragraph: In hitting Roger Goodell with a blow that shakes his already wobbly legacy, Judge Richard M. Berman summarized pent-up criticism of the N.F.L. commissioner when he said Goodell had administered “his own brand of industrial justice” to a player he felt had crossed a line.

headline: A Glass for Enjoying a Sip of Whisky While Floating in Space
abstract: Ballantine’s, the Scotch distiller, is unveiling a glass that works for drinking in zero-gravity, no straw required.
lead_paragraph: When space tourism finally takes off and the rich and famous head off for a holiday in orbit as easily as on the Riviera, they may want to sip something stronger than Tang as they gaze down at Earth.

headline: Review: Different Thinking About Steve Jobs, the Man Behind Apple
abstract: Alex Gibney’s new documentary, subtitled “The Man in the Machine,” is a merciless anatomy of a complicated public character.
lead_paragraph: The transformative impact Steve Jobs has had on culture and society has become an article of faith since his much-mourned death in 2011. The secular canonization of Mr. Jobs, the mastermind behind Apple, is the starting point for “Steve Jobs: The Man in the Machine,” Alex Gibney’s trenchant new documentary, which asks with sincere curiosity: What’s the fuss about? And more to the point: What’s wrong with this picture?

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Time Out of Mind’

headline: ‘Time Out of Mind’ (With Movie Trailer): Oren Moverman Narrates a Scene
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from his film featuring Richard Gere.
lead_paragraph: He’s played a gigolo, an officer, a lawyer and many other roles over the years. But for the first time in his career, Richard Gere is playing a homeless man. He stars as a down-on-his-luck character in “Time Out of Mind,” from the director Oren Moverman. In this scene, the character is panhandling on the streets of New York.

headline: Review: ‘Transmissions’ at MoMA Explores an Era When Art Upended Tradition
abstract: The exhibition includes about 300 pieces that chronicle the changes in art and attitudes in Eastern Europe and Latin America between 1960 and 1980.
lead_paragraph: A visit to “Transmissions: Art in Eastern Europe and Latin America, 1960-1980,” a big, spirited group show that opens on Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art, is like walking into a party of extremely personable strangers conversing on subjects you can’t quite make out. For every name you recognize, there are 10 you don’t. Multiple languages — Czech, Romanian, Slovak, Spanish, Portuguese, as well as English — fill the air. As for topics discussed, art, poetry, film and theater seem to be getting about equal time.

headline: Donald Trump Stumbles and Bristles During Foreign Policy Interview
abstract: Donald J. Trump revealed gaps in his mastery of international affairs during a radio interview on Thursday, appearing to mistake the Quds Force, an Iranian military group, for the Kurds, a Middle Eastern people, and growing testy over questions about foreign leaders.

headline: ‘Opus Hypnagogia’
abstract: Art that is born of the state between sleep and wakefulness at the Morbid Anatomy Museum, Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: Art that is born of the state between sleep and wakefulness at the Morbid Anatomy Museum, Brooklyn

headline: Review: The Morbid Anatomy Museum Presents a View From the Subconscious
abstract: “Opus Hypnagogia” spans centuries and styles to home in on works inspired by the moments when the sleeping mind and the waking one intersect.
lead_paragraph: Hypnagogia is an unfamiliar word for a common mental experience. Coined in the 19th century, it refers to the transition period between wakefulness and sleep, when, while still conscious, you might find yourself seeing images, having thoughts or hearing things that make little logical sense. This is the gateway to lucid dreaming and, possibly, astral traveling and divine revelation.

headline: Sensational Murder Case in India Stirs Media Frenzy Fed by Police Leaks
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The case of Indrani Mukerjea, accused in her daughter’s death, has become the latest to draw attention in a hyper-competitive unrestrained reporting environment.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In the middle of last week, with the arrest of the former media executive Indrani Mukerjea on suspicion of involvement in her daughter’s death, India’s crime reporters embarked on their latest bender.

headline: To Pledge or Not to Pledge?
abstract: On Thursday, Donald Trump signed a pledge to support the eventual Republican presidential nominee, weeks after saying he wouldn’t. Not everyone agreed with his change of heart.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Donald Trump signed a pledge to support the eventual Republican presidential nominee, weeks after saying he wouldn’t. Not everyone agreed with his change of heart.

headline: Drawing a Bead
abstract: Sue Grafton’s “X” is packed with eccentric characters who fall for the conversational wiles of the private eye Kinsey Millhone.
lead_paragraph: Sue Grafton ignored her own rule when she chose an abbreviated title for the 24th of her popular “alphabet” mysteries. Unlike the other books in this series, which began in 1982 with “A Is for Alibi,” X (Putnam, $28.95) is the big cheese that stands alone. Having made that radical change to her reliable formula, perhaps she’ll make an even bolder move and just keep writing when she ­reaches the end of the alphabet.

headline: Facebook Takes a Step Into Education Software
abstract: A small team at the social media giant is developing the educational software, which is being used in about 30 schools but has much broader ambitions.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook, which transformed communication with its social networking service, now wants to make a similar impact on education.

headline: Candidates Respond to Kim Davis Case With Varying Intensity
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The story of Ms. Davis, the Kentucky county clerk ordered to jail for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, continued to divide the Republican presidential field.
lead_paragraph: The fast-developing story of Kim Davis, the Kentucky county clerk ordered to jail on Thursday for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, continued to divide the Republican presidential field.

headline: In Syria’s Struggle, Memories of the Soviet Union
abstract: Sergey Ponomarev’s trips to Syria reminded him of his native Soviet Union: from the government security forces that kept track of his movements to destroyed areas that looked like the Battle of Stalingrad.

headline: Palestinian Expects Flag Will Fly at U.N.

lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The Palestinian ambassador to the United Nations said Thursday that he expected to raise the Palestinian flag at the gates of United Nations headquarters in time for the annual meeting of world leaders here at the end of the month.

headline: The Truth of ‘Black Lives Matter’
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Discrimination', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Efforts to portray the movement as inflammatory or anti-white ignore the long history of racism and violence against blacks in America.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party and its acolytes in the news media are trying to demonize the protest movement that has sprung up in response to the all-too-common police killings of unarmed African-Americans across the country. The intent of the campaign — evident in comments by politicians like Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky — is to cast the phrase “Black Lives Matter” as an inflammatory or even hateful anti-white expression that has no legitimate place in a civil rights campaign.

headline: One Worker Dies and 2 Are Injured in Wall Collapse at Brooklyn Construction Site
abstract: The wall fell at 656 Myrtle Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said, burying the three workers beneath a pile of cinder blocks.
lead_paragraph: One worker was killed and two others were seriously injured when a wall collapsed on them at a construction site in Brooklyn on Thursday, officials said.

headline: Endre A. Balazs, Doctor Who Found a Lubricant for Arthritic Knees, Dies at 95
abstract: Dr. Balazs transformed a syrupy natural substance from rooster combs into a palliative for arthritis and a skin protectant that made eye surgery routine.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Endre A. Balazs, who transformed a syrupy natural lubricant derived from rooster combs into a palliative for arthritic knees and a skin protectant that made eye surgery routine, died on Aug. 29 at a hospital near his summer home in St. Tropez, France. He was 95.

headline: The Hague: Warlord Offers a Defense
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The Congolese militia leader Bosco Ntaganda, whose trial on war crimes charges opened on Wednesday told his judges on Thursday that “I am not a criminal.”
lead_paragraph: The Congolese militia leader Bosco Ntaganda, whose trial on war crimes charges opened on Wednesday at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, told his judges on Thursday that “I am not a criminal” but a “trained officer” who always protected civilians. Mr. Ntaganda was allowed to address the court briefly after teams of prosecution and defense lawyers had each delivered their opening presentations on the charges he faces related to attacks in 2002 and 2003 in which villagers in Ituri, a Congolese mining area, were killed or raped. Mr. Ntaganda, 41, who was born in Rwanda, said he had joined the Tutsi forces in Rwanda that put an end to that country’s genocide in 1994, then later moved across the border to Ituri. “The word had gone out to kill all the Tutsis in Ituri, or those who looked like them,” he said. His role was to protect civilians, he said in court. “I ask you to make a distinction between a revolutionary rebel and a criminal.” Earlier, the prosecutor had called him a “notorious and powerful” fighter who enriched himself and used children as his foot soldiers and henchmen and as sexual slaves for his troops. The trial will resume on Sept. 15.

headline: Philip Falcone, Former Head of Vast Fund, Tries a 3rd Act
abstract: His latest effort, HC2 Holdings, faces hurdles because of his history with regulators, and his first comeback has had lackluster results, but he remains undeterred.
lead_paragraph: Philip A. Falcone, the brash hedge fund titan who once managed $26 billion before stumbling and running afoul of regulators, is pressing ahead on a new comeback effort, his second.

headline: 3 Corrections Deputies in California Charged With Murder in Death of Mentally Ill Inmate
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The quick arrests are a departure from the typically drawn-out process that enmesh law enforcement officials when members of their own are suspected of committing crimes.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — In a rare step, the sheriff of Santa Clara County on Thursday arrested and filed murder charges against three corrections deputies who work for her, after the discovery last week that a mentally ill inmate had bled to death in his cell as a result of a blunt force trauma, according to the local coroner’s office.

headline: Friendship Between Putin and Xi Becomes Strained as Economies Falter
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Relations', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: Slowdowns in Russia and China have put energy deals between the countries in question, affecting the once-vaunted relationship between the two leaders.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — They have met more than a dozen times and stood shoulder to shoulder during Thursday’s military parade here. But the once-vaunted relationship between the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, and Russia’s leader, Vladimir V. Putin, has come under strain as the economies of their countries have faltered.

lead_paragraph: How intimidating is it to stand on a court across from Serena Williams, one of the greatest tennis players in history?

headline: Guard for Donald Trump Hits Protester
abstract: In a tussle outside Trump Tower, a member of the Trump security team ripped away a protester’s sign and, after the protester grabbed him, struck him in the face.
lead_paragraph: In a tussle outside Trump Tower on Thursday, a member of Donald J. Trump’s security team responded to a protester, who had grabbed him from behind, by hitting him in the face.

headline: Liberia: Ebola-Free, for a Second Time
abstract: The World Health Organization declared Liberia free of Ebola for a second time on Thursday, several months after it was first thought to have halted the virus in May.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization declared Liberia free of Ebola for a second time on Thursday, several months after it was first thought to have halted the virus in May, only to experience a brief resurgence of cases that puzzled epidemiologists. “Today the World Health Organization declares Liberia free of Ebola virus transmission in the human population,” said Dr. Alex Gasasira, the organization’s representative in Liberia. But the Ministry of Health called for 90 days of “heightened surveillance” around the country to watch for any new cases. Dr. Gasasira applauded the government and Liberian communities for their quick response to the May outbreak, which left two people dead. The government has urged all Liberians to continue observing preventive measures like washing hands and is strengthening its monitoring efforts across the country, said Dr. Francis Ketteh, Liberia’s chief medical officer. More than 4,800 people have died in Liberia because of the Ebola crisis, according to the World Health Organization.

lead_paragraph: Long before he ordered a county clerk to jail on Thursday for refusing to issue same-sex marriage licenses, David L. Bunning first drew attention as a federal judge for a ruling on gay rights.

headline: A Back-to-School List With Cameras, Bulletproof Walls and More Deadbolts
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Building (Construction)']

lead_paragraph: In his Cold War childhood, Bill Ferguson and his schoolmates at St. Elizabeth’s in Ozone Park, Queens, drilled for air raids that never came. “You hid under the desk, or went to certain places in the building, laid down and covered your eyes,” he said.

lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw David C. Duncan Dekker (a name that is incredibly fun to say out loud, unless a tour of the New York Times building is passing by your desk, in which case it’s best not to do that, not that I would know), he was doing some mighty heavy lifting, construction-wise, in a pangrammatic Saturday puzzle from March of this year.

headline: At 41, Jason Gore Brings a Different Look, and Sensibility, to the FedEx Cup Playoffs
abstract: Gore’s lone win on the PGA Tour was 10 years ago. Late-season momentum has carried him to the FedEx playoffs.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — At the Plainfield Country Club in New Jersey, Jason Gore outdrove his playing competitor, Dustin Johnson, by 13 yards on the second hole, a 445-yard par 4. Gore, who is four inches shorter than Johnson and easily 50 pounds heavier, flexed his right biceps. Gore’s gesture last week during the third round of the Barclays, the first event of the FedEx Cup playoffs, elicited laughter from Johnson, who is built like a 6-foot-4 small forward to Gore’s 250-pound beer league shortstop.

lead_paragraph: In the eyes of his human companion, Shandor was a “playful puppy” and “Alpha Male of the household,” court papers said, known to all to protect his caretaker and be at ease among strangers.

lead_paragraph: ESTES PARK, Colo. — When a young Stephen King checked into the Stanley  Hotel here in 1974, he had a nightmare that inspired him to write “The Shining,” the novel that went on to become Stanley Kubrick’s 1980 cult classic film.

headline: Leon A. Gorman, Who Made L. L. Bean a Household Name, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Gorman, a grandson of L. L. Bean’s founder, led the company for 34 years and oversaw the beginning of its online operations.
lead_paragraph: Leon A. Gorman, who transformed L. L. Bean from his grandfather’s folksy store and catalog business into a billion-dollar global outdoor-gear retailer and made its signature rubber-soled hunting boot as synonymous with Maine as lobster, died on Thursday at his home in Yarmouth, Me. He was 80.

headline: Illinois: Chicago Mayor Weighs Major Property Tax Increase
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Property Taxes', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Chicagoans may face a significant tax increase next year as the city is required to start making larger payments to some of its underfunded pension funds.
lead_paragraph: Chicagoans may face a significant tax increase next year as the city, the nation’s third largest, is required to start making larger payments to some of its underfunded pension funds. Mayor Rahm Emanuel, who is expected to issue details of his budget plan for 2016 later this month, acknowledged to reporters on Thursday that he was weighing a property tax increase, which has long been expected here. “It’s going to be fair and progressive,” he said. The Chicago Sun-Times reported that the mayor was poised to raise property taxes by $500 million. He would need approval from Chicago’s City Council.

headline: Smokeless Tobacco Use Found Higher Among Student-Athletes
abstract: Very active high school athletes use smokeless tobacco products at higher rates than students who do not participate in sports, according to a report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
lead_paragraph: Very active high school athletes use chewing tobacco and other smokeless tobacco products at higher rates than students who do not participate in sports, but they smoke less, according to a report issued Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In 2013, about 6 percent of students who did not play sports used smokeless tobacco, compared with 12.5 percent of students on three or more sports teams. In contrast, 21 percent of students who did not play sports smoked cigarettes, compared with 15.8 percent of students on three sports teams.

headline: Jets Finally See Tebow Throw Touchdown Pass, but It’s for Eagles
abstract: Tim Tebow passed for 189 yards and a touchdown in a preseason finale.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Philadelphia Eagles are expected to put up a lot of points this season, so when their third-team offense scored against the Jets’ second-team defense just before halftime Thursday night, it should not have stunned many on either sideline.

headline: Egypt: American Soldiers Are Wounded
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Six international peacekeepers stationed in Egypt, including four American soldiers, were wounded by two improvised explosive devices on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Six international peacekeepers stationed in Egypt, including four American soldiers, were wounded by two improvised explosive devices on Thursday, according to the Defense Department. The peacekeepers were part of the Multinational Force and Observers, a mission stationed in Egypt’s restive Sinai Peninsula to support the 1979 peace treaty between Egypt and Israel. The six wounded soldiers were airlifted to a medical facility where they were being treated for injuries that were not life-threatening. “The safety and security of U.S. forces remains our top priority, and we are committed to taking necessary steps for their protection,” said Jeff Davis, a Navy captain who is the director of press operations for the Defense Department, which provided no further information on the soldiers’ injuries or what had happened.

headline: Aylan Kurdi’s Death Resonates in Canadian Election Campaign
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The Syrian boy, 3, drowned off Turkey after his family was unable to secure a Canadian visa.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — While the photograph of a 3-year-old Syrian boy’s body quickly focused the world’s attention on the migrant crisis in the Middle East and Africa, it has taken on a particular resonance in Canada with the discovery that the boy’s family had been unable to obtain immigration visas.

headline: Giants Game No Match for News Off the Field
abstract: The Giants and the Patriots wrapped up the preseason in a game overshadowed by the overturning of Tom Brady’s four-game suspension by a federal judge earlier Thursday.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The Giants and the New England Patriots completed regular-season preparations on Thursday night with a preseason finale at Gillette Stadium that was insignificant compared with off-field news.

headline: California Lawmaker Is Focus of House Ethics Panel Inquiry
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: The House Ethics Committee is investigating allegations that Representative Mike Honda of California, may have improperly used his office staff to help his re-election efforts over the last four years.
lead_paragraph: The House Ethics Committee is investigating allegations that Representative Mike Honda, Democrat of California, may have improperly used his government office staff to help his re-election efforts over the last four years, the committee confirmed Thursday, as it released a preliminary report on the inquiry. The initial review, conducted by the Office of Congressional Ethics, found that his staff appeared to have “researched a potential campaign opponent, prepared materials for the campaign, used information from the congressional office for campaign purposes and discussed campaign matters during official meetings,” in the lawmaker’s district office and at a staff retreat. Mr. Honda has denied that he formally broke the rules, but his aides have conceded that he could have done a better job separating political and government business. The Ethics Committee said it would continue to investigate the matter, but it put no deadline on its inquiry.

headline: Colorado: Pro-Marijuana Activists Pull Back on Ballot Measure
abstract: Activists campaigning to allow the drug to be used legally in nightclubs or bars said they were withdrawing a measure to put the issue before voters in November.
lead_paragraph: Pro-marijuana activists campaigning to allow the drug to be used legally in adults-only businesses like nightclubs or bars said on Thursday they were withdrawing a ballot measure that would have put the issue before voters in Denver in November. Activists said they were pulling the initiative because they believed they could reach a compromise with city  officials and business groups that would result in local legislation to allow some limited social use of marijuana in Denver. When Colorado voters in 2012 became the first in the nation, along with Washington State, to legalize marijuana for recreational use, they did so with a caveat: No public use. But advocates said the restrictions on public use were too strict and had prohibited marijuana everywhere except private homes and a handful of marijuana-friendly bed-and-breakfasts scattered around the state. The ballot proposal would have allowed people to eat edible marijuana or inhale vaporized forms of marijuana indoors, but would have relegated smoking to outdoor areas blocked from public view. Organizers said that it was still too early to know what might be included in a compromise ordinance, and that if the effort stalled, they might reintroduce the ballot measure next year.

headline: Suspect and Witness Are Sought in Fatal Brooklyn Fight
abstract: The victim succumbed to his injuries more than a week after the altercation, which the police said was caught on video outside a Bushwick restaurant.
lead_paragraph: The two men stood outside the restaurant and bar in Bushwick, Brooklyn, last month, arguing. Then the disagreement escalated into a physical fight, leaving the police to find one of them on the sidewalk critically injured.

lead_paragraph: An unauthorized drone crashed into a section of empty seats at Louis Armstrong Stadium about 8:30 p.m. Thursday during a second-round match between Flavia Pennetta and Monica Niculescu, causing a brief delay and some fear and confusion.

headline: Dr. J. Donald Millar, 81, Dies; Led C.D.C. Mission That Helped Eradicate Smallpox

lead_paragraph: Dr. J. Donald Millar, a physician and former public-health official whose work helped eradicate smallpox in Africa and with it, the world, died on Sunday at his home in Murrayville, Ga. He was 81.
