lead_paragraph: A Coast Guard plane crashed in a field in northern New Jersey on Thursday afternoon, seriously injuring the pilot and co-pilot, officials said.

headline: A Defeat. Retirement. Then a Win. All in a Day.
abstract: Lisa Raymond assumed she had played the last match of her career after a defeat in women’s doubles, but moments later, she was summoned to play a mixed doubles match.
lead_paragraph: The last point of Lisa Raymond’s career seemed as if it might go on forever. The ball went back and forth over the net on Court 6, allowing Raymond numerous chances to hit a final forehand, a last backhand or a farewell volley.

keywords: ['Baseball', 'Social Media', 'Television', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Little League World Series']
abstract: ESPN suspended Schilling, one of its “Sunday Night Baseball” analysts, for the rest of the regular season and the postseason wild-card playoff game.
lead_paragraph: ESPN suspended Curt Schilling, one of its “Sunday Night Baseball” analysts, for the rest of the regular season and the postseason wild-card playoff game — extending punishment that had already been imposed for sharing a Twitter meme last month about extremist Muslims and Nazis. Schilling was suspended from one Little League World Series game and last Sunday’s prime-time Major League Baseball game.

headline: Lleyton Hewitt Exits Final Open Showing the Tenacity That Defined His Career
abstract: Hewitt, 34, looked as if he was going to close his career at the Open with a quick loss, but he fought back against Bernard Tomic, 22, and grinded to the end.
lead_paragraph: It looked at first like a pure mercy killing. In what he has called his final United States Open, in the last working year of the intimate setting known as the Grandstand, Lleyton Hewitt was absorbing a routine beating at the hands of Bernard Tomic, his 22-year-old countryman.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) AMERICAN MASTERS: ALTHEA Arthur Ashe may have been the first African-American man to win Wimbledon, in 1975. But Althea Gibson (1927-2003), above, broke the color barrier nearly two decades earlier, in 1957, becoming the first African-American woman to win that tournament as well as the United States Nationals (the precursor of the United States Open). This documentary from Rex Miller traces the life of Ms. Gibson, the daughter of a South Carolina sharecropper who as a young child moved with her family to Harlem, where she progressed from paddle tennis on the streets to tennis at the Cosmopolitan Club and on to Florida A&M with the help of the bandleader Buddy Walker, the boxer Sugar Ray Robinson and two African-American doctors, Hubert Eaton and Robert W. Johnson. In the 1950s, she emerged as the queen of a sport that was still highly segregated and went on to win 11 Grand Slam titles, including six in doubles. The Wimbledon champions Billie Jean King (an executive producer of the film) and Dick Savitt; Jeanne Moutoussamy-Ashe, Mr. Ashe’s widow; and Angela Buxton, Ms. Gibson’s doubles partner, among others, offer perspective.

headline: In Syria’s Struggle, Memories of the Soviet Union

headline: After Beijing’s Military Parade, Blue Skies Yield to Gray
abstract: An independent air quality monitoring site showed pollution levels rising sharply from midnight after the event.
lead_paragraph: Just hours after China’s Victory Day extravaganza on Thursday, when splendid blue skies framed a parade of thousands of troops marching through central Beijing to celebrate the end of World War II, the city’s air was filling again with dirt. An independent air-quality monitoring site showed pollution levels rising sharply from midnight.

headline: Cheeseburger, Hold the Salmonella
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Consumer Protection', 'Meat', 'Beef', 'E Coli (Bacteria)', 'Salmonella (Bacteria)', 'Cattle', 'Hamburgers', 'Factory Farming', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning']
abstract: The Department of Agriculture must further tighten standards on salmonella, and the industry should curb the use of antibiotics for cattle.
lead_paragraph: Americans eat more than 50 pounds of beef per person each year. That’s a lot of beef. It’s also a lot of risk, because about half — or more than two billion pounds — is ground beef, which can too easily harbor dangerous bacteria. There is always an uproar after serious outbreaks of illness like the Jack in the Box case in 1993, when 700 people were sickened and four children died after eating tainted hamburgers. But as a new report points out, there is more the Department of Agriculture and the Food and Drug Administration can do to keep Americans safe and some simple things consumers could do themselves.

headline: G.E., Finish the Job on the Hudson
abstract: The river is still in need of restoration, but the company is about to walk away.
lead_paragraph: Hudson River update, September 2015: The river is still contaminated and it’s still General Electric’s fault. Toxic industrial waste is still flowing down nearly 200 miles of river from north of Albany to New York City. And though the company has spent the last six years digging up the PCBs that it dumped into the river decades ago, it is about to walk away from an unfinished job. It is getting ready to dismantle its dredging operation this fall, and leave 136 undredged acres for others to worry about.

abstract: The investigation into the 2012 attacks has become an aimless exercise in partisanship.
lead_paragraph: Washington — NOT long after it was formed last year, members of the Select Committee on Benghazi gathered to meet privately with family members of the four Americans killed on that dreadful night in Libya in 2012. The meetings were emotional, and the chairman assured those present that the committee would be scrupulously nonpartisan and devoted to finding out the truth of what had happened.

headline: The New Romantics in the Computer Age
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Careers and Professions', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The tasks where humans will continue to stand out above technology are mostly soft and squishy relational stuff.
lead_paragraph: Just once I’d like to have a college student come up to me and say, “I really wanted to major in accounting, but my parents forced me to major in medieval art.” That probably won’t happen. It always seems to be the parents who are pushing their children in the “practical” or mercenary direction.

lead_paragraph: The message to the Crisis Text Line was answered by Aaron Amrich, a volunteer crisis counselor based in California. It was sent by a 19-year-old woman who wrote that she was feeling hopeless and beginning to give up on life. Amrich, a veteran who served in Afghanistan and Iraq, has himself suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder and depression. He understood the feeling.

headline: Online Gambling Firm Bwin.Party Favors GVC Holdings Bid
abstract: The company’s board of directors said it would now recommend shareholders approve a revised bid from GVC instead of an offer from 888 Holdings.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The battle for Bwin.Party Digital Entertainment took another turn on Friday as the online gambling company said its board of directors would now recommend that shareholders approve an offer from its rival GVC Holdings over a previously agreed-to deal with 888 Holdings.

headline: How the Co-op Crumbles
abstract: When developers try to convert small co-ops into condos, some shareholders are eager to sell. Others are very, very resistant.
lead_paragraph: For three decades, Todd Selbert has lived in a sunny one-bedroom on the Upper East Side, surrounded by books, his vast jazz record collection and several abstract oil paintings. A former advertising executive, Mr. Selbert, 75, owns the top floor of a four-story co-op at 150 East 78th Street.

headline: Exploring Havasu Falls
abstract: Havasu Falls are at the bottom of a narrow gorge near the southwest corner of the Grand Canyon National Park.
lead_paragraph: Havasu Falls are at the bottom of a narrow gorge near the southwest corner of the Grand Canyon National Park.

headline: Boise State Faces the Coach Who Helped It Grow
abstract: The Broncos have continued their winning ways and their blue-collar identity since Chris Petersen left to lead Washington, which lost to Boise State,16-13, in Friday night’s season opener.
lead_paragraph: BOISE, Idaho — The words “blue collar” are painted in large block letters along one wall of Boise State’s football weight room. This would seem to be a perfectly appropriate ethos for Boise State’s football program, given that its identity is so closely tied to blue — the color of the Broncos’ quirky playing surface.

headline: What We Learned From Summer Love
abstract: We know love blooms in New York City in the summer; after all, we live here. But as the Metro staff of The New York Times traveled the five boroughs for our Summer Love series, we got some surprises.
lead_paragraph: We know love blooms in New York City in the summer; after all, we live here. But as the Metro staff of The New York Times traveled the five boroughs for our Summer Love series, we got some surprises.

headline: Remarrying the Ex: Ilze Thielmann and Aitken Thompson Try Again
abstract: The couple married for the first time in 1995, split in 2003, became best friends, and now are newlyweds again.
lead_paragraph: During Aitken Thompson and Ilze Thielmann’s many years together, they have been through all kinds of relationship stages and permutations: platonic best friends; girlfriend and boyfriend; ex-girlfriend and ex-boyfriend sharing an apartment; husband and wife; divorced; friendly, sometimes flirtatious, co-parents; and exes who go on a date together.

headline: Within the Grand Canyon, the Lure of Havasu Falls
abstract: An idyllic place yields plenty of surprises, including a warm welcome by American Indian villagers and a restorative dip in a stunning natural pool.
lead_paragraph: One has only to lay eyes on a picture of the incandescent pools of Havasu Falls, somewhere between beryl and cerulean, to feel its pull. The vibrant basins of the rippling natural pool are a study in contrast with the stunning force of the waterfall that crashes into them, spilling 90 feet over red rocks. It is, simply, beatific. And the falls, at the bottom of a narrow gorge near the southwest corner of the Grand Canyon National Park, are about a two-mile hike north of Supai Village in one of the most remote indigenous-American enclaves in the country.

headline: Rihm to Replace Boulez as Lucerne Academy Director
abstract: Wolfgang Rihm will take over as artistic director of the Lucerne Festival Academy next summer, helping to train young musicians, composers and directors in music of the 20th and 21st centuries.
lead_paragraph: The German composer Wolfgang Rihm will succeed Pierre Boulez next summer as the artistic director of the Lucerne Festival Academy, which trains young musicians, composers and directors in music of the 20th and 21st centuries, the festival announced on Friday.

headline: Conducting a Field Test on Pheromones
abstract: The mystery of scents inspires a personal research trial.
lead_paragraph: In a room full of strangers, who are you drawn to? I enjoy rueful laughter, and thus, in any given setting, will gravitate toward a man who looks like Jeff Goldblum or a woman with a throaty Sambuca rasp.

headline: Learning to Live With Vitiligo
abstract: A man confronts his changing appearance after the onset of a skin disease.
lead_paragraph: Everyone has a sort of avatar, a mental image of an ideal self that sits in the corner of your consciousness, sneering or smiling, as you surf the day. You, walking the city streets. You, skulking out of the movies. You, riding the mechanical bull at Gilley’s.

headline: Billy Eichner, Off the Street and Into the Museum of Sex

lead_paragraph: “This is like a terrible ‘Sex and the City’ episode,” said the comedian Billy Eichner, standing in the lobby of the Museum of Sex on a recent afternoon while peering at pleasure devices both manual and electric, metal and plastic, large and small, contoured and classically cylindrical.

headline: Exodus of Syrians Highlights Political Failure of the West
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Little has been done in Western capitals to stop or mitigate the slow-motion disaster that was befalling Syrian civilians and sending them on the run.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Arresting images of desperation on the West’s doorstep have brought Syria, for the moment, back to worldwide attention: refugees cramming into train stations and climbing border fences; drowned Syrian toddlers washing up on beaches, a girl in polka dots, a boy in tiny shoes.

lead_paragraph: NICKELSDORF, Austria — Thousands of migrants who have been bottled up in Hungary, demanding passage to the West, will be allowed into Austria and Germany, the Austrian chancellor said late Friday. Early Saturday, the first buses carrying them arrived at the Hungary-Austria border.

headline: London Theater Journal: A Scorching Momma Rose
abstract: A review of Imelda Staunton in “Gypsy.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The small, determined woman who is sharing her obsessions so enthrallingly from the stage of the Savoy Theater here is unmistakably a product of the United States. She’s as American as apple pie — or perhaps the homemade blueberry kind she says she’s so tired of; as American as the Great Depression, marathon dancing and another desperate soul who took his country’s myth of success too much to heart, Willy Loman from “Death of a Salesman.”

headline: ‘The Moon’
abstract: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: This poem, translated from the original Spanish, unfolds as a litany of the many ways the moon has been described. One long, complex sentence links all the previous iterations, while a second, much shorter sentence isolates the image of yet another moon. The prose-poem form seems to contain the patch of night sky from which that new apprehension — the moon reflected in the vision of a solitary witness, the poem’s speaker — arrives.

headline: How to Fight Fires From a Plane
abstract: Learn to read the smoke signals. Prepare to spend months away from home.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Your job is to slow the fire down and buy time for the firefighters on the ground,’’ says John Gallaher, a pilot who travels the country dropping fire retardant from the air. Every morning, check out of your hotel, and be prepared to check into another one thousands of miles away at day’s end. Always keep your packed bags loaded in the plane.

headline: Today in Politics: Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton Have an Island All to Themselves
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Hillary Rodham Clinton find themselves in Puerto Rico on Friday at the same time. And Mr. Rubio is wasting little time previewing his idea of what the general election might look like.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning. Donald J. Trump had a big day on Thursday, but on Friday, other candidates, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Hillary Rodham Clinton, will find themselves in Puerto Rico at the same time. And Mr. Rubio is wasting little time previewing his idea of what the general election might look like.

headline: The Intruder
abstract: What was he doing there, on the second floor?
lead_paragraph: My friend Pierre recently bought a house in Popenguine, a small seaside town in Senegal. Determined to mold the house into more of his dream and less of its previous owner’s, he has gutted and remodeled its interior, broken up the pavement outside, replaced the wiring (after he was electrocuted in the shower) and even uprooted and transplanted full-grown trees.

abstract: Defense to Rest Its Case in Trial of Ex-Dewey & LeBoeuf Executives | A Third Act for Philip Falcone
lead_paragraph: MARKETS SLIDE AHEAD OF U.S. JOBS REPORT | Markets were cautious on Friday ahead of the latest United States labor market report, Reuters reports. Asian markets extended their losses on Friday morning, with the Nikkei 225 closing down 2.15 percent. Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday. European stocks were also down in early trading.

headline: How Economists Can Be Just as Irrational as the Rest of Us
abstract: A research group discovered that more people read working papers that were listed first in its weekly email. But it found a solution.
lead_paragraph: Retailers know that the items they place at eye level of store shelves will sell faster than those that are down low. The top headline on a news website will usually be clicked more often than the ones down lower. So maybe it shouldn’t be surprising that the same logic applies to economics research, with long-lasting implications for what ideas are propagated.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Fanny Packs
abstract: For too long, cultural baggage has prevented us from embracing the sheer practicality of these tidy, self-contained accessories.
lead_paragraph: My maternal grandmother, Helen, was a fashion icon of her own making. The daughter of a master tailor, she became an eager seamstress herself. Once, as a teenager, sneaking into her father’s sewing room to whip together a fancy dress, she was so overcome with enthusiasm that she ran a needle straight through her finger. In later years, she abandoned dresses for velour track suits, which made her look like an early-’80s M.C., except she covered hers with every single item in stock from Michaels Arts & Crafts — floral appliqué, rhinestones, puffy paint, embroidery, ribbons, sequins, confetti, ‘‘Proudest Grandma’’ patches. If she could have decorated her clothes with fresh fruit, I think she would have.

headline: The Fight to Save a Prairie Chicken
abstract: Despite a vigorous breeding program, the population of Attwater’s prairie chickens has dwindled. Conservationists say the species may not survive.
lead_paragraph: EAGLE LAKE, Tex. — Every spring during mating season, the few dozen remaining male Attwater’s prairie chickens gather to perform an elaborate courtship ritual.

headline: On Stockholm’s Islands, Chasing Insects and Literary Inspiration
abstract: A little red house by the sea is also home to the writer and entomologist Fredrik Sjoberg, who knows the island of Runmaro intimately.
lead_paragraph: I came to Runmaro to meet a peculiar entomologist with a gift for digression, and to try to understand the secret life of the Baltic island he has lived on for nearly 30 years — a place just one hour away from Stockholm but accessible only by boat, whose complicated natural and literary history is encoded in a landscape of deceptively simple beauty.

headline: Weeks After Tianjin Blasts, Many Residents Await Compensation for Damaged Homes
abstract: City officials said that more than half of affected households had settled their cases. But several residents said on social media and in interviews that they had been pressured to do so.
lead_paragraph: The chemical blasts that rocked the northeastern port city of Tianjin last month damaged an estimated 17,000 homes, shattering windows, overturning furniture and knocking down walls. But more than three weeks after the explosions, many Tianjin residents have yet to receive compensation for their losses, and some say they have been pressured into dropping their claims.

headline: Friends at Work? Not So Much
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Friendship', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Americans used to socialize more with their colleagues. Now, the office is more transactional.
lead_paragraph: ONCE, work was a major source of friendships. We took our families to company picnics and invited our colleagues over for dinner. Now, work is a more transactional place. We go to the office to be efficient, not to form bonds. We have plenty of productive conversations but fewer meaningful relationships.

headline: 1915: Maker of Tape Machine Dies
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The creator of tape machines dies in London in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In newspaper offices, in clubs and in large hotels, is kept a little wizard under a glass case, and it is called a tape machine. All night through it sings a metallic song about things that have happened at the ends of the earth — and in the street round the corner. To people without the mechanical faculty this machine is a perpetual wonder, for the wheels that seem to hesitate and change their mind about a letter appear to hide a divinity. But the only divinity is that of the operator at the central office, where all news is gathered and tapped out. The man who perfected this instrument, Mr. Frederick W.H. Higgins, has died at his house at Stamford Hill, London. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 5, 1915

But like his idol, Anton Chekhov, Williams was also a prolific producer of short fiction. His “Collected Stories” runs more than 500 pages and spans nearly half a century of work, from 1928 to 1977.

keywords: ['Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']

headline: Apple Kuchen for a Sweet Jewish New Year
abstract: More coffeecake than dessert, the simplest cake for Rosh Hashana uses a quickly made batter topped with sliced fruit, sprinkled with sugar and baked.
lead_paragraph: Aunt Edith was the best cook I knew when I was a boy. Everything that came from her kitchen was sensational. Dinner at her house was unlike other dining, better than most restaurants. The food was so intoxicatingly delicious, and so abundant, I always ate and ate like there was no tomorrow. And oh, my, could this lady bake.

abstract: A few ideas on where to hang out during the waning days of summer.

headline: Ann Beattie’s ‘The State We’re In’
abstract: The characters in Ann Beattie’s new stories, set largely in Maine, feel that their lives are wasted.
lead_paragraph: Ann Beattie’s first collection of new short stories in a decade is mostly set in the state I’m in. This means I read “The State We’re In: Maine Stories” with the kind of suspicious diligence one uses in scouring a dog for ticks: looking for regional missteps, out-of-tune phrasings, any sign she had committed the special literary felony of getting Maine wrong. That she had committed the kind of sins summer people — one of which Beattie, who divides her time between Key West and Maine, has long been — might be prone to commit. You know, throwing out the Cabot Cove “ayuhs” while the curtains at the cottage windows billow in the shore breeze and the colorful lobster buoys bob in the harbor.

headline: Inside the Walls
abstract: Danny Lyon’s “Conversations With the Dead” is a book of photographs taken inside six Texas prisons in the late 1960s.
lead_paragraph: “We should not be tolerating overcrowding in prison,” President Obama said in July. Against the backdrop of a growing national debate about incarceration rates in America, Phaidon is republishing Danny Lyon’s “Conversations With the Dead,” a book of photographs taken inside six Texas prisons in the late 1960s.

headline: ‘A Clue to the Exit,’ by Edward St. Aubyn
abstract: Three passengers discuss life’s meaning in a novel within Edward St. Aubyn’s novel about a dying screenwriter.
lead_paragraph: “Those of us who are dying,” Charlie Fairburn writes toward the end of this sparkling and morbid confession of a novel, “as opposed to those who are lounging around in their studies making dinner engagements, and then reluctantly disconnecting the phone for 20 minutes in order to browse through a medieval textbook and look up some realistic details — those of us who are really dying haven’t got time to ponder the past. The present is scintillating with horror and precision.”

headline: ‘The Wake,’ by Paul Kingsnorth
abstract: A novel about an Englishman undone by the Norman invasion is rendered in a devised Anglo-Saxon “shadow tongue.”
lead_paragraph: What happens after the end? Since the portrayals of world-destroying deluges in early writings (“Gilgamesh,” the Matsya Purana, Genesis, the “Timaeus”), narratives of apocalypse have structured our understanding of time and history. Religious eschatology looks to the end of days as a prelude to the absolute finality of the kingdom of God. Secularized as “the Singularity,” a similar idea drives the imagination of Silicon Valley entrepreneurs and cybernetic doomsayers, who believe we are approaching a technological punctum beyond which humanity as we know it will no longer exist. In the face of economic crisis and anxiety about climate change, postapocalyptic science fiction, long a genre staple, is undergoing one of its cyclical peaks of popularity. Our screens and pages are crowded with survivors, grimly coping with the aftermath of plagues, wars, natural disasters, zombie attacks and alien invasions.

headline: ‘The Making of Asian America,’ by Erika Lee
abstract: A historian broadens the focus on the experience of the very diverse Asian-American community.
lead_paragraph: Early in Erika lee’s sweeping “The Making of Asian America: A History” she suggests that Asian-Americans constantly cycle between being labeled “good Asians” versus “bad Asians,” depending on the shifting and often contradictory politics behind their immigration and settlement. We were a “despised ­minority” when Asian immigrants threatened 19th- and early-20th-century white labor, yet since the Cold War we’ve been described as a “model minority,” valorizing the promise of American meritocracy. The capricious ease with which those labels get swapped highlights how our precarious social position rests on our perceived utility: as cheap labor, as anti-­Communist soldiers, as overachievers meant to ­success-shame other communities of ­color. In doing all of this “work,” Lee argues, Asian-­Americans have redefined not only immigration politics and racial categories but also “the very essence of what it means to be ­American.”

headline: ‘Trigger Mortis: A James Bond Novel,’ by Anthony Horowitz
abstract: The ultimate spy returns to the 1950s, but he’s much more P.C.
lead_paragraph: James Bond is a synchronic spy. From the day that the first Bond thriller, “Casino Royale,” was published in 1953, all the way through to this year’s forthcoming “Spectre” movie, Bond has always been thoroughly modern, with all the latest toys. In “Trigger Mortis: A James Bond Novel,” however, Bond ventures somewhere Ian Fleming, or the movie producer Albert Broccoli, would never go: back, into the past.

headline: ‘You Too Can Have a Body Like Mine,’ by Alexandra Kleeman
abstract: Characters in this debut novel relate to media more than people.
lead_paragraph: Edgar Allan Poe’s unnamed narrator in “The Man of the Crowd” sits in a coffee shop referred to as “D,” looking toward the street and its never-ending stream of passing strangers. At nightfall, amid the multitude, he spots a man who absorbs his attention. He decides to pursue him, until at last the sun begins to rise again and the narrator realizes that he has been following nothing but a man of the crowd — a man, the reader suspects, who mirrors the narrator in his banal pursuit of others and in his incapacity for being alone.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Louise Penny, whose novel “The Nature of the Beast” is No. 3 on the hardcover fiction list, once said: “I know that if I’m not in the top five on the Times best-seller list, I’m going to feel like a failure.”
lead_paragraph: The 11th Coming: “The Nature of the Beast,” Louise Penny’s 11th novel about the Québécois detective Armand Gamache, hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 3. Penny started the series in 2005 after two decades as a CBC radio host, and its popularity caught her by surprise. “It’s difficult to learn from success. I’ve learned more from my mistakes,” she told the author and critic Joel Yanofsky in 2013. “Fortunately, I’m capable of manufacturing my own problems.” In her 20s and early 30s those included a battle with alcoholism, and later a five-year bout of writer’s block that was, according to Yanofsky, “mainly spent watching Oprah, eating gummy bears and lying to everyone, including her husband, about how well her writing was going.” Things have improved since then. “Now I know that if I’m not in the top five on the Times best-seller list, I’m going to feel like a failure,” she said in the same interview. No worries here! But that doesn’t mean Penny’s life is challenge-free: In the past few years she’s had to care for her husband as he slides into dementia. “I find now that the writing is a safe harbor,” she told The Vancouver Sun last month. “It’s a place I go to that is mine.” You have to wonder if Penny had her husband’s condition in mind when she quoted Yeats’s “The Second Coming” in the new book — that’s the poem about things falling apart and the center not holding, which concludes, “And what rough beast, its hour come round at last, / Slouches towards Bethlehem to be born?” Maybe. But mostly, Penny told The Sun, “the beast is ourselves.”

headline: Ask Well: What Diseases Can You Get from a Water Fountain?
abstract: Public drinking water fountains are less germy — and less risky — than most people might think.

headline: Donald Trump Golf Course Seeks to Ease Tax Bite With Lower Valuation
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s golf company is trying to reduce the property taxes it pays on the Trump National Golf Club, its 140-acre complex in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., by about 90 percent.
lead_paragraph: For Donald Trump, it is typically good business to be optimistic about the worth of his extensive portfolio of golf courses and real estate developments. But in one instance, the Republican presidential hopeful is apparently seeing benefits in minimizing the value of a property.

headline: Donald Trump’s Gomorrah Problem
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: New York City has long been a liability for Republican presidential candidates, though it is now a bastion of the conservative movement.
lead_paragraph: This past week, in an effort to make his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination seem less somnolent, Jeb Bush released an ad attacking Donald J. Trump. Using years-old footage of interviews with Mr. Trump, the ad intends to show us that the Republican presidential campaign’s current front-runner is an ideological phony — an espouser of liberal beliefs who has variously declared himself in favor of abortion rights, single-payer health care and more aggressively taxing the very rich. (This last position is one he hasn’t even tried to conceal, given that as recently as two weeks ago, he appeared on “Face the Nation” arguing that current tax policy left hedge funders “getting away with murder.”)

lead_paragraph: ODESSA, Ukraine — BEHIND a barred metal gate, the dilapidated two-story building’s dreary hallways led to worn but neat playrooms decorated with dour socialist realist art and a few “SpongeBob SquarePants” appliqués. Divided by age, groups of girls and boys up to 7 played in the heat, wearing only underpants.

headline: A Day After 71 Migrants Died, 81 Escaped the Back of a Truck in Austria
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Human Trafficking', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Asphyxiation, Choking, and Suffocation', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: A police official said migrants who pried open a truck door and escaped were apparently taken to Western Europe by the same smugglers as the migrants who died.
lead_paragraph: EISENSTADT, Austria — Smugglers whose callous negligence killed 71 refugees found in an abandoned truck last week at the side of an Austrian highway risked the death of scores more just a day later, the police said on Friday. But those migrants saved their lives by breaking open a truck door with a crowbar and were eventually abandoned near a traffic circle in eastern Austria.

keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity']

The analysis purports to show that white people are more likely than black people to be killed by the police.

Donoghue’s 2010 novel “Room” followed a mother and child who develop a loving and imaginative existence despite their punishing captivity. Here, the author reimagines a real-life unsolved murder from 1870s San Francisco. Blanche, a French prostitute, befriends Jenny, a cross-dressing vendor of frogs’ legs. After Jenny is murdered in the room they share, Blanche suspects that she herself was the intended target.

headline: Blue Claws: The Tasty Embodiment of Crabby
abstract: Adult male blue claw crabs (Jimmies) and females (Sallies until they mature, then sooks) are colorful, ill-tempered and delicious.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, an adult blue claw crab is a creature with claws and spines at every joint — with a few extras thrown in for good measure. It does not seem to have many good moods and is inclined to fits of anger, which it expresses like a cartoon Tasmanian devil: blood-crazed and claw-waving.

headline: How I Spent My Summer: With Bernstein and Stravinsky
abstract: A youthful encounter with Leonard Bernstein’s New York Philharmonic finally opened up “The Rite of Spring” for this music critic.
lead_paragraph: Given that Stravinsky’s “The Rite of Spring” has long been a staple of orchestra programs, it’s hard to convey how radical this 1913 shocker was still considered to be during the mid-1960s, when I was a high school student. The score was thought to be playable only by major orchestras equipped to grapple with its difficulties. In contrast, most conservatory ensembles today can perform it capably.

abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton denied that her campaign was harmed beyond repair by the email controversy and had some choice words for Donald J. Trump in a TV interview on Friday.
lead_paragraph: In the third sit-down national TV interview of her presidential campaign, Hillary Rodham Clinton said the candidacy of Donald J. Trump was a “bad development for our American political system,” rejected the implication that her campaign was irrevocably damaged by the email controversy and took a veiled jab at Senator Bernie Sanders, whose populist message has drawn big crowds and given him a lift in recent polls in Iowa and New Hampshire.

abstract: The state is caught up in a clash between oil and environmental interests, and the issues are so thorny that even Democratic leaders are on opposing sides.

headline: Giants Cut Weatherford, One of the Last of Their Super Bowl Winners
abstract: The Giants replaced Steve Weatherford with Brad Wing, whom they acquired in a trade with the Steelers.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants on Friday released punter Steve Weatherford, a popular player and one of the few remaining links in the locker room to the franchise’s last Super Bowl-winning team. Giants Coach Tom Coughlin had been sparse in his praise of Weatherford this preseason and frequently hinted that the team might be in the market for a new punter.

headline: Obama and Saudi King Sidestep Dispute Over Iran Nuclear Deal
abstract: At the beginning of their meetings at the White House, the two leaders stressed a long history of cooperation and friendship between their nations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and King Salman of Saudi Arabia moved to put their differences behind them on Friday in a long-delayed White House meeting amid months of tension over the nuclear agreement with Iran and a continuing schism over the way forward in Syria.

headline: A Lamp That Brings the Cosmos Indoors
abstract: Aptly called Helios, one new design would have looked at home in Galileo’s lab.
lead_paragraph: This lamp is called Helios and seems to conjure celestial bodies in motion. The sun is a naked bulb, burning bright or barely glowing, depending on how you deploy the dimmer or position the 12-inch hand-spun brass dish that serves as a planetary lampshade — angled in front, it creates a full eclipse. Designed by Robert Highsmith, a co-founder of the Brooklyn-based Workstead studio, known for a spare, industrial aesthetic warmed by luxurious materials (they did the interiors of the Wythe Hotel in Williamsburg), the lamp’s luminous components hover above a 4-inch cube base, available in three types of stone: pale Italian Carrara, deeply veined green Connemara and creamy gray travertine. Tethered yet flexible, it would have looked at home in Galileo’s lab.

headline: ‘Grandpa Woodstock’ Spreads Peace and Love on a Village Green
abstract: Allyn Richardson, known as Grandpa Woodstock, spends his days on the village green in Woodstock, N.Y., posing for photographs with tourists during the day and camping at night.

abstract: The two pleaded not guilty Friday to assaulting the inmate, Ambiorix Celedonio, who prosecutors said was attacked in a closet, away from video surveillance cameras.
lead_paragraph: A Rikers Island captain and a correction officer were charged on Friday with assaulting a teenage inmate in a storage room where there were no video surveillance cameras, and then filing false paperwork to conceal their actions.

headline: Piercing the Denial on Refugees
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: The heartbreaking images of a Syrian boy who drowned may finally provoke more European leaders to act.
lead_paragraph: Photographs of a lifeless little boy, dressed in a red shirt and dark shorts, lying face down on a beach, and then, minutes later, cradled in the arms of a police officer, have taken the world by storm. These heartbreaking images of 3-year-old Aylan Kurdi, who drowned when the rubber dinghy that was to carry him and his Syrian family to safety in Greece capsized off the coast of Turkey on Wednesday, have succeeded, finally, in bringing home the terrible human cost of Europe’s failure to deal with a surging refugee crisis.

headline: Obama Meets With Saudi King
abstract: The president and King Salman of Saudi Arabia met at the White House to discuss topics including the Iran nuclear deal and the conflict in Syria.
lead_paragraph: The president and King Salman of Saudi Arabia met at the White House to discuss topics including the Iran nuclear deal and the conflict in Syria.

headline: Ernest Logan’s Sunday Routine Goes From Church Back to School
abstract: For Mr. Logan, the head of the union of New York City school administrators, Sunday, like every other day, is “centered on prayer.”
lead_paragraph: While New York City’s principals, assistant principals and district supervisors rinse off the sand and sunblock to get their schools student-ready this week, the head of their union, Ernest A. Logan, is on call. A former Brooklyn principal, Mr. Logan, 64, has led the 6,500-member Council of School Supervisors and Administrators for the past 10 years. He lives in Brooklyn’s Crown Heights North Historic District with his wife, Beatrice Logan, 68, a retired guidance counselor. For them, Sunday is all about church, a daylong event filled with prayer, song and service. “I encounter a lot of crazy stuff on this job,” Mr. Logan said. “I have to stop and pause.”

headline: National Humanities Medal Winners Include Larry McMurtry and Alice Waters

headline: Food Choices Expand Near Grand Central
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Restaurants', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Plus: the Upper West Side adds baked goods; pies that aren’t round; Sugarfina comes to New York; and a food space below Columbus Circle.
lead_paragraph: A permanent new indoor food hall on Vanderbilt Avenue next to Grand Central Terminal is set to open Sept. 14. It’s from UrbanSpace, which runs outdoor pop-up markets of vendors (not just the food type) in London and New York. This time, it’s all food. Kiosks from about 20 producers line the perimeter, with some booths, including Red Hook Lobster Pound’s, in the center. There are communal tables. Whet your appetite for Roberta’s pizza, Toby’s Estate Coffee, La Palapa tacos and Amali Mou for wines by the glass: UrbanSpace Vanderbilt, 230 Vanderbilt Avenue (45th Street), 646-747-0822, urbanspacenyc.com.

headline: U.N. Official Urges Stronger Action by Peacekeepers in Central African Republic

lead_paragraph: GENEVA — United Nations peacekeepers should take tougher action against armed groups to restore stability to the crisis-torn Central African Republic, the United Nations human rights chief said Friday, but they need to be reinforced with more men and attack helicopters to fulfill their mission.

headline: The Narcissist in Chief
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Narcissism', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: What kinds of leaders do egotists make?
lead_paragraph: WITH the presidential campaign in full swing, a perennial question has resurfaced: How much weight should voters give to candidates’ personalities? The political rise of Donald J. Trump has drawn attention to one personality trait in particular: narcissism. Although narcissism does not lend itself to a precise definition, most psychologists agree that it comprises self-centeredness, boastfulness, feelings of entitlement and a need for admiration.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Quarterback’s Headache Solved!
abstract: The high school quarterback had the worst headache of his life. A number of New York Times readers solved the mystery.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 15-year-old boy with the worst headache of his life. I thought it was a fascinating case and apparently so did many of you. More than 120 readers offered some very thoughtful possibilities and nearly two dozen of you got it right.

headline: At Visa Pour l’Image Festival, Photojournalists at the Ramparts
keywords: ['Photography', 'News and News Media', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: At the Visa Pour l’Image festival, the World Press Photo prize intensifies an ethical debate.
lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — The prestigious World Press Photo contest caused an uproar in March and damaged its standing when it bestowed, then revoked, a top prize to an Italian photographer who had misrepresented the location of an image. Amid an intense debate about the line between photojournalism and art photography, many photojournalists were outraged that images in which the photographer, Giovanni Troilo, had intervened — by using a remote-control flash, for example — had been categorized as reportage.

abstract: Home break-ins are often perceived as lesser crimes, but a series of thefts in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, have shown how victims’ trauma can linger.

abstract: Films like “Everest” (climbing disaster), “Black Mass” (murderous gangsters), “Spotlight” (sex abuse) and “Beasts of No Nation” (child soldiers) had their premieres at the world’s oldest cinema festival.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — “The things of this world reveal their essential absurdity when they are put in the Venetian context.” So wrote Mary McCarthy in her charming, philosophical travel essay “Venice Observed.” It can be argued that the essential absurdity of movies is never really in doubt, but the Venice Film Festival — the oldest such event in this world — puts its own stamp on the marvelous, magical and perhaps fundamentally preposterous activities of making, displaying and watching movies.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Late Summer Scenes
abstract: Around Labor Day, the colors of the outdoor market at Union Square take on more autumnal hues.
lead_paragraph: Around Labor Day, the colors of the outdoor market at Union Square take on more autumnal hues. Shoppers’ light summer clothes were often replaced with black pieces. Also sighted: one of the artist Priscilla Snyder’s animal bags, made of thread. Cascades of hydrangeas surrounded houses along the Eastern Seaboard. Zinnias, dahlias and sunflowers added their vibrant colors.

headline: Treatment of Migrants Evokes Memories of Europe’s Darkest Hour
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Concentration Camps']
abstract: Jewish and human rights figures warn of historical amnesia as migrants are tricked into going to camps, marked with identification numbers and denounced as dangerous outsiders with a foreign religion.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — In Hungary, hundreds of migrants surrounded by armed police officers were tricked into boarding a train with promises of freedom, only to be taken to a “reception” camp. In the Czech Republic, the police hustled more than 200 migrants off a train and wrote identification numbers on their hands with indelible markers, stopping only when someone pointed out that this was more than a little like the tattoos the Nazis put on concentration camp inmates.

headline: New Orleans Mayor May Face House Arrest in Pay Dispute

keywords: ['Birds', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)', 'Glass']

For bird lovers, the appellation was apt since the building was a major site of bird fatalities, as the unwitting creatures smashed into the mirrorlike facade.

headline: Nepali Women in Queens Challenge Tradition, Taking Lead With Quake Aid

headline: Eugenie Bouchard’s Star Returns to Its Lofty Trajectory
abstract: With a 7-6 (9), 4-6, 6-3 victory over Dominika Cibulkova on Friday, Bouchard, seeded No. 25, advanced to the fourth round and served notice that she is coping with some of her recent struggles.

headline: The New Jersey Psychic With a Box of Swiss Gold
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Psychics and Psychic Phenomena', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: The contents of a safe deposit box led investigators to a New Jersey woman and a list of suspicious slip-and-fall incidents in New York and New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Detectives entered a Wells Fargo branch in Cliffside Park, N.J., in April with a search warrant authorizing them to open safe deposit box No. 679. The box’s contents led them to Manhattan’s diamond district, uptown to a frail woman’s apartment in Washington Heights, then back across the river, revealing a multilayered, multistate network of deception and crime.

headline: Kentucky Clerk’s Stance Tests County Where Opposing Views Are Welcomed

I tried explaining to him that being gay was innate and had nothing to do with wanting to subvert convention, but he refused to retract his label. Looking back, perhaps he was correct.

headline: Trades and the Tides of Time
abstract: Inevitably, there will be a day when our favorite players have to walk away from the game — or, bad enough, from the team we love.
lead_paragraph: As a kid, I was not a Dodgers fan by any stretch. In 1977 and 1978, Los Angeles knocked off my beloved Philadelphia Phillies in consecutive National League Championship Series. They went on to make a legend out of Reggie Jackson over two World Series while falling to the Yankees. But for me, there was no satisfaction in their defeat, because all I wanted was the Phillies to make it, to beat the Yankees and secure me bragging rights in the halls of Emerson Elementary School, in Teaneck, NJ.

headline: The Tao of a Corncob Pipe
abstract: Smoking a corncob pipe is the act of tending something that is of the land, tied to values, practices and a thought process worth preserving.
lead_paragraph: BUSHKILL, Pa. — EVEN now, when I conjure him and he deigns to come, I always see him the same way. He’s encircled in sweet blue smoke, standing on the cool stone of the walkway around midnight. A little man, ancient, almost swallowed by the vivid articles of clothing that his devoted daughter always bought for him. They were nothing like the slate-colored clothes my grandfather would have chosen for himself. But they covered him and kept him warm.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) WILD (2014) Reese Witherspoon, in an Oscar-nominated performance, portrays Cheryl Strayed, who copes with the aftermath of her heroin use, her marital infidelity and the death of her mother by hiking the Pacific Crest National Scenic Trail, spanning more than 1,000 miles, from the Southern California desert to the forests of Oregon. Her routine — walking, thinking, pitching her tent at night and packing it up in the morning — is punctuated by montages of memories and encounters in the wilderness, mostly with men. Some are scary; others are kind; but almost all are intrigued by the presence of a solitary woman so far from civilization. “ ‘Wild’ may be full of natural beauty — Yves Bélanger’s cinematography unostentatiously captures the infinite colors and vistas of the West — but it is also a celebration of the power of art,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about Jean-Marc Vallée’s adaptation of Ms. Strayed’s memoir, from a script by Nick Hornby. And the film has its shortcomings, he added, with too much montage in the middle and too much voice-over at the end, and maybe not quite enough detail about some of Cheryl’s relationships. “But you wouldn’t want a movie that celebrates imperfection, improvisation and the importance of mistakes to be slick or seamless. What makes its heroine worth caring about — what makes her a rare and exciting presence in contemporary American film — is not that she’s tidy or sensible or even especially nice. It’s that she’s free.”

headline: Seneca Art and Culture Center to Open in October
abstract: Built on the site of the original Seneca settlement, the center will offer changing exhibits conveying the story of the Seneca and Iroquois people.
lead_paragraph: Seneca Center The Seneca Art and Culture Center opens Oct. 24 at Ganondagan State Historic Site in Victor, N.Y., 20 miles southeast of Rochester. The center is built on the site of the original Seneca settlement, destroyed in 1687. The gallery will offer changing exhibitions conveying the story of the Seneca and Haudenosaunee (also known as Iroquois) people through centuries of artistic and historical artifacts and will also include work from contemporary Native American artists.

headline: The Architecture of Segregation
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Poverty', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Minorities', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The fight against the interlinked scourges of housing discrimination and racial segregation in America is far from finished.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years after the creation of the Department of Housing and Urban Development — and nearly that long after the passage of the Fair Housing Act of 1968 — the fight against the interlinked scourges of housing discrimination and racial segregation in America is far from finished. Economic isolation is actually growing worse across the country, as more and more minority families find themselves trapped in high-poverty neighborhoods without decent housing, schools or jobs, and with few avenues of escape.

headline: Rising to Your Level of Misery at Work
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Careers and Professions', 'Happiness', 'Research']
abstract: It’s common for people to move away from what they love and take on management jobs they dislike. There’s a solution, though.
lead_paragraph: EVERYONE has heard of the Peter Principle: Managers rise to the level of their incompetence. Today, however, a whole class of hyper-competent Americans will never find their level of incompetence. Instead, they will suffer a similar principle in which they rise to their level of misery.

headline: Foreign Journalists Under Fire
keywords: ['Editorials', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The recent spate of politicized cases against journalists warrants a much stronger international response.
lead_paragraph: A kangaroo court in Egypt recently sentenced three journalists from the Al Jazeera English network to three years in prison for committing journalism.

headline: Getting a Grip on Football
abstract: The game continues to be haunted by far more vital issues than “Deflategate.”
lead_paragraph: “Deflategate” always sounded so childish: Did the star quarterback know that air had been secretly leaked from footballs he was throwing to help him win a big game? There’s still no firm answer to that question after an exhaustive court fight. But here comes the National Football League season nevertheless, and there is the star quarterback, Tom Brady, free to throw footballs again for the New England Patriots, having prevailed last week against an attempt by the league commissioner, Roger Goodell, to suspend him for four games.

headline: Blessed Be My Freshly Slaughtered Dinner
keywords: ['Hunting and Trapping', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Meat', 'Empathy', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: The eat-what-you-kill movement is drawing new converts across the country.
lead_paragraph: COULD you look through a rifle’s scope into the long-lashed eyes of an elk and pull the trigger if it would be the only meat you ate for the year? Would your conscience be more or less troubled if instead you slit the necks of animals you planned to eat after they were nurtured like adored pets on an idyllic farm?

headline: The Refugee Crisis Isn’t a ‘European Problem’
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The United States, Canada and others must do more to help.
lead_paragraph: THOSE of us outside Europe are watching the unbelievable images of the Keleti train station in Budapest, the corpse of a toddler washed up on a Turkish beach, the desperate Syrian families chancing their lives on the night trip to the Greek islands — and we keep being told this is a European problem.

headline: The Internet of Way Too Many Things
keywords: ['Home Automation and Smart Homes', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Innovation', 'Smartphones']
abstract: You may be able to get your phone to project bright colors if your window sensor detects a burglar, but what is protecting you from your phone?
lead_paragraph: At a design conference recently, I was introduced to Leeo, a new product that I initially understood to be a reboot of something really in need of a redesign: the smoke detector. As the designer explained his process, I quickly came to understand that Leeo was nothing of the sort. It was a gadget, a night light that “listens” for your smoke detector to go off and then calls your smartphone to let you know your house might be on fire.

headline: Who Failed Aylan Kurdi?
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Each nation with some degree of responsibility for the Middle East situation must do what it can to ease the Syrian crisis.
lead_paragraph: THE image of a dead Syrian boy washed up on a Turkish beach has inspired a wave of Western soul-searching, with much talk about how “the world” failed 3-year-old Aylan Kurdi, who drowned along with his mother and brother while trying to escape their country’s civil war.

headline: The Myth of Quality Time
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Nothing nourishes intimacy and love like an investment of hours.
lead_paragraph: EVERY summer for many years now, my family has kept to our ritual. All 20 of us — my siblings, my dad, our better halves, my nieces and nephews — find a beach house big enough to fit the whole unruly clan. We journey to it from our different states and time zones. We tensely divvy up the bedrooms, trying to remember who fared poorly or well on the previous trip. And we fling ourselves at one another for seven days and seven nights.

headline: Awash in Data, Thirsting for Truth
abstract: Shoe-leather reporting and data journalism don’t have to be at odds in the search for truth.
lead_paragraph: Mark Twain complained about “lies, damned lies and statistics” more than a century ago. “Figures often beguile me,” he wrote, “particularly when I have the arranging of them myself.”

headline: A Doctor at His Daughter’s Hospital Bed
abstract: I was afraid she might die, so I broke into the cart and took over.
lead_paragraph: Omaha — I’VE been watching the monitor for hours. Natalie’s asleep now and I’m worried about her pulse. It’s edging above 140 beats per minute again and her blood oxygen saturation is becoming dangerously low. I’m convinced that she’s slipping into shock. She needs more fluids. I ring for the nurse.

headline: The Collateral Victims of Criminal Justice
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Families and Family Life', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Bail']
abstract: An arrest, whether or not a conviction follows, has long-term consequences for a defendant’s family.
lead_paragraph: SINCE the financial crisis, complaints that corporate wrongdoers suffer light penalties have become routine. One reason is the Department of Justice’s longstanding policy that prosecutors must consider the “collateral consequences” that pursuing a corporation might have on innocent employees, shareholders, pensioners and even the financial system at large.

headline: Australian Leader, Opposing Gay Marriage, Faces Party and Family Opposition
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Abbott has staked out an uncompromising stance against same-sex nuptials, pitting him against his sister, who is gay.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Even the prime minister’s sister is unhappy with him.

headline: Times Magazine Editor on ‘Creative Apocalypse’ Article
abstract: Jake Silverstein answers my questions about a magazine cover story that stirred many complaints.
lead_paragraph: Are creative artists thriving in the digital age? A recent magazine cover story makes the case that they are, and that a “creative apocalypse” never happened, despite fears and predictions that it would.

headline: Adult, Autistic and Ignored
abstract: There is virtually no substantive national discussion on the fate of older autistic people like my brother.
lead_paragraph: TWO months before she died of pancreatic cancer in November 2010, my normally strong, stoical mother broke down weeping in my arms over the fate of my autistic older brother.

headline: A.F.C. East Teams on a Quest to Dethrone the Patriots
abstract: The Patriots have won the A.F.C. East 12 of the past 14 seasons, but the Bills and Dolphins have made significant moves that could make the division one of the most competitive this year.
lead_paragraph: Before becoming the Miami Dolphins’ executive vice president for football operations, Mike Tannenbaum joined the organization as a consultant. He traveled to Europe to research how professional soccer teams use science to optimize performance, and now the Dolphins monitor sleep patterns, revitalize players with customized smoothies and employ a director of sports performance.

headline: With a Paddle, Tennis Stars Find They’re Up the Creek
abstract: When U.S. Open players matched up with table tennis professionals at a party in New York, they discovered that their racket skills took them only so far.
lead_paragraph: With his fluid, rhythmic strokes, it is clear that Sam Querrey has a knack for table tennis. But when he hits a backhand with two hands, as he does on the tennis court, it becomes obvious that it is not his sport of choice.

headline: Wealthy Gulf Nations Are Criticized for Tepid Response to Syrian Refugee Crisis
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The affluent nations reject the criticism, insisting they have given generously to humanitarian aid programs and provided work for fleeing Syrians.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Arab nations of the Persian Gulf have some the world’s highest per capita incomes. Their leaders speak passionately about the plight of Syrians, and their state-funded news media cover the Syrian civil war without cease.

headline: A King of Sliders Surmounts a Fall
abstract: J. R. Richard had a fleet but glorious career for the Astros, then illness and misfortune left him impoverished and sleeping under bridges. But he has recovered.
lead_paragraph: A recent player poll in Baseball America judged Chris Archer, the young ace of the Tampa Bay Rays, to have the best slider in the American League. Archer, a right-hander, has used the pitch to establish himself as an All-Star, and last month he fired a one-hit shutout with 11 strikeouts against the Houston Astros.

headline: Weary Migrants Show Relief as They Reach Austria Safely
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: New arrivals got donations from volunteers and shouted “Thank you!” as, against all odds, they reached a safe and desired stop.
lead_paragraph: NICKELSDORF, Austria — The safer they finally felt, the calmer the thousands of refugees who crossed into Austria from Hungary on Saturday became.

headline: A Spurt of No-Hitters May Not Be All That Exceptional
abstract: When Jake Arrieta of the Chicago Cubs threw a no-hitter last week, it was the sixth in 81 days and the 250th no-hitter of the modern era.
lead_paragraph: When Jake Arrieta of the Chicago Cubs threw a no-hitter last week, it was the sixth in 81 days and the 250th no-hitter of the modern era. The major league record for no-hitters in a single season is seven.

headline: U.S. Open 2015: Once Again, a Late Burst Propels a Spotlight Grabber
abstract: In front of an overflow crowd at the Grandstand, Donald Young absorbed the electricity from the fans and overcame a two-set deficit to beat Viktor Troicki, 4-6, 0-6, 7-6 (3), 6-2, 6-4.
lead_paragraph: Saturday’s matches at Arthur Ashe Stadium began around 11:10 a.m., about 10 hours after Rafael Nadal and Fabio Fognini departed it.

headline: Confederate Flags Crash Nascar’s Plan for a Homecoming
keywords: ['Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Automobile Racing', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Nascar Sprint Cup Series']
abstract: Nascar, so closely associated with its Southern roots, continues to struggle in trying to broaden its appeal nationally without alienating its base.
lead_paragraph: DARLINGTON, S.C. — Throwback paint schemes on racecars and retro logos and signs welcomed Nascar fans when they arrived at Darlington Raceway this weekend for the Bojangles’ Southern 500 Sprint Cup race. The marketing campaign was designed to make one of the most storied tracks on the circuit look like the early 1970s all over again.

headline: Nathan Eovaldi’s Shaky Inning Proves Too Damaging as Yanks’ Offense Stalls
abstract: The Yankees’ offense struggled and, unlike many of their recent games, they were unable to overwhelm their opponents with home runs.
lead_paragraph: Before his first pitch at Yankee Stadium on Saturday afternoon, starter Nathan Eovaldi scooped up a rosin bag and patted it against his arms, creating clouds of powder. He then vigorously dug in with his foot around the pitching rubber and kicked dirt in the air, ruining the layout of a mound that was perfectly manicured just moments earlier.

headline: Jets Cut 2 Quarterbacks, Leaving Rookie as Backup
abstract: The moves leave the rookie Bryce Petty as the Jets’ only healthy option behind Ryan Fitzpatrick for next week’s season opener against Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: The Jets released both of the veterans who had been vying for the backup quarterback job, for now leaving the rookie Bryce Petty as the only healthy option behind Ryan Fitzpatrick for next week’s season opener against Cleveland.

headline: The Pirates’ Winning Path Is Blocked by a Familiar Foe
abstract: The Pittsburgh Pirates have the second-best record in the National League, but they’re in the same division as the team with the best record, the perennially powerful St. Louis Cardinals.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Francisco Cervelli was raised by the Yankees, who traded him to the Pittsburgh Pirates last fall after parts of seven seasons in the majors. Cervelli reported to his new team in spring training, and it was as if nothing had changed.

lead_paragraph: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from Aug. 28 to Sept. 3.

abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in sports.

headline: Rhoda Lerman, Writer Who Defied Labels, Dies at 79
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Ms. Lerman was a difficult writer to categorize, but she had a feminist bent, a Jewish sensibility and a taste for ribaldry.
lead_paragraph: Rhoda Lerman, whose critically praised novels melded history with contemporaneity, mythology with social criticism, feminism with a Jewish sensibility and snark with seriousness, died on Aug. 30 at her home in Port Crane, N.Y., near Binghamton. She was 79.

headline: Hillary Clinton Urges Cooperation on Inquiry Into Her Emails, as She Finds Joy Elsewhere
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton said Saturday that everyone involved in the investigation into her email practices as secretary of state should cooperate and insisted that she was running her campaign with joy even as that controversy hounds her.
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — Hillary Rodham Clinton said Saturday that everyone involved in the investigation into her email practices as secretary of state should cooperate and insisted that she was running her campaign with joy even as questions persist around why she conducted government business on a private server.

headline: Ben Kuroki Dies at 98; Japanese-American Overcame Bias to Fight for U.S.
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Japanese-Americans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Mr. Kuroki, a decorated member of the Army Air Forces of World War II, was hailed on the American homeland at a time when tens of thousands of Japanese-Americans were confined to internment camps.
lead_paragraph: Ben Kuroki, a decorated Japanese-American gunner in the Army Air Forces of World War II, who was hailed on the American homeland at a time when tens of thousands of Japanese-Americans were confined to internment camps as supposed security risks, died on Tuesday in Camarillo, Calif. He was 98.

headline: On the Trail of a Mentally Ill Brother, Lost in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Homeless Persons', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Group Homes and Supportive Housing', 'Evictions']

lead_paragraph: Ever since they were children, Aukejshia Boyce-Gaskins made sure to look out for her younger half brother, Birshon Daley.

abstract: On Saturday, migrants in Vienna crowded onto trains headed for Munich.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, migrants in Vienna crowded onto trains headed for Munich.

headline: Pope Francis’ Visit to U.S. Is His First Ever, for Several Reasons
abstract: Unlike predecessors who traveled to the United States before rising to the papacy, Pope Francis has waited until age 78 to visit the country that thinks of itself as the center of everything.
lead_paragraph: During his first private meeting with Pope Francis in the Vatican two years ago, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan said, the pope took out an atlas with a map of the United States and asked Cardinal Dolan, the archbishop of New York, to point out the various regions and cities and talk about how they differed.

headline: Matt Harvey Weighs In (Gingerly) Over Talk of His Being Shut Down
abstract: Harvey kept his answers vague, without choosing a side, leaving much for interpretation.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Dr. James Andrews, the surgeon who performed Tommy John surgery on Matt Harvey in 2013, called him recently to check in. Andrews had been in contact with Scott Boras, Harvey’s agent, and he told Harvey that he was now recommending limiting him to 180 innings this season, his first full year back pitching after the surgery.

headline: Powerful Auburn Overcomes Its Quarterback’s Misadventures
abstract: Quarterback Jeremy Johnson made a mess of what was supposed to be his coming-out party, but the Auburn’s defensive front led the Tigers to victory with its marauding play.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Auburn’s defense was a marauder for three quarters on Saturday.

headline: Rickie Fowler, at Four Shots Back, Relishes Thrill of the Chase
abstract: Fowler, ranked ninth in the world, was at eight under, four strokes behind Charley Hoffman, who produced Saturday’s low score, a nine-birdie, one-bogey 63.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — If Rickie Fowler did not have two more rounds to play at TPC Boston, he would be perfectly at home at Jumptown, a sky-diving club in Orange, Mass., about an hour west of Boston. Fowler is an adrenaline seeker, and when his golf game is in high gear, the rush he gets rivals any feeling he experienced on the motorcycle dirt tracks or Pacific wave sets of his youth.

headline: Guatemalans Ousted President Otto Pérez Molina. Now What?

lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — Sergio Bacini is a music producer, a tattoo artist and a D.J. When the five-month protest movement that swept out Guatemala’s president last week seemed to flag during the summer, he knew how to revive it: He organized a rock concert.

headline: Women’s Films Do Not Tell the Whole Tale of Telluride

lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — Film festivals have sharply different personalities. The one that got underway here on Friday is wealthy and white, and it is the Tiffany of festivals, as its promotional materials accurately maintain.

headline: Michael Mmoh Is a Rising Hope for Several Countries

lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic was a little late to his hitting date with the young American player Michael Mmoh at Wimbledon in July. But Boris Becker, Djokovic’s coach, was there, and he and Mmoh reminisced while waiting for Djokovic to arrive.

headline: Playoff Pursuit Is the Mets’, but the Career Is Matt Harvey’s

headline: Flicker of Hope for Children With Rare and Devastating Disease
abstract: The disease, rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata, is a painful form of dwarfism, usually accompanied by intellectual disability and respiratory ills.
lead_paragraph: LEESBURG, Ala. — Once a year, Crystal and Jonathan Bedford drive 1,000 miles from their home in Texas to rural Alabama, their three children in tow. Beside a wooded lake, they huddle with other families whose children have the same extremely rare genetic disorder that their 5-year-old daughter, Marley, has.

lead_paragraph: Parents of children with RCDP, a very rare, terminal form of dwarfism, hope a potential new drug originally developed to treat Alzheimer’s will help their kids, too.

headline: As Europe Grasps for Answers, More Migrants Flood Its Borders
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Despite cheers of welcome in Germany, it remained unclear how Europe would deal with successive waves of people, for months or even years.
lead_paragraph: HEGYESHALOM, Hungary — Throughout the day on Sunday, train after packed train arrived at this border town from Budapest, the passengers smoothly shifting to a gleaming Austrian train on the opposite side of the platform and being whisked on to Vienna and beyond — 13,000 of them in the first 36 hours after Hungary allowed throngs of refugees and migrants to travel toward Germany.

headline: On the ‘Barbecue Patrol,’ a Summer Ritual for New York Police
abstract: During the warmer months, a small but notable number of outdoor celebrations devolve into gun violence after sundown.
lead_paragraph: After hours of checking on boisterous barbecues and other loud gatherings in the Bronx, making sure none grew out of control, Officers Joseph Helgerson and Edwin Vega stopped alongside their lieutenant’s car to check in. It was 11:07 p.m. on a Saturday.

headline: ‘Steve Jobs’ Receives Warm Reception at Telluride Film Festival
abstract: As portrayed by Michael Fassbender, acting from a script written by Aaron Sorkin, Mr. Jobs is part genius and part monster, a man who seems to go out of his way to be cruel but who has a genius understanding of technology and marketing.
lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — Before the world premiere of his new film on Saturday night, Danny Boyle told a crowd of 650 here at the Telluride Film Festival not to expect a representational biopic. Rather, he said, his “Steve Jobs” is a meant to be a direct signal from inside the Apple co-founder’s mind, “with all of its wonders and all of its horrors.”

abstract: The decision by Austria and Germany to throw open their borders and take in thousands of refugees does not seem to have stilled the movement or refugees across the continent.
lead_paragraph: The decision by Austria and Germany to throw open their borders and take in thousands of refugees does not seem to have stilled the movement or refugees across the continent.
