lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, announced on Sunday that she will support the nuclear agreement with Iran that has roiled many in her Florida district.

headline: Family Balks at Talk by Russia to Move Rachmaninoff’s Remains
abstract: Russia’s culture minister said recently that the remains of the composer Sergei Rachmaninoff, who was born in Russia but died in the United States, should be moved to his homeland.
lead_paragraph: VALHALLA, N.Y. — It was quiet beneath the mountain laurel shrubs shielding the grave of the composer Sergei Rachmaninoff from the late-summer sun. The furor is 4,500 miles away, in Russia, its indelible voice in every melodic line he wrote — a different Russia, a different sensibility, a different life, different time.

headline: Ousted as Gay, Aging Veterans Are Battling Again for Honorable Discharges
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Emboldened by recent advances for homosexuals in and out of the military, more gay veterans look to have their ousters reclassified.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — When the Army discharged Pvt. Donald Hallman in 1955 for being what it called a “Class II homosexual,” the 21-year-old was so scared of being an outcast that he burned all his military records, save for a single dog tag he hid away.

headline: Netanyahu Rejects Calls for Israel to Accept Syrian Refugees
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Border Barriers', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Palestinians']
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu also said on Sunday that plans to construct a fence along Israel’s eastern border with Jordan would go ahead.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday rejected calls from opposition politicians for Israel to accept refugees from Syria, saying that Israel was “a very small country that lacks demographic and geographic depth.” He also said that plans to construct a fence along the eastern border with Jordan would go ahead.

headline: 1940: United Regime Is Antonescu’s Rumanian Goal
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: General Ion Antonescu of Romania tries to form a cabinet in 1940.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST — Following the abdication this morning [Sept. 6] of King Carol II in favor of his eighteen-year-old son, Prince Michael, Rumania has been thrown into a state of wild excitement, and the general feeling here is that anything may happen within the next forty-eight hours.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13) ARTHUR & GEORGE In the time it took to puff on his pipe, Sherlock Holmes would have discerned everything: the eavesdropper at the private club, as well as his name, political persuasion and birthplace — all from the dust on his shoes. But Arthur Conan Doyle? Shockingly oblivious, a detractor declares in this three-part “Masterpiece Mystery!” presentation. “If you pursue your interest in the Edalji case, you’ll be judged by his high standards, and judged harshly,” the man chides Holmes’s creator. “But if you fall short, as you are bound to do, you’ll taint not only yourself but the world’s favorite consulting detective.” Edalji is the titular George, an Anglo-Indian solicitor imprisoned for mutilating livestock — and threatening schoolgirls with worse — in 1903 Staffordshire. He longs to be exonerated for crimes he maintains he did not commit, and Conan Doyle wagers his reputation that Edalji’s conviction was racially motivated. Martin Clunes, above, and Arsher Ali star in this adaptation of Julian Barnes’s fact-based novel, which unveils Conan Doyle’s personal life as he contemplates a future with his true love after his wife’s death. Charles Edwards plays Conan Doyle’s secretary, Alfred Wood — in other words, his Dr. Watson. “There’s just enough Sherlockian fun — Conan Doyle’s deductive abilities’ being compared unfavorably with those of his creation, Wood’s alarm when Conan Doyle considers a false beard as a disguise — to make the case for ‘Arthur & George,’ ” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times.

headline: For Now, Taubman Sale Means No Gift for Detroit Museum
abstract: The Detroit Institute of Arts is not a named beneficiary in the will of A. Alfred Taubman, a former owner of Sotheby’s who helped shape the museum, but it may benefit from his private foundation in coming years.
lead_paragraph: Few institutions have benefited more from the generosity of A. Alfred Taubman, a businessman from Michigan, than the Detroit Institute of Arts, where a wing bears his name. Before his death in April, Mr. Taubman, a philanthropist and shopping-mall magnate who at one point was the principal owner of the auction house Sotheby’s, provided the museum with tens of millions of dollars and about two dozen artworks that are part of its permanent collection.

headline: Alleviating Pain, Delivering Love
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Hospice Care']
abstract: A photojournalist learns what it is like for a family to care for a critically ill child while spending time at a pediatric palliative care program.
lead_paragraph: Casey Barnes was born with multiple life-limiting conditions, among them quadriplegia cerebral palsy. She cannot move, suck, swallow, gag or blink. To the untrained or uncomprehending eye, she looks uncommunicative, inert, a small person with extreme breathing problems (her airway must be suctioned every 15 minutes or so). When we met, I had no idea how to interact with or even how to be around her, let alone how to approach her with a camera.

headline: Vienna Welcomes Refugees
abstract: Austrians received refugees with food, drinks and applause as they arrived by train from Hungary this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Austrians received refugees with food, drinks and applause as they arrived by train from Hungary this weekend.

headline: 1890: Whisky and Tea Drinkers Worried
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Distillers fear the rise of taxes on whiskey and tea in 1890.
lead_paragraph: Western distillers are protesting against the increases made by the Senate on imported liquors. They fear the next step will be a rise of the internal revenue tax on domestic whiskies, in order to meet a possible deficit in the revenues of the Government. The Senate to-day adopted an amendment to the Tariff bill offered by Mr. Evarts as follows. It relates to stock held in London particularly: — ‘‘All teas the growth or produce of countries east of the Cape of Good Hope when imported from places west of the Cape of Good Hope shall pay duty 10 per centum ad valorem. Teas entered for consumption or for warehouse in any country intermediate between the country of export and the United States shall be treated as teas imported from such intermediate country and berated for duty accordingly.’’  — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 7, 1890

headline: Republicans Criticize Hillary Clinton and Discuss Kentucky Clerk’s Case
abstract: On the Sunday talk shows, Carly Fiorina questioned Hillary Rodham Clinton’s explanation for her private email server, and Mike Huckabee and John Kasich weighed in on the county clerk jailed for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples.
lead_paragraph: It was a relatively quiet Sunday on the talk shows, with candidates likely saving their energies (or enjoying a holiday) before a burst of activity on Labor Day, the traditional start of the campaign season. In truth, the presidential campaign has been blowing at near gale force for months.

headline: Montreal Symphony Orchestra Plans U.S. Tour
abstract: The ensemble is set to appear in 10 cities in March.
lead_paragraph: The Montreal Symphony Orchestra will embark in March on its most extensive tour of the United States in 25 years, the ensemble announced on Sunday, with concerts planned in 10 cities from coast to coast under the baton of its music director, Kent Nagano.

headline: Workers Organize, but Don’t Unionize, to Get Protection Under Labor Law
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Foreign Workers']
abstract: As unions have weakened, work site committees offer an alternative that is easier to form and can guard workers’ rights and improve job conditions.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — Jorge Porras used to report to his carwash job here most mornings at 8:15 a.m., but he said that his boss often did not let him clock in until 11, when customers frequently began streaming in. Many days he was paid for just six hours, he said, even though he worked nine and a half hours.

headline: Lynn Walker Huntley, Lawyer in Prominent Civil Rights Issues, Dies at 69
abstract: Ms. Huntley was a lawyer whose cases and causes involved issues including capital punishment, race relations and employment discrimination.
lead_paragraph: Lynn Walker Huntley, a lawyer who was deeply involved in a wide spectrum of civil rights cases and causes, including capital punishment, race relations and employment discrimination, died Aug. 30 at her home in Atlanta. She was 69.

headline: Taliban’s New Leader in Afghanistan Moves to Quash Dissent
abstract: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour has sent hundreds of fighters to Zabul Province to battle forces loyal to Mullah Mansour Dadullah, who has refused to pledge allegiance to the new leader.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In one of the first tests of his leadership, the head of Afghanistan’s Taliban militants is moving aggressively against a breakaway faction in the south of the country, according to Afghan and Taliban officials.

abstract: Mr. Kriegsmann, the director of programs, discusses his vision for Live Arts as the first dance performance of his inaugural season begins on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Maverick. Radical. Transformer. Socialist. Re-animator.

headline: Carrie Brownstein, Carly Rae Jepsen and Others on First-Time Cultural Experiences
abstract: Entertainers like Carrie Brownstein and Bridget Everett ruminate about what cultural encounters they would relive for the first time again if they could.
lead_paragraph: What would you see for the first time, all over again? The critics have already weighed in. The Times asked cultural figures, as well as readers, for their choices. Read about their first encounters with “The Rite of Spring,” dinner at Momofuku and . . . cat videos.

headline: Review: Lauren Groff’s ‘Fates and Furies’ Features a Wife Who’s Full of Surprises
abstract: This elaborate two-part story of a marriage gives the husband’s perspective, and then introduces readers to a completely different wife from the one they thought they knew.
lead_paragraph: “Fates and Furies” is Lauren Groff’s third novel, and it’s sure to be regarded as her most approachable book thus far — if only as some measure of the others’ extreme peculiarity. In “The Monsters of Templeton,” she wrote a genealogical mystery about a thinly disguised version of Cooperstown, N.Y. (Ms. Groff’s birthplace), and put a dead, 50-foot-long prehistoric monster in the local lake for good measure. “Arcadia” followed a hippie commune, mostly through the 1960s and ’70s, so vividly that the smells of the place wafted off the page.

headline: Buzzr Presents the Evolution of Game Shows and Ourselves
abstract: A new station devoted to game shows is serving up a collection of pilot episodes, some from classics like “The Match Game,” others from shows that never made it on the air.
lead_paragraph: A new channel called Buzzr might seem to have the fairly modest aim of catering to viewers who enjoy watching old game shows, but a programming stunt it is running this week suggests a much more ambitious purpose. This channel, if inadvertently, is documenting a startling acceleration in the pace of human evolution.

headline: Review: ‘The Odyssey’ Takes a Populist Turn as a Musical
abstract: Professional actors like Brandon Victor Dixon and amateur entertainers combine to turn this adaptation of Homer’s poem into a vibrant tapestry.
lead_paragraph: A selfie with a celebrity has replaced the autograph as a coveted prize, but a selfie with a legendary hero, the great Greek warrior Odysseus? Well, that would beat Beyoncé, hands down. A lucky young prince gains such a digital trophy in the brash, funny and heart-stirring musical version of Homer’s “The Odyssey” being presented by the Public Theater at the Delacorte Theater through Monday night.

headline: Steven Matz Has Strong Start, but Mets Fall to Marlins
abstract: Matz’s performance helped bolster belief that he could provide steady pitching in a push toward the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Steven Matz, sweat dotting his forehead, marched off the mound and paced the infield grass. With a stern expression, he watched the ball clear the wall in left-center field, then returned to the mound.

abstract: Two documentaries benefit from happenstance during filming and afterward.
lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — There is something spooky about “Sherpa” and timing.

lead_paragraph: Eugenie Bouchard’s entry into the second week of the United States Open was supposed to have coincided with the return of her new coaching consultant, Jimmy Connors, who had planned to rejoin her if she reached the fourth round.

headline: West Indian American Day Parade Comes Together One Costume at a Time
abstract: During the summer, hundreds of people construct the elaborate costumes seen at the parade in Brooklyn, often sprinting to the finish.
lead_paragraph: Reisha Maynard-Holder meticulously cut patterns for a collar out of foam rubber as a fan whirred in the sweltering heat. Next, she turned her attention to feathers, attaching them to the collars one at a time with a glue gun. It was another grueling evening in a monthslong effort to create some of the most elaborate and spectacular costumes seen on the streets of New York.

headline: Serena Williams’s Victory Sets Up a Showdown With Her Sister
abstract: She will meet Venus Williams in the quarterfinals at the U.S. Open, where Venus will attempt to deny her a Grand Slam.
lead_paragraph: At age 35, Venus Williams has been making a gallant effort to win an eighth major tennis title, her last one coming seven years ago at Wimbledon. But if she is to do it at this year’s United States Open, it will come at a heavy cost. She will have to deny her younger sister the rare opportunity to win a Grand Slam.

headline: Review: Electric Zoo, a Menagerie Designed for Dancing
abstract: This year’s festival had abundant options and polarities playing out on five stages.
lead_paragraph: The seventh annual Electric Zoo, the Labor Day weekend electronic dance music festival on Randalls Island, was billed as Electric Zoo: Transformed. The sound-and-lights superstructure of its redesigned main stage was shaped like a phoenix. Actually, it was Electric Zoo persevering and slightly shrunken, with fewer performers, fewer stages and shorter schedules on most of them — a lineup of 85 acts, not the more than 100 at Electric Zoos since 2011.

abstract: After a shaky start, a surge in the bottom of the sixth powered the Yankees to a victory.

headline: Apple Unveils New Products, and Stephen Colbert Returns to Late Night
abstract: This week, China will report on its economy, Puerto Rico may strike a deal to restructure its debt, and Stephen Colbert will start on CBS’s “The Late Show.”
lead_paragraph: China reports a basket of monthly data this week that is expected to provide a clearer picture of how much its economic growth is slowing. On Tuesday, it will release trade figures for August; exports have been flat so far this year, and imports declined 15 percent in the first seven months of 2015. Other reports include inflation figures on Wednesday and industrial output, investment and retail sales on Saturday. Investors will also be watching on Monday for August data on China’s foreign exchange reserves. While still the world’s largest, China’s reserves are expected to have declined after the surprise devaluation last month of its currency, the renminbi, which has raised concerns over capital outflows. — Neil Gough

headline: Jeb Bush, Family Ties and a Museum That Never Materialized
abstract: A case of misplaced trust offers a cautionary tale about the downside of the vast network of friends and supporters that has been an essential part of the Bush family’s political success.
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — When Jeb Bush set out to build a political base of his own in South Florida three decades ago, he did not lack for new friends. He was a magnet for a long line of Republicans eager to be associated with him and his powerful family, including a Cuban immigrant and former corrections officer named Tony Campos.

headline: Productivity and Pay
abstract: A study you should read.
lead_paragraph: Still in Sydney (next stop Tokyo), where it’s much too beautiful a day to sit inside blogging. But I did want to flag an excellent report by Josh Bivens and Larry Mishel on the productivity-pay gap.

keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Television Sets and Media Devices', 'Apple TV', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)', 'PlayStation (Video Game System)']

headline: A Train Journey From Communism to Freedom, Almost Ended in Hungary
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: More than three decades ago, my mother, grandmother and I boarded a train in Bucharest. I was 5, and I had been told we were going on a holiday to Paris.
lead_paragraph: More than three decades ago, my mother, grandmother and I boarded a train in communist Romania, armed with the papers my mother had painstakingly gathered in an effort to give me a better life. I was 5 years old, and I had been told we were going on a holiday to Paris. I realized something was wrong when my surrogate grandfather Tata Geo (Father Geo) broke into sobs as we left the house.

headline: China’s Military Cutbacks
abstract: China announced that it would cut 300,000 troops, its largest reduction in nearly two decades.
lead_paragraph: China announced that it would cut 300,000 troops, its largest reduction in nearly two decades.

headline: Celebrating Bud Collins, a Tennis Treasure Told in Words and Pants
abstract: “Where else would you want to be right now?” Bud Collins asked Sunday when the United States Tennis Association recognized his contributions to the sport.
lead_paragraph: Across the decades, Bud Collins had a standard line for when someone — typically a newspaper competitor — would rush over and wonder if he had a moment to answer a question. He would cheerily look up from his keyboard and say, “Ask two.”

headline: German Quota System Highlights Possible Path and Pitfalls for Handling Crisis
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Germany is in many ways a laboratory of how the European Union could jointly tackle the migrant crisis, and key to the response so far has been a quota system that has been in place for decades.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Rania al-Hamawi had gone to sleep on Saturday on a clean, bright blue cot alongside her three sons and another 1,700 people who had made the arduous journey to the Bavarian capital from Syria and other strife-ridden countries. But when she woke on Sunday, half the beds in the cavernous conference center-turned-migration camp were empty.

headline: Out of Perceived Weakness Is Born an Act of Aggression
abstract: The inside-out forehand, once seen as a sign of a shaky player, has become “the most devastating shot in the game.”
lead_paragraph: Hit to your opponent’s backhand. For generations, that was considered the most foolproof tactic in tennis.

headline: The Crowding-Out Effect of Gargantuan Movies
abstract: Ticket sales at North American cinemas rose 10 percent, to $4.48 billion, this summer. But it was a lopsided victory for the studios.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood had one of its best summers ever at the domestic box office, but it was a sharply lopsided victory. Studios either thrived or withered, an outcome that reflects the winner-take-all nature of the mass-appeal movie business.

headline: Another Hot Stroke: The Drop Shot
abstract: The drop shot has continued to gain favor after Roger Federer used it to help win his first French Open in 2009.
lead_paragraph: The inside-out forehand is not the only high-risk, high-reward shot in vogue on the ATP Tour. The drop shot has also become a weapon of choice.

headline: Greenland’s Farmers Torn Over Tapping Pristine Land for Mineral Riches
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Rural Areas', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Uranium']
abstract: As the territory pushes forward with plans to mine its vast deposits of resources, many citizens fear their farming and fishing culture could be disrupted.
lead_paragraph: QASSIARSUK, Greenland — Carl and Ellen Frederiksen gazed anxiously at a spot on the snow-flecked mountain behind their village. The sheepdogs had been running back and forth, and they feared a lamb was trapped on one of the slopes.

headline: Activists Say Police Abuse of Transgender People Persists Despite Reforms
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The New York Police Department codified rules in 2012 for interacting with transgender people, but advocates and those affected say harassment is still commonplace.
lead_paragraph: New Year’s revelers clamored outside the window of Shagasyia Diamond’s apartment in the Bronx the day she was arrested.

headline: Time Warner Cable Plans Channel Dedicated to Pope Francis’ Visit
abstract: The papal channel, featuring round-the-clock coverage of the pope’s visit in the New World this month, will reach 15 million households.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis will not be hard to find on television during his visit to the United States.

headline: When Finding Housing Is a Job in Itself
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Parenting', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Section 8 (Housing)', 'Vouchers']
abstract: If I had $6000 for a deposit and broker’s fees, I wouldn’t need this Section 8 voucher.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago I went into the New York City shelter system. For 11 months, I searched for apartments like crazy. I had few options. I had just come out of a psychiatric hospital. I had a 4-year-old son and was pregnant with my daughter. I had a housing voucher and was living off of Supplementary Security Income (a Social Security program) and food stamps. I went in and out of real estate offices until I found an apartment at the western edge of the Bronx, in the River Park Towers.

headline: Experts Reject Official Account of How 43 Mexican Students Were Killed
keywords: ['Missing Persons', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Organized Crime']
abstract: An international panel said there was no evidence to support the government’s conclusion that the college students who disappeared last fall were executed by a drug gang.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — An international committee of experts reviewing the case of 43 missing college students whose disappearance last fall traumatized Mexico said Sunday that there was no evidence to support the government’s conclusion that the students were executed by a drug gang that then burned the bodies to ashes in a garbage dump.

headline: Threat to Arizona’s Salt River Horses Spurs New Battle Over Western Lands
keywords: ['Horses', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Land Use Policies', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Plans to remove the horses from the Tonto National Forest, putting them at risk of slaughter, set off a campaign that won a four-month reprieve.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Soon after federal officials announced the imminent capture of 100 or so horses within the boundaries of a national forest near here — to be sold at auction, “condemned and destroyed, or otherwise disposed of” — a resourceful cadre of self-appointed guardians issued a desperate call for action.

headline: Visiting 99 Counties in Iowa Doesn’t Get Candidates as Far as It Used to
abstract: Rick Santorum is the first candidate this year to visit all of Iowa’s 99 counties, but he has yet to catch up in the polls to Donald J. Trump, who has rarely visited the state.
lead_paragraph: ROCK RAPIDS, Iowa — In a state that prizes retail campaigning, nothing is more revered than “the full Grassley” — a politician’s visit to all of Iowa’s 99 counties, named for the state’s peripatetic senior senator, Charles E. Grassley.

headline: Yoenis Cespedes Wows the Mets Underhand, Overhand and Many Other Ways
abstract: After the Mets acquired Cespedes, his offensive influence was obvious and immediate. But Cespedes also does things that his teammates and coaches have never seen; when he bats or fields or runs, they make sure to watch.
lead_paragraph: During spring training in 2012, when Yoenis Cespedes had just arrived in the United States from Cuba and was still getting to know his teammates on the Oakland Athletics, he started doing a trick they had never seen: He would throw the ball underhand with stunning velocity, movement and accuracy. Like a softball player.

headline: Appeal Filed in Kim Davis’s Contempt Ruling
keywords: ['Appeals Courts (US)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Lawyers for Ms. Davis, the Kentucky county clerk who was jailed last week, filed a notice of appeal on the grounds that her right to due process had been violated.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Ms. Davis, the Kentucky county clerk who was jailed last week, filed a notice of appeal on the grounds that her right to due process had been violated.

headline: Jailed Kentucky Clerk Starts Federal Appeal
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: Lawyers for the Kentucky county clerk who was jailed after refusing to issue marriage licenses to gay couples said they have begun the process of appealing the judge’s ruling on the grounds that her right to due process was violated.
lead_paragraph: The Kentucky county clerk who was jailed for defying a federal court order to issue marriage licenses to gay couples has begun the process of appealing the judge’s ruling that landed her there, her lawyers said on Sunday.

headline: Guatemalans Head to Polls Days After President’s Ouster
abstract: The scandal surrounding President Otto Pérez Molina upended earlier forecasts of the race, but many voters were hopeful they would soon be able to hold politicians accountable.
lead_paragraph: MIXCO, Guatemala — Guatemalans voted on Sunday in presidential elections, disgusted by corruption and disheartened by their choices just five days after a wave of mass protests forced President Otto Pérez Molina from office.

headline: Matt Harvey Says He Will Pitch On
abstract: Despite his surgeon’s recommendation that he not exceed 180 innings this year, Harvey vowed in an essay for The Players’ Tribune that he would pitch in the playoffs if the Mets reached the postseason.
lead_paragraph: For three days, the debate over Matt Harvey’s innings limit raged on in the news media. His agent, Scott Boras, and his boss, General Manager Sandy Alderson, laid out their sides publicly, and Mets fans hammered Harvey on social media for not definitively saying, during a news conference Saturday, that he would pitch into the postseason.

headline: Jean Darling, Child Actress in ‘Our Gang’ Series, Dies at 93
abstract: Ms. Darling appeared in the comedy series as a child and performed in the original Broadway production of “Carousel” in 1945.
lead_paragraph: Jean Darling, who appeared in the “Our Gang” comedy films as a child and performed in the original Broadway production of “Carousel,” died on Friday in Rödermark, Germany. She was 93.

headline: Best Move for Matt Harvey: Shield Arm, and Ears
abstract: Harvey, who has helped lead the Mets back to respectability, would be wise to tune out critics and listen to those who have his best interests at heart.
lead_paragraph: Good God, the kid has gone pusillanimous on us. A coward, a phony, a fugazi. As a wealthy 60-something tabloid columnist puts it, Mets pitcher Matt Harvey is quitting on his stool.

headline: The Train to Germany
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Syrian migrants took a train from Austria to their final destination: Germany.
lead_paragraph: Syrian migrants took a train from Austria to their final destination: Germany.

headline: Beyond 2 Black Champions, a Void for the U.S.T.A.
abstract: Though Serena and Venus Williams have forcefully carried the flag for American tennis, the United States Tennis Association has made little progress in identifying and developing African-American stars.
lead_paragraph: Identifying the next great African-American talent is tricky business for the United States Tennis Association.

headline: U.S. Revamping Rebel Force Fighting ISIS in Syria
abstract: The proposed changes come after a Syrian affiliate of Al Qaeda attacked the rebel group of the first 54 Syrian graduates of the military program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an acknowledgment of severe shortcomings in its effort to create a force of moderate rebels to battle the Islamic State in Syria, the Pentagon is drawing up plans to significantly revamp the program by dropping larger numbers of fighters into safer zones as well as providing better intelligence and improving their combat skills.

headline: Where Both Shredders and Sharpshooters Go to Shop
abstract: Dick’s Country Store Gun City & Music Oasis, which sells guns, guitars, groceries and more, has been a fixture in the North Country since 1962.
lead_paragraph: CHURUBUSCO, N.Y. — Three miles from the Canadian border, along a remote stretch of highway where giant wind turbines fill the sky, Dick’s Country Store & Music Oasis is a hardy survivor. Better known as Dick’s Groceries, Gas, Guns & Guitars, this North Country mainstay has been in business since 1962 thanks to its hybrid retail strategy and its role as a community hub.

headline: Kendall Fuller’s Ties With Virginia Tech Are Rooted in Family
abstract: Fuller, an all-American cornerback who will lead Virginia Tech against top-ranked Ohio State on Monday night, has three older brothers who played football at Virginia Tech and went on to play in the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: BLACKSBURG, Va. — Kendall Fuller said that his earliest experience playing football was the flag football league his parents put him in at age 6 or 7. To hear his parents tell it, though, it is not an unequivocally happy memory.

headline: No. 1 Is Slipping From a Fading Rory McIlroy
abstract: With few competitive rounds after coming back from an ankle injury, and a lethargic performance at the Deutsche Bank Championship, McIlroy is likely to hand the top ranking back to Jordan Spieth.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — It was like watching the tennis superstar Roger Federer practice hours before a night match at the United States Open, only every stroke that Rory McIlroy, a friend of Federer’s, took on Sunday morning counted. Several dozen fans made it to the first hole at TPC Boston in time to watch McIlroy, the world No. 1 for at least another 24 hours, begin his third round at the Deutsche Bank Championship.

headline: No Foul Mouths on This Field: Football With a New Age Twist
abstract: Breaking away from football’s harsher motivational techniques, Seattle Coach Pete Carroll fosters an atmosphere of positive reinforcement and Zen-like focus.
lead_paragraph: RENTON, Wash. — Jimmy Graham, an all-star tight end, quickly learned things were different with the Seattle Seahawks after he arrived this spring from the New Orleans Saints in an off-season trade.

headline: Andy Murray Keeps Winning, and Resting and Recuperating
abstract: In his latest conversation with The New York Times, Murray spoke about how he recharges after a match.
lead_paragraph: As he marches through the United States Open while battling a cold, Andy Murray talks to The New York Times about rest, recuperation and recovery. Murray has defeated Nick Kyrgios, Adrian Mannarino and Thomaz Bellucci, and he plays Kevin Anderson in a fourth-round match Monday.

headline: ‘Masters of Sex’ Recap: Libby’s Last Stand and Bill’s Admission
abstract: Dan Logan and Virginia Johnson sound like a bad drawing-room play.
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 9, “High Anxiety”

headline: Shaped by Camp, Alumni Fight to Prevent Its Move
abstract: Camp Rising Sun, which counts directors and government officials among its former campers, is forced to consider moving, stirring a fight among its alumni.
lead_paragraph: RED HOOK, N.Y. — They were teenagers spending a summer or two at sleepaway camp, but the memories never left them. Decades later, with those campers in middle and old age, the memories are stoking a fight to keep Camp Rising Sun where it is for other generations of youngsters.

headline: Heisman Trophy Watch
abstract: A look at the top players in contention for college football’s highest honor.
lead_paragraph: A look at the top players in contention for college football’s highest honor.

headline: Life on the Streets
abstract: Visits with dozens of homeless New Yorkers reveal how job losses, mental health issues, substance abuse and problems with the city shelter system drove many to the streets.
lead_paragraph: Visits with dozens of homeless New Yorkers reveal how job losses, mental health issues, substance abuse and problems with the city shelter system drove many to the streets.

headline: New Yorker Festival Announces Lineup
abstract: The New Yorker Festival will feature interviews with Billy Joel, Toni Morrison and Lin-Manuel Miranda.
lead_paragraph: The 2015 New Yorker Festival will cover comedy, race and technology with some of the leaders in each field. Featuring interviews with Toni Morrison, Lin-Manuel Miranda, Billy Joel and Jason Segel, the 16th annual festival will run from Oct. 2 to 4 in New York and include live performances, film previews and a new tech conference.

headline: Obama Orders Federal Contractors to Provide Workers Paid Sick Leave
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Labor and Jobs', "Workers' Compensation Insurance", 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: The latest executive order changing workplace rules, which will take effect in 2017, calls for up to seven days of paid leave a year.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — President Obama signed an executive order on Monday requiring federal contractors to provide up to seven days of paid sick leave a year, even as he accused Republican congressional leaders of endangering the economy and Republican presidential candidates of undercutting American workers.

headline: Pertussis Passed to Newborns From Siblings
abstract: A new study suggests that siblings, not mothers, are now the most common source of whooping cough infections in newborns.
lead_paragraph: A new study has found that siblings, not mothers, are now the most common source of pertussis infection in newborns.

headline: Jets Sideline Injured Dee Milliner
abstract: The Jets placed Milliner on short-term injured reserve, preventing him from practicing for six weeks and from playing for eight.
lead_paragraph: The Jets placed cornerback Dee Milliner (wrist) on short-term injured reserve on Sunday. The move prevents him from practicing for six weeks and from playing for eight. Milliner would be eligible to return for the Nov. 8 game against Jacksonville.

headline: Carl Edwards Wins at Darlington
abstract: Edwards led for only 15 laps but won the Southern 500, a Nascar Sprint Cup race, at Darlington Raceway in South Carolina, edging Brad Keselowski and Denny Hamlin.
lead_paragraph: Carl Edwards led for only 15 laps but won the Southern 500, a Nascar Sprint Cup race, at Darlington Raceway in South Carolina, edging Brad Keselowski and Denny Hamlin.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:15 P.M. (Cinemax) LOST IN TRANSLATION (2003) An American movie star (Bill Murray), cashing in on his celebrity to make a lucrative ad in Japan, meets a young woman (Scarlett Johansson, above, with Mr. Murray) who has been temporarily deserted by her husband (Giovanni Ribisi), in this comic melodrama written and directed by Sofia Coppola, who won an Oscar for best original screenplay. As they escape the confines of the Tokyo Hyatt, something like love ensues. Mr. Murray, who received an Oscar nomination, “supplies the kind of performance that seems so fully realized and effortless that it can easily be mistaken for not acting at all,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 7, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “For us, getting another month with your child or another year or another five years — that’s kind of everything.”

headline: Reforms Follow Protests in Ferguson
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Local Government', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Police']
abstract: Changes in Missouri are already yielding results, but much more remains to be done.
lead_paragraph: It has been a year since the police shooting of an African-American teenager in Ferguson, Mo., ignited the community protest and street turmoil that ultimately laid bare local government’s exploitation of citizens, particularly blacks. It is no small achievement that Missouri began enforcing a series of tough new court reforms last month aimed at ending one particularly flagrant abuse: the systematic fleecing of accused traffic offenders in a revenue scheme to bolster the budgets of local governments.

headline: Help for the Way We Work Now
keywords: ['Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'United States Economy', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Employee Fringe Benefits']
abstract: Freelancers deserve more security than the gig economy provides.
lead_paragraph: WITH the presidential race well underway, Labor Day is a good time to consider how our political leaders are grappling with the many challenges facing American workers. While the next president will confront a host of important labor and economic issues, one is poised to be a particularly significant factor in 2016 and beyond: the freelance economy.

headline: You Deserve a Raise Today. Interest Rates Don’t.
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Recession and Depression', 'Executive Compensation', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: While the economy and executives’ bonuses have recovered since the recession, workers wages have declined. The proof is in the paycheck.
lead_paragraph: For most Americans, paychecks determine living standards. Unfortunately, wages in America have long stagnated or declined for most working people, including college graduates.

headline: Trump Is Right on Economics
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Taxation', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Jeb Bush’s attacks on the G.O.P. front-runner are on issues where the Republican voting base and the party’s rich donors diverge.
lead_paragraph: So Jeb Bush is finally going after Donald Trump. Over the past couple of weeks the man who was supposed to be the front-runner has made a series of attacks on the man who is. Strange to say, however, Mr. Bush hasn’t focused on what’s truly vicious and absurd — viciously absurd? — about Mr. Trump’s platform, his implicit racism and his insistence that he would somehow round up 11 million undocumented immigrants and remove them from our soil.

headline: Sexual Attraction and Fluidity
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Youth', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Age, Chronological']
abstract: People must define their own sexuality, despite the categories others would impose.
lead_paragraph: Recently, Miley Cyrus told Elle UK, “I’m very open about it — I’m pansexual.”

headline: Patent Law Shouldn’t Block the Sale of Used Tech Products
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Computer Printers', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Inventions and Patents']
abstract: American patent law should not be used to prevent consumers from reselling, altering or fixing technology products.
lead_paragraph: American patent law should not be used to prevent consumers from reselling, altering or fixing technology products. A federal appeals court will soon hear a case that could clearly establish this principle.

headline: We Don’t Need Kim Davis to Be in Jail
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: The Kentucky county clerk symbolizes what happens when same-sex marriage and its critics can’t find a way to coexist.
lead_paragraph: KIM DAVIS, the clerk in Rowan County, Ky., went to jail last week, and there was no good reason for her to be there. Americans can expect more conflicts over religious conscience and same-sex marriage if we don’t find a way to coexist peacefully. Ms. Davis has become a symbol of what happens when we don’t.

headline: Tesco Sells South Korean Business Homeplus for Over $6 Billion
keywords: ['Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']
abstract: The British grocery chain sold the Homeplus Group to a consortium of investors led by Asian private-equity firm MBK Partners as it looked to improve its performance.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tesco, one of the biggest British grocery store chains, said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its South Korean operations to a consortium of investors led by the Asian private equity firm MBK Partners for more than $6 billion.

headline: The Whitney Taps Frank Stella for an Inaugural Retrospective at Its New Home
abstract: The artist, known for his “Black Paintings” in the late 1950s, has continued to work well into his 70s and is currently producing spindly and surprisingly lightweight sculptures.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Whitney Museum of American Art has left its longtime digs on Madison Avenue for an all-new, terrace-laden building in Chelsea, its fall schedule seems likely to be read as a mission statement. What does it mean, for instance, that Frank Stella, 79, the champion of abstract art, has been tapped for the inaugural retrospective at the new building? Perhaps abstract painting is hot again, or perhaps the Whitney has entered a mature phase, celebrating not just the rise of art stars but the feat of staying artistically elevated over the years.

headline: Hotel Room Work Spaces Go Casual
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Hotels are redesigning rooms to reflect the way many people now work, replacing desks with tables and adding laptop trays and more electrical outlets.
lead_paragraph: As workers become less tethered to their desks, hotels are giving their old in-room work spaces the pink slip.

headline: On ‘The Muppets,’ Miss Piggy Has a Talk Show and a Chatty Staff
abstract: “The Muppets,” beginning on ABC this month, plays with a current series form the way the original toyed with the variety-show format.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Last winter, Miss Piggy found herself doing what many middle-aged actresses are forced to do when they hit the box office skids: looking for work.

headline: Melting Ice Isn’t Opening Arctic to Oil Bonanza
keywords: ['Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: The region remains inhospitable for drilling, while environmental concerns, a sagging market and sanctions against Russia also have impeded plans.
lead_paragraph: TERIBERKA, Russia — The warming Arctic should already have transformed this impoverished fishing village on the coast of the Barents Sea.

abstract: Visits to some spaces in Manhattan revealed that public access had been diminished, if not eliminated.
lead_paragraph: Like many who work on Broadway, Peter Wolf, a stage manager for 25 years, hates the Great White Way packed as it is with tourists and traffic.

headline: Lung Screening May Not Push Smokers to Quit
abstract: Money spent on screening smokers for lung cancer may be better spent helping them kick the habit altogether.
lead_paragraph: The results of an admittedly small but telling new study suggest that Medicare and other insurers could be spending billions of dollars on screening smokers for lung cancer that would be better spent on helping them quit and keeping others from starting.

headline: Report on Toll From Shandong Blast Is Called ‘Coldblooded’
abstract: The insensitivity toward the victims and the focus on stability in a city government’s announcement prompted heated criticism online and censure from Xinhua, China’s state news agency.

headline: A Steady Flow Staggers Into Europe, Outpacing Pledges of Shelter
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: France said it would accept 24,000 asylum seekers over two years, Britain plans to accept 20,000 Syrian refugees and Germany set aside $6.7 billion to help new arrivals.
lead_paragraph: ROSZKE, Hungary — Fraying tensions snapped along Hungary’s southern border on Monday as thousands more migrants staggered into the country from Serbia while European leaders scrambled to figure out what to do with them and how to stanch the flow.

headline: After Fatal Attack, Turkey Strikes at Kurdish Rebels
abstract: The clashes signaled an escalation in violence in the southeast, where Kurdish militants have resumed an insurgency against the Turkish state.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish military carried out airstrikes against Kurdish insurgents on Monday, a day after what appeared to be the deadliest rebel assault since the breakdown in July of a fragile peace process with the Turkish state.

headline: Novak Djokovic: The Unloved Champion
abstract: The top-ranked tennis player has not won over the crowds in the manner of Roger Federer, but that has only made him better.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic has spent most of the last four years as the world’s No. 1 ranked tennis player, but he is not necessarily the people’s champion. Having finally overtaken the affable, urbane superstar Roger Federer and his longtime foil, Rafael Nadal (a popular underdog), Mr. Djokovic knows the crowd is not always on his side. But that has only steeled his resolve.

headline: As the Complaint Box Fills, Mayor de Blasio Adopts a Mr. Fix-It Approach
abstract: Past New York City mayors often dismissed critics and refused to admit fault, but advocates, elected officials and others have noted a shift under Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: New York City mayors have not generally taken kindly to criticism.

headline: Pakistan Says Its Drone Killed 3 Militants
abstract: The drone was aimed at a hide-out in the Shawal Valley, a military spokesman said, but no details were provided about the identities of the dead.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan said on Monday that three high-profile militants had been killed in the country’s violence-plagued northwest in the first strike by a locally manufactured drone.

headline: China, Trying to Bolster Currency, Taps Foreign Reserves
abstract: Despite a record monthly decrease of nearly $100 billion, the nation still has the world’s biggest cache of foreign reserves, government data shows.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China is burning through its huge stockpile of foreign exchange reserves at the fastest pace yet as it seeks to prop up its currency and stem a rising tide of money flowing out of the country.

keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']

headline: China’s Turmoil May Stall Rebound in Watch Sales

lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — After nearly three years of government austerity and slow economic growth, sales of luxury watches in China are showing signs of rebound — although many factors, including the recent weakening of the renminbi and stock market turmoil, could stall that momentum again.

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At least 28 people, many of them agricultural workers in fields, were killed by lightning when storms lashed southern and eastern India, officials said on Monday.

headline: European Leaders Grapple With Response to Migrant Crisis
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The relentless stream of migrants continued to flow into Europe, prompting France, Germany and Britain to pledge more support.
lead_paragraph: The relentless stream of migrants continued to flow into Europe, prompting France, Germany and Britain to pledge more support.

headline: Times Critics’ Guide: What to Do This Week
abstract: Looking for something new this week? Writers and critics for The Times can help.
lead_paragraph: Looking to break out of a cultural rut?

headline: Scented Leather Goods, Made the 17th-Century Way
abstract: The cult French perfumer Francis Kurkdjian teamed up with a Parisian saddle maker to create unisex cardholders that smell like musky sandalwood and vanilla amber.
lead_paragraph: The cult French perfumer Francis Kurkdjian, who co-founded his eponymous fragrance house in Paris in 2009, introduces his first line of leather goods today — and, unsurprisingly, they smell quite nice. “Scented leather was very obvious to me since it is a direct link to the origins of perfumery,” says Kurkdjian in a reference to the 17th century, when gloves were perfumed to mask the odors left behind from the tanning process. Back then, a mixture of fragrant spices, blooms and natural oils were rubbed into the leather repeatedly to ensure staying power. But for his debut collection of scented cardholders, Kurkdjian developed a long lasting, pure-oil-based formula.

headline: Back-to-School Worries for Gay Parents
abstract: In school, they often hear comments that don’t seem malicious or constitute bullying, but that researchers refer to as “microaggression.”
lead_paragraph: “Oh, you’re Mia,” the camper from the other bunk said. “You’re the one who’s adopted and has two moms.”

headline: The Horses of the Salt River
abstract: Floating along with the current, kayakers and paddleboarders on the Salt River in Arizona might catch a glimpse of a special sight: a herd of wild horses out for a swim.
lead_paragraph: Floating along with the current, kayakers and paddleboarders on the Salt River in Arizona might catch a glimpse of a special sight: a herd of wild horses out for a swim.

headline: Israel in a Post-Deal World
abstract: Mending relations with the White House is a necessary first step to ensuring that the West keeps Iran in check.
lead_paragraph: HAIFA, Israel — THE day after six world powers reached a nuclear agreement with Iran in July, the Israeli Knesset’s foreign affairs and defense committee called on Israel’s government to “continue to closely follow the precise and strict implementation” of the agreement “to ensure that Iran is not continuing to fool the international community as it did in the past, while strengthening the historic alliance between the United States and Israel.”

headline: Britain Says It Killed 3 ISIS Suspects in First Drone Strike in Syria
abstract: Crossing a threshold in its battle with jihadist groups, Britain said it had killed two of its own citizens, suspected members of the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Crossing a significant threshold in its battle with jihadist groups, Britain announced on Monday that it had conducted an armed drone strike for the first time inside Syria, killing three suspected members of the Islamic State, including two British citizens.

headline: Anish Kapoor Work at Versailles Is Vandalized (Again)
abstract: The installation, which centers on a sculpture entitled “Dirty Corner,” was defaced Saturday night, with highly offensive sentences in French scrawled on the sculpture and nearby rocks that are also part of the work.
lead_paragraph: The artist Anish Kapoor’s temporary installation at the Palace of Versailles was vandalized this weekend for the second time since June, this time covered in graffiti that included anti-Semitic slurs.

headline: 1965: India and Pakistan Bombed
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The conflict between India and Pakistan expands in 1965.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Jet bombers carried death and destruction to Indian and Pakistani cities today [Sept. 7] as the threat of all-out war spread across the vast subcontinent of 590 million people. Pakistan reported Indian bombers attacked cities in both East and West Pakistan, including Rawalpindi and Karachi. India said Pakistani planes attacked near Calcutta and several other cities. Thus the Indian-Pakistani confrontation — originally over the control of the small vale of Kashmir — had spread from Karachi, on the Arabian Gulf, to Calcutta, 2,000 miles east. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 8, 1965

headline: Summery Cocktails From Bars Around New York City
abstract: T’s online managing editor Alainna Lexie Beddie celebrates the unofficial end of summer with seasonal drink recipes from bars around New York City.
lead_paragraph: T’s online managing editor Alainna Lexie Beddie celebrates the unofficial end of summer with seasonal drink recipes from bars around New York City.

headline: U.S. Denies an Airstrike Killed 11 Afghan Narcotics Officers
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: An Afghan official said that the strike came during an operation to arrest drug smugglers in Helmand Province on Sunday, and that four officers were also wounded.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An American airstrike may have mistakenly killed at least 11 narcotics officers in southern Afghanistan on Sunday night, Afghan officials said on Monday. But the American military denied that such an airstrike had taken place.
