abstract: A Concacaf doubleheader on Tuesday and the return of Europe’s top leagues on Friday highlight the schedule this week.
lead_paragraph: The best stories and games are in Europe this week, but a Concacaf doubleheader on Tuesday night qualifies as must-see television for American fans.

headline: ‘I Am Cait’ Recap: Getting Ready for the ESPY Awards
abstract: The best moments on this show illuminate what goes on behind the media curtain.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 7: “What’s In A Name?”

headline: Sun, Surf and Horses’ Thundering Hooves Keep a Tradition Alive in Spain
abstract: The horse races at Sanlúcar de Barrameda have gained prominence as a bright spot in the otherwise gloomy landscape of horse racing in Spain.
lead_paragraph: SANLÚCAR DE BARRAMEDA, Spain — Local fishermen first started racing cart horses on the beach here while waiting to unload the day’s catch from their boats.

headline: Pop-Up Shop at Barneys to Feature a Billy Sullivan Drawing
abstract: The designer Madeline Weinrib is opening a pop-up shop at Barneys Chelsea Passage, and one of the works, a still life with magenta flowers and lime-green fabric, is by Billy Sullivan.
lead_paragraph: It started with a casual lunch in Bridgehampton, N.Y. The textile designer Madeline Weinrib was hosting Billy Sullivan, an artist who has been a fixture of the New York art scene since the 1960s. He wanted to keep a visual diary of the scene, so he made some pastel drawings.

headline: Pop and Jazz Listings and Albums for the Fall Season
abstract: Among the artists with new albums or big shows this season are Lana Del Rey, the Weeknd, Alabama Shakes and Justin Bieber.
lead_paragraph: More listings for the new season: Art | Dance | Classical | Theater | Film | Television

headline: New York Chef Brothers Return Home to Detroit (and to Hot Dogs)
abstract: Max and Eli Sussman return to their Michigan roots to reflect on — and chow down in — the places that shaped them.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘THIS IS THE TICKET, folks,’’ says Eli Sussman. ‘‘This is the jam right here.’’ A coney has been placed in front of him on a table at American Coney Island, a red-and-white rockabillyish restaurant in downtown Detroit that could have easily doubled as the set of a White Stripes music video. In Michigan parlance, ‘‘coney island’’ essentially signifies a Greek diner, and a coney is a hot dog. And in this city, it’s only served one way: smothered in chili, yellow mustard and a fistful of raw white onions — no substitutions. ‘‘When you look at it, you say, ‘Oh, man, this is a terrible idea,’ ’’ says Eli’s older brother, Max. ‘‘Then you eat it and you’re like, ‘I kind of want another one.’ ’’

headline: Cuomo Administration Lawyer Is Shot in Head Before West Indian Day Parade
abstract: Carey Gabay, who was critically injured in the attack just hours before the start of the parade on Monday, was “not doing well,” Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said.
lead_paragraph: The revelers were crowded onto Bedford Avenue in Brooklyn partaking in the annual West Indian American Day celebration early on Monday when the bullets began to fly in all directions.

headline: Can You Crack the 24 Puzzle, and the 10 Puzzle That Went Viral in Japan?
abstract: Can you make 24 using 2, 4, 4, 6 and the four basic operations + – × /?
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Nishant Pappireddi, a senior at the University of California, Berkeley, where he studies math as well as molecular and cell biology. I’d recently been introduced to Nishant by Ken Ribet, a professor at Berkeley famous for paving the way to a proof of Fermat’s Last Theorem. Ken considered Nishant to be one of his best students, so I asked Nishant if he had a favorite simple puzzle he might like to share on Numberplay. He responded with —

headline: Humanizing Technology: A History of Human-Computer Interaction
abstract: The rise of modern computing owes much to human-centered software design. A leading computer scientist has built a web site highlighting the work of the field’s pioneers.
lead_paragraph: The march of progress in computing is a climb. Each big step forward is also a step up, so that communication is further away from the machine, more on human terms.

headline: 1940: Berlin Takes Savage Attack
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: British air forces retaliate for the bombing of London in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Returning blow for blow and bomb for bomb with interest, the Royal Air Force countered with sledge-hammer attacks against Berlin early this morning [Sept. 7] in one of the heaviest raids that the focal point of Hitlerism has yet received. As the docklands of London were burning tonight in so-called retaliation raids, new forces of R.A.F. bombers swung off from their airdromes, heading eastward to let the Germans know that the fighting power of this country has only begun to make itself felt. The British bombers were still restricted by their belief that bombs should be dropped at least within the bomb sight of the target. — New York Herald Tribune, September 8, 1940

headline: Exhibitions Where Moral Force Trumps Market Forces
abstract: Coming exhibitions take on matters of gravity, but the best events might not even appear on schedules.
lead_paragraph: The most important art events of the coming season are likely to be of a kind that don’t appear on lists like this, because they aren’t announced far in advance. Their medium is surprise. I hope this year they’ll include guerrilla actions by groups like Gulf Labor and Black Lives Matter aimed at shaking up a politically torpid art industry. I fear they’ll include further assaults by ISIS on art itself. Constructive or destructive, these examples of politically motivated activism have one thing in common: They acknowledge, as our corporate-minded museums and art schools don’t, that art is more than just market fodder. It is, or can be, a moral force.

headline: Chosen by Mississippi Democrats, Shy Trucker Is at a Crossroad
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Governors (US)']
abstract: Robert Gray won the Democratic primary even though he never campaigned, and his own mother did not know he was running until she saw the ballot.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — Only three people who had ever met this man, Robert Gray, knew that he was running in the primary for governor of Mississippi.

headline: Experiencing Architecture Through ‘Hippie Modernism’ and Retrospectives
abstract: Several exhibitions this fall will try to immerse viewers in the world of a designer.
lead_paragraph: In 1965, four artists bought seven acres in southeastern Colorado, intending to make live-in works of art. Their communal project came to be known as Drop City, where residents lived in zonohedron domes of their own creation, sometimes constructed of automobile roofs and other scavenged materials. One dome, made of a fluorescent-painted lattice filled in with Mylar panels, made the trip east in 1968 to the Brooklyn Museum, filled with a five-foot-wide, round, spinning, “collaborative” work of art — “The Ultimate Painting” — that changed composition when illuminated by strobe lights.

headline: The Weeknd Tops the Billboard Charts
abstract: The once-shadowy Canadian R&B singer has completed his evolution from Internet triumph to full-blown pop star.
lead_paragraph: Abel Tesfaye, the once-shadowy Canadian R&B singer better known as the Weeknd, has completed his evolution from Internet triumph to full-blown pop star, hitting No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week.

headline: Will Ryman Prepares His New Exhibition at Paul Kasmin Gallery
abstract: The conflation of theater and visual arts, heightened in choreographed gallery settings, is a hallmark of the artist’s work.
lead_paragraph: A recent visit to Will Ryman’s cavernous two-story sculpture studio on Bowery, upstairs from a restaurant supply store, delivered a jolt of drama from the first encounter, when the artist opened the door to a back room.

headline: Museum of Food and Drink to Open Permanent Space in Brooklyn
abstract: The museum is opening its first permanent location, Mofad Lab, on Oct. 28 in Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Food and Drink, which is opening its first brick-and-mortar location this fall, wants to change how you think about what you eat.

headline: A Western Showdown With Mussels
abstract: Several states in the Rocky Mountains are checking boats hauled on highways to try to keep mussels from invading waterways.
lead_paragraph: COUTTS, Alberta — At an inspection station here on the border with Montana, a black dog in an orange vest briskly scoured the hull of a motorboat, her nose twitching as she investigated every crevice.

headline: A Feast of Egyptian Treasures, Picasso Sculptures and Eye-Catching Toys
abstract: The season includes exhibitions devoted to Egypt’s Middle Kingdom, Frank Gehry’s architecture, kinetic sculptures from the Netherlands, Hellenistic bronzes and much more.
lead_paragraph: The fall exhibitions are looking very three-dimensional, and as David Letterman often used to say, I couldn’t be more excited. Seriously. The shows that intrigue me most range from masterworks created in Middle Kingdom Egypt to Swedish wooden toys, the latest in “Afropolitan” architecture and beach-friendly kinetic sculptures. There should be a prize for anyone who sees every show.

headline: National Sawdust Prepares for an Oct. 1 Opening
abstract: A new nonprofit performance space in Brooklyn will play host to artists with “very, very strong identities,” its creative and executive director says.
lead_paragraph: Paola Prestini, the creative and executive director of National Sawdust, stood in the space’s balcony one recent afternoon, looking over what would soon be a bustling concert hall. “The speakers just came in,” she said cheerfully, pointing at a rig hanging from the ceiling, still in its filmy protective covering. A geometric metal framework crisscrossed the room’s far wall, next to the hydraulic platforms that will make for a flexible stage.

headline: The Tardigrade: Practically Invisible, Indestructible ‘Water Bears’
abstract: Growing in popularity if not in stature, the creature fascinates scientists with its ability to survive in extreme conditions.
lead_paragraph: When scientists at the American Museum of Natural History mounted an exhibit about creatures that survive under conditions few others can tolerate, they did not have to go far to find the show’s mascot.

headline: Ought’s ‘Sun Coming Down’: Polar Opposites, but Hand in Hand
abstract: “Sun Coming Down,” the second album from the Montreal band Ought, strikes a balance in its moods and sentiments.
lead_paragraph: “Beautiful Blue Sky,” a new song by the Montreal post-punk band Ought, might be the quickest way to understand what the group is all about.

headline: Janet Jackson’s ‘Unbreakable’ Is Right on Time
abstract: With a tour and the release of her latest album, Ms. Jackson reminds the music world that she was a forerunner of artists like Rihanna and Beyoncé.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé, Rihanna, Britney Spears, Janelle Monáe, F.K.A. twigs, Tinashe, Kelela — they’d probably all admit that Janet Jackson established their 21st-century archetypes decades in advance. So in a way, Ms. Jackson’s timing is appropriate for the release of “Unbreakable,” her first album since 2008 and the resumption of her collaboration with her longtime co-producers Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis.

headline: Republicans Fear Donald Trump Is Hardening Party’s Tone on Race
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Mr. Trump has given voice to conservative activists’ unease with America’s changing demography, prompting rivals to follow suit and worrying party leaders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans are growing increasingly concerned that Donald J. Trump’s inflammatory language is damaging the party, fearing that his remarks are hardening the tone of other candidates on racial issues in ways that could repel the voters they need to take back the White House.

headline: Premature Babies Study Raises Debate Over Risks and Ethical Consent
abstract: A judge rejected a lawsuit over whether families had been properly warned about health risks, but some bioethicists say the informed consent was not adequate.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, researchers in a clinical trial involving oxygen levels for the tiniest premature babies were accused by a federal watchdog agency of not properly disclosing the risks to families who participated.

headline: Guatemala Comedian Wins First Round of Presidential Vote
abstract: Jimmy Morales, a television comedian who campaigned under the slogan “Not corrupt, not a thief,” won almost 24 percent of the vote.
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — A comedian won the first round of voting in Guatemala’s presidential election, five days after a wave of protests forced the country’s president from office.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to articles in Science Times.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Former Leader of Chad Hauled Into Court as Trial Resumes
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Four masked guards pinned former President Hissène Habré to a chair in the courtroom in Senegal where he is being tried.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Shouting in protest, Chad’s former president was hauled by masked guards into a special court in Senegal on Monday as he began a new struggle with its judges over their right to try him on charges of crimes against humanity, torture and war crimes.

headline: Flies Want Your Blood, Too
abstract: Biting flies may differ from mosquitoes in appearance in habits, but they are all members of the group known as true flies.
lead_paragraph: Q. Mosquitoes are seeking blood, but what do flies get out of biting people?

headline: Networks and Cable Channels Go Mano a Mano
abstract: The broadcast networks still hold sway for the fall, but cable and streaming outlets are moving in.
lead_paragraph: The confoundingly persistent fall television season is upon us, when the broadcast networks present their new shows like shiny toys, most of them soon to be lost or thrown away.

headline: On ‘Scream Queens’ and ‘American Horror Story,’ Being Scary Is Terrifying
abstract: Despite new shows like “Scream Queens” and “Ash vs. Evil Dead” and returning series like “American Horror Story,” the fall season offers more laughter than terror.
lead_paragraph: I can remember the last time television made me laugh, and the last time it made me cry. But I can’t remember the last time a scripted TV show scared me, and that worries me, because I like a good scare. So do I have hopes for the fall season, which brings the high-profile newcomers “Scream Queens” and “Ash vs. Evil Dead” along with returning fright fare like “American Horror Story”?

headline: ‘Empire’ on Fox Has Become a Star Attraction
abstract: Season 2, with eight more episodes than its abbreviated winter run, again promises a wealth of big-name guest stars.
lead_paragraph: If your TV show is called “Empire,” there is no such thing as too much.

headline: After Deflategate, the Sequel on Wheels
abstract: Formula One auto racing has recently had its own version of deflated items that could have given a competitor an advantage. In this case, it’s not footballs but tires.
lead_paragraph: An important sporting event. Charges of impropriety involving deflation. Lots of references to “pounds per square inch.”

headline: Jesse Plemons Moves On and On From ‘Friday Night Lights’
abstract: The actor best known for his role on “Friday Night Lights” has gracefully moved from good guy to bad guy to just about every guy.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Growing up in Mart, Tex., a small town of 2,000 outside of Waco, Jesse Plemons grew up on 34 acres roping and riding and playing football. But for the most part, from before he was old enough to walk, he lived life on the edge of his sofa, a play gun at his side, rewatching the mini-series “Lonesome Dove,” about Larry McMurtry’s retired Texas Rangers and their epic adventure pushing cattle north. “I was always kind of by myself wishing I was Gus,” he said. “The older I got I started to try and trace just how Robert Duvall and Tommy Lee Jones did what they did to me, how they made me believe they were those people. I bought every part of their world. I guess I’ve sort of been chasing that honesty of theirs ever since.”

headline: Review: ‘Stoned: A Doctor’s Case for Medical Marijuana’
abstract: In his new book, Dr. David Casarett immerses himself in the culture, science and smoke of medical marijuana.
lead_paragraph: Two-legged or four-legged, some guinea pigs have more fun than others.

headline: Big-Budget Blockbusters Dominate Fall Video Games
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)', 'PlayStation 4 (Video Game System)']
abstract: The fall release schedule is dominated big-budget blockbusters, and the season is likely to see the first trickle of a rush of virtual-reality headsets marketed to ordinary consumers.
lead_paragraph: The twin rise of digital distribution and a robust independent scene has made video games more diverse, more rewarding and more unpredictable than at any time in the medium’s history. It’s usually hard to see much evidence of that, however, in the fall release schedule, which is dominated by big-budget blockbusters that too often play it safe.

headline: Jets’ Geno Smith Is Up for Drills, but Not for Questions
abstract: Speaking to reporters for the first time since a punch from a Jets teammate broke his jaw, Smith offered little information about the incident.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The last four weeks have given quarterback Geno Smith ample time to reflect — on his future with the Jets, on the Aug. 11 altercation that left him with a broken jaw, on his standing among his teammates — and he said he learned a valuable lesson.

headline: London Theater Journal: Firebrands
abstract: Ben Brantley reviews “The Heresy of Love” and “Jacqueline Wilson’s Hetty Feather.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The plight of the immensely talented 17th-century dramatist Sister Juana Inés de la Cruz is, on one level, sadly familiar to female playwrights of today. Though it is widely acknowledged that she wrote wondrously witty and accomplished works, she could not get them produced.

headline: The Detroit Graduates
abstract: Attention shifted away from Detroit after the bankruptcy. But for five high school students, life has moved on, sometimes in unexpected ways, as the city struggles to get back on its feet.
lead_paragraph: Attention shifted away from Detroit after the bankruptcy. But for five high school students, life has moved on, sometimes in unexpected ways, as the city struggles to get back on its feet.

headline: Fresh Face on TV: Yasmine Al Massri of ‘Quantico’
abstract: Ms. Massri, who grew up in Beirut and studied in Paris, plays a Muslim F.B.I. recruit on Joshua Safran’s new series, “Quantico.”
lead_paragraph: When Yasmine Al Massri read the part of Nimah Amin in Joshua Safran’s “Quantico,” she was shocked.

headline: Sandy Alderson Proposes Compromise for Mets’ Matt Harvey
abstract: Alderson, the general manager, discussed a plan with Harvey that would keep him in the rotation, but whether it passes muster with Scott Boras, Harvey’s forceful agent, remains to be seen.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours before the Mets began their biggest series of 2015 against the Washington Nationals on Monday, General Manager Sandy Alderson met with the team’s ace, Matt Harvey, and outlined a compromise plan designed to keep Harvey as a viable, if less active, member of the starting rotation in the season’s final weeks.

headline: Fresh Face on TV: Lee Jones of ‘The Bastard Executioner’
abstract: This Australian actor, the star of “The Bastard Executioner” on FX, was primarily a stage actor before his breakthrough in the show’s title role.
lead_paragraph: The key to a clean beheading, according to Lee Jones, is to come in at just the right angle. “You want to come in flat,” he said, “so you don’t have to go in and do extra chopping.”

headline: Fresh Face on TV: Jaina Lee Ortiz in ‘Rosewood’
abstract: “She’s Latina, she’s from New York, and she’s a homicide detective,” the actress says of her character, Annalise Villa. “Villa is me to a T.”
lead_paragraph: That police officer hovering in the corner of a crime scene? In real life, he’s the father of the actress Jaina Lee Ortiz. That salsa partner she’s burning up a dance floor with? None other than her husband.

headline: Oysters May Serve as Link in Transmission of Norovirus
abstract: The shellfish appear to be an important link in the transmission of norovirus among humans, according to research from China.
lead_paragraph: Oysters appear to be an important link in the transmission of norovirus among humans, according to new research from China.

headline: Prospect of Another Shutdown Looms as Congress Girds for Fights Over Spending
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: Lawmakers have scheduled 12 legislative days to find a compromise to keep the government open, debate the Iran deal and decide the future of Planned Parenthood funding.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Congress returns for business on Tuesday, lawmakers have scheduled a mere 12 legislative days to find a bipartisan compromise to keep the government open, vote on one of the most contentious foreign policy matters in a generation, reconcile the future of funding for Planned Parenthood and roll out the red carpet — and a few thousand folding chairs — to greet Pope Francis.

headline: The Iran Nuclear Deal: Congress Has Its Say
abstract: Both the House of Representatives and the Senate are scheduled to debate and vote on a resolution of disapproval over the Iran nuclear accord this week.
lead_paragraph: At the top of the agenda for Congress this month is a resolution disapproving President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran. Democrats have enough votes to sustain a presidential veto of the resolution and ensure that the deal will go into effect, but the debate will still be heated about an agreement that eases economic sanctions against Iran in exchange for new limits on its nuclear program. Here are some nuts and bolts on the situation about to unfold on Capitol Hill.

headline: Crowdfunding a $500 Million Ferris Wheel, With a Wall Street Spin
abstract: Project leaders of the 630-foot New York Wheel, which is being built on Staten Island, plan to attract investors via the 99Funding online crowdfunding platform, among others.
lead_paragraph: Investing in stocks is at times compared to a thrill ride — a rocket ship taking off, or a roller coaster rushing down.

headline: Israeli Film Director Delves Into Killing of Yitzhak Rabin
abstract: “Rabin: The Last Day,” directed by Amos Gitai, pries open the fissures of Israeli politics and society that led to Yitzhak Rabin’s assassination in 1995.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In one scene, a group of Jews wrapped in prayer shawls begin reciting a mystical death curse known as the Pulsa Dinura. A man in a suit who has urged them to invoke the angels of destruction promises that their prime minister, Yitzhak Rabin, “will be dead within a month.”

headline: Marketing to Sports Fans Online, With Help From Google and Social Networks
abstract: As brands try to align themselves with football games beyond television, Google, Facebook, Twitter and Snapchat shop around new marketing products.
lead_paragraph: When the National Football League season begins on Thursday, Google will not be merely sitting on the sidelines.

headline: Palestinian National Council Meeting Is Postponed Amid Boycotts
abstract: The council had been slated to convene next Monday and Tuesday to consider, among other things, the membership of the Palestine Liberation Organization’s executive committee.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A conference of the Palestinian National Council that had been scheduled for next week has been indefinitely postponed amid boycotts by some political factions and debate about the agenda and structure of the meeting. The 700-plus-member council, which has not had a regular session since 1996, was slated to convene in the West Bank city of Ramallah next Monday and Tuesday to consider, among other things, the membership of the Palestine Liberation Organization’s executive committee. The P.L.O. chairman, Mahmoud Abbas, who is also president of the Palestinian Authority, was to submit his resignation along with 10 of the executive committee’s 18 members, though it was unclear whether he and his colleagues would actually step down or stand for re-election. Whether Mr. Abbas truly plans to withdraw from political life or is trying to shake up the leadership in order to curtail criticism and consolidate power has been the subject of speculation for weeks.

headline: Patrick Drahi Positions Himself to Be a Player in U.S. Cable
abstract: Mr. Drahi, a French-Israeli billionaire, has charted a course to prominence in the cable industry that prizes expansion and relies heavily on debt.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When the French-Israeli billionaire Patrick Drahi bought a St. Louis cable TV company in May and was mentioned as a potential suitor for Time Warner Cable, it may have been the first time many Americans had heard his name.

headline: Readers’ Summer Highlight Reel
abstract: The New York Times asked readers on Twitter and Facebook to finish the sentence, “The best thing I did in New York City this summer was.” Here is a selection of the responses.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times asked readers on Twitter and Facebook to finish the sentence, “The best thing I did in New York City this summer was.” Here is a selection of the responses.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Compete For Union Support
abstract: In dueling town-hall meetings this weekend, Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders courted the endorsement of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
lead_paragraph: NEWTON, Iowa – Bernie Sanders recalled his days on picket lines. Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke out against privatizing government jobs.

headline: Companies Struggle to Comply With Rules on Conflict Minerals
keywords: ['Conflict Minerals and Resources', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Dodd-Frank Act requires companies to disclose their use of minerals mined in warring parts of Africa, a challenging task that involves tracking long and disjointed supply chains.
lead_paragraph: A pink My Little Pony balloon does not usually evoke images of rifle-toting warlords in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Still, Party City Holdings, the decorations and costumes retailer, recently disclosed a possible link to securities regulators, helping to put it near the bottom of a list ranking companies on their compliance with laws against using minerals mined in war-torn regions across Africa.

headline: Apple and Other Tech Companies Tangle With U.S. Over Data Access
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Computer Security', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Government conflicts with Apple and Microsoft reflect heightened resistance by businesses intent on demonstrating efforts to protect customer information.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an investigation involving guns and drugs, the Justice Department obtained a court order this summer demanding that Apple turn over, in real time, text messages between suspects using iPhones.

headline: Italy’s Highest Court Explains Decision to Clear Amanda Knox
abstract: The Court of Cassation said the inquiries into the killing of Meredith Kercher, for which Ms. Knox was convicted and later cleared, were flawed from the start.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy’s highest court said Monday that the case against the Seattle resident Amanda Knox and her former boyfriend — whose convictions in the 2007 murder of a British student were definitively overturned in March — was marked by “culpable omissions of investigative activity” and “contradictory evidence” that raised reasonable doubt of their guilt.

headline: For Online Sports Videos, the Action Is No Longer on the Field
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Young sports fans are increasingly drawn to a digital parallel world where videos of skateboarding, snowboarding, surfing and other “action sports” dominate.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Anyone who went to the Apple iTunes store to buy a movie in mid-August might have noticed that sitting in the digital queue, next to blockbusters like “Mad Max: Fury Road,” was the seemingly obscure title “We Are Blood,” which was not exactly a movie, but a video consisting mostly of skateboarders performing tricks.

headline: FIFA Ruling Forces Ben Lederman Back to U.S.
abstract: Lederman, the 15-year-old whose career at Barcelona was cut short by FIFA transfer regulations, plans to enroll at the IMG Academy in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Ben Lederman, the teenage soccer player whose career at Barcelona was cut short by FIFA transfer regulations, has returned to the United States and plans to enroll at the IMG Academy in Bradenton, Fla.

headline: Jon Batiste Will Lead ‘The Late Show With Stephen Colbert’ Band in a Style He Sees Fit
abstract: Mr. Batiste, 28, has a breezy disregard for genre pieties, and it’s easy to picture him acclimating fast to a late-night talk show.
lead_paragraph: There comes a point in almost any scheduled performance by Jon Batiste when he pops up from the piano and strides into the crowd, tootling his melodica, a toylike wind instrument, with bandmates in tow. It’s a trademark shtick that happens to carry a whiff of the authentic, given Mr. Batiste’s lifelong familiarity with New Orleans second-line parades. Naturally, it was one of the factors that led to his role as bandleader on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert,” which makes its debut on CBS on Tuesday.

headline: Mets’ David Wright Says It All: ‘What a Game’
abstract: The National League East-leading Mets took an early 3-0 lead in the opener of a three-game series, but they had to erase a 5-3 deficit to rebuild their advantage over the Nationals to five games.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — David Wright rounded third base, chugging as fast as he could with a bad back, and saw Tim Teufel, the Mets’ third-base coach, swinging his left arm like a windmill, waving him on. The Mets had just built a two-run lead in the top of the seventh, and now Teufel, going for the kill, wanted to make it three.

headline: Plague Cases in U.S. on the Rise
abstract: There have been 13 cases and three deaths from plague in the United States in the past five months. In a typical year, there are three cases annually.
lead_paragraph: There have been 13 cases and three deaths from plague in the United States in the past five months, but researchers do not know why the disease appears to be on the rise.

headline: Photo Zines Explore Singapore’s Identity
abstract: A series of zines produced by photographers in Singapore offer insider’s views of the country, its history and its eccentricities.
lead_paragraph: A series of zines produced by photographers in Singapore offer insider’s views of the country, its history and its eccentricities.

headline: Erica Jong’s ‘Fear of Dying’ Defies the Sunset of Sex
abstract: Forty-two years after her wildly successful “Fear of Flying,” the author’s new book challenges another taboo.
lead_paragraph: Two words have vexed Erica Jong for the last 42 years. The first is “zipless,” and the word that follows is not printable in this newspaper.

headline: Sara Little, Peripatetic Product Designer, Dies at 97
abstract: Ms. Little, who consulted for three decades for companies like 3M, General Mills and Coca-Cola, took inspiration from sources as varied as geishas, burglars and cheetahs.
lead_paragraph: Sara Little Turnbull, an innovative product designer who found inspiration for her work in geisha styles, a Kenyan game park, an American prison and other unlikely places, died on Friday at her home in Seattle. She was 97.

headline: Martin Milner, Clean-Cut Star of ‘Route 66’ and ‘Adam-12,’ Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Milner had a successful run in late-1950s movies (including “Sweet Smell of Success”) before finding stardom on television.
lead_paragraph: Martin Milner, an actor who broke out of supporting movie roles as the quintessential clean-cut young man to achieve television stardom as one of two road-hungry bachelors in “Route 66” and later as a veteran police officer in “Adam-12,” died on Sunday at his home in Carlsbad, Calif. He was 83.

headline: Review: ‘Fortune Smiles,’ Stories From Dark Places, by Adam Johnson
abstract: Like Mr. Johnson’s earlier fiction, this new collection has contemporary settings and features characters reeling from displacement and emotional vertigo.
lead_paragraph: Adam Johnson set his deeply affecting Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, “The Orphan Master’s Son,” in the hermit kingdom of North Korea, where government oppression and propaganda combine to make daily life as strange and harrowing as anything dreamed up by a dystopian satirist on hyperdrive. Mr. Johnson’s earlier writing — his 2002 story collection, “Emporium,” and his first novel, “Parasites Like Us” — also had a surreal, even sci-fi feel. And while many tales in his potent new collection, “Fortune Smiles,” have recognizable, contemporary settings, they, too, feature characters reeling from displacement, dislocation or emotional and cultural vertigo.

headline: Affinity and Inflation
abstract: The never-ending story.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong marvels at Peter Schiff insisting to Josh Barro that US inflation is far higher than the official statistics acknowledge, and hence that the economy is actually shrinking. Incidentally, the independent Billion Prices index — which is internet-based, and places a higher weight on goods as opposed to services including housing — is actually showing deflation right now.

headline: Timothy Snyder’s ‘Black Earth’ Puts Holocaust, and Himself, in Spotlight
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Mr. Snyder’s latest book is another example of his willingness to touch sensitive subjects and set off debate.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — When Timothy Snyder’s book “Bloodlands: Europe Between Hitler and Stalin” was published in 2010, it quickly established its author as one of the leading historians of his generation, a scholar who combined formidable linguistic skills — he reads or speaks 11 languages — with an elegant literary style, white-hot moral passion and a willingness to start arguments about some of the most fraught questions of the recent past.

headline: Review: ‘They Are Gone’ Is Kathryn Hamilton’s Play About Protest and Apathy
abstract: This multimedia work blends fiction and reality as it speaks to the power of artists to incite action with images.
lead_paragraph: A bare-breasted woman was gently beating a shirtless man with nunchaku sticks. Another woman was stapled to the wall by her hair, long strands of it wrapped across her eyes, mouth and throat.

headline: Review: Satellite Collective Mixes Media and Messages at BAM Fisher
abstract: The program included a poetic monologue, a stop-motion film, three dances pieces and a lot of creative voices.
lead_paragraph: Satellite Collective is an admirably cooperative endeavor and a peculiar one. Its program at BAM Fisher on Thursday included a poetic monologue, a stop-motion film and three dance pieces, with and without video accompaniment. Everything had live musical accompaniment, and there were standalone musical selections, too. Seven composers, three choreographers, one filmmaker, two writers, one lighting designer and three costume designers contributed, with some of those people wearing multiple hats. Even for a sampler, that’s a lot of creative voices.

headline: Children Tossing School Lunch Fruits and Vegetables
abstract: Requiring children to select a fruit or vegetable as part of the school lunch program has not resulted in more consumption of fruits and vegetables.
lead_paragraph: You can lead a child to vegetables, but it appears you can’t make him eat.

headline: Expecting Little, Simona Halep Finally Reaches Round of 8
abstract: Halep reached the U.S. Open quarterfinals for the first time, beating 24th-seeded Sabine Lisicki in three sets, and Petra Kvitova defeated Johanna Konta to match the feat.
lead_paragraph: Simona Halep is the No. 2 seed at the United States Open, and she entered her round of 16 match with more hardcourt victories this year than any other woman in the main draw, having compiled a 35-5 record.

headline: Plutonium Is Unsung Concession in Iran Nuclear Deal
abstract: In the proposed nuclear agreement, Tehran promises to forsake production of plutonium, potent fuel for an atom bomb.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the metals that give atom bombs their destructive fury might seem interchangeable: Uranium and plutonium are both more valuable than gold. Both captivate would-be atomic powers. And both fueled bombs that leveled Japanese cities — uranium at Hiroshima and plutonium at Nagasaki.

headline: West African Child Is Paralyzed by Vaccine-Derived Polio
abstract: The patient’s parents traveled from Guinea to Mali seeking medical care. An emergency vaccination drive is being organized to forestall an outbreak.
lead_paragraph: A case of vaccine-derived polio has paralyzed a child in Bamako, the capital of Mali, and an emergency vaccination drive is being organized to forestall an outbreak, the World Health Organization announced Monday.

headline: European Farmers Demand Aid as Produce Prices Sag
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Commodities', 'Milk', 'Pork']
abstract: As a protest raged in Brussels, agriculture ministers were holding a special session to consider an aid package worth $560 million.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Thousands of farmers snarled traffic and pelted the police with eggs on Monday in a protest to demand emergency aid to offset falling prices for milk, pork and other agricultural products.

headline: Migrant Influx May Give Europe’s Far Right a Lift
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Parties in opposition to immigration, Islam’s influence and the European Union are pointing out the difficulty of now shutting the migrant tap.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Europe basks in good feelings over its generosity to thousands of migrants and asylum seekers last weekend, critical voices from the political right and far right are poised to become among the biggest beneficiaries of the continuing flow.

headline: Hillary Clinton: Puppy Mills Can be Cruel
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Dogs', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Presidential candidates need to be prepared for any questions, even those about animals.
lead_paragraph: NEWTON, Iowa – It was not the Iran deal, or her private email server, that a woman at a crowded coffee shop wanted to question Hillary Rodham Clinton about on Sunday.

headline: Russia Answers U.S. Criticism Over Military Aid to Syria
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Foreign Aid', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Sharp exchanges between the U.S. and Russia over Russian military aid to the Syrian government appeared to have dampened a brief spirit of cooperation.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Foreign Ministry here expressed surprise on Monday over an American warning to Russia against escalating the conflict in Syria, saying that the Kremlin’s Syrian policy — in particular furnishing military aid to help the government confront extremist forces — had been consistent for years.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Show More Humor and Heart, Aides Say
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Staff members say the noise and distractions of modern campaigning have obscured these sides of Mrs. Clinton’s personality.
lead_paragraph: There will be no more flip jokes about her private email server. There will be no rope lines to wall off crowds, which added to an impression of aloofness. And there will be new efforts to bring spontaneity to a candidacy that sometimes seems wooden and overly cautious.

headline: ‘The Fix,’ a Ribald Musical About Political Showmanship
abstract: The Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., seizes on a fractious election season to restage this 1997 work about the dark arts of campaigning.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — Even against the backdrop of a circuslike election season replete with investigations of a private email account and mudslinging by a billionaire reality television star, the plot of the “The Fix,” a musical about the dark arts of campaigning, is sordid enough to give political operatives pause.

headline: Greg Bird’s Walk Aids Yankees, and His Homer Wins Game
abstract: In the fifth, after pretending to be hit by a pitch and then being called back into the batter’s box, Bird drew a walk. In the seventh, after the Orioles had tied the game, he hit a three-run shot.
lead_paragraph: With the Yankees mounting a fifth-inning rally Monday, Greg Bird wanted to reach base by any means necessary. The Orioles’ Wei-Yin Chen threw Bird an inside pitch, and Bird, a 22-year-old rookie, winced as if he had been hit.

headline: Mindy Kaling: By the Book
abstract: The actress, producer and author, most recently, of “Why Not Me?” secretly read in bed as a child. “My parents encouraged reading, but they didn’t anticipate me reading Michael Crichton’s ‘Sphere’ until 2 a.m. on a school night.”
lead_paragraph: The actress, producer and author, most recently, of “Why Not Me?” secretly read in bed as a child. “My parents encouraged reading, but they didn’t anticipate me reading Michael Crichton’s ‘Sphere’ until 2 a.m. on a school night.”

headline: Dispute at Coke Bottling Plant Could Signal Labor Challenges for E.U.
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Strikes', 'Organized Labor', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A decision due from a Spanish court could test the government’s effort to give employers flexibility to address the country’s high unemployment rate.
lead_paragraph: FUENLABRADA, Spain — Can a Spanish court force a multinational company to bottle Coca-Cola against its will?

headline: Raymond Kelly, Ex-Police Commissioner, Blames Mayor de Blasio for Rise in Killings
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: Mr. Kelly, whose memoir comes out on Tuesday, said the administration’s curtailing of police stops in New York had led to more violence.
lead_paragraph: Former Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said last week that Mayor Bill de Blasio’s constraints on the stop-and-frisk strategy of the Bloomberg administration was to blame for the uptick in murders in New York City. Mr. Kelly also attributed the rise in homicides in other cities to a backlash to the killing last year of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo.

headline: India’s Middle-Class Revolt
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Caste Systems', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A protest by ​500,000 ​members of a relatively well-off caste is a rebuke of the government’s economic policies.
lead_paragraph: Protests by members of a relatively prosperous caste in India who want to be included in affirmative action programs highlight a major problem: India isn’t creating enough good jobs. This is a big challenge to Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who has built his political career on promises to reform and modernize the stalled economy.

headline: A Jogging Biden Hears Calls to ‘Run, Joe, Run!’
abstract: The vice president repeatedly responded with a word of thanks but no hint of what he may do.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The calls of encouragement could be heard on nearly every block as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. jogged his way through the Labor Day parade here.

headline: Serpico, Seeking Seat on Town Board, Sees Corruption and Pledges to Fight It
abstract: Frank Serpico, whose whistle-blowing in the New York Police Department made him a household name, is running for office in Stuyvesant, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: STUYVESANT, N.Y. — He no longer looks like the young, full-haired, wild-eyed officer played by Al Pacino in the 1973 film “Serpico.” But the real Frank Serpico, 79, was still energetic and loquacious as he headed from his secluded cabin in this small upstate town to visit the local county fair last week on its opening day.

headline: A Los Angeles Plan to Reshape the Streetscape Sets Off Fears of Gridlock
keywords: ['Transit Systems', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'City Councils']
abstract: The City Council has approved a far-reaching transportation program that is part of a larger push to get people out of their cars and onto sidewalks.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — This city of fast cars and endless freeways is preparing to do what not long ago would have been unthinkable: sacrificing car lanes to make way for bikes and buses.

headline: Palestinians Pay Homage to a 3rd Firebomb Victim
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Palestinians', 'ARSON', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Riham Dawabsheh was the third member of her family to die after their home in the West Bank was firebombed on July 31 by suspected Jewish extremists.
lead_paragraph: DUMA, West Bank — Palestinians in Duma held their third funeral in six weeks, as they buried victims of an arson attack in which Jewish extremists have been accused. First, they buried a toddler, Ali Dawabsheh, then his father, and on Monday, they buried his mother, Riham Dawabsheh, each dying of injuries sustained in the fire on July 31.

headline: Clinging to Blinders, Victoria Azarenka Closes In
abstract: Azarenka, a fiery Belarussian, isn’t looking ahead, but she’s prepared for what the future brings, including a possible showdown against Serena Williams in the U.S. Open final.
lead_paragraph: Oh, look, Victoria Azarenka won her fourth-round match on Monday at the United States Open, letting our vision of a final against Serena Williams live on.

headline: What Are a Hospital’s Costs? Utah System Is Trying to Learn
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Most businesses know the cost of everything that goes into producing what they sell — essential information for setting prices. Medicine is different.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Only in the world of medicine would Dr. Vivian Lee’s question have seemed radical. She wanted to know: What do the goods and services provided by the hospital system where she is chief executive actually cost?

headline: Judy Carne, ‘Sock It to Me’ Girl on ‘Laugh-In,’ Dies at 76
abstract: Ms. Carne rocketed to pop culture fame on “Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In,” before her career was derailed by drug arrests and a near-fatal accident.
lead_paragraph: Judy Carne, a sprightly British actress and comedian who rocketed to pop culture fame as the “sock it to me” girl on “Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In,” a landmark of television zaniness, before her career was derailed by drug arrests and a near-fatal automobile accident, died on Thursday in Northampton, England. She was 76.

headline: Decoding Steve Jobs, in Life and on Film
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The efforts to paint Steve Jobs as either hero or villain miss a larger truth: He can be both and still be worthy of acclaim.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four years after Steve Jobs died, a debate is still raging.

headline: Rehab, Degree, Playoffs. Two Down, One to Go.
abstract: Blue Jays pitcher Marcus Stroman, who finished his degree at Duke while recovering from knee surgery, is eager to join a pennant race less than six months after the operation.
lead_paragraph: PAWTUCKET, R.I. — Marcus Stroman cried when a doctor told him in March that he had torn his anterior cruciate ligament after falling in a spring training fielding drill. He called his father, his mother and Ryan Bahnsen, his best friend from high school on Long Island.

headline: Rail Biking Arrives in Adirondacks, but Future of Track Is in Doubt
keywords: ['Railroads', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Bicycles and Bicycling']
abstract: A new company called Rail Explorers has attracted thousands of visitors to ride a six-mile stretch of abandoned railroad track, but the state has targeted the railroad for demolition.
lead_paragraph: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y. — Hoots, hollers and laughter echoed through the air as passengers aboard a mechanical device, previously unknown to the Adirondacks, made their way through the woods.

headline: Cardale Jones Settles Question and Ohio State Provides Exclamation Point
abstract: Jones, a redshirt junior, started over J. T. Barrett against Virginia Tech. Another former starting quarterback, Braxton Miller, made big plays as a halfback.
lead_paragraph: BLACKSBURG, Va. — The greatest trick play that Coach Urban Meyer has so far devised may have been letting all the focus be on who would start at quarterback when Ohio State opened the season against Virginia Tech on Monday night.

headline: Second Review Says Classified Information Was in Hillary Clinton’s Email
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign disagreed with the conclusion of the inquiry looking into messages received by the former secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A special intelligence review of two emails that Hillary Rodham Clinton received as secretary of state on her personal account — including one about North Korea’s nuclear weapons program — has endorsed a finding by the inspector general for the intelligence agencies that the emails contained highly classified information when Mrs. Clinton received them, senior intelligence officials said.

headline: Migrants Who Survived Shipwreck Are Grateful, but Disillusioned
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: The 2013 sinking of a flimsy boat carrying more than 500 people off the Italian island of Lampedusa was a signature moment in Europe’s migration crisis. Survivors share their stories.
lead_paragraph: SANDVIKEN, Sweden — As tens of thousands of migrants run the gantlet of dangers to reach Europe, Natanael Haile, a refugee from Eritrea now living in Sweden, is struggling to get over his nightmarish journey.

headline: Andy Murray, Blanked in Tiebreaker, Falls at U.S. Open
abstract: Kevin Anderson, who ended the 4-hour-18-minute match with a shutout in the fourth-set tiebreaker, reached the quarterfinals at a major for the first time, upending the third-seeded Murray.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray had built a record of consistent excellence since the beginning of 2011. He had played in 18 major tournaments and reached the quarterfinals each time, winning twice, including at the 2012 U.S. Open.

headline: Yazidis Settle in Nebraska, but Roots Run Deep in Iraq
abstract: Decades before the rise of the Islamic State, members of a persecuted sect began settling in Lincoln, now thought to have the largest concentration in America.
lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Neb. — They came to America seeking the freedom to pray and work in peace. But in death, many hoped to be buried among the hills of their homeland, in northern Iraq.

headline: Rebecca Livengood, Nathaniel Wenstrup
abstract: The couple went to Yale, but did not meet until a summer job brought them together.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Jane Livengood and Nathaniel Christian Wenstrup are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Charles Kroloff at the vacation home of the bride’s parents in Culver Lake, N.J.

headline: Rickie Fowler Edges Henrik Stenson as Playoff Field Narrows
abstract: Fowler, who shot a three-under-par 68 to win the Deutsche Bank Championship by a shot, and the rest of the top 70 in the FedEx Cup standings advance to the BMW Championship.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — The day before the start of the Deutsche Bank Championship, Collin MacDonald, a teenage volunteer, caught up to his favorite player, Rickie Fowler. He had met Fowler two years ago, when he carried a scoring standard for Fowler’s group. He had returned to do the same job this year, and on Thursday he said he told Fowler, “Maybe on Monday afternoon everything will click together.”

headline: J’ouvert and the Annual West Indian Parade
abstract: Thousands of revelers line the streets in Brooklyn each year for the event, which celebrates Caribbean culture.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of revelers line the streets in Brooklyn each year for the event, which celebrates Caribbean culture.

headline: Somewhat Family-Friendly
abstract: How will you rate Jacob Stulberg’s puzzle?
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — The day that The Boy could go “legally” see a PG THIRTEEN movie with us was a happy day indeed. I don’t even remember the movie. I just remember the distinct lack of whining when we didn’t have to leave him behind.

headline: Jason Pierre-Paul Visits Giants Two Months After Injury
abstract: Team officials and Pierre-Paul, a defensive end who lost his right index finger in a fireworks accident, began deliberations about when he might be ready to play.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — About two months after a Fourth of July fireworks accident cost him his right index finger, Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul flew to the New York area on Monday to meet with the team’s medical personnel. It was the first time the Giants had seen the damage to Pierre-Paul’s hand.

headline: Vulgar Videos Lead to Ouster of 2 Canadian Candidates From Ballot
abstract: The Conservative Party dropped the pair after embarrassing footage surfaced of pranks committed several years ago.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The governing Conservative Party of Canada on Monday dropped two of its candidates for the House of Commons because of embarrassing videos featuring them.

headline: South Korea: North Agrees to Reunions
abstract: South and North Korea agreed to arrange for hundreds of elderly relatives separated during the Korean War to meet siblings and other family members next month.
lead_paragraph: South and North Korea agreed Tuesday to arrange for hundreds of relatives separated during the Korean War to meet siblings and other family members next month in those families’ first reunions in more than six decades. The 1950-53 Korean War — which was halted by a truce, not by a formal peace treaty — left the Korean Peninsula divided and numerous Koreans separated from their relatives. The so-called separated family members have never been allowed to exchange letters or meet each other, unless both governments arranged occasional reunions limited to a few hundred people. The last such reunions took place in February last year. After an overnight negotiation at the border village of Panmunjom, the two Koreas signed an agreement on Tuesday to hold a new round of family reunions at the Diamond Mountain resort in the southeast of North Korea on Oct. 20-26. The nations agreed in principle to a new round of reunions during an Aug. 25 deal to defuse a military showdown along the border.

headline: Verizon to Offer Free Mobile TV, With an Eye on Millennials
abstract: Aimed at millennials, the service, Go90, will be available to all users, not just Verizon customers. It will include shows from Comedy Central, Food Network, ESPN, NFL Network and Discovery.
lead_paragraph: Verizon Communications is hoping that millennials will start flipping their mobile phones 90 degrees and streaming live and on-demand television.

headline: Doctors’ Association Sees Harm in Insurance Mergers
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Hospitals', 'Doctors']
abstract: The American Medical Association says the proposed merger of Anthem and Cigna, along with that of Aetna and Humana, could reduce competition in 154 metropolitan areas in 23 states.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Doctors and hospitals are stepping up their criticism of proposed health insurance company mergers.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | multilingual
abstract: This word has appeared in 56 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: multilingual • \ˈməl-te-ˈliN-gwəl, -ˈliN-gyə-wəl\ • adjective

headline: Roger Federer Solves John Isner’s Serve, Finally, and Advances
abstract: Federer, the No. 2 seed, earned a rare break of Isner’s serve and won in straight sets, advancing to play Richard Gasquet in the quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: Roger Federer saved the break of serve for last, doing what no man had managed to do at the U.S. Open against John Isner since 2013.

headline: Jean-Georges Vongerichten Has Designs on South Street Seaport
abstract: The chef is teaming up with the Howard Hughes Corporation on an ambitious new food market starting in 2017.
lead_paragraph: The chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten is planning an ambitious new food market to anchor the culinary offerings at the South Street Seaport starting in 2017.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 8, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “In this country — in Soviet times, in czarist times — nobody thinks about the next generation.”

headline: Corrections: September 8, 2015
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, September 8, 2015.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: What’s On TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:15 A.M. (HBO Signature) GHOST TOWN (2008) After a near-death experience during a colonoscopy, Bertram Pincus (Ricky Gervais, in bed), a misanthropic Manhattan dentist, starts to see spirits — namely, Frank Herlihy (Greg Kinnear), a two-timing yuppie who was hit by a bus while avoiding a falling air-conditioner. He wants Bertram to befriend his widow, Gwen (Téa Leoni), and prevent her from remarrying. She hates Bertram, and then she doesn’t. “A latter-day hybrid of ‘Topper’ and ‘Blithe Spirit’ and a visual ode to autumn in New York, ‘Ghost Town’ is a screwball comedy with no big surprises or hidden metaphors,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this romantic froth, directed by David Koepp. But instead of becoming “mired in sentimentality like flies in molasses,” the film “tiptoes to the edge of that sticky mess, but it doesn’t get caught there.”

headline: Photo Zines That Explore Singapore’s Identity
abstract: A series of zines produced by photographers in Singapore offer insider’s views of the country, ranging from transformations in its urban landscape to its social ills to the hidden history of one participant’s grandfather.
lead_paragraph: For years, Sim Chi Yin had felt unique, if out of place, within her family. Since starting out at Singapore’s The Straits Times in 2001, and later switching careers to become a full-time photographer, she never seemed to gain their approval.

headline: Violence and Mental Illness
abstract: Just because someone who commits a terrible crime has a “mental problem” does not mean it is a treatable psychiatric illness.

abstract: Readers discuss what the inability to replicate more than half of 100 psychology studies means for the profession.

keywords: ['E-Cigarettes', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']

headline: Teachers Aren’t Dumb
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Education (K-12)', 'Vocational Training', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: But a lot of the training they get in school sure is.
lead_paragraph: ONE of my colleagues at the University of Virginia, a world authority on how culture influences personality, almost didn’t become a professor. He wanted to teach high school, but went for his Ph.D. because it seemed easier; he thought he would fail the exacting admissions test for teacher candidates. Perhaps I should mention that my colleague is from Japan.

headline: The Price for Lowering Cholesterol
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Cholesterol', 'Praluent (Drug)', 'Repatha (Drug)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Statins (Cholesterol-Lowering Drugs)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: Two new powerful drugs have been approved. The question is whether the benefits will outweigh the long-term costs.
lead_paragraph: Two new, powerful and expensive drugs to treat very high cholesterol are raising concerns about the ability of public and private insurers to pay and whether the benefits the drugs bring will outweigh their long-term costs.

headline: When Congress Puts NASA on Hold, Planets Don’t Wait
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Government shutdowns and congressional budget battles can have disastrous effects on scientific research.
lead_paragraph: THE United States asks NASA to do an extraordinary amount with very little money. Explore Mars, document climate change, stop doomsday asteroids, find life on Europa — all for less than one-half of 1 percent of the federal budget. But budget uncertainties on Capitol Hill, including delays in federal appropriations legislation and temporary government shutdowns, measurably harm the American space program. Even the threat of a shutdown can have a far-reaching impact on scientific projects, often in unexpected ways.

Mr. Abe will remain party leader for a second three-year term.

This summer three American politicians have risen to the fore, and they all sit outside or at the margin of the party they are trying to lead.

lead_paragraph: About once a month since the Napa Valley Wine Train began chugging through California’s wine country in 1989, the sound of clinking stemware has been accompanied by the spectacle of passengers being removed from the train.

headline: Donald Trump Likens His Schooling to Military Service in Book

headline: The Stylish Men of Tumblr
abstract: A visit with the employees of the short-form blogging platform at their Manhattan office.
lead_paragraph: Worker bees buzz through Tumblr’s headquarters in the Flatiron district of Manhattan. With so many young employees, who move between glass-walled conference rooms and a rooftop patio, the place is vibrant. Founded by David Karp in 2007 as a medium for short-form blogs and acquired by Yahoo for $1.1 billion in 2013, Tumblr has hosted more than 115 billion posts. Its users, nearly half of whom are ages 13 to 34, according to the company, add 85 million more each day. People use their Tumblrs for all sorts of things, from old-fashioned cat appreciation to sad-kid blogging, but fashion is the platform’s largest area of interest. We visited Tumblr recently in search of tech chic.

headline: Camp for Migrants in Hungary
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Several hundred people, including children, spent the night in tents at a reception center in an open field in Roszke, Hungary, after crossing into the country from Serbia.
lead_paragraph: Several hundred people, including children, spent the night in tents at a reception center in an open field in Roszke, Hungary, after crossing into the country from Serbia.

headline: Scott Shane’s ‘Objective Troy’
abstract: Barack Obama, Anwar al-Awlaki and the dilemmas posed by America’s use of a contentious weapon.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most difficult political, legal and moral issues in counterterrorism involve the use by the United States of unmanned aerial vehicles, commonly known as drones, to kill suspected terrorists in faraway places. These issues arose in especially salient and acute form regarding Anwar al-Awlaki, who became the first American citizen since at least the Civil War to be hunted down and intentionally killed overseas by his own government without his case’s ever being considered in a court. At the time he died in September 2011, Awlaki was probably the most prominent jihadi terrorist in the world apart from Osama bin Laden. The president who announced that death, Barack Obama, has become identified with drone strikes since they are the principal tool his administration has used to fight international terrorists. Scott Shane’s “Objective Troy” (the title refers to the military’s code name for Awlaki) is a lucid and richly informed account of how these two men came to occupy their respective places in the history of the drone age.

headline: Lauren Groff’s ‘Fates and Furies’
abstract: Groff’s new novel about a long-term relationship is a tale told twice, first from the husband’s perspective, then the wife’s.
lead_paragraph: There’s always the danger, with novels structured around a marriage, that they’ll be perceived as centrally concerned not only with that particular relationship but with the nature of marriage itself. A domestic union set prominently in a work of fiction has the sometimes unfortunate capacity to obscure whatever else is going on. Yet “Fates and Furies,” Lauren Groff’s remarkable new novel, explodes and rages past any such preconceptions, insisting that the examination of a long-term relationship can be a perfect vehicle for exploring no less than the nature of existence — the domestic a doorway to the philosophical.

headline: Hotel and Resort News: Music in Paris, Coffee Lessons in Orlando

headline: Yanis Varoufakis: How Europe Crushed Greece
abstract: We had a plan to fix the debt crisis, but divisions between France and Germany over how to run the eurozone buried it.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Since the beginning of Greece’s financial crisis in 2010, two prime ministers have been swept from office after they were forced to adopt an unfeasible package of austerity measures in exchange for a bailout from the troika, as the eurozone authorities — the European Commission, the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund — are known. It pains me to watch the same fate befall a third prime minister, my friend and comrade Alexis Tsipras.

headline: ScienceTake | The Hummingbird’s Tongue
abstract: Drinking nectar requires a tongue that fits the flower and works like a pump.
lead_paragraph: Drinking nectar requires a tongue that fits the flower and works like a pump.

headline: The Hummingbird’s Tongue: How It Works
abstract: Hummingbirds have forked tongues that spring open once inserted into a flower acting like a pump to draw out nectar.
lead_paragraph: Hummingbirds are great subjects for evolutionary biologists because they are so extreme. They live at a fast pace, wings a blur, tongue darting in and out of flowers at a frenetic pace, often 15 or 20 times a second.

headline: Morning Agenda: More Signs of a Sharper Slowdown in China

China’s trade slump deepened in August — an indication of a sharper industrial slowdown at home and weaker demand from overseas. Exports fell 5.5 percent in August and 1.4 percent in dollar terms in the first eight months of the year.

headline: Today in Politics: Summer Lull Ends as Old Fights Greet Congress and Campaigns
abstract: Congress returns on Tuesday from its summer break to a potentially tumultuous month, beginning with a fight over the Iran nuclear agreement, despite its predetermined outcome.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning. Lawmakers return from their breaks well rested and ready to pick up the gauntlets from where they had dropped them. With Labor Day behind them, Congress and the presidential candidates have a chance to reassess their battle plans and to gird for the next stage of the fight.

headline: What Is the Point of College?
abstract: Is it supposed to train students, or transform them? Can these two perspectives be reconciled?
lead_paragraph: I gave my first university lecture in philosophy at the University of Ghana, Legon, when I was a freshly credentialed 21-year-old. My audience was a couple of hundred students gathered in a vast hall, with ceiling fans to move the hot and humid air. Above the murmur of the fans and the muttering of students, I tried to explain why Descartes thought the mere possibility that there was an Evil Demon deceiving their senses meant they couldn’t know for sure that I was really there. Ah, Cartesian skepticism! I remember diagraming the structure of the argument in huge chalk letters on an enormous blackboard.

headline: Is College Tuition Really Too High?
keywords: ['Tuition', 'Colleges and Universities', 'For-Profit Schools', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'United States Economy', 'Education', 'Grants (Corporate and Foundation)']
abstract: The answer depends on what you mean by college.
lead_paragraph: To understand the feeling of crisis that many see in higher education right now, it’s useful to start with some figures from 40 years ago. In 1974, the median American family earned just under $13,000 a year. A new home could be had for $36,000, an average new car for $4,400. Attending a four-year private college cost around $2,000 a year: affordable, with some scrimping, to even median earners. As for public university, it was a bargain at $510 a year. To put these figures in current dollars, we’re talking about median family income of $62,000, a house for $174,000 and a sticker price of $21,300 for the car, $10,300 for the private university and $2,500 for the public one.

headline: Why There’s Disagreement Over Screening Every Child for Autism
abstract: Pediatricians tend to favor universal screening, but a national task force says there is no conclusive evidence to back that position.
lead_paragraph: Few would dispute that children who are exhibiting signs or symptoms of autistic spectrum disorder should be referred and tested. It is when we talk about screening every child for autism that the debate becomes heated.

headline: On Europe’s Goth Trail, From the Brontës to Byron
abstract: Three other places in England and Switzerland where fans of the Gothic Romantic movement can connect with writers of the past.
lead_paragraph: Dracula not enough for you? Need more literary scares? Here are some other spots to follow in the footsteps of other Gothic writers.

headline: Where Dracula Was Born, and It’s Not Transylvania
abstract: Bram Stoker found inspiration for his famous Gothic villain in an unlikely place — a sunny seaside Yorkshire village.
lead_paragraph: From its quay in early summer, Whitby was a sun-scrubbed idyll, fluttering with the trimmings of a typical English seaside holiday. Souvenir shops hawked postcards and sand toys, pub bartenders poured midday pints of beer, and the smell of fish and chips hung on the breeze. Along the shore, a row of rainbow-hued beach huts sheltered swimmers brave enough to take a dip in the North Sea. A group of sunburned schoolchildren raced through cobblestone streets, past antiques shops and tearooms, toward the 199 steps ascending to a cliff. I followed them, listening as their excited chatter gave way to dead silence. “Please, Miss,” a little girl appealed to her teacher in an unnerved tone, “I can’t go up there.”

headline: In a New Show, Lanvin’s Process Comes Into Focus
abstract: An exhibition in Paris examines the brand by tracing garments from conception to production.
lead_paragraph: Alber Elbaz is, perhaps, the least high-tech designer working in fashion today. “You know, I don’t drive, I don’t have computers, I don’t use the Internet,” the 54-year-old Lanvin designer says. “Technology brings everything to us fast, but I find it makes things more flat — you don’t hear the voice, you don’t know the truth.” Because of this, Elbaz says he finds clothes today more “flat” than ever: “hard edges, bright colors, prints — things that look good in the 2D.” But, he emphasizes, fashion is a 3D art: “It’s not only about the front and back. It’s everything in between.”

headline: 1915: Tsar Stimulates Russians
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Tsar decides to fight from the front in 1915.
lead_paragraph: Latest advices from newspaper correspondents in Petrograd indicate that the Tsar’s decision to take the field in person, coupled with the comparatively encouraging news from the front, where all the German efforts to break through the Dvina line have failed and where the enemy is elsewhere checked and hampered by resolute rearguard actions, has greatly encouraged the people, who believe that the tide of military fortune is about to turn. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 9, 1915

headline: A New Wave of Migrants Flees Iraq, Yearning for Europe
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Emboldened by media coverage showing their countrymen and fellow Arabs fleeing the war in Syria, many who had resisted leaving during past crises now see a chance to go.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Having sold his car for $4,600, and then some of his wife’s jewelry, and having loaded his smartphone with photographs of his five children, all that was left for Haider Abdella to do was say goodbye.

headline: Will the World Come To Europe?
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Population', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Is this year’s refugee crisis an extraordinary exception, or a sign of things to come?
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column took up the question of the world’s obligations to Syrian refugees, and looked back to an earlier column to question the wisdom of Germany’s present open door policy. Given the demographic pressure facing Europe over the next half-century— the aging of the native population and the rapid population growth to Europe’s southeast and (especially) south — I argued that the continent needs to manage migration policy very carefully, or risk a dramatic escalation of its existing assimilation problem (and the nativist backlash associated with it).

headline: 1940: East End Poor Suffer in Raids
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The poor in East London suffer from air raids in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For nearly ten miles in the East End of London there was a scene of devastation today such as is not often seen in the course of history. It is the result of the hellishness which broke loose yesterday afternoon and last night, when mass formations of Nazi bombers dropped load after load on military objectives in the dock areas and civilian homes alike. For every military objective hit, there are two or three civilian buildings smashed to smithereens. The grim thing about this war is that the poor people are getting the worst of it. For it is the working-class people, living and toiling for a couple of pounds a week, who live in the dock areas behind the factories and warehouses and gas and oil tanks which the Nazis are attempting to destroy. — New York Herald Tribune, September 9, 1940

headline: Setting Aside Shame and Blame in Financial Decisions
abstract: Not only does shame fail at changing behavior, it can also trigger the mistakes you are trying to avoid.
lead_paragraph: I’m a huge advocate of the “no shame, no blame” rule when it comes to money. But I think there’s some confusion about how the rule works. It’s not that you won’t feel guilt. It’s also not about avoiding responsibility. Instead, it’s about recognizing the zero-sum game of relying on shame and blame to make better money decisions.

headline: ‘Black Mass’ Resurrects Boston’s Long Memories of Whitey Bulger
abstract: Recalling the crime boss and longtime fugitive, endless fodder for films and the subject of a new movie starring Johnny Depp.
lead_paragraph: Whitey Bulger, the Boston crime boss who is the subject of “Black Mass,” Scott Cooper’s new movie starring Johnny Depp and opening on Sept. 18, is probably the most mythologized gangster since Al Capone. Mr. Cooper, who took over the project from Barry Levinson, said recently that he had been fascinated by the Whitey story for years, and that in 2011, when Mr. Bulger was discovered hiding in Santa Monica, Calif., of all places, it seemed like a filmmaker’s godsend. “I was gobsmacked,” he said. “And to think he had been living just miles from my house.”

headline: Review: ‘Welcome to Leith,’ a Documentary About a Town Fighting a Racist Takeover
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: This documentary charts how a tiny North Dakota town united to block a racist’s plan to turn their enclave into a haven for white supremacists.
lead_paragraph: There are a few moments in “Welcome to Leith,” a documentary about a North Dakota town that resists being taken over by white supremacists, when the film might be mistaken for a horror movie about an alien invasion. Only one business operates in this village of 24 residents, mostly farmers and ranchers, in Grant County. Three years ago, a scruffy gray-bearded stranger with beady eyes appeared and began buying properties in the area. When his real estate spree ended, he had accumulated at least a dozen plots of land.

headline: Facts & Figures: Cutting Carbon Could Save Cities Almost $17 Trillion

headline: Inside the Artist Joan Jonas’s SoHo Loft
abstract: Filled with light, works and no shortage of artfully depicted dogs, her home and studio is steeped in the Canadian wilderness.
lead_paragraph: It was in 1974 that Joan Jonas, the American artist who represented the U.S. at the 56th annual Venice Biennale this May with the triumphant multimedia installation “They Come to Us Without a Word,” moved into a vast, light-filled loft on Mercer Street. And for the past 40-something years, it has served the many purposes you might imagine for an artist’s space in SoHo: a home, a studio, a theater stage (Jonas would perform for a room full of friends and artists in the ’70s) — even a film set, on which her dogs have been known to wander randomly and end up as part of the final product. “My dogs are all a bit mystical,” Jonas says about the three she has owned over the course of her career, while her current dog, a dashing white poodle named Ozu, sleeps on a large green pillow nestled in front of a small library reserved for Jonas’s “absolute favorite books.”
