lead_paragraph: My brother Ned had spent eight hours painting crates on a Chinatown roof in 94-degree heat when I picked him up to go shopping.

headline: Mike Huckabee (Not Ted Cruz) Captures Spotlight at Kim Davis Event
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Mike Huckabee captured the political spotlight on Tuesday, rallying to the side of Kim Davis, the Kentucky clerk who refused to issue marriage licenses to gay couples, and casting her fight as a choice between tyranny and religious freedom.
lead_paragraph: Mike Huckabee captured the political spotlight on Tuesday, rallying to the side of Kim Davis, the Kentucky clerk who went to jail for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, and casting her fight as a choice between tyranny and religious freedom.

lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Cheney was criticizing the Iran nuclear deal when a banner-wielding protester interrupted.

lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidate Mike Huckabee spoke to crowds in Kentucky about Kim Davis, the clerk who was jailed for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples.

headline: ‘The League,’ on FXX, Kicks Off Its Final Season
abstract: This sitcom about six friends in a fantasy football league sets the shock bar high as it begins its farewell season.
lead_paragraph: When you have been one of television’s raunchiest shows for six seasons and have announced that the seventh will be your last, what can you do to start things off that will be truly shocking? That is the problem facing “The League,” an FXX comedy about six friends in a fantasy football league, which returns on Wednesday night.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Hungary and Elsewhere
abstract: Hungary and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Hungary and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Andrew Bolton Chosen to Lead the Met’s Costume Institute
abstract: The selection of Mr. Bolton comes after the institute’s curator in charge, Harold Koda, decided to retire after 14 years of overseeing ambitious, crowd-pleasing shows.
lead_paragraph: After 14 years of overseeing ambitious, crowd-pleasing shows like “Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty” in 2011 and the recent “China: Through the Looking Glass,” which have helped put the Metropolitan Museum of Art at the crossroads of glamour, fashion, scholarship and art, Harold Koda is retiring as curator in charge of the museum’s Costume Institute. On Tuesday the Met board chose Andrew Bolton, his fellow curator, to succeed him.

headline: September 8, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Hungary, Greece, Yemen and Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Hungary, Greece, Yemen and Gaza.

headline: When Fashion Shows Were Fun
abstract: A few decades ago, people were as excited about attending a show as they might have been, in an earlier era, about seeing the Stones in concert.
lead_paragraph: Naomi Campbell wore backless chaps. Have I got your attention?

headline: A Painful Lesson for the Jets’ Geno Smith, but What Did He Learn?
abstract: Smith’s news conference on Monday did not inspire confidence that he fully understands what it will take to lead a franchise desperate for a championship.
lead_paragraph: Geno Smith’s journey as the Jets’ quarterback of the future was seriously derailed in August when his jaw was broken by Ikemefuna Enemkpali in the team’s locker room over an unpaid debt. Enemkpali was sent packing the same day. But while the perpetrator was banished, the episode raised questions about whether Smith has what it takes to be an important part of the Jets’ future, or whether he will turn out to be just the latest quarterback passing through. I wonder whether the injury and the events leading up to it have been a wake-up call.

headline: Nancy Harms Celebrates Duke Ellington
abstract: Ms. Harms sang a program of songs associated with Duke Ellington, including “Mood Indigo,” at the Metropolitan Room.
lead_paragraph: “A royal-blue night sky and twinkling stars: the perfect moment.” With those words, the complicated jazz singer Nancy Harms introduced her rendition of “Prelude to a Kiss” on Sunday evening at the Metropolitan Room, where she sang a program of Duke Ellington-related songs titled “Ellington at Night.”

headline: In a New Paris Bistro, Daniel Rose Dishes Out Comfort Food
abstract: At La Bourse et La Vie, the chef will focus on culinary classics — and coffee.
lead_paragraph: The French-trained American chef Daniel Rose recently celebrated his 17th year in France, and today debuts his first new project since the first iteration of Spring, his much-venerated restaurant, shook up the Paris food scene nine years ago. With La Bourse et La Vie, his new 29-seat eatery located between La Bourse, the city’s former stock exchange building, and the Palais Royal, Rose applies his experience and skilled precision to the most comforting of French dishes: pot au feu, artichoke salad with foie gras (the first dish Rose ate when he moved to Lyon for cooking school), whole roasted chickens and steak-frites. Consider it an ode to the bistro. “We’re doing a lot of the fundamental dishes that we learned about in cooking school but didn’t think were very interesting at the time,” Rose explains. “The reality is, these are the traditional recipes that many people travel to Paris for but which have become harder to find — or at least, hard to find executed with any care.”

headline: Hillary Clinton, Citing Her ‘Mistake,’ Apologizes for Private Email
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton said what many supporters had been wanting to hear in hopes that it would quell the controversy that has overshadowed her presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton acknowledged on Tuesday that her use of a private email server while she was secretary of state was a “mistake,” and apologized directly for it, uttering words that many of her allies have waited to hear from her in hopes that she can quell a controversy that has dogged her presidential candidacy for months.

headline: Restaurant Debuts That Stand Out Above the Rest
abstract: L’Amico by Laurent Tourondel, and La Sirena from Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich, are among the most intriguing new places in New York.
lead_paragraph: The list of riches on these pages may seem as intimidating as a zillion-course tasting menu. To get started, let me tell you which new developments intrigue me the most.

headline: The Fall Restaurant Preview
abstract: A look at the restaurants opening in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens this fall.
lead_paragraph: These days, restaurants open in New York throughout the year, but fall still brings scores of fresh choices and a blast of energy. Florence Fabricant sizes up the season’s highlights, from pizzerias to formal dining rooms. (Dates may change.)

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting interesting stories from around the web. In this installment, great reads from Jodi Rudoren, Mike Isaac and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Raw Fish Finds a Spot on Chinese Menus
abstract: High-end Chinese menus in New York are starting to serve raw fish, which they customize with seasonings.
lead_paragraph: Sure, you can find sushi alongside General Tso’s chicken in cheap neighborhood places. But this season, some high-end Chinese menus in New York will include raw seafood in many forms.

headline: In New Restaurants, the Faces Are Increasingly Female
abstract: April Bloomfield and Missy Robbins are among the women behind the most anticipated new and reinvented places in New York.
lead_paragraph: Women have been running influential kitchens and restaurants in New York for quite a while, but not all that many. This season, the roster of women behind the most anticipated new and reinvented places is especially long.

headline: Pile High the Chicken and Biscuits
abstract: There’s plenty of Southern food moving in, and plenty to get excited about.
lead_paragraph: All the talk in New York these days is about bagels, but there’s just as much to get excited about in kitchens where the gold standard is the biscuit. Southern staples like pimento cheese, shrimp and grits, and fried chicken with waffles recently arrived at Marcus Samuelsson’s Streetbird in Harlem; Burnside Biscuits in Astoria, Queens; Birds & Bubbles on the Lower East Side; and Arrogant Swine in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

headline: United C.E.O. Is Out Amid Inquiry at Port Authority
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The airline said two other executives were also leaving in connection with an investigation into whether flights were a favor for a top agency official.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive and two senior officials of United Airlines resigned on Tuesday amid a federal investigation into whether the airline had traded favors with the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

headline: Japanese Restaurants Focus on Specialties
abstract: The finer new Japanese places often showcase expertise in one area, like ramen or sushi.
lead_paragraph: The finer Japanese restaurants, taking their lead from the mother country, often have a narrow focus: Rather than serving a mixed bag, they zero in on, say, ramen or sushi or tempura. It’s an approach that showcases expertise, and it’s in full swing this season in New York.

headline: In the Heights: ‘Hamilton’ Reaches Top Tier at Broadway Box Office
abstract: The musical “Hamilton” was the second-highest-grossing show on Broadway last week.
lead_paragraph: As improbable as it may sound, a musical about the nation’s first Treasury Secretary last week bested “Aladdin,” “The Book of Mormon” and “Wicked” to become the second-highest-grossing show on Broadway.

headline: Harry Reid Defends Iran Deal
abstract: The Democratic Senate leader spoke in support of the nuclear deal with Iran in a speech at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Senate leader spoke in support of the nuclear deal with Iran in a speech at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

headline: New Cholesterol Drugs Are Vastly Overpriced, Analysis Says
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Cholesterol', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Praluent (Drug)', 'Repatha (Drug)']
abstract: A report from the Institute for Clinical and Economic Review says the prices on two drugs to fight cholesterol that cost more than $14,000 a year should be slashed.
lead_paragraph: Two powerful new drugs that can sharply lower cholesterol are vastly overpriced based on the value they provide, according to a new analysis by an independent organization that evaluates pharmaceutical costs.

headline: Yahoo Rethinking Alibaba Spinoff After Getting No I.R.S. Guidance
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service refused to rule in advance on whether a proposed spinoff would incur a huge tax bill.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo is reconsidering its plan to spin off its $23 billion stake in Alibaba after federal tax authorities declined to rule in advance on whether the transaction would mean huge capital gains taxes for Yahoo or its shareholders.

headline: Women’s Voices Theater Festival Celebrates Female Playwrights
abstract: The Women’s Voices Theater Festival, which runs through Nov. 22, will present 56 world-premiere productions at 51 participating theaters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ordinarily, plays written by men dominate stages in the nation’s capital, just as they do in the rest of the country — an imbalance that female playwrights have been agitating to change for a while. But for the next couple of months here, the usual rules will not apply.

headline: Nearly 8,000 Killed in Ukraine Conflict, U.N. Says
abstract: Its report blamed a continuing influx of fighters and weaponry from Russia as the major obstacle to peace.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Nearly 8,000 people have died in the conflict in eastern Ukraine, the United Nations said Tuesday in a report blaming the continuing influx of fighters and weaponry from Russia as the major obstacle to peace.

headline: Dentist Who Killed Lion Returns to Work
abstract: Dr. Walter Palmer, the dentist who killed Cecil the lion on a hunt in Zimbabwe last month, returned to work on Tuesday amid protests in Bloomington, Minn.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Walter Palmer, the dentist who killed Cecil the lion on a hunt in Zimbabwe last month, returned to work on Tuesday amid protests in Bloomington, Minn.

headline: Trademark Collaborates With William Wegman
abstract: The photographer has created images of his Weimaraners in overcoats, turtlenecks and more.
lead_paragraph: When Pookie and Louisa Burch, the designers behind Trademark, set out to create images for their fall collection, they had a goal in mind: to work with William Wegman, the photographer famous for his pictures of Weimaraners. Their collaboration, which releases exclusively here and which will be installed in their flagship store this week, features Wegman’s two dogs modeling a bright red single-breasted coat, tasseled loafers, pajama tops and turtlenecks. “My dogs Flo and Topper — sensing Pookie and Louisa’s high expectations of them — were eager to perform,” Wegman told T in an email. “They loved the attention and seemed to like the clothes but we can’t be sure of that. What we can be certain of is that they enjoyed the collaboration, as did I.”

headline: Review: ‘The Taming of the Shrew’ Is Given a Self-Reliant Update
abstract: A production by the Drilling Company at Bryant Park has sweetened some of the aftertaste of this play about a husband breaking the will of his hot-tempered wife.
lead_paragraph: It takes gumption to stage a play like Shakespeare’s “The Taming of the Shrew” at a time when gender inequality is a growing concern. (And that’s before you take into account the challenges of performing it in Bryant Park in Manhattan, with passing planes overhead, fickle microphones and crowd noises from the Bryant Park Grill.) After all, this comedy, at least on its face, is about a husband breaking the will of his hot-tempered wife. But the Drilling Company (the troupe behind Shakespeare in the Parking Lot) has taken it on and sweetened some of its aftertaste.

headline: Review: Annie Gosfield Makes Machines Hum in ‘Electric Sweepers and Vacuum Creepers’
abstract: Ms. Gosfield’s “Electric Sweepers and Vacuum Creepers” and “Lost Signals and Drifting Satellites” were performed on a lineup celebrating her birthday.
lead_paragraph: The motorized vacuum cleaner, most would agree, is a useful device. Its sound has practical applications, too, as many new parents can confirm who have soothed fussy babies with its milky white roar. But when it comes to making music, vacuums have mostly had to suck it up and wait.

headline: A Conversation With David L. Shorenstein
abstract: Mr. Shorenstein is a founder and principal of Silvershore Properties, a New York-based company that acquires, repositions and develops multifamily rentals and mixed-use properties.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Shorenstein, 34, is a founder and principal of Silvershore Properties, a New York-based company that acquires, repositions and develops multifamily rentals and mixed-use properties in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens.

headline: Corporate Efforts to Address Social Problems Have Limits
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A survey by researchers at Harvard Business School shows a recognition among executives of social problems, but pessimism that they can be addressed.
lead_paragraph: There is something appealing about the concept of “shared value.”

headline: ‘You’re the Worst,’ on FX, Extends Its Subversive Rom-Com Arc
abstract: The second season opener continues to take down the genre while remaining faithful to it.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve heard that FX’s “You’re the Worst” is a smutty and subversive take on the relationship sitcom, but you haven’t watched it yet, you might be in for a surprise. The show is both takedown and loving, detailed celebration — no series on TV more closely mimics the structure and rhythms of the classic romantic comedy. Its 10-episode first season was haunted by the ghosts of Hepburn and Grant, Ryan and Hanks, Zellwegger and the other Grant.

headline: Nick Nixon: Photographing Slowly for Forty Years
abstract: Nick Nixon has worked methodically to create images using a view camera and printing in the darkroom. A new retrospective of his work reminds him of the importance of slowing down.
lead_paragraph: Nick Nixon has worked methodically to create images using a view camera and printing in the darkroom. A new retrospective of his work reminds him of the importance of slowing down.

headline: A White Poet Borrows a Chinese Name and Sets Off Fireworks
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature', 'Chinese-Americans', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Sherman Alexie, editor of the “Best American Poetry” anthology, noted that despite the headaches, the controversy showed how much passion discussion of poetry can stir.
lead_paragraph: This year’s edition of the anthology “Best American Poetry” has come under criticism for including a poem by a white poet writing under a Chinese pseudonym, touching off intense online debate about diversity, inclusion and racial entitlement in the poetry world.

headline: ‘Aferim!,’ an Oscar Contender, Explores the Enslavement of the Roma
abstract: Radu Jude’s film has stirred broad discussion of a practice that lasted for 500 years in Romania but until recently was largely ignored.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — The slow black-and-white scenes in which two horsemen ride through vast, bleak landscapes in Radu Jude’s latest movie, “Aferim!,” could have come straight out of a classic American western, as could the central theme of injustice. Yet the movie is set in 19th-century Wallachia, part of modern-day Romania, where for almost 500 years ending in 1856, the Roma (or Gypsies, as they have been more commonly known) were viewed as property to be bought and sold.

headline: Review: Richard Gere in ‘Time Out of Mind,’ a Life Adrift on the Margins
abstract: This film is an intimate portrait of a man caught between the desire to be left alone and a need for human connection.
lead_paragraph: Every so often, George Hammond gets a look on his face that suggests he’s about to figure something out, and perhaps share his newly found insight. But those moments are fleeting, and the longed-for epiphany never arrives. Usually George’s features are slack, his sentences mumbled and incomplete, his eyes cloudy under heavy brows. His vague personality seems to reflect drifting circumstances; he is a creature of negative space.

headline: As New Mexico Scandals Grow, Democrats Hope to Tarnish Governor
abstract: Criminal charges against the secretary of state, Dianna Duran, highlight a string of troubles for recently ascendant Republicans in the state.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — Once an integral part of the Republican Party’s rise to power under Gov. Susana Martinez’s stewardship in this Democratic stronghold, the secretary of state, Dianna Duran, has now been abandoned by her party, threatened with impeachment by her political opponents and called on to resign by one of the state’s leading newspapers.

headline: Atop the Guggenheim, a Tiny, Secret Installation
abstract: The Argentine artist Adrián Villar Rojas’s work on the museum’s roof, only seen by museum employees, is designed to continually erode and be recreated.
lead_paragraph: When New York’s Guggenheim Museum closes its exhibition “Storylines” tomorrow, there’s one artwork the art handlers won’t be packing up. Few are even aware of its existence; its creator is listed in some of the exhibition materials, but not in others. It is a permanent commission that will be a presence within the museum in perpetuity, but no photos of it exist — and until a persistent journalist got her way, no one outside the artist’s cadre had even seen it.

headline: Hungarian Journalist, Petra Laszlo, Fired for Kicking Migrants on Camera
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Social Media']
abstract: A Hungarian camerawoman was fired on Tuesday after images of her kicking and tripping migrants spread across social networks.
lead_paragraph: An Internet television channel associated with Hungary’s far-right Jobbik party fired a camera operator on Tuesday after images of her kicking and tripping migrants spread across social networks.

headline: Corduroy’s New Energy
abstract: The fabric exits the lecture hall and struts onto the runway.
lead_paragraph: The fabric exits the lecture hall and struts onto the runway.

headline: Review: In ‘Coming Home,’ a Family Rocked by the Cultural Revolution
abstract: Amid the Cultural Revolution, a father is imprisoned, his teenage daughter denounces him, and a family tries to recover from that pain in this film by Zhang Yimou.
lead_paragraph: Zhang Yimou and Gong Li constitute one of the great director-actress pairings in movie history. In the 1980s and ’90s they worked together on a remarkable run of movies — including “Red Sorghum,” “Raise the Red Lantern,” “Shanghai Triad” and “To Live” — that were central to the resurgence of Chinese cinema and made international stars of both of them. Ms. Gong, noble, fragile and indomitable, was for Mr. Zhang a muse, an alter ego and an emblem of China’s suffering and resilience at important moments in the nation’s history.

headline: ‘A Gentleman’s Guide to Love and Murder’ to Close on Broadway in January
abstract: A near-flop that went on to win four Tony Awards and became a hit will play its final performance on Jan. 17.
lead_paragraph: In the end, there was only one way to save the doomed D’Ysquiths: Close their show.

headline: Corduroy: Not Just for Professors Anymore
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Coats and Jackets']
abstract: From Dunhill, Burberry, Sacai, Marc Jacobs and Bottega Veneta, a modern take on a venerable fabric.
lead_paragraph: All too often, corduroy is relegated to the professor type. Think of the English instructor in an ill-fitting suit of chocolate brown, as immortalized by Donald Sutherland in the 1978 film “National Lampoon’s Animal House.”

headline: Venezuela’s U.N. Envoy Defends Crackdown Along Border With Colombia
abstract: The ambassador, Rafael Ramírez, said Colombian smugglers and other criminals were devastating his country’s economy.
lead_paragraph: The Venezuelan ambassador to the United Nations offered an impassioned defense on Tuesday of his country’s border closings with Colombia, arguing that illicit trafficking of domestic fuel, food and other goods by Colombian smugglers accounted for 35 percent of all Venezuelan economic output.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
keywords: ['Real Estate Brokers', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: Caring for the Other Refugees
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Jordan, Turkey and Lebanon need more assistance to help them cope with the millions of Syrian refugees they have taken in.
lead_paragraph: The world’s attention has been riveted on the refugee crisis unfolding in Europe, and on the shift in Europe as leaders, finally, take steps to deal with it. But one of the reasons Syrians are risking their lives to reach Europe is that life has become unbearable in the countries closer to home where many have taken refuge.

headline: An Art-World Fortress of Solitude Comes to New York City
abstract: Hauser & Wirth will host the late artist Mike Kelley’s “Kandors” series.
lead_paragraph: “To tell you the truth, I’m not interested in the story” of Kandor, the capital of the fictional planet Krypton, remarked the late artist Mike Kelley in 2008. For those unfamiliar with DC Comics lore, the arch-villain Brainiac shrinks the hero’s megalopolis to be housed inside of a glass bottle — which Superman later intercepts and keeps in his Fortress of Solitude. Anyway: “I’m not a fan of Superman comics,” Kelley continued. “I just like the idea of being burdened with one’s past.”

headline: 26-Point Game Propels Unseeded Italian Roberta Vinci
abstract: Roberta Vinci, a 32-year-old from Italy, beat Kristina Mladenovic, 22, of France, in three sets to become the second unseeded woman in two years to reach the United States Open semifinals.
lead_paragraph: Roberta Vinci and Kristina Mladenovic were locked in a marathon game in the third set of their United States Open quarterfinal at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Michigan: New Sentencing for Teenager in Sex Crime
abstract: A judge has vacated the sentence of Zachery Anderson, whose arrest on a charge of having sex with a 14-year-old girl when he was 19 prompted a call to change sex offender registries.
lead_paragraph: A judge has vacated the sentence of Zachery Anderson, whose arrest on a charge of having sex with a 14-year-old girl when he was 19 prompted a call to change sex offender registries. Judge Dennis M. Wiley of Berrien County District Court said in a ruling dated Thursday that a different judge would resentence Mr. Anderson. Mr. Anderson said he believed the girl was 17 and above the age of consent in Michigan when they met online and subsequently had a single sexual encounter in December. Mr. Anderson, a resident of Indiana, pleaded guilty to fourth-degree criminal sexual conduct and was sentenced to 90 days in jail and probation, but he was told that he would spend the rest of his life on the state’s sex offender registry. He was also ordered not to use the Internet or smartphones for five years, forcing him to abandon computer science studies at a community college. Mr. Anderson’s lawyer said he hoped that a new judge would grant his client a special status under Michigan law for youthful offenders, which would mean he would not be required to be on the state’s sex offender registry.

headline: N.F.L. Cheerleaders’ Wage Fight Gains Momentum
abstract: For years, cheerleaders labored off the radar of enforcers of wage and hour laws. In the world beyond the castle that is the N.F.L., this is known as wage theft. But the cultural dial is turning.
lead_paragraph: Lacy Thibodeaux grew up in southern Louisiana, football country in all of its humid and insane passions.

headline: Andrew Kohut, Pew Pollster Who Shed Light on Public Opinion, Dies at 73
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Kohut was widely respected for his nonpartisanship, expertise and clarity in understanding the findings of national and global surveys.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Kohut, a leading pollster who for three decades mined the public’s views on subjects like sex, race and religion but who, as an impartial professional, rarely revealed his own, died on Tuesday in Baltimore. He was 73.

headline: Parents Spending Less on Back-to-School Season Despite Growing Lists of Supplies
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Construction paper used to be provided at school. Nowadays, it is one of many items parents are expected to provide. And yet a retailers group expects parents will spend 6 percent less this season.
lead_paragraph: As a young student, Tom McMahon never had to bring scissors to school.

headline: Cuomo Pledges Advice and Assistance to Puerto Rico
abstract: Noting the territory’s importance to New York, the governor announced an “aggressive action plan” to aid Puerto Rico with its health care and business issues.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo completed a daylong tour to Puerto Rico on Tuesday by promising to offer advice, technical assistance and summitry to a territory facing some $72 billion in debt.

headline: Dewey & LeBoeuf Chairman’s Lawyer Cites ‘Fantasy Fraud’
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Legal Profession', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The lawyer for Steven H. Davis argued that prosecutors had failed to prove the former chairman of Dewey & LeBoeuf was aware of any wrongdoing before the law firm’s collapse in 2012.
lead_paragraph: The lawyer for Steven H. Davis, former chairman of Dewey & LeBoeuf, told a state jury on Tuesday that the criminal case against his client was a “fantasy fraud” brought by prosecutors in Manhattan with “fanciful theories” about the spring 2012 collapse of the once-prominent law firm.

headline: Kevin Anderson’s Breakthrough Has a Small Cost
abstract: Anderson, who had to pay some change-of-travel fees, will face fifth-seeded Stan Wawrinka in the U.S. Open quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Anderson’s long-awaited Grand Slam breakthrough to the quarterfinals of the United States Open came at a price: $400.

headline: Strike by Seattle Teachers Adds to School Turmoil in State
abstract: Washington’s public system was already facing uncertainty as a new year began, after a court ruled last week that its charter schools are unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The union representing about 5,000 teachers and other workers in the Seattle public schools said Tuesday night that contract talks had broken down and that the first teachers strike here in 30 years would begin on Wednesday, which had been the first scheduled day of classes.

headline: Trial Ordered for Ex-Leader of Guatemala
abstract: Otto Pérez Molina, who resigned as president last week, is in detention, charged with bribery, customs fraud and conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — A Guatemalan judge ordered former President Otto Pérez Molina on Tuesday to stand trial on charges of bribery, customs fraud and conspiracy, and returned him to detention.

headline: Investment Strategies Meant as Buffers to Volatility May Have Deepened It
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Exchange Traded Funds', 'Hedge Funds']
abstract: Risk-parity and exchange-traded funds, both considered ways of providing steady returns in a pitching market, are now thought to have added to the turbulence.
lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, a cure is proving to be nearly as bad as the disease.

headline: Across Town, Another Arm Rests for the Long Run
abstract: Like the Mets’ Matt Harvey, the Yankees’ Dellin Betances has an elbow operation in his past, a pennant race in his present and no long-term contract to cover his future.
lead_paragraph: He is a hard-throwing, homegrown, 20-something New York pitcher with a serious elbow operation in his past, a pennant race in his present and no long-term contract to cover his future. Sometimes he must rest to protect his prized right arm.

headline: Perdue Buys Niman Ranch, as It Expands in Specialty Meat Business
abstract: The purchase of Niman Ranch gives Perdue, a poultry producer, a bigger base in pork and beef.
lead_paragraph: Perdue, the big, family-owned poultry company, ended weeks of speculation on Tuesday when it announced that it was the buyer of Niman Ranch, a specialty meats business.

headline: Youth Movement Takes a Detour at the Presidents Cup
abstract: Jay Haas, the United States Presidents Cup captain, went with Phil Mickelson over Brooks Koepka.
lead_paragraph: Jay Haas, the United States Presidents Cup captain, held up a finger to gauge which direction the wind was blowing and somehow missed the gales of change that swept through the PGA Tour in 2015, toppling the established stars and allowing 20-something players like Rickie Fowler, Jordan Spieth, Rory McIlroy and Jason Day to grow toward the spotlight.

headline: Violence Casts a Shadow Over J’ouvert Celebration in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Parades', 'West Indian-American Day', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Seemingly every year, violence intrudes on the margins of J’ouvert, a predawn carnival procession that precedes the West Indian American Day Parade.
lead_paragraph: For the many thousands who flood the streets of central Brooklyn in the darkness of the first hours of Labor Day, it is a release: a chance to celebrate, in costume or out, and dance to melodies and rhythms of the Caribbean.

headline: Roger Goodell Says Changes to His Role May Be Coming
abstract: The N.F.L. commissioner said on a radio show that a discipline officer or a panel making the initial decision on whether to suspend a player “would make for a better system.”
lead_paragraph: After a series of stinging legal defeats, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said he would consider changing his role in governing the league’s personal conduct policy. Goodell said Tuesday on the ESPN Radio program “Mike & Mike” that a discipline officer or a panel making the initial decision on whether to suspend a player “would make for a better system.” But he said the league was against having a third-party arbitrator — something other leagues use — because “the standards of the N.F.L. are important to uphold and we don’t want to delegate that responsibility or standard.”

headline: 1926: Royal Birth Raises Prospect of Second Queen Elizabeth
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Princess Elizabeth is born in London on April 21, 1926.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The prospect that in the ordinary course of nature — assuming the Prince of Wales remains a bachelor — a Queen Elizabeth may again sit on the English throne is held out by the birth of a daughter this morning to the Duchess of York, wife of King George’s second son. The duchess’s first child and the king’s first granddaughter was born at 2:40 a.m. at 17 Bruton Street, London, house of the Earl and Countess of Strathmore, the Duchess of York’s parents. She became the third heir in the line of succession to the throne, ranking after the Prince of Wales and her father. She is expected to be christened Mary Victoria Elizabeth, respectively after Queen Mary, who will be the child’s principal godmother; after Queen Victoria, whose name it has become the custom to keep in each royal generation, and after her mother, the Duchess of York. The last name will probably be that by which the child will be known, and thus a famous name in British history will be revived in the Royal family. — The New York Herald, European Edition, April 22, 1926

headline: 1947: Princess Elizabeth Is Engaged
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Princess Elizabeth is engaged to Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten in 1947.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The engagement of Princess Elizabeth, twenty-one-year-old heiress-presumptive to the throne of England, and Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten, twenty-six-year-old former Prince Philip of Greece, was announced to night [July 9] by her parents, King George VI and Queen Elizabeth. The young couple will be married in the autumn, probably in October, at Westminster Abbey, according to present plans. The formal announcement of the engagement was made in tonight’s Court Circular. It said: “It is with the greatest of pleasure that the King and Queen announce the betrothal of their dearly beloved daughter, the Princess Elizabeth, to Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten. RN, son of the late Prince Andrew of Greece and Princess Andrew (Princess Alice of Battenberg), to which union the King has gladly given his consent.

headline: 1947: Princess Elizabeth Weds Lieutenant Mountbatten
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Princess Elizabeth II weds Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten, former Prince Philip of Greece on Nov. 20, 1947.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A wedding pageant of precision, color and magnificence in the best traditions of English royal splendor unfolded today [Nov 20] before tens of thousands of people along the two-mile route from Buckingham Palace to Westminster Abbey.

headline: 1952: King George VI Dies, Elizabeth Is Queen
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: King George VI dies unexpectedly on February 6, 1952, leaving the throne to his daughter Elizabeth.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — King George VI, a quiet, modest monarch, passed quietly away in his sleep early today [Feb. 6] at his country home in Sandringham, a few feet from where he was born 56 years ago. His elder daughter, Princess Elizabeth, 25, simultaneously inherited the throne. She was proclaimed Queen of Great Britain, Northern Ireland and the British Dominions Beyond the Seas by an Accession Council of 300 members who assembled at St. James’s Palace, London, at 5 p.m. The new Queen will return here by plane tomorrow from Kenya, one of her dominions in East Africa, where she was spending a few days with her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, in the course of a tour to Ceylon, Australia and New Zea­land. She will make final arrangements for the funeral.

headline: Queen Elizabeth II, Britain’s Longest-Reigning Monarch
abstract: Excerpts from the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Queen Elizabeth II’s birth in 1926 to her coronation in 1953.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Queen Elizabeth II becomes the longest-serving monarch in British history. The length of her reign surpasses that of her great-great-grandmother, Queen Victoria, who ruled for more than 63 years, from 1837 to 1901. Queen Elizabeth II ascended to the throne after the death of her father, George VI, on Feb. 6, 1952. Below, some excerpts from the archives, from her birth to her coronation:

headline: 1953: Queen Elizabeth Optimistic About Her Reign
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The coronation of Queen Elizabeth II on June 2, 1953.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II, in a world-wide broadcast tonight [June 2] urged her many millions of subjects to look upon her Coronation as cause for new optimism for the future. “I have behind me not only the splendid traditions of the annals of more than a thousand years,” she said, “but the living strength of the Commonwealth empire; of societies old and new; of lands and races different in history and origin, but all by God’s will, united in spirit and in aim. Therefore I am sure that this, my Coronation, is not the symbol of a power and a splendor that are gone, but a declaration of hope for the future and for the years I may, by God’s grace and mercy, be given to reign and serve you as your Queen.”

abstract: Should an elected official go to jail for defying a Supreme Court ruling?
lead_paragraph: Last week a Kentucky county clerk went to jail after she refused to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples. Her very public defiance of the Supreme Court turned her into a hero for some and a villain for others.

headline: E.U. Nations Urged to Accept 160,000 Migrants
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The president of the European Commission urged Europeans to remember ancestors who sought refuge from religious persecution and war and famine.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s top executive proposed a plan on Wednesday to distribute 160,000 migrants throughout the member nations, even while acknowledging that this measure alone was inadequate to the depth of the crisis.

headline: ‘Beauty Is a Wound’ and ‘Man Tiger’ by Eka Kurniawan
abstract: In two family chronicles set in turbulent 20th-century Indonesia, the supernatural blends with the everyday.
lead_paragraph: In what is presumably late 1965, as Indonesia is racked by violence in the wake of a failed coup blamed on Communists, a gravedigger named Kamino hits upon a novel method of seduction: He allows himself to be possessed by the spirit of a recently murdered Communist so that the Communist’s daughter can speak with her father one last time. In gratitude, she cooks Kamino dinner. A week later, after Kamino has buried 1,232 Communists in one mass grave, she accepts his marriage proposal. By the time the newlyweds return from their honeymoon, Eka Kurniawan’s fictional Javanese city of Halimunda is “filled with corpses sprawled out in the irrigation channels and on the outskirts of the city, in the foothills and on the riverbanks, in the middle of bridges and under bushes. Most of them had been killed as they tried to escape.”

headline: ‘Date-Onomics,’ ‘The Sex Myth’ and ‘Modern Romance’
abstract: Books on sex, dating and the relentless search for “the One.”
lead_paragraph: Back when adultery and gay sex were widely criminalized in the United States, when masturbation was thought to make you crazy and fellatio was taboo, the Kinsey Institute famously revealed that Americans were secretly less faithful, more gay, more various in their sexual practices and more perverse than most wanted to think. Sixty years later, many of us have come to regard sex — preferably passionate, hot, transformative sex — as central to our lives. In the time of Tinder, our sexuality feels anything but secret. But romance is still mysterious — what does it feel like for everyone else? — and three new books try to explain modern mating.

headline: Resort and Cruise News: Tennis With Connors; Trips in Alaska
abstract: What you need to know if you’re on a trip or planning one soon, including hotel deals in Florida and new cruises in Myanmar and China.
lead_paragraph: Our morning travel news digest, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

headline: Why Runners Get Slower With Age (and How Strength Training May Help)
abstract: After age 50, runners use certain leg muscles quite differently than younger runners, a new study found. Exercises to strengthen the calf and ankle flexors may help older runners prevent injuries and increase speed.
lead_paragraph: Young runners are different from you and me. They have more speed. And to achieve that swiftness, they use certain leg muscles quite differently than runners past age 50 do, according to a new study of runners’ strides at different ages. The study also intimates that many of us might be able to reinvigorate our flagging pace with the right type of strength training.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get the briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New York Today: Back to School
abstract: Wednesday: In session, sweltering weather, and our polyglot city.
lead_paragraph: Updated 8:37 a.m.

headline: Obama Promotes Plan for College Affordability on Michigan Trip
abstract: The visit is intended to increase pressure on lawmakers by building support for the president’s proposal across the nation, his domestic policy adviser said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the clock ticks toward the end of his presidency and he faces a Republican Congress that is in no mood to cooperate, President Obama on Wednesday kicked off a public-relations campaign aimed at building support for his plans to make college more affordable.

headline: Morning Agenda: Yahoo Rethinks Alibaba Spinoff
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Exchange Traded Funds', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Taxation', 'Television', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Volatility Buffers May Have Deepened Market Turmoil | 3 Nomura Traders Charged | Media General to Buy Meredith Corporation
lead_paragraph: YAHOO RETHINKS ALIBABA SPINOFF | Yahoo is reconsidering its plan to spin off its $23 billion stake in Alibaba after the United States tax authorities declined to rule in advance on whether the transaction would mean huge capital gains taxes for Yahoo and its shareholders, Vindu Goel reports in The New York Times.

headline: The ‘Daunting’ Din: Readers React to Noisy Restaurants
abstract: An article on noise levels in restaurants inspired comments about the din and theories as to why dining rooms have gotten so loud.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Gordinier’s article on efforts to combat noise levels in New York restaurants inspired readers to post comments sharing their own frustration about the din and theories as to why owners would let their dining rooms get so loud. Selections from those comments are below; some have been edited for space.

headline: Conan O’Brien Tries to Give Lincoln Chafee a Lift in the Polls
abstract: Lincoln Chafee has failed to garner a single supporter in the last four national polls, which have queried a total of 1,475 Democrats and Democratic-leaning voters.
lead_paragraph: Pollsters tend to be cut and dry in their analyses of how candidates are faring, but Monmouth University made a point on Tuesday of kicking one lagging Democratic presidential candidate while he is down.

headline: Candidates Address the Growing Refugee Crisis
abstract: The refugee crisis in the Middle East and Europe shows no signs of abating and if it worsens in the coming weeks, candidates running for president of the United States will continue to be asked how they would solve the problem.
lead_paragraph: The migrant crisis in the Middle East and Europe shows no signs of abating, and if it worsens in the coming weeks, candidates running for president of the United States will continue to be asked how they would solve the problem.

headline: Review: On ‘Late Show’ Premiere, Stephen Colbert Tries to Bring Big Back to Late Night
abstract: As overstuffed and messy as this new “Late Show” could be, the goal was a refreshing one at a time when late-night shows have been redefined as content creators for your phone.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Colbert was not given to effusions of humility when he played a blowhard pundit on his Comedy Central series. But he opened his first night as host of “The Late Show” with one. “I am not replacing David Letterman,” he insisted.

headline: Today in Politics: Hillary Clinton to Weigh In on Iran Deal as Donald Trump and Ted Cruz Try to Crush It
abstract: The debate over the Iran nuclear deal leaps to the front of the campaign trail as Hillary Rodham Clinton is set to speak to its merits, and Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas are holding a rally at the Capitol to oppose it.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning. The fate of the nuclear deal with Iran was high on the to-do list of lawmakers returning from vacation. But on Wednesday, the debate leaps to the front of the campaign trail as Hillary Rodham Clinton is set to speak to its merits, and Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas are holding a rally at the Capitol to tell the expected crowd of thousands what they think about the “catastrophic” deal.

headline: Why We Should Fear University, Inc.
abstract: Against the corporate taming of the American college.
lead_paragraph: Here at Purdue University, where I recently completed my Ph.D. in English, we have a little garden on the far west side of our enormous campus, where students and their families and professors and nearby residents tend to tomatoes and sunflowers. It’s one of my favorite places here. Overgrown and seemingly unmanaged, this western fringe of campus is perhaps the only place left at the university that is not meticulously landscaped and stage-managed for tour groups and the website. There’s nothing specific to Purdue in this aesthetic conformity. Over the past two decades, financial crises notwithstanding, the American university writ large has undergone a radical physical expansion and renovation, bringing more and more campuses into line with grand architectural visions. That’s precisely why I love the garden: It’s one of the last little wild places left at Purdue. Naturally, it’s slated for demolition.

headline: A Prescription for More Black Doctors
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Medical Schools', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Equal Educational Opportunities']
abstract: How does tiny Xavier University in New Orleans manage to send more African-American students to medical school than any other college in the country?
lead_paragraph: Norman Francis was just a few years into his tenure as president of Xavier University of Louisiana, a small Catholic institution in New Orleans, when a report that came across his desk alarmed him. It was an accounting of the nation’s medical students, and it found that the already tiny number of black students attending medical school was dropping.

headline: Teaching Martin Luther King Jr. in the Age of Freddie Gray
keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Education']
abstract: A professor becomes a witness to her students’ debate about the limits of nonviolence.
lead_paragraph: In 1968, when my father was a teenage boy in Memphis, Martin Luther King Jr. went there to support the city’s striking sanitation workers. He marched with King and thousands of other protesters, and in the violence that erupted afterward, the police shot another black boy, Larry Payne. They claimed he was a looter. King called Payne’s mother to console her, but a planned visit never happened. King was murdered just a few days later.

headline: At Arnhem Festival, ‘Living Dolls’ Are on Display
abstract: John Eicke, a two-time winner of the World Living Statues Festival, on what’s it’s like performing for tourists and competing against other “living dolls.”
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 26 and 27, more than a quarter-million people are expected to fill the streets of Arnhem, the Netherlands, to marvel at dozens of “living dolls” from at least 20 countries competing for the World Championship of Living Statues at the eighth World Living Statues Festival. Topping the list of contestants is John Eicke, 50, of Berlin, the only two-time winner, in 2010 and 2013. Mr. Eicke, a professional performer who goes by JOHNman, has displayed his multiple personas at arts festivals in nearly 30 countries and will return to Arnhem this year. Following are edited excerpts from an interview with Mr. Eicke.

headline: McDonald’s Plans a Shift to Eggs From Only Cage-Free Hens
keywords: ['Eggs', 'Chickens', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Factory Farming', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Avian Influenza', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Restaurants']
abstract: The fast-food giant will eventually stop buying eggs laid by hens housed in cages the size of a file drawer.
lead_paragraph: In a move that has significant implications for American and Canadian egg producers, the McDonald’s Corporation is announcing that it will begin phasing out the use of eggs from hens housed in cages.

headline: Donald Trump vs. the Party: Why He’s Still Such a Long Shot
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Endorsements']
abstract: It’s tempting to think of Mr. Trump as the person who can defy the odds, but the party elites typically have the final say.
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump reached the top of the polls in July, his candidacy seemed very familiar, at least to me.

headline: Russia Defends the Presence of Its Military Advisers in Syria
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces']

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Foreign Ministry confirmed on Wednesday that Russian military advisers were in Syria, but it said that their presence was part of a longstanding agreement to provide military aid to the country.

headline: K.K.R. Takes 24.9% Stake in Hedge Fund Marshall Wace
abstract: The private equity giant has formed a long-term strategic partnership with the fund and can increase its ownership stake up to 39.9 percent.
lead_paragraph: The private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is making its biggest push yet into hedge funds, announcing on Wednesday that it is taking a minority stake in the London firm Marshall Wace.

lead_paragraph: Jean-Claude Juncker, president of the European Commission, said European nations needed to take in 160,000 migrants and announced a package for legal migration, expected in early 2016.

abstract: An employee of a private television channel associated with Hungary’s far-right Jobbik party was filmed kicking migrants.
lead_paragraph: An employee of a private television channel associated with Hungary’s far-right Jobbik party was filmed kicking migrants.

headline: Classical Music This Week: Kosugi, a New Old Stravinsky and Arvo Pärt at 80
abstract: A look at what’s happening in the classical music world.
lead_paragraph: While the cats are still away, the mice get to play. In other words, the big-gun halls and orchestras are still more or less on summer break, so the blossoming performances these first weeks of September bring a fantastic concentration of the new and unusual. Delve in!

headline: China’s Response to Stock Plunge Rattles Traders
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In addition to imposing extraordinary restrictions on the sale of stocks, the authorities have harnessed a security apparatus usually more focused on political dissent.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The police have been dropping in on investment firms and downloading their transaction records. Senior executives at China’s biggest investment bank have been arrested on suspicion of illegal trading. A business journalist has been detained and shown  apologizing on national television for writing an article that could have hurt the market.

headline: Jeb Bush Holds His Own on Stephen Colbert’s New Show
abstract: On Tuesday evening, as the first political guest of Stephen Colbert’s network television life, Jeb Bush did his best to impress.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush worked the host’s brother from the stage, pouncing when he learned the man hailed from an early nominating state. He lamented a lack of “fiscal restraint” during his own sibling’s second term as president. He appraised the merits of the exclamation point in his logo.

headline: Singapore Vote Will Test Long Ruling Party’s Grip on Power
abstract: Chastised in the 2011 election, the governing People’s Action Party will find out on Friday whether steps taken since to make amends have been enough.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — The vast open field was awash in blue.

headline: Evian Championship, Newest Women’s Major, Retains Past Spirit
abstract: The tournament’s $3.25 million prize purse and an international field of top players sharply contrast with the inaugural event, which attracted mostly Europeans for a top-shelf corporate pro-am.
lead_paragraph: The Evian Championship is in only its third year as one of the L.P.G.A.’s majors. But, if you ask players how they feel about the tournament, that designation seems to be merely a question of semantics.

headline: A First Day of School Spent in Limbo Instead of in Class
abstract: It was a day of paperwork, pleading and raised or dashed hopes for New York City students who were seeking to transfer, or to just get into any school at all.
lead_paragraph: There was the 15-year-old boy who had recently arrived from Haiti, by way of Florida, did not speak much English and had never been in a New York City school.

headline: A Path for Entrepreneurs, When a Start-Up Is Not the Goal
abstract: A growing number of people are realizing their own business dreams by buying small to midsize companies and helping them prosper.
lead_paragraph: When friends heard that James Higgins, 31, his wife, Trish, 29, and his brother Palmer, 27, left their traditional jobs in finance and sold their charming Greenwich, Conn., townhouse, they assumed it was for an exciting opportunity elsewhere.

headline: Daily Report: China Asserts Tech Presence; Apple Shows Off New Products
abstract: The tech world has focused mostly on news related to China so far this week, with the main tech news event — Apple’s unveiling of new products — set to take place on Wednesday.

headline: Tourists Revive Italian Hilltop Village, but Nature Has Other Plans
abstract: This year, over 500,000 people are expected to visit Civita, population six or eight. However, it has been slowly collapsing because of landslides.
lead_paragraph: CIVITA DI BAGNOREGIO, Italy — Forgive Sandro Rocchi if he seems a smidgen satisfied as he enjoys a midday glass of red wine at his children’s restaurant and relishes the unlikely revival of this stunning hilltop village. He moved away in the 1970s for lack of prospects. Now there are shops, restaurants, boutique properties and gobs of tourists.

headline: Puerto Rico Lays Out 5-Year Plan for Restructuring Its Debts
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: The plan requires either concessions negotiated from creditors or legislation enacted in San Juan or Washington, suggesting a difficult road ahead.
lead_paragraph: Trying to balance the demands of anxious island residents on one side and powerful financial institutions on the other, the governor of Puerto Rico announced a plan Wednesday for bailing the island out of debt that would require at least five years of bruising reform if it is to succeed.

headline: Google Follows Amazon Web Services Into On-Demand Supercomputing
abstract: The growing competition between the two companies could take so-called machine learning to the masses.
lead_paragraph: Google is chasing Amazon Web Services in a new area –- providing access to “on-demand” supercomputing resources.

headline: How I Became a Helicopter Daughter
abstract: When my elderly father moved into our living room, I flew into action.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — DURING the past year, my 88-year-old father finished reading two books, Anthony Doerr’s “All the Light We Cannot See,” and “The Train to Crystal City,” written by our friend Jan Jarboe Russell. As far as I could tell, he thoroughly enjoyed them.

lead_paragraph: Set on a hillside overlooking Playa Hermosa, this four-bedroom house is on the market for $975,000.

lead_paragraph: A MODERN HOME WITH OCEAN VIEWS IN PLAYA HERMOSA

headline: Queen Elizabeth II Becomes Britain’s Longest-Reigning Monarch
abstract: After her coronation at age 25, her reign has included 12 British prime ministers, seven archbishops of Canterbury and seven popes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Her Majesty’s a pretty nice girl, but she doesn’t have a lot to say,” Paul McCartney wrote in 1969, as a coda to “Abbey Road.” Of course, Queen Elizabeth II met the Beatles, too, in what has now become, by reason of fate and genes, Britain’s longest reign.

headline: Fashion Week, Reinvented
abstract: The future of fashion is being reimagined by WME/IMG, the entertainment and sports management company that now owns New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Imagine this: There you are, relaxing in your favorite ergonomic recliner, flipping channels on your tablet or TV, sipping green juice or espresso or chardonnay, when you come across a program featuring Maria Sharapova, Emma Stone, Charlize Theron and Kobe Bryant.

headline: Robert Fairchild to Spin Briefly Back to City Ballet
abstract: Robert Fairchild will return to City Ballet for three Broadway-flavored performances this fall.
lead_paragraph: If ballet seemed to go Broadway during the past year, with top dancers appearing on the Great White Way, a little bit of Broadway will be returning to the ballet this season.

headline: At Performa and Crossing the Line, Barreling Through the Fourth Wall
abstract: Staged in venues across New York City, both festivals challenge convention with adventurous programming.
lead_paragraph: This fall, two ambitious festivals, Crossing the Line and Performa, will try to take over New York: not only in theaters and gallery spaces but also on sidewalks. Havens for multidisciplinary performance and dance, each dispenses with convention in favor of adventurous programming that makes you think as much about your place in the world as about the art itself.

headline: A Dance Season of Premieres Mixed With Masterworks
abstract: The fall harvest of new dances includes premieres from Twyla Tharp, Mark Morris, Paul Taylor and younger choreographers like Justin Peck and Troy Schumacher.
lead_paragraph: There are proven masterpieces to be seen this fall, but on paper what looks crucial is the wealth of new works on offer. Premieres are coming our way by Michelle Dorrance, Mark Morris, Justin Peck, Troy Schumacher, Paul Taylor, Twyla Tharp; and by many others too. Any good artist can have a fiasco; but the mere facts here whet the appetite.

headline: How an Area’s Union Membership Can Predict Children’s Advancement
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Urban Areas', 'Poverty', 'Income Inequality', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Children born to low-income families typically ascend to higher incomes in metro areas where union membership is higher, a study shows.
lead_paragraph: It is well established that unions provide benefits to workers — that they raise wages for their members (and even for nonmembers). They can help reduce inequality.

headline: Aakash Odedra and Jean Butler, Mixing Tradition and Innovation
abstract: Two dancers trained in classical styles decide to go rogue.
lead_paragraph: I first encountered the dancer Aakash Odedra in 2013 at the Apollo Theater in Harlem, where he was spinning and fast-stepping to a remix of James Brown. This was a curious first sighting, considering that Mr. Odedra, who is British, is trained in the classical Indian forms of kathak and bharatanatyam. But he was up to the challenge of adapting those vocabularies to foreign grooves. The audience went wild, and his performance in the Brown tribute revue “Get on the Good Foot” won him a Bessie award.

headline: The American Classical Orchestra and Juilliard415 Mine Telemann’s Gold
abstract: Three shows this fall will feature works by the prolific German composer Georg Philipp Telemann, a longer-lived contemporary of Bach and Handel.
lead_paragraph: Georg Philipp Telemann composed too many works for his own good, or posterity’s. “Factory products,” the 19th-century music publisher and writer Hermann Mendel called them, achieved “by dint of sedulous scribbling” (as quoted in Richard Petzoldt’s Telemann biography).

headline: Esa-Pekka Salonen Explores Messiaen’s Masterly ‘Turangalîla-Symphonie’
abstract: Mr. Salonen, the composer in residence at the New York Philharmonic, will conduct Messiaen’s masterpiece as part of an event in March.
lead_paragraph: The Finnish composer and conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen, the composer in residence at the New York Philharmonic this season, has described the moment when he first heard Messiaen’s “Turangalîla-Symphonie” as “an amazing shock,” because of its “completely new landscape.” Mr. Salonen, who has been much discussed as a possible successor to Alan Gilbert as the Philharmonic’s music director, will conduct Messiaen’s glittering, otherworldly masterpiece on March 10-12 at Avery Fisher Hall as part of a weeklong exploration of the music of that visionary French composer, who died in 1992.

headline: Mark Padmore Takes on ‘Winterreise’ and More
abstract: The English tenor, with the pianist Paul Lewis, will present three of Schubert’s song cycles, including “Winterreise.”
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers have enjoyed a, well, flurry of performances of Schubert’s “Winterreise” (“Winter Journey”) over the past couple of seasons. Among recent standout performers of this heart-scrapingly bleak song cycle about love lost and obsessed over during a winter’s travels are the baritones Gerald Finley, Christian Gerhaher and Matthias Goerne. In fact, ever since the iconic recordings by Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, this cycle has been so firmly associated with baritones that it is easy to forget that Schubert initially wrote it for the tenor voice. On Oct. 17 at Alice Tully Hall, the English tenor Mark Padmore will present what should be a memorable “Winterreise” at Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival.

headline: 1890: Flooding Recedes in Vienna
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Life returns to normal in Vienna after severe flooding, in 1890.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Yesterday being a public holiday here, offices and shops remained closed in Vienna, and many thousands of people thronged the Kron Prinz Rudolf-bridge and other points of vantage to enjoy the sight of the Danube in its present grandeur. Since yesterday the Danube has been steadily falling, and Vienna may now be considered entirely out of danger. Today it is expected the over flow water will return into the river bed. The larger part of the Prater remains impassable for pedestrians. The Freudenau racecourse resembles a large lake, and it is feared has been much injured. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 10, 1890

headline: The Fantasy Might Be Believing Adrian Peterson Is Still a No. 1 Pick
abstract: While Peterson was the consensus No. 1 choice in fantasy football leagues this year, owners must wonder how his age and time off will affect his production.
lead_paragraph: The pro football season starts Thursday, which means fantasy football starts Thursday as well. For some fans, that is the more exciting news.

headline: Helping Children Balance School and Fun
abstract: Too much activity is bad for kids and the health of your family, but so is too little.
lead_paragraph: I love September. I still get that new-school-year thrill when I get a whiff of freshly sharpened pencils and crisp, unsullied notebooks. Unfortunately, September also stinks of a return to the same old struggles we left behind in a heap amid the sticky lunchboxes and ripped backpacks of last June.

headline: At a Brooklyn Shop, Bras From A to M
abstract: At Iris Lingerie, in Boerum Hill, Iris Clarke takes an old-fashioned, hands-on approach to finding the perfect fit for customers.
lead_paragraph: There are simple T-shirt bras and lacy lingerie. Silky slips and nursing bras. Shapewear, strapless, corsets, bathing suits. The sizes run from the smallest smalls all the way up to a 46M. For items that are mostly meant to be hidden by clothing, underwear comes in a wide selection. But at Iris Lingerie in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, customers rarely paw through the racks of unmentionables. Instead, women put themselves in the capable hands of Iris Clarke.

headline: Revivals That Illuminate the Met’s Future
abstract: Starting with an “Otello” staged by the theater director Bartlett Sher, the Metropolitan Opera season features many challenges.
lead_paragraph: One of the most anticipated events of the new season at the Metropolitan Opera comes on the gala opening night, Sept. 21, with the premiere of Bartlett Sher’s production of Verdi’s “Otello.” The next three offerings during the first week, all revivals, at first glance seem much less newsy.

headline: Down Syndrome and Abortion: Readers Share Their Stories
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Down Syndrome', 'Families and Family Life', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Readers offered their experiences of abortion decisions and living with family members with Down syndrome in response to a recent op-ed.
lead_paragraph: As legislators in Ohio consider banning abortion following a fetal diagnosis of Down syndrome, readers shared stories of abortion decisions and living with family members with the disorder.

headline: Andris Nelsons Named Music Director of Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra
abstract: Mr. Nelsons will continue to lead the Boston Symphony, creating an unusual alliance between the two ensembles.
lead_paragraph: The career of Andris Nelsons, the dynamic young conductor who became music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra last season, continued its crescendo on Wednesday when he was named the next music director of the venerable Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra.

headline: An Emotional First Day of School
abstract: School began for more than one million public school students in New York City, whether they liked it or not.
lead_paragraph: School began for more than one million public school students in New York City, whether they liked it or not.

headline: BAM Presents a Survey of 14 Ingrid Bergman Films
abstract: The movies include “Casablanca” and “Notorious,” the 1946 Hitchcock thriller in which her role eerily anticipated her scandalous reputation in the early 1950s.
lead_paragraph: Forever luminous in our memories, Ingrid Bergman would have been 100 last month, and to celebrate, the Brooklyn Academy of Music has assembled a 14-film survey that runs through Sept. 29. Screenings begin on Sunday with the classic “Casablanca” (1942), which features her most famous role: the angelic Ilsa Lund, the thing that keeps Victor Laszlo going. On Saturday is the more complicated “Notorious,” the 1946 Hitchcock thriller in which she plays Alicia Huberman, the dissolute, self-destructive daughter of a Nazi spy. The role eerily anticipated the scandalous reputation that would attach to her in the early 1950s, after she left her husband and daughter for the Italian director Roberto Rossellini.

headline: Works From African Kongo Art at the Metropolitan Museum
abstract: “Kongo: Power and Majesty,” at the Met, aims to reveal the range of creative production by Kongo artists of Central Africa.
lead_paragraph: “In this Kingdom of Kongo, they make fabrics with a nap like velvet, some of them worked in velvety satin, so beautiful that nothing finer is made in Italy,” wrote the Portuguese explorer Duarte Pacheco Pereira, one of the first but certainly not the last European to wax ecstatic over the sumptuous artistic production of the political power that ruled over the vast territory that today includes part of the Republic of Congo, Angola and the Democratic Republic of Congo.

headline: Hillary Clinton Backs Iran Nuclear Deal, With Caveats
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton said the accord would work only “as part of a larger strategy toward Iran” that contained the power Tehran may gain as sanctions are lifted and money flows back into the country.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Donald J. Trump rallying at the Capitol Wednesday against President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran, Hillary Rodham Clinton embraced the agreement a short distance away. But she warned it would work only “as part of a larger strategy toward Iran” that contained Tehran’s power in the region as sanctions are lifted.

headline: The Singers of Mycale Blend Voices in Zorn’s ‘Book of Angels’
abstract: Ayelet Rose Gottlieb, Sofia Rei, Sara Serpa and Malika Zarra were brought together by John Zorn to perform original vocal arrangements from his “Book of Angels” Masada series
lead_paragraph: Mycale is — prepare yourself now for context — a four-woman vocal group brought together by John Zorn to perform original a cappella arrangements from “Book of Angels,” the second galaxy in his universe of succinct compositions collectively titled Masada, all of which use the so-called Jewish scales. (Among the many others who have recorded parts of “Book of Angels”: the guitarist Pat Metheny, the cellist Erik Friedlander, the guitarist Marc Ribot, the trio Medeski, Martin & Wood.) Mycale is Ayelet Rose Gottlieb, Sofia Rei, Sara Serpa and Malika Zarra — from Israeli, Argentine, Portuguese and Moroccan backgrounds — singing texts in Hebrew, French, Spanish, Portuguese and Arabic, from the Hebrew Bible, Rumi, Fernando Pessoa, Heraclitus and elsewhere. And the group’s second record, “Gomory: The Book of Angels, Vol. 25” (Tzadik), released in May, is astonishingly beautiful, a high point in the series: The singers’ individually rigorous tones and dispositions and arranging impulses surround the music and give it another dimension of originality; it sounds medieval and new at the same time.

headline: Cello and Percussion Performances in Queens and Manhattan

lead_paragraph: Friendship and travel are the twin sources of the Australian-born composer Kate Moore’s “Stories for Ocean Shells,” an hourlong collection of short pieces she wrote for the cellist Ashley Bathgate, a bright light on the new-music scene and a member of the Bang on a Can All-Stars. On Sunday afternoon at the Noguchi Museum in Queens, Ms. Bathgate will perform the entire suite, which she and Ms. Moore call a picture book that reflects Ms. Moore’s travels as well as the two women’s deepening ties.

headline: Clive Owen’s Broadway Debut in Pinter’s ‘Old Times’
abstract: The last time the Roundabout Theater staged this drama, in 1984, Pinter himself came to rehearsal to offer help to the cast.
lead_paragraph: The last time the Roundabout Theater produced “Old Times,” in 1984, its dramatist, Harold Pinter, came to rehearsal to offer help to its cast. As reported in The New York Times, Anthony Hopkins, who starred, asked him to explain the play’s ending. Pinter’s response: “I don’t know. Just do it.” Pinter has since died, but his masterly and enigmatic dramas, as spare as his advice to actors, endure, although New York is perhaps due for a revival of “Old Times” (an acclaimed English production in 2013 starred Rufus Sewell). The 1971 play is about a couple who are visited by an old friend of the wife’s whose stories from the past startle and confuse, setting up a classic Pinter power struggle that manages to be both brutal and elusive at once. In this new production, the Oscar nominee Clive Owen makes his Broadway debut opposite Eve Best (who starred in the Broadway revival of Pinter’s “The Homecoming”) and Kelly Reilly (“True Detective,” the Donmar Warehouse’s “After Miss Julie”). Douglas Hodge directs. (Previews start on Sept. 17, American Airlines Theater, roundabouttheatre.org.)

headline: 1965: Pakistani Army Invades India
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Pakistan invades India as war over Kashmir and the Punjab expands, in 1965.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI — Pakistani troops drove into India east of Lahore tonight after pushing Indian forces across the border at Wagah, a Pakistani spokesman said. India neither affirmed nor denied the Pakistani announcement and said only that heavy fighting was in progress in most sectors. According to radio reports reaching Karachi, Pakistan’s first invasion into east Punjab followed a heavy counterattack against Indian tank troops at Wagah, which was the crossing point for India’s first invasion of Pakistan last Monday. The second invasion point was at Jassar, 60 miles from Lahore. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 10, 1965

headline: A New Kind of Uniform
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Coats and Jackets', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: This season, designers seem taken with the romantic side of the historical soldier.
lead_paragraph: DESIGNERS HAVE always had a soft spot for the hard men who protect us during wartime. The word ‘‘panache,’’ after all, is borrowed from the French term for a plume on a helmet. This season, they seem taken with the romantic side of the historical soldier, with clothing that evokes sepia-toned photographs and the verse of Rupert Brooke. Inspired by military ‘‘drabs’’ with a dose of sober black, designers have created an aura more poetic than macho. Sarah Burton at Alexander McQueen celebrated a hero returned, his coat emblazoned with eight-point stars resembling the Grand Cross of the Order of the British Empire. Gucci accessorized a military-style jacket with a bag whose strap was reminiscent of the Sam Browne belt, named after the British officer who created it at the dawn of the Raj era. Craig Green reinterpreted the billowing straps of the daring parachutist.

Now they’re hanging up their cleats: The show’s seventh season, which premieres on Wednesday night, is its final one.

headline: 36 Hours in Portland, Ore.
abstract: Ignore the hype, and indulge in the city’s simple pleasures — from $4 films to a puppet museum, Ping-Pong and pétanque and a picnic by the river.
lead_paragraph: There is no place in the country better known as a bastion of good living, leisure and happy inebriation than Oregon’s largest little city, the low-lying mini-metropolis of Portland. Bisected by a river and surrounded by peaks, Portland is nothing if not a very pretty and almost preternaturally pleasant town. But much of its appeal comes from being, for better or worse, one of our national capitals of cool. The city’s sensibility — its stylized aesthetic, its thoroughly hyped food culture, its taste for irony — is celebrated, imitated and satirized. Portland is at its best, though, when you step back from its overwrought reputation and appreciate its appetite for simple pleasures: beer and bike riding, day trips to the Columbia River or Sauvie Island’s farm stands, movies in vintage theaters and cocktails in ornate lounges.

abstract: The firm’s quarterly results could offer some insight into just how much the Volcker Rule helps or hinders investment banks in volatile markets.

If big banks like Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase could put their own capital to work, investors would not have endured so much volatility, or so the thinking went. But thanks to new regulations in the Dodd-Frank Act, they had to sit idly by, unable to either profit much or lend a hand.

headline: Simone Rocha on Her (Very Personal) First Store
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2015)']
abstract: The designer says her new shop in London, which is filled with art installations and flower motifs, is a brick-and-mortar embodiment of her identity.
lead_paragraph: It’s been five years since Simone Rocha first showed at London Fashion Week, when she was just a promising Central Saint Martins graduate with a familiar last name. (Her father, John Rocha, had long been on the schedule with his eponymous label, run in partnership with her mother, Odette Gleeson.) But over the last 10 seasons, the younger Rocha has built a brand that has little to do with her family. Her textural, tough-romantic clothes have won her two British Fashion Awards, for Emerging Designer 2013 and New Establishment Designer 2014, and today her pieces are stocked by the likes of Dover Street Market, Colette, Bergdorf Goodman and 10 Corso Como. Finally, this fall, she has opened her first standalone store on London’s Mount Street, alongside Marc Jacobs, Roksanda and Céline.

headline: ‘Paid For,’ by Rachel Moran
abstract: A woman looks back on her early years as a Dublin prostitute.
lead_paragraph: A few months after she began selling sex on the streets of Dublin at 15, Rachel Moran writes in her memoir, “Paid For,” a pack of teenage girls descended upon her on the sidewalk and beat her. As the girls retreated, Moran remembers, “one of them turned and screamed back at me, ‘Your body is your own and no one else’s!’ ” That the lesson came with blows did not bother Moran, at least at the time of writing. On the contrary, she sees it as a “misdirected” expression of justified female fury at the sex trade. “Prostitution is objectionable to females,” she writes. “I of all people know that.”
