headline: Facts & Figures: Sarah Palin’s Glacier Claims
abstract: She’s right that some glaciers are growing, according to FactCheck.org, but that’s not evidence against climate change.
lead_paragraph: Apropos of President Obama’s visit to Alaska, Sarah Palin cited the fact that some glaciers are growing in size as evidence against human-caused climate change. “Obama was up here looking at, say, the glaciers and pointing out a glacier that was receding,” she said on CNN over the weekend. “Well, there are other glaciers, though, that are growing up here.”

headline: An Uninhibited New Show from an Art-World Provocateur
abstract: The painter Dana Schutz often embarks on her challenging figurative works just to prove she can.
lead_paragraph: Ask Dana Schutz, as a reasonable person might, why she painted a man eating his own face — or a gyrating woman simultaneously cooking and urinating in her kitchen, or the autopsy of Michael Jackson, four years prior to his actual death — and her guileless reply often boils down to some variation on: “I wanted to see if I could.” Though she frames these assays as essentially formal challenges, skirmishes between painter and paint, Schutz’s imagination has given rise to some of the most memorably skewed canvases of the past 15 years. That she so often succeeds reflects the sheer visual appeal of her clamorous palette, her bold gestures, and her knack for reflecting all-too-human foibles in absurdist scenarios.

headline: Migrant Tide Bringing Out Europe’s Best and Worst
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Thousands of volunteers have come forward with support and material aid, but even in the most welcoming of countries, tensions have flared.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Thousands of volunteers have heeded calls to help the stream of migrants arriving in Europe in recent days, cheering them at train stations in Austria and Germany and showering them with food, drinks and toys. But signs of tension have continued to appear this week, even in the most welcoming countries, reflecting fear, misunderstanding or racism as the Continent struggles to cope with an influx of tens of thousands of people.

headline: Classical Playlist: Brahms, Vivaldi and Tallis
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: Brahms: The Complete Songs, Vol. 6Ian Bostridge, tenor; Graham Johnson, piano(Hyperion)In his complete lieder surveys for the Hyperion label, one of Graham Johnson’s great talents has been matching songs to singer, building recital recordings that work on their own and also suit the demands of the whole. Ian Bostridge’s reflective, often pained way with words would not suit all of Brahms’s songs, but, despite occasional strain, this is one of the tenor’s finest releases. Take the Opus 85 landscapes, the Heine settings “Sommerabend” and “Mondenschein,” which shimmer with detail, or the last of the Opus 32 “Lieder und Gesänge,” “Wie bist du, meine Königin” — a master class of descriptive subtlety from singer and pianist alike. (David Allen)

headline: Harold Koda on Passing the Torch at the Costume Institute
abstract: Mr. Koda discusses his legacy and plans as he approaches his January retirement.
lead_paragraph: When Harold Koda, 65, retires in January, after 14 years heading the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, he will leave behind a legacy of ambitious and crowd-pleasing shows like “Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty” and the recent “China: Through the Looking Glass,” exhibitions that not only set attendance records but also reflected radical shifts in our understanding of the sociocultural, ethnographic and even anthropological dimensions of fashion and costume.

headline: No Charges for Washington State Officers in Hispanic Man’s Death

headline: Hooray for Hollywood! (No, Really.)
abstract: Our chief film critics discuss the state of the movies and find reason for hope.
lead_paragraph: The system is broken. High-quality, mid-budget prestige movies are an endangered species. Television is better. Audiences are fleeing. Film is dying. Sequels are ruining everything. These are some of the familiar objections that surface whenever critics, media journalists and other entertainment pundits take stock of the big picture, an appraisal that often turns into agony over the (inevitably worsening) state of the art and industry. What everyone agrees on is that “they” don’t make movies like they used to.

There you’ll find beautiful objets like a Nightingale top-handle bag in a multicolor carpet print ($2,395) that’s sure to make you stand out from the street-style scrum. At 747 Madison Avenue.

headline: Why Did So Many Famous Couples Break Up This Summer?
abstract: As Jon Hamm and Jennifer Westfeldt join the list of celebrity couples calling it quits, a publicist, a therapist and a gossip columnist theorize on the timing.
lead_paragraph: Summer lovin’, had me a blast. Or that’s the idea, anyway.

headline: Thabo Sefolosha, Atlanta Hawks Player, Spurns Lenient Plea Bargain
abstract: Mr. Sefolosha’s lawyer said his client believed four officers arrested him outside a Manhattan nightclub for no reason, breaking a bone in his leg and causing him to miss the N.B.A. playoffs.
lead_paragraph: Thabo Sefolosha, the basketball player, was offered a lenient plea bargain on Wednesday to resolve criminal charges against him arising from a scuffle with the police in Manhattan: Do a day of community service, stay out of trouble for six months and the charges would be dismissed.

headline: Justice Department Sets Sights on Wall Street Executives
abstract: New policies prioritize the prosecution of individual employees and put pressure on corporations to turn over evidence against their executives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stung by years of criticism that it has coddled Wall Street criminals, the Justice Department issued new policies on Wednesday that prioritize the prosecution of individual employees — not just their companies — and put pressure on corporations to turn over evidence against their executives.

headline: President Obama to Greet Pope Francis at Andrews Air Force Base
abstract: Presidents almost never go to Andrews to welcome visiting foreign leaders, instead waiting for them at the White House. But Mr. Obama will make an exception when the pope arrives on Sept. 22.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will take the rare step of heading to Andrews Air Force Base outside of Washington to personally greet Pope Francis when he arrives for a visit on Sept. 22, the White House said on Wednesday.

headline: Lawyer for Ex-Dewey Executive Seeks to Sow Doubt on Evidence Against Him
abstract: A lawyer for Stephen DiCarmine, ex-executive director of defunct law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, said the grand larceny and fraud case against him was built on email evidence that could be misinterpreted.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for Stephen DiCarmine, the former executive director of the once-prominent law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, told a New York jury on Wednesday not to convict his client based solely on dozens of emails.

headline: André Saraiva Adds Breakfast to His Portfolio
abstract: At the new Café Henrie in Manhattan, the artist and club owner will practice the art of bringing people together.
lead_paragraph: André Saraiva, the rakish graffiti artist and international club owner, has historically focused his ambitions at entertaining between dusk and dawn. For his next trick, he’s taking aim at a new frontier: breakfast.

headline: New Justice Dept. Guidelines
abstract: “One of the most effective ways to combat corporate misconduct is by seeking accountability from the individuals who perpetuated the wrongdoing,” wrote Sally Q. Yates, the deputy attorney general, in the memo on new guidelines.
lead_paragraph: “One of the most effective ways to combat corporate misconduct is by seeking accountability from the individuals who perpetuated the wrongdoing,” wrote Sally Q. Yates, the deputy attorney general, in the memo on new guidelines.

headline: United Airlines and the Port Authority
abstract: The executive ousters are a spectacular reminder of the troubled culture in the bistate agency.
lead_paragraph: Reverberations from the traffic jam engineered two years ago by aides of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey have now hit United Airlines. Jeff Smisek, United’s chief executive, and two senior officials resigned this week “in connection with the company’s previously disclosed internal investigation related to the federal investigation associated with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey,” according to the official company statement.

headline: Report Finds Most Nations Hinder Women
abstract: A World Bank study said 90 percent of the countries surveyed have at least one law that discriminates against women.
lead_paragraph: The United States is one of four countries around the world with no national laws requiring paid parental leave for new mothers.

headline: Maine: Speedy Hiker Will Pay Fine After Champagne Celebration
abstract: Scott Jurek, the ultramarathon runner who set a speed record for hiking the Appalachian Trail in 46 days, agreed to pay a $500 fine for public drinking at the trail’s terminus on Mount Katahdin.
lead_paragraph: Scott Jurek, the ultramarathon runner who set a speed record this summer for hiking the Appalachian Trail in 46 days, agreed Wednesday to pay a $500 fine for public drinking at the trail’s terminus on Mount Katahdin. In exchange, the state of Maine agreed to drop charges that he was littering when he spilled celebratory Champagne on the mountaintop and that he was traveling with an oversize group. Baxter State Park, the location of Katahdin, has said that so many hikers were breaking the rules, it might move the Appalachian Trail out of the park. That matter, which was not part of the case against Mr. Jurek, remains a question. Walter McKee, Mr. Jurek’s lawyer, said that while Baxter was hoping the charges might limit the number of hikers, “as a result of the attention, there will probably be more people on the trail and in the park.” R. Christopher Almy, who prosecuted the case, said the $500 fine — up from the normal $200 — reflected the seriousness of the charge.

headline: Queen Elizabeth II: Key Moments in Her Reign
abstract: Key moments highlighted during the reign of Queen Elizabeth II.
lead_paragraph: Key moments highlighted during the reign of Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: Seattle Teachers Go on First Systemwide Strike in 30 Years After Talks Collapse
abstract: The school shutdown affected 53,000 students and 5,000 teachers and other workers; negotiations are to resume Thursday.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Elias Lawrence’s first day of kindergarten did not turn out as planned. With teachers walking the picket lines and classes across the city canceled, Elias, 5, instead got a day at a city community center near his home and a brief lesson in labor relations from his father, Noah Lawrence.

headline: A Senseless Delay on the Iran Deal
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans seem determined to drag out the fight, even if it means neglecting other business.
lead_paragraph: The bruising battle over the Iran nuclear agreement should be over, now that 42 Democratic senators declared their support for the deal and made it clearer than ever that efforts to kill it will fail. But the Republican-led Congress seems determined to drag out the fight, even if it means neglecting other business, including legislation to fund the government.

headline: In Making ‘Everest,’ Filmmakers Embrace Towering Ambitions
abstract: To make it real, filmmakers contended with freezing temperatures, thin air and avalanches.
lead_paragraph: To make it real, filmmakers contended with freezing temperatures, thin air and avalanches.

headline: Toyota Fashions a Bolder Image for the Practical Prius
abstract: The new Toyota Prius is longer and sleeker than the current egg-shaped model, and it comes with striking new headlamps and a prominent rear spoiler.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Toyota Prius gas-electric hybrid did not need cutting-edge styling to become the best-selling alternative-fuel car in the world. If anything, its sensible design struck a chord with consumers more interested in fuel economy than fashion.

headline: Saudi Diplomat in India Is Accused of Rape
abstract: The diplomat could be expelled if authorities substantiate allegations that he imprisoned and raped two Nepali maids. The Saudi Embassy has denied the allegations.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian police are investigating allegations that a Saudi diplomat imprisoned and repeatedly raped two Nepali maids who worked in his home. The Saudi Embassy has denied the allegations.

headline: The Rail Executive United Airlines Tapped to Lift Its Fortunes
abstract: Until his surprise appointment on Tuesday as chief executive of United Airlines, Oscar Munoz had been a rising star at CSX Corporation.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, Oscar Munoz might seem like an unlikely pick to run one of the world’s largest airlines.

headline: Stanton R. Cook, a Chief of the Tribune Company, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Cook rose from an engineer post in the production department of The Chicago Tribune to chief executive of the Tribune Company, taking it public in 1983.
lead_paragraph: Stanton R. Cook, who as chief executive of the Tribune Company in the 1970s and ’80s transformed it from a privately held, conservative family enterprise into a publicly traded, more centrist media empire, died on Sept. 3 at his home in Kenilworth, Ill., near Chicago. He was 90.

headline: Kerry Favors an American Commitment to Bringing in More Refugees
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The secretary of state tells lawmakers that the United States could possibly accept as many as 100,000 next year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry told lawmakers in a closed-door session on Wednesday that he favored significantly increasing the number of refugees the United States is willing to accept, possibly to as many as 100,000 next year, according to congressional staff members and Obama administration officials.

headline: James Blake, Retired Tennis Pro, Says Police Pushed Him Down; Inquiry Is Opened
abstract: Mr. Blake, in New York for the United States Open, said he was pushed outside a Manhattan hotel by the police and handcuffed after being mistaken for a suspect in a fraud case.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department is investigating an episode in which James Blake, a retired top-10 professional tennis player, said he was pushed to the ground outside his hotel by a police officer on Wednesday and handcuffed by several officers who had mistaken him for a suspect in a fraudulent credit card operation.

headline: Fires in West Have Residents Gasping on the Soot Left Behind
abstract: California’s largest fire has exposed an effect of record drought in the Central Valley: dangerous drops in air quality that exacerbate ongoing public health problems in this region.
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — The air in the San Joaquin Valley hangs thick with gray-brown dust, a result of the state’s largest fire, which has burned through more than 160 square miles in the nearby hills.

headline: Others Left Standing Face a Tall Hurdle in Serena Williams
abstract: Odds are that it will require something resembling the match of a lifetime to deny Williams’s bid for a Grand Slam: The other U.S. Open semifinalists have a combined one victory against her.
lead_paragraph: So who can still stop the first Grand Slam in 27 years?

headline: Dynamic Voodoo
abstract: This is getting even more ridiculous.
lead_paragraph: We have a first score on the Jeb! tax plan — in answer to Matt O’Brien, I think we refer to this as the Bush! tax! cuts! It’s $3.4 trillion in lost revenue. But most of this will be made up through higher growth, Bush’s advisers, led by Glenn Hubbard, assure us.

headline: Dennis Greene, a Singer With Sha Na Na, Dies at 66
abstract: Mr. Greene, who left the band after 15 years, went on to become a vice president of Columbia Pictures and then a law professor.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Greene, a founding member of Sha Na Na, a band that became famous in the 1970s for its simultaneously nostalgic and comedic approach to the rock ’n’ roll of the 1950s, died on Saturday at a hospital near his home in Dayton, Ohio. He was 66.

headline: Minneapolis Fighting Terror Recruitment
keywords: ['Youth', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Law enforcement officials and some Somali leaders said the new programs were a way to stop extremism long before an arrest became necessary.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS —  This city’s struggle with terrorism recruitment showed itself on two fronts Wednesday. In the morning, a Somali-American teenager admitted in court here that he had tried to flee the country and join the Islamic State. Hours later, federal prosecutors and some leaders among the region’s large Somali population announced about $1 million in funding for programs meant to combat just that type of radicalization.

headline: Two D.N.C. Officials Call for Adding More Debates
abstract: Two vice chairs of the Democratic National Committee are publicly calling on the party to increase the number of presidential debates, adding high-profile voices to efforts to change a process some have criticized as being too restrictive and too favorable to Hillary Rodham Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Two vice chairs of the Democratic National Committee are publicly calling on the party to increase the number of presidential debates, adding high-profile voices to efforts to change the process.

headline: Breakthrough Performances of the Fall Season
abstract: Taissa Farmiga, Jacob Tremblay, Laia Costa and Geza Rohrig are actors to watch.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Final Girls’

headline: Rain Aids Simona Halep; Flavia Pennetta Wins Under Scorching Sun
abstract: Halep’s match against Victoria Azarenka was delayed during the third set, allowing her to refocus and advance to the U.S. Open semifinals for the first time. Pennetta beat Petra Kvitova.
lead_paragraph: The retractable roof on Arthur Ashe Stadium is not finished, despite the new steel structure rising above the court.

headline: Onetime Chairwoman of NBCUniversal News Announces Her Exit
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Patricia Fili-Krushel’s tenure has coincided with a difficult time for NBCUniversal’s news division, marked by ratings slides of valued properties.
lead_paragraph: The former chairwoman of NBCUniversal News, Patricia Fili-Krushel, said Wednesday that she was leaving the company, probably in the coming months.

headline: New York City Health Board Repeals Rule on Consent Forms for Circumcision Ritual
abstract: A rule had required parents to sign a consent form before metzitzah b’peh, a ritual in the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community that has been linked to herpes infections in infants.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Board of Health voted on Wednesday to ease regulations on a controversial circumcision ritual practiced in the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community, fulfilling a priority of Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: California Democrats Drop Plan for 50 Percent Oil Cut
abstract: Opponents, in dealing a major setback to environmentalists, had warned that the percent mandate would result in higher fuel and electricity costs.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a major setback for environmental advocates in California, Gov. Jerry Brown and Senate Democrats abandoned a 50 percent cut in petroleum use by 2030 that was a centerpiece of emissions legislation, blaming an intense campaign against the mandate by the oil industry.

headline: Auto Safety Agency Sets Date for Update on Airbag Recall
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration will hold a public meeting on Oct. 22 to provide updates on the sweeping recall of defective Takata airbags.
lead_paragraph: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration will hold a public meeting on Oct. 22 to provide updates on the latest progress, or lack thereof, in the sweeping recall of defective Takata airbags. The airbags, linked to at least eight deaths and scores of injuries, contain faulty inflaters that can explode and spray metal into the cabin of a vehicle. Last week, the safety agency said the recall affected 23.4 million inflaters in 19.2 million vehicles. So far, only 4.4 million of those inflaters have been replaced. In a statement on Wednesday, the agency’s administrator, Mark R. Rosekind, said the meeting would be “an opportunity to provide the information we’ve gathered since launching the coordinated remedy proceeding in May.”

headline: Senate Republicans Balk at Iran Deal
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Vetoes (US)', 'International Relations']
abstract: As President Obama will, in all likelihood, obtain the votes needed to avoid a veto, Republican senators continued to frame the deal as dangerous and destabilizing.
lead_paragraph: As President Obama will, in all likelihood, obtain the votes needed to avoid a veto, Republican senators continued to frame the deal as dangerous and destabilizing.

headline: Review: ‘The Legend of Georgia McBride,’ From Elvis Impersonator to Drag Queen
abstract: A straight young man in the Florida Panhandle finds an unlikely path to prosperity in this Matthew Lopez play at the Lucille Lortel Theater.
lead_paragraph: A young Elvis impersonator barely eking out a living finds an unlikely path to prosperity in “The Legend of Georgia McBride,” a stitch-in-your-side funny, if improbable, new comedy by Matthew Lopez that opened on Wednesday at the Lucille Lortel Theater. The salvation of Casey, the play’s beleaguered hero, portrayed with winning boyish (and girlish) charm by Dave Thomas Brown, turns out to be equipment already in his proverbial toolbox: sequins, makeup and a highly developed skill in lip-syncing.

headline: BMI to Announce It Surpassed $1 Billion in Revenue
abstract: Strength of the digital sector helped the licensing agency collect slightly more last year than Ascap, its biggest competitor.
lead_paragraph: The music industry may be struggling to make money in the streaming age, but one part of the business has been growing consistently: payments to songwriters.

headline: Blab
abstract: Tracy Gray’s puzzle is full of something, and it’s probably not what you are thinking.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — It will surprise absolutely no one who has been reading this blog for more than a month that I had an extremely slow start on this one. If I find myself glaring menacingly at the grid with very little filled in even after gaining a toehold, I automatically assume that the theme has a rebus element. Then I go about looking for places to squeeze letters into individual squares.

headline: Gabrielle Burton, Feminist Novelist and Screenwriter, Dies at 76
abstract: Ms. Burton considered conventional marriage lopsided but identified with the pioneering Donner Party wife who perished protecting her husband.
lead_paragraph: Gabrielle Burton, a feminist novelist, memoirist and screenwriter who considered conventional marriage lopsided but identified with the pioneering Donner Party wife who perished protecting her husband, died on Sept. 3 at her home in Venice, Calif. She was 76.

headline: New Jersey Man Pleads Guilty to Pledging to Join ISIS
abstract: Samuel Rahamin Topaz planned to travel to Turkey and told the authorities that he sympathized with the Islamic State, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A 21-year-old New Jersey man pleaded guilty in federal court on Wednesday to planning to travel abroad with other men from New York and New Jersey to join the Islamic State.

headline: Putin and Pope May Hold Talks at United Nations
abstract: Under protocol, the pope is to hold a meeting with the leader of the country that presides over the Security Council. Currently, that is Russia.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia could have an audience with Pope Francis on the sidelines of the development summit meeting here this month — but only, the Vatican envoy to the United Nations said Wednesday, if Mr. Putin gets here in time.

headline: Roger Federer and Stan Wawrinka Prey on Fatigue at U.S. Open
abstract: With remarkable efficiency, the second-seeded Federer beat Richard Gasquet to move into the semifinals, where he will face his Swiss countryman Stan Wawrinka, a victor over Kevin Anderson.
lead_paragraph: Richard Gasquet, ragged and panting, sweat cascading down his face, reached out and barely got his racket to the ball. It seemed to take every bit of energy he had just to do that.

headline: Mets’ Latest Comeback Puts Rivals Far Behind
abstract: Two pitches after Nationals Manager Matt Williams pulled Stephen Strasburg, Yoenis Cespedes crushed a two-run homer, giving the Mets a sweep and a seven-game lead in the N.L. East
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nationals Manager Matt Williams emerged from the home dugout in the eighth inning Wednesday and headed to the mound for a routine pitching change, hanging his head as if to shield himself from a chorus of boos.

headline: Giants’ Jason Pierre-Paul Isn’t Ready for Opener, Coach Says
abstract: Tom Coughlin credited Pierre-Paul, hurt in a July fireworks accident, for staying in good shape, but the team’s doctors did not consider his hand to be in playing condition.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Since the Fourth of July fireworks accident that resulted in the amputation of Jason Pierre-Paul’s right index finger, nothing about the interaction between the Giants and Pierre-Paul, their best defensive player, has been orthodox. Shortly after the accident, he turned away team officials who arrived at his hospital in Florida. The Giants later withdrew a $60 million contract offer.

headline: Lawmakers Against the Iran Nuclear Deal
abstract: Twenty-three Democratic lawmakers have said they will not support President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran, joining their Republican colleagues in the House and the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-three Democratic lawmakers have said they will not support President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran, joining their Republican colleagues in the House and the Senate.

headline: Shoddy Fielding Sabotages C. C. Sabathia’s Return to Yankees
abstract: Sabathia had a heartening showing in his first outing since coming off the disabled list, but an error allowed two runs to score, and the Yankees went on to lose to the Orioles.
lead_paragraph: It was like old times for C. C. Sabathia. Two strikes on a batter, a pivotal moment in the game, and the Yankee Stadium crowd throwing its support behind him.

headline: Wider Division Lead May Ease Matt Harvey Dilemma
abstract: Recent wins over the Nationals have offered the Mets more flexibility in how they handle Harvey, their ace, who is approaching his recommended innings limit.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Monday and Tuesday, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson was reduced to a fan, watching the team he had constructed make two scintillating comebacks to beat the Washington Nationals in two of its biggest games of the season. A lawyer and a former member of the Marine Corps, Alderson flashed a rare wide smile Wednesday afternoon before the Mets completed their sweep of the Nationals with a 5-3 win.

lead_paragraph: Looks from the VFiles collection label winners: David Ferreira, Namilia, Moses Gauntlett Cheng, Kozaburo and Feng Chen Wang.

headline: Irving Harper, Creator of the Marshmallow Sofa, Dies at 99
abstract: The industrial designer was a pioneer of mid-20th-century Pop Art furniture designs, which included ball clocks and sunburst clocks.
lead_paragraph: Irving Harper, who pioneered Pop Art furniture design with whimsical mid-20th-century modernist classics like the marshmallow sofa, the ball clock and the sunburst clock, died on Aug. 4 at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 99.

headline: What’s On TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12:45 P.M. (Sundance) AMERICAN BEAUTY (1999) Lester Burnham (Kevin Spacey, above), a middle-age suburbanite, trades in his bourgeois trappings for a red Pontiac Firebird and a job at a fast-food restaurant after going wild for his teenage daughter’s cheerleader friend (Mena Suvari) and discovering that his wife (Annette Bening) has been unfaithful. “As these characters struggle viciously — and hilariously — to escape the middle-class doldrums, the film also evinces a real and ever more stirring compassion,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times about Sam Mendes’s Oscar winner for best picture, director, actor (for Mr. Spacey), screenplay (Alan Ball) and cinematography (Conrad L. Hall). “As it detects increasingly vital signs of life behind the absurd surfaces that Mr. Mendes presents so beautifully, the film takes on a gravity to match its evil zest. There’s a haunting power to Lester’s last narrative note to the viewer: that if you don’t share the film’s piercing vision of what really matters, someday you will.”

headline: Rachel Comey: Spring 2016 RTW
abstract: Looks from Ms. Comey’s spring 2016 presentation.
lead_paragraph: Looks from Ms. Comey’s spring 2016 presentation.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 10, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “Corporations can only commit crimes through flesh-and-blood people. It’s only fair that the people who are responsible for committing those crimes be held accountable.”

headline: The Intimate and Infinite Along the 100th Meridian
abstract: Combining aerial and large-format photography, Andrew Moore aimed to capture the vast landscape of the 100th meridian line, and the stories of families connected to the land.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Moore is a veteran New Yorker accustomed to claustrophobic and overstimulated environments. Perhaps that’s why a visit to North Dakota in 2005, and an encounter with the arid, expansive and mostly desolate lands of the 100th meridian, appealed to him as it had homesteaders in years past.

headline: The Quieter Gun Death Toll
abstract: The presence of poorly secured firearms in American homes offers too much of a risk for those in despair.
lead_paragraph: The grisly carnage from mass shootings regularly attracts the nation’s focus as a public safety issue, if only fleetingly. But the highest death toll from guns by far continues to be the far less noticed wave of suicides — nearly 20,000 a year — by Americans whose easy access to guns presents an irresistible temptation in a critical moment of despair.

headline: Tianjin Chemical Explosion Raises Concerns, in China and the U.S.
abstract: Readers urge greater oversight of industrial safety in both countries.

headline: Compassion for Refugees Isn’t Enough
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Unless we address the war in Syria, the exodus will grow.
lead_paragraph: Bravo to Pope Francis, Angela Merkel and so many ordinary Germans and Austrians who have welcomed refugees into their lands. Kudos to those American politicians acknowledging that we should accept more Syrian refugees — the U.S. has admitted only 1,500 since the war started four years ago, which is pathetic.

headline: Hillary Is Hobbling, for Now
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The media, and possibly the public, loathes coasting. Trajectory makes a better story. And for Clinton, the only available trajectory was down.
lead_paragraph: I must say that I’m starting to feel bad for Hillary Clinton. There is a sense surrounding her candidacy of building doom and imminent disaster.

headline: A Presidential Primary Cheat Sheet
abstract: Let’s recap what the Republicans have been up to.
lead_paragraph: The presidential campaign is getting serious, people. Just four months to the Iowa caucuses! You’re supposed to be concerned citizens, and your friends are going to expect you to update them regularly. If you can’t, be prepared to take an active part in discussions about the Tom Brady divorce rumors.

headline: A Smarter Way to Raise Paychecks
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Minimum Wage', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Poverty']
abstract: Subsidies work better than tax credits or a minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: LOCAL and state minimum-wage increases are in style this season, with cities nationwide moving toward a $15-an-hour floor. But simply mandating that employers pay more is a clumsy and potentially counterproductive way to help the poor. Although some workers gain, others lose out on jobs altogether, while consumers — many poor themselves — face higher prices.

headline: A Flawed Medical Malpractice System
abstract: Doctors and lawyers discuss how the current system fails both doctors and patients.

headline: Helping a Suicide When the End Isn't Near
abstract: Should people who are not dying but suffer unbearably be permitted assistance in killing themselves?

headline: News Q’s | The Hummingbird’s Tongue: How It Works
abstract: What does new research reveal about how hummingbirds use their tongues?
lead_paragraph: In “The Hummingbird’s Tongue: How It Works,” James Gorman reports on new research about how hummingbirds drink nectar.

headline: The Target Neighborhood: Hamilton Heights
abstract: Janet Aschkenasy and Jimmy Napoli knew where to look for an apartment with more space and lower living expenses.
lead_paragraph: Many years ago, Janet Aschkenasy’s grandfather bought the five-story townhouse near Gramercy Park that housed his dental practice. He later moved his practice to the 1963 white brick co-op building diagonally across the street.

headline: ‘My Father’s Last Romance’: Readers (and Arlene Herself) Respond
abstract: Last Sunday’s Modern Love column elicited a wide range of opinions on elderly love and Arlene’s decision not to live with the author’s father. Most notably, we heard from Arlene herself.
lead_paragraph: Last Sunday’s Modern Love column elicited a wide range of opinions on elderly love and Arlene’s decision not to live with the author’s father. Most notably, we heard from Arlene herself.

headline: Europeans Seek to Use Force Against Smugglers at Sea
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Human Trafficking', 'Smuggling', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The proposal is a step down from what leaders originally wanted: approval to conduct military operations along Libya’s coast, on land and water, to seize and disrupt smugglers.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — European countries are pushing for a United Nations Security Council resolution to allow their military forces to apprehend human-smuggling vessels in the international waters of the Mediterranean Sea, diplomats here said.

headline: Notre Dame President Stands Firm Amid Shifts in College Athletics
abstract: The Rev. John I. Jenkins suggests that student-athletes be able to monetize their fame, with limits. But he adamantly opposes a model in which college sheds what is left of its amateur ways.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — Now is a good time to take a reflective walk with the president of the University of Notre Dame, through the woods behind his office in a golden-domed building, beside two lakes named after saints. A good time, and a serene setting, to ponder a sacred matter of profound moral implications: college athletics.

headline: Review: Mike Kelley Uncorks Superman’s Kandor City in a Bottle
abstract: In the decade before he took his own life, Mr. Kelley pursued a major project about loneliness and isolation — 30 works from which are on display at a new exhibition.
lead_paragraph: During his last decade, Mike Kelley (1954-2012), one of the most influential artists of his generation, devoted an extraordinary amount of time and effort to a theme from Superman comics: the city of Kandor, capital of Superman’s home planet, Krypton. Before Krypton was destroyed by a chain reaction in its radioactive core, the space archvillain Brainiac shrank Kandor and put it and its live inhabitants into a bottle. Years later, the grown-up Superman wrested the bottled city away from Brainiac. Unable to restore Kandor to its original size, he kept it in his Arctic Fortress of Solitude, along with all his other memorabilia.

headline: Afghans See American General as Crucial to Country’s Defense
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: Although Afghanistan is supposed to be running the war, Gen. John F. Campbell’s prominent role may be a sign that the fight against the Taliban is not going well.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Gen. John F. Campbell holds several titles: top NATO commander in Afghanistan, commander of the Resolute Support Mission coalition, commander of United States Forces-Afghanistan.

headline: Homo Naledi, New Species in Human Lineage, Is Found in South African Cave
abstract: A cave in South Africa yielded the discovery of a previously unidentified member of the early human lineage — Homo naledi, a hominin species who seem to have buried their dead.
lead_paragraph: Acting on a tip from spelunkers two years ago, scientists in South Africa discovered what the cavers had only dimly glimpsed through a crack in a limestone wall deep in the Rising Star Cave: lots and lots of old bones.

headline: What Does it Mean to Be ‘a Real Man’?
abstract: Do you think American men — and maybe men elsewhere in the world — are confused about what it means to be a man? What does “being a man” mean to you? Why?
lead_paragraph: Do you think American men — and maybe men elsewhere in the world — are confused about what it means to be a man? A professor at Stony Brook University does, and he has founded a Center for the Study of Men and Masculinities to study the problem.

headline: Minotaur in His Maze
abstract: MacDonald ­Harris’s view of human identity as a kind of freak accident provides an undergirding structure of mystery to much of his work.
lead_paragraph: No one, observing MacDonald ­Harris, would have taken him for a literary genius. He did not dress head to toe in black. He never posed for a photograph in a wrestling singlet, in Zen robes or atop a granite outcrop whose austere majesty was echoed by his windswept quiff. By September 1985, when I became his student and his friend, there was no hair at all to invite the wind’s attention. The luster of his pate gave his head the appearance of the polished ball end of some precision-­engineered chrome socket, or an observatory dome. You might have supposed that the mind inside that dome was busy working up new techniques of heat dissipation in airplane engines, but not new plots, new characters. He wore button-down shirts, tucked into jeans that were belted and pressed. His preferred footwear was the kind of tan hybrid of sneaker and Oxford shoe favored by Elderhostelers. Sometimes, it is true, he would wear a floppy-brimmed bucket hat and a funny kind of jacket, vaguely suggestive of an interest in trout fishing or photo safaris. But — as with the high, lustrous cranial dome — if you saw him in his goofy hat and jacket, you would have been less likely to think, “There goes a literary innovator gifted with an original and unfettered artistic imagination” than “There goes a chemical engineer who enjoys cultivating succulents.”

headline: If You Build It, They Will Come ... Won’t They?
abstract: The University of Cincinnati is trying to raise its profile through a risky (but increasingly common) investment: expensive architecture.
lead_paragraph: When you think of a classic American college campus, you probably envision a set of pastoral images: a demure brick rowhouse crowned with a white steeple, a gargoyle perched on a limestone archway, a domed library on a sunlit grass quadrangle. Often far from cities or shielded from them by gates and walls, campuses exude a sense of refuge. Thomas Jefferson famously wanted the University of Virginia to resemble a kind of ‘‘academical village.’’

headline: Teaching Working Students
abstract: For some of the brightest undergraduates, getting through college is a logistical problem, not an intellectual one.
lead_paragraph: Students are generally passive when talking about the law, but Ellie, a sophomore at CUNY’s John Jay College of Criminal Justice, leapt into the discussion of the constitutionality of capital punishment in my death-­penalty course. When she eviscerated the Supreme Court ruling upholding Texas’ death penalty law, I knew I had met a special student. On the midterm, she earned the highest grade anyone had ever gotten on the exam. Later, I learned that she had scored 1,480 on her SAT. Ellie wanted to be an attorney; it seemed inevitable that she would end up at an Ivy League law school. She had a prodigious, nimble intellect and, as I saw it, a limitless future.

headline: At Hawaii Resort, Yoga by Day, Party by Night
abstract: At the Wanderlust festival at Oahu’s Turtle Bay Resort, ‘wellness’ includes stretching, deep breathing and a nightly concert.
lead_paragraph: It may have been the most beautiful setting for a yoga class anyone ever imagined, the view out the plate glass window framing a dream-perfect slice of Oahu’s North Shore: elegantly arching palm trees, the fabled surf crashing against the rocky shoreline, a set of wispy clouds floating across an azure sky. The teacher of the class, the impossibly named Noelani Love, strummed a ukulele while the class sang a mantra, eyes closed, and she said we sounded like angels.

headline: On Alaska’s Ferries, Beloved Bars No Longer Make the Trip
abstract: The ferries of the Alaska Marine Highway System had been home to some of the most gloriously quirky bars in the 49th state.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the ferries of the Alaska Marine Highway System have been home to some of the most gloriously quirky bars in the 49th state. As the ferries, 11 of them now, make their runs along Alaska’s south central coast, the Aleutian Islands and the Inside Passage of southeast Alaska and British Columbia, they collect all manner of passengers, from fishermen, oil workers, military personnel and adventure travelers to big fans of the ferries’ communal watering holes. The bars came with names like the Pitch & Roll aboard Motor Vessel Tustumena, and some had deliciously divey décor, as on Motor Vessel Columbia: shiny lamé wallpaper, gold Naugahyde booths and dimmer bulbs across the ceiling.

headline: The Return of the Sex Wars
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Sexual Harassment', "Women's Rights", 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)']
abstract: The decades-old intellectual debate simmering beneath the current conversation over sexual assault on campus.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, the Harvard law professor Janet Halley sat down at her dining-room table to look through a set of policies that her university created for handling complaints of sexual assault and harassment. Halley had taught this area for years, and she was interested to see what the university came up with. The new rules were released amid pressure from student-led groups of rape survivors and their advocates, who demanded that schools across the country do more on behalf of victims. Harvard was also responding to years of calls for change by the Obama administration. Just eight months earlier, Valerie Jarrett, a senior presidential adviser, called for a ‘‘more victim-centered’’ campus approach to dealing with the problem of sexual assault.

headline: Video Review: The California Lives Up to the Ferrari Name
abstract: The last California got a bit lost in the company’s other high-performance models, but the latest version drives like a true member of the Ferrari family.
lead_paragraph: EVEN aristocratic families have a member who, while successful, doesn’t hit the lofty heights the others reach. In Ferrari’s case, it would be the entry-level California. Consider it the college professor of the clan in a dynasty filled with brain surgeons, diplomats and chief executives. Successful in its own right? Sure. But surrounded by overachieving siblings and a legendary lineage including 250 GTOs and F40s, the spotlight eludes it.

headline: 1940: Churchill Visits East End
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Prime Minister Churchill pays a visit to the East End’s bombed sites in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With part of its East End blasted, blackened and leveled by fire and explosions and its West End pock-marked by bombs dropped indiscriminately, far from legitimate objectives, London survived today [Sept. 10] its third night of terror and prepared for another. Thousands of newcomers swelled the tide of the homeless from the working-class district behind St. Paul’s Cathedral, its magnificent dome standing unscathed against a fiery background. Grim-faced firemen turned from their hoses to cheer when they suddenly found Prime Minister Winston Churchill standing beside them on the charred and sodden debris which littered a street near the cathedral in which those British heroes of another day are entombed. — New York Herald Tribune, September 11, 1940

headline: 1965: Fancy Presidential Footwear
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: President Johnson gets scandal-risking cowboy boots in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Twelve-inch cowboy boots made of black alligator leather from Brazil! Six rows of gold silk stitching! And on the front of the boots, in red, white and blue, the presidential seal! President Johnson may be clumping around the White House in just such a pair of dazzling boots. He was presented with them by a Texas bootmaker. Quite recently a panty girdle resembling the Stars and Stripes was taken off the market after a protest by the Daughters of the American Revolution. The DAR has not yet been heard from on the boots, but is it proper for the presidential seal to appear on the presidential feet? — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 11, 1965

headline: This Pooch Has a Tony: Annaleigh Ashford on Playing a Poodle in ‘Sylvia’
abstract: The actress takes on the title role in A. R. Gurney’s play about a Manhattan love triangle (husband, wife and pet).
lead_paragraph: Annaleigh Ashford was walking through Central Park, keeping an eye out for dogs. It was a sunny early evening in August, and the park was bustling, but the busy city dogs didn’t seem to realize there was a celebrity — a role model, even — among them. Ms. Ashford is about to play the title role in “Sylvia,” A. R. Gurney’s play about a Manhattan love triangle (husband, wife and pet), which is finally making it to Broadway, beginning previews on Oct. 2 at the Cort Theater.

headline: In Bed With Bruce Willis (on Broadway)
abstract: The action star on his upcoming stage turn as a mattress-bound romance writer in “Misery.”
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, Bruce Willis slipped into a two-bedroom suite on the 11th floor of the Trump International Hotel Central Park, at Columbus Circle. The room was decorated in taupes, grays and sedate purples, so tasteful it nearly came back around to tasteless. Mr. Willis looked pretty tasteful, too, in an off-white shirt, tan corduroy pants and gray sneakers. He had a handsome scruff of salt-and-pepper stubble and a bald head that shone like the dome of some well-tended mosque.

headline: FIFA Official Proposes Reforms to Its Executive Committee
abstract: Many of the report’s proposals would require FIFA’s executive committee to relinquish some of its power – a prospect its author conceded would be challenging.

The proposals, he said, offer top FIFA officials a chance to enact meaningful reforms for world soccer’s governing body as it navigates corruption investigations in the United States and Switzerland.

headline: ‘Never Enough: Donald Trump and the Pursuit of Success,’ by Michael D’Antonio
abstract: “Never Enough” plants Donald Trump’s rise, fall and comeback in the context of broader social, psychological and technological trends.
lead_paragraph: As pure entertainment, the race for the Republican presidential nomination has been a resounding success. Donald Trump, the star, has been by turns witty, provocative, outrageous — and always telegenic. He helped draw an estimated 24 million viewers to the first televised Republican debate, a record, and a ratings bonanza for Fox News, with which he nonetheless publicly feuded. Blithely flouting all conventions of presidential debate and decorum, Trump indulged in the name­-calling, personal attacks and one-liners that have vaulted him to the top of the polls.

headline: Alessandra Ferri to Return as Juliet for One Performance
abstract: The ballerina, who retired from American Ballet Theater in 2007, will return to the Metropolitan Opera House in the role of Juliet in Kenneth MacMillan’s “Romeo and Juliet.”
lead_paragraph: One of the great ballerinas of her generation, Alessandra Ferri, who retired from American Ballet Theater in 2007, will return to the Metropolitan Opera House stage for one performance next season with the company, in the role of Juliet in Kenneth MacMillan’s “Romeo and Juliet.” Her scheduled performance, on June 23, will be almost nine years to the day since she bade farewell to Ballet Theater, where she had been a principal dancer for 22 years.

headline: Mitsuko Uchida Among Winners of Praeamium Imperiale Awards
abstract: The pianist Mitsuko Uchida and the ballerina Sylvie Guillem are two of the winners of the prestigious Praemium Imperiale international arts awards.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Mitsuko Uchida and the ballerina Sylvie Guillem are among the winners of this year’s prestigious Praemium Imperiale international arts awards, the Japan Art Association, which presents the awards, announced Thursday.

headline: Moncler’s “Art for Love”
abstract: Submissions by Solve Sundsbo, Alasdair McLellan and more.
lead_paragraph: Submissions by Solve Sundsbo, Alasdair McLellan and more.

headline: The Pink and the Black
abstract: The fashion designers Elsa Schiaparelli and Coco Chanel — larger-than-life figures who were real-life rivals — are the subjects of two new biographies for children.
lead_paragraph: In these boom times for biographies written for children, the 20th-century fashion designers Elsa Schiaparelli and Coco Chanel make good subjects: Their lives were filled with drama and intrigue, not to mention stunning visuals. Both worked hard and succeeded against long odds, defying convention on the way to making a real impact on the world. Each honed her craft and rose to prominence in 1920s Paris, but they had little in common, background-wise or personality-wise: The down-to-earth yet flamboyant Schiaparelli came from a cultured, well-off Italian family, the theatrical but restrained Chanel from a dirt-poor French one. The two women developed a tense rivalry, capped off by their choices during World War II, when Schiaparelli did relief work for the French and trained as a Red Cross nurse’s aide, while Chanel became a Nazi agent. So it’s fitting that two new books intended to plant their life stories in the imaginations of a new generation, “Hot Pink: The Life and Fashions of Elsa Schiaparelli” and “Coco and the Little Black Dress,” take completely different approaches.

headline: When Homework Stresses Parents as Well as Students
abstract: When homework means arguments and leaves parents feeling helpless, it affects more than just students.
lead_paragraph: Educators and parents have long been concerned about students stressed by homework loads, but a small research study asked questions recently about homework and anxiety of a different group: parents. The results were unsurprising. While we may have already learned long division and let the Magna Carta fade into memory, parents report that their children’s homework causes family stress and tension — particularly when additional factors surrounding the homework come into play.

headline: Police Officers Charged in Freddie Gray’s Death to Be Tried in Baltimore
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: In keeping the trial in the city, a judge rejected arguments that fair trials would be impossible because of the rioting and unrest set off by Mr. Gray’s death.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Six police officers charged in the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who sustained a fatal spinal cord injury in police custody, will be tried in Baltimore, a circuit court judge ruled here Thursday, saying defense lawyers had “not met their constitutional burden” for moving the trials to another jurisdiction.

headline: Welcome, Illustrator Allison Steen
abstract: The Motherlode blog has a new artist-in-residence.
lead_paragraph: The Motherlode blog welcomes our new artist-in-residence, the illustrator Allison Steen. Allison is a recent graduate of Pratt Institute and lives in Colorado with her two cats.

headline: British Panel Urges Tate to Return Looted Constable Painting, Again
abstract: For the second time in a year and a half, the panel is pressing the Tate to return an oil landscape by John Constable to the heirs of a Jewish aristocrat.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For the second time in a year and a half, a British government panel is pressing the Tate Gallery in London to return an oil landscape by John Constable to the heirs of a Jewish aristocrat whose art works were looted by the Germans during World War II from his homes and bank vault in Hungary.

headline: Presidential Race in Taiwan Reflects Women’s Rise in Politics
abstract: Two of the three candidates are women, including the front-runner, Tsai Ing-wen, showing how well Taiwan does in putting women into political office, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — The people of Taiwan appear poised to elect their first female president. Two of the three leading candidates in the January election, including the nominees of both major parties, are women.

headline: Donald Trump Questions Ben Carson’s Faith and Credentials
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Donald Trump calls into question the faith and medical skill of Ben Carson, a retired neurosurgeon and presidential candidate who is gaining Republican support, according to a new CNN poll.
lead_paragraph: Is Donald J. Trump playing defense?

headline: Back to School, Then and Now
abstract: While many kids head back to class this week, Elizabeth A. Harris, an education reporter, looked back at the first day of school over the last several decades.
lead_paragraph: Photographs of children on the first day of a new school year have a particular energy about them, with a mix of excitement and jitters — sometimes even a touch of dread — all swirling around in tiny bodies. Also, they’re so cute!

headline: In Prague, Riding the Wave of a Cocktail Revolution
abstract: In the capital of a beer-loving nation, cocktail bars are also catching on, offering sophisticated drinks at reasonable prices.
lead_paragraph: The drink looked like a whiskey sour, topped with a light cloud of foamy egg whites, much like the Boston sour variation of the classic cocktail. But the first sip was much lighter and fruitier than I had expected. Instead of whiskey, the bartender had used Zufanek Hruskovica, a type of pear brandy that had been aged in oak barrels, as well as house-made chocolate bitters. The taste was as acidic and sweet as the classic, but still noticeably different, making it both internationally recognizable and location-specific.

headline: At Hawaii Resort, Downward Dog Is a Party Animal
abstract: At the Wanderlust festival at Oahu’s Turtle Bay Resort, ‘wellness’ includes stretching, deep breathing and a nightly concert.
lead_paragraph: At the Wanderlust festival at Oahu’s Turtle Bay Resort, ‘wellness’ includes stretching, deep breathing and a nightly concert.

headline: Janis Ian and Patricia Snyder’s Relationship Builds Upon Decades of Social Upheaval
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Music', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Vows (Times Column)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Folk Music', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: Ms. Ian, the folk singer, has borne witness to many of the societal changes of the last 50 years. Her marriage to Ms. Snyder in 2003 was one example.
lead_paragraph: Janis Ian, the singer and songwriter, has lived through many of the social upheavals of the last 50 years and has borne witness to many of them in song.

headline: Exploring Whitby and the Roots of ‘Dracula’
abstract: Bram Stoker found inspiration for his famous Gothic villain in an unlikely place — a sunny seaside Yorkshire village.
lead_paragraph: Bram Stoker found inspiration for his famous Gothic villain in an unlikely place — a sunny seaside Yorkshire village.

headline: New Seamus Heaney Translation to be Published Next Year
abstract: The work is a translation of the sixth book of Virgil’s Aeneid, in which the hero Aeneas travels to the underworld to find his dead father.
lead_paragraph: In the months before he died, the poet Seamus Heaney worked on a project that had occupied him since the 1980s: a translation of the sixth book of Virgil’s Aeneid, in which the hero Aeneas travels to the underworld to find his dead father.

headline: Banksy and the Problem With Sarcastic Art
abstract: On the empty spectacle of “Dismaland.”
lead_paragraph: The day Banksy unveiled “Dismaland” — a sprawling exhibition of conceptual art that is itself a concept, with mock security guards and mouse-eared employees instructed to frown instead of smile — its ticketing website was so overwhelmed it crashed. Hours before the opening of the park, which is built on a disused resort in Weston-super-Mare, England, hundreds of people had lined up outside in the rain. “Dismaland” is a heartening display of public interest in conceptual art, even if the concept is “What if Disneyland were as bad as real life?”

headline: Fat Dad: A Vegetarian Rosh Hashana
abstract: After my dad returned from a six-month stay at a fat farm, I cooked my father his first vegetarian Rosh Hashana dinner.
lead_paragraph: When I was 11 years old, my father spent six months at a Durham, N.C., fat farm, where he lived on the rice diet in order to shed an extreme amount of weight.

headline: The Folly of N.F.L. Predictions
abstract: A five-year review shows that season forecasts usually look similar to the prior season’s final standings, with poor results.
lead_paragraph: Super Bowl 50 will be played in five months. The game is so far in the future that The San Jose Mercury News has nothing better to do than speculate about whether Taylor Swift might sing at the halftime show. A long list of events needs to unfold at Levi’s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif., before it hosts the big game on Feb. 7: like an entire N.F.L. season, for instance.

headline: WeWork Caught in Labor Dispute
abstract: Adam Neumann, one of the founders of WeWork, tried to persuade protesters that his company had taken the moral high ground in a labor dispute that left about 100 jobless.
lead_paragraph: Adam Neumann, one of the founders of WeWork, tried to persuade protesters that his company had taken the moral high ground in a labor dispute that left about 100 jobless.

headline: Change to Bank Rules Could Spur Political Fight in a Crisis
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Financial regulators are throwing a bone to sprawling global banks by watering down plans for what happens if a lender goes bust. But it makes resolving crises a bit harder.
lead_paragraph: Global bank supervisors are tying themselves in knots over T.L.A.C. This ugly initialism – for total loss-absorbing capacity – is supposed to mean that regulators ensure creditors pay for cross-border bank busts. The emerging rules look likely to be watered down for banks like HSBC, to make sure they aren’t disadvantaged against their less sprawling rivals. But what’s being proposed will make the final system even more prone to political standoffs.

headline: At WeWork, an Idealistic Start-Up Clashes With Its Cleaners
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Cleaning Services', 'Organized Labor', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Start-ups']
abstract: To its chagrin, the office-space rental firm, with a $10 billion valuation, is accused of callous, anti-labor behavior toward cleaning workers.
lead_paragraph: Adam Neumann bounded through the downtown Manhattan headquarters of WeWork, beaming as he pointed out the amenities of the open floor plan.

headline: You're All Artists Now
abstract: We asked readers to respond to a Sunday Review essay about adult creativity by drawing on the illustration that accompanied it. Here is a sample of their work.
lead_paragraph: We asked readers to respond to a Sunday Review essay about adult creativity by drawing on the illustration that accompanied it. Here is a sample of their work.

headline: Salt-Encrusted Tilefish
abstract: Chef Ignacio Mattos shares a recipe for the showstopping dish he prepared for each of Rachel Comey’s tables last night.
lead_paragraph: Chef Ignacio Mattos shares a recipe for the showstopping dish he prepared for each of Rachel Comey’s tables last night.

headline: A Recipe From Rachel Comey’s Fashion Week Feast
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2015)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: At the designer’s seasonal dinner show, chef Ignacio Mattos of Estela served whole, salt-encrusted tilefish, which he has adapted for home cooks.
lead_paragraph: Pair the fashion designer Rachel Comey with chef Ignacio Mattos of Estela for a dinner-party-slash-fashion show and you’ve got a recipe for one very chic unofficial start to New York Fashion Week, which begins today. Add in a musical performance by Justin Vivian Bond, choreographed models donning Comey’s spring/summer 2015 collection, a sprawling arts venue near the Brooklyn waterfront, and it’s no wonder the event last night drew a crowd that included notable artists and performers, as well as fellow figures from the style and culinary worlds.

headline: Justice Dept. Vow to Go After Bankers May Prove a Promise Hard to Keep
abstract: Recent investigations suggest that changes to Justice Department guidelines may not guarantee a Wall Street “perp walk.”
lead_paragraph: Banks don’t break the law, bankers do.

headline: New Data Gives Clearer Picture of Student Debt
abstract: The increases in debt and default rates are concentrated among students at for-profit and community colleges, even though those students borrow less on average.
lead_paragraph: An air of mystery has long surrounded student debt. We know the total number of borrowers and their combined debt — 40 million people owe $1.2 trillion — but beyond these headline numbers, the data has been frustratingly thin. Who borrows? Who defaults? Why are so many borrowers in distress? The answers have been unclear, leaving analysts and policy makers to prescribe remedies without an accurate diagnosis of the disease.

headline: White Bordeaux Demands Close Attention
abstract: These wines don’t come to you like big, wagging dogs. Instead, they slowly draw you in.
lead_paragraph: The last 25 years in wine have been signified by the discovery or rediscovery of regions unknown, obscure or half-forgotten. Consumers, and critics for that matter, have often embraced wines from these regions. But they have occasionally rejected them, too, with no small measure of befuddlement.

headline: Brian Williams to Start at MSNBC on Sept. 22
abstract: He will now be an anchor of breaking news and special reports, but the exact details about what he would be doing once he returns were not disclosed.
lead_paragraph: Brian Williams, the beleaguered former anchor of NBC’s “Nightly News,” will start in his new position at the cable news network MSNBC on Sept. 22, an NBC News spokesman said on Thursday.

headline: Family Protests White Poet’s Use of Chinese Pen Name
abstract: The family of a woman named Yi-Fen Chou, who attended the same high school in Fort Wayne, Ind., as Michael Derrick Hudson, has stepped forward, demanding that he immediately stop using the pen name.
lead_paragraph: Controversy erupted in the poetry world earlier this week when it was discovered that a poem included in the annual “Best American Poetry” anthology was written by a white poet, Michael Derrick Hudson, who had submitted it to a journal under the Chinese pseudonym Yi-Fen Chou.

keywords: ['Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Unemployment']

lead_paragraph: A California agency ruled in August that a former Uber driver should have been considered an employee, according to recently unearthed documents.

headline: When a Coat Is More Than a Coat
abstract: To benefit amfAR, Moncler asked 32 big-name photographers to creatively reimagine its classic puffer jacket.

headline: Your Next Lesson: Chinon
abstract: Thought-provoking reds from the Touraine region of the Loire Valley in France.
lead_paragraph: Are you ready for some red wine? I know I am. Next comes one of the most overlooked yet thought-provoking reds I know: Chinon from the Touraine region of the Loire Valley in France.

lead_paragraph: It was all about the music at Creatures of the Wind’s spring/summer 2016 show — in the beauty references, at least. The makeup artist Aaron de Mey’s vivid, graphic eyes, inspired by Siouxsie Sioux, accompanied by the hairstylist Anthony Turner’s disheveled “festival hair” brought a modern punkishness to Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters’s psychedelica-inflected collection.

headline: Autopsy Cites ‘Intentionally Removed’ Plug in Ruling Kayaker’s Death a Homicide
abstract: The lawyer for the woman accused of killing the kayaker, Vincent Viafore, said the Orange County, N.Y., medical examiner had overstepped in reaching that conclusion. Some legal experts agree.
lead_paragraph: The medical examiner’s conclusion is clear: Vincent Viafore, who the police say was killed by his fiancée during a kayaking trip on the Hudson River this past spring, was a victim of homicide caused by a “kayak drain plug intentionally removed by other.”

abstract: Plus: a companion’s mouthful of food; a friend in need (or not); and ignoring a frenemy.

keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Tennis', 'Race and Ethnicity']

abstract: Aid groups called the action a token one given the size of the U.S. economy and population, and some Republicans said President Obama was allowing in potential terrorists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, under increasing pressure to demonstrate that the United States is joining European nations in the effort to resettle Syrian refugees, has told his administration to take in at least 10,000 displaced Syrians over the next year.

headline: N.F.L. Team Scoring Just 1 Point? Now It’s Possible
abstract: Among the tweaks to N.F.L. rules for 2015 was one that went relatively unnoticed: A conversion after a touchdown can result in a safety, and is worth 1 point.
lead_paragraph: A listing of N.F.L. scores usually includes a lot of familiar numbers: 21, 14, 35, 17.

abstract: Room eight at the motel, where the singer-songwriter Gram Parsons died in 1973, is still available to rent.
lead_paragraph: Room eight at the motel, where the singer-songwriter Gram Parsons died in 1973, is still available to rent.

headline: A Joshua Tree Motel Room, Haunted by the Ghost of a Country Legend
abstract: The singer-songwriter Gram Parsons died in 1973, in a room still available to rent — and which has become a pilgrimage site for fans.
lead_paragraph: Through the curves of the Morongo Valley pass in San Bernardino County, Calif., and across a desert that shifts from a sandy void to a land dotted with Seussian plants, there’s the Joshua Tree Inn. It’s a normal motel on the side of a highway, albeit one washed in a buzzing ochre light that comes in by sundown. It is also haunted, some say, by the ghost of Gram Parsons.

lead_paragraph: Do not expect plumed caps. The outlook for high steps, flag-waving and chiropractor-defying back bends is unclear. But next month Alan Gilbert, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, will lead the orchestra’s brass section along with the mighty Michigan Marching Band at the homecoming football game against Northwestern.

lead_paragraph: General Electric has already been moving to shed its huge lending arm. Now the industrial conglomerate is potentially becoming even smaller.

headline: Northern Ireland Faces Crisis as Unionist First Minister Resigns
abstract: Peter Robinson and his party members stepped down after other parties refused to suspend assembly business during an investigation into the murder of a former Irish Republican Army member.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The fractious power-sharing provincial government in Northern Ireland came perilously close to collapse on Thursday as Peter Robinson, leader of the majority party, followed through on his threat to resign as first minister. It was the latest chapter in a political crisis prompted by police claims that the Irish Republican Army is still active a decade after it said it had disbanded.

headline: India Seeks Saudi Cooperation to Investigate Rape Allegations Against Envoy
abstract: India summoned the Saudi ambassador on Thursday to ask for his embassy’s cooperation in an investigation of claims that a Saudi diplomat raped and confined two Nepalese women.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian government summoned the Saudi ambassador on Thursday to convey a police request for his embassy’s cooperation in an investigation of allegations that two Nepali women were repeatedly raped and confined by a Saudi diplomat in the city of Gurgaon, a suburb of Delhi.

headline: Rain Postpones U.S. Open Women’s Semifinals
abstract: Thursday night’s matches, featuring Serena Williams versus Roberta Vinci and Simona Halep versus Flavia Pennetta, were rescheduled for Friday morning.
lead_paragraph: With the forecast calling for persistent rain, United States Open organizers postponed Thursday evening’s women’s singles semifinals until Friday morning, with play scheduled to begin at 11 a.m.

headline: Teaching ‘Mockingbird,’ ‘Watchman’ and Harper Lee With The New York Times
abstract: Does “Watchman” change how you’ll teach “Mockingbird”? Here are six ideas for teaching “Mockingbird” today, as well as many resources for connecting Harper Lee and her work to the world around us.

abstract: Jeb Bush, who was Florida’s governor when his rival Marco Rubio was speaker of the Statehouse, is boasting about all the endorsements he has received from the men who used to have Mr. Rubio’s job.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush has a message for Marco Rubio: Your former colleagues like me better.

headline: A Pregnancy Souvenir: Cells That Are Not Your Own
abstract: The process by which women acquire cells from a fetus, called fetal microchimerism, is not as rare as once thought, but remains quite mysterious.
lead_paragraph: Recently, a team of pathologists at Leiden University Medical Center in the Netherlands carried out an experiment that might seem doomed to failure.

headline: Breaking Good News Can Be as Hard as Breaking Bad
abstract: A large part of what it means to be a physician is to be the harbinger of bad news.
lead_paragraph: I was standing at a counter on the medical ward, having my afternoon coffee, when one of the residents threw her hands up in the air.

headline: The Surf Is Always Up at This NoLIta Boutique
abstract: Rob Magnotta and Winnie Beattie, the owners of Warm, carry men’s wear from obscure labels, and certain staples are available year-round.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of cooler weather doesn’t mean that summer has to end. Warm, a boutique in NoLIta that caters to men and women, has a beachy feel all year. An alcove near the entrance is where the shop’s owners, the husband-and-wife team Rob Magnotta and Winnie Beattie, stock their men’s wear from obscure Japanese and French labels, not to mention their men’s wares, like candles in tin cups and knives handmade from reclaimed disk plows. While the couple redesigns Warm’s interior for each season, certain staples, like flip-flops and swim trunks, are available year-round. Stepping into the store, you feel as if you’ve been transported from New York City to the Venice section of Los Angeles. Here, Mr. Magnotta talks more about Warm.

headline: Answers to Questions About Apple’s New Products
abstract: Here are our responses to reader queries about the new Apple devices introduced at a company event on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: We asked readers to send us questions about Apple’s new products on Wednesday when the company unveiled updated iPhones, a bigger iPad, an upgraded Apple TV and accessories. Many readers had queries about the new devices and how they work. Brian X. Chen and J. D. Biersdorfer answered the most frequently asked ones.

Guests included Emily Ratajkowski, dressed in Balmain and a Target necklace, who said she was not quite a fashion week veteran. “I’m kind of like a sophomore or junior,” she said.

headline: As Head-Up Displays Become Common, Distraction Becomes an Issue
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Automobiles']
abstract: The technology, which shows data like a vehicle’s speed in front of the driver, is moving beyond performance cars and appearing in more models.
lead_paragraph: When Manish Undavia took delivery of the 2016 Audi A7 sedan — list price, about $71,000 — it came with technology rarely found in automobiles, even five years ago: collision avoidance systems, sensors to keep the car from drifting and, perhaps most baffling to Mr. Undavia, a head-up display.

headline: No Surf, but Maybe Dunes in NASA’s Latest Pluto Photos
abstract: Newly released photos suggest that the dwarf planet is covered in dunes, or something that looks like dunes but was created by something other than wind.

headline: Bernie Sanders Has a Fan in the James Bond Actor Daniel Craig
