headline: Why Tennis Transcends Nationalism
abstract: Fans at the U.S. Open are more inclined to wear a player’s logo than a nation’s flag — and that’s O.K.
lead_paragraph: With the towering exception of Serena Williams, who is on the cusp of completing a calendar grand slam and tying Steffi Graf’s mark of 22 major singles titles, these are pretty lean times for American tennis. Williams is one of just two Americans in the women’s Top 20. John Isner is the only American in the men’s Top 20, and it has been 12 years since an American man won the U.S. Open.

headline: Staying Signed Into Gmail
abstract: Browser cookies store the information used to log in to websites like Gmail, and a user can adjust a browser’s settings to manage them
lead_paragraph: Q. I keep checking the box to stay signed into my Gmail account when I log into the Firefox browser on my Mac, but when I quit the program, the browser never retains the information and I have to keep logging in and typing in the security code that gets texted to my phone. How can I get Firefox to remember me?

headline: Next Steps in Putting Iran Nuclear Deal Into Effect
abstract: Five questions and answers regarding the adoption of the agreement, when it takes effect and steps that will follow.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Senate Democrats blocking passage of a resolution disapproving of the Iran nuclear deal, the attention will shift from the halls of Congress to the nations and international agencies that must put the accord into effect. Here’s what happens next.

headline: N.F.L. Week 1 Schedule and Picks
abstract: The Seahawks vs. Rams and Giants vs. Cowboys are two of the best games in the opening weekend of the N.F.L. season. Here’s what to watch on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Seahawks at Rams

headline: They Made New York
abstract: Twenty-eight legends of the Downtown scene — including Philip Glass, Larry Kramer, Chuck Close and Iman — gather in SoHo for a special portrait.
lead_paragraph: On July 14, 2015, T magazine assembled some of the artists, writers, performers, musicians and intellectuals who defined New York’s inimitable and electrifying cultural scene of the late 1970s and early ’80s. There were longtime friends (and some rivals) in the group, but overall, the mood was one of celebration. And why not? Every generation thinks it’s uniquely special, but this generation really is: These are the people who came to, and stayed in, New York when it was at its worst, and in so doing, created what was arguably the most important multidisciplinary artistic movement that the city has ever seen.

headline: Why Can’t We Stop Talking About New York in the Late 1970s?
keywords: ['Nineteen Hundred Seventies', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Art', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Those years were dangerous, electric and, as it turns out, great fodder for today’s pop culture.
lead_paragraph: The late 1970s were some of the darkest, bleakest years in New York’s history. So why can’t we stop talking about them?

headline: ‘Longmire,’ Revived on Netflix, Continues Its Embrace of Western Traditions
abstract: The show, now available for streaming, begins its fourth season by returning to the mystery of who killed the sheriff’s wife.
lead_paragraph: “Longmire” is the third major show Netflix has picked up following its cancellation on television, after “Arrested Development” and “The Killing.” At first glance, it might seem like an odd choice: a popular but old-fashioned crime procedural that was dropped by A&E after three seasons because its audience was north of the 18-to-49 demographic.

headline: Review: Louise Lecavalier Is a Typhoon of Physicality in ‘So Blue’
abstract: In this 60-minute work at New York Live Arts, Louise Lecavalier displays a fierce precision, at times with evocations of boxing, guitar playing and yoga.
lead_paragraph: In the first half of “So Blue,” Louise Lecavalier is like a one-woman typhoon, twisting and snapping her slender, androgynous body while contorting wildly to Mercan Dede’s lurching, pulsating beat. Ushering in the fall season at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, this Canadian dancer — best known as a leading member of Édouard Lock’s La La La Human Steps (from 1981 to 1999) — comes out, arms and legs swinging, in loose track pants and a skin-hugging top. Often during this moody, 60-minute work, it seems that Ms. Lecavalier is engaged in battle, but with what is hard to say.

headline: A New Concept Store in SoHo Boasts Basquiat — and Foosball
abstract: On Wooster Street, Material Good was designed for hanging out, and sells everything from vintage watches to works of art.
lead_paragraph: Perched on a second-floor loft on Wooster Street, an ambitious new concept jewelry store brings high-end pieces — the kind you find around 50th Street, where Madison and Park Avenue giants like Tiffany’s reign — to SoHo. And it’s buying into the downtown, stay-awhile vibes of its neighboring shops. A custom-made Douglas Little light fixture hangs above a long dining table, not far from a shearling daybed, a dining room table, a custom foosball table and a kitchen. But the walls are lined with gold, silver and diamonds. “It’s unforced luxury,” says Rob Ronen, a co-owner, about the homey loft. “I want people to be able to come in, and, you know, enjoy a cup of coffee or a glass of Champagne, not necessarily just to buy something. Just to hang out.” But if they are in the market, there’s no shortage of items to choose from: In addition to high-end jewelry and watches (Ronen, alongside the store’s other co-owner, Michael Herman, are authorized dealers for Audemars Piguet and Richard Mille), there are vintage watches, bought at auction houses like Christie’s and Sotheby’s; custom-made furniture by designers such as Prouvé or Charlotte Perriand; and contemporary art, including works by Jean-Michel Basquiat and Andy Warhol.

headline: “The Downtown Decade: NYC 1975 – 1985”
abstract: A new exhibition celebrates the New York underground’s most interesting 10 years.
lead_paragraph: A new exhibition celebrates the New York underground’s most interesting 10 years.

headline: Review: ‘A Brilliant Young Mind’ Facing Infinite Obstacles
abstract: A young mathematical genius played by Asa Butterfield struggles with his autism and the aftermath of his father’s death.
lead_paragraph: “A Brilliant Young Mind” refuses to soft-pedal the infuriating arrogance and coldness of its protagonist, Nathan Ellis (Asa Butterfield), a British math prodigy with autism. More than most films that address that condition, this one shows the amount of patience, understanding and commitment required from caring parents and friends who deal with someone who, however gifted, may appear selfish and unfeeling.

headline: A Time Capsule From Downtown New York’s Most Interesting Decade
abstract: The curator Lauren Miller Walsh’s new show of photos from 1975–1985 culls from the archives of MoMA PS1 and the East Village Eye.
lead_paragraph: As Edmund White notes in T’s Fall Men’s issue, our current culture is fascinated by the late ’70s and early ’80s in New York, a period when the city was veering toward financial ruin and downtown looked like a war zone. “The was a reason there was a bar called Downtown Beirut,” says the curator Lauren Miller Walsh. But downtown New York was where artists, actors, musicians and playwrights could afford to live and work, forming a vibrant artistic community.

headline: Review: Twin Terrors Haunt ‘Goodnight Mommy’
abstract: When Mommy comes back from the hospital a changed person with bandages obscuring her face, her twins take action.
lead_paragraph: Like many foreign movies that venture outside their home countries, “Goodnight Mommy” must live with an English title far inferior to its Austrian original, which literally translates as “I see, I see.” Eyes — and what we think they see — are everything in this carefully controlled creep-out, gazing into mirrors and peering through shutters and tightly wrapped gauze. When it’s over, even those who have guessed its final twist (because we have seen it before) will immediately want to watch again, if only to check the logic of its shifting points of view.

headline: Bratton on Arrest of James Blake
abstract: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said he wanted “to extend a personal apology’’ to James Blake, a retired tennis player, after his mistaken arrest on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said he wanted “to extend a personal apology’’ to James Blake, a retired tennis player, after his mistaken arrest on Wednesday.

headline: Review: Annaud’s ‘Wolf Totem,’ Set in Inner Mongolia in the 1960s
abstract: The landscape and painstakingly trained wolves are the true stars of this film, which focuses on a student who leaves Beijing to teach in a remote village during the Cultural Revolution.
lead_paragraph: In “Wolf Totem,” the French director Jean-Jacques Annaud, no stranger to animals (“The Bear”) or turbulent Chinese history (“Seven Years in Tibet”), adapts a novel that grew into a controversial phenomenon in China. The book, written by a Beijing professor, Lu Jiamin, under the pseudonym Jiang Rong, was second in circulation only to Mao’s little red book, according to a 2008 review in The New York Times.

headline: Australia Pulls Out of Soccer Friendlies With U.S. Women’s Team
abstract: Australia withdrew from two friendly matches that were to be part of the United States women’s national team’s World Cup victory tour, but U.S. Soccer said the games would go on with Haiti as a replacement opponent.
lead_paragraph: Australia on Thursday pulled out of two exhibition matches that were to be part of the United States women’s national team’s World Cup victory tour, but U.S. Soccer said the games in Detroit and Birmingham, Ala., would go ahead as scheduled with Haiti as a replacement opponent.

headline: Avon Is Said to Be in Talks About Selling a Stake
abstract: The cosmetics maker has discussed bringing in a private equity firm for what is known on Wall Street as a private investment in public equity or PIPE.
lead_paragraph: Avon Products is in talks with investment firms about selling a stake in itself, potentially bringing in a partner to help the cosmetics maker turn itself around, a person with direct knowledge of the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Review: ‘Listening,’ a World Where Your Thoughts Are Not Your Own
abstract: Khalil Sullins directed this techno-paranoia fable about mind control and hard-wired telepathy.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a while since there has been as loopy a techno-paranoia fable as Khalil Sullins’s “Listening.” This quasi-philosophical treatise on mind control and hard-wired telepathy begins as a fitfully intriguing character study before flying off the rails as a nightmarish vision of government encroachment on free thought.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Sept. 11 to 18, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: White House Wants to Admit More Refugees
abstract: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, said that President Obama wants the United States “to accept at least 10,000 Syrian refugees in the next fiscal year.”
lead_paragraph: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, said that President Obama wants the United States “to accept at least 10,000 Syrian refugees in the next fiscal year.”

headline: Fiat Chrysler Recalls Nearly 1.7 Million Ram Pickups
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']
abstract: The automaker issued three recall notices, two related to airbags and one to a defect that could affect steering.
lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler is recalling almost 1.7 million Ram pickup trucks over airbag or steering problems, the automaker said on Thursday. Just two months ago, Fiat Chrysler was assessed $105 million in civil penalties to settle regulators’ accusations that it jeopardized public safety by failing to comply with federal laws in 23 other recalls.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Wildfires', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: Japan and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Japan and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: September 10, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Japan, Greece, Germany and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Japan, Greece, Germany and Afghanistan.

headline: Biden Discusses Minimum Wage in New York
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. applauded Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday for approving plans to raise the minimum wage for fast-food workers to $15 an hour.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. applauded Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday for approving plans to raise the minimum wage for fast-food workers to $15 an hour.

headline: A Plan to Save Refugees and Europe’s Open Borders
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: A relatively modest proposal for quotas should be only a starting point in meeting the growing crisis with compassion.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Claude Juncker, the president of the European Commission and the highest official of the European Union, has laid out a plan to  distribute 160,000 refugees among E.U. members by mandatory quotas. It is a plan Europe simply must adopt if it is to get a handle on the crisis and remain true to its history and values.

headline: Bill de Blasio Opposes a Joe Biden Presidential Bid
abstract: Asked if Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. should challenge Mrs. Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York wasted no time in saying no.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York has held out on endorsing his former boss, Hillary Rodham Clinton, in the presidential race, saying he needs to hear more about her vision for the country.

headline: A Tiki Bar in Queens With an Off-the-Menu Daiquiri
abstract: After years behind the scenes, Valentin González is a head bartender at last, and he’s making a mean cocktail at a new tavern in Forest Hills.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, End of the Century is very much within the Queens Neighborhood Watering Hole genotype. There are exposed brick walls, a red-felt pool table,and a signed photo of the former Mets captain Keith Hernandez with Rodney Dangerfield.

headline: Review: ‘The Moving Creatures,’ Three Tales of Family Ordeals
abstract: Written and directed by Caetano Gotardo, this three-part movie about Brazilian families is a chilling reminder that a simple life is no shield against the disastrous.
lead_paragraph: “The Moving Creatures,” written and directed by Caetano Gotardo, is a small-bore examination of three Brazilian families beset by wrenching ordeals.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Sept. 11 to 18, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Sprawling Art Shows in Brooklyn Bridge Park and on Governors Island
abstract: Photoville and the Governors Island Art Fair will feature photography exhibitions, artworks arranged by their creators inside historic houses, how-to sessions, swaps and more.
lead_paragraph: The work of more than 100 artists will grace two of the city’s waterfront sites this weekend, giving New Yorkers the opportunity to become better photographers, take home pieces and meet their creators.

headline: U.S. Makes Final an Array of Rules on Food Safety
keywords: ['Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Consumer Protection', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The regulations, which will start to take effect next summer, require food processing companies to reduce risks instead of acting only after someone gets sick.
lead_paragraph: Far-reaching food industry rules aimed at reducing food-borne illness in the United States have become final, the federal government announced on Thursday, nearly five years after Congress passed a law requiring an overhaul of the nation’s food safety system.

headline: Palestinians Get Approval to Fly Flag at United Nations
abstract: Over Israeli and American objections, the General Assembly approved a symbolic measure that allows the flag of Palestine to fly at the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Palestinians overwhelmingly won the right on Thursday to fly their national flag in front of United Nations headquarters, a symbolic step opposed by Israel and the United States.

headline: At Venice Festival, the Wisdom of Lunatics, the Wildness of Age
abstract: Two of the best films at the festival are by the directors Marco Bellocchio and Jerzy Skolimowski, old masters taking risks.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — There is a character in “Sangue del Mio Sangue” — the Italian director Marco Bellocchio’s strange and wonderful new film — known as Il Pazzo, which translates as the Madman. He’s an unshaven, excitable fellow who wears a mismatched plaid suit, guzzles the aperitif Aperol and spouts barely comprehensible conspiracy theories. If you believe a possibly tongue-in-cheek interpretation Mr. Bellocchio offered at a news conference on Tuesday, he may be the only sane person in the movie. The lunatic-as-truth-teller is a venerable literary conceit (found in “King Lear” and, more locally, in the harlequins and zanni of commedia dell’arte) and also a notion that has a particular relevance to this festival.

headline: Nick Jonas, at Terminal 5, Sings His Hits and Covers, Too
abstract: In concert, Mr. Jonas offered pop and soul but nothing from his Jonas Brothers heyday.
lead_paragraph: Nick Jonas came onstage Wednesday night at Terminal 5 in a conspiratorial crouch, not to look smaller, as if he wanted to hide himself, but to move more slowly, emphasizing the creeping movements of his muscles, as if he were about to pounce.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Salman Rushdie and Bear Grylls
abstract: Bear Grylls and Salman Rushdie take shelter in an inflatable tent while considering doorstep drugs and a rodent romance.
lead_paragraph: Bear Grylls and Salman Rushdie take shelter in an inflatable tent while considering doorstep drugs and a rodent romance.

headline: Donald Trump Denies Attacking Carly Fiorina’s Looks
abstract: Mr. Trump said Thursday he was not referring to Mrs. Fiorina’s looks when he was quoted as saying, “Look at that face” and, “Would anyone vote for that?”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said Thursday he was not referring to Carly Fiorina’s looks when he was quoted as saying, “Look at that face” and, “Would anyone vote for that?”

headline: Review: ‘Paul Taylor: Creative Domain’ Shows a Choreographer at Work
abstract: Kate Geis’s absorbing new documentary follows a Taylor dance, “Three Dubious Memories,” as it takes shape in a matter of weeks.
lead_paragraph: “Paint doesn’t talk back,” Paul Taylor muses in Kate Geis’s absorbing new documentary, “Paul Taylor: Creative Domain.” But dancers do, and choreographers need dancers. Mr. Taylor seems to have figured out how to make this work: His dancers, as seen here, don’t talk back much, either. They’re too busy working and trying to please him, to give him something more than he asks for.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

abstract: Photos of off-the-runway scenes at fashion week.

headline: Review: ‘Negroland,’ by Margo Jefferson, on Growing Up Black and Privileged
abstract: Ms. Jefferson, a former critic for The New York Times, writes about growing up in a privileged family in Chicago yet persistently feeling the effects of racism.
lead_paragraph: Margo Jefferson’s memoir, “Negroland,” possesses a refrain, a series of sentences that are repeated, as if out of a Duke Ellington composition, so the author can hang onto them and so can we.

headline: Clinton Rips Trump After Fiorina Insult
abstract: The Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton criticized Donald Trump’s remarks on women on Thursday after he insulted the looks of his Republican rival, Carly Fiorina.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton criticized Donald Trump’s remarks on women on Thursday after he insulted the looks of his Republican rival, Carly Fiorina.

headline: Inside Christian Marclay’s World of Words
abstract: The artist opens “Surround Sounds,” a new show at Paula Cooper that focuses on comic book onomatopoeia.
lead_paragraph: Entering Christian Marclay’s newest work, “Surround Sounds,” is like walking into a particularly loud comic book. Inside a large, darkened room, cut-out sound effects whizz by on all four walls. Though the room is silent, words like “SHEEEE” and “TIC “crawl across the space. “BAM!” flashes aggressively. “I hope,” Marclay told this T reporter, “that you don’t have epilepsy.”

headline: Review: ‘The Visit’ Is ‘Hansel and Gretel’ With Less Candy and More Camcorders
abstract: M. Night Shyamalan’s new movie is one of those tales of child peril that have reliably spooked audiences for generations.
lead_paragraph: In “The Visit,” an amusingly grim fairy tale, floorboards creak, doors squeak and lights lower and sometimes shriek to black. The story, a “Hansel and Gretel” redo for Generation Selfie, has the virtue of simplicity and familiarity: A young brother and sister travel into the deep, dark woods, but where they once innocently held hands, they’re now holding camcorders to record an adventure quickened by anxious laughs, yelps and screams and one shivery long knife. These children don’t need someone else to immortalize their once-upon-a-time; they just point and shoot.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, Sept. 11 to 18, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: In ‘Meet the Patels,’ a Son Submits to a Marriage Quest
abstract: In this documentary, the wisecracking son of Indian-born parents agrees to look for a spouse with a similar background.
lead_paragraph: “Meet the Patels” is a tidy, easygoing documentary in which peripheral players prove more intriguing than its central focus. That would be Ravi Patel, a successful actor (“Transformers”; the coming TV series “Grandfathered”) in Los Angeles who has separated from his redheaded girlfriend, Audrey, lacking the nerve to tell his Indian-born parents about their relationship.

headline: To Glimpse Pope Francis, Ticket or Patience Is Required
abstract: A parade along the National Mall in Washington, a motorcade in New York’s Central Park and Mass on a Philadelphia parkway are on the schedule.
lead_paragraph: When he visits the United States this month for the first time, Pope Francis will meet with the mighty (world leaders, members of Congress, archbishops) and the meek (homeless people, schoolchildren, day laborers).

headline: Review: Come to American Beech for the Sea and Sun, Stay for the Chicken
abstract: At American Beech, seafood is a focus but dishes from terra firma are not ignored.
lead_paragraph: American Beech Restaurant, Bar & Suites has taken over the 19th-century horse stable in Greenport’s Stirling Square that previously housed Main Restaurant and Oyster Bar and, a few years before that, North Fork Oyster Company. The new establishment is light, airy and appealing. The old rustic look, along with the oyster shucker at the front of the restaurant, is history. Now it has a sparkling white bar, dove-gray walls and a floor painted in wide strips of gray and white.

headline: A Venezuelan in Silicon Valley Finds a Niche in Finance
abstract: Meyer Malka of Ribbit Capital became a rising force in Silicon Valley by betting on financial technology when few others did.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Jonathan Gheller went from selling tequeños, a Venezuelan fried, cheese-filled appetizer, in Caracas to building a company that he sold to Facebook. Now, working at its placid Menlo Park, Calif., headquarters, he credits mostly one person for his change in fortune.

headline: Comedy Listings for Sept. 11-17
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Hillary Clinton Takes Aim at Donald Trump for ‘Insulting Women’
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, apparently alluding to Donald J. Trump, says, “There is one particular candidate who just seems to delight in insulting women every chance he gets.”
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s Uncomplimentary Comments About Carly Fiorina

headline: As a Boom Fades, Brazilians Wonder How It All Went Wrong
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The crisis, including the downgrading of Brazil’s credit rating to junk status, is unleashing a withering exploration of how the country squandered its hard-won success.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — The president of Brazil should have been ecstatic. She had just won re-election after an intense campaign in which she fiercely defended her role in making Brazil, for a few fleeting years, a rising star on the global stage.

headline: Review: In ‘Home From Home,’ a Blacksmith’s Son Dreams of a Different World
abstract: Edgar Reitz’s film captures the rhythms of village life in Germany in the 1840s, when the prospect of emigration to Brazil beckoned.
lead_paragraph: Jacob, the blacksmith’s son in the German historical epic “Home From Home,” is the rare reader in his poor village, and a formidable anthropologist. The same tag could be given to Edgar Reitz, the director of this thick slice of life in 1843 Germany and its landmark predecessor, the 50-plus-hour “Heimat” film series.

headline: New Leader for Atlanta Symphony
abstract: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra named a new administrative leader, Jennifer Barlament, to replace one who resigned last year during a two-month musicians’ lockout.
lead_paragraph: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, which has been led by an interim president since its last one resigned last year in the midst of a two-month lockout during a heated labor dispute, announced Thursday that it had selected a new leader: Jennifer Barlament, currently the general manager of the Cleveland Orchestra.

abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series. A complete list of new releases is at nytimes.com/intheaters.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Review: ‘Field Notes’ Uses Visual Art to Explore Caribbean Heritage
abstract: This show at the Museum of Contemporary African Diasporan Arts showcases the work of seven emerging artists.
lead_paragraph: ‘FIELD NOTES’

headline: As Lobsters Dwindle in Long Island Sound, Oysters Thrive
abstract: As many sea animals seek cooler waters, aquaculture farmers are turning to resilient mollusks.
lead_paragraph: To see some of Connecticut’s most industrious food producers, you will need to move beyond its many orchards and cornfields and head past the shore. Beneath the briny waters along the rocky coast and sandy shoals of Long Island Sound, you will find a thriving oyster industry.

headline: Restaurant Review: Fogama in Rye Helps Customer Work Up to Sushi
abstract: Still not sure you want to eat raw fish? The Fogami restaurant in Rye gently helps sushi neophytes adjust to the taste.
lead_paragraph: Fried calamari is available just about anywhere in Westchester County, from high-end seafood restaurants to Italian neighborhood joints. But the version at Fogama, a nearly two-year-old “neo-Japanese” spot in Rye, still has the power to surprise.

headline: Searching for the Best Bar Burgers in New Jersey
abstract: The burgers had to be simple, juicy and close to beer. Three bars stood out.
lead_paragraph: Finding a simple cheeseburger is difficult these days. Gastropubs, for example, take enormous pride in offering fancy burgers with novel-like back stories.

abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and Sites

headline: Review: ‘Breathe,’ the Story of a Scary Teenage Romance
abstract: This movie by Mélanie Laurent conveys insight into the psychology of late adolescence, when childhood fantasies can combust with adult sexuality.
lead_paragraph: The scary, spellbinding performance of Lou De Laâge in “Breathe,” the story of a high school friendship that goes bad, is so gripping that Ms. De Laâge’s dangerous mixture of sensuality and bravado brings to mind Angelina Jolie in “Girl, Interrupted” and Jeanne Moreau’s Catherine in “Jules and Jim.” She is the kind of seductive daredevil who challenges admirers to follow her into the fire, no matter what the consequences.

headline: Tome: Spring 2016 RTW
abstract: Looks from Ryan Lobo and Ramon Martin’s spring 2016 collection.
lead_paragraph: Looks from Ryan Lobo and Ramon Martin’s spring 2016 collection.

abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Review: The Three Sopranos, at the Resonant Bodies Festival
abstract: Tony Arnold, Lucy Shelton and Dawn Upshaw each devised her own inventive 45-minute set at Merkin Concert Hall.
lead_paragraph: For new-music lovers, Wednesday evening’s performance at Merkin Concert Hall outdid any of those old Pavarotti, Domingo and Carreras three-tenor spectacles. Presented by the indispensable Resonant Bodies Festival, here were the Three Experimental Sopranos, given the freedom to program their own 45-minute sets.

headline: Review: A Kingston Painter, Chronicler of the Hudson River School
abstract: Two exhibitions, in Kingston and New Paltz, explore the legacy of Jervis McEntee, an artist whose work and journals show the evolution of a 19th-century movement.
lead_paragraph: Jervis McEntee’s legacy moment arrives at last, if 125 years after his death. Two exhibitions celebrate this influential and prolific 19th-century painter, best known until now for his personal journals, a treasure trove for scholars studying the early days of what is considered the United States’ first native art movement, the Hudson River School.

headline: Review: ‘The Beauty Inside’ Features 123 Actors for One Leading Man
abstract: This quirky romance from South Korea is about a life that begins each day in a different body.
lead_paragraph: Who plays the leading man in this quirky romance?

headline: Review: In ‘Sleeping With Other People,’ Star-Crossed Sex Addicts Make a Pact
abstract: This romantic comedy stars Jason Sudeikis and Alison Brie as romantic failures who try to preserve their friendship by keeping it platonic.
lead_paragraph: Gee, it’s tough for straight women and men to lock lips and fates together on screen. One obvious problem is that virginity, marriage and children are no longer necessarily compulsory, which has complicated the happily-ever-after thing. The writer and director Leslye Headland gets this, but she apparently enjoys a challenge, so she has worked hard to complicate her romantic comedy “Sleeping With Other People,” about a man and a woman who do everything to stay apart even though they and everyone else know they were, sort of, made for each other.

headline: Remembering ‘Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In’
abstract: The hourlong comedy cocktail of rapid-fire one-liners and knock-knock jokes on NBC that was an instant hit from its prime-time debut in 1968.
lead_paragraph: 47 YEARS AGO

headline: Meet the Orleys of Orley
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2015)']
abstract: After impressing critics and industry people, it’s time to start selling clothes.
lead_paragraph: After impressing critics and industry people, it’s time to start selling clothes.

headline: A Poet Shaped by a Bleak Childhood in Ireland
abstract: Connie Roberts writes of abuse, poverty and the stigma of living in an orphanage.
lead_paragraph: Connie Roberts endured a harsh childhood in Ireland, including an abusive father and a dozen years in a bleak Irish orphanage. Now, in a near-miraculous transformation, she is an adjunct assistant professor at Hofstra University in Hempstead, the mother of an 11-year-old son, and the author of “Little Witness,” a book of poetry published this year by Arlen House, a literary press in Dublin.

headline: In Ridgefield, a Movie Theater With a Lofty Mission
abstract: The Prospector Theater was built with a focus on training and employing people with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: When Debbie Kadagian and her parents, Dale and Joan Learn, headed out for a Friday matinee of “Ricki and the Flash” recently, they did so with a simple goal.

headline: Jobless Claims
abstract: Jobless claims dropped by 6,000 in the week ended Sept. 5.
lead_paragraph: Jobless claims dropped by 6,000 in the week ended Sept. 5.

headline: Orley, a Tastemakers’ Gem, Looks to Turn Praise Into Sales
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'September Fashion Week (2015)']
abstract: It is a crucial moment for the fledgling fashion label. After impressing critics and industry people, it’s time to start selling clothes.
lead_paragraph: The Orleys of Orley, a fledgling fashion label, tend to call one another by their full names. “That is a bad habit that we all have,” Matthew said. Even among themselves, they are Matthew Orley, 29, the oldest sibling; his brother Alex Orley, 27, who spearheads design; and Matthew’s wife, Samantha Orley, 30 (nee Florence).

headline: Review: ‘The People Before the Park,’ a Family Clash Rich in New York History
abstract: A new drama set in a mostly African-American village soon to be razed for Central Park will debut at Kean University.
lead_paragraph: Once the exposition has been delivered and the plot is established and the characters are sketched out, a fairly good play emerges in “The People Before the Park.” Still, it takes some time to get there.

headline: Review: ‘90 Minutes in Heaven,’ Then a Long Road Back
abstract: This movie, based on a best-selling memoir, dwells on the physical and spiritual recovery of Don Piper, a Texas pastor who was declared dead in a car crash.
lead_paragraph: Caveat emptor: “90 Minutes in Heaven” does not in fact depict a full hour and a half of the afterlife, as the travel-guide-like title might suggest. Rather, Michael Polish’s cinematic homily dwells on the physical and spiritual recovery of a Texas pastor, Don Piper (Hayden Christensen), after he is declared dead in a car crash. It’s based on Mr. Piper’s best-selling book.

headline: A Mash Note to New York at Photoville
abstract: New York Times photographers will be highlighted in projections at the Photoville festival. Also featured will be work by Eli Reed, Ernesto Bazan, Tanya Habjouqa, Joni Sternbach and others published on Lens.
lead_paragraph: New York Times photographers will be highlighted in projections at the Photoville festival. Also featured will be work by Eli Reed, Ernesto Bazan, Tanya Habjouqa, Joni Sternbach and others published on Lens.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Visit’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Visit.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Visit.”

headline: Cooking With Friends (Without a Fight)
abstract: Our food editor answers readers’ questions about how to cook with friends (and keep them as friends), the best way to sauté and what “blanch” means.
lead_paragraph: Have questions about recipes, cooking and food? I aim to answer them. Ask me anything: foodeditor@nytimes.com.

headline: Works from “Picasso Sculpture” at MoMA
abstract: Selections from the exhibition, which fills 11 galleries on the fourth floor of the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Selections from the exhibition, which fills 11 galleries on the fourth floor of the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Review: Picasso, Completely Himself in 3 Dimensions
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art’s staggering “Picasso Sculpture” exhibition is a once-in-a-lifetime event.
lead_paragraph: Many exhibitions are good, some are great and a very few are tantamount to works of art in their own right — for their clarity, lyricism and accumulative wisdom.

headline: Theater Listings for Sept. 11-17
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Paris Apartment for the Hermès Men’s Wear Designer
abstract: Véronique Nichanian gives a tour of her favorite room in her airy Paris apartment.
lead_paragraph: Véronique Nichanian

headline: Movie Review: ‘Sleeping With Other People’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Sleeping with Other People.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Sleeping with Other People.”

headline: Fighters in Yemen Agree to Talks With U.N. Mediator
abstract: The warring parties agreed to abide by a resolution calling on Houthi rebels to pull out of major cities, but the U.N. did not mention any halt in fighting.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The warring parties in Yemen have agreed to hold direct talks mediated by the United Nations envoy next week, the United Nations announced Thursday.

headline: British Airways Jet That Aborted Takeoff Had Multiple Engine Breaches
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Accident investigators for the National Transportation Safety Board said they found multiple breaches in the engine of British Airways flight 2276, which had to abort a takeoff in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: Federal accident investigators said on Thursday that they found multiple breaches in the engine of a British Airways aircraft that was forced to abort its takeoff on Tuesday at the Las Vegas McCarran International Airport, suggesting the airplane had suffered an uncontained engine failure.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Time Out of Mind’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Time Out of Mind.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Time Out of Mind.”

headline: Review: ‘Laugh It Up, Stare It Down,’ on Love and Marriage
abstract: If an existentialist philosopher ever attempted a light romantic comedy, it might sound a little like this quaintly absurdist play by Alan Hruska at the Cherry Lane Theater.
lead_paragraph: If an existentialist philosopher ever attempted a light romantic comedy, it might sound a little like “Laugh It Up, Stare It Down,” Alan Hruska’s quaintly absurdist play at the Cherry Lane Theater. An amiable, if surface-skimming approach to love, marriage and all that sort of thing, it follows Joe (Jayce Bartok) and Cleo (Katya Campbell) from first date to probable death after a storm surge threatens to obliterate Rhode Island.

headline: Review: Charles Swedlund’s ‘Buy Photographs’ Highlights His 1970s Work
abstract: This solo show is Mr. Swedlund’s first in New York and includes images of nude women and wooden coins.
lead_paragraph: Charles Swedlund’s exhibition of playful images from the early 1970s offers an amusing trip back to a time when conceptually minded photographers were looking for ways beyond the Modernist, black-and-white print. Now 80 and having his first solo exhibition in a New York gallery, Mr. Swedlund is a Chicago native who taught for many years at Southern Illinois University until his retirement in 2000.

headline: Review: ‘Everything, Everyday’ Explores Affinities at Studio Museum in Harlem
abstract: Works by Eric Mack, Lauren Halsey and Sadie Barnette are featured in this year’s artist-in-residence show at the Studio Museum in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: “Everything, Everyday,” the title of this year’s artist-in-residence show at the Studio Museum in Harlem, catches the assemblage character of much of what three artists made during their stay. Eric Mack has worked out a deft combination of painting and sculpture using swatches of fabric, distressed clothing, rope, clamps, pegboards, packing blankets and paint. The result is a threatening-to-fall-apart choreography of heavy and light. In one piece, “Alldayz,” a big paint-spangled industrial blanket looks pretty enough to curl up in. In another, “Metal (jacket),” a quilted cold-weather coat, has been pierced with holes like wounds.

headline: A Ralph Lauren Workout Shirt, Punky Vans Sneakers And Other Items for the Fall Shopping List
abstract: An eclectic collection of fall must-haves.
lead_paragraph: An eclectic collection of fall must-haves.

headline: Review: Eduardo Paolozzi’s Sculpture and Prints Visit Brooklyn
abstract: A show at the Clearing gallery in Bushwick features three Paolozzi sculptures that did time as playground equipment, as well as screen prints.
lead_paragraph: The gap between art and life might best be summed up as the difference between public sculpture and playground equipment. Despite the seemingly obvious disparities between those objects, the Internet brims with stories of people — primarily children, but adults, too — who have climbed a sculpture and become stuck in it. In the best Pop Art tradition — that is, blurring the boundary between art and life — the three Eduardo Paolozzi sculptures here actually did time as playground equipment.

headline: Joe Biden’s Trip to New York Smacks of Campaign Visit
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Violence Against Women Act (1994)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The vice president, who has not announced a presidential bid, passionately expounded on two of his favored areas: women’s issues and the minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: As he contemplates whether to run for president, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is continuing his day job. And along the way, he is offering a peek into the kinds of issues that might animate a White House campaign, many of which have been at the center of his political identity for decades.

headline: Ellen Pao Ends Legal Battle, Citing Personal Resources
abstract: After losing a high-profile sex discrimination case against her former employer, a venture capital firm, Ms. Pao has decided not to pursue an appeal.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Pao, a tech industry executive who brought an unsuccessful discrimination lawsuit against her former employer, the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, said on Thursday that she would not pursue an appeal.

headline: Review: Jeanine Durning’s ‘To Being,’ a Dance Premiere in Queens
abstract: The dance, which had its premiere at the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City, features “nonstopping,” or movement that never settles.
lead_paragraph: How will they get themselves out of this? I kept wondering that during Jeanine Durning’s “To Being,” which had its premiere on Wednesday at the Chocolate Factory in Queens, and not because I wanted it to end. This marathon of a dance enmeshes the dancers so wholly in doing, doing, doing that you can’t imagine them being done. It’s like watching people live, right in the thick of passing time.

headline: The Architect Poy Gum Lee Finally Has a Retrospective
abstract: The Museum of Chinese in America exhibition will explore Mr. Lee’s designs for hundreds of buildings and interiors in New York and China.
lead_paragraph: A few months after his descendants retrieved his archive from storage, the Chinese-American architect Poy Gum Lee is receiving his first retrospective. They have lent stacks of drawings and documents, which had lain largely unknown since his death in 1968, to the Museum of Chinese in America for “Chinese Style: Rediscovering the Architecture of Poy Gum Lee, 1923-1968,” opening on Sept. 24.

headline: Review: A Garden Idyll for Noguchi’s Stones and Steel
abstract: Eighteen sculptures by the artist attempt a dialogue with the park’s plants, waterways and structures.
lead_paragraph: It’s a great and rare occurrence to see art installed in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Some might argue that this is where you go to look at nature rather than art — although tags and labels on the plants remind you that humans made this garden and bred plenty of the species in it. The Japanese-American artist Isamu Noguchi (1904-1988) is an excellent choice for a show here, since he himself created parks, playgrounds and gardens around the world, drawing heavily from a Japanese art tradition that considered aesthetics in relation to nature.

headline: A Fish Caught by Hemingway Is Being Restored
abstract: A taxidermied blue marlin caught by Ernest Hemingway off the Bahamas in the 1930s is being repaired at the L. C. Bates Museum in Hinckley, Me.
lead_paragraph: A chipped and scuffed blue marlin hangs in a gallery at the L. C. Bates Museum in Hinckley, Me., above preserved sea creatures arranged in wooden display cases. The marlin’s skin, wrapped around a wooden core, came from a 12-foot-long fish that Ernest Hemingway caught off the Bahamas in the 1930s. This fall visitors to the museum will be able to watch Ronald Harvey of Tuckerbrook Conservation in Lincolnville, Me., repair the deteriorated marlin, which he will access by maneuvering along a platform.

headline: Rudolf Hulka Photos Show Europe and North Africa in the 1920s
abstract: A show of his work at Columbia University concentrates on scenes from a mountainous area that is now part of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, librarians in Prague started sorting through about 4,400 images that the Czech photographer Rudolf Hulka took in Europe and North Africa, mostly in the 1920s. Two-dozen prints from his negatives, found in storage at the National Library of the Czech Republic, go on view Wednesday in the Harriman Institute Atrium at Columbia University.

headline: Tom Wesselmann Nudes, and the Collection of the ‘Baron of Botox’
abstract: Mitchell-Innes & Nash will present the first survey of Wesselmann paintings in New York since his death in 2004; contemporary works collected by the celebrity dermatologist Fredric Brandt go up for auction.
lead_paragraph: WESSELMANN’S NUDES UNCOVERED AT SHOW

headline: Series of Highway Shootings Unnerves Phoenix
abstract: A series of shootings over nearly two weeks along highways in the Phoenix area has alarmed residents and confounded the police.
lead_paragraph: A series of shootings over nearly two weeks along highways in the Phoenix area, most involving the same stretch of Interstate 10, has alarmed residents and confounded the police.

headline: Prosecutor in Dewey Case Appeals to Common Sense
abstract: The assistant district attorney focused on potentially incriminating emails from the three defendants, which he said were buttressed by guilty pleas from former Dewey employees.
lead_paragraph: For more than two days, lawyers for three former Dewey & LeBoeuf executives on trial for cooking the law firm’s books picked holes in the prosecution’s case by pointing out the unreliability of email evidence and the paucity of accounting experts called to testify during the lengthy trial.

headline: The Dubious Case of Dewey & LeBoeuf
abstract: Whether three top executives of the fallen law firm defrauded the firm’s lenders and bondholders in a sophisticated accounting conspiracy is now up to a jury.
lead_paragraph: The names Enron and WorldCom are synonymous with accounting fraud and an era in which top executives turned to desperate measures to inflate company earnings, mislead investors, prop up share prices and supercharge their already exorbitant compensation.

headline: Cuomo Pivots Again as He Seeks a $15 Minimum Wage
abstract: The governor said that New York should lead the country in setting a minimum wage that would provide workers with a decent standard of living.
lead_paragraph: With Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at his side, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York presented himself as a champion of the working class on Thursday, pledging to campaign for a statewide minimum wage of $15 an hour.

headline: ‘Mamma Mia!’ Is Closing, and Super Troupers Give Thanks for the Music
abstract: Sorry, Chiquitita, but after 14 years, the Abba musical is closing on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Sorry, Chiquitita, but after 14 years, the Abba musical is closing on Broadway.

headline: For California, El Niño’s Dark Clouds Could Mean Rain but Also Trouble
keywords: ['Weather', 'Drought', 'Floods', 'Water', 'Conservation of Resources', 'El Nino Southern Oscillation', 'Landslides and Mudslides']
abstract: Torrents of rain forecast for the end of the year could ease the drought but could also cause flooding and mudslides and reverse gains made in water conservation.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A soaking El Niño weather system is in the forecast, promising to pummel California with torrents of rain by the end of the year. That would seem like Champagne-popping news as this state suffers through its worst drought in a millennium.

headline: Partisan Tussle Keeps Top U.S. Aid Job Vacant
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Foreign Aid', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As governments and aid agencies worldwide confront a migrant crisis, the nominee to lead the United States agency responsible for overseas humanitarian issues is stalled in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the international community confronts a refugee crisis, the nominee to head the American agency responsible for overseas humanitarian issues is stalled in the Senate, leaving the Obama administration with a critical vacancy as it grapples with how to assist those displaced by conflict in the Middle East and Africa.

headline: House Hearing on Insurers’ Mergers Exposes Health Care Industry Divide
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A House subcommittee is investigating competition in the industry and how it would be affected by mergers combining Aetna with Humana and Anthem with Cigna.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Doctors, hospitals and health insurance companies clashed Thursday over the merits of mergers planned by four of the five biggest insurers in the United States.

headline: Inquiry’s Trail: From George Washington Bridge to United’s Executive Offices
abstract: The shutdown two years ago of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge set off a chain of events that ultimately led to the surprise resignation of Jeff Smisek, the C.E.O. of United Airlines.
lead_paragraph: It was a traffic jam that, in the end, rerouted the career of the chief executive of the world’s fourth-largest airline, and how one led to the other is a tale of power, politics and New Jersey wheeling-dealing.

headline: Evans Bank Settles New York ‘Redlining’ Lawsuit
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Mortgages', 'Discrimination', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Evans Bancorp reached an $825,000 settlement with Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York after it was accused by the state of discriminatory lending practices.
lead_paragraph: Redlining, the practice of denying mortgages to predominantly African-American neighborhoods, was supposed to be a relic of a long-gone era. But a settlement on Thursday between the New York attorney general and a small bank near Buffalo suggests that the practice persists.

headline: Review: Summation Dance’s ‘At the Hour’ Elevates the View From Below
abstract: The dancers in “At the Hour,” in the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Fishman Space, use the cage-like deck beneath the lighting grid, crawling like monkeys in a rain forest canopy.
lead_paragraph: At the start of “At the Hour,” the hour appears to be early. Light is slowly dawning. Birds are beginning to chirp. A woman in a loose shift might be doing her morning exercises, bending and twisting with her feet in ballet positions, and if you watch her closely enough, you may soon be surprised to realize that she is not alone. Others have appeared — some on the balconies that run along two sides of the stage area, some directly above your own head.

headline: Duke Energy to Pay Fine Over Power Plant Violations
abstract: The settlement requires the company, the nation’s largest electric utility, to pay a $975,000 fine and spend $4.4 million on environmental programs.
lead_paragraph: Duke Energy, the nation’s largest electric utility, agreed on Thursday to pay nearly $5.4 million to settle a 15-year legal battle with federal regulators over whether its power plants skirted Clean Air Act regulations in the 1990s.

headline: Four Years After a Fire, a Congregation Returns to Its Synagogue
abstract: With dancing and singing, Kehilath Jeshurun, one of New York City’s most affluent and influential congregations, reopened in time for the start of Rosh Hashana.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Rabbi Haskel Lookstein gazed with fear and sorrow at the smoke billowing from the roof of the synagogue in Manhattan he had presided over for more than three decades. But instead of lamenting what had been lost in the fire, he recalled, he found himself wondering what the building that would replace the structure would look like.

headline: CNN Sets Lineup for Republican Presidential Debate
abstract: Donald J. Trump will again be squarely in the middle of the stage, the spot reserved for the top performer in the polls, flanked by Ben Carson and Jeb Bush. Carly Fiorina will be among the 11 debaters.
lead_paragraph: CNN released on Thursday night the lineup for its Republican presidential debate next week, showing Donald J. Trump once again squarely in the middle of the stage, the spot reserved for the top performer in the polls, with the retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson to his right and Jeb Bush to his left.

headline: In Second Republican Debate, Donald Trump’s Rivals Seek Points, Not Knockout
abstract: As the presidential campaign enters a more combative phase, many in the G.O.P. field are refining their battle plans for next week’s debate on CNN.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidates, increasingly certain that their televised debates can have make-or-break consequences for their campaigns, are preparing aggressive new tactics for their next face-off on Wednesday, hoping to draw voters away from the surprisingly durable Donald J. Trump as the 2016 race enters a more combative phase.

headline: Stan Wawrinka Rises, Challenging Roger Federer’s Swiss Supremacy
abstract: Over the last two seasons, Wawrinka has won two major singles titles — the 2014 Australian Open and this year’s French Open — while Federer has won none.
lead_paragraph: Famously smooth with a tennis ball in play, Roger Federer likes the rest of his professional life to move along smoothly as well: minimal controversy, minimal complications.

headline: New York City Prosecutor Using Millions Taken From Banks for Rape-Kit Testing
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., is sending money to cities around the country to pay for the testing of 56,000 backlogged rape kits.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan district attorney is sending $38 million taken in civil forfeiture from international banks in New York to cities and counties across the country to pay for testing 56,000 rape kits that have been collecting dust in police storage rooms for years.

headline: Joe Biden, in Colbert Interview, Expresses Doubts About Bid for President
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., on the “Late Show” Thursday, said, “I’d be lying if I said that I knew I was there.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., in an emotional, wide-ranging interview on Stephen Colbert’s “Late Show” on Thursday, expressed doubt about the likelihood that he would run for president, saying that “I’d be lying if I said that I knew I was there.”

headline: Netanyahu Makes Quick Pivot From Loss on Iran Deal
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu talked of other priorities, like restarting talks with the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In the week since it became clear that Congress would not block the Iranian nuclear deal he loathes, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has largely toned down his rhetoric on the issue and pivoted to others.

headline: Merv Adelson, Las Vegas Developer-Turned-Daring TV Producer, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Adelson, a personable world-class schmoozer, built malls and supermarkets before co-founding Lorimar, producer of ‘The Waltons,’ ‘Eight Is Enough,’ ‘Knots Landing’ and a string of other popular TV series.
lead_paragraph: Merv Adelson, a real estate and resort developer who pivoted to become one of television’s most successful producers in a roller-coaster life involving the mob, the Teamsters’ pension fund, a marriage to Barbara Walters and a huge fortune made and lost, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 85.

headline: Influential Pro-Israel Group Suffers Stinging Political Defeat
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: The American Israel Public Affairs Committee’s failure to block the Iran deal, after spending nearly $30 million to defeat it, raises questions about whether its power has now been diminished.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Officials at the American Israel Public Affairs Committee knew the odds were against them in the fight to block President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran from surviving a congressional vote. But the influential pro-Israel group threw itself into a nearly $30 million advertising and lobbying effort to kill the accord anyway.

headline: Dan Tepfer Plays Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola With Seasoned Elders in Tow
abstract: Mr. Tepfer’s set included gems he played with the drummer Billy Hart and the bassist Gary Peacock.
lead_paragraph: After putting the finishing touch on a delicate, rapturous ballad at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Wednesday night, the pianist Dan Tepfer reflected on his present circumstance. He was leading a trio with musicians more than 40 years his senior: the drummer Billy Hart, 74, and the bassist Gary Peacock, 80. Working in such company, “I’m constantly reminded of the amazing people they’ve played with over the years,” Mr. Tepfer said.

headline: Blue Jays’ Swift Rise in the A.L. East Was Built on Patience and Prospects
abstract: Alex Anthopoulos, Toronto’s general manager, has rejected the notion that anything is impossible for his Canadian team to try to accomplish.
lead_paragraph: Alex Anthopoulos had been general manager of the Toronto Blue Jays for two seasons when he welcomed a reporter to his office in Dunedin, Fla., in the spring of 2012. The topic was Brandon Morrow, an inconsistent pitcher with alluring potential who had just signed a modest three-year contract. The premise of the story was that the Blue Jays were wise to gamble on such players as a way to compete in the rugged American League East.

headline: A Stolen Car Found, With the Help of Cold War Technology
abstract: A police officer helped to quickly track down a vehicle taken in New York using tracking software that is the descendant of centuries of inventions.
lead_paragraph: A police car headed the wrong way down Smith Street in Brooklyn, three young officers inside, one of them thumbing through a smartphone and calling out directions.

headline: New York Police Focus on Fraud Involving Credit Cards
keywords: ['Identity Theft', 'Credit Cards', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Tennis', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: The highly publicized instance of mistaken identity involving retired tennis player James Blake has also highlighted the Police Department’s crackdown on credit card fraud.
lead_paragraph: The undercover investigators arranged to meet at a hotel near Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan around the lunchtime rush on Wednesday. They were looking for men they believed had used stolen credit card information to go on a shopping spree, spending about $18,000 on 16 transactions — mostly on luxury designer shoes.

headline: Review: Richard Maxwell’s ‘Isolde’ Returns With Starry Eyes
abstract: This romantic love triangle, which played at the Abrons Arts Center, is now playing in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: “Isolde,” which played at the Abrons Arts Center in April 2014, reopened last night at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center, Fort Greene, Brooklyn; 866-811-4111, tfana.org. Here are excerpts from Ben Brantley’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 14; the full text is here.

headline: Review: ‘Empire Travel Agency’ Guides Adventurers on a New York Odyssey
abstract: Woodshed Collective’s theatrical scavenger hunt sends participants racing from one location to the next in Lower Manhattan, often at a jog, sometimes in a moving vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Is the 4 train a place of mystery and danger? It feels that way when you are slinking around a subway car, whispering code words in an anxious attempt to locate a shadowy Manitoban. When you have fled kidnappers, buskers and more than one sinister cabal, there is much more to stand clear of than just the closing doors.

headline: Review: ‘Desire,’ Six Plays That Second-Guess Tennessee Williams
abstract: This production includes short plays by Beth Henley, Elizabeth Egloff, John Gaure, Marcus Gardley, David Grimm and Rebecca Gilman.
lead_paragraph: “Desire” makes for a generic if apt title for a collection of short plays adapted from stories by Tennessee Williams, the playwright who has anatomized that emotion — its pleasures, tortures, dangers — more thoroughly and with more lyric eloquence than any other. This production from the Acting Company, which opened on Thursday at the 59E59 Theaters, directed by Michael Wilson, features works from six notable playwrights, based on tales mostly written by Williams in the 1940s.

headline: Tremble With Indignation
abstract: Friday fun with Peter A. Collins.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Crossword puzzle constructors are a competitive lot. You’ve got your faction who are constantly trying to construct a puzzle with the fewest number of words in it. You’ve got your faction of constructors who try to “outstack” each other in terms of having long entries piled on top of each other. And then there is the faction of constructors who try to get lively and unusual entries into their puzzles before anyone else does.

headline: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Scott Walker Over Unions at Event in Wisconsin
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton has picked up a string of early support from labor unions in recent weeks and on Thursday took her pro-union message to Gov. Scott Walker’s backyard.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton has picked up a string of early support from labor unions in recent weeks and on Thursday took her pro-union message to Gov. Scott Walker’s backyard.

headline: 3 Men Laundered Over $5 Billion for Drug Cartels, U.S. Says
abstract: Using the Chinese counterfeit market, a group of Colombians “provided the lifeline for drug cartels to operate and push illegal drugs into the United States,” the Drug Enforcement Administration said.
lead_paragraph: A group of Colombians used the Chinese counterfeit market to launder more than $5 billion for drug traffickers in the United States, Europe and Asia, federal prosecutors said Thursday.

headline: What’s On TV Friday

(Starz) INTO THE WOODS (2014) After being cursed by a witch (Meryl Streep, above, in an Oscar-nominated performance), a baker (James Corden) and his wife (Emily Blunt) find their fates bound to Cinderella (Anna Kendrick), Little Red Riding Hood (Lilla Crawford), Rapunzel (MacKenzie Mauzy) and other fairy tale characters in this Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine musical, directed for the screen by Rob Marshall. This “splendid” Disney adaptation “infuses new vitality into the tired marketing concept of entertainment for ‘children of all ages,’ ” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “That usually translates to mean only children and their doting parents. But with ‘Into the Woods,’ you grow up with the characters, young and old, in a lifelong process of self-discovery.”

headline: The Russia I Miss
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Books and Literature', 'Cold War Era']
abstract: Gone is the depth of soul that influenced Western culture for 150 years.
lead_paragraph: St. Petersburg, Russia — People who came of age after the end of the Cold War may not realize how powerfully Russia influenced Western culture for 150 years. For more than a century, intellectuals, writers, artists and activists were partly defined by the stances they took toward certain things Russian: Did they see the world like Tolstoy or like Dostoyevsky? Were they inspired by Lenin and/or Trotsky? Were they alarmed by Sputnik, awed by Solzhenitsyn or cheering on Yeltsin or Gorbachev?

abstract: The Resolution Project is a new sort of angel investor, one that helps young people realize start-ups for social change.
lead_paragraph: Rose Wang wants you to eat bugs. Two billion people in the world already do. Her new company, Six Foods — so named because six legs is better than four — sells Chirps: snack chips made from cricket flour. Insects are an environmentally sustainable source of complete protein: Producing a pound of beef uses 2,000 times the water and creates 100 times the greenhouse gas emissions of producing a pound of cricket meat, and crickets are higher in protein and lower in fat.

headline: Teaching Slavery to Reluctant Listeners
abstract: Ushering college students into the darkest corners of America’s past reveals a great deal about the present.
lead_paragraph: One thing is certain as I prepare to teach another course on U.S. history. Invariably, at least one student evaluation will complain that ‘‘Professor Baptist only talks about slavery.’’ It’s an annual reminder that while I’ve been trying to teach the history of slavery for two decades in American classrooms, America has tried to evade thinking about that history for far longer. Twenty-­four decades have passed since the Continental Congress deleted Thomas Jefferson’s criticisms of slavery from his first draft of the Declaration of Independence, and college students today arrive knowing little about the way America’s history of slavery has shaped their lives. Avoidance of the topic is deeply ingrained.

headline: The First Day of College
abstract: Parents and students say goodbye — for the next few months, at least.
lead_paragraph: It is a late-summer rite: A convoy of shambling family vehicles descends on clean-scrubbed, iron-gated villages whose sole recent inhabitants, it would seem, have been lawn mowers and paintbrushes. The cars have license plates from distant places, clattering bike racks and the occasional cumbersome item (lacrosse stick? longboard?) secured to the roof with straps. Their interior contents are more disorderly still: typically a pair of adults well past the age of footloose road trips and a veteran teenager on the slippery cusp of a new world. The previous few years of test-taking, application-filing and hand-wringing have been aimed at learning the name and address of the site where this rift would occur. In short order the travelers will part ways; it’s a long-awaited, inescapable and horrible fact — and if all goes well, it will be more or less permanent. But fortunately, with so many families going through this drama at once, the ensuing chaos has a way of tempering emotions — at least initially.

headline: Teaching a Different Shakespeare From the One I Love
keywords: ['English Language', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Education', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: After discovering that students don’t share his passion for the playwright’s command of language, a professor concludes that all’s well that ends well.
lead_paragraph: My first encounter with Shakespeare — ‘‘As You Like It,’’ in Miss Gillespie’s eighth-grade English class — left me cold. I still remember the words ‘‘I pray thee, Rosalind, sweet my coz, be merry,’’ which I must have been compelled to recite out loud, with a shudder. But not long afterward, I fell in love with him, not through the charm of performance but through the hallucinatory power of his language.

headline: Uber Would Like to Buy Your Robotics Department

abstract: When the company wanted a team of roboticists, it raided a university lab to get them. Can high-tech academia survive today’s Silicon Valley talent binge?
lead_paragraph: In the center of the lab, CHIMP stretched out one huge arm, then gracefully unfurled its three metal fingers, as if about to beckon someone. On its head, two rapidly rotating laser scanners enabled it to monitor its surroundings, but the engineers standing nearby were wary nonetheless. If the robot — a five-foot-tall, crimson-colored humanoid machine designed to emulate the complex movements of the human body — moved suddenly and hit one of them accidentally in the chest, it could easily break some ribs. The contraption weighs 407 pounds and is powerful enough to bench-press 150 pounds.

headline: Charlatans, Cranks, and Apparatchiks
abstract: Bad ideas with different roots.
lead_paragraph: The Jeb! tax plan confirms, if anyone had doubts, that the takeover of the Republican Party by charlatans and cranks is complete. This is what the supposedly thoughtful, wonkish candidate of the establishment can come up with? And notice that the ludicrous claim that most of the revenue effects of huge tax cuts would be offset by higher growth comes from economists who, like Jeb!, are very much establishment figures – but who evidently find that the partisan requirement that they support voodoo outweighs any fear of damage to their professional reputations.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Erica Jong
abstract: The writer and feminist icon shares the 10 titles she'd want with her on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from Erica Jong, the writer and feminist icon whose 11th novel, Fear of Dying, is out this week.

headline: Indian Court Convicts 12 in 2006 Bombings of Mumbai Trains
abstract: The prosecution argued that the suspects in the attacks that killed more than 180 people were members of a radical Islamic group.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — After a trial lasting more than seven years, aspecial antiterror court in Mumbai convicted 12 men on Friday in connection with near-simultaneous bombings in 2006 on seven commuter trains in the city, an attack that killed more than 180 people and left 800 wounded, a prosecutor said.

headline: Architect’s Dream Home Roils Rowayton, Conn.
abstract: A local architect’s two-year struggle over plans to design and build a house along Farm Creek.
lead_paragraph: Last month marked two years since Bruce Beinfield, a 63-year-old architect, bought the property on which he hoped to build a house he had designed for himself. The 0.64-acre tract, in Rowayton, Conn., a coastal section of Norwalk, consisted of a long strip of land, just 50 feet across at its widest point, that extended away from the shore into the middle of a serene tidal estuary called Farm Creek. A modest single-story cottage sat at the tip, a rustic throwback to 1949.

headline: Hobo Chic From the Bindle Bros. of Brooklyn
abstract: Guised as Josiah and Dusty Bindle, two entrepreneurs offer “artisanal bindles” to the Williamsburg crowd.
lead_paragraph: The Bindle Brothers, Josiah and Dusty, have a name that sounds like one of those banjo-plucking decidedly old-timey musical groups. With their suspenders, floppy caps and cotton work clothes, you may imagine them playing a foot-stomping rendition of “Big Rock Candy Mountain.”

lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. season is only one game old, and already a league eager to move past controversies has its first one. Once again it involves the New England Patriots and strange doings at their stadium.

headline: Poland Versus Greece
abstract: Low productivity does not explain the crisis.
lead_paragraph: Yannis Ioannides and Christopher Pissarides, in a new Brookings Paper, talk about the ways lack of structural reform hurts Greek productivity and competitiveness. I have no reason to doubt that there are big things that should change, and that Greece would be much better off if it could somehow break the political barriers to making these changes.

headline: 1940: Royalty Visits Ruined Homes
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Sovereigns take refuge in London as Nazi bombers attack in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — King George VI and Queen Elizabeth took refuge in an air-raid shelter below a police station in a devastated district of South London today [Sept. 11] when Nazi bombers broke through the city’s defenses on another expedition of destruction. The King and Queen had been visiting some of the areas where homes of working people had been blasted by heavy-caliber bombs. The sovereigns went where danger was gravest and suffering most intense. They talked with Air-Raid Precaution workers, demolition squads working on the debris of the latest raid and homeless people trying to salvage their belongings. Wherever they went, they were cheered by their people as their car, preceded only by a police guide car, made its way through shattered streets. The way the people felt about it was summed up by one woman who said to the King and Queen, ‘‘Hitler has to have a bodyguard wherever he goes, but you come down here just like this. God bless you and keep you safe.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, September 12, 1940

lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake, who has come under withering criticism since riots tore through this city in April, announced Friday that she would not seek re-election next year, saying she wanted to focus “on the city’s future, and not my own” as Baltimore prepared for the racially charged trials of six police officers in the death of a 25-year-old black man, Freddie Gray.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Jonathan Franzen’s “Purity,” No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list, includes a riff about the “plague of literary Jonathans.”
lead_paragraph: The Plague: Is there any way, at this point, to separate Jonathan Franzen’s work from his polarizing public image? Most readers will recall that Franzen’s fame problem began in 2001, when he openly squirmed after Oprah Winfrey picked his novel “The Corrections” for her book club, then escalated through no real fault of his own when media outlets (including The Times) hailed his 2010 follow-up, “Freedom,” as a masterpiece. Both were best sellers, but they also fostered an enthusiastic backlash among people who objected less to Franzen’s writing than to Franzen himself, as an emblem of literary ambition and elitism. (Laura Miller put her finger on this in a recent essay for The New Yorker’s website: “Franzen’s persona,” she wrote, “has its own audience, one that seems to derive great pleasure from hating it. Although his fiction is the occasion of his fame, it is now no longer necessary to have read any of it to have an opinion about Franzen.”)

headline: From 'No, Thanks!' to Separate Bedrooms, Comments on Remarrying the Ex
abstract: Readers shared personal stories of rekindling romance with their exes and expressed concern as to whether people really change.

headline: Alaska: Aided by Governor, Medicaid Coverage Grows
abstract: Alaska expanded federal Medicaid coverage after the state’s highest court on Monday refused an appeal by the State Legislature to halt Gov. Bill Walker’s expansion order.
lead_paragraph: Alaska expanded federal Medicaid coverage after the state’s highest court on Monday refused an appeal by the State Legislature to halt Gov. Bill Walker’s expansion order. Mr. Walker, an independent, said that the expansion could save the state about $100 million and bring 20,000 or more residents into health care coverage, and that he did not need legislative approval. The Republican-controlled Legislature, in filing a lawsuit and seeking a temporary restraining order, said Mr. Walker had violated the State Constitution’s separation of powers provisions. The expansion will, among other changes, increase federal reimbursement to 100 percent from 50 percent for medically necessary travel for Medicaid-eligible Alaska Natives and American Indians receiving care in Indian Health Service facilities, which is a major medical expense and care concern in rural Alaska. The Alaska Supreme Court upheld a lower court decision, issued last week, not to halt the plan while the Legislature’s lawsuit proceeds.

headline: When Family Members Run Foundations, Scrutiny Never Ends
abstract: The I.R.S. and state attorneys general pay extremely close attention to the compensation of family members who run private charities.
lead_paragraph: JAY RUDERMAN went to work in his family’s foundation after careers as a lawyer, political lobbyist and captain in the Israel Defense Force. He hadn’t imagined that he would become a professional philanthropist, charged with giving away $8 million to $10 million a year. But he found that he liked the role immensely.

headline: Megan Barry Becomes First Female Mayor of Nashville in Runoff

lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Megan Barry, a liberal member of the consolidated city-county council here, was elected mayor Thursday, besting a more conservative opponent in a contest in which bouts of mudslinging threatened to overshadow pressing issues of growth and development in the booming city.

headline: London Theater Journal: Nowhere Man
abstract: Ben Brantley on two plays by Simon Stephens: “Song from Far Away” and “One Minute.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There’s not a lonelier sight in town at the moment than that of the naked man in a naked room on a stage at the Young Vic Theater. The name of this chillingly solitary soul is Willem. And he has just returned to New York from spending time with his family in Amsterdam, an experience that leaves him more than ever with the sense that he belongs nowhere and to no one.
