headline: Matthew Levey’s Charter School Quest
abstract: Inside the three-year effort to open an economically diverse, academically rigorous charter in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, on a warm, luminous morning, Matthew Levey, a 48-year-old former McKinsey consultant, stood on Willoughby Street in Downtown Brooklyn and shook hands with his new charges: 65 kindergartners, a sea of neon sneakers, starched dresses and cotton golf shirts. It was the first day — ever — for the International Charter School of New York. And Mr. Levey, who had spent the last 36 months planning, developing and hiring for his new elementary school, was in high spirits. The kindergartners would be joined a few days later by 70 first graders. Ultimately, plans call for the school to run through fifth grade, educating students in topics that Mr. Levey cares about: how Francis Bacon developed the scientific method, why Aristotle matters and what led to the decline of the Roman Empire.

lead_paragraph: SOME LUCK, by Jane Smiley. (Anchor, $15.95.) Smiley returns to the familiar terrain of Iowa in this novel, the first in a trilogy. Its multi­generational story of a Midwestern farming family unfolds against the backdrop of American cultural and economic upheaval, spanning the time from before the Depression through the years after World War II.

headline: 1965: Astronauts to Tour Africa
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Nations of the developing world were to meet American astronauts in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gemini-5 astronauts L. Gordon Cooper and Charles Conrad will leave Wednesday [Sept. 15] on a six-nation, 12-day tour through the Near East and Africa, the White House announced yesterday. The trip will mark the first time that any nation of the developing world will have the chance to see in person Americans who have traveled in space. Before the astronauts leave the United States, they will come to Washington on Tuesday for a day of honors which will be highlighted by a meeting with President Johnson. Their tour will take them to Greece, Turkey, Ethiopia, the Malagasy Republic, Kenya and Nigeria. Accompanying them will be their wives; Lt. Col. Cooper’s teen-age daughters; Dr. Charles Berry, who is chief of medical programs at the Manned Space Flight Center in Houston, and Maj. Hugh Robinson, a Negro who serves as one of the White House military aides. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 12, 1965

The 20-foot-wide-by-100-foot-deep property is on a leafy block between Avenue of the Americas and Varick Street in the Charlton-King-Vandam Historic District.

headline: Review: PBS’s ‘Walt Disney’ Explores a Complex Legacy
abstract: This two-part “American Experience” documentary looks at Disney’s boundary-pushing life.
lead_paragraph: Before his name became synonymous with a staid, whitewashed version of Americana, Walt Disney was considered a boundary pusher, expanding the possibilities and ambitions of his art form. Making your way through the two-part treatment of him on PBS’s “American Experience” on Monday and Tuesday nights, you may find yourself wishing that some boundary pushing had gone into the program.

headline: Does Donald Trump Really Need Ideas?
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Jeb Bush says Mr. Trump can’t “insult his way to the presidency.” Is he right?
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush told CNN’s Jake Tapper on Thursday that Donald Trump can’t “insult his way to the presidency” or even the Republican Party’s 2016 nomination. I certainly hope he is right.

headline: ‘Black Man in a White Coat,’ by Damon Tweedy
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Medicine and Health', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Doctors']
abstract: A look at the challenges and realities facing black doctors and patients.
lead_paragraph: On average, black women can expect to live three years less than white women; the difference between black and white men is nearly five years. These and other racial disparities led Damon Tweedy to announce in his memoir, “Black Man in a White Coat,” what many of us already knew: “Being black can be bad for your health.” This is an inescapable fact, especially when you consider the following people and circumstances surrounding their deaths: Kathryn Johnston, Tarika Wilson, Trayvon Martin, Eric Garner, ­Michael Brown, Tamir Rice, Walter Scott and Freddie Gray. It seems strange that none of them are mentioned in this book.

lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2016 show.

headline: ‘The Marvels,’ by Brian Selznick
abstract: A hybrid novel fuses two tales, one told entirely in illustrations, of family legacies and lore.
lead_paragraph: What’s fiction made of? Do true stories “matter” more than invented ones? These are heady questions for any book to ­tackle, especially one aimed at young readers. But Brian Selznick’s “The ­Marvels” takes them on and, like the best children’s literature, doesn’t shy away from complex answers. The book revels in complication, echoes and mirrorings, and peeling back its layers makes for a rich and surprising reading experience.

headline: Greenwich Village Townhouse Sold for $22.3 Million
abstract: A four-story Greenwich Village townhouse was the sale of the week, and the likely buyer was a Facebook founder.
lead_paragraph: A vintage four-story Greenwich Village townhouse with a separate studio in the rear has quietly sold for $22,300,000 — the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records — amid speculation that the new owner might be from the upper echelons of Facebook’s past or current corporate offices, even the chief executive and co-founder, Mark Zuckerberg.

headline: ‘Beyond the Pond,’ ‘The Tea Party in the Woods’ and ‘The Little Gardener’
abstract: Three picture books evoke the joy of adventure and discovery, without the interference of fearful adults.
lead_paragraph: On my walk to the studio each morning, I pass a busy playground. Recently I overheard one mother telling another: “Thank God! I found him! He was hiding.” She held the sheepish child firmly by the wrist. I have felt the intense panic of temporarily losing a child, but nonetheless I shot the kid a sympathetic glance. It’s hard to be an explorer these days. Summer camps and preschools tout “exploration” as part of their agenda, as long as you wear a brightly colored uniform T-shirt, never stray out of sight and explore only things that have already been thoroughly explored.

headline: ‘George,’ by Alex Gino
abstract: The protagonist of this middle-grade novel knows she’s a girl, though her birth certificate says otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Prepare yourself, Alex Gino: You’ll be receiving lots of feedback when readers discover your timely, touching novel.

headline: ‘The Boys Who Challenged Hitler’ and ‘Somewhere There Is Still a Sun’
abstract: Two books tell the stories of young people who resisted the Nazis, as partisans and in a concentration camp.
lead_paragraph: Heroism is not in fashion right now. We prefer our heroes smudged and compromised; it’s more comforting, less demanding. Yet two new nonfiction portraits of young people during World War II remind us that bravery, defiance and generosity of spirit are possible even in the direst circumstances.

headline: Justice Dept. Shift on White-Collar Crime Is Long Overdue
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: It may no longer be possible for Wall Street companies to cut deals that allow individual wrongdoing to be swept under the rug.
lead_paragraph: It took only 16 years, but the Justice Department’s horribly misguided “Holder Doctrine” has finally been relegated to the dustbin of history where it belongs.

headline: At Toronto Restaurant, Unfussy, but Fish Aplenty
abstract: At Honest Weight, comfort starts with the restaurant’s interior, which has the assured charm of an old-time fish shop.
lead_paragraph: This restaurant does one thing exceedingly well: seafood, both finned and shellfish. That may sound like damning with faint praise, but it’s what John Bil envisioned when he opened his fish counter and sit-down restaurant in the scruffy Toronto neighborhood called the Junction in January.

headline: A Borscht for Vegetarians That’s Light and Comforting
abstract: Combine beets and mushrooms for a broth with a heady flavor.
lead_paragraph: Nose around for borscht recipes, and you’ll find that most classic hot borschts call for beef stock or a beef or veal shank to simmer along with the vegetables.

headline: ‘Appleblossom the Possum’ and ‘Firefly Hollow’
abstract: Small animals with great ambitions (and a curiosity about humans) are featured in these middle-grade books.
lead_paragraph: Appleblossom is the smallest of Mama Possum’s babies. She may be little, but by the time she’s just a few months old she must be prepared to face, on her own, the great big world and the many dangers it holds for possums. Appleblossom is timid, but she’s also curious — and skeptical of Mama’s warnings, which is how she becomes interested in a small monster (a human girl) and falls down a chimney into the monster’s house. This is just the beginning of the wild and wholly engaging adventure on which Appleblossom unwittingly sends two of her brothers. It takes them from the safety of their neighborhood all the way to big-city night life. More important, it shines a spotlight on Mama’s teachings about the solitariness of possums.

headline: Friday Night Music: Bob Fosse on Fiscal Policy
abstract: Hey, big spender.
lead_paragraph: I know, not night yet in New York, but I’m still traveling — and still making the case for more spending, which Bob Fosse got:

headline: In California, Olive Oil Tourism Is on the Rise
abstract: Many makers of artisan olive oil in California are opening their estates to the public, providing tours and oil samplings.
lead_paragraph: Olive oil tourism in California is growing. The state produces 99 percent of the extra-virgin olive oil in the United States and 4 percent globally, according to the California Olive Oil Council, a trade association. Many artisan labels are within a few hours’ drive of San Francisco and have recently opened their estates to the public.

headline: Erica Jong’s ‘Fear of Dying’
abstract: Erica Jong inspired by aging, and by Isadora Wing.
lead_paragraph: In Erica Jong’s “Fear of Flying,” published 42 years ago, Isadora Wing invented the notion of “zipless” sex, that is to say, no-strings sex with a near stranger. Thus Jong presented millions of women readers with the possibility of — the great joys of — agency in place of soporific and joyless passivity in life and, of course, sex. Isadora nudges her way onto the sidelines of Jong’s latest novel, not coincidentally titled “Fear of Dying.” On display is the author’s characteristic mix of salty language and broad humor, warmth and truth-telling.

headline: Joe Meno’s ‘Marvel and a Wonder’
abstract: Two men set out to reclaim a stolen inheritance.
lead_paragraph: “Do you ever have a thought you keep to yourself?” Jim asks his grandson, Quentin, as the boy explains that he “can talk to animals and some trees,” and is able to hear things “most other mortals cannot.”

headline: ‘Can I Go Now?’ by Brian Kellow
abstract: A biography of Sue Mengers, a larger-than-life Hollywood agent from the 1960s through the ’80s.
lead_paragraph: Even the brightest star is occasionally eclipsed by a moon. Sue Mengers was a moon. Photographs from the 1970s show her looming, lipsticked and luminously coifed, at the elbows of the A-list ­movie actors she represented (considering television and theater somewhat lesser forms, for losers): Faye Dunaway or Ryan ­O’Neal or her especial favorite, Barbra Streisand. For a time beaming brighter even than Swifty Lazar, with his bald head, black-rimmed glasses and parties at Spago, Mengers inspired characters in “The Last of Sheila,” the shadowy cult movie with a screenplay by Anthony Perkins and Stephen Sondheim; and very likely also in the novels “Myra Breckinridge,” by her pal Gore Vidal, and “The Love Machine,” by Jacqueline Susann.

headline: ‘The Long Emancipation,’ by Ira Berlin
abstract: A fight against slavery led by free African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: Ira Berlin ranks as one of the greatest living historians of slavery in the United States, in no small part because of his commitment to readers beyond academia. For almost four decades, he has been the moving force behind the Freedmen and Southern Society Project, based at the University of Maryland. He and his colleagues at the project have combed through millions of documents generated by emancipation and Reconstruction. They have found amazing characters, like the newly commissioned, recently liberated black soldiers who sent letters to their former masters, demanding that these white Southerners hand over still-­enslaved family members.

headline: Debut Novels
abstract: New books by Sarah Leipciger, Sara Taylor, Sophie McManus, Julie Iromuanya and Rebecca Dinerstein.
lead_paragraph: THE MOUNTAIN CAN WAITBy Sarah Leipciger311 pp. Little, Brown, $26.

headline: No Slouch
abstract: A look back at reviews of Joan Didion’s work.
lead_paragraph: At 80, Joan Didion has never been cooler, which in her case is really saying something. Earlier this year, she was featured in an ad for the luxury fashion brand Céline. The Los Angeles bookstore Book Soup recently floated the idea of putting her image on the $10 bill.

headline: ‘The Making of Home,’ by Judith Flanders
abstract: A history, spanning centuries and continents, of the difference between house and home.
lead_paragraph: There’s no place like home, as Dorothy told Toto somewhere between Oz and Kansas. Home is where the heart is, and that’s where the trouble starts. “Home” is what we think we know best already, wherever and however we live. It’s the most intimate of subjects, involving privacy, comfort, childhood memories, somewhere clean and protected from the street and modern times, a woman’s own place. (Or so men insisted, thoughtfully providing ­labor-saving devices that made housework even more difficult for middle-class women who took on work once done by servants or other women in other houses.)

headline: ‘A Nation of Nations,’ by Tom Gjelten
abstract: An NPR correspondent looks at how immigration has altered the face of a Virginia county.
lead_paragraph: Over the past half-century, immigration to the United States has radically transformed. In his prologue to “A Nation of Nations,” the NPR correspondent Tom Gjelten describes how his 19th-century Norwegian ancestors arrived in America and homesteaded their way across the upper Midwest, striking out into the wilderness. For the first 200 years of the country’s history, most of the foreigners who settled here voluntarily were ­European and white. In 1965, however, legislators rewrote our restrictive immigration laws, and over the past 50 years, the foreign-born population has become far more diverse, with new immigrants hailing from South America, Asia and Africa.

headline: ‘The Last Love Song,’ a Biography of Joan Didion
abstract: A biography of Joan Didion — Californian, New Yorker, American.
lead_paragraph: In a spiky little essay on the painter Georgia O’Keeffe, Joan Didion writes ­coded instructions for would-be biographers. “Where I was born and where and how I have lived is unimportant,” she quotes ­O’Keeffe. “It is what I have done with where I have been that should be of interest.” In other words, study the particulars of the paintings, not the particulars of the life. In the next sentence, however, Didion tells the story of her 7-year-old daughter, who, on seeing one of O’Keeffe’s sublime “Sky Above Clouds” paintings in the Art Institute of Chicago, runs toward it and whispers: “Who drew it? . . . I need to talk to her.” The longing to corroborate one’s own feelings with the facts of an artist’s life — the assumption “that the glory she saw in the work reflected a glory in its maker” — is a primal one, Didion suggests. But there is a paradox inherent in the encounter with art: Even as it may touch us acutely, it is essentially mysterious. It carries only a trace of its maker, and this is style. “Style is character,” Didion declares, throwing down the gauntlet: Find me if you can.

headline: ‘The Story of My Teeth,’ by Valeria Luiselli
abstract: A playful novel shaped by inventive collaborations.
lead_paragraph: On its not-so-placid surface, Valeria Luiselli’s second novel is the tale of a guy named Gustavo (Highway) Sánchez Sánchez, who auctions off his old teeth, claiming they are from the mouths of Plato, Montaigne, Virginia Woolf and Borges, among others. Then he takes his profits and buys a set of teeth that supposedly belonged to Marilyn Monroe, implanting them in his own mouth. After that, things go well for a while until Highway’s son, Siddhartha, knocks him out and steals Monroe’s teeth, leaving his dad chopperless. Eventually Highway runs into a man named Voragine (an abyss?) who helps him, and who later appears to be the person telling this story. Along the way, the names of Proust, Unamuno, Foucault, Walser, Cortázar and Raymond Roussel burst out of random paragraphs like startled grouse.

headline: ‘The President and the Apprentice: Eisenhower and Nixon, 1952-1961’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Irwin F. Gellman’s account of the vice-presidential years presents two Nixons, a demagogue and a pragmatist.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., someone who unquestionably understood charisma, considered Vice President Richard Nixon “one of the most magnetic personalities” he had ever encountered. “When you are close to Nixon,” King observed in 1958, “he almost disarms you with his apparent sincerity.” But King also worried that there might be a hidden duality to Nixon, or worse, a facade. If the vice president was actually insincere, King warned, he could be “the most dangerous man in America.”

headline: On 9/11 Anniversary, a Small and Somber Ritual in Lower Manhattan
abstract: Hundreds gathered on Friday, a smaller turnout than in years past, for what has become an annual rite of remembrance — a reading of the victims’ names.
lead_paragraph: At 8:48 a.m., 14 years and two minutes after a plane crashed into the north tower of the World Trade Center, the recitation of the names began.

headline: Marc Jacobs Hosted a Heck of a Party Last Night
abstract: The fashion designer celebrated the new book “Gloss: The Work of Chris von Wangenheim” with a strict (and literal) “dress to kill” dress code.
lead_paragraph: Despite the host Marc Jacobs’s encouragements, not one guest rode astride a white horse to the book party for “Gloss: The Work of Chris von Wangenheim” last night at the resurrected Tunnel nightclub in Chelsea. A galloping equine sculpture instead overlooked the bar, where lemon- and orange-flavored “Marctails” were served to a thirsty throng of black-and-sequined clotheshorses.

headline: What I Learned in the Locker Room
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Men and Boys', 'Gender']
abstract: A big part of being a sports fan is dealing with male anxiety by forming a defensive huddle of dudes.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — TOWARD the end of my sophomore year in college, I secured a summer internship with the sports department of my hometown newspaper, which was located just south of San Francisco.

headline: For New York’s Pools, It’s Not the Heat, It’s the Politics
keywords: ['Swimming Pools', 'Beaches', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Income Inequality', 'Labor Day']
abstract: Extending the public pool season — along with the already longer beach season — could be an imperative of democracy, given how few children come from wealthy families with weekend houses.
lead_paragraph: On the day after Labor Day, as so many people uploaded moody pictures of empty meadows and forlorn marine birds, indulging the ritual mourning of summer’s end that social media has amplified, the temperature in Central Park reached 97 degrees. This surpassed a record for the day (set in 1919 when it was 4 degrees cooler), making Sept. 8, 2015, the hottest September day in New York City in 32 years. Among the masses already returned from Nantucket or Vermont or Beach 108th Street, complaint and distress proceeded accordingly.

headline: Winning Her Back, Using a Little Political Clout
abstract: A former United States senator helps re-form a union after a regrettable split.
lead_paragraph: A former United States senator helps re-form a union after a regrettable split.

lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

abstract: The company has confirmed that it has guaranteed roughly the full $500 million it expects to take in from its sale of the art collection of A. Alfred Taubman, its former chairman who died in April.
lead_paragraph: Sotheby’s has confirmed in records with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has guaranteed roughly the full $500 million it expects to take in from its sale of the art collection of A. Alfred Taubman, its former chairman who died in April.

headline: A New York Hotel Inspires a Scarf Design for Rodarte
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']

lead_paragraph: Collaborations between prolific fashion designers and luxury hotels aren’t a novel concept, but the latest such partnership, debuting in time for New York Fashion Week, has a more personal touch.

headline: House Rejects Iran Nuclear Deal
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The House rejected the deal overwhelmingly, along partisan lines, as congressional Republicans showed no sign of letting up in their effort to pressure the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Following the playbook of their crusade against the Affordable Care Act, congressional Republicans on Friday showed no sign of letting up in their effort to pressure the White House over the Iran nuclear accord, even after the Senate effectively settled the matter and blocked a Republican resolution aimed at stopping the deal.

headline: Argentine Ants Carry Virus Deadly to Honeybees
abstract: Already one of the world’s most damaging pests, the ants may infect the bees with a pathogen linked to colony collapse, researchers have found.
lead_paragraph: The Argentine ant, already known as one of the world’s most widespread and damaging pests, may be infecting honeybees with a deadly virus, a new study finds.

headline: Biden Talks to Colbert About His Son
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said he was overwhelmed at times by his son’s death and unsure he could fully commit to being president, in an interview on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said he was overwhelmed at times by his son’s death and unsure he could fully commit to being president, in an interview on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert.”

headline: Sussman Brothers Expand in Berg’n
abstract: Ed & Bev’s Detroit-Style Coney Island is serving Sussman versions of diner dishes like saganaki and Greek salad.
lead_paragraph: The chefs and brothers Max and Eli Sussman this week opened Ed & Bev’s Detroit-Style Coney Island, a stand in Berg’n, the beer hall in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where they already run a shawarma stand called Samesa. In Detroit, where the two men grew up, a “coney island” is a Michigan spin on a Greek diner; coney islands are ubiquitous in and around that city.

headline: Reactions to Mumbai Bombing Convictions
abstract: Lawyers and a victim reacted after a court in India convicted 12 of the 13 men accused of bombing commuter trains in Mumbai in 2006.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers and a victim reacted after a court in India convicted 12 of the 13 men accused of bombing commuter trains in Mumbai in 2006.

lead_paragraph: The Merchant Ivory director’s 19th-century mansion in New York’s Hudson Valley is filled with memories and ephemera from over 50 years of filmmaking with his late partner Ismail Merchant.

headline: James Ivory’s White Castle
abstract: After four decades spent patiently restoring his early 19th-century mansion, the director James Ivory finally has a home befitting his extraordinary life.
lead_paragraph: After four decades spent patiently restoring his early 19th-century mansion, the director James Ivory finally has a home befitting his extraordinary life.

headline: At Jason Wu, Don’t Let the Red Lips Fool You
abstract: Models barely wore any makeup in the designer’s spring/summer 2016 show.
lead_paragraph: “I think beauty’s becoming less about piling on, and more about what’s underneath,” said the makeup artist Yadim about his minimalist-inspired beauty look for Jason Wu’s spring/summer 2016 collection. Don’t let the red lips fool you. Beyond that one standout feature, faces were clean — literally. “We didn’t use any foundation, just a tiny bit of concealer where they needed it,” he went on. Same goes for blush (none) and mascara (transparent), which played to Wu’s particular kind of “polished” girl this season. Moments before curtain call, Yadim applied a ruby red powder pigment over a layer of Maybelline’s Vivid Matte Liquid in Rebel Red, for a deep, velvety appearance and texture — and a timeless, low-maintenance look for any season.

headline: As the Nation Watches, Joe Biden Struggles With Whether to Run for President
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In recent appearances, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. looked like a candidate but sounded like an unhappy warrior, still mourning his son and unsure of his future.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. looks like a man running for president, but he does not sound like it.

headline: The Stylish Streets of New York Fashion Week
abstract: As models and guests rushed between fashion shows, photographer Craig Arend captured some looks of the day.
lead_paragraph: As models and guests rushed between fashion shows, photographer Craig Arend captured some looks of the day.

headline: It’s My Nervous System That’s Lazy
abstract: The human nervous system ensures that the body expends as little energy as possible with every movement, a new study reports.
lead_paragraph: The human nervous system ensures that the body reserves its energy and expends as few calories as possible with every movement. Now, a new study reports that the nervous system performs this optimization in real time.

headline: A Week of Insults as Candidates Turn Nasty and Personal
abstract: When Republican presidential candidates meet for their second debate next week, the gathering could get uncomfortable for the candidates firing off one zinger after another.
lead_paragraph: When Republican presidential candidates gather in California for their second debate next week, it could be a little awkward. The ability to deliver a well-crafted political insult is a necessary skill when it comes to running for office, but this week the zingers have rapidly zagged from the political to the personal to the nasty.

headline: After Death of Family of Five in Minnesota, a Search for Answers
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: The victims in what the police termed a murder-suicide were Brian Short, founder of Allnurses.com, his wife and three children, an employee said.
lead_paragraph: Five members of a family who were found dead in their home in a Minneapolis suburb died of gunshot wounds in an apparent murder-suicide, the police said Friday.

headline: As Hungarian Camerawoman Apologizes, Video of Food Tossed at Penned Migrants Stirs Fresh Outrage
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Social Media', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: Hungarian police are investigating two cases prompted by social media images that appear to show the abuse of migrants.
lead_paragraph: Hungarian officials opened a police investigation on Friday into conditions at a migrant camp near the country’s border with Serbia, as video circulated on social networks showing officers throwing food to detainees held in pens.

headline: Scores Killed in Mecca as Crane Crashes Into Grand Mosque
abstract: The toll reached 107 as Saudi authorities were preparing for the annual hajj pilgrimage to Mecca, one of Islam’s holiest cities.
lead_paragraph: IZMIR, Turkey — A large construction crane toppled over and crashed into the Grand Mosque in the holy city of Mecca on Friday, killing at least 107 people and raising fears about the safety of the site before the yearly hajj pilgrimage that is expected to bring in millions of visitors to Saudi Arabia this month.

headline: Jeremy Corbyn, Unlikely Front-Runner for Labour Leader, Poised to Win Party Vote
abstract: Mr. Corbyn stands a good chance of being elected leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, sharpening the ideological debate within the country.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He wants to scrap Britain’s nuclear missiles, nationalize key industries and print money to bolster the economy. He is a critic of NATO and seems less than enthusiastic about the European Union.

headline: James Ivory’s Home Befits His Extraordinary Life
abstract: The director’s early 19th-century mansion on the Hudson is where, for 40 years, he and his longtime friends and collaborators gathered to feast, drink, argue and make movie magic. At 87, he’s still creating beauty.
lead_paragraph: The director’s early 19th-century mansion on the Hudson is where, for 40 years, he and his longtime friends and collaborators gathered to feast, drink, argue and make movie magic. At 87, he’s still creating beauty.

headline: Review: ‘Johnny Cash: An American Rebel,’ Even if You Already Know the Story
abstract: On the 12th anniversary of Cash’s death, CMT presents a documentary to watch for the musical clips.
lead_paragraph: “Johnny Cash: An American Rebel,” a documentary debuting on CMT on Saturday, the 12th anniversary of Cash’s death, includes a fair amount of image-burnishing and hagiography. This is expected, given that it was made in association with the John R. Cash Revocable Trust and counts Cash’s son, John Carter Cash, among its executive producers.

headline: Motion Picture Academy Settles Dispute Over Planned Museum
abstract: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has reached an agreement with a neighborhood group over plans for its new movie museum.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and its planned movie museum cleared a hurdle as the academy reached a settlement with a neighborhood group that had been expected to challenge the project in court.

headline: Donald Trump Says He Has Bought NBC’s Miss Universe Stake
abstract: NBC refused to broadcast the beauty pageant in July after comments about immigrants by Mr. Trump, who owned 49 percent of the organization.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said on Friday that he had bought  NBC’s stake in the Miss Universe Organization, the group that produces the beauty pageant, which the network refused to broadcast this summer.

headline: Study Predicts Antarctica Ice Melt if All Fossil Fuels Are Burned
abstract: Burning all the world’s coal, oil and natural gas would lead to temperature increases that would melt Antarctica’s ice sheet and raise sea level more than 200 feet, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Burning all the world’s deposits of coal, oil and natural gas would raise the temperature enough to melt the entire ice sheet covering Antarctica, driving the level of the sea up by more than 160 feet, scientists reported Friday.

headline: Justice Department Releases Letters to Congress
abstract: In response to a Freedom of Information Act request by the New York Times, the Department of Justice has released three batches of letters it sent to lawmakers on congressional oversight committees between 2011 and 2013. The letters cover a wide variety of topics, including enforcement of civil rights laws, leak investigations, antitrust matters, spending on conferences, and criminal prosecutions.
lead_paragraph: In response to a Freedom of Information Act request by the New York Times, the Department of Justice has released three batches of letters it sent to lawmakers on congressional oversight committees between 2011 and 2013. The letters cover a wide variety of topics, including enforcement of civil rights laws, leak investigations, antitrust matters, spending on conferences, and criminal prosecutions.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Long Road to ‘Sorry’ Over Email Use
abstract: After a tumultuous lifetime in politics, Mrs. Clinton’s instincts have repeatedly guided her toward digging in, not giving in, when under attack.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton did not want to apologize.

headline: Cuba to Release 3,522 Prisoners Before Pope Francis’ Visit
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Political Prisoners', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The Cuban government has twice before released prisoners before a papal visit, measures meant to elicit good will for the state.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The Cuban government announced Friday that it would release 3,522 prisoners from its jails before the pope’s visit this month, a gesture the nation also took before the last papal visit, in 2011.

abstract: Bruce Weber photographs the actor Michael Fassbender in Montauk, N.Y. for T magazine’s fall men’s issue cover.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Weber photographs the actor Michael Fassbender in Montauk, N.Y. for T magazine’s fall men’s issue cover.

headline: Kathleen Chalfant to Portray Rose Kennedy in New Play
abstract: The play, by Laurence Leamer, focuses on the week following the car crash at Chappaquiddick involving Sen. Edward Kennedy.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Chalfant will play Rose Kennedy in “Rose,” a one-woman show about the political matriarch written by the longtime Kennedy watcher Laurence Leamer that will have its world premiere at the Clurman Theater at Theater Row in Manhattan this fall.

headline: How Jeffrey Immelt Is Staking His Legacy on Alstom
abstract: Buying the French energy provider is a steal of a deal. The acquisition also serves as a symbol of G.E.’s shrewd refocus on industry over finance.
lead_paragraph: It has taken 14 years, but Jeffrey R. Immelt has finally been emancipated – by the French.

lead_paragraph: Anna Sale explains how she wound up in the kitchen of Alan and Ann Simpson, getting advice on maturity, commitment, and of course, sex.

lead_paragraph: Looks from Mr. Wu’s spring 2016 show.

headline: Yale Grapples With Ties to Slavery in Debate Over a College’s Name
abstract: As students, alumni and faculty members call on Yale to rename a residential college named for the white supremacist John C. Calhoun, the university weighs whether to expunge such displays of its history.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — When Maya Jenkins was accepted to Yale, her family erupted in joy. Still, her mother confessed a concern: that her daughter might be assigned to Calhoun College, one of the 12 residential colleges at the heart of the university’s undergraduate life. It is named for John C. Calhoun, a Yale valedictorian-turned-politician from South Carolina and one of the 19th century’s foremost white supremacists, who promoted slavery as “a positive good.”

headline: The Case of the Missing Jewels
abstract: Daniel Terna’s photographs of empty diamond district storefronts.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Terna’s photographs of empty diamond district storefronts.

headline: Michael Fassbender, Nobody’s Fool
abstract: Despite his surprisingly straightforward approach to acting, the man who will soon play both Macbeth and Steve Jobs is full of contradictions. On the road with film’s magnetic outsider.
lead_paragraph: “I HAD ALREADY been turned down by two drama schools,” Michael Fassbender was explaining over breakfast in one of those New York hotel restaurants where beautiful people add wheatgrass to their smoothies. That rejection at 19 led him to London to try his luck auditioning for the Drama Centre there. He had prepared an Iago monologue, had gone over it hundreds of times, but he was still nervous. He had been replaying the words of a director from one of the other drama schools, who had told him that he could recognize an actor from the way he enters a room. ‘‘I still hate that,’’ said Fassbender. Before the audition, he was trying to get the director’s words out of his mind. ‘‘I went to the urinal, and as I was pissing, I saw that someone had written ‘Hi, Cookie!’ on the wall. Those words were staring at me, as I stood there. I had just finished playing the Cook in a production of ‘Mother Courage,’ and I had done it with a Scottish accent. Cook; cookie. ‘I’ll do the Iago monologue in a Scottish accent,’ I decided, even though that wasn’t how I had prepared it.’’ After the audition, Fassbender was asked why he’d chosen that accent, to which he answered something about it being a way to bring mischief into the piece, which seemed true enough. ‘‘It’s funny. I haven’t thought about that for years and years. I’m not saying what I saw was a sign or anything. But maybe I did sort of take it that way, and that helped me.’’

headline: Anna Sale and Arthur Middleton: A Political Favor Wins Her Back
abstract: The groom tried and failed to convince the WNYC producer he was serious about their relationship, so he emailed former Wyoming senator Alan Simpson for help.
lead_paragraph: The season was to be the “Summer of Anna.” So proclaimed Anna Sale, a New York City-based radio reporter, in 2011. “One of the rules of the Summer of Anna was if something seemed intriguing, I would just say, ‘Yes,’ ” Ms. Sale said.

headline: When the Jewels Are Unseen in the Diamond District, but Beauty Remains
abstract: Some saw empty busts in the windows of West 47th Street shops closed for the High Holy Days, but the photographer Daniel Terna saw regal sculptures that were “more beautiful” than when they were draped with necklaces.
lead_paragraph: A gold necklace can be a pretty thing. But a missing gold necklace is something more interesting. It is a story.

headline: Donald Trump’s Immigration Plan Is Laughable. But . . .
abstract: Mr. Trump’s proposal to expel 11 million people from the United States is ludicrous. But is laughing the right response?
lead_paragraph: Maybe you thought Donald Trump was speaking rhetorically, or joking, when he promised, as president, to expel all 11 million unauthorized immigrants from the United States. He has just put a time frame on his proposal: The deportations would take 18 months to two years, he said in a Thursday conference call with supporters in Alabama.

headline: A Go-Ahead on the Iran Nuclear Deal: Cheers and Fears

abstract: Readers are split over what is viewed as a major victory for President Obama.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:Re “Democrats Hand Victory to Obama on Pact With Iran” (front page, Sept. 11):

headline: NCR Is Said to Resume Attempt to Sell Itself
abstract: The move comes after talks to sell itself to the investment firm Thoma Bravo fell through this summer.
lead_paragraph: The NCR Corporation’s efforts to sell itself may not be done after all.

headline: New Study: Burn it All (Fossil Fuel), Lose it All (Antarctic Ice and Today’s Coasts)
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'ANTARCTIC REGIONS', 'Coast Erosion', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Ice', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: A new study of Antarctic ice and warming finds humanity will have to write off today’s coastal cities centuries from now if it chooses to keep burning fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: A new analysis of Antarctica’s vast ice sheet in a world heated by unabated greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuel burning comes to a stark, if unsurprising, conclusion: Burn it all, lose it all.

headline: Step Aside, Turkey. Finding the Next Great Vegetarian Main Course for Thanksgiving
abstract: This year, Well’s Vegetarian Thanksgiving is looking for show-stopping vegetarian main courses that will make even the most devoted carnivore forget about the turkey.
lead_paragraph: Every fall, Well celebrates Thanksgiving by focusing on the best part of the meal — the vegetarian side dishes.

headline: Roberta Vinci Ends Serena Williams’s Grand Slam Bid at U.S. Open
abstract: Williams’s quest for a Grand Slam ended in stunning fashion, with a 2-6, 6-4, 6-4 loss to unseeded Vinci in the Open’s semifinals on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Grand Slam seemed there for the taking. The Grand Slam will have to wait.

headline: T City Guides: New York
abstract: Five leaders in creative fields share their favorite places to eat, drink, shop and play.
lead_paragraph: Five leaders in creative fields share their favorite places to eat, drink, shop and play.

headline: The Other Side of the Counter
abstract: There’s a big difference between people who are relaxed and people who are trying to relax, writes a Hamptons local.
lead_paragraph: Tumbleweed Tuesday is what Hamptons locals call the day after Labor Day. It’s always refreshing. The summer people have disappeared. Parking spaces reappear. Stress levels dip.

headline: Pope Wants Poor Helped in Climate Debate
abstract: Pope Francis, meeting with the foundation for Sustainable Development at the Vatican, called for inclusion of the world’s poor in the climate discussion.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis, meeting with the foundation for Sustainable Development at the Vatican, called for inclusion of the world’s poor in the climate discussion.

headline: Pynchon Intrigue Abounds Over ‘Cow Country’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Hoaxes and Pranks', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Harper’s Magazine kicked off a literary conspiracy theory that a little-read satirical novel was really written by the reclusive Thomas Pynchon.
lead_paragraph: “Cow Country,” a 540-page satirical novel about a dysfunctional community college, landed with a thud when it came out in April. It has amassed all of two reviews on Amazon in the months since its publication, and has been largely overlooked by critics.

headline: Review: Israeli Chamber Project Offers an Emotive Mix of Old and New
abstract: The young ensemble, devoted to finding new audiences, showed off its range in a program of Schumann, Dvorak, Henriette Renié and Gilad Hochman.
lead_paragraph: A new chamber ensemble can make its mark in several ways. A high level of refined and exciting playing is a good start. Interesting programs, including overlooked historical gems and terrific new works, help. So does outreach driven by an appetite for developing new audiences in out-of-the-way places. And having a budding superstar in your lineup never hurts.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Sculptural Earrings
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2015)']
abstract: On the second day of fashion week, there was already a strong showing of statement accessories.
lead_paragraph: By the second day of fashion week, there had already been bucket hats, fishnets and furry shoes on the runways. But one accessory that stood out among the rest were the big statement earrings at a handful of shows. At Creatures of Comfort, elegant tiered white discs came down the runway; at Tome, models wore two different pairs — one in the shape of silver fish, the other in the shape of fish bones. Rounding out the trio was Rosie Assoulin, who collaborated with her mother-in-law, Roxanne Assoulin of Lee Angel, on a series of large-scale sculptural baubles in blue, pink, white and metallic.

headline: Times Was Right to Change Insensitive Graphic
abstract: After protests, The Times removed an offending element and later published an editor’s note.
lead_paragraph: Many Times readers wrote to me Thursday about a graphic that appeared online and in print accompanying a story about the Iran nuclear deal. They protested a column in the graphic that identified whether lawmakers were Jewish, with a one-word heading: “Jewish?”

headline: Grilled Rib-Eye Steak
abstract: Melissa Clark grills rib-eye steak, and tops it off with blue cheese, butter and chives.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark grills rib-eye steak, and tops it off with blue cheese, butter and chives.

headline: Grilling Thick Steaks, a Leisurely Approach
abstract: With a bone-in piece of meat, indirect heat helps cook things move evenly and gently but without sacrificing the char. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: For our close family friend Dr. Ruby, cooking steak was a meditative and ritualistic act. As a child visiting the Ruby family’s country house, about an hour north of Manhattan, I’d watch him stand over an enormous porterhouse on the charcoal grill, icy martini in one hand, tongs in the other, staring at his watch.

headline: For Widows, Social Security System Can Provide Rude Shocks
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Widows and Widowers', 'Social Security (US)', 'Personal Finances', 'Calculators', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: There is no simple, universal road map for maximizing benefits because of the complexity of Social Security rules and the variations in individual circumstances, including age and work history.
lead_paragraph: WITHIN weeks after her 78-year-old husband, James, died last year, Jo Etta Brown, 75, came face to face with the financial realities of being a widow living on Social Security.

headline: Shiite Militia Releases Video of Turkish Workers Kidnapped in Iraq
abstract: In the video, the men, recently abducted from Baghdad, state their names and call on the Turkish president to fulfill the demands of their abductors.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A previously unknown Shiite militia released a video Friday that shows more than a dozen Turkish construction workers who were kidnapped in Baghdad recently and demands that Turkey stop the flow of jihadists into Iraq and lift a siege of several Shiite-dominated villages in Syria.

headline: Popcast: Jon Batiste and ‘The Late Show With Stephen Colbert’
abstract: Times music critics discuss Mr. Batiste’s role as bandleader on the show.
lead_paragraph: Jon Batiste, the 28-year-old musical director of “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert,” is a serious people-pleaser: as our guest Nate Chinen attests, his gigs can have the same effect on small children that it does on grown adults. They often involve parading through the audience and other kinds of interaction; he’s from New Orleans, and understands music as a nourishing, everyday social function. But he has intensified the social aspect of performing into a modern virtuosic act, using the dynamics of flash mobs and viral videos.

headline: How David Oliver Cohen, Co-Creator of @WhiteGrlProblem on Twitter, Spends His Sundays
abstract: For Mr. Cohen, who lives in the West Village with his wife and two children, the day is focused on family, away from technology.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, the writer David Oliver Cohen and two collaborators created the Twitter account White Girl Problems, which chronicled the musings of the fictional Babe Walker. It was meant to be a tongue-in-cheek “platform for our grievances,” said Mr. Cohen, 35. Since then, Babe and her issues (“Why do I always feel fat after I eat a banana?”) have inspired two books and yielded a movie deal (a third book is to be published next year). A wine, White Girl Rosé, was introduced over the summer, and about 120,000 bottles have been sold since July. Mr. Cohen lives with his wife, Cristi Andrews, 35, an actress, and their children, Penelope, 5, and Hal, 3, in the West Village.

headline: The 38-Year-Old Frat Boy
abstract: My foolish, near-fatal quest for Greek brotherhood — a little late in life.
lead_paragraph: “WERE you in the Army or something?” a tall kid in khakis and a polo shirt asked as I refilled my Solo cup for the fifth time that night. “You look old for an undergrad.”

headline: Arro, a Ride-Hailing App, Connects Directly With Yellow Taxis
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Mobile Applications', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Arro, a new ride-hailing app, is directly connected with yellow taxis, meaning drivers can accept new passengers on the move without having to resort to their smartphones.
lead_paragraph: Uber is a behemoth in New York City. The shared-ride service has more than 20,000 drivers in the city who can be summoned with the tap of a smartphone. Taxi medallion owners have seen the value of their licenses drop precipitously, largely because of Uber’s rapid spread.

headline: Giants and Eli Manning Agree on Four-Year, $84 Million Extension
abstract: The new deal would include a $31 million signing bonus and $65 million in guaranteed money. In other news on Friday, Victor Cruz and Jon Beason were ruled out of Sunday’s season opener.
lead_paragraph: Rushing to prevent Eli Manning from entering this season in the final year of his contract, which would raise the prospect of Manning’s becoming a free agent in 2016, the Giants agreed on Friday to make him one of the highest-paid players in the N.F.L., with a four-year, $84 million contract extension.

headline: Jason Wu Spring/Summer 2016
abstract: Sculptural silhouettes were balanced out by safe colors.
lead_paragraph: Sculptural silhouettes were balanced out by safe colors.

lead_paragraph: Scott Freier is not on the New Jersey Jackals roster, but he does play for the team.

headline: 1968 | The Washington Bureau Chief Who Wasn’t
abstract: In honor of some recent appointments in the Washington bureau, David W. Dunlap looks back at an old battle over the position in 1968.
lead_paragraph: “Abe, do me a favor,” James L. Greenfield said to A. M. Rosenthal, the assistant managing editor, as they huddled in a windowless office just outside The Times’s main newsroom.

headline: Baltimore Mayor Won’t Seek Re-election
abstract: Stephanie Rawlings-Blake said she would not seek re-election, nearly five months after the city erupted in rioting following the death of a man injured in police custody, Freddie Gray.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Rawlings-Blake said she would not seek re-election, nearly five months after the city erupted in rioting following the death of a man injured in police custody, Freddie Gray.

headline: Future-Proofing, With Beer, at Crown Victoria
abstract: As summer waned, a trans-Atlantic group of co-workers from the Future Foundation, a consumer-trends forecasting firm, unwound in a backyard bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Some pessimists might argue that summer is over. But literalists, pointing to the calendar, can counter that the season doesn’t really end for another week and a half. It certainly seemed summery enough one night last week at Crown Victoria, on South Second Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where, in the record-breaking heat, dozens of late-season al fresco diners were breathing in the balmy air while seated around picnic tables in the beer garden. Though September had arrived, the atmosphere seemed more mid-July, with plenty of cold drinks and fried food, a hot breeze blowing off the river and a carefree crowd of revelers.

headline: New York Comptroller Clashes With Mayor de Blasio Over Shelter Contracts
abstract: Comptroller Scott M. Stringer’s office is holding up payments to nonprofits that shelter homeless people, saying the city may be putting people in unsafe conditions.
lead_paragraph: Millions of dollars in payments to dozens of nonprofits that shelter homeless people in New York are being held up by the city comptroller, who said the city was potentially placing shelter residents in unsafe conditions under existing contracts.

headline: Penny Arcade is Still a Force in Edinburgh
abstract: The pink-haired former Warhol superstar just completed a show at the annual fringe festival.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — In certain ways, Penny Arcade is a quintessential New Yorker. She’s a pink-haired former Warhol superstar who can say “been there, done that” about a great many things (and does).

headline: Hungarians Say Images of Harshness Toward Migrants Are Unfair
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Widely seen video of ugly incidents has obscured daily examples of kindness during an overwhelming rush across the border, officials say.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — More than 170,000 migrants have crossed the border of Hungary so far this year, taxing its police, transportation system, commerce and finances. With all that, the image that is likely to linger is that of a Hungarian camerawoman sticking out her foot to trip a migrant carrying his young daughter as they ran from the police.

headline: Artisanal Satire Straight Out of Brooklyn
abstract: Two entrepreneurs say they’re ‘trying to build adventures,’ one stick at a time.
lead_paragraph: Two entrepreneurs say they’re ‘trying to build adventures,’ one stick at a time.

headline: A Yankees Speedster With a Surprising Tutor
abstract: The Yankees think the call-up Rico Noel, who was mentored by Dave Roberts, their 2004 playoffs nemesis, can be a dangerous pinch-runner and stolen base threat down the stretch.
lead_paragraph: With three weeks left in the regular season, a tight playoff race, like the one between the Yankees and the Toronto Blue Jays, can turn on the most trifling plays, ones that might easily be overlooked on a weeknight in May: a groundout that advances a runner, a bobble that kills a chance to turn a double play, or an outfielder’s hitting (or missing) the cutoff man.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
abstract: A Labor Day parade, a rally against the Iran nuclear deal and campaign cookies in this week’s political pictures.

headline: Officer Who Arrested James Blake Has History of Force Complaints
abstract: Past accounts about Officer James Frascatore’s conduct emerged as the New York Police Department released surveillance footage that showed him manhandling Mr. Blake in a mistaken arrest in Midtown.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, a Queens man said, Officer James Frascatore pulled him over for a broken taillight, opened his car door and punched him three times in the mouth, unprovoked.

abstract: The march was held on Catalonia’s national day, but it was also the start of campaigning for a regional parliamentary election on Sept. 27.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — More than half a million pro-independence Catalans on Friday took over one of Barcelona’s main avenues, as their separatist leaders began their latest attempt to break loose from Spain.

keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Kenneth Richard, publisher of the online fashion magazine The Impression, lives and works in a 1965 house in Weston, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Standing by the pool behind his midcentury house in the backwoods of Weston, Conn., Kenneth Richard was taking a breather from preparing for another New York Fashion Week. It’s been 18 years since his last runway show, when he was a designer with his own label who showed in the Bryant Park tents and sold his collection to stores like Barneys New York.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The executive who expanded Yahoo’s ambitious efforts to make itself a digital media force is leaving the company after some of its recent projects have struggled to gain attention from viewers and advertisers.

headline: Obama Plans to Host Meeting With Netanyahu
abstract: The meeting between the leaders, planned for November, marks the start of efforts to repair a relationship badly frayed by feuding over the Iran nuclear agreement.
lead_paragraph: Washington — President Obama plans to host Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel for a meeting in November, the White House said on Friday, marking the start of efforts to repair a troubled relationship between the United States and Israel badly frayed over the nuclear agreement with Iran.

headline: Gabriela Hearst’s Art-Filled Presentation
abstract: The designer showed her second collection in the lighting designer Lindsey Adelman’s studio.
lead_paragraph: Gabriela Hearst’s presentation was as good a way as any to ease into the second official day of fashion week. Held this morning in the designer Lindsey Adelman’s SoHo studio, Hearst’s models walked around a room filled with an impressive lineup of works by Sol Lewitt, Ad Reinhardt, Robert Ryman, Jasper Johns — and under Adelman’s constellation of branching bubble chandeliers.

headline: The 9/11 Anniversary Gets Fashion Week Off to a Somber Start
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2015)']
abstract: Not much prompting is needed to remind those in the industry of an event now linked to the spring show season.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers huddled in front of their TV screens Friday morning were greeted by a haunting sight: a wrenching replay of the “Today” show live coverage of the 9/11 terror attacks, broadcast in the post-dawn hours on MSNBC.

headline: A Military Base in Brooklyn, Still Active, Has an Unparalleled View
abstract: The Harbor Defense Museum at Fort Hamilton offers an unparalleled view of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.
lead_paragraph: Short of removing your shoes, negotiating the checkpoint at Fort Hamilton is a bit like passing through airport security. A photo ID must be presented, followed by a brief background check. The payoff for this minor hassle is admittance to the only active-duty military base in New York City and the Harbor Defense Museum, not to mention an unparalleled view of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

headline: High-Tech Lights to Help Baby Sleep, or Students Stay Alert
abstract: New types of specialty bulbs are being used or tested in health applications, to enhance learning or alertness, create a mood, or aid in sleep.
lead_paragraph: Like many expecting parents, Tracy Mizraki Kraft in Portola Valley, Calif., worried about how her newborn would sleep. So she paid attention when her doctor handed her a light bulb that he said would help her son do just that.

headline: Islamic State Ordnance Shows Traces of Chemical Agents, U.S. Says
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Sulfur and Sulfur Compounds']
abstract: Tests showed the presence of a partially degraded form of distilled sulfur mustard, a banned substance that burns a victims’ skin, air pathways and eyes.
lead_paragraph: The United States has confirmed the presence of traces of sulfur mustard, a chemical warfare agent, on fragments of ordnance recently used by the Islamic State in attacks in Syria and Iraq, according to two American officials familiar with the results of laboratory analysis of the samples.

headline: Serena Williams Lost, and Her Fans Got Very Mad at Drake
abstract: To her protective supporters, this is all the rapper’s fault.
lead_paragraph: After Serena Williams’s hopes for a Grand Slam were dashed by an unseeded player at the United States Open on Friday, her fans decided to take their frustration out on Drake.

abstract: The government is in effective limbo after the resignation of the unionist first minister, and it is unclear how the impasse can be resolved.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Northern Ireland was thrown into turmoil this week when the province’s pro-British first minister resigned from the executive branch, taking his party’s ministers with him and leaving the government unable to function. Here are answers to some questions about the developments:

lead_paragraph: A New York police officer traveling with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s motorcade was injured on Friday when the motorcycle he was on fell as the caravan entered Queens, the police said.

headline: Garbo, Gloss and ‘Hir’
abstract: A look at artwork for the Taylor Mac show at Playwrights Horizons.
lead_paragraph: In the new dark comedy “Hir,” a soldier returns stateside after fighting in the Middle East to find a maelstrom back home, including a transgender brother and mother on a radically feminist mission. This being a play by Taylor Mac, the downtown writer and performer known for his flamboyant club-kid-meets-drag-mother persona, neither the patriarchy nor gender norms stand a chance.

keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Chinese-Americans', 'Physics', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: All charges against the Temple University professor were dropped after it became apparent the Justice Department had misinterpreted a key piece of evidence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Justice Department arrested the chairman of Temple University’s physics department this spring and accused him of sharing sensitive American-made technology with China, prosecutors had what seemed like a damning piece of evidence: schematics of sophisticated laboratory equipment sent by the professor, Xi Xiaoxing, to scientists in China.

headline: Lesbian Love Blossoms in New Screen Dramas
abstract: These mainstream releases portray lesbian relationships as romantic, fulfilling and, above all, natural.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Loud and proud, “Freeheld” wears its politics on its working-class sleeve. Subtle and sophisticated, “Carol” wraps its message in meticulous period costumes and clouds of cigarette smoke.

headline: Two Weeks in New York
abstract: Behind the scenes of Serena Williams’s historic Grand Slam bid — and ultimate collapse.
lead_paragraph: The path to a Grand Slam had been weed-whacked of obstacles, and Serena Williams, maybe the greatest women’s tennis player in history having her greatest season, needed to do nothing more than win two matches against two aging Italian players ranked outside the top 20.

headline: The Complicated World of Luxury Watches
abstract: It would seem that the demise of the mechanical watch would be fast approaching, but high-end timepieces are doing just fine.
lead_paragraph: With the rise of digital devices that tell time, track your steps and even pay the dinner bill, it would seem that the demise of the mechanical watch would be fast approaching. But in fact, high-end timepieces are doing just fine. Last year, Switzerland exported a record $24.3 billion worth of them (which says nothing of the equally booming vintage business). And while the Apple watch, which launched in April and sold an estimated 2.5 million units in its first quarter, is likely to affect those numbers, most traditional producers are taking their smart competition in stride. After all, they survived the ravages of the 1970s, when quartz technology made 60,000 watchmakers obsolete. Indeed, the Swiss are in the midst of a horological renaissance in which dedicated collectors wait years — and pay millions — for timepieces that make up for their lack of digital functionality with analog elegance and a promise: Given regular servicing, they’ll run in perpetuity.

headline: A Promising New Policy for Transgender Inmates
abstract: San Francisco’s jails will move toward housing transgender inmates according to their gender identity, the Sheriff’s Department has announced.
lead_paragraph: Prisons and jails across the country have typically moved to protect the rights and safety of transgender inmates only in response to lawsuits. But the San Francisco Sheriff’s Department has taken a proactive step: On Thursday, it unveiled a new policy that will ultimately allow transgender jail inmates to be housed according to their gender identity.

headline: For an Immersive Installation, an All-Star Soundtrack
abstract: To score Jonah Freeman and Justin Lowe’s massive new environment, the Black Bananas frontwoman Jennifer Herrema called on more than a dozen famous friends.
lead_paragraph: When the artist duo Jonah Freeman and Justin Lowe decided they wanted a sound installation to accompany their newest immersive environment, they called on their friend Jennifer Herrema, the frontwoman of the Black Bananas, formerly of Royal Trux. Herrema assembled an impressive group of musicians for the soundtrack, reaching out to her network rather than taking the formal route of going through managers and agents. “I kind of just wanted to go at it alone,” Herrema says. “Just get people that I knew who were fans of Justin and Jonah’s work that were predisposed to wanting to be part of it anyway.”

headline: Blue Jays Rattle Yankees; Mark Teixeira Is Out for the Year
abstract: The Yankees were thumped by the Blue Jays after learning earlier in the day that Teixeira, who was leading the team with 31 home runs and 79 runs batted in, had a cracked bone in his shin.
lead_paragraph: If this is how the Yankees began what they acknowledged was their biggest series in three years, they might want to cover their ears and close their eyes for the rest of the weekend.

headline: Trump’s Campaign Hat Becomes an Ironic Summer Accessory
keywords: ['Hats and Caps', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Donald Trump’s “Make America Great Again” cap has become a must have this season for a variety of reasons.
lead_paragraph: An old-school, wide-brimmed rope hat — some in white and navy, others in red and white — has seemingly become the ironic must-have fashion accessory of the summer.

headline: Review: The Resonant Bodies Festival Completes Its Third Year
abstract: In the programs, singers are allowed to build their own 45-minute sets, leading to some unpredictable sounds.
lead_paragraph: “Yeah, we’re going there,” said Amanda DeBoer Bartlett, just before she gave the premiere of Jonathan Sokol’s “Basic Lands” on Thursday at the Abrons Arts Center.

headline: Report Finds Vulnerabilities in Guardrails Lining U.S. Roads
abstract: A report by the Federal Highway Administration and a nonprofit group identified potential hazards in guardrails approved under old safety standards.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of guardrails on American roads, made under an old safety standard, may experience problems if hit by vehicles at certain angles or if they were improperly installed, according to federal and state transportation officials.

headline: Review: BEAT Festival Opens With a Potpourri
abstract: Comedy, dance, opera and theater were all on the menu at the festival’s opening night at the Brooklyn Museum.
lead_paragraph: It can be hard to follow the BEAT — or at least it was on Thursday, when that annual festival, whose name stands for Brooklyn Emerging Artists in Theater, opened at the Brooklyn Museum with an array of brief performances in comedy, dance, opera, theater and the spoken word. Artists appeared in various museum spaces, but what was the point of it all? Ostensibly meant as a primer for the festival, now in its fourth year, the opening-night presentation came off more like a haphazard trade show.

headline: Berlin Airport Used in Cold War Airlift Gets a New Humanitarian Mission
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'AIRPORTS', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: As Germany opens itself to waves of migrants in dire need, Berlin leaders ponder ways to shelter arrivals in the historic hangars of Tempelhof Airport.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The planes touched down every five minutes for months, often cutting through a thick fog to bring food, coal and other supplies to those marooned on an island in a red sea of communism, as the grim joke went.

headline: Review: In ‘The Perfect Guy,’ a Stalker Is Stirred
abstract: Michael Ealy plays a computer-security analyst and Sanaa Lathan the object of desire he just can’t quit in this thriller directed by David M. Rosenthal.
lead_paragraph: Michael Ealy has a very ominous stare and Sanaa Lathan sells her inconsistent character pretty well, but “The Perfect Guy” is still just a boilerplate stalker story that proceeds more or less as you suspect it will.

headline: Donald Trump Says Ukraine Crisis Reflects Obama’s Weakness
abstract: Donald J. Trump made a brief, unusual foray into foreign affairs, appearing at a conference via a video link to suggest that the Ukraine crisis was rooted in weakness on the part of President Obama.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine – Donald J. Trump made a brief, unusual foray into foreign affairs on Friday, appearing at a conference here via a video link to suggest that the Ukraine crisis was rooted in weakness on the part of President Obama.

headline: Amid Violence, Journalists in Turkey Vow to Remain Resilient
abstract: After mobs vandalized the headquarters of the newspaper Hürriyet, its chairwoman responded with admirable courage.
lead_paragraph: Journalists covering Turkey’s latest military campaign against Kurdish rebels have been been detained, deported and maligned. This week, mobs vandalized the headquarters of Hürriyet, one of the country’s largest newspapers, two days in a row.

headline: Review: Koosil-ja Embraces Revolution in ‘I Am Capitalism’
abstract: Performing at the Kitchen, this choreographer has created a dance to exorcise the economic system she was born into.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of the first section of “I Am Capitalism,” the choreographer Koosil-ja explains the work’s quixotic aim. Capitalism, she says, is a delirium from which she wishes to awake. She was born into capitalism; it is in her body. But she wants to exorcise it, to erase herself entirely to discover within herself “a new type of revolutionary potential.”

headline: Review: All Beethoven, All Evening, on Period Instruments
abstract: A fortepiano and a young Chinese-born pianist add a dimension to a performance of Beethoven by the American Classical Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Critical acclaim for the vital performances and typically adventurous programming of the period-instrument American Classical Orchestra, founded and directed by Thomas Crawford, often comes with a sensible suggestion: It is high time that the ensemble scrap its longstanding motto, “Music as the masters heard it.” Past time, in fact.

headline: Picturing Men
abstract: The most compelling images in this issue do seem to be imbued with a sense of yearning.
lead_paragraph: HISTORICALLY, images of the male form project strength and power, from heroes in the military and politics to titans of industry. But there is very little imagery depicting men simply going about their lives as men. What of the rich and varied moments that make up real life? Are these not fodder for art?

lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Saying that he hoped to spend time with his young son, a former police officer asked a judge on Friday to release him on bond while he awaits trial in the shooting death of an unarmed black man after a traffic stop in April.

headline: Ohio: Report Says Killing by Officer Was Preventable
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The University of Cincinnati officer, Raymond Tensing, “was not justified in using deadly force” in a July traffic stop, a university consultant said.
lead_paragraph: A University of Cincinnati police officer “was not justified in using deadly force” in a July 19 traffic stop in which he fatally shot a driver, a consultant hired by the university reported Friday. The security firm Kroll reported that video shot by Officer Raymond Tensing’s body camera contradicts his central claim, that his arm was caught in Samuel DuBose’s car, and he was being dragged. It said Officer Tensing, who has been charged with murder, appeared to have his arm free, and the car had not moved, or had barely moved, when he fired at Mr. DuBose. Calling the shooting “entirely preventable,” the report faulted both men for needlessly escalating the situation before that point — Mr. DuBose by disobeying the officer’s instructions and restarting his car, as if to drive off. Kroll also said the university police were unsuited to street-level policing, especially off campus, and should consider narrowing their mission.

lead_paragraph: The women’s final of the United States Open will be an all-Italian matchup that very few people had dared to predict. The men’s final, however, is a more predictable matchup of heavyweights.

headline: Births to Undocumented Parents Decline
keywords: ['Birth Rates', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: About 295,000 babies were born in 2013 to undocumented parents, down from a peak of about 370,000 in 2007.
lead_paragraph: About 295,000 babies were born in 2013 to undocumented parents, about 8 percent of all births in the United States that year, according to a study by the Pew Research Center.  The number of babies with at least one parent in the United States illegally declined from a peak of about 370,000 in 2007, Pew found.  In all, at least 4.5 million children who are American citizens because they were born in the United States have an undocumented immigrant parent. Donald J. Trump, a contender for the Republican presidential nomination, recently stirred debate by calling for a repeal of the constitutional right to birthright citizenship. He said he would deport the 11 million undocumented immigrants in the country and their children, even if they are citizens.

headline: Center to Give Trauma Care on South Side of Chicago
abstract: The new $40 million facility will serve adults with the most urgent health issues in neighborhoods that have long had few options.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The city’s South Side will become home to a medical center able to handle adult patients with some of the most urgent, traumatic health problems, officials announced on Friday, answering what has been a yearslong fight over inequities in health care and the dearth of nearby care for people living in some Chicago neighborhoods.

lead_paragraph: Large banks are preparing to pay $1.865 billion to settle accusations that they conspired unfairly to control a derivatives market that stood at the center of the financial crisis, a lawyer suing the banks said in court on Friday.

headline: U.N., Facing Abuse Scandal, to Withhold Pay of Peacekeepers Accused of Misconduct
abstract: The United Nations undersecretary of peacekeeping affairs, said Friday that he had suspended the salaries of several soldiers and police officers accused of sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In his most extensive public remarks since a string of sexual abuse allegations against peacekeepers in the Central African Republic, Hervé Ladsous, the United Nations under secretary of peacekeeping affairs, said Friday that he had taken the unprecedented step of suspending the salaries of troops accused of misconduct and had proposed sending soldiers on “rest and recreation” breaks every few months to relieve stress.

headline: Russia’s Risky Military Moves in Syria
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations']
abstract: The latest assistance may be expanding Russian involvement in the conflict to a new and more dangerous level.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few months a series of diplomatic meetings from Moscow to Washington raised hopes for a serious new push toward a political solution to the vicious war in Syria that has killed more than 250,000 people and forced thousands more to flee to Europe. That optimistic idea has been put in doubt by Russia’s recent moves to significantly bolster military support for Syria’s ruthless dictator, Bashar al-Assad, whose hold on his country is weakening.

lead_paragraph: AS the National Football League starts a new season, millions of Americans will settle in for the next five months to enjoy the thrill of pro football. Forty-five percent of those fans are female, and the league has spent millions of dollars in recent years trying to increase its appeal among women.

headline: What a Compelling Blood Pressure Finding Means for Patients
abstract: A study on reducing blood pressure ended suddenly because medical ethics demand that researchers stop giving inferior treatment to any participants.
lead_paragraph: A large blood pressure study, funded exclusively by the federal government and using almost entirely generic drugs, ended abruptly more than a year ahead of schedule because the accumulating data were so compelling. Participants who got their systolic blood pressure below 120 had a markedly lower death rate and fewer heart attacks and strokes than those whose goal was a blood pressure below 140.

lead_paragraph: DHULIKHEL, Nepal — An injured riot police officer was dragged from an ambulance in southern Nepal on Friday and beaten to death, officials said, the latest flash of violence in several weeks of protests over a draft constitution.

lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — As exclusive all-male clubs at Harvard go, the Spee Club may have seemed relatively progressive. The 163-year-old organization admitted Catholics at the turn of the 20th century, Jews in the 1930s and blacks in the 1960s.

headline: Opposition in Venezuela Is Unsettled by Leader’s Sentence
abstract: Only a few hundred people showed up to support Leopoldo López, a day after he was convicted and sentenced to nearly 14 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS — A year ago Leopoldo López, a Venezuelan opposition leader, walked at the head of rallies of tens of thousands of people, calling for the exit of President Nicolás Maduro and setting off a wave of demonstrations and unrest as the country boiled with discontent. But on Friday, only a few hundred people showed up at a demonstration to support him, a day after he was convicted and sentenced to nearly 14 years in jail for his role in leading last year’s protests.

headline: Hometown Salute for 3 Boyhood Friends Who Thwarted Train Attack in France
abstract: Thousands of Sacramentans attended a ticker-tape parade honoring Alek Skarlatos, Anthony Sadler and Spencer Stone near the California State Capitol on Friday.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — In bursts of fluttering ticker tape and amid peals of cheers on Friday, this city reclaimed the somber date of Sept. 11 as a day of celebration. Under the blazing California sun, an exuberant parade unfurled through the streets in honor of the three young natives who last month tackled a would-be terrorist on a speeding train in France, likely preventing untold casualties.

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., died on Sept. 3 at a hospice in Carlsbad, Calif. He was 89.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Fashion Kaleidoscope
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2015)']
abstract: Shown here are four important ideas from the past spring and summer.
lead_paragraph: An army of promoters and press agents are determined to turn New York Fashion Week into entertainment and build their own power base in the money-making industry. But the simple fact remains: Fashion is about commerce, not entertainment. Once the show is over, and the celebrities have left in their borrowed (or free) clothes, it’s the private women who pay for their own clothes who are the final arbitrators of fashion. Shown here are four important ideas from the past spring and summer.
