headline: Obama Won’t Stay at Waldorf Astoria for U.N. Event; Security Concerns Are Cited
abstract: The hotel was bought by a company with deep ties to China’s ruling elite and poses spying concerns during the president’s visit next week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Chinese spies rummaging through White House emails, President Obama has decided not to risk making their spying any easier: He will break with tradition and abandon the Waldorf Astoria, which was bought last year by Chinese investors with deep ties to Beijing’s ruling elite, when he attends the United Nations General Assembly next week.

headline: Steven Matz Struggles, but His Mets Teammates Pick Him Up
abstract: Matz, the Mets’ rookie left-hander, labored through five innings, but Yoenis Cespedes went 3 for 5 and delivered a two-run homer.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — As soon as Steven Matz saw his sinker miss the strike zone for Ball 4, he turned and grimaced. He had loaded the bases with two outs in the fourth inning of a one-run game. He stomped around the mound, picked up the rosin bag for a moment and immediately hurled it down. He looked upset, as if he knew that he knew better.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (HBO) FERRELL TAKES THE FIELD On Sept. 8, 1965, the shortstop Bert Campaneris of the Kansas City Athletics became the first person to play every position in a single major league game as part of a stunt to draw crowds during a losing season. On March 12, Will Ferrell recreated the feat by visiting five Arizona ballparks during spring training and playing every position for 10 teams on the same day. Mr. Campaneris joins Mr. Ferrell in this special, a collaboration between Funny or Die and Major League Baseball to benefit organizations dedicated to fighting cancer. (Image: Mr. Ferrell taking the field.)

headline: A Look Back and A Nod to Others
abstract: Revisiting some old favorites
lead_paragraph: While writing my farewell piece, I had a good time revisiting some of my favorite columns from over the years:

headline: Man Buns Are Holding On in Brooklyn
abstract: The hairstyle, which used to bestow a certain cachet, is now mainstream, and some are calling for its wearers to “liberate their locks.”
lead_paragraph: Initially popularized by Brooklyn bartenders, professional athletes and, of course, Jared Leto, the man bun bestowed its wearer with a certain cachet: He was stylish, comfortable with his masculinity and needed to keep his mane out of harm’s way while changing Marconi light bulbs.

headline: Todd Oldham’s Life After Fashion
abstract: The designer left the garment trade behind, but he remains a wildly creative, almost uncategorizable maker of things.
lead_paragraph: Todd Oldham can recall the precise moment he lost interest in fashion. It was back in 1997, and he was working on an emerald green silk satin shift that Cindy Crawford would wear in his spring runway show. The dress looked sweet and simple, but its construction was anything but. With ribbon straps made in France and fabric woven in South Korea, the piece was silk-screened with a print of a cherry tree made by Mr. Oldham on acetate, over which the designer painted a spray of cherry blossoms that were embroidered with freshwater pearls back in Texas, where his clothes were put together in his family’s factory.

headline: Karlie Kloss and Christy Turlington: Supermodels Then and Now
abstract: The models discuss their surprising careers and a shared commitment to education and improving the lives of women.
lead_paragraph: Technically, the term “supermodel” predates the 1980s, but that is when we civilians first knew who they were: Linda, Naomi and Christy. (Evangelista, Campbell and Turlington.) Famously called the “Trinity,” they were the first fashion models to challenge the celebrity of movie stars. And they were everywhere: not only modeling, but also appearing in music videos, on talk shows, and palling around together in the pages of celebrity magazines.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted by @nytimes took Instagram followers from Lower Manhattan to the hilltop village of Civita di Bagnoregio.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted by @nytimes took Instagram followers from Lower Manhattan to the hilltop village of Civita di Bagnoregio.

headline: With Jeremy Corbyn Elected as New Leader, Britain’s Labour Party Takes a Hard Left Turn
abstract: With the elevation of Mr. Corbyn, the Labour Party is in the hands of the hard left for the first time in decades.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After three decades as a political outsider and clarion of the left, Jeremy Corbyn on Saturday won the leadership of Britain’s opposition Labour Party with an emphatic victory and a program that includes expanding the economy, scrapping nuclear missiles and dismantling the centrist policies of his predecessors, including former Prime Minister Tony Blair.

headline: A Decline in the Nutritional Value of Crops
abstract: Studies have suggested that foods being grown now are less nutritious, but there may be more factors involved than just soil depletion.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is today’s food less nutritious than it was in the past because agricultural soil is being depleted of minerals?

headline: Sailing Was More Than Respite for Roosevelt and Kennedy
abstract: The two presidents were successful in weaving the pastime into their political identities, and it was also an escape from crushing pressures.
lead_paragraph: Politicians who sail may be vulnerable to complaints that the sport seems expensive and elitist. But there were two presidents in the last century who were serious sailors, and both succeeded in weaving the pastime into their political identities.

headline: Explosion in India Town Kills Dozens
abstract: The blast, which killed at least 89 people, occurred in a shop carrying explosives in Petlawad, in the state of Madhya Pradesh, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A powerful explosion ripped through a shop in a town in central India on Saturday, causing the collapse of nearby buildings, including a restaurant, and killing at least 89 people, police and medical officials said Saturday.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Android Pay and Apple Products
abstract: Another mobile payment app enters the fray, a gender-discrimination appeal is dropped and Apple unveils new devices.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the industry.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Givenchy
abstract: A pair of Victorian-inspired boots were decked out with beads.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Givenchy’s Bejeweled Masks and (Almost) Bare Faces
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2015)', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: A yin-and-yang of beauty from the makeup artist Pat McGrath.
lead_paragraph: Givenchy’s spring/summer 2016 show last night was every bit the spectacle, and the makeup was no exception — most notably on the faces of four models, who wore elaborate bejeweled masks that were applied directly onto their skin. If Tisci’s tuxedo-inspired black-and-white collection suggested a night at the opera, then these were his take on the four horsemen of the apocalypse. A painstaking process comprising gold, pearl and white beading, pieces of fabric, and professional adhesive, the entire undertaking required nearly seven hours to complete makeup artist Pat McGrath’s vision.

headline: Why the Fed Raised Interest Rates
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Officials said the economy was strong enough to keep growing with a little less help from the central bank. They said rates would rise slowly, but borrowing costs already have started to climb.
lead_paragraph: Officials said the economy was strong enough to keep growing with a little less help from the central bank. They said rates would rise slowly, but borrowing costs already have started to climb.

headline: The Fed’s Policy Mechanics Retool for a Rise in Interest Rates
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The Federal Reserve threw so much money at the financial crisis and recovery that it must take yet another unconventional approach to begin unwinding the stimulus.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to take for granted the Federal Reserve’s ability to raise interest rates. Even among the legions who doubt that Fed officials will pick the ideal moment to start increasing rates for the first time since 2008, few question the Fed’s technical competence. The central bank has a long history. The engine is known to work.

headline: Eastern Bloc’s Resistance to Refugees Highlights Europe’s Cultural and Political Divisions
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Eastern Europe's resistance to taking in migrants is the latest evidence of the stubborn cultural and political divides that persist between East and West.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Even though the former Communist countries of Central and Eastern Europe have been asked to accept just a tiny fraction of the refugees that Germany and other nations are taking, their fierce resistance now stands as the main impediment to a unified European response to the crisis.

headline: Variety: Spiral Puzzle
abstract: The Spiral variety puzzle is like walking a meditative path. Try one today.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — It’s tough to call, but these Spiral puzzles by Will Shortz rank pretty highly on my list of favorite variety puzzles. I really like watching the words and phrases come together as I toggle back and forth between the Inward and Outward clues.

headline: Scenes from Givenchy’s New York Spectacle
abstract: Last night’s show on Pier 26 brought out beaded face masks, a 9/11 tribute and Nicki Minaj.
lead_paragraph: Last night’s show on Pier 26 brought out beaded face masks, a 9/11 tribute and Nicki Minaj.

headline: Givenchy’s Giant New York Spectacle
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2015)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: The French fashion house staged an enormous show on Friday that featured performance artists, bejeweled masks and Kim and Kanye.
lead_paragraph: Guests were told to bring government-issued identification to the Givenchy show, which was held last night on Manhattan’s Pier 26 — an enormous space jutting into the Hudson River and in the shadow of the Freedom Tower. They were greeted by a set of recycled industrial materials crafted into giant pillars where performance artists (under the direction of Marina Abramovic) stood. Atop one pillar, a couple moved in different stages of embrace; under another, a woman in a white dress shirt stood quietly under a running shower. A monk chanted through the loudspeakers. “The 11th of September is the most sad day in recent American history,” wrote Abramovic in her notes for the show. “As the artistic director, I want to create something respectful and humble.”

headline: Special Offer, Time Machine Not Included
keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'Rebates and Refunds', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Consumer Protection', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: One consumer’s attempt to collect a $60 rebate for his new router leads to a maddening odyssey through the fine print into the even finer print.
lead_paragraph: In this episode, a small rebate debacle, one that the Haggler idiotically assumed would be resolved with a polite nudge. To this, dear reader, you are no doubt muttering, “Rebates are always complicated, Haggler. You are an idiot.” Yes, concurs the Haggler. That is why he used the word “idiotically” in the first sentence.

headline: The Daily Do: Zimmermann
abstract: The hair at the show yesterday was purposefully undone, with ample flyaways.
lead_paragraph: Nicki and Simone Zimmermann, the sisters behind the romantic and always-pretty line Zimmermann, complemented their Victorian-inspired collection yesterday with a rebellious twist: messy updos with purposeful flyaways. The careless knots beautifully offset the collection and were framed on both sides with metallic gold-and-silver-leaf barrettes created by Brent Lawler.

headline: Patty Stonesifer of Martha’s Table: Zigzag Your Way to the Top
abstract: The chief of a company that provides food and clothing for low-income people advises getting a broader view of the world by avoiding a fixed career ladder.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Patty Stonesifer, chief executive of Martha’s Table, a provider of food and clothing for low-income people, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: With Website to Research Colleges, Obama Abandons Ranking System
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Tuition', 'Graduation Rates', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: White House officials unveiled a new website that does not attempt to rate schools, but provides information about annual costs, graduation rates and salaries after graduation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Saturday abandoned his two-year effort to have the government create a system that explicitly rates the quality of the nation’s colleges and universities, a plan that was bitterly opposed by presidents at many of those institutions.

headline: Kim Suozzi’s Last Wishes
abstract: Kim knew she was dying, but she believed that cryonic preservation had a “1 or 2 percent chance” of offering her another shot at life. And for that, it was worth trying.
lead_paragraph: Kim knew she was dying, but she believed that cryonic preservation had a “1 or 2 percent chance” of offering her another shot at life. And for that, it was worth trying.

headline: The Neuroscience of Immortality
abstract: New efforts to understand the brain are generating methods that make “mind uploading” seem at least a bit more plausible. Here is a look at how close, and far, we are to each requirement for keeping the brain alive after death.
lead_paragraph: New efforts to understand the brain are generating methods that make “mind uploading” seem at least a bit more plausible. Here is a look at how close, and far, we are to each requirement for keeping the brain alive after death.

headline: A Dying Young Woman’s Hope in Cryonics and a Future
abstract: Cancer claimed Kim Suozzi at age 23, but she chose to have her brain preserved with the dream that neuroscience might one day revive her mind.
lead_paragraph: In the moments just before Kim Suozzi died of cancer at age 23, it fell to her boyfriend, Josh Schisler, to follow through with the plan to freeze her brain.

headline: Investigations Stymied in Malaysia, Critics of Najib Razak Take Their Case Global
abstract: Opponents of the prime minister are prodding foreign governments and agencies to look into allegations of graft and money laundering related to the his personal financial accounts.
lead_paragraph: PENANG, Malaysia — Since reports first surfaced alleging that hundreds of millions of dollars had been transferred into the personal accounts of the Malaysian prime minister, investigations into the scandal have met stiff government resistance.

headline: Phillies’ G.M. Exits on Down Note
abstract: Ruben Amaro Jr., who stocked the Phillies with more stars after their 2008 world title run, ended up trading many stalwarts before being fired Thursday.
lead_paragraph: In his last act as the general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, Ruben Amaro Jr. was left to dismantle the decaying team he had helped build. A year ago, the Phillies were still stocked with stalwarts from their championship teams, like Chase Utley, Cole Hamels and Jimmy Rollins. But Amaro traded them all — plus Jonathan Papelbon, Ben Revere and others — before the team fired him on Thursday.

headline: At Michigan State, Thriving on Saturdays With Help of Sundaes
abstract: The Michigan State Dairy Store, which helps train future ice cream makers, offers flavors that are popular with many people, including football linemen who grew up on nearby farms.
lead_paragraph: EAST LANSING, Mich. — For years, the most popular flavor at the Michigan State Dairy Store was Blueberry Pie: vanilla ice cream, blueberry swirl and pie flakes. Then, 10 years ago, the store introduced Sesquicentennial Swirl in recognition of Michigan State’s founding in 1855 and began concocting flavors to represent the other Big Ten colleges.

headline: Walt Disney, a Visionary Who Was Crazy Like a Mouse
abstract: Disney was constantly reinventing his company, a practice that drove his more business-minded brother crazy but ultimately helped his studio thrive.
lead_paragraph: Here is something that might surprise you: Walt Disney, that icon of American ingenuity, was in financial straits through most of his career. You probably thought he would have been a business genius — a model for others to study. But Disney was an atrocious businessman, constantly running his company into the ground. At the same time, though, he was a corporate visionary whose aversion to typical business practices led to the colossus that the Walt Disney Company became.

headline: Playing the Confidence Game
abstract: We take it as a truism that confidence is a prerequisite for success, and we struggle to look confident even when we are not.

headline: Jenna Miller: Demystifier of Genetic Disorders
abstract: As a genetic counselor, Jenna Miller helps individuals and couples discover and come to terms with genetic traits that may affect their offspring.
lead_paragraph: Jenna Miller, 25, is a genetic counselor with Recombine, a genetic testing company in New York.

headline: Body of U.S. Tourist in Spain Is Found, and Arrest Is Made
abstract: The body Denise Thiem was found after months of investigation and with the help of search dogs, helicopters and more than 300 police and military officers.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — The Spanish police on Saturday identified a body found on a farm in northern Spain as that of an American tourist who disappeared  five months ago as she walked along the Camino de Santiago, an ancient Catholic pilgrimage route.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: The ‘Golden Age for Women in TV’ Is Actually a Rerun
abstract: What looks like progress is more like a moonwalk: the illusion of forward motion while sliding backward.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles — NOT long ago, I recommended a young woman for a job in late-night TV and when we met face to face to celebrate her getting hired, we made a charming discovery: She was born in 1987, the same year that I got my first job on a late night show.

headline: G.O.P. Anti-Gay Bigotry Threatens First Amendment
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Religion-State Relations', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Congressional Republicans are pushing a bill that would deliberately warp the bedrock principle of religious freedom under the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: This past June, in the heat of their outrage over gay rights, congressional Republicans revived a nasty bit of business they call the First Amendment Defense Act. It would do many things, but one thing it would not do is defend the First Amendment. To the contrary, it would deliberately warp the bedrock principle of religious freedom under the Constitution.

headline: Miss America, My Guilty Pleasure
abstract: I know it’s not feminist, but nothing can stop me from the ritual of watching, and making fun of, the pageant.
lead_paragraph: Sunday night, I will do what I’ve done ever since I was a girl. I’ll turn on the TV, settle into the couch and then, with the remote at my side, guilt in my heart and, possibly, an actual scorecard in my hand, I will judge other women as I watch “Miss America.”

headline: The Pope’s Marriage Endgame
abstract: Is Francis leading Catholicism toward compromise or division?
lead_paragraph: IT’S been 18 months since Pope Francis invited Cardinal Walter Kasper to raise anew the argument that divorced and remarried Catholics should be allowed to receive communion. That invitation touched off a civil war within the church’s hierarchy, pitting cardinal against cardinal, theologian against theologian; the conflict has reverberated across books, speeches, and op-ed pages, and it’s dominated the church’s synod on the family, whose second meeting looms this fall.

headline: Northern Ireland Must Resist Pull of the Past
abstract: A crisis that threatens to collapse the government could bring about a prolonged political struggle or even a return to widespread violence.
lead_paragraph: Ending the power-sharing provincial government in Northern Ireland will serve no good purpose, either for Protestant unionists or Catholic nationalists. The only ones who gain are the dark forces on both sides who remain consumed by sectarian hatred and violence, nearly two decades after the Good Friday peace agreement promised a better future.

headline: Candidates Afloat on a Sluice of Money
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Action Committees', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: While most are taking advantage of unlimited contributions, only a few are calling for campaign finance reform.
lead_paragraph: When the Republican presidential candidates debate this week, it would help if voters could hear them offer detailed proposals for dealing with the 800-pound fat cat in the room — superrich donors who are making enormous, often untraceable contributions that undoubtedly tie candidates to special-interest agendas.

headline: A Farewell
keywords: ['Food', 'Minimum Wage', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Lunch and Breakfast Programs']
abstract: Yes, it’s a cliché. I’m going to work for a start-up, to try to change the world and not just write about it.
lead_paragraph: THIS is my last regular opinion column on food for The Times. I’m leaving to take a central role in a year-old food company, to do what I’ve been writing about these many years: to make it easier for people to eat more plants. (“Oh,” say my friends, “you move to California and join a start-up.” Yup. Corny as can be.) I see it as putting philosophy into action and will talk about details soon.

headline: How to Measure a College’s Value
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Research', 'Happiness', 'Credit and Debt', 'Student Loans', 'Gallup Poll']
abstract: An ambitious survey finds that brand matters less than other factors in graduates’ future contentment.
lead_paragraph: WE know all too well which colleges are the hardest to get into. The news media swoons over and trumpets this information, which is advertised as well by the most selective schools themselves.

headline: The Next Genocide
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Global Warming', 'Food', 'Shortages', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Hitler denied science and exploited ecological panic to lay the groundwork for genocide. It could happen again.
lead_paragraph: New Haven — BEFORE he fired the shot, the Einsatzgruppe commander lifted the Jewish child in the air and said, “You must die so that we can live.” As the killing proceeded, other Germans rationalized the murder of Jewish children in the same way: them or us.

headline: Tovah Klein
abstract: An expert on toddlers with an interest in Michigan football, rock ‘n’ roll and monster trucks.
lead_paragraph: Tovah Klein is the director of the Barnard Center for Toddler Development. Her research focuses on how toddlers as well as their parents develop and thrive.

keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Discrimination', 'E-Learning', 'Minorities', 'Women and Girls', 'Research', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Evidence suggests that it’s not the right form of teaching for many women, minorities and low-income students.
lead_paragraph: DOES the college lecture discriminate? Is it biased against undergraduates who are not white, male and affluent?

headline: What the Privileged Poor Can Teach Us
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Minorities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Income']
abstract: How to bottle the advantages of prep school.
lead_paragraph: SELECTIVE colleges look nothing like they did 20 years ago. In the late 1990s, they began adopting no-loan policies to promote socioeconomic diversity. Princeton kicked things off in 1998. Amherst College followed in 1999 and has been a leader in creating diverse classes ever since. Spurred by a combination of blistering reports that documented the loss in human capital caused by financial barriers to college attendance and by politicians like Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, who admonished colleges for not spending more of their endowments on access, 48 schools adopted similar policies in 2007 and 2008. Many people celebrated the opening of college doors to a broader array of students. I benefited myself from these new policies.

headline: There Is No Theory of Everything
abstract: We have always been perplexed by our lives. That is how it should be.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, I have had the good fortune to teach a lot of graduate students, mostly in philosophy, and have noticed a recurring fact. Behind every new graduate student stands an undergraduate teacher. This is someone who opened the student’s eyes and ears to the possibility of the life of the mind that they had perhaps imagined but scarcely believed was within their reach. Someone who, through the force of their example, animated a desire to read more, study more and know more. Someone in whom the student heard something fascinating or funny or just downright strange. Someone who heard something significant in what the student said in a way that gave them confidence and self-belief. Such teachers are the often unknown and usually unacknowledged (and underpaid) heroes of the world of higher education.

headline: U.S.T.A.’s Dabble in Blue Becomes a Tidal Wave
abstract: Once primarily a motley of greens and reds, hardcourts around the world have become predominantly blue.
lead_paragraph: Tennis has spent the last decade in a blue period that even Picasso would have marveled at.

headline: Scott Walker Cancels Stops to Focus on Iowa and South Carolina
abstract: Mr. Walker, the Wisconsin governor, no longer plans to appear next weekend at a prestigious Republican conference in Michigan or at the California Republican Party convention.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is refocusing his Republican presidential campaign on Iowa and South Carolina, where his early popularity in opinion polls has crumbled with the ascent of Donald J. Trump, and he has taken the unusual step of canceling major speeches in Michigan and California this coming week to spend time in those two crucial states.

headline: A Journeywoman Hopes to Lead a Protégée Beyond Her Footsteps
abstract: Ann Grossman Wunderlich, who reached the fourth round of the United States Open in 1994, is coaching the junior Francesca Di Lorenzo, who reached the semifinals of this year’s girls’ tournament.
lead_paragraph: There was a time, only a few years ago, when Ann Grossman had to buy tickets to the United States Open. If she had advanced one round further in 1994, to the quarterfinals, she would have earned a lifetime pass to the grounds for the tournament.

headline: With Words at Play, Tom Coughlin Motivates the Giants
abstract: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin, entering his 46th season as a football coach, contends that he can motivate with a traditional medium: words he has written on paper.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was just before 8 a.m. Wednesday in the auditorium at the Giants’ training complex. Somewhat sleepily, more than 50 players were assembled in wide rows and cozy seats as Coach Tom Coughlin marched briskly across the stage to a lectern in front of a 20-foot-wide projection screen.

headline: From Somaliland to Harvard
abstract: A 21-year-old freshman grew up in a home without electricity and has six siblings who never attended school.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — OF the millions of young men and women settling into college dorms this month, one of the most unlikely is Abdisamad Adan, a 21-year-old beginning his freshman year at Harvard. Some of his 18 siblings are illiterate and never went even to first grade, and he was raised without electricity or indoor plumbing by an illiterate grandmother in a country that doesn’t officially exist.

headline: The Google Art Heist
abstract: The tech giant is trying to digitally replicate and curate the world’s art and culture, and it’s facing head-on doubts about its true intentions.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — JUST seeing the Crayola colors painted on the tall iron fence of the 18th-century hotel particulier made me shiver. The big panda in flip flops in the lobby, arms up in greeting, scared me. And the petite ham sandwiches getting wheeled around to Google staffers looked positively menacing.

headline: Flavia Pennetta Defeats Roberta Vinci for U.S. Open Title
abstract: Pennetta, 33 years old and the oldest first-time winner of a major tournament, announced after the match that she would retire from tennis at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Storm clouds were gathering overhead and the wind was kicking up as Flavia Pennetta and Roberta Vinci walked off the court together, having played the first all-Italian women’s final in the history of the United States Open. While they sat in their chairs waiting for the trophy ceremony to begin, Pennetta leaned over to whisper a secret to Vinci, her friend of more than 20 years.

lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Democratic presidential hopeful Senator Bernie Sanders spoke Saturday to a half-empty gymnasium at Benedict College in South Carolina. The school is historically black, but the crowd appeared to be largely white.

headline: To Put It Differently
abstract: Joe DiPietro offers a puzzle where the distinction between clue and entry gets blurred.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — There does not appear to be an “official” name for the type of puzzle I’m thinking about, but Joe DiPietro’s crossword reminded me of the puzzles I solved as a kid, in which words were configured in unusual ways and were meant to convey an entirely different word or phrase. I loved those, and today’s puzzle took me back to that fun time.

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — ON a warm August evening, I found myself sitting with three educated young Russians at the Beverly Hills Diner, a chain restaurant whose gaudy décor includes human-size figures of Porky Pig and Marilyn Monroe.

lead_paragraph: The first collection designed for Brooks Brothers by Zac Posen.

headline: Blue Jays Counter Yankees’ Every Move in an Emphatic Doubleheader Sweep
abstract: Toronto broke through in the 11th inning of the first game, then piled on and led throughout the second game.
lead_paragraph: It took 4 hours 32 minutes to complete Game 1 of a single-admission doubleheader at Yankee Stadium on Saturday, and by the end of it, the Yankees looked exhausted and deflated. They had expended six relievers, two pinch-runners and a pinch-hitter. The Toronto Blue Jays had answered every strategic move.

headline: Review: The Broad Is an Old-Fashioned Museum for a New Gilded Age
abstract: The $140 million museum opening in Los Angeles next week is devoted to new art, but needs more surprises.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Traditional art museums are some of the most conservative and controlling institutions on earth. They are built as vaults to preserve the past, and as monuments to edited histories. In the Gilded Age America of a century or so ago, many new museums were also monuments to private collectors — Henry Clay Frick, J. P. Morgan, Isabella Stewart Gardner — who strove to shape and fix an image that history would have of them, as enlightened power brokers of their day and benefactors to the future.

headline: Body Blow on Texas Referee Shakes School and Sport
abstract: A violent hit by two Texas high school football players has raised a question of whether it was an isolated incident or one more sign of a darker trend in sports.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — In a state where football rules the sports world, where Friday night lights blaze over hundreds of high school stadiums at the start of every autumn weekend, the John Jay Mustangs have seldom been on center stage.

headline: In Pakistan, U.S. Aid Agency’s Efforts Face Skepticism
abstract: Critics accuse the United States Agency for International Development of, among other things, taking on projects with little concern for local priorities.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — The ads are a staple of Pakistani television: footage of water gushing through dams, farmers standing in green fields, a girl using a computer. At the end, the red, white and blue logo of an aid organization flashes on the screen with its slogan, “from the American people.”

headline: Justice Breyer Sees Value in a Global View of Law
abstract: In a new book, Supreme Court Justice Stephen G. Breyer addresses the influence of foreign law and practices on American judicial decisions.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Justice Stephen G. Breyer’s modest study in his home here is nothing like his grand chambers at the Supreme Court. Cluttered and lived in, it bears signs of a restless intellect and a doting grandfather. The bookshelves are stuffed with volumes of law and literature, and a large dollhouse sits on the floor.

lead_paragraph: Mr. Siriano’s spring 2016 collection.

headline: A Hunting Ban Saps a Village’s Livelihood
keywords: ['Hunting and Trapping', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'ANIMALS', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Conservation of Resources']
abstract: Villages like Sankuyo, Botswana, have lost income from trophy hunting while growing numbers of lions and elephants threaten their livestock and crops. Many in Africa argue that Western sensitivities are actually hurting conservation efforts.
lead_paragraph: SANKUYO, Botswana — Lions have been coming out of the surrounding bush, prowling around homes and a small health clinic, to snatch goats and donkeys from the heart of this village on the edge of one of Africa’s great inland deltas. Elephants, too, are becoming frequent, unwelcome visitors, gobbling up the beans, maize and watermelons that took farmers months to grow.

headline: Premier Quits With Cabinet, Roiling Egypt
abstract: With parliamentary elections looming, the prime minister and his cabinet step down amid a corruption scandal.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, accepted the resignation of his prime minister and cabinet on Saturday after a series of high-profile accusations of corruption.

headline: Yemen Air Campaign’s Heavy Toll
abstract: Of the many perils Yemen’s civilians have faced during six months of war, none has been as deadly as the airstrikes by a Saudi-led military coalition.
lead_paragraph: Of the many perils Yemen’s civilians have faced during six months of war, none has been as deadly as the airstrikes by a Saudi-led military coalition.

headline: Airstrikes Take Toll on Civilians in Yemen War
abstract: A Saudi-led aerial campaign against the Houthis, a rebel militia movement, has become so broad and vicious that critics accuse the coalition of collectively punishing people living in areas the Houthis control.
lead_paragraph: HAJJA, Yemen — The airstrike slammed into Al-Sham water-bottling plant at the end of the night shift, killing 13 workers who were minutes away from heading home.

headline: James Blake Says Officer Who Arrested Him Should Be Fired, for a Start
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'United States Open (Tennis)', 'Tennis']
abstract: Taking questions at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel, Mr. Blake, the former tennis star, called for apologies to other victims and New York Police Department reforms.
lead_paragraph: James Blake stepped into a car on his way to the United States Open this week, his body a bit sore and his credit cards having just been taken from him and rifled through. During the 10 minutes the retired tennis star recalled spending in handcuffs, Mr. Blake said, the words “N.Y.P.D. officer,” “law,” or “policeman” had never been spoken.

headline: Flavia Pennetta Wins U.S. Open Final
abstract: With the surprise announcement on the court that she would retire at the end of the year, Flavia Pennetta’s first major title will also be her last.
lead_paragraph: With the surprise announcement on the court that she would retire at the end of the year, Flavia Pennetta’s first major title will also be her last.

headline: Donald Trump Gets Rock Star Greeting in Iowa
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker and Senators Marco Rubio and Rand Paul also mingled with a tailgating crowd before the Iowa-Iowa State game, but Mr. Trump drew the biggest crowds.
lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa — It probably made sense on paper: invite presidential candidates to visit the Iowa Republican Party’s tent in the parking lot before the big Iowa vs. Iowa State football game on Saturday.

headline: Calibrating the Shock Value of Serena Williams’s Monumental U.S. Open Loss
abstract: If you are looking for equivalent Grand Slam disappointment, you will find Martina Navratilova, who won the first three legs of the Slam in 1984 only to be beaten in the Australian Open semifinals.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams’s loss to Roberta Vinci was, beyond any reasonable doubt, a gargantuan upset.

headline: Leaders of Moreland Commission Panel Felt Cuomo Intervened, Prosecutors Say
abstract: The United States Attorney’s office summarized the officials’ statements in a letter included in court papers filed by lawyers for Sheldon Silver, the former Assembly speaker.
lead_paragraph: Senior officials of a state anticorruption commission shut down last year by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo have told federal prosecutors that they believed he and his staff intervened in its operations “in a manner that, at times, led them to question the independence” of the panel, the prosecutors said in a recent letter.

headline: Nashville’s Mayor-Elect Finds Path Between Liberalism and Commerce
abstract: It might seem contradictory, a left-leaning mayor who is also business-friendly. But in Nashville, and elsewhere in the heartland and the South, it’s becoming the new normal.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — In her acceptance speech on Thursday, Mayor-elect Megan Barry, a candidate characterized as a purveyor of “extreme” leftist views in a bruising runoff here, mentioned the various residents who would write the next chapter for this fast-growing Southern city. In a notably nonextreme move, she spoke first of the city’s business community.

lead_paragraph: A look at the top players in contention for college football’s highest honor.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the annual Labor Day Parade

headline: After Body Blow in Eighth, the Mets Rally and Fatten Their Lead by Another Game
abstract: Adonis Garcia’s home run tied the game in the eighth inning, but the Mets responded swiftly and forcefully, scoring two runs in the next half-inning to defeat Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — When the ball left Adonis Garcia’s bat, everyone on the field knew it was gone. Garcia emphatically flipped his bat. Tyler Clippard, the Mets’ otherwise dominant setup man, watched the ball for a second and then hung his head. Yoenis Cespedes, the left fielder, turned and just watched the three-run home run go.

headline: Three Inmates Killed as Violence Breaks Out at Oklahoma Prison
abstract: Five others were injured at a prison in central Oklahoma where a fight in June had also led to injuries.
lead_paragraph: A prison in central Oklahoma was rocked by violence for the second time in four months on Saturday when rioting broke out, killing three inmates and injuring five others, officials said.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13) ARTHUR & GEORGE Arthur Conan Doyle (Martin Clunes) puts his reputation and that of his creation, Sherlock Holmes, on the line as he continues his efforts to exonerate George Edalji (Arsher Ali), an Anglo-Indian lawyer imprisoned for mutilating livestock — and threatening schoolgirls with worse — in 1903 Staffordshire. Charles Edwards plays Conan Doyle’s secretary, Alfred Wood — that is, his Dr. Watson — in this adaptation of Julian Barnes’s novel. In “Sherlock, Series III: The Sign of Three,” at 9, Holmes (Benedict Cumberbatch), the best man at the wedding of Watson (Martin Freeman) to Mary Morstan (Amanda Abbington), finds his attention diverted as a murder is plotted. (Image: Mr. Freeman, left, and Mr. Cumberbatch.)

headline: Labour Party’s Jeremy Corbyn May Help Tories in Next British Elections
abstract: It is difficult to imagine a British electorate that just handed Conservatives a majority turning to a party that has moved so far to the left by electing their new leader, Mr. Corbyn.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Corbyn, the new leader of the opposition Labour Party, has stopped wearing T-shirts in public and now favors blue shirts and darker jackets. But even with his more prime ministerial attire, it is difficult to imagine a British electorate that just handed Conservatives a parliamentary majority turning to a party that has lurched so far to the left.

abstract: A new version of the Apple TV device has a lot more capabilities than earlier versions. But getting television shows on the device is a challenge.

lead_paragraph: Panthers at Jaguars

headline: A Smooth Recovery
abstract: A model takes a tumble at Givenchy and rises with aplomb.
lead_paragraph: A model takes a tumble at Givenchy and rises with aplomb.

headline: Gaps in Earnings Stand Out in Release of College Data
abstract: At some expensive colleges, the salaries of students 10 years after enrollment are bleak, and there is an earnings gender gap at every top university.
lead_paragraph: Colleges give prospective students very little information about how much money they can expect to earn in the job market. In part that’s because colleges may not want people to know, and in part it’s because such information is difficult and expensive to gather. Colleges are good at tracking down rich alumni to hit up for donations, but people who make little or no money are harder and less lucrative to find.

headline: Stacy Martin Follows Her Nose
keywords: ['Smells and Odors', 'Perfumes and Fragrances', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: The actor, and face of Miu Miu’s first fragrance campaign, shares scent memories.
lead_paragraph: As a rule, the French-British actress Stacy Martin eschews wearing fragrance while on set: “I try to leave myself behind. I’m not going into a role to show myself,” she says of her technique. “The same for my jewelry: I will only bring certain things on set with me, like a book I’m reading, to kill time between takes.” On the power of a scent, she says, “It influences me when I don’t realize it. Almost every smell makes me stop and think about the past, a person or an event.”

headline: 1890: Switzerland’s Unexpected Revolt
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A band of radicals raided Ticino, Switzerland, in 1890.
lead_paragraph: BELLINZONA — The following are the leading facts about yesterday’s revolution [Sept. 11] in Ticino, as gathered on the spot. The movement was commenced by a band of Radicals entering the arsenal and arresting the manager. All the bells in the town were immediately set ringing, shops and cafés were closed and the gendarmes scattered about the place were surprised, disarmed and locked up. The Prefect was arrested.

headline: At Alexander Wang, It’s Back to the Natural Look
abstract: For his 10th-anniversary show, the designer opted to keep models in minimal hair and makeup.
lead_paragraph: “Alex said he wanted to get back to his roots. Go back to a natural look,” said lead makeup artist Diane Kendal backstage at the Alexander Wang spring/summer 2016 show. With the exception of a little concealer here and there, the models’ faces were completely devoid of makeup. The starring product on the makeup tables: Nars Luminous Moisture Cream, which lent a fresh, dewy finish to complexions. “There’s no real one definition of beauty these days,” Kendal later said, another reason why she chose to let the models’ individual features shine through.

headline: The Daily Do: Baja East
abstract: Designers Scott Studenberg and John Targon said their collection was inspired by three-day parties.
lead_paragraph: Brunette, spiky mullets came down the runway at the psychedelic Baja East show yesterday. The designers, Scott Studenberg and John Targon, said they were inspired by three-day raves for their spring/summer 2016 collection — which translated into psychedelic prints, flowing tunics and fanny packs worn over parachute pants. Models kept their faces bare, with only a few coming down the runway in remnants of glittering eye shadow. The effect, indeed, felt like the remains of a desert party — like models had just woken up the day after Burning Man.

headline: Subway Station for 7 Line Opens on Far West Side
abstract: The station, at 34th Street and 11th Avenue, opened to the public on Sunday afternoon when regularly scheduled No. 7 trains started rolling through.
lead_paragraph: In a West Side neighborhood long isolated from the rest of Manhattan, crowds gathered on Sunday for a truly rare sight in New York City: the opening of a new subway station. Train aficionados and local families streamed in, squealing in delight and snapping photos of the city’s first new subway station in a quarter century.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Alexander Wang
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2015)', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The designer showed shoes that were equal parts sporty and grunge.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Germany Orders Curbs at Border in Migrant Crisis
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The move was seen as a strong sign that Germany was growing weary of shouldering so much of the burden for Europe’s largest humanitarian crisis in decades.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With record numbers of migrants pouring across the Hungarian border and rushing west, Germany, the country that had been the most welcoming in Europe, suddenly ordered temporary border restrictions on Sunday that cut off rail travel from Austria and instituted spot checks on cars.

headline: On Eve of Holiday, Israeli Police and Palestinians Clash at Al Aqsa Mosque
keywords: ['Temple Mount (Jerusalem)', 'Palestinians', 'Rosh Hashana', 'Mosques', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Young Palestinians clashed with Israeli police officers who entered the compound in what appears to have become an increasingly familiar occurrence on the eve of Jewish holidays.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Palestinian youths, some of them masked, clashed with Israeli police officers who entered Jerusalem’s Al Aqsa Mosque compound early Sunday in what has become an increasingly familiar occurrence on the eve of Jewish holidays.

headline: Moses Malone, 76ers’ ‘Chairman of the Boards,’ Dies at 60
abstract: Malone, a three-time league M.V.P., was the first modern player to go straight from high school to the pros when he made his A.B.A. debut in 1974.
lead_paragraph: Moses Malone, the N.B.A. center known as the Chairman of the Boards for prodigious rebounding that propelled him to the Basketball Hall of Fame and acclaim as one of the top 50 players in the league’s first half-century, died during the weekend in Norfolk, Va. He was 60.

headline: A Watch With Lifetime Access to Ebbets Field Has Mysterious Origins
abstract: A gold watch offering admittance to Ebbets Field in Brooklyn once belonged to Gen. Douglas MacArthur’s pilot, but no one knows where it came from.
lead_paragraph: On Thanksgiving Day in 1990, a customer sat down in a restaurant on the East Side of Manhattan and plopped a gold watch on the table.

headline: ‘The Perfect Guy’ Tops the Box Office
abstract: The film, a “Fatal Attraction”-style thriller starring Sanaa Lathan, took in an estimated $26.7 million, or about 50 percent more than analysts had predicted based on pre-release surveys.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – For the fifth consecutive weekend, a movie with a predominantly black cast topped the North American box office. And, the horror film “The Visit” overperformed, ending a prolonged cold streak for M. Night Shyamalan.

headline: Alexander Wang Show, Spring 2016
abstract: Alexander Wang’s 10th anniversary show finale.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Wang’s 10th anniversary show finale.

headline: Guarded Optimism as Cease-Fire Holds in East Ukraine
abstract: Buoyed somewhat by the relative success of a two-week-old cease-fire in eastern Ukraine, four foreign ministers urged fighters and mediators to withdraw weapons and remove land mines.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Buoyed somewhat by the relative success of a two-week-old cease-fire in eastern Ukraine, the foreign ministers of Germany, France, Russia and Ukraine have urged fighters and mediators to build on that progress and withdraw weapons and remove land mines as well as prepare for local elections later this year.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 3
abstract: Alexander Wang celebrates his 10th anniversary at strip-club-themed party with Lady Gaga, ASAP Rocky, Lil Wayne and others.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Wang celebrates his 10th anniversary at strip-club-themed party with Lady Gaga, ASAP Rocky, Lil Wayne and others.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Debating Style
abstract: Highlights from political debates featuring Jeb Bush, the cerebral, halting former governor of Florida with an aversion to sound bites.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from political debates featuring Jeb Bush, the cerebral, halting former governor of Florida with an aversion to sound bites.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 3
abstract: Alexander Wang celebrates his 10th anniversary at strip-club-themed party with Lady Gaga, ASAP Rocky, Lil Wayne and others.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Wang celebrates his 10th anniversary at strip-club-themed party with Lady Gaga, ASAP Rocky, Lil Wayne and others. See the photos.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Cerebral Debate Style Faces a Test: Donald Trump
abstract: In rigorous practice sessions for Wednesday’s Republican debate, Mr. Bush has been preparing pointed responses to Mr. Trump’s most frequent insults.
lead_paragraph: On the debate stage, Jeb Bush has committed the sin of over-explanation, answering a pithy 1994 attack on his business career with so many details about leases and debts that a baffled crowd erupted into boos.

headline: Alexander Wang’s Raucous After-Party
abstract: The designer hosted a mega-fete in honor of his 10th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: The designer hosted a mega-fete in honor of his 10th anniversary.

headline: Scenes From Alexander Wang’s All-Night Rager
abstract: In honor of his tenth anniversary in fashion, the designer threw a fete that included dancers on poles and fake currency baring his likeness.
lead_paragraph: As soon as the lights had dimmed on Alexander Wang’s 10th-anniversary show on Pier 94 last night, a wall pulled back to reveal a party: a cavernous space filled with ice luges, pink-neon lights and six acrobatic dancers gyrating up and down poles. The room was littered with fake currency emblazoned with Wang’s likeness — $10 bills bearing the unofficial signature of Treasurer “Spend Lyka Dem” in honor of his clothing line’s first decade in business. The currency was scattered on the concrete of a roped-off VIP section, where Lady Gaga, Kanye West, Nicki Minaj, Mary J. Blige, Kylie Jenner, Tyga, Miguel, the Weeknd and the Fat Jew mingled and danced on banquettes. Waitstaff from Hooters served chicken wings and sliders while an ice sculpture spelled “Wang10.” A DJ mixed together an irregular-heartbeat-inducing medley that included Missy Elliott’s “Lose Control,” David Banner’s “Play” — until early in the morning, Tinashe, Lil Wayne and Ludacris took the stage for a surprise set.

headline: Victoria Beckham: Spring 2016 RTW
abstract: Ms. Beckham’s spring 2016 designs.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Beckham’s spring 2016 designs.

headline: Ben Carson and Bernie Sanders, on the Rise and on the Talk Shows
abstract: The summer of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s discontent continued on the Sunday talk shows, as the political class continued to chew on the challenges facing her candidacy. Ben Carson defended himself against claims by Donald J. Trump, and Senator Bernie Sanders discussed foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Summer might be over, but the summer of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s discontent continued on the Sunday talk shows, as the political class continued to chew on the challenges facing her candidacy — including the continuing investigation into her private email, the rise of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont in Iowa and New Hampshire, and the potential threat of a candidacy from Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: At Derek Lam, ‘I Don’t Care’ Hair
abstract: Beauty and hair at the designer’s show was a study in deliberate nonchalance.
lead_paragraph: There has been no shortage of minimalist, stripped-down makeup on the runways this season, but for Derek Lam’s spring/summer 2016 collection, makeup artist Tom Pecheux gave us effortless-looking beauty that required at least a little bit of effort. “The key word was natural,” he said, “but with something twisted.”

headline: 1940: Nazi Government Bills Vichy 8 Million a Day
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: French taxpayers are asked to pay for the German occupation in 1940.
lead_paragraph: The Nazi government has decreed that France must pay 20,000,000 marks daily ($8,000,000 at the official rate of exchange) for the upkeep of the German army of occupation, it was revealed tonight. This figure was disclosed by the French Ministry of Finance, which stated that the “Journal Officiel” would publish tomorrow a law opening a special account to be called “Expenses of Maintaining the Army of Occupation.” This law approves an agreement concluded between the French state and the Bank of France, putting at the disposal of the former an advance of 50,000,000,000 francs (nominally $1,000,000,000) to cover this charge.

headline: Moving Fast, Fire Scorches Community in California
abstract: Two wildfires north of San Francisco had burned through more than 100,000 acres and destroyed at least 1,000 homes and commercial structures, according to state officials.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The fire moved fast, faster than even veteran firefighters had seen. As it ripped down a hill toward Middletown, two hours north of San Francisco, some residents hardly had time to dress before they fled.

headline: This Week’s Movies | September 11, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Time Out of Mind,” “Sleeping with Other People” and “The Visit.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Time Out of Mind,” “Sleeping with Other People” and “The Visit.”

abstract: Dao-Yi Chow and Maxwell Osborne’s latest collection.
lead_paragraph: Dao-Yi Chow and Maxwell Osborne’s latest collection.

headline: Review: In ‘Genet Porno,’ Yvan Greenberg Leaves Little to the Imagination
abstract: Inspired by a Jean Genet novel, this misbegotten mash-up includes nudity, cross-dressing and a bathroom break.
lead_paragraph: If you have ever longed for a play starring a pair of fake penises, I have a show for you. These outsized appendages are easily the most credible and intriguing performers in “Genet Porno,” a misbegotten mash-up of Jean Genet’s novel “Our Lady of the Flowers” and a pornography star’s YouTube diary.

headline: Fashion Week’s Opening-Day Star Is Jason Wu
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2015)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: The earliest shows at the New York collections are for up-and-comers, like Creatures of the Wind and Wes Gordon.
lead_paragraph: Pity the poor designer who shows at the beginning of New York Fashion Week. There’s so much competing action around — in culture (the Venice International Film Festival), sports (the United States Open, the start of football season) and national memory (Sept. 11) — that a label has to work very hard for attention.

headline: Shinzo Abe Is Re-elected as Leader of Japan’s Liberal Democrats
abstract: “Abenomics is still halfway through,” Mr. Abe said.
lead_paragraph: “Abenomics is still halfway through,” Mr. Abe said.

lead_paragraph: The spring 2016 collection from Mr. Tahari.

abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio was among the first riders to enter the 7 line station at 34th Street and 11th Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio was among the first riders to enter the 7 line station at 34th Street and 11th Avenue.

headline: Ad Contrasts Ronald Reagan’s Views With Republicans’ Words on Immigration
abstract: The ad from a pro-immigration group is timed to this week’s Republican presidential debate and features clips showing Mr. Reagan’s upbeat tone in welcoming people to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Timed to this week’s Republican presidential debate, a pro-immigration group will run a television ad that juxtaposes Ronald Reagan’s upbeat tone in welcoming people to the United States against the words of the current party candidates.

headline: A Look Back at the Sixth Avenue Subway Line Opening
abstract: The Sixth Avenue line was the last subway line in Manhattan to be built and one of the most challenging ones. It opened in 1940.
lead_paragraph: The Sixth Avenue line was the last subway line in Manhattan to be built and one of the most challenging ones. It opened in 1940.

headline: Review: In ‘Judy,’ Societal Regression, Circa 2040
abstract: Max Posner’s play depicts the households of three siblings in the future, when everyone seems to spout bizarre thoughts.
lead_paragraph: The title is a tease in the new play “Judy,” by Max Posner. We never meet a woman by that name, but that’s the least of the oddities in this ponderous puzzle, set in 2040. Generally dramas taking place in the future push hard on the futurism, but Mr. Posner’s 25 years ahead doesn’t seem wildly more exotic than today, except that everyone apparently lives in basements, most people have forsworn profanity (fat chance) and Internet connections are worse (a disturbing thought).

headline: Rivalry Builds Off the Field as Talent Agencies Turn to Sports
abstract: With the movie and television businesses facing an uncertain future, Creative Artists Agency and William Morris Endeavor are going all in on athletics.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As the National Football League begins another season, almost a third of its starting quarterbacks — including Peyton Manning and Drew Brees — will be represented by Creative Artists Agency. And as Novak Djokovic won the U.S. Open on Sunday, his team from William Morris Endeavor was in the stands cheering him on.

headline: From Givenchy and Alexander Wang, Competing Visions of New York
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2015)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Plus different female ideals from Public School, Victoria Beckham, Joseph Altuzarra and Derek Lam.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 11, as the sun set over the Hudson and bathed 1 World Trade Center in silver and rose, Givenchy held a fashion show on Pier 26, on the far western edges of TriBeCa, in the shadows of the skyline.

headline: “Shear Madness” Opening in New York for the First Time
abstract: “Shear Madness,” a comedy that opened in Boston 36 years ago, is coming to Off-Broadway this October.
lead_paragraph: After 36 years of performances in Boston, Washington, and all around the globe, the play “Shear Madness” is coming to New York for the first time. The long-running farce about a murder in a beauty parlor will begin performances Off Broadway on Oct. 22nd at Stage 4 at New World Stages, with an official opening of Nov. 11.

headline: Tracy Reese: Spring 2016 RTW
abstract: The spring 2016 collection from Ms. Reese.
lead_paragraph: The spring 2016 collection from Ms. Reese.

headline: Rodriguez Screams, Blue Jays Fall Silent, and Yankees Rebound
abstract: Alex Rodriguez’s outburst after scoring on a sacrifice fly seemed to energize the Yankees, who got a strong outing from Masahiro Tanaka and won the finale of a four-game series.
lead_paragraph: It was not a particularly deep fly ball, but this was not a particularly normal game for Alex Rodriguez, who steadied himself at third base, poised to pounce toward home. His body, after 2,698 career regular-season games, could still cover plenty of ground.

headline: Big Win but Bigger Worries for Jets
abstract: Cornerback Antonio Cromartie and linebacker Lorenzo Mauldin were hurt during the game.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Jets wanted to celebrate but could not, at least not the way they wanted. They wanted to smile but did not, at least not as wide. They wanted to crow about all the touchdowns they scored and all the turnovers they forced, their second-half dominance in a 31-10 season-opening victory against Cleveland, but they did not, at least not much.

headline: The Concert Hall as Refuge in a Restless, Web-Driven World
abstract: A case can be made for classical music as a tonic for an increasingly wired society.
lead_paragraph: For all the wonders of the web, it “threatens habits of deeper inquiry,” Ian Leslie argues in “Curious: The Desire to Know and Why Your Future Depends on It.” This book is among a growing number exploring what might be lost as we “lean on search engines and offload our memories to cloud storage,” to quote a review of four contributions to the topic last year by Jacob Silverman in The New York Times.

headline: Joshua Roth Takes United Talent Agency Into the Art World
abstract: Seven months after United Talent Agency created a fine arts division, it is announcing a client, which Mr. Roth hopes is the start of a fruitful cross-pollination.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The office of Joshua Roth, a lawyer-turned-agent at the United Talent Agency headquarters here, has all the trappings of a Hollywood player: the expensive swivel chair, the big flat-screen TV. It also boasts the outward signs of an art dealer. Issues of Artforum and Art in America are fanned out on his desk, alongside entertainment industry publications. On the wall hangs an ’80s-pink portrait by the Los Angeles artist Alex Israel. Works by the painter Jonas Wood and the ceramist Shio Kusaka line the space. And Mr. Roth’s assistant is busy planning his trips to scout talent — not just at Cannes and Sundance, but at Art Basel Hong Kong and the Frieze Art Fair in New York.

headline: Review: Carlos Henriquez Radiates Gratitude in a South Bronx Homecoming
abstract: The bassist for the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra is the focus of a concert and has a new album, “The Bronx Pyramid,” coming out this week.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every note from Carlos Henriquez, the bassist for the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, is cool, clear, judicious, full of body and intent. His sound doesn’t grasp or rush; informed by the economy of Afro-Latin tumbao bass patterns, it connects and assists. It has its moral priorities straight.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 14
keywords: ['Municipal Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Review: Cantata Profana Revives a Henze Cycle Inspired by German Poems
abstract: The Cantata Profana performance at St. Peter’s Church on Friday included a semi-staged version of Hans Werne Henze’s “Kammermusik 1958.”
lead_paragraph: A penchant for dramatizing chamber music is central to the mission of Cantata Profana, a group of adventurous young instrumentalists and singers whose core members met as students at the Yale School of Music. The ensemble opened its fourth season on Friday night at St. Peter’s Church in Midtown with an imaginative new semi-staged version of Hans Werne Henze’s “Kammermusik 1958.” This piece is an hourlong song cycle for tenor, guitar and eight other instruments that alternates vocal settings of six feverish, strangely haunting German poems by Friedrich Hölderlin with seven instrumental interludes.

headline: Review: Jeanine Durning’s ‘To Being,’ a Dance Premiere in Queens
abstract: The dance, which had its premiere at the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City, features “nonstopping,” or movement that never settles.
lead_paragraph: How will they get themselves out of this? I kept wondering that during Jeanine Durning’s “To Being,” which had its premiere on Wednesday at the Chocolate Factory in Queens, and not because I wanted it to end. This marathon of a dance enmeshes the dancers so wholly in doing, doing, doing that you can’t imagine them being done. It’s like watching people live, right in the thick of passing time.

headline: Basilica Soundscape: A Festival of Pop, Punk and So Much Else
abstract: A weekend-long festival of music, art, poetry and style, this event celebrates music that aims beyond the visible horizon.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON, N.Y. —  “I always wanted to be less subculturally lonely,” declared Jenny Hval, the Norwegian avant-pop polymath, at Basilica Soundscape on Saturday night. “But here I see no subculture.”

headline: Review: Arvo Pärt and 9/11, Paired at the Metropolitan Museum
abstract: The Temple of Dendur — though unloved by musicians for its acoustics — only enhanced a sense of quasi-religious ritual.
lead_paragraph: Sept. 11 was, of course, many things before it became 9/11. For one, it was the birthday of the Estonian composer Arvo Pärt.

headline: Royal Topper
abstract: Zhouqin Burnikel tops off our solving week in a royal way.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Merl Reagle Memorial Alert! If you live in or plan to be in the Tampa, Florida area on Sunday, September 27, Marie Reagle will be hosting a memorial for Merl from 5:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m. at the University of Tampa in the Vaughn Center (9th floor). The event is open to the public.

headline: Review: In ‘Black Man in a White Coat,’ a Doctor Navigates Bruising Terrain
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Doctors', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Damon Tweedy’s memoir is at once a painful self-examination and a look at the health implications of being black in a country where blacks are more likely to suffer from certain ailments.
lead_paragraph: As a student at Duke University Medical School in the mid-1990s, Damon Tweedy once treated a black teenager who was hysterical and having a late-stage miscarriage. He made a flailing attempt to take her history — she denied being pregnant and said she had no bad habits — whereupon his supervisor barreled in and barked, “When is the last time you smoked crack?”

headline: Review: Melanie Martinez Performs ‘Cry Baby’ and Other Songs From Her Debut Album
abstract: Ms. Martinez stayed on message about grown-up realities during her concert at the Highline Ballroom.
lead_paragraph: Melanie Martinez, a 20-year-old songwriter who performed on Friday night at the Highline Ballroom, could teach career politicians how to stay on message. She single-mindedly and thoroughly explores one scenario: What happens when childhood illusions give way to bitter adult realities.

headline: Review: ‘Available Light’ Takes Over an Armory at Philadelphia’s Fringe Festival
abstract: This revival of a work choreographed by Lucinda Childs and scored by John Adams, with a set by Frank Gehry, mines a breathtaking spectrum of kaleidoscopic patterns.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of an extensive European tour, “Available Light,” a 1983 collaboration among the choreographer Lucinda Childs, the composer John Adams and the architect Frank Gehry, made an American stop over the weekend. Presented by FringeArts in Philadelphia as part of the 2015 Fringe Festival, the work took over the Drexel University Armory, a space vast enough to accommodate its grand if minimalist proportions. Ms. Childs was among the revolutionaries of Judson Dance Theater in the 1960s, and like some of her fellow postmodernists she has found a more ardent audience — and more funding, presumably — in Europe than in the United States. But as the writer Suzanne Carbonneau notes in a program essay, Philadelphia has been good to her, with the Pew Center for Arts & Heritage supporting the reconstruction of her early works and giving them a handsome online platform, the exemplary archival project “A Steady Pulse: Restaging Lucinda Childs, 1963-78.” You can enjoy that from anywhere.

headline: A Rabbi From Uber
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A hired car service proved unusually convenient when the rider told the driver she was going to see her grandfather’s grave.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

lead_paragraph: 15 memorable articles, columns and video clips from Mr. Carr, a prolific media columnist for The New York Times, including his last piece that was published the day before he died.

headline: Discovering Shaken Baby Syndrome
abstract: The pediatric neurosurgeon who first identified shaken baby syndrome has a surprising take on the very syndrome he’s credited with discovering.
lead_paragraph: The pediatric neurosurgeon who first identified shaken baby syndrome has a surprising take on the very syndrome he’s credited with discovering.

headline: The Nanny Murder Trial
keywords: ['Shaken Baby Syndrome', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Child Care', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: In 1997, a young British nanny charged with murder brought shaken baby syndrome into the national spotlight, and raised a scientific debate that continues to shape child abuse cases today.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, a young British nanny charged with murder brought shaken baby syndrome into the national spotlight, and raised a scientific debate that continues to shape child abuse cases today.

headline: The Anatomy of a Murder Case
keywords: ['Shaken Baby Syndrome', 'Child Care', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The anatomy of a shaken baby case from the perspective of defense attorney Adele Bernhard.
lead_paragraph: The anatomy of a shaken baby case from the perspective of defense attorney Adele Bernhard.

headline: Shaken Baby Syndrome: A Diagnosis That Divides the Medical World
keywords: ['Shaken Baby Syndrome', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: For years, doctors swore by the symptoms of head trauma that were accepted as evidence of a crime against a child. Now, a growing number are not so sure.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no crime staggers the mind, or turns the stomach, more than the murder of a baby, and so it is not a surprise when law enforcement comes down hard on the presumed killers. Often enough, these are men and women accused of having succumbed to sudden rage or simmering frustration and literally shaken the life out of a helpless infant who would not stop crying or would not fall asleep.

headline: The New Mets: They Finish a Sweep, Then Grumble About Their Miscues
abstract: The Mets scored three runs on a two-out ninth-inning home run to tie the game and then scored three more times in the 10th inning to complete a four-game sweep in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Daniel Murphy shook his head, muttered something to himself and kicked the dirt near second base, perhaps trying to forget the last play. Freddie Freeman had driven a hard-hit ball that took a high bounce just in front of him, and Murphy had turned and held out his glove backhanded, trying to snatch the ball out of the air. But it screamed by him.

headline: Cities United, de Blasio’s Immigration Coalition, Has Big Goals but Modest Start
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York founded the group with lofty aspirations, but progress has been stymied by politics and the logistical difficulties of coordinating action across dozens of cities.
lead_paragraph: The coalition of the nation’s mayors was envisioned as a powerful advocacy machine, banding together to put President Obama’s executive actions on immigration into effect and to “amplify the progressive vision” by pushing for wholesale immigration reform.

headline: Frank D. Gilroy, Who Had Smash Debut With ‘Subject Was Roses,’ Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Gilroy won a Pulitzer Prize, a Tony and a Drama Critics’ Circle Award for that play, his 1964 Broadway debut, but it was his only major theatrical success.
lead_paragraph: Frank D. Gilroy, whose 1964 Broadway debut, “The Subject Was Roses,” won the theater’s triple crown — a Pulitzer Prize, a Tony and a Drama Critics’ Circle Award — but proved to be the high note in his life as a playwright and television and Hollywood dramatist, died on Saturday at his home in Monroe, N.Y. He was 89.

abstract: The United States government, which spent more than $4 billion in assistance to El Salvador’s military during its civil war, is now working to bring some of the officers to justice.
lead_paragraph: Early in the morning on Nov. 16, 1989, soldiers from an elite battalion of the Salvadoran Army walked into the religious center of a Jesuit university and killed everyone they found inside.

headline: Details on Bowe Bergdahl, Soldier Freed by Taliban, May Emerge at Hearing
keywords: ['Desertion (Military)', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Courts-Martial', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A hearing on Thursday will lead to a decision whether to court-martial Sergeant Bergdahl, 29, who was captured and held by the Taliban for five years.
lead_paragraph: In the 15 months since American commandos whisked Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl from an Afghanistan hilltop in a trade with the Taliban, he has been portrayed as both a traitor and a hero, even as most facts uncovered about what happened when he left his outpost six years ago have remained officially under wraps.

headline: Consumers and Lawmakers Take Steps to End Forced Labor in Fishing
keywords: ['Fishing, Commercial', 'Human Trafficking', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Forced Labor', 'Pet Foods', 'Consumer Protection', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Citing a recent New York Times series on lawlessness at sea, lawmakers have asked fishing and pet food companies to increase transparency and accountability in their labor practices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal lawmakers, State Department officials, fishing and pet food companies, and class-action lawyers are stepping up efforts to combat forced labor at sea.

headline: 4th Inmate Dies After Oklahoma Prison Brawl
abstract: A prisoner wounded in an outbreak of violence at the Cimarron Correctional Facility in Oklahoma died of his injuries, bringing the number of dead fto four.
lead_paragraph: An inmate hospitalized after a weekend outburst of violence at a prison in Oklahoma died of his injuries, the company that owns and operates the prison said on Sunday, bringing the number of dead from the episode to four.

headline: Etsy Welcomes Manufacturers to Artisanal Fold
abstract: With Etsy Manufacturing, the online marketplace plans to connect sellers and small manufacturers that meet certain production and workplace criteria.
lead_paragraph: Molly Goodall’s store on Etsy, the online crafts marketplace, started as a creative solution to a parenting problem.

headline: Stanley Hoffmann, Who Brought Passion to Foreign Policy Analysis, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Hoffmann taught at Harvard for more than half a century and wrote a series of influential books that explored international relations.
lead_paragraph: Stanley Hoffmann, a French-educated political scientist and foreign-affairs analyst who perceptively interpreted France and the United States to each other, and who, in a series of influential books, explored the forces that govern the relations between states, died over the weekend at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 86.

headline: Ben Carson Works His Way Up the Donation Ladder
abstract: A soft-spoken Republican candidate who apparently had stage fright in the first debate is gaining confidence and wealthier donors.
lead_paragraph: First came the grass-roots support. Now Ben Carson, the retired neurosurgeon who has quietly arrived near the front of the Republican presidential field, is scooping up $100,000 a night from wealthy donors in Texas and California — evidence that he is fast transforming from a novelty candidate into one to be taken seriously by rivals and party leaders alike.

abstract: Rainbow Music, a crammed and beloved record shop in the East Village, will close after 17 years at the end of the month.
lead_paragraph: “Hello, this is Rainbow Music,” said the stooped man in the rumpled clothes, as he answered the phone in the middle of what could safely be described as a Grand Canyon of CDs.
