headline: Fed’s Decision on Interest Rates, Autoworkers’ Contract Talks and a Greek Election
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Automobiles', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Consumer Price Index', 'Interest Rates', 'Elections']
abstract: This week, the Fed announces whether it will raise interest rates, contract talks with Detroit’s three automakers enter the final stretch and an election in Greece will help determine its economic future.
lead_paragraph: Airbus, the European airplane maker, will formally open a jet assembly plant in Mobile, Ala., on Monday, its first such factory in the United States. The move into the heart of Boeing’s home turf is part of a long-term strategy by Airbus aimed at doubling its share of the American market for 150-seat airplanes, which is currently dominated by Boeing’s top-selling 737. Airbus plans to build as many as 36 of its competing A320 and A321 models a year by 2018 and says the Mobile plant has the capacity to double that production. All of the aircraft produced at the site are destined for delivery to American carriers, which are expected to need as many as 4,700 new single-aisle planes over the next 20 years. —Nicola Clark

headline: William Becker, Who Transformed Janus Films, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Becker, a culturally minded businessman, acquired Janus Films in 1965 with a partner, and they vastly expanded its library and broadened its distribution.
lead_paragraph: William Becker, a theater critic and financier who acquired Janus Films with a partner in 1965, expanded its catalog of art-house and Hollywood classics and broadened their distribution to university audiences and home viewers on DVD, died on Saturday at his country home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 88.

headline: Russian Local Elections Draw Charges of Fraud
abstract: As Russians voted in local and regional elections, democracy advocates accused the authorities of fraud and said the police blockaded an apartment where opposition activists were tracking the vote.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — As Russians voted in local and regional elections on Sunday, democracy advocates in the only region where they were allowed to run accused the authorities of fraud and said the police had blockaded an apartment where opposition activists were tracking the vote.

headline: U.S. and Iran Both Conflict and Converge
abstract: With the nuclear deal having cleared its biggest congressional hurdle, the United States will have to navigate an increasingly complicated regional maze with a newly empowered Iran.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — American troops advising Iraqi security forces in restive Anbar Province are sharing a base with odd bedfellows: an Iranian-backed militia that once killed United States soldiers. Both are fighting the militants of the Islamic State.

headline: Martina Hingis’s Doubles Comeback Yields Fifth Major Title of Year
abstract: Hingis and Sania Mirza won in straight sets at the U.S. Open, giving Hingis a 20th major title over all: five in singles, 11 in women’s doubles and four in mixed doubles.
lead_paragraph: Martina Hingis won the Grand Slam in women’s doubles in 1998, part of a remarkable year when she also won the Australian Open singles title and the WTA Tour championship. She did not accomplish all that this year, but what she did was still quite impressive.

headline: Early College Season Holds No Sway? Some Hope It Does
abstract: Just as early losses can be forgotten, teams with huge victories in the early going hope they will be remembered come playoff selection time.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Walking through the quad here Saturday an hour before Alabama’s kickoff was practically as good as listening to a radio play-by-play of the Auburn game’s closing minutes. Cheers indicated good news for Jacksonville State, which plays in the second-tier Football Championship Subdivision and was shockingly leading the Tigers with minutes to go. Disapproving murmurs indicated plays made by Alabama’s archrival.

headline: Baidu and CloudFlare Boost Users Over China’s Great Firewall
abstract: The Chinese search giant Baidu and CloudFlare, a start-up based in San Francisco, have joined in an unusual business arrangement to speed Internet traffic into and out of China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It is one of the best-guarded borders in the world, and one of the most time-consuming to cross. Yet in the past few months, a new agreement has let people speed over it billions of times.

headline: Boston Enlivens City Hall Plaza by Rolling Out Green Carpet
abstract: Practically overnight, the setup, minimal as it is, has transformed this widely derided stretch of cityscape into a park space.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A new terroir has emerged atop the downtown badlands known as City Hall Plaza: an enormous carpet of fake grass, affixed with tape to a section of the barren brick that stretches for almost an entire city block in front of this city’s dystopian-looking municipal nerve center.

headline: One Symptom in New Medical Codes: Doctor Anxiety
abstract: Under the new coding regime, government programs and private insurers will require doctors, hospitals, clinics and nursing homes to report vastly more information about the care they provide patients.
lead_paragraph: TERRE HAUTE, Ind. — The nation’s health care providers are under orders to start using a new system of medical codes to describe illnesses and injuries in more detail than ever before. The codes will cover common ailments: Did a diabetic also have kidney disease? But also included are some that are far less common: whether the patient was crushed by a crocodile or sucked into a jet engine.

headline: Suit Says Police Violated Occupy Wall Street Protesters’ Constitutional Rights

lead_paragraph: As the first anniversary of the Occupy Wall Street protests approached three years ago, organizers planned a series of marches and rallies, including an attempt to block the streets surrounding the New York Stock Exchange.

keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Drownings', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The deaths were the latest in a catalog of drownings as migrants continue to make the often perilous crossing from Turkey to Greece.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The Greek Coast Guard recovered the bodies of 34 migrants, including 15 children, on Sunday in the Aegean Sea after their wooden boat flipped over in strong winds as it attempted the short but often perilous crossing from nearby Turkey.

headline: Yankees Don’t Want Wild Card, but They May Need It
abstract: The Yankees, three and a half games behind Toronto in the A.L. East, insisted their focus was on winning their division, but recent history shows that a wild-card spot is not so bad.
lead_paragraph: The wild card is the prize nobody wants, until there is no other choice. Acknowledging its presence — without absolutely having to — is all but forbidden in baseball. Never mind that two wild-card teams met in the last World Series.

lead_paragraph: Several lawmakers joined Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan on Sunday in condemning the scalping of tickets to a procession by Pope Francis during his stop in New York City on a national tour, calling it contrary to the spirit of the pontiff’s visit.

headline: ScienceTake | Zombie Spiders
abstract: How a parasitic wasp larva turns an orb weaver spider into a slave that builds a web to host the larva’s cocoon.
lead_paragraph: How a parasitic wasp larva turns an orb weaver spider into a slave that builds a web to host the larva’s cocoon.

headline: A Wasp That Turns a Spider Into the Walking Dead
abstract: First an ichneumonid wasp lays an egg on an orb weaver spider. The larva essentially turns the spider into a zombie, uses its web and eats the spider.
lead_paragraph: If spiders had nightmares, the larvae of ichneumonid wasps would have to star in them. The wasp lays an egg on the back of an orb weaver spider, where it grows fat and bossy, and occupies itself with turning the spider into a zombie. As Keizo Takasuka and his colleagues point out in The Journal of Experimental Biology, this is a classic case of “host manipulation.” Using more colorful language, he described the larva turning the spider into a “drugged navvy.”

headline: Which Fed Leaders Fear Inflation? Look at When They Grew Up
abstract: Economic events during formative years might exert an outsize influence on how policy makers see the world. That’s an argument for studying history.
lead_paragraph: If you are an 18-year-old college freshman in the United States, inflation in your lifetime has averaged less than 2 percent. If you are a 30-year-old millennial, you experienced inflation above 5 percent for only one year — when you were in kindergarten, perhaps in the form of the coins in a piggy bank buying fewer pieces of candy the longer they sat unspent.

headline: A Quick Reminder of Football’s Violence
abstract: As the Jets played the Browns, it took all of 14 minutes for a concussion to occur, another 25 for a star to tear up his knee, and three and a half quarters for a player to be carted off the field.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In Week 1 of a new N.F.L. season and at Game 1 of Todd Bowles’s tenure as Jets head coach, the dark cloud of violence that has been a fixture over the league descended on MetLife Stadium as if it had been waiting for just that moment.

headline: Federer’s Strengths Abandon Him on the Big Stage
abstract: Roger Federer has a reputation for his precision and his resolve, but against Novak Djokovic in the U.S. Open final, those normally dependable characteristics failed him in key moments.
lead_paragraph: Roger Federer sat down in his chair during a changeover late in the fourth set of the United States Open men’s final against Novak Djokovic and made an exasperating realization about why he was about to lose the match.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:20 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE SKIN I LIVE IN (2011) Robert Ledgard (Antonio Banderas), a Spanish plastic surgeon whose wife has died of burns, experiments on a patient named Vera (Elena Anaya, above, with Mr. Banderas), whom he keeps locked in his isolated mansion, in what Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called Pedro Almodóvar’s “intoxicating, lush mystery.” But how did Vera get there, and why? The subplots involve a rapist (Roberto Álamo), the doctor’s housekeeper (Marisa Paredes), his daughter (Blanca Suarez) and a young man she has met (Jan Cornet). “Despite all these moving, spinning parts,” Ms. Dargis added, “Mr. Almodóvar’s control remains virtuosic and the film hangs together completely.”

headline: On Verge of Inspiring Win, Giants’ Defense Collapses Against Cowboys
abstract: Tony Romo led Dallas 72 yards down the field in 82 seconds, connecting with tight end Jason Witten for an 11-yard touchdown pass that gave the Cowboys a comeback victory.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Giants’ offense was struggling. The incandescent Odell Beckham Jr. had largely been held in check. On defense, the Giants’ pass rush was nonexistent. A relentless Dallas attack had allowed the Cowboys to dominate the game’s time of possession.

headline: Austerity Success Stories
abstract: This is the best they have to offer?
lead_paragraph: One thing you encounter a lot in Europe these days are assertions that the “success” of Spain and Portugal proves that the critics of austerity were all wrong. To make this sort of claim, however, you have to do two things. First, you need to define success way, way down. Second, you have to willfully misread what Keynesians have been saying from the beginning about about the process of internal devaluation.

headline: How Congress Can Help Puerto Rico
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Bankruptcies', 'Credit and Debt', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Bankruptcy should be allowed for the island’s municipalities.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Alejandro García Padilla of Puerto Rico has offered a comprehensive proposal for reversing the territory’s downward spiral. Unlike prior proposals, which focused solely on restructuring Puerto Rico’s debt or cutting its spending, the new plan recognizes the urgent need for both. It could actually work, but only with a major assist from Congress.

headline: Labour’s Dead Center
abstract: In contrast to the new leader of the British party, its moderates bought into conservative economic nonsense about the need for austerity.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Corbyn, a long-time leftist dissident, has won a stunning victory in the contest for leadership of Britain’s Labour Party. Political pundits say that this means doom for Labour’s electoral prospects; they could be right, although I’m not the only person wondering why commentators who completely failed to predict the Corbyn phenomenon have so much confidence in their analyses of what it means.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — SYRIA is being destroyed. The civil war, now more than four years old, has left the country in ruins. The implacable Islamic State controls vast areas of the north and east, and the barbaric regime of President Bashar al-Assad maintains its Damascus stronghold.

abstract: The building of Semiperm Housing, which serves single mothers and their children, allowed a developer to add 114,000 square feet to 15 Central Park West.
lead_paragraph: When she found herself on the subway on a sweltering August night two years ago, her two young children and their few belongings squeezed onto the hard plastic seats beside her, Nichelle Way had no idea where they were going. Her abusive ex-boyfriend had just thrown them out of his apartment, where they had been living for three months. When she called her family in York, Pa., they offered no help, only scolding.

headline: Jewish Man Dies as Rocks Pelt His Car in East Jerusalem

lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — A Jewish man died early Monday morning after attackers pelted the road he was driving on with rocks as he was returning home from a dinner celebrating Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year, the Israeli authorities said. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called an emergency meeting to discuss rock-throwing, mostly by Palestinian youths.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 14, 2015
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by commenting on what you see and why. A live discussion is offered that day from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Sept. 18, 2015

headline: Stephen Breyer’s ‘The Court and the World’
abstract: The Supreme Court justice argues that globalization has made engagement with foreign law and international affairs simply unavoidable.
lead_paragraph: In all the fanfare surrounding the Supreme Court’s end-of-term rulings this past June, a little-noticed passage in an opinion by Justice Stephen Breyer quietly revisited a debate that has roiled American law for nearly two decades. Dissenting on the final day of the term from a decision to uphold Oklahoma’s new lethal injection protocol, Breyer (joined by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg) observed that 137 countries — a full 70 percent of member states in the United Nations — have abolished the death penalty either formally or in practice. Breyer noted further that in 2013 the United States was one of only 22 countries in the world to carry out any executions at all.

headline: Wil Haygood’s ‘Showdown’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An account of Thurgood Marshall’s historic appointment to the Supreme Court — and the battle to confirm him.
lead_paragraph: Thurgood Marshall sits in Room 2228 of the New Senate Office Building on July 13, 1967, a month after Lyndon Johnson has named him to the United States Supreme Court. Facing him are, among others, four arch-segregationist Southerners on the Senate Judiciary Committee: John McClellan, Sam Ervin, Strom Thurmond and its chairman, James Eastland. Marshall is determined to become the first black man ever to sit on the nation’s highest court. The senators are equally determined to block him.

headline: ‘Sisters in Law’ Looks at Sandra Day O’Connor and Ruth Bader Ginsburg
abstract: Two justices broke through more than a few glass ceilings to sit together on the United States Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Two young women, near age-mates, grow up in very different corners of the country, one in near isolation on a vast Southwestern cattle ranch and the other on the crowded streets of Brooklyn. They obtain superb educations, enter into early marriage and motherhood, and set out to make their way in a man’s world. Decades later, we find them, having broken through more than a few glass ceilings, sitting together on the United States Supreme Court.

headline: Malcolm Turnbull Defeats Tony Abbott to Become Prime Minister of Australia
abstract: Mr. Turnbull is a moderate Liberal, whose views, most recently on the legitimacy of same-sex marriage, had conflicted with those of his prime minister.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Malcolm Turnbull, a former investment banker and lawyer, was sworn in as prime minister of Australia on Tuesday, after defeating Tony Abbott in a vote of Liberal Party lawmakers.

headline: Morning Agenda: Pitfalls on the Frontiers of Banking
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Insurance', 'Interest Rates', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The Fed’s Policy Mechanics Retool | Banks Settle in Suit Over Financial Crisis
lead_paragraph: PITFALLS ON THE FRONTIERS OF BANKING | Upstart online lenders have taken on big, lumbering banks with outdated branches and skittish risk departments. They have won plaudits for their low costs and straightforward terms. But now, they are starting to exhibit their own troubling traits, Michael Corkery reports in DealBook.

headline: What Comes After the Heimlich Maneuver
abstract: Dr. Henry Heimlich’s method helps thousands of choking victims a year, but sometimes it doesn’t work. Then it’s good to know what else can be done.
lead_paragraph: JoAnn Okin knew how to do the Heimlich maneuver. The 69-year-old resident of Kingston, N.Y., said she had used it successfully on other people who were choking. But she couldn’t save her husband, Stuart, when a piece of pastry lodged deep in his trachea last month. Neither could a bystander.

keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']

headline: Plants That Are Predators
abstract: Carnivorous plants like the Venus flytrap capture prey, and minds, with their deadly allure.
lead_paragraph: As a refined Victorian gentleman, Charles Darwin naturally gravitated toward the macabre, and few things fascinated him like those floral flouters of the conventional food chain: carnivorous plants. He experimented with them and wrote a major treatise about them. He called the Venus flytrap, with its elaborate hair-trigger snap trap and its lethal brew of digestive juices, “one of the most wonderful plants in the world.”

headline: For Older Adults, Questioning a Diagnosis of Chronic Kidney Disease

lead_paragraph: As if there were not enough visitors to Iowa these days, the first caucus state will host on Monday the one person who knows for a fact he won’t be living at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue come the end of January 2017.

headline: Marcus Mariota’s Strong N.F.L. Debut Answers the Skeptics
abstract: Mariota of the Titans had perhaps the greatest statistical performance by a rookie quarterback in his first game in N.F.L. history.
lead_paragraph: Marcus Mariota threw a 52-yard touchdown pass to Kendall Wright on Tennessee’s first drive of the season. On the team’s next drive, Mariota threw a short pass to running back Bishop Sankey for a 12-yard touchdown. Before the half ended, he threw two more touchdowns, one each to Harry Douglas and Delanie Walker. It was a record-setting day for Mariota, the number two overall selection in the 2015 N.F.L. Draft.

abstract: Officials in Yangshuo County have asked the central government in Beijing to designate the area around the Yulong River as a national park.
lead_paragraph: YANGSHUO, China — With both hands gripping a pole, Deng Hongyou rowed a bamboo raft carrying a couple and their 2-year-old daughter down the quiet Yulong River one morning. Hills of karst rock shaped like camel humps and blanketed with plants rose from the banks.

headline: Broncos Top Ravens on Bad Day for Offenses; Terrell Suggs Is Out
abstract: Peyton Manning and Joe Flacco’s teams combined for six field goals in Denver’s 19-13 victory on Sunday; the game’s two touchdowns came off interceptions.
lead_paragraph: The Denver Broncos are known for a high-powered offense that scored the most points in the American Football Conference last year. The Baltimore Ravens have been known for years for their stifling defense.

headline: 1940: Buckingham Palace Bombed
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Buckingham Palace is attacked by German air forces in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The belief that the German air attack on Buckingham Palace was a deliberate attempt on the lives of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth was great in force today as expressions of horror and disgust poured in from all over the empire. The rails and stone lamp pillars in front of the palace were hurled down when a time bomb dropped in a recent raid exploded this morning with terrific force, hurling debris over the forecourt and the memorial to Queen Victoria, and gouging a deep crater in the sidewalk. — New York Herald Tribune, September 15, 1940

headline: Turnbull on Ousting Abbott as Premier
abstract: Australia’s prime minister-elect, Malcolm Turnbull, spoke on Monday after Prime Minister Tony Abbott was ousted from power in an internal party ballot.

headline: Older Children More Likely to Be Injured in a Car, Less Likely to Have Car Seats Checked for Safety
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Child Car Seats', 'Parenting', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Infant and toddler car seats may seem harder to install, but seats for older children can have safety issues, too.
lead_paragraph: Booster seat-aged children — that is, children in forward-facing child seats, including those who use the car safety belt and those who have built-in harnesses — are twice as likely to suffer serious injury or death in a car crash than younger children, but a new study shows they may be less likely to have car seats inspected for safety. Researchers from the University of Michigan found that although only 1 in 10 of the car seat inspections performed free at inspection stations in Michigan covered booster seat-aged children, ages 4 to 7, 30 percent of those children were in what they called a “sub-optimal restraint.”

headline: Apple Says iPhone Pre-Orders Are Beating Last Year’s Pace
abstract: Global pre-orders for the company’s iPhone 6S and iPhone 6S Plus are on track to beat last year’s sales of 10 million new iPhones in the first weekend last year.
lead_paragraph: Apple said Monday that global pre-orders for its latest iPhones were on track to beat last year’s sales of 10 million devices in the first weekend, which was a record for the company.

headline: Carolina Herrera’s Rosy Outlook (and Makeup)
abstract: Models were as fresh — and pink — as the designer’s spring 2016 collection.
lead_paragraph: It’s Miss Herrera this season. That’s not to say clients above the age of, say, 30, were excluded from Carolina Herrera’s vision for her spring/summer 2016 collection, but the beauty looks created by the hairstylist Orlando Pita and the makeup artist Diane Kendal did convey a distinct air of youthfulness. “The clothes are very light and airy, and the colors of flowers, so hair is kinda young — infantile,” explained Pita backstage. The room behind him revealed several diaphanous gowns in variations of ballet pink; and rose sculptures and bouquets installed throughout the Frick Collection set the scene for the show.

headline: Newly Risen From Yeast: THC
abstract: By recreating constituents of marijuana, researchers hope to test its worth as a medicine.

Now comes the perhaps inevitable sequel: Scientists have created yeasts that can make important constituents of marijuana, including the main psychoactive compound, tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC.

headline: London Theater Journal: The Greeks All Over Again
abstract: Ben Brantley on two versions of “The Oresteia,” part of the current fashion for Greek tragedy on London and New York Stages.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – There’s more than one way to rebuild a haunted mansion. The House of Atreus, world literature’s most enduring home of horrors, is now receiving visitors on both sides of the Thames in this city, in different, retrofitted versions of Aeschylus’s “The Oresteia,” the revenge-driven trilogy in which the bloody lair for a damned family figures so oppressively.

abstract: Appreciation for the simple, classic form has come full circle.

headline: U.S. Attorney General Predicts More Charges in FIFA Case
abstract: Appearing with the Swiss attorney general in Zurich, U.S. Attorney General Loretta Lynch spoke of an expanded investigation and the “next round” of arrests.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch said Monday that the United States’ crackdown on corruption in global soccer was expanding, with new charges expected in the coming months.

headline: ‘I Am Cait’ Season 1 Finale Recap: The Show Tried. It Really Did.
abstract: Just because “I Am Cait” was necessary doesn’t mean it was good.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 8: “A New Beginning”

headline: Traces of Themselves
abstract: As a number of migrants use the Balkans as a route to pursue a better life in Europe, one photographer captures what many leave behind.
lead_paragraph: As a number of migrants use the Balkans as a route to pursue a better life in Europe, one photographer captures what many leave behind.

headline: The Luxury Industry Embraces Virtual Reality
abstract: Within the worlds of high-end cosmetics, cars and travel, a revenge of the nerds.
lead_paragraph: Once solely the obsession of gamers and tech geeks, virtual reality has found sexy new bedfellows in the worlds of high-end cosmetics, cars and air travel. Dior Eyes, an in-the-works VR device with hi-def video and immersive surround sound, will take prospective consumers on a trip backstage at one of the house’s runway shows. From the outside, the wraparound goggles evoke Darth Vader; from within, the wearer finds herself amid the fizzy whirl of makeup artists, photographers and models in various states of undress — all the while being seduced into buying beauty products. Similarly, Lexus has a new device that sends you careening down Spain’s mega-exclusive Ascari race track in a Lexus RC F, and on certain Qantas flights, first-class passengers can go snorkeling in the Great Barrier Reef from 40,000 feet.

headline: 1965: Planning for the Apollo Mission
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Apollo program is more than half finished in 1965.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Today in the Athens Hilton Hotel where the 16th International Astronautical Congress is meeting, Wernher von Braun, director of the Marshall Space Flight Center at Huntsville, Ala., said the U.S. Apollo program was more than 50 percent completed and should achieve its goal of landing a man on the moon before 1970. Mr. Braun said three men would go to the moon in the Apollo spacecraft, consisting of a command module, a service module, a lunar excursion module and a launch escape system. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 15, 1965

headline: The Artistry in Jill Bialosky’s Pastry Brush
abstract: The utensil completes the picture of the writer’s ideal kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Jill Bialosky’s kitchen was immaculate, but still she could not find her little wooden pastry brush.

headline: The Daily Do: Edun
abstract: Models wore their hair in low ponytails, buns and loose waves.
lead_paragraph: Natural beauty has appeared at several shows this week — in the form of natural faces and un-fussed-with hair. Edun’s show yesterday continued that trend: Models wore their faces bare and many had elegant updos. There were low, half-up styles (tied in the back as a bun) and simple ponytails. A few models even wore their hair in natural waves. The effect played up the movement of the collection (which featured fringe and flowing silhouettes) — and yet felt completely laid back.

headline: Lynch Says More Soccer Arrests Expected
abstract: Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch, speaking in Zurich on Monday, said that she anticipated pursuing additional charges in the continuing investigation into corruption in international soccer.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch, speaking in Zurich on Monday, said that she anticipated pursuing additional charges in the continuing investigation into corruption in international soccer.

headline: Facts & Figures: 43 Percent of Republicans Think Obama Is Muslim
abstract: And 20 percent of Americans believe he was born outside the country.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-nine percent of Americans and 43 percent of Republicans believe President Obama is a Muslim, according to a CNN/ORC poll released on Sunday. And 20 percent of Americans think he was born outside the United States.

headline: Study Finds Snowpack in California’s Sierra Nevada to Be Lowest in 500 Years
abstract: The report suggests droughts in the state may become more common as precipitation on the Sierra Nevada Mountains reduces because of global warming.
lead_paragraph: The snow that blanketed the Sierra Nevada in California last winter, and that was supposed to serve as an essential source of fresh water for the drought-stricken state, was at its lowest levels in the last 500 years, according to a new study.

headline: Visually Arresting New Tables, Mirrors and Lamps
abstract: Complex geometry makes these five pieces look good from every angle.
lead_paragraph: Complex geometry makes these five pieces look good from every angle.

headline: Matt Enlow’s Bag-Stuffing Problem
abstract: How many ways can you put nine bags into a 10th bag? Try this pattern-finding challenge.
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle is an original suggested by Matt Enlow, a math teacher at the Dana Hall School in Wellesley, Mass. We’ve seen Matt before — he’s the brain behind Marking the Ruler and Dividing a Rectangle. As with his previous challenges, this week’s is a bit more challenging than it seems at first. Let’s try —

headline: Athens Democracy Forum
abstract: The forum, which includes the Op-Ed columnists Paul Krugman and Roger Cohen, explores the state of liberal democracy around the world.
lead_paragraph: The Athens Democracy Forum (September 13-15) explores the state of liberal democracy across the world. The event features diplomats, scholars, corporate executives, politicians and intellectuals from around the world. Contributors include the Op-Ed columnists, Paul Krugman (Tuesday at 10:15 AM and 7:30 PM, local time) and Roger Cohen (Tuesday at 12:15 PM and 7:30 PM), and the contributing op-ed writer Nikos Konstandaras (Monday, 12:45 PM).

headline: Ceres’s Bright Spots of Mystery
abstract: New images captured by NASA’s Dawn spacecraft were the best view to date of bright spots on the dwarf planet — though nobody yet knows what they are.
lead_paragraph: New images captured by NASA’s Dawn spacecraft provide the best view to date of bright spots on the dwarf planet Ceres — though nobody yet knows what they are. Ceres is thought to hold water beneath its surface. The bright spots, spangled across the bottom of the Occator crater, may be ice formed by water leaking from below, or perhaps salt left after the water evaporated. Mission scientists also produced a 3-D topographic map of the crater, finding that in places, the rim rises almost vertically for one mile.

headline: Condé Nast Names Robert Sauerberg New C.E.O.
abstract: The publishing company also said Charles Townsend would become chairman of Condé Nast U.S. and said S.I. Newhouse Jr. would become chairman emeritus.
lead_paragraph: Condé Nast announced an executive shake-up Monday, appointing its president, Robert A. Sauerberg Jr., as its chief executive, and moving Charles H. Townsend from C.E.O. to chairman of Condé Nast U.S.

headline: Dear Parent: If Your Child Left It Home, Don’t Bring It In
abstract: One school’s policy: no drop offs of forgotten items. “Please plan accordingly.”
lead_paragraph: A school in Seminole County, Fla., has a rule, clearly posted in the front office: “Attention students and parents: We do not accept items for dropoff such as lunches, backpacks, homework, sports equipment. Please plan accordingly.”

headline: Glencore Model Is Battered, but Not Broken
abstract: Ivan Glasenberg’s mining creation has been hit by a slump in commodity prices. But the company’s mix of trading and mining is logical and robust.
lead_paragraph: Glencore’s chief executive, Ivan Glasenberg, has been wrong-footed. His reputation has taken a hit by the slump in minerals prices and China’s slowing appetite for commodities. Most painfully, he has had to adjust to shareholder worries about debt. Yet he was — and is — right to insist that Glencore’s unusual mix of mining with trading makes sense.

headline: Djokovic Comments on His U.S. Open Win
abstract: The winner of the men’s competition at the 2015 U.S. Open, Novak Djokovic of Serbia, posed in New York with his trophy on Monday and said winning it felt “amazing.”
lead_paragraph: The winner of the men’s competition at the 2015 U.S. Open, Novak Djokovic of Serbia, posed in New York with his trophy on Monday and said winning it felt “amazing.”

headline: Egyptian Military Fires on Mexican Tourists During Picnic
abstract: The attack in broad daylight by a helicopter raised new questions about the competence of security forces and the prevalence of the militants they were hunting.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The convoy of four sport utility vehicles full of Mexican tourists was about three hours southwest of Cairo on a typical adventure trip through the White Desert, an otherworldly landscape of monumental chalk-rock formations. Around midday on Sunday, a diabetic passenger complained that she needed to eat.

headline: A First Look at Design Miami’s 2015 Entry Pavilion
abstract: Designed by students, this year’s structure brings to the spotlight the poetry, and importance, of unrealized works.
lead_paragraph: As designers know all too well, for every finished project — what gets walked down a runway or stocked on a shelf — there are dozens, if not hundreds, of unrealized ideas that never make it out of the studio. This work, often frustrating and messy, is so central to the design process, yet so often goes unseen — until this December, when it will be presented front and center at Design Miami’s entry pavilion.

headline: George Zimmer Takes On Men’s Wearhouse With Tuxedo Start-Up
abstract: With his foray into the tuxedo rental business, Mr. Zimmer is competing directly with the company he founded that later ousted him.
lead_paragraph: Last year, George Zimmer was ousted from Men’s Wearhouse, the company he founded. His latest start-up, an online tailoring platform, is not doing so well. But now, Mr. Zimmer is sure he has a winner.

headline: Noma’s Former Pastry Chef Is on a Taco Mission
abstract: Rosio Sanchez, who grew up as the daughter of Mexican immigrants in Chicago, slings Mexican street food in Copenhagen.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — Rosio Sanchez gets a lot of questions as she cranks out tortillas by hand here in the heart of the Torvehallerne market. Danes, it seems, aren’t exactly up to speed on the whole concept of tacos.

headline: René Redzepi Plans to Close Noma and Reopen It as an Urban Farm
abstract: The culinary pioneer in Copenhagen plans to reopen his restaurant in 2017 as part of a move to position the farm next to the table.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — “Welcome to the new Noma,” the chef René Redzepi said on a bright summer day. “This is it.”

headline: Review: In ‘The Bastard Executioner,’ a Warrior Switches Blades
abstract: Lee Jones stars in this new FX saga of vengeance and gruesome deaths in 14th-century Wales.
lead_paragraph: A sampling of prominent images in the first three hours of “The Bastard Executioner”: a spear slowly penetrating a throat; a dagger entering the back of a head and exiting, dripping, through the mouth; a finger with its nail pulled off; a disemboweled woman; a severed nose, and the severing thereof; a bird feasting on a corpse’s innards; sundry slit throats; a soiled chamber pot rag.

headline: Joyce Mitchell, Who Helped Prisoners Escape, Says She Was Driven by Fear and Depression
abstract: Ms. Mitchell, in a TV interview with Matt Lauer, apologized for her role in a breakout at a maximum-security unit in northern New York.
lead_paragraph: Joyce E. Mitchell, a former prison employee who is set to be sentenced this month for helping two killers escape from a unit in northern New York, has given a national television interview in which she apologizes for her actions but asks for understanding, saying she was driven by depression and fear that the men would hurt her family.

headline: 3 Major California Wildfires Remain Largely Out of Control
keywords: ['Wildfires', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: Despite the efforts of 8,800 firefighters, the fires have consumed 270,000 acres, forcing thousands to flee and killing at least one, state officials said.
lead_paragraph: CALISTOGA, Calif. — Despite the efforts of 8,800 firefighters, three major blazes whipping through California’s tinder-dry forests and brush had consumed a combined 270,000 acres and remained largely out of control, state officials said on Monday, forcing thousands of people to flee and destroying up to 1,000 buildings.

lead_paragraph: The Justice Department wants the message to go out that federal prosecutors will be taking aim at executives over their role in corporate misconduct by issuing a new policy that requires companies to identify every wrongdoer within the organization, regardless of rank, or be considered uncooperative.

lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has sold the Miss Universe Organization to the talent agency WME-IMG, the company announced on Monday.

headline: New Leader Turns British Labour Party to the Left
abstract: Jeremy Corbyn gave the economic portfolio to John McDonnell, an ideological soul mate, but also allocated senior positions to more centrist figures.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After three decades on the far-left fringes of British politics, the new leader of the Labour Party in Britain, Jeremy Corbyn, confronted several unfamiliar problems on Monday, including whether to give top jobs to internal opponents and whether to kiss the hand of Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: Scott Walker Details Plan to Curb the Power of Labor Unions
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is calling for anti-union measures that, if carried out, would greatly reduce the influence of organized labor in public and private workplaces.
lead_paragraph: Returning to his political roots as his campaign struggles, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin called on Monday for anti-union measures that, if carried out, would greatly reduce the influence of organized labor in public and private workplaces.

headline: Measles Outbreak in Democratic Republic of Congo Kills 400
abstract: More than 23,000 people, mostly children, have been infected with the disease in the Katanga region of the country.
lead_paragraph: More than 23,000 people, mostly children, have been infected with measles in the Katanga region of the Democratic Republic of Congo. More than 400 have died, according to United Nations agencies and Doctors Without Borders.

headline: N.B.A. Stars Carry Their Countries’ Hopes at EuroBasket 2015
abstract: Spain, led by Pau Gasol, will meet Greece on Tuesday; France will play Latvia. On Wednesday, Serbia plays the Czech Republic, and Italy meets Lithuania.
lead_paragraph: It is only September, but for some N.B.A. players, the meaningful games have already begun. A lot is at stake in the EuroBasket tournament in Lille, France, as the two finalists will qualify for the 12-team field in the Olympics.

headline: The Cool Kids of Eckhaus Latta’s Spring Show
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2015)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: The designers Mike Eckhaus and Zoe Latta share Polaroids from their casting exclusively with T.
lead_paragraph: Zoe Latta and Mike Eckhaus, the designers behind Eckhaus Latta, have been known to stage unconventional runway shows. (Last season, for example, their show featured a model knocking down a sheetrock wall with a hammer.) For their spring/summer 2016 collection, which shows today, they have enlisted several friends and nonmodels to walk alongside professional faces. The designers shot Polaroids at their casting last week and shared the images exclusively with T. From Grace Dunham to the artist Bjarne Melgaard, click through the slideshow to see the faces of today’s Eckhaus Latta show.

headline: Celebrity-Filled Show to Precede Pope Francis’ Mass at Madison Square Garden
abstract: The archdiocese announced that the pope’s Mass next week would be preceded by prayer and music, with performances by Harry Connick Jr., Gloria Estefan, Jennifer Hudson and others.
lead_paragraph: To persuade the thousands of Roman Catholics who will attend Pope Francis’ Mass at Madison Square Garden next week to arrive early, the Archdiocese of New York announced on Monday that the Mass would be preceded by a two-hour show with prayer and devotional music performed by stars including Harry Connick Jr., Gloria Estefan and Jennifer Hudson.

headline: Wall Street Banks Reach Deal With Regulators on Data Retention
abstract: Deutsche Bank, Goldman Sachs, Credit Suisse and Bank of New York Mellon will keep communications that could be used to track evidence of rigging schemes among traders.
lead_paragraph: Four of Wall Street’s biggest banks on Monday agreed to cooperate with New York regulators and retain copies of communications sent through the messaging platform known as Symphony.

headline: Injuries to Two Jets Are Not as Devastating as First Feared
abstract: The rookie linebacker Lorenzo Mauldin, injured on a play that involved a sack, sustained a concussion and not a neck injury. Cornerback Antonio Cromartie sustained a sprained left knee, not a torn anterior cruciate ligament.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — One day after the Jets’ 31-10 rout of the Cleveland Browns at MetLife Stadium had been dampened by injuries to the rookie linebacker Lorenzo Mauldin and cornerback Antonio Cromartie, the team’s overriding emotion was relief after it received encouraging news about both players.

headline: A Report Card the Doctor Doesn’t Want to Take Home
abstract: Continuous quality improvement grades leave one physician wondering whether, in the absence of context, they can gauge success and failure.
lead_paragraph: I got my report card the other week, and I must say I didn’t do very well. I’m pulling around a B, better than average but not by much. My parents would be appalled.

headline: Dine Like Plato, Try Buffalo Jerky, Celebrate Mexican Independence
abstract: An Ancient Greek cooking class to learn what may have been on Plato’s table.
lead_paragraph: For an idea of what may have been on Plato’s table, Maria Benardis, the owner of a food company called Greekalicious, is teaching about the foods of ancient Greece in sessions that include dinner. Among the dishes will be barley and pomegranate salad with herbs and walnuts, and lamb Myma-style with a feta crust. Ms. Benardis incorporates some New World items like quinoa and chocolate into her recipes to show students how to use modern foods in the dishes: Ancient Greek class, $130, Sept. 23 from 6:30 to 9 p.m. at Coco-Mat, 49 Mercer Street (Broome Street); ancient Greek dinner and demonstration, $140, Sept. 29 from 6:30 to 9 p.m. at Natural Gourmet Institute, 48 West 21st Street; greekalicious.com.au.

headline: Bernie Sanders Makes Rare Appeal to Evangelicals at Liberty University
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders, in a speech at Liberty University, an evangelical Christian college, repeatedly sought to build what he called “common ground” with students, beginning with the foundations of Christianity itself: the Bible.
lead_paragraph: LYNCHBURG, Va. – Senator Bernie Sanders took his message of confronting inequality to unfamiliar ground on Monday at Liberty University, a leading evangelical Christian college, where he sought to build what he called “common ground” with students, beginning with the foundations of Christianity itself: the Bible.

abstract: Kathleen Turner will direct and act in the Off Broadway play “Would You Still Love Me If … “
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Turner will both direct and act in a new transgender-themed Off Broadway play after the show’s director and one of its stars left the production.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:55 A.M. (Encore) SAVING MR. BANKS (2013) Tom Hanks stars as Walt Disney in this Disney movie directed by John Lee Hancock about the making of “Mary Poppins,” which at the time of its creation in the early 1960s was the most expensive live-action film the studio had produced. It eventually became one of the most beloved, too, and one of the biggest moneymakers. Emma Thompson is the author P. L. Travers, who conjured the magical nanny and is something of a crank. “I won’t have her turned into one of your silly cartoons,” she says of her creation, lips pursed. There’s a back story, too, in which Travers is a little girl (Annie Rose Buckley) in a dusty Australian town, where her hopelessly alcoholic father (Colin Farrell) can barely hold on to his bank job. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this movie “part of the Disney brand, of course: fun for everyone, with a spoonful of therapeutic medicine to help the sugar seem nutritious.” (Image: From left, Lily Bigham, Ms. Buckley, Ruth Wilson and Mr. Farrell.)

headline: $30 Million Settlement in Insider Trading Ring Linked to Hacking
abstract: Jaspen Capital Partners and its chief settled S.E.C. claims that they illegally profited from corporate information stolen from newswire services.

headline: Do Humans Have a Future in Deep Sea Exploration?
keywords: ['Oceans and Seas', 'Submarines and Submersibles', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Shipwrecks (Historic)']
abstract: A government laboratory in Hawaii has made important deep-sea discoveries with piloted submersibles. But dwindling budgets and increased use of robots threaten to close the operation.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — Entering the Hawaii Undersea Research Laboratory hangar is akin to stepping onto the set of a Spielberg film. The dull metal shell, perched on the Makai pier along the Windward Coast of Oahu, is nondescript, but the inside bristles with Zodiac boats and a dizzying assortment of hoists and tools, and the walls are festooned with 30 years of snapshots. At the center of it all, two 20-foot-long Pisces submarines sit atop skids like alien spacecraft, their robotic arms outstretched, beckoning for another mission.

headline: Stripe Introduces New Tools to Simplify Mobile Shopping
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'E-Commerce', 'Mobile Applications', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Social Media', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Stripe unveils new software tools that will let retailers more easily sell goods across apps and social networks, such as from inside Twitter messages.
lead_paragraph: Since the early days of the dot-com era, people have been buying more stuff — from pet food to diapers — on the Internet. The process was straightforward: Fire up your web browser, fill out your shipping and payment information, and receive your products in a week or two.

headline: Model-Morphosis: Vanessa Moody at Public School

headline: North Korea Plans Rocket Launch That Could Lead to Missile
keywords: ['Satellites', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States International Relations', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: The launch is officially to put a new weather satellite in orbit, but the United States and allies see the rocket as a nascent intercontinental ballistic missile.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea indicated on Monday that it was preparing to put a new satellite into orbit using a rocket that is widely seen as an intercontinental ballistic missile in the making.

headline: Russian Authorities Rule Google Broke Antitrust Regulations
abstract: Officials said that the company had abused its dominant market position with Android, its mobile operating system, by favoring the company’s own own services over those of its rivals.
lead_paragraph: Russian antitrust authorities ruled on Monday that Google broke the country’s competition rules, adding to the regulatory headaches the search giant is facing worldwide.

headline: Pope’s Visit Poses a Security Test for New York
abstract: Several dozen agencies are increasing personnel and organizing strategies for the visit of Pope Francis, who plans to connect with people on the street directly.
lead_paragraph: For hours on Monday morning, scores of law enforcement officials, police commanders and representatives from at least 48 agencies sat in a room on the second floor of Police Headquarters in Lower Manhattan and imagined the worst.

headline: When Did Jeb Bush Become the Smarter Brother?
abstract: Experts on the Bush family say it’s an old idea, but it may not be correct.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush’s presidential campaign has brought with it a resurgence of the idea that he’s the smarter of the two political Bush brothers. Experts on the Bush family say it’s an old idea, but it may not be correct.

headline: Algerian President Fires Intelligence Chief in a Shake-Up of Security Forces
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The ousted official, Mohamed Mediene, better known as Toufik, was a powerful figure who headed the intelligence service for 25 years.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — In a move that has surprised and enthralled many Algerians, the ailing President Abdelaziz Bouteflika has replaced his powerful intelligence chief in a shake-up of the security forces.

headline: In Bushwick, a Live-In Gallery That’s an Art Bellwether
abstract: Signal’s solo-show-focused program is largely driven by instinct — and has attracted the attention of larger galleries that draft from its roster.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, real estate dictated fate for friends Kyle Clairmont Jacques, 27, and Alexander Johns, 28, when a search for an affordable joint studio turned into the opening of Signal — an independently minded art gallery in Bushwick, Brooklyn. “Four or five years ago, everything around here felt slapdash. Sometime during our search for a space, it became very clear that we could present things in this area at a level that was more professional and respectful,” says Clairmont Jacques, an artist-turned-designer who has recently added gallerist to his résumé. “There was nowhere showing art that fit in with the mature contemporary discourse that was happening elsewhere in the city.” Opportunity came in the form of a vaulted industrial space that had been previously used for rug storage, and the duo seized the moment — transforming the warehouse into a live-in gallery space with a coat of white paint and elbow grease.

headline: Hispanics in Congress Ask Treasury to Prevent ‘Catastrophe’ in Puerto Rico
abstract: Eight Hispanic lawmakers urged Secretary Jacob J. Lew to intervene on behalf of the financially struggling island as his predecessors helped automakers.
lead_paragraph: A group of Hispanic members of Congress called on the Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, to take a more muscular role in Puerto Rico’s debt crisis and prevent what they said could become “an economic catastrophe” on the island.

headline: 732,000: American Lives Saved by Vaccination
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Children and Childhood', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Hepatitis', 'Whooping Cough', 'Tetanus', 'Mumps', 'Measles', 'German Measles (Rubella)', 'Rotaviruses']
abstract: A federal agency estimates that the vaccination of children from 1994 to 2013 will prevent hundreds of thousands of early deaths.
lead_paragraph: The vaccination of children from 1994 to 2013 will prevent 732,000 early deaths in the United States, according to a recent estimate by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Hillary Clinton Vows to Confront Sex Assault Issue on Campuses
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged to take extra steps to end sexual assaults on college campuses, saying during a trip to Iowa that she would try to “ensure a fair process” in such cases and increase support for victims.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged on Monday to take extra steps to end sexual assaults on college campuses, saying during a trip to Iowa that she would try to “ensure a fair process” in such cases and increase support for victims.

headline: In a First, Aspirin Is Recommended to Fight a Form of Cancer
abstract: An expert panel backed the drug to help prevent heart attacks and colorectal cancer. Some critics say there are better and safer preventives.
lead_paragraph: For years, doctors have recommended daily aspirin to lower cardiovascular risk in certain men and women. Now, for the first time, an expert panel is recommending aspirin therapy to prevent heart attacks and colorectal cancer.

headline: A Vinyl LP Frenzy
abstract: Six decades-old presses are being refurbished at a plant in New Jersey to meet the exploding demand for vinyl records.
lead_paragraph: Six decades-old presses are being refurbished at a plant in New Jersey to meet the exploding demand for vinyl records.

headline: The Rocky Revival of Vinyl Records
abstract: The owners of Independent Record Pressing expect to churn out up to 1.5 million records a year. Their challenge won’t be finding business, it will be keeping the antiquated machinery running.
lead_paragraph: The owners of Independent Record Pressing expect to churn out up to 1.5 million records a year. Their challenge won’t be finding business, it will be keeping the antiquated machinery running.

headline: ‘Hedwig’ Broadway Run Closes on a Box-Office Upswing
abstract: “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” grossed over $625,000 in its 76th and final week on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Fans of “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” gave the show a nice box-office bump in its final week, boosting its grosses as the show ended a 76-week run on Broadway and prepared to start a tour in San Francisco.

headline: Listening to the Book Review
abstract: Inside The New York Times Book Review is the paper’s oldest and most popular podcast. Book Review Editor Pamela Paul writes about the weekly show.
lead_paragraph: Inside The New York Times Book Review is the oldest and most popular podcast at The New York Times. The debut episode “aired” on April 30, 2006, (first guest: Gary Shteyngart) and the show has been recorded weekly ever since.

headline: California’s Gavin Newsom Chides Donald Trump on Immigration Plan (and Comb-Over)
abstract: Gavin Newsom, the lieutenant governor of California who is planning to run for governor in 2018, released an online ad that criticizes Donald J. Trump’s proposals on immigration and mocks his hair.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is getting a chilly welcome to California from Gavin Newsom, the state’s lieutenant governor.

headline: Vinyl LP Frenzy Brings Record-Pressing Machines Back to Life
abstract: Old presses are being restored and put to work making vinyl records, still a niche product but much in demand from younger music enthusiasts.
lead_paragraph: BORDENTOWN, N.J. — The machines at Independent Record Pressing whirred and hissed as they stamped out a test record. The business’s owners waited anxiously for Dave Miller, the plant manager, to inspect the still-warm slab of vinyl.

headline: A Sense of Instability Settles Over Turkey as Conflict With Kurds Flares
abstract: Economic and political instability are deepening before a snap election scheduled for November.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Nationalist and pro-government throngs filled the streets of Istanbul and Ankara for two nights last week, chanting “God is great” as they stormed a prominent newspaper and set fire to the offices of a Kurdish political party.

headline: Review: In ‘Pas de Detour,’ Cornfield Dance Plays With Obstacles
abstract: A new work by Ellen Cornfield made its debut at University Settlement on Friday, with a standout performance by Cori Kresge.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Cornfield has been choreographing since at least 1982, when she left Merce Cunningham’s company. The 25th anniversary of her own troupe, Cornfield Dance, came and went last year without much fanfare. What inspires her to keep making works? One answer can surely be found in the dancers she is able to recruit.

headline: Review: Sonia Olla Flamenco Company, Passionately Blending Cultures
abstract: The troupe’s program at the Theater at the 14th Street Y featured Arooj Aftab, Ismael Fernández, Nino de los Reyes and Ms. Olla herself.
lead_paragraph: It’s all too easy for a flamenco dance troupe that believes in tradition but wishes to explore new directions to go astray. There was a moment in “Por los Caminos,” a program presented at the Theater at the 14th Street Y over the weekend, when the Sonia Olla Flamenco Dance Company, performing in front of projected images of paths through dark woods, seemed on the verge of getting lost. But this troupe knows its way home.

headline: Review: In ‘Takehisa Kosugi: Music Expanded,’ Violinist Uses More Than Strings and a Bow
abstract: Mr. Kosugi was joined by two collaborators, Kiyoshi Izumi and Ken Hamazaki, in a survey of works that spanned five decades and often employed everyday objects.
lead_paragraph: For the final piece of his performance on Sunday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Takehisa Kosugi picked up a bow and an electric violin and proceeded to play. It was the last thing I expected him to do at that point, the end of the museum’s two-day retrospective of his work, “Takehisa Kosugi: Music Expanded.” His biography may identify him as a composer, violinist and improviser, but during the weekend’s two shows he had mostly used everyday objects: bicycle spokes, for instance, an inflatable ball, a sheet of paper, or a bag of Japanese soup mix. Some of his compositions unfolded in almost complete silence.

headline: Turtle Maternity Ward
abstract: The Ostional Wildlife Refuge in Costa Rica is a crucial nesting site for the olive ridley turtle.
lead_paragraph: The Ostional Wildlife Refuge in Costa Rica is a crucial nesting site for the olive ridley turtle.

headline: Brandy Clark and Shane McAnally on ‘Moonshine: That Hee Haw Musical’
abstract: The show is an extension of the long working relationship that has made them two of the most in-demand and disruptive songwriters in country music.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Brandy Clark and Shane McAnally sat across from each other at one end of a long conference table in a long conference room on a high-up floor at the Wyly Theater here. It was an early September morning, and they were tired.

headline: Review: In ‘Photograph 51,’ Nicole Kidman Is a Steely DNA Scientist
abstract: Playing Rosalind Franklin, a lone woman among male researchers in London, Ms. Kidman projects relentless determination.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Nicole Kidman steps out of the shadows, breaking off from a wall of men, and onto the edge of the stage at the Noël Coward Theater, where Anna Ziegler’s “Photograph 51” opened here on Monday night, her eyes beam undiluted willpower. It is a gaze that both chills and warms, radiating and demanding trust in this singularly self-possessed presence. Ms. Kidman makes it clear that she is in charge here, and woe unto those of us who doubt it.

headline: Chelsea Clinton’s ‘It’s Your World’

lead_paragraph: One of the most striking moments in Hillary Clinton’s newly released State Department emails was not something written by Hillary but by her daughter, Chelsea, who had just returned from a fact-gathering trip to post-earthquake Haiti. The email starts:

headline: Review: ‘Once in a Great City’ Chronicles Detroit’s Glory Days
abstract: David Maraniss’s latest book looks back wistfully to Detroit’s heyday in the 1960s, when Motown was rocking and the city was full of promise.
lead_paragraph: Detroit in the early 1960s was a symbol not of urban decline and Rust Belt blight, but of high hopes and youthful dreams. Coveted cars didn’t have model numbers then but names that spoke of flight and fantasy and raw animal power — the Ford Galaxie, Thunderbird and Mustang, the Plymouth Barracuda, the Chevrolet Impala — and they were rolling off the Detroit assembly lines at a record pace. The country was dancing to the beat of Motown’s irresistible pop-soul groove, and with hit after hit by Stevie Wonder, Smokey Robinson, Marvin Gaye, the Temptations and the Four Tops rolling off his assembly line, Berry Gordy would proudly proclaim Motown “the sound of young America.”

headline: Debating Style, Courtesy of Jeremy Scott and Carolina Herrera
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2015)']
abstract: Diane von Furstenberg, Tommy Hilfiger and Prabal Gurung also state their case.
lead_paragraph: Is Jeremy Scott the Donald Trump of American fashion? Not in terms of politics — definitely not in terms of politics — but in terms of positioning? Mr. Scott, after all, is an oft-dismissed polarizing outsider who built his brand beyond the system by mocking fashion’s orthodoxies. He has been categorized as an entertainer and a disrupter, with emphasis on show rather than substance. Yet his approach — Instagram-ready, direct to pop culture consumers — has resulted in a documentary “The People’s Designer”; a stint redesigning the Video Music Awards Moonman statuette, and a second job as creative director of the global brand Moschino. Plus, this week: Mr. Scott’s largest show to date, in front of the singer Rita Ora and the actress Lucy Hale and a chunk of the cast of the TV show “Empire,” including Bryshere Gray.

abstract: While most experts don’t expect that an increase in interest rates will lead to 2008-style instability, tighter monetary policy could expose frailties in the financial system.
lead_paragraph: The moment that Wall Street has long been dreading could happen this week.

headline: These Public Libraries Are for Snowshoes and Ukuleles
abstract: Libraries from Maine to California are recasting themselves as hands-on creative hubs where people can learn crafts and experiment with technology like 3-D printers.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Libraries aren’t just for books, or even e-books, anymore. They are for checking out cake pans (North Haven, Conn.), snowshoes (Biddeford, Me.), telescopes and microscopes (Ann Arbor, Mich.), American Girl dolls (Lewiston, Me.), fishing rods (Grand Rapids, Minn.), Frisbees and Wiffle balls (Mesa, Ariz.) and mobile hot spot devices (New York and Chicago).

headline: Bridge to Connect Upper Manhattan to Nearby, Yet Remote, Riverside Park
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Building (Construction)']
abstract: A $24 million pedestrian bridge will link Hamilton Heights and the northern stretch of the park, currently separated by train tracks and the West Side Highway.
lead_paragraph: The northern stretch of Riverside Park has long been an attraction for residents of Hamilton Heights. But getting to it is not easy.

headline: Autoworkers Go to Fiat Chrysler for First Talks
abstract: The United Automobile Workers is starting with Fiat Chrysler, the least profitable of the three automakers and the one with the most younger workers.
lead_paragraph: Contract talks continued on Tuesday between the United Automobile Workers union and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, which was selected by the union to be the first among Detroit’s three carmakers to negotiate a new national labor agreement.

headline: On the Instagram Presidential Campaign Trail
abstract: Presidential candidates are using Instagram to shape their image and communicate with voters with varying success. A look at their feeds reveals some of their strategies — or lack thereof.
lead_paragraph: Presidential candidates are using Instagram to shape their image and communicate with voters with varying success. A look at their feeds reveals some of their strategies — or lack thereof.

headline: Numbers of Migrants and Unrest Prompted Germany’s Border Controls
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Although not unprecedented, the step dealt a blow to European pride in freedom of movement — and signaled that Germany’s patience was spent.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After a full week of record arrivals, Munich appeared dangerously close on Saturday to missing its pledge to provide a bed for every migrant heading its way. The police appealed to the public for donations of blankets and camping mattresses. Cookies and water would be welcome, too.

headline: Stanford Business School Dean to Resign Over a Lawsuit
abstract: Garth Saloner said he did not want “a baseless and protracted lawsuit related to a contentious divorce” to hurt the school’s reputation.
lead_paragraph: Garth Saloner, the dean of the Stanford Graduate School of Business, announced his resignation on Monday, saying he did not want “a baseless and protracted lawsuit related to a contentious divorce” to hurt the school’s reputation. The divorce involves two Stanford professors. Mr. Saloner began a relationship with the wife shortly after the couple separated, Stanford acknowledged on Monday. The husband is suing the university, saying he was discriminated against. Stanford said he was treated “fairly and equitably.” Mr. Saloner, who has been dean since 2009, told the Stanford community he had become “increasingly concerned that the ongoing litigation and growing media interest will distract all of you.” After Mr. Saloner steps down at the end of the current academic year, he will return to teaching. He did not respond to a request for an interview. U.S. News & World Report rated Stanford’s business school the best in the nation last spring.

headline: Sri Lanka Lays Out Plan for Reconciliation
abstract: The country’s foreign minister announced the new government’s plan to set up a truth, justice and reconciliation commission and to draft a new constitution.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Sri Lanka’s new government said Monday that it would set up a truth, justice and reconciliation commission and draft a new constitution to stabilize the country and address the bitter grievances left by its decades-long civil war.

headline: Critiquing Republican Field, Obama Dodges Names
abstract: Speaking at a high school in Des Moines, Mr. Obama was asked to weigh in about the candidates in the current race and started to beg off. But didn’t.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — He may not be a candidate anymore, but President Obama could not help wading a bit into the high-octane campaign to succeed him on Monday, urging the state that holds the nation’s first caucuses to vote against candidates who rail against teachers or fail to support adequate federal financing for public education.

headline: Martin O’Malley Calls for Reduction in Availability of Guns
abstract: At a round table in New York, Mr. O’Malley described a spate of shooting deaths as “not isolated incidents — they’re part of a full-blown sickness” in the country.
lead_paragraph: Martin O’Malley took his presidential campaign to Manhattan on Monday, holding a round-table conversation with women who lost relatives to gun violence.

headline: Sheldon Silver, Former Assembly Speaker, Helped Developer Block Methadone Clinic’s Relocation, U.S. Says
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Relocation of Business', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Court filings say Mr. Silver profited by leading the defeat of a proposed methadone clinic in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: When a methadone clinic sought to relocate to Manhattan’s financial district in 2011, parents, local business owners and others rallied in opposition. Perhaps the most prominent opponent was Sheldon Silver, then the powerful speaker of the State Assembly who represented that neighborhood.

headline: 5 From Baruch College Face Murder Charges in 2013 Fraternity Hazing

abstract: A grand jury in Monroe County, Pa., recently recommended that 37 students and their fraternity, Pi Delta Psi, face a range of criminal charges in the death of Chun Hsien Deng at a 2013 retreat.
lead_paragraph: Five fraternity members from Baruch College in Manhattan will face murder charges in Pennsylvania for their involvement in the death of a freshman who was hazed during a rural retreat in 2013, officials said on Monday.

lead_paragraph: In February 2007, Stephanie Lenz, a mother in Gallitzin, Pa., went on YouTube and uploaded a 29-second video of her toddler dancing while Prince’s song “Let’s Go Crazy” played in the background.

lead_paragraph: The sellout crowd in Arthur Ashe Stadium was cheering Novak Djokovic’s miscues and even disrupting his service motion on occasion, all with the common goal of trying to propel Roger Federer across the finish line under the Sunday night lights at the United States Open.

headline: Review: PBS’s ‘Dawn of Humanity’ Puts Prehistory in a New Light
keywords: ['Television', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Homo Naledi', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The two-hour program elaborates on the discovery of early hominid bones deep in a cave northwest of Johannesburg.
lead_paragraph: Documentaries about prehistory and paleoanthropology are usually interesting, sometimes even thought-provoking. But you don’t often encounter one that’s thrilling. Yet that is a fitting adjective for “Dawn of Humanity,” a program being broadcast on Wednesday night that brings an aura of breaking news to a field that can often seem musty.

headline: With Some Paths Shut, Migrants Seek Others
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: In Hungary, Macedonia, Serbia and elsewhere, special efforts have been imposed to move migrants quickly to border areas.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — For three years, Hussam Haffi had been living in a Lebanese camp for those displaced by the war in Syria, eager to move his wife and four children to Europe, but wary of the journey’s many dangers. Finally, with Hungary threatening to crack down on migrants beginning Tuesday, Mr. Haffi decided it was time to act.

headline: Power Cuts Prompt Palestinians to Take to Gaza Streets in Largest Protests in Years
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Palestinians', 'Shortages', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Power Failures and Blackouts']
abstract: Several hundred Palestinians demonstrated in central Gaza on Monday evening over increasing power cuts, the latest in a series of protests that appear to have erupted over the issue.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY, Gaza Strip — Several hundred Palestinians demonstrated in central Gaza on Monday evening over increasing power cuts, the latest in a series of protests that appear to have erupted over the issue.

headline: Porsche, Aiming at Tesla, Unveils Electric Concept Car
abstract: The planned luxury performance sedan has 600 horsepower and can reach 60 miles an hour in under 3.5 seconds, Porsche says. Top speed is 155 miles an hour.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Tesla’s Model S went on sale in 2012, the start-up automaker has had the market for high-end electric cars to itself. But that is changing as other automakers start to introduce their own models.

headline: Amid California Wildfires, Escapes and Choices
abstract: Firefighters across the state are still battling to contain a dozen large wildfires that have killed at least one person, destroyed hundreds of homes and displaced 13,000 people.
lead_paragraph: MIDDLETOWN, Calif. — As they watched the sky go black and flames race toward their homes, the artists and campers, retirees and families living in this mountain town knew it was time to flee. Some, fearing that the drought-fueled fires raging across California would bring this moment to their door, had bags packed, ready to go. Others did not.

headline: As Mets Rise, a City Starts to Change Its Pinstripes
abstract: The Mets’ sudden turnaround has led to shifts in attendance and television viewership that suggest a narrowing popularity gap with the Yankees.

headline: Trauma Needs a Witness
abstract: Abuse is bad enough. But when it goes unrecognized, things get worse.
lead_paragraph: The thing about Paul, I realized some weeks into our work together, was that he seemed to exist outside of time. He was anchored well enough in the present, with his marriage and friends, his career and daily obligations, but when he spoke of the past, it was with such cool composure that he gave the impression that it wasn’t his history he was talking about. He was only in his mid-30s when he first came to see me, so the remoteness of his childhood was striking. This quality, along with his air of culture and sophistication, made it seem as if he had entered the world fully grown, sprung from the head of Zeus.

headline: Margo Jefferson’s ‘Negroland: A Memoir’
abstract: A critic returns to her early years among Chicago’s black elite.
lead_paragraph: The phrase “Black Lives Matter,” which emerged as a rallying cry during a year of frequent deadly showdowns between police officers and unarmed black citizens, has almost always been pointed at whites. It’s a way of saying, Stop discounting us. Stop mowing us down with your hatred, fear and disregard. But “Black Lives Matter” might just as easily have been the mantra of America’s black elite who, as far back as before the abolition of slavery, sought to establish themselves in communities characterized by privilege and extreme class consciousness. Of course for them, the phrase would have been transmitted insularly, from one to another, as a reminder of how much was riding upon their success at not merely performing gentility but also believing in the inviolable dignity that gentility has always been thought to confer. Why? Because believing a thing like that will make you less susceptible to everything America has concocted to turn you right back into chattel.

headline: Who Qualifies for ‘Asylum’?
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'English Language', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The word once conveyed a basic human right, but now countries disagree on who's worthy of refuge.
lead_paragraph: It’s an ancient promise: When outsiders flee to a new place in desperate need, they will not be turned away. The Hebrew Bible speaks of six cities of refuge where someone who caused a death unwittingly would be protected from being killed in revenge. The Greeks allowed slaves who ran away from abusive masters and even some criminals to seek sanctuary in certain temples; ‘‘asylum’’ comes from their word for inviolable. According to legend, Romulus, the founder of Rome, extended asylum to people we would call migrants, choosing a spot between two groves on Capitoline Hill for his city’s temple of asylum. ‘‘A crowd of commoners, both free and enslaved, poured in from the neighboring territories, eager for new conditions,’’ the historian Livy wrote. ‘‘This was the first step towards the strength Romulus envisioned for Rome.’’

headline: The Daily Do: Thom Browne
abstract: For the designer’s spring/summer 2016 show, sweet hair and makeup references got a decidedly twisted spin.
lead_paragraph: Thom Browne has become one of the most anticipated shows during New York Fashion Week — not only for his beautifully focused designs, but for his shows’ theatricality. This season, his set design took a simple, sweet reference — a schoolroom — and turned it on its head, literally: A fenced-in schoolyard and swing set hung upside-down from the ceiling. Models received the same sentimental-but-twisted treatment with nostalgic pairs of braids that stood straight up (and pierced through topless top hats), and geisha-inspired makeup with a gothic spin.

headline: Tuesday Morning Quarterback: Eli Manning Outsmarts Himself
abstract: N.F.L. coaches typically make the “safe” choice and lose. But the Giants could have played it safe and won, and instead tossed the game away.
lead_paragraph: What did Eli Manning know and when did he know it? This seems to be the question as the New York Giants — the last time you will see that name in this column — face the aftermath of their botched outing at Dallas, the team’s worst epic fail since the 2010 contest in which they allowed the Eagles to score four touchdowns in the final seven minutes to overcome a seemingly bulletproof 31-10 mid-fourth-quarter advantage.

headline: New England Patriots Lead A.F.C. East to a Rare 4-0 Week
abstract: The Patriots, the Jets, the Bills and the Dolphins all won in the same week for the first time since Week 10 in 2010.
lead_paragraph: In Week 1, the Bills, the Dolphins, the Jets and the Patriots emerged victorious. That was the first time the four teams in the A.F.C. East had a clean sweep in the same week since Week 10 in 2010, and the first time any division was 4-0 in the season’s opening week since the A.F.C. West did so in 2002. With the Patriots as defending Super Bowl champions and the Dolphins, the Bills and the Jets having made key additions in the off-season, the A.F.C. East figures to be one of the most competitive divisions. And in Week 1, the four teams played true to form.
