headline: Microbeads: The Very Tiny Troublemakers
keywords: ['Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Lakes', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'States (US)', 'Teeth and Dentistry', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: The plastic orbs wind up in waterways and threaten human health, and state and local governments are taking steps to ban them.
lead_paragraph: The Great Lakes are being threatened by an invasion of tiny plastic orbs called microbeads, but lawmakers for one state that depends on this huge freshwater ecosystem have failed to do anything about it. That state is, of course, New York, where lawmakers this year sat on a good bill to ban these unnecessary bits of plastic.

headline: Bringing Seafood Charcuterie to the Table
abstract: Chefs all across the country are redefining the smoked meat plate.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, chefs are expanding the definition of the traditional meat plate, swapping out fatty pork for the catch of the day. At Cure in Pittsburgh, Justin Severino has reimagined classics like ’nduja (a spreadable spicy pork sausage) with sockeye salmon, and finocchiona (a fennel-seed salami) with swordfish. At Greenpoint Fish & Lobster Co. in Brooklyn and at Seamore’s in Manhattan, diners can smear rich pâtés of smoked bluefish onto crusty bread. Matt Jennings, the owner of Townsman in Boston, delivers a clever spin on mortadella by substituting scallops for pork. And when Norah in West Hollywood opens next month, Angelenos can dig into smoked trout rillettes and shrimp boudin.

headline: 1940: Vichy Arrests Former Premier Leon Blum
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Vichy arrests the leader of French socialists in 1940.
lead_paragraph: VICHY — Leon Blum, twice Premier of France and leader of the French Socialist party, was arrested today [Sept. 15] and ‘‘administratively interned,’’ as an official communique put it, in Chateau Chazeron. There he joined the distinguished company of two other former French Premiers, a former generalissimo of the Allied armies, and a former French Minister of Interior who believed in making war on the Germans to the bitter end, Georges Mandel. Of the five eminent Frenchmen now under ‘‘guarded residence,’’ only one — Mandel — so far has been indicted. He was charged with plotting against the security of the state. — New York Herald Tribune, September 16, 1940

headline: What to Do Before Deployment? There’s No Crying at Disneyland
abstract: How do you enjoy the present when the future is all you can think about?
lead_paragraph: My husband, finally finished with the year of work-ups (short deployments preparing for the “big one”) and about to deploy, sat with me on the curb at Disneyland, watching our two children gape in awe at the Paint the Night Parade. Lightning McQueen revved his engine and the Princesses twirled before us, and the air was filled with the music’s repeating refrain: “When can we do this again? I never want this to end.”

headline: Restaurant Review: Casa Mono in Gramercy Park
abstract: A Spanish tradition of small-serving size lives on, as do the satisfying results.
lead_paragraph: Casa Mono has a lot to answer for. Founded by Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich in 2003, it was among the earliest and most influential restaurants to twist the Spanish tapas idiom into what New Yorkers learned to call small-plates dining. The Casa Mono style has spread far and wide, leaving in its wake a trail of cluttered tables, unpredictably sequenced dishes, and diners reduced to asking pathetically, “Will that be enough food?”

headline: Malcolm Turnbull Takes Helm as Australian Prime Minister
abstract: Mr. Turnbull, the new prime minister, will have to lead not only the lawmakers in his own party, but also a country where policy in recent years often seems to have been made on the run.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — When Malcolm Turnbull was sworn in on Tuesday, he did not only become Australia’s 29th prime minister — he also became its fourth in just over two years. His three immediate predecessors were ousted by their own parties, including Tony Abbott, who was forced out Monday in a leadership challenge led by Mr. Turnbull.

headline: 1965: Americans Flee to Iran
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: American women and children are evacuated from Pakistan in 1965.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — More than 600 American women and children were evacuated to here today [Sept. 15] in a massive airlift from war-torn West Pakistan. Seven giant C-130 planes airlifted them from Lahore. In Washington, the State Department said a similar airlift of Americans from the Dacca area of East Pakistan would begin shortly, possibly tomorrow. There are about 900 Americans in the Dacca area but a State Department spokesman said he did not know how many would leave. The spokesman said another airlift may be made from West Pakistan. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 16, 1965

headline: Changes in Credit Default Swap Market Bode Well for Transparency

abstract: While change has been slow in coming, new regulations are bringing less risk and more openness to the market.

Twelve banks on Friday agreed to a $1.9 billion settlement in the United States after investor accusations that they had abused their market-making position in credit default swaps, which enable investors to protect themselves against losses. Even so, the market is mending itself.

headline: Banjo Innovator Wins Steve Martin Bluegrass Award

lead_paragraph: As if dedicating your life to an instrument like the banjo wasn’t sufficiently avant-garde, the winner of this year’s Steve Martin Prize for Excellence in Banjo and Bluegrass is a musician recognized for his experimental approach to that seemingly quaint stringed instrument. Danny Barnes, the Texas-based banjo player and a founder of Bad Livers, the nonconformist roots-music group, has been named the recipient of the Steve Martin Prize, its organizers said; in a news release, they hailed Mr. Barnes as “one of bluegrass music’s most distinctive and innovative performers,” and for the “raw and unpolished musical breadth of his compositions” that have “propelled him across the industry today.”

keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Inflation (Economics)']
abstract: Can looking at central bankers’ blunders from the recent past offer any useful guidance for what the Fed ought to do this week? It’s worth hoping.
lead_paragraph: Central banks, to boil their job down to its simplest level, face this perpetual dilemma: Should they push for easier money, to try to support a nation’s economic growth, or for tighter money, to try to head off inflation?

headline: Celebrating the Flavors of Eataly With Ice Cream (Not Gelato)
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Cheese']
abstract: To toast its fifth birthday, the Italian mega-store collaborated with Morgenstern’s on a cheesy treat.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Eataly opened its doors on Fifth Avenue and 23rd Street, and ushered in the era of the high-end, themed, culinary mega-store. Since then, massive shrines to all things Italian have popped up around the globe, in places like Chicago, Dubai and, as of late last month, Seoul.

headline: Disney-ABC Names Cindy Davis and John Frelinghuysen to Senior Posts
abstract: Ms. Davis is a former executive at Walmart, and Mr. Frelinghuysen was an executive at AOL.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As it works to shore up its non-ESPN television division in a time of tremendous industrywide challenges — perhaps with the eventual introduction of a direct-to-consumer streaming service — the Walt Disney Company on Tuesday named a former Walmart executive and a former AOL leader to senior posts.

abstract: The actress discusses her roles in two films showing at the 40th Toronto International Film Festival, “Freeheld” and “Into the Forest.”
lead_paragraph: The actress discusses her roles in two films showing at the 40th Toronto International Film Festival, “Freeheld” and “Into the Forest.”

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 5
abstract: Mariah Carey shows up at W magazine’s dance; the Kardashian/Jenner sisters party with Galore; and Karolina Kurkova celebrates the Slowear opening.
lead_paragraph: Mariah Carey shows up at W magazine’s dance; the Kardashian/Jenner sisters party with Galore; and Karolina Kurkova celebrates the Slowear opening.

headline: When the Mission Is to Be an Outcast
abstract: The irreverent men's wear brand Gypsy Sport debuts its first women’s collection today. But its founder, Rio Uribe, doesn’t want you to define his collections along gender lines.
lead_paragraph: On a stifling day last month, the designer Rio Uribe sat in his basement-level, midtown studio wearing shorts, Reeboks, and a yellow basketball jersey emblazoned with a planetary “Haturn” logo that has become the emblem of his three-year-old label, Gypsy Sport. The studio is a physical manifestation of the brand: exploding with color and pattern, every surface is covered in red and gold paper lanterns, bamboo plants and the vibrant remnants from past collections. Over the past five seasons, Uribe’s vividly eccentric designs have made the brand famous for its irreverent, gender-fluid take on men’s wear.

headline: Egypt Rejects Criticism Over Airstrike That Killed Mexican Tourists
abstract: Mexico’s foreign minister flew to Egypt on Tuesday to demand answers about an airstrike over the weekend that hit a picnic full of Mexican tourists, killing a dozen people.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Mexico’s foreign minister traveled to Egypt on Tuesday to demand answers about a mistaken military airstrike over the weekend that hit a picnic full of Mexican tourists, killing a dozen people, while her Egyptian counterpart defended the professionalism and sacrifice of the Egyptian security forces.

headline: Vera Wang: Spring 2016 RTW
abstract: The latest spring designs from Ms. Wang.
lead_paragraph: The latest spring designs from Ms. Wang.

headline: House Vote Said to Be Near on Repeal of Oil Export Ban
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the majority leader, predicted that a repeal of the 40-year-old ban would be approved in a vote later this month. Senate passage, however, might be problematic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California and majority leader, said on Tuesday that the House was preparing to vote later this month to repeal a 40-year-old ban on the export of crude oil. The plan was immediately celebrated by the oil industry but is already drawing fire from environmental groups.

headline: Timeline: Democracy in Recession
keywords: ['Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]

headline: Tough Going for Health Co-ops
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Cooperatives', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Start-ups']
abstract: The federal marketplace was intended to increase competition, partly by creating consumer-led co-ops. But many new entrants have struggled, and several have folded.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, the Nevada Health Co-op became the third casualty among 23 insurance start-ups created under the federal health care law to inject competition for coverage in certain parts of the country.

headline: Model-Morphosis: Frederikke Sofie at Vera Wang
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2016 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2016 Fashion Week in New York.

headline: Blue Origin, Jeff Bezos’ Rocket Company, to Launch From Florida
abstract: A rocket company founded by Jeffrey P. Bezos, the Amazon chief executive, announced plans to use a historic launch site at Cape Canaveral.
lead_paragraph: Blue Origin, a secretive rocket company started by Jeffrey P. Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon, made a splashy public announcement on Tuesday, saying it will build rockets and send them into orbit from Florida.

headline: Bruce Springsteen and Jon Stewart to Perform at ‘Stand Up for Heroes’ Event
abstract: Bruce Springsteen, Jon Stewart and John Oliver will perform at Madison Square Garden to raise money for injured veterans.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Springsteen and Jon Stewart will return to Madison Square Garden to headline the ninth annual Stand Up for Heroes performance on Nov. 10. Presented by the Bob Woodruff Foundation and the New York Comedy Festival, the performance also stars Seth Meyers, John Oliver and Ray Romano and will raise money to support wounded veterans and their families.

headline: ‘London Fields’ Premiere in Toronto Troubled by Creative Rift
abstract: The principal actors, including Amber Heard and Billy Bob Thornton, have written to its producers, objecting to a provocative cut of the movie not overseen by the director.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — It has not been hard to spot Johnny Depp at the giant film festival here. Monday night, he walked the red carpet with his wife, Amber Heard, to celebrate a showing of his movie “Black Mass.” Two days earlier, it was Mr. Depp on Ms. Heard’s arm, at a screening of “The Danish Girl,” of which she is a star.

headline: Brooklyn Man Sought in Similar Deaths of 2 Women at Hotels
abstract: Officials have released video images of Joseph Danclair, 36, who is believed to have spent time with women who were found dead in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: It was July 23 when the first woman was discovered dead in Room 3 of a Brooklyn hotel, her body bearing the telltale signs of strangulation, the police said. On Sept. 8, a second woman was found dead, this time at a hotel in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Street Style: A Colorful Mix
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2015)']
abstract: The style on the street during New York Fashion Week is a changeable as the weather.
lead_paragraph: The style on the street during New York Fashion Week is a changeable as the weather.

headline: David Chang Opens Fuku+ in Midtown
abstract: An added location for the fried-chicken-sandwich cubbyhole; a rooftop beer garden in Downtown Brooklyn; a reprieve for La Luncheonette; and more.
lead_paragraph: Fuku+ Across the street from Harry Winston’s rocks, you can now get a heaping bowl of crisp chicken nuggets with jade-green hot sauce for just $6. It’s one of the items at the new Midtown edition of Fuku, the fried-chicken-sandwich cubbyhole that David Chang recently opened in the East Village. Crunchy salt-and-pepper head-on shrimp, several salads and flatbread slathered with nubbly Sichuan pork are served along with beer, wine and cocktails. The space, inside the Chambers Hotel, is at street level, behind the Milk Bar stand and overlooking Má Pêche below. Set menu packages, serving up to eight people, can be ordered ahead online. The little restaurant has some unexpected extras, like waiter service and Bob Dylan and Waylon Jennings on the playlist to ramp up the energy of the crowd at the counter and high-top tables: 15 West 56th Street, momofuku.com.

headline: Russia Resisting Europe Request for Tough U.N. Anti-Smuggling Step
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Human Trafficking']
abstract: Russia’s United Nations ambassador, the current Security Council president, said in an interview that he opposed any measure allowing military action.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — A European bid to obtain Security Council approval for a military operation against boats suspected of human smuggling on the Mediterranean Sea is running into opposition from Russia, which wants to ensure that it cannot be used to justify a broader military intervention, diplomats here said.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 2: Waiver Wire Picks
abstract: Fantasy owners will be without some players after injuries in Week 1, so it is crucial to stay on top of the free-agent pool to fill any holes.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. had a fair number of injuries in Week 1, some more significant than others. Injuries are a main contributor to the emergence of waiver wire darlings, and because nobody wins a fantasy football league on draft day, it is crucial to be on top of the free-agent pool. Here are the best waiver wire picks after the first week (ownership percentages based on Yahoo leagues).

headline: Extreme Downhill Biking
abstract: The mountain biker Primoz Ravnik rode down a steep 200-foot dam spillway in Zirovnica, Slovenia.
lead_paragraph: The mountain biker Primoz Ravnik rode down a steep 200-foot dam spillway in Zirovnica, Slovenia.

headline: The Fixers Who Rescue Dye Jobs Gone Wrong
abstract: A hair coloring that is far from you what you imagined is hard to stomach. Luckily there are salons that can correct even the most egregious mistakes.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Humphrey sat rigidly on a couch at the Sally Hershberger Downtown salon, her eyes darting across the waiting area.

headline: New High-Shine Lip Glosses for Fall
abstract: Moving away from the matte look, several makeup lines are releasing fresh glosses that lend lips a vivid sheen.
lead_paragraph: This fall, a handful of companies are offering alternatives to the stainlike matte lipsticks that have been popular for the last few seasons: shiny lip glosses, some in highly pigmented formulas that add a surprisingly vivid swipe of color.

headline: Coming Soon to Facebook: A ‘Dislike’ Button
abstract: The social network’s thumbs-up button will soon be accompanied by a way to express more negative emotions.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s famous “like” button, with its silhouette of an upturned thumb, will soon be accompanied by an alternative: a way to “dislike” a post.

headline: Ted Cruz Ad Uses Scorpion to Depict Threat of Islamic Terror
abstract: During the Republican debate at the Reagan Library in California on Wednesday, the campaign of Senator Ted Cruz of Texas will evoke the threat of Middle East terrorism by using a scorpion crawling in the desert.
lead_paragraph: For aficionados of political ads, the line “There’s a bear in the woods” still brings a shivery memory of a 1984 spot for Ronald Reagan that helped define his foreign policy of peace through strength.

headline: Cuomo and Christie Say States Can Pay Half of Hudson Rail Tunnel Project
abstract: In a letter to President Obama, the governors urged the federal government to pledge grants to cover the rest of the $20 billion work.
lead_paragraph: The governors of New York and New Jersey sent a letter to President Obama on Tuesday offering to line up funding for half of the costs of new Hudson River rail tunnels if the federal government pledges grants for the other half.

headline: Protests at Annual Bull-Killing Festival
keywords: ['Bullfighting and Bull Runs', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: Demonstrators attended the annual Toro de la Vega festival in the Spanish town of Tordesillas last year to protest the traditional bull-spearing event.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators attended the annual Toro de la Vega festival in the Spanish town of Tordesillas last year to protest the traditional bull-spearing event.

headline: Charlie Hebdo Mocks Europe’s Response to Migrant Crisis With Cartoons of Dead Syrian Boy
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Social Media']
abstract: Two French illustrators have been denounced on social networks for publishing editorial cartoons inspired by harrowing photographs of Aylan Kurdi.
lead_paragraph: French illustrators have been denounced on social networks in recent days for publishing editorial cartoons inspired by photographs of Aylan Kurdi, a 3-year-old Syrian boy whose drowning in the waters off Greece this month prompted an outpouring of sympathy for refugees.

headline: Looking for Conventions, Cities Add Hotel Rooms
keywords: ['Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Hotel projects have drawn financial support from cities seeking increased convention business, but this support has sometimes become contentious.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — When Kansas City failed to make the cut for the 2016 Republican National Convention, some officials chalked it up to politics.

headline: Online Ad for Jeb Bush Paints Dark Picture of Donald Trump
abstract: The “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush released an online ad that contrasts remarks made by Donald J. Trump with Mr. Bush’s optimistic offer of “positive, conservative leadership.”
lead_paragraph: [Video: Watch on YouTube.]

headline: Reactions Vary to News of New ‘Mary Poppins’ Film
abstract: Some fans responded with venom when Disney announced plans to make a new “Mary Poppins” film.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Disney is developing a new “Mary Poppins” film. Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious? Or something quite atrocious?

headline: ‘The Nightly Show With Larry Wilmore’ Renewed Through End of 2016
abstract: Mr. Wilmore’s show debuted in January on Comedy Central.
lead_paragraph: Larry Wilmore and his staff at “The Nightly Show” now have certainty that they will be keeping it 100 through the end of next year and for the duration of the presidential election: Comedy Central said on Tuesday that it had renewed the news-satire series through the end of 2016, confirming a report that first appeared on CNN.com.

headline: Police Discuss Charges in Baruch Hazing
abstract: Chief Chris Wagner of the Pocono Mountain Regional Police Department said Tuesday that a grand jury had recommended that fraternity members face charges in the death of a Baruch College freshman.
lead_paragraph: Chief Chris Wagner of the Pocono Mountain Regional Police Department said Tuesday that a grand jury had recommended that fraternity members face charges in the death of a Baruch College freshman.

headline: Rand Paul to Run Ad During Debate Calling Himself ‘a Real Conservative’
abstract: Senator Rand Paul, in an ad to run on CNN during the presidential debate on Wednesday, says America needs a real conservative — leaving viewers to guess who the fake conservative on stage is.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul is not betting that his time on the stage during the Republican presidential debate on Wednesday night will be enough to get his message out and re-energize his campaign. So he is buying time on CNN, the network hosting the debate, so he can run an ad during the commercial breaks.

headline: Legislators in Missouri Take Aim at Union Dues
abstract: On Wednesday, the Republican-dominated General Assembly is expected to attempt to override the governor’s veto of a bill that would allow workers not in unions to avoid paying fees.
lead_paragraph: AFFTON, Mo. — During a recent visit to this working-class suburb of St. Louis, Gov. Jay Nixon told cheering union workers that he would fight to preserve a bedrock of labor organizing: the right to require workers, including those who opt out of joining a union, to pay dues or their equivalent.

headline: Chinese-American Cleared of Spying Charges Now Faces Firing
abstract: Government officials say they will dismiss Sherry Chen, a hydrologist at the National Weather Service. The Justice Department last year dropped a case against her.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Government officials say they intend to fire a Chinese-American hydrologist who was prosecuted but eventually cleared of espionage-related charges.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Carolyn Ryan, Jason Stallman and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.

headline: Review: Comedy Central’s ‘Moonbeam City’ Recalls the World of ‘Miami Vice’
abstract: Rob Lowe, Elizabeth Banks and Will Forte provide the voices for the law enforcement characters in this animated satire.
lead_paragraph: If you were a graphic artist, a Duran Duran fan or, really, just someone with eyes during the late 1970s and early ’80s, you know the work of Patrick Nagel. His flat, Art Deco-ish illustrations of women, their features reduced to pouting lips and dramatic eyes, were ubiquitous for a time, gracing the pages of Playboy, the cover of Duran Duran’s “Rio” album and, as the art critic Peter Plagens wrote in The New York Times, “hairdressing salons and white-shag-carpet condos from Coral Gables to La Jolla.”

headline: Review: ‘Peace Officer’ Explores Military-Style Raids by Law Enforcement
abstract: Focusing on a quest by a retired sheriff, this documentary examines the consequences of the flow of military weapons to local departments.
lead_paragraph: “Peace Officer,” a documentary about the militarization of law enforcement, is nothing if not timely, though its focus is mostly confined to one state.

headline: Review: ‘Tree of Codes,’ an Explosion of Energy in a Sea of More
abstract: This dance spectacle at the Park Avenue Armory combines Olafur Eliasson’s visual design, a score by Jamie xx and choreography by Wayne McGregor.
lead_paragraph: Arrive early to “Tree of Codes,” the dance spectacle at the Park Avenue Armory, and you can spend some time observing your shadow, psychedelically multiplied, along the walls of the 55,000-square-foot Wade Thompson Drill Hall. Audience members lingered there, Instagramming, at the New York premiere on Monday. That installation, by the Danish-Icelandic visual artist Olafur Eliasson, turns out to be one of the more subtle elements in this high-profile collaboration, which features Mr. Eliasson’s visual design, a score by the English composer Jamie xx and choreography — lots of it — by Wayne McGregor.

headline: New Website Aims to Provide Guidance to Theater Fans
abstract: Show-Score.com will aggregate reviews and pricing information for New York shows.
lead_paragraph: There are web sites that aggregate film reviews, and those that compare prices for all kinds of products. But the theater business has traditionally been seen as too small, and the shelf life of shows too short, to sustain such technology for Broadway.

headline: A Migration Juggernaut Is Headed for Europe
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Foreign Workers', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Europe can expect several decades of heavy immigration, and the sooner it develops policies to help integrate migrants the better for all concerned.
lead_paragraph: European leaders probably don’t want to hear this now, as they frantically try to close their borders to stop hundreds of thousands of desperate migrants and asylum seekers escaping hunger and violence in Africa and the Middle East. But they are dealing with the unstoppable force of demography.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Surfer Vibes on the Runway
abstract: Altuzarra, Victoria Beckham and Tommy Hilfiger all included references to life on the beach.
lead_paragraph: Memories of the beach are, evidently, still lingering in the minds of New Yorkers: So far this season, several designers have included nods to surf culture in their spring/summer shows. At Altuzarra, an acid-green tie-dyed dress came down the runway, unbuttoned to expose a bra underneath. At Victoria Beckham, the inspiration was more literal: abstract drawings of surfers appeared on zip jackets, low-cut dresses and skirts. And at Tommy Hilfiger, the island-themed runway featured colorful, striped Baja pullover sweaters — a tried and true surfer staple.

headline: Bezos Announces Rocket Launch Site
abstract: Jeffrey P. Bezos, the founder of Amazon and the chief executive of Blue Origin, revealed plans to build a rocket manufacturing plant and use a launch site in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey P. Bezos, the founder of Amazon and the chief executive of Blue Origin, revealed plans to build a rocket manufacturing plant and use a launch site in Florida.

headline: Democrats Move to Beef Up Fund-Raising With Staff Overhaul
abstract: The Democratic National Committee is moving to drastically beef up its fund-raising arm, adding a co-chairman and six others to leadership positions to help raise money for the 2016 presidential race.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Committee is moving to drastically beef up its fund-raising arm, adding a finance co-chairman to the current one, who has at times prompted controversy, and announcing six others to leadership positions to help raise money for the 2016 presidential race.

headline: G.O.P. Discord Over Ex-Im Bank Intensifies, as G.E. Shifts Jobs Abroad
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: General Electric and Boeing blamed a halt in export credit for job transfers and a loss of contracts, reigniting Republican infighting over the fate of the Ex-Im Bank.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — General Electric announced plans on Tuesday to move 500 jobs overseas, and Boeing said it had lost a second foreign satellite contract in weeks, developments that both corporate giants blamed on the Republican-led Congress’s failure to keep the federal Export-Import Bank open to help finance new deals.

headline: The GoPro That Fell to Earth
abstract: In June 2013, members of the Grand Canyon Stratospheric Balloon Team launched a balloon with a camera into the stratosphere, where it burst. It was found by a hiker two years later.
lead_paragraph: In June 2013, members of the Grand Canyon Stratospheric Balloon Team launched a balloon with a camera into the stratosphere, where it burst. It was found by a hiker two years later.

abstract: The spring 2016 collection.
lead_paragraph: The spring 2016 collection.

headline: Review: Circuit des Yeux, With Haley Fohr’s Deep Vocals, Seeks an Essential Truth
abstract: Ms. Fohr, 26 and making albums since 2008, has figured out a group sound and she takes less time to get to the heart of a song.
lead_paragraph: A full-band Circuit des Yeux show these days is a forceful and elegant process with resonance and harmony and drones, a gathering force around its deep-voiced pressure center, the singer, guitarist and songwriter Haley Fohr. I’ve seen two over the last month. I could see another right now.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Sale of Twombly Work to Help Fund Expansion of Wilshire Boulevard Temple in Los Angeles
abstract: A 25-year-old purchase by a Los Angeles philanthropist could now help pay for a Rem Koolhaas building.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s become something of an art-market trope to say that for the price of a single painting by a blue-chip artist you could pay for an entire building by a well-known architect.

headline: Review: Making Connections at Istanbul’s Biennial
abstract: Organized by Carolyn Christov-Bakargiev, this sprawling international exhibition in Turkey blurs the borders among art, history and science.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Three years ago, the American-Italian curator Carolyn Christov-Bakargiev garnered ecstatic reviews for her edition of Documenta, the superexhibition that takes place every five years in Kassel, Germany. Challenging and disorderly, it dissolved borders among art, history and science, placing contemporary art alongside Afghan antiquities, objects from Hitler’s apartment and meteorites.

headline: Martin McDonagh’s ‘Hangmen,’ a Mordant Stage Homecoming in London
abstract: The playwright talks about his new play, which is being staged at the Royal Court 15 years after the theater turned down his “Lieutenant of Inishmore.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In 2000, the bad-boy playwright Martin McDonagh accused the Royal Court Theater here of cowardice for declining to stage his ultraviolent Irish Republican Army-themed play, “The Lieutenant of Inishmore.”

headline: Review: ‘Pawn Sacrifice,’ Another Take on the Royal Game
abstract: Edward Zwick directs this film interpretation of the superpowers’ chess battle waged by Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky in 1972.
lead_paragraph: It was a challenge to play Bobby Fischer in chess, and it’s a challenge for an actor to play him on the screen. Anyone taking on the task needs to be careful not to get carried away with the man’s eccentricities, to make sure to retain the pathos beneath the sideshow.

headline: Review: ‘Storm, Still,’ a Riff on ‘King Lear’ in a Brooklyn Backyard
abstract: In Gabrielle Reisman’s play, three sisters sort through their dead father’s belongings in search of a will.
lead_paragraph: The playwright Gabrielle Reisman has taken that “All the world’s a stage” business to heart. And she has taken it home: Her tumbledown backyard in the wilds of Bushwick is the setting for her minor but likable “Storm, Still.”

headline: Nicolas Berggruen Wants to Bridge the East-West Gap
abstract: Mr. Berggruen and his research group say they will take a philosophical angle in its study of the differences between the East and the West.
lead_paragraph: Western universities and private philanthropists have poured resources into China in recent years, funding scholarships, campuses and other initiatives to bridge the gap between East and West.

abstract: The label’s latest looks.
lead_paragraph: The label’s latest looks.

headline: Where Gay Love Is Illegal
abstract: The photographer Robin Hammond traveled to seven countries to make portraits of L.G.B.T. individuals who had been attacked because of their sexual orientation.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Robin Hammond traveled to seven countries to make portraits of L.G.B.T. individuals who had been attacked because of their sexual orientation.

headline: Video Retrieved From GoPro Balloon That Soared to Nearly 100,000 Feet
abstract: Breathtaking footage of the Grand Canyon was retrieved from the camera, found by a hiker in the desert two years after it crashed.
lead_paragraph: Strapped to a weather balloon bound for space, this GoPro camera soared almost 100,000 feet, into the stratosphere, to capture high-resolution footage of the Grand Canyon in 2013. An hour and a half into its flight the balloon burst and the camera plummeted back to earth.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Germany and Elsewhere

lead_paragraph: Germany and More — Pictures of the Day

abstract: Photos from Germany, Serbia, Hungary and North Korea.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Germany, Serbia, Hungary and North Korea.

headline: Hewlett-Packard to Cut About 10 Percent of Work Force
abstract: The company is splitting into two, and refocusing from costly, low-margin business services to higher-value consulting and cross selling.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — A year ago, Meg Whitman announced she was cutting Hewlett-Packard in two. On Tuesday, she detailed job cuts expected at the company.

headline: Paul Taylor American Modern Dance Announces New Season
abstract: Paul Taylor’s renewed company announces its new season.
lead_paragraph: The reinvented Paul Taylor American Modern Dance, which had its inaugural season at Lincoln Center earlier this year, will return next spring to present the fruits of its latest venture, Taylor Company Commissions.

headline: Review: ‘The Fool’ Is Yuri Bykov’s Look at Corruption
abstract: In this film, Mr. Bykov’s main character is frustrated after noticing a structural flaw that could lead to a building’s collapse.
lead_paragraph: The dreary unidentified Russian town that is the setting of Yuri Bykov’s devastating film, “The Fool,” is an outpost of hell. If you can bear to look at it, I recommend you pay a visit and study it from behind bulletproof glass, because similar places aren’t all that uncommon.

headline: How the New York Times/CBS News Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 9 to 13 with 1,261 adults throughout the United States.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 9 to 13 with 1,261 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,021 said they were registered to vote.

headline: More Republicans See Donald Trump as a Winner, Poll Finds
abstract: A Times/CBS News poll finds that, although many Republicans have reservations about Mr. Trump, he appears to be gaining acceptance.
lead_paragraph: Republicans increasingly think that Donald J. Trump has the best chance of winning the 2016 presidential election as their nominee as confidence fades in traditional politicians like Jeb Bush and Scott Walker, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: A Conversation With Steven Rutter
abstract: Mr. Rutter, 56, is director of Stribling Marketing Associates, a unit of the Stribling & Associates brokerage firm, which focuses on residential developments in New York.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Rutter, 56, is the director of Stribling Marketing Associates, a division of the Stribling & Associates boutique brokerage firm, which focuses on new residential developments in New York City. Among the projects currently being marketed are 252 East 57th Street, 210 West 77th Street and the Philip House at 141 East 88th Street.

headline: Champions League Comes Before Domestic Ones for Some Top Clubs
abstract: Powerhouses like Paris-St. Germain, Manchester City and Bayern Munich make no secret of their emphasis on the Champions League over their domestic leagues.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — One of the great, if occasionally confusing, aspects of European soccer is the sheer number of opportunities that exist for someone — anyone — to win something. It has not gotten so bad that associations are handing out participation trophies (yet), but in many of the big soccer countries, so many competitions run concurrently in any given season that it can sometimes feel like an exercise in memorization to simply keep track of them all.

headline: A New York Times/CBS News Poll on the State of the Presidential Race
abstract: Republicans increasingly think that Donald J. Trump has the best chance of winning the 2016 election as their nominee, but support for Ben Carson is up since August, according to a New York Times/CBS News nationwide poll.
lead_paragraph: Republicans increasingly think that Donald J. Trump has the best chance of winning the 2016 election as their nominee, but support for Ben Carson is up since August, according to a New York Times/CBS News nationwide poll.

headline: De Blasio to Announce 10-Year Deadline to Offer Computer Science to All Students
abstract: Meeting the requirement set by Mayor Bill de Blasio for New York public schools will present major challenges, mostly in training enough teachers.
lead_paragraph: To ensure that every child can learn the skills required to work in New York City’s fast-growing technology sector, Mayor Bill de Blasio will announce on Wednesday that within 10 years all of the city’s public schools will be required to offer computer science to all students.

headline: Why Is That Dog Looking at Me?
abstract: The reasoning behind why dogs look at humans — and wolves don’t — is not easily explained.
lead_paragraph: Among the deep and intriguing phenomena that attract intense scientific interest are the birth and death of the universe, the intricacies of the human brain and the way dogs look at humans.

headline: London Theater Journal: Getting Giddy
abstract: Ben Brantley reviews “The Beaux’ Stratagem” at the National Theater.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – There was a time when “caper,” used as an adjective, signaled an especially sprightly form of entertainment. It usually meant a movie or play that involved a heist or a theft, or some sort of illicit deception, and bristled with lively counterplots and sexual intrigue. Caper is now an anachronistic word, and the light-handed, light-fingered genre it once stood for has been largely eclipsed, at least on screen, by more adrenalized, special-effects-heavy fare.

lead_paragraph: Golf announcers do not often defect from one network to another, so David Feherty’s move from CBS Sports to NBC and Golf Channel is unusual.

abstract: ­You will literally stand out. Embrace it.
lead_paragraph: As with any new piece of automated equipment, navigating the proper etiquette of standing desks can involve a bit of a learning curve.

headline: Back to School With Thom Browne and Rodarte
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2015)']
abstract: Mr. Browne constructed his own schoolroom, while the Californian designers behind Rodarte offered their own sentimental education.
lead_paragraph: One of the weirder coincidences of New York Fashion Week is that it starts, almost exactly, on the first day of school in most of the city. The parallels of children going back to class and fashion going back to shows are hard to ignore. There’s something about the beginning of the season that feels like a continuing education course: The subjects, broadly, are the same, but the curriculum has been updated. It’s a week of cramming.

headline: Misidentified and Tackled by the New York Police, but No Tennis Star Treatment
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Both James Blake, an internationally known former tennis star, and Angie, an 11-year-old student in the Bronx, found themselves thrown to the ground by a police officer. Then their cases diverge.
lead_paragraph: It was February and the streets were crusted with winter, not a September day steeped in high-noon mugginess. The scene was the street outside a barber shop on Teller Avenue in the Bronx, not the entrance to the Grand Hyatt New York hotel on East 42nd Street in Manhattan. And the person taken to the ground was an 11-year-old girl, not an internationally known former tennis star.

headline: Autoworkers’ Union Reaches Tentative Deal With Fiat Chrysler

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and the United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative agreement on Tuesday on a new contract that could establish a pattern for labor deals at the other two American carmakers, General Motors and Ford.

headline: Oklahoma: Governor Refuses Request to Delay Execution
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Richard Glossip is to die on Wednesday for arranging a murder in 1997.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mary Fallin said Tuesday that she would not delay the execution of Richard Glossip, who is to die on Wednesday for arranging a murder in 1997. Mr. Glossip’s defense lawyers, the anti-death penalty campaigner Sister Helen Prejean, the Innocence Project and others had publicized what they call significant new evidence casting doubt on his guilt. His conviction rested largely on the testimony of the admitted killer, who was spared the death penalty in return for testifying that Mr. Glossip was the mastermind. But Ms. Fallin said she had seen “no credible evidence of Richard Glossip’s innocence.” Late Tuesday, his lawyers filed a new request for a stay of execution with the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals, arguing that in view of the new evidence, he “would be acquitted at trial today.”

headline: Charities Say U.S. Should Take Tens of Thousands of Syrians
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: Major charitable aid groups, seeing disarray in Europe’s response to the refugee crisis, urged the Obama administration to take many thousands.
lead_paragraph: Executives from leading American aid groups, watching the muddled international response to the migrant crisis with dismay, called on the United States government on Tuesday to multiply many times over its recent commitment to take 10,000 displaced Syrians in the next year.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: A judge in Manhattan has dismissed a lawsuit brought by the financier Alphonse Fletcher Jr. against the Dakota building, ruling that Mr. Fletcher had failed to provide evidence that the celebrated building’s co-op board had discriminated against him because he is black.

headline: Patrick Kane’s Status Is Shrouded in Silence
abstract: Kane, a Buffalo-born N.H.L. star, finds himself the subject of a criminal investigation into a rape allegation. But no one is talking much.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Kane skates with grace, a raw-boned little man with a preternatural feel for the game and an asp’s bite of a backhand shot. He has hoisted the Stanley Cup over his head three times, most recently when the Chicago Blackhawks won the championship in June.

headline: Attitudes Shift on Paid Leave: Dads Sue, Too
abstract: As more men take time off work when a baby is born, many are also filing lawsuits and complaints about how much time they can take and the professional setbacks they endure when they return to work.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades, women who believed their employers had punished them with lower wages and missed promotions after they had become mothers have been filing gender discrimination complaints and bringing lawsuits.

headline: Frantic Evacuation in California Left Animals to Face Wildfire Alone
abstract: The suddenness of the Valley Fire’s surge in Northern California last weekend forced thousands of evacuating residents to leave their animals, both pets and livestock, behind.
lead_paragraph: MIDDLETOWN, Calif. — When the Valley Fire blew up in this rural area 100 miles north of San Francisco last weekend, many residents fled with only the clothes they were wearing. The suddenness of the fire’s surge — half an hour from warning to life-threatening conflagration in many parts of Lake County — sent people scattering, their homes undefended and possessions left to fate or luck.

headline: Obama Weighing Talks With Putin on Syrian Crisis
abstract: President Obama’s administration is debating whether the two leaders should try to work out their differences. Some fear a meeting would only play into Mr. Putin’s hands.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than a year, President Obama has resisted meeting one on one with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and only reluctantly taken a phone call, freezing out the Kremlin leader over his intervention in Ukraine in their own personal cold war.

They took their places, with their hands behind their backs — the young pitchers, the midseason acquisitions and the veterans who had posed for several of these before. This group would be commemorated, at the least, as the team that ended the Mets’ streak of six consecutive losing seasons.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) BREATHLESS (1961) Turner Classic Movies pays tribute to the director Jean-Luc Godard, starting with this New Wave classic about two erratic days in the lives of star-crossed young lovers — Jean-Paul Belmondo, as a French hoodlum on the lam after killing a cop, and Jean Seberg, as an American expatriate newspaper vendor — living in Paris. As sordid as the film is, “and sordid is really a mild word for its pile-up of gross indecencies,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times, it is no cliché — rather “more a chunk of raw drama, graphically and artfully torn with appropriately ragged edges out of the tough underbelly of modern metropolitan life.” The evening continues with “Pierrot le Fou” (1968), featuring Mr. Belmondo as an unhappily married man who abandons his bourgeois life for a crime spree with an ex-girlfriend (Anna Karina), at 10:15; “Masculin Féminin” (1966), about an aspiring writer (Jean-Pierre Léaud) who becomes involved with a rising pop star (Chantal Goya) and her roommates, at 12:15 a.m.; “Alphaville” (1965), in which a private investigator (Eddie Constantine) is sent to rescue a scientist from a future world ruled by computers, at 2:15; and “A Woman Is a Woman” (1964), about an exotic dancer (Ms. Karina) intent on finding a man to father a child, at 4. (Image: Ms. Seberg and Mr. Belmondo.)

headline: A Very Unusual Subway Stop in New York
abstract: After seeing the new 7 line station, riders may find it hard to return to the grime so typical of the city’s transit system.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s long-suffering commuters might be wise to avoid a glittering new subway stop on the No. 7 line that opened Sunday at Hudson Yards on the West Side of Manhattan. After seeing the $2.4 billion station that has ignited a burst of development in this once-grim industrial area, riders may find it hard to return to the grime so typical of New York City’s vast 660-mile public transit system. And while no single station can be as sleek, efficient and “air tempered” as this one, commuters will almost certainly find themselves asking why the system as a whole cannot be greatly improved.

headline: Iran Deal Players’ Report Cards
abstract: It’s time to rate the performances of a number of the people who worked hard to get the agreement or to stop it.
lead_paragraph: The Iran nuclear deal is now sealed — from Washington’s end. But since this has been one of America’s most important foreign policy shifts in the last four decades, it’s worth looking back and grading the performance of the key players.

headline: Constitutionally, Slavery Is No National Institution
abstract: It is one of the most destructive falsehoods in American history to say otherwise.
lead_paragraph: THE Civil War began over a simple question: Did the Constitution of the United States recognize slavery — property in humans — in national law? Southern slaveholders, inspired by Senator John C. Calhoun of South Carolina, charged that it did and that the Constitution was proslavery; Northern Republicans, led by Abraham Lincoln, and joined by abolitionists including Frederick Douglass, resolutely denied it. After Lincoln’s election to the presidency, 11 Southern states seceded to protect what the South Carolina secessionists called their constitutional “right of property in slaves.”

headline: Can Anything Be Done About All the Money in Politics?
abstract: It may seem counterintuitive, but lifting the restrictions on fundraising by political parties would help.
lead_paragraph: Nearly everyone in America agrees that there is too much influence-seeking money in politics, except for the people who benefit from it. Public concern over the potential for corruption in this flood of cash has resulted, over the past half century, in five separate approaches to the regulation of campaign finance.

headline: In Yemen, Death From Above, Grief Below
abstract: A single missile shattered my family’s future.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — LEWZA was my sister-in-law. She was a good person, one of the kindest I have ever known.

headline: ‘My Silver Hair’
abstract: In this short animation, a woman explains why she wears her hair in its natural color.
lead_paragraph: When I was in college, I met a beautiful woman in her early 20s who had a full head of gray hair. At first, I pitied her for being so radiant and yet cursed with such a glaring blemish. But after talking with her for just a few seconds I realized it wasn’t her appearance that I was attracted to — gray hair or not — but her confidence and poise. Her clear self-acceptance, regardless of how others might view her, impressed me so deeply that 30 years later, I still remember the chance meeting. Today, all I remember about her was her hair color and her confidence.

headline: Migrants Clash With Police in Hungary, as Others Enter Croatia
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Officers beat migrants with batons, doused them with water cannons and sprayed them with tear gas at the border with Serbia. Thousands of migrants sought alternate routes west.
lead_paragraph: HORGOS, Serbia — In one of the worst bursts of violence that this tense refugee summer has seen, Hungarian riot police responded on Wednesday to rocks, taunts and small fires set by agitated migrants at the border crossing here with water cannons, head-cracking batons and both tear gas and pepper spray.

headline: Living in Midwood, Brooklyn
abstract: Families are attracted to Midwood, Brooklyn, which offers relatively inexpensive homes and tree-lined streets.
lead_paragraph: Families are attracted to Midwood, Brooklyn, which offers relatively inexpensive homes and tree-lined streets.

headline: Midwood, Brooklyn, Where Urban and Suburban Meet
abstract: Midwood has long been known as a Jewish neighborhood, but there is also a mix of recently arrived immigrants as well as lifelong New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: The tree-lined streets of Midwood, with many single- and multifamily houses at prices that are relatively inexpensive for Brooklyn, naturally attract plenty of families. In fact, the basketball hoops dotting the driveways, and the Cozy Coupes and tricycles scattered along the sidewalks, might make visitors wonder if they were still in New York City.

headline: A Building That Resembles What It Stores: Salt for New York City’s Roads
abstract: Looking at the $20 million Spring Street Salt Shed, which is nearing completion on the Manhattan waterfront, it is hard not to see a giant salt grain.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a coarse chunk of gray salt 69 feet high.

headline: Clive Owen, Suave and Roguish, on Making His Broadway Debut in ‘Old Times’
abstract: Mr. Owen, who stars in “The Knick” on Cinemax, will take the stage for the first time in 14 years in the Broadway revival of Harold Pinter’s play.
lead_paragraph: Clive Owen has chosen Fanelli Cafe in SoHo as the place to submit to an interview, and there’s a logic to that. He’s the star of “The Knick” — a television series set in Lower Manhattan at the turn of the 20th century that has featured opium dens and race riots — and Fanelli sits in a 168-year-old building that at various times served as brothel, African-American boardinghouse and speakeasy.

headline: Which 2016 Presidential Candidates Interest You Most?
abstract: More than a dozen Republicans and a handful of Democrats have announced that they are running for their party’s 2016 presidential nomination. Are you following the race so far?
lead_paragraph: More than a dozen Republicans and a handful of Democrats have announced that they are running for their party’s 2016 presidential nomination, and the second Republican presidential debate airs on Sept. 16.

headline: U.N. Urges Sri Lanka to Establish Court to Investigate War Abuses
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The recommendation came in a landmark report that detailed “horrific” crimes committed by both sides during the country’s 26-year civil war.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Rejecting Sri Lanka’s offer to set up a truth and reconciliation commission to address grievances from its 26-year civil war, the United Nations on Wednesday called for it to set up a special court, including international judges and lawyers, to investigate what it called “horrific” abuses committed by both sides.

headline: Elizabeth Gilbert’s ‘Big Magic’
abstract: Elizabeth Gilbert offers advice on pushing past obstacles to an inspired life.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Gilbert’s memoir “Eat, Pray, Love” sold 10 million copies and became the kind of cultural touchstone that makes its author famous, wealthy and controversial. To the book’s fans, including Oprah Winfrey and Julia Roberts (who starred in the movie adaptation), Gilbert’s tale of overcoming a bad divorce and deep depression by traveling to Italy, India and Indonesia in search of pleasure, devotion and balance felt like an authentic and moving search for happiness and enlightenment. To her critics, many of whom never even read it, “Eat, Pray, Love” was a cannily constructed narrative with a pat happy ending that preached personal satisfaction as the highest goal, one you could attain by throwing money around, especially in the third world.

headline: ‘Finale,’ by Thomas Mallon
abstract: This novel of the Reagan years shows how the 40th president dominated those around him without revealing himself.
lead_paragraph: Readers of “Finale,” Thomas Mallon’s sly and penetrating ninth novel, are well aware that the book’s protagonist, the nation’s 40th president, is destined to be revered as the Republican Party’s patron saint, his very name synonymous with conservative virtue. However, none of the novel’s characters know this in real time. “Finale” takes place primarily in 1986, two years after Ronald Reagan’s final triumphant campaign and two years before he vacates the White House for good. His presidential legacy is on the line, and the events of 1986 — a fateful nuclear arms meeting in Reykjavik with Mikhail Gorbachev and the brewing Iran-contra scandal — threaten to undo it. The sense of foreboding, bordering at times on panic, that pervades this work of historical fiction stands as an arresting contrast to today’s notion of the unassailable Teflon president.

headline: A Sprained Ankle May Have Lifelong Consequences
abstract: Several new studies suggest that the effect of even a single sprained ankle could be more substantial and lingering than we have supposed, potentially altering how well and often someone moves, for life.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of Americans sprain an ankle every year. But ankle sprains get little respect, with most of us shrugging off the injury as inconsequential and soon returning to normal activities.

headline: The Rituals of Modern Death
abstract: After all the poking and prodding hospital patients endure, most never know about the final steps a doctor must take to pronounce them dead.
lead_paragraph: Before I was an intern standing in the middle of the night over a pale, motionless woman about to certify her death, I had a very different vision of what a person’s final moment would be like. Like many young people, my exposure to death was confined to stories others had told me or depictions of deaths on television. I didn’t see the true face of death until I was the one filling out the death certificate.

headline: Netromancy
abstract: Technomysticism is a fittingly nebulous ideology in a time of economic and social upheaval.
lead_paragraph: When Bri Luna started her website, the Hoodwitch, she intended to carry on the legacy of her grandmother, who was a curandera: a traditional spiritual healer from Mexico. Luna, a beautician in her 20s who lives in Seattle, uses the site to publish tutorials on topics like how to cleanse a new home by burning sage and how the lunar cycles affect your daily life. What started out as a hobby became so popular that Luna turned it into a business, opening an online shop where she sells crystal clusters, bundles of dried herbs and vintage tarot guides.

headline: Should I Help a Classmate Who Sexually Harassed My Friend Get a Job?
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Careers and Professions', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The ethicists consider whether mistakes made at 18 disqualify someone from an opportunity.
lead_paragraph: At work, we fill a lot of vacant positions through word of mouth. I recently posted a job on my college’s career network and received a résumé from someone in my graduating class. I’ve never met this person, and I know him to have been a diligent student who won a prestigious fellowship during senior year. He would probably be a leading candidate, and by passing his résumé on, I would be implicitly giving my stamp of approval. The problem is that freshman year he sexually harassed and attempted to sexually assault a good friend of mine. A third party intervened before it escalated and brought her to me and another friend. She decided not to take the incident to any authority, and she eventually worked through the experience. The thought of working with the man who brought so much pain to a good friend is hard to swallow, but I do not know what the ethical thing to do is. It is not my story to share, and I do not want to bring the question to my friend for fear of opening old wounds. Am I allowed to share this information with the head of human resources? Can I take an act committed five years ago by somebody I never met and use it to determine his future job status? Is there a way to bring up my discomfort without outing him? NAME WITHHELD

headline: Barbie Wants to Get to Know Your Child
keywords: ['Barbie (Doll)', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Toys', 'Children and Childhood', 'Women and Girls', 'Robots and Robotics']
abstract: With the help of A.I., America’s most famous doll tries to fulfill a timeless dream — convincing little girls that she’s a real friend. What will happen if they believe her?
lead_paragraph: It looked like a child’s playroom: toys in cubbies, a little desk for doing homework, a whimsical painting of a tree on the wall. A woman and a girl entered and sat down in plump papasan chairs, facing a low table that was partly covered by a pink tarp. The wall opposite them was mirrored from floor to ceiling, and behind it, unseen in a darkened room, a half-dozen employees of the toy company Mattel sat watching through one-way glass. The girl, who looked about 7, wore a turquoise sweatshirt and had her dark hair pulled back in a ponytail. The woman, a Mattel child-testing specialist named Lindsey Lawson, had sleek dark hair and the singsong voice of a kindergarten teacher. Microphones hidden in the room transmitted what Lawson said next. ‘‘You are going to have a chance to play with a brand-new toy,’’ she told the girl, who leaned forward with her hands on her knees. Removing the pink tarp, Lawson revealed Hello Barbie.

headline: 1915: New York Gasps in Heat Wave
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: New York experiences a sizzler in 1915.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — To-day [Sept. 16] is a sizzler. The streets in the lower part of Manhattan between the towering skyscrapers of steel and masonry are stifling with the heat reflected from all sides as well as poured down from above. Despite the busy whirring of thousands of electric fans, offices are like stokeholds, and work is subordinated to the effort to keep cool. Café bars and soda-water fountains are besieged by crowds clamoring for cool drinks, and all pretence at correct dress has been given up in the attempt to reduce discomfort. The Herald is continuing its free distribution of ice and will keep it up indefinitely as long as the hot spell lasts. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 17, 1915

headline: 1965: Russians to Shift Space Crews
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Soviets plan to swap crews in space in 1965.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — A Soviet cosmonaut who walked in space said today [Sept. 16] that his country plans to try a midspace exchange of crews on a permanent satellite before landing a man on the moon. This disclosure by Alexei Leonov indicates that the Soviet Union is attaching a different priority than the United States to the goals of putting a man on the moon. It also opens the possibility that the Russians are thinking of sending a much bigger ship to the moon than the U.S. three-man Apollo vehicle. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 17, 1965

headline: A School With Room for Everyone at the Barre
abstract: For 32 years, Peridance Capezio Center in Manhattan has welcomed all pursuing a love of movement, from Broadway professionals to absolute beginners.
lead_paragraph: Inside Peridance Capezio Center, a 32-year-old dance school near Union Square, things can get a little crowded. The space was once a horse-auction market, and the lobby and hallways are often sardined with dancers stretching before class or catching up over blueberry chia muffins baked in the small on-site cafe. The floor-to-ceiling mirrors in each of the six dance studios reflect a constant blur of legs and leotards.

headline: Review: ‘Best Time Ever With Neil Patrick Harris’ Tries to Reinvent the Variety Show

lead_paragraph: An improv class, an automobile crash test and your cousin’s home videos somehow interbred, and on Tuesday night the result turned up on NBC in the form of “Best Time Ever With Neil Patrick Harris,” a live variety show. How can three things interbreed? Hey, if you really want to reinvent something, you have to think outside the box.

headline: Why Americans Still Think the Economy Is Terrible
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Income', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: A middle-income family is making less money in inflation-adjusted terms than 15 years ago, and new census numbers show no sign of progress.
lead_paragraph: If your entire understanding of the economy comes from headlines about the latest economic data, you would be forgiven for thinking these are the best of times. The unemployment rate is down to 5.1 percent, after all!

headline: Two Refreshing, Cool Cocktails From Fashion Week
abstract: The Simon Miller presentation featured drinks from the NoMad’s beverage director Leo Robitschek.
lead_paragraph: “It’s more of a party,” said the designer Jake Sargent about this season’s Simon Miller presentation. It was late last week, and he and his co-designer Daniel Corrigan were finalizing the one remaining detail of their spring/summer 2016 show: the drinks. “This season we’re heading back to the Southwest — but bringing in this Southwest Modernist vibe, so drawing a lot of inspiration from artists’ communities like Marfa and Santa Fe. We’re going to be offering a mezcal-based cocktail that really plays on that, and we’re also going to be offering a sake-based cocktail to speak to our Japanese side.”

headline: Big | Brave, Alexis Spight and Others Show Growth in New Albums
abstract: A look at promising records from the Montreal trio Big | Brave, the gospel singer Alexis Spight, the cellist Tomeka Reid and the singer and multi-instrumentalist Amy Bezunartea.
lead_paragraph: Big | Brave

headline: Hungarian Police Block Migrants
abstract: There were chaotic scenes on Wednesday in Horgos, a Serbian town bordering Hungary, as Hungarian police used water cannons and tear gas to stop migrants from entering the country.
lead_paragraph: There were chaotic scenes on Wednesday in Horgos, a Serbian town bordering Hungary, as Hungarian police used water cannons and tear gas to stop migrants from entering the country.

headline: France Says It Will Join Air Campaign Against ISIS in Syria
abstract: The airstrikes would represent an expansion of France’s military activity in the region, where it has already been involved in bombing Islamic State targets in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France will join the coalition of Western and Middle Eastern countries carrying out airstrikes against the Islamic State in Syria, the country’s defense minister said on Wednesday, with the first strikes likely to come in the next couple of weeks.

headline: Erroll Garner’s ‘Concert by the Sea’ Gets a New Sound
abstract: An album of a Garner performance from 1955 that influenced generations of jazz pianists is reissued and expanded.
lead_paragraph: There’s no way Erroll Garner could have foretold, from his perch at the piano on a Monday evening almost exactly 60 years ago, that he was creating one of the most popular albums in jazz history. He probably didn’t even know tape was rolling.

headline: Panel Urges More Time on Train Safety Technology
abstract: The Government Accountability Office found that the vast majority of railroads will not install the technology, known as positive train control, by Dec. 31.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress should extend the deadline for freight and passenger railroads to install technology that could prevent deadly train accidents like the Amtrak derailment in May that killed eight people and injured more than 200, according to a report released on Wednesday.

abstract: Each day during fashion week, T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Gossip: The Best Gift Your Teenager Can Give You
abstract: When your teenager drops a gossip bombshell, she’s giving you an opportunity to talk and connect.
lead_paragraph: “Hey Mom, you know Josh, the junior I played basketball with last summer? He’s selling Adderall to ninth graders.”

headline: Apple Delays Release of New Apple Watch Software
abstract: Apple said it was delaying the release of a software update to Apple Watch because of a bug in the software.
lead_paragraph: Apple postponed the release of a software update to the Apple Watch, the smartwatch it released to much fanfare, and skepticism, earlier this year.

headline: At Michael Kors, Windswept Desert Hair and Makeup
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Hair', 'September Fashion Week (2015)', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Models looked naturally sun-kissed in the designer’s spring/summer 2016 show.
lead_paragraph: Fashion has always had the ability to transport its wearer, but the dusty makeup and messy, windswept hair in the Michael Kors spring/summer 2016 show conveyed a distinct sense of place all on its own — even without the garments. Here was a woman fully immersed in the American Southwest.

headline: Silent on Priorities, Yellen Makes Fed Choice a Cliffhanger
abstract: Economists and others are pushing the Fed to keep rates near zero, citing a slow economic recovery, while some Fed officials are saying the labor market is strong enough.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, faces a crucial moment on Thursday when the Fed’s policy-making committee announces whether the time has come to start raising interest rates.

headline: Interview: Emily Blunt
abstract: The actress discusses her film “Sicaro” at the Toronto International Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: The actress discusses her film “Sicaro” at the Toronto International Film Festival.

headline: Camille A. Brown and Jaamil Olawale Kosoko Present Meditations on Black Identity
abstract: Ms. Brown’s “Black Girl: Linguistic Play” at the Joyce Theater explores black female identity, and Mr. Kosoko’s “#negrophobia” at Gibney Dance considers the fear associated with the black male body.
lead_paragraph: In “Between the World and Me,” widely considered one of the most important books of the year, Ta-Nehisi Coates analyzes the physicality of being black in America, and the burden and symbolism of the black body historically and today. Dance, the voice of the body, is in a distinctive position to contribute to this conversation, and that is especially true this week. Beginning on Tuesday, Sept. 22, at the Joyce Theater, Camille A. Brown presents “Black Girl: Linguistic Play,” which explores the broad spectrum of black female identity. Ms. Brown is a sharp storyteller, and here she illuminates her theme with infectious spirit by borrowing from the ritual of childhood games (through Sunday, Sept. 27). Starting on Wednesday, Sept. 23, Jaamil Olawale Kosoko, a Detroit-born Nigerian-American artist based in Brooklyn, brings “#negrophobia” to Gibney Dance, in which he considers the “erotic fear associated with the black male body” through a personal and a social lens (through Saturday, Sept. 26). In very different ways, both elevate, celebrate and complicate the black body. (Joyce Theater, 212-242-0800, joyce.org; Gibney Dance Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center, 646-837-6809, gibneydance.org.)

headline: ‘Fresh Off the Boat’ and ‘black-ish’ Start New Seasons
abstract: The two comedies deal with the collisions of cultures.
lead_paragraph: In a new season laden with superhumans, sorority girls and Muppets, two ABC sitcoms still offer some of television’s most piquant viewing. Both deal with the collision of cultures and the angst of assimilation. In “Fresh Off the Boat,” inspired by the life of the celebrity chef Eddie Huang, an Asian-American family jockeys for position among the lily-white country club set in Orlando, Fla. In “black-ish,” spun from the experiences of its creator, Kenya Barris, a well-off African-American father refuses to let his kids become homogenized into the bland affluence of Los Angeles.

headline: ‘Crescent to Cross’ by Richard Long Is at Sperone Westwater
abstract: The sculptor’s new work was inspired by a long walk in Spain.
lead_paragraph: The British sculptor Richard Long last year walked from the Great Mosque of Córdoba in Andalusia, Spain, to the Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela, a sacred destination in Galicia. His new work inspired by this trip is on view at Sperone Westwater in a show called “Crescent to Cross,” the title of his text about the journey. A large-scale mud installation, “Red Gravity,” is one of several works Mr. Long has made since the 1960s that originated in planned walks inscribing physical or metaphorical marks into the landscape, often recording his observations as text.

headline: Big Beer Deals
abstract: The deal between Anheuser-Busch InBev and SABMiller is the latest merger of mass-market beer brands.
lead_paragraph: The deal between Anheuser-Busch InBev and SABMiller is the latest merger of mass-market beer brands.

headline: ‘Cheap Chic,’ Manifesto of a Fashion Revolution, Is Back
abstract: Revered by young bloggers and inspiration for designers, the 1975 original, packed with advice about clothing and confidence, has long been a touchstone.
lead_paragraph: It was an imperfect, yet memorable, title for what would be the handbook to a revolution.

headline: The Death of the Party
abstract: Twenty-somethings are scaling back on the partying so heartily embraced by previous generations.
lead_paragraph: In his 1992 song “Parties in the U.S.A.,” Jonathan Richman lamented what he perceived as a decline in informal social gatherings since his 1960s adolescence.

headline: Answering Your Questions About Aspirin, Heart Attack and Colon Cancer
abstract: Well answers questions about the proposed new guidelines that recommend aspirin therapy to prevent both heart attacks and colon cancer.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, an influential medical panel issued new draft recommendations about taking aspirin to prevent heart disease and colon cancer. It was the first time a major medical organization has recommended using low-dose aspirin to ward off a type of cancer, but the guidelines from the United States Preventive Services Task Force aren’t for everyone. Here are answers to some of the questions people are asking.

headline: Few U.S.-Trained Syrians Still Fight ISIS, Senators Are Told
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The top American commander in the Middle East told the Senate Armed Services Committee that the United States would not reach its goal of training 5,000 Syrian fighters anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Only four or five Syrian individuals trained by the United States military to confront the Islamic State remain in the fight, the head of the United States Central Command told a Senate panel on Wednesday, a bleak acknowledgment that the Defense Department’s $500 million program to raise an army of Syrian fighters has gone nowhere.

headline: Mediterranean Diet Linked to Reduced Breast Cancer Risk
abstract: Women who ate a Mediterranean-style diet supplemented with extra-virgin olive oil had a 68 percent lower risk for breast cancer compared with controls.
lead_paragraph: The Mediterranean diet — rich in vegetables, fruits, whole grains and olive oil, and low in dairy products and red meat — is linked to a reduced risk for breast cancer, according to a randomized trial.

headline: The Met Considers Naming Rights, and Other Ways Forward
abstract: Peter Gelb, the Metropolitan Opera’s general manager, discussed ideas to raise money and increase its audiences, including Sunday performances and expanding the opera house’s lobby.
lead_paragraph: A bigger glass lobby stretching into Lincoln Center’s plaza. Operas on Sunday. And perhaps, following the lead of its neighboring theaters recently renamed for David Geffen and David H. Koch, slapping another wealthy donor’s name on the storied Metropolitan Opera House.

headline: Creditors Loom Over Elections in Greece
abstract: For many Greek voters, no matter the outcome of the vote on Sunday, their country’s future has already been determined by its creditors.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Inside campaign tents pitched by various political parties seeking to win over Greek voters here, including an immense one set up near Korai Square by the leftist Syriza party of the former Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, the chairs and tables were empty the other day.

headline: Bush, Bush, Baker and Others Join Advisory Panel for Eisenhower Memorial
abstract: The Eisenhower Memorial Commission adds several political heavyweights to its advisory committee.
lead_paragraph: The commission in charge of building a $142 million memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower is enlisting some big guns to help realize a project that has been plagued by controversy and delays.

keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration']

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'West Indian-American Day', 'Parades', 'Gangs']

lead_paragraph: A Cuomo administration lawyer who was shot in the head during a predawn celebration before the West Indian American Day Parade last week died on Wednesday evening, according to a family friend.

headline: Assad Calls on Syrian Rebels to Join Him in Fight Against ISIS
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria urged insurgents fighting his government to join with his forces instead in the battle against Islamic State militants.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria called on insurgents fighting his government to join with his forces instead, and do battle against the Islamic State. Only after that group is defeated can there be a political solution to the war that has devastated the country, Mr. Assad said in an interview broadcast on Wednesday.

headline: Christopher Houlihan, Organ Virtuoso, Tackles Doleful Vierne
abstract: In addition to that program at the Co-Cathedral of St. Joseph, the coming week’s offerings include staged selections of Verdi from LoftOpera at the Muse.
lead_paragraph: The young organist Christopher Houlihan has made something of a specialty of the works of Louis Vierne, the organ virtuoso whose sad life, full of illness and disappointment, was at least in part an influence on his six brooding symphonies for the instrument. On Sunday, Sept. 20, at the grand Co-Cathedral of St. Joseph in Brooklyn, Mr. Houlihan plays Vierne’s Fourth Symphony, with its aching Romance movement, on a program that also includes Bach, Saint-Saëns and the New York premiere of Patrick Greene’s “Steel Symphony,” inspired by metal sculptures at a Massachusetts museum. (3 p.m., Prospect Heights.)
