lead_paragraph: A knife-throwing accident — or is it an accident? — is the bloody beginning of “The Cruel Tale of the Medicine Man,” one of the highlights on Sunday, Sept. 20, as the always eclectic Coney Island Film Festival concludes.

headline: Festival of New Trumpet Music Embraces a Range of Sounds
abstract: This year’s kickoff, on Thursday, Sept. 24, is at Rockwood Music Hall Stage 3.
lead_paragraph: The Festival of New Trumpet Music, which folds an enormous range of original music into its embrace, was founded in 2002 by Dave Douglas, whose music tends to get sorted under jazz. Increasingly, Mr. Douglas has engaged a brain trust of fellow trumpeters to help program the event. This year’s kickoff, on Thursday, Sept. 24, at Rockwood Music Hall Stage 3, was organized by C. J. Camerieri of yMusic and Stephanie Richards of Asphalt Orchestra, and it will feature both of those style-hopping ensembles.

headline: More Evidence for Coming Black Hole Collision
abstract: A new report supports the theory that two black holes in a galaxy 3.5 billion light-years away are headed for a cosmic collision of unimaginable scale.
lead_paragraph: The apocalypse is still on, apparently — at least in a galaxy about 3.5 billion light-years from here.

abstract: Sometimes, a big Week 1 is a sign of big weeks ahead. But it can also turn out to be a flash in the pan.
lead_paragraph: When a player has a big game in Week 1, it is easy to get carried away. For some, the big week will indeed be a sign of big weeks ahead. But for many others, it will turn out to be a flash in the pan.

headline: Yasuko Yokoshi’s Dance ‘Zero One’ Is a Study of Performers’ Lives
abstract: The piece, which opens at Danspace Project, has its origins in a friendly joke.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Yasuko Yokoshi was working on a project with high school students in Fukushima, Japan, the site of the devastating earthquake and tsunami in 2011, when an idea for a dance was born. Manami Fukuoka, a dancer and former student who was assisting her, said casually over dinner one night, “I have a twin sister.”

headline: Obama Calls Out Republicans on Planned Parenthood
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Inequality', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The president took on the threat of a government shutdown over Planned Parenthood funding in a speech on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: It has become a disturbing ritual: Nearly every year since he took office and the Republicans in Congress announced that their only agenda was to block his agenda, President Obama has faced another threat to shut down the government from the right wing.

headline: Bedford Stuyvesant Restoration Center Announces Fall Arts Lineup
abstract: The Bedford Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation will bring actors, musicians and activists to Bed-Stuy for a full lineup of performances this fall.
lead_paragraph: The Bedford Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation has announced its slate of arts and cultural events for the fall, under the lens of “Project Protest: The Art of Revolution.” The lineup includes a talk with the actor Wendell Pierce, a concert by the hip-hop artist Rakim, and a premiere production of “12 Angry Men,” directed by the Tony Award winner George Faison.

headline: Richard Glossip Execution Is Halted by Oklahoma Court
abstract: The court acted with just hours to spare after lawyers produced accounts from two people that, they said, demolished the credibility of the main witness who had implicated Mr. Glossip.
lead_paragraph: Three and a half hours before he was scheduled to die by lethal injection, Richard Glossip won a two-week reprieve on Wednesday from an Oklahoma appeals court, which said it wanted time to study new evidence filed by his lawyers the day before.

headline: Video Feature: Pitch-Perfect Ways to Read Music Better
abstract: Sight-reading music is an essential skill for students of any instrument. Several apps offer confidence-building and entertaining exercises.
lead_paragraph: Like many students this time of year, my 7-year-old son has started learning a new musical instrument. His piano lessons emphasize confidence and noisemaking right now, but soon he will learn phrases like “Elephants get big dirty feet” for the notes on a musical stave and move on to more theory and instrument skills. For all the stages of his music education, there are many apps that can help.

headline: App Smart | Gamify Music Lessons

headline: Paid Leave for Moms and Dads: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Noam Scheiber offers insight into his article on Time Warner’s settlement with a former CNN correspondent who said the company’s parental leave policy discriminated against fathers.
lead_paragraph: A vast majority of companies do not provide paid parental leave to mothers or fathers, but that is rapidly changing. In 2014, only 12 percent of the companies surveyed by the Society of Human Resource Management offered paid maternity and paternity leave. This year, as the labor market tightens, those numbers are up to 21 percent and 17 percent, respectively. It’s not just at Netflix, it turns out; benefits are expanding in much of the United States economy.

headline: Breaking Down a Look at Delpozo
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2015)', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Josep Font’s spring/summer 2016 collection was inspired by Klimt’s bohemian partner and a book of Spanish poems.
lead_paragraph: When he set out to create his spring/summer 2016 collection, Delpozo’s creative director Josep Font had two distinct inspirations in mind: the “Gypsy Ballads,” by the Spanish writer Federico García Lorca — and Emilie Flöge, the bohemian partner of Gustav Klimt who, Font says, “was ahead of her time.” That translated into voluminous ruffled pants, floor-skimming dresses with tiers of tulle and large structural tops — or, as he puts it, clothes for “a modern yet passionate woman.”

headline: An Ad Blitz for Fantasy Sports Games, but Some See Plain Old Gambling
abstract: About 8,000 television spots by DraftKings and FanDuel in the N.F.L.’s opening week raised awareness of daily fantasy sports games, but critics still questioned their legality.
lead_paragraph: The average amount of actual game action over the course of a three-hour broadcast of an N.F.L. game is about 11 minutes. Fans watching the first week of this season’s games might have been struck by how much of the rest of the broadcast was filled by advertisements for the hottest product in the sports industry: daily fantasy sports games.

headline: Netanyahu to Visit Moscow Over Concerns About Russian Moves in Syria
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will meet with President Vladimir V. Putin to discuss Russia’s military aid to Syria, which Israel fears could end up in Hezbollah’s hands.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel plans to travel to Russia next week for talks with President Vladimir V. Putin about the stationing of Russian forces in Syria, Mr. Netanyahu’s office said in a statement on Wednesday.

headline: Bowe Bergdahl’s Lawyer Pushes Army to Release Report on Disappearance
abstract: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s defense team wants the Army to release the investigation summary and an interview that may address claims that soldiers died trying to find him.
lead_paragraph: Army prosecutors seeking to court-martial Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl for desertion and for endangering the soldiers ordered to search for him have disclosed that they will not try to prove at a coming court hearing that any service members were wounded or killed looking for him, or that he had sought to desert to the Taliban, according to a legal filing by the soldier’s defense team.

headline: Detroit Institute of Arts Names New Director: Salvador Salort-Pons
abstract: Mr. Salort-Pons, a curator at the museum, succeeds Graham W. J. Beal, who retired in June after leading the institution for 16 years.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Institute of Arts, which survived a near-death experience last year after creditors demanded the sale of pieces to help satisfy debts in the city’s federal bankruptcy case, announced Wednesday that it had chosen a new director from within its ranks, Salvador Salort-Pons, a curator who runs the museum’s European art department and oversees collection strategies.

keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The choice to speak in Spanish could put Pope Francis in the middle of this country’s vicious debate over what it means to be an American.
lead_paragraph: Now comes the news that Pope Francis, making his first visit to the United States later this month, intends to deliver 14 of his 18 speeches in Spanish.

headline: Obama to Host Netanyahu in First Meeting Since Nuclear Deal With Iran
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is scheduled to go to the White House on Nov. 9 to talk about the way forward now that the Iran nuclear deal has cleared obstacles in Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will host Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel at the White House on Nov. 9 in their first face-to-face meeting since their rupture over the international nuclear agreement with Iran, the White House said Wednesday.

headline: S.E.C. Judge May Have Weakened Justice Dept. Stance in Insider Trading Case
abstract: The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court to review an insider trading case, but an S.E.C. administrative judge might have undercut its argument.
lead_paragraph: The appeals court decision in United States v. Newman that reversed the convictions of two hedge fund managers caused the Justice Department to take the rare step of asking the Supreme Court to overturn what it called the “stark and overt departure from this court’s definition of insider trading.” But an opinion issued on Monday by one of the Securities and Exchange Commission’s internal judges might have undercut that argument when it found that the Newman case did not work much of a change in the law.

headline: Picking Up CCS Where Foot Locker Left Off
abstract: Daddies Board Shop, a small surf and skateboarding retailer, acquired new challenges when it bought the well-known but battered brand CCS from Foot Locker.
lead_paragraph: There’s a natural order to how small-business acquisitions typically work: Big companies buy smaller ones. But in one recent takeover, things ran in reverse — the guppy swallowed the whale.

headline: Protecting Homes Elsewhere, California Firefighters Find Their Own Burned Down
abstract: Many of the people touched by the wildfires raging across California are firefighters, and many had been battling other wildfires when the flames arrived at their own towns.
lead_paragraph: MIDDLETOWN, Calif. — Justin Galvan was out on the fire line trying to hem in a ravenous mountain blaze on the western flank of the Sierra Nevada when he got a distress call from home, 150 miles away. A wildfire had exploded in the mountains above his hometown. It had swallowed his parents’ house, and was barreling toward his own.

headline: Lineup Announced for Havana Concert
abstract: Marin Alsop and Lang Lang are among the performers in works by American and Cuban composers in a much-anticipated October concert in Havana.
lead_paragraph: A major concert in Havana being planned for next month will open with an American conductor, Marin Alsop, leading the National Symphony Orchestra of Cuba in the “Cuban Overture” by that most American of composers, George Gershwin. It will go on to feature the star pianists Lang Lang and Chucho Valdés playing together in works by the Cuban composers Ernesto Lecuona and Antonio María Romeu and the American composer James P. Johnson.

headline: 36 Hours in Boston
abstract: Boston has emerged from its brainy, introverted shell to offer a livelier mix of cultural offerings, not to mention an exploding food scene.
lead_paragraph: Boston has emerged from its brainy, introverted shell to offer a livelier mix of cultural offerings, not to mention an exploding food scene.

headline: Reliving the ’90s With the Decade’s Stars
abstract: At 90s Fest, a one-day festival of nostalgia in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, fashion and music rule.
lead_paragraph: At 90s Fest, a one-day festival of nostalgia in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, fashion and music rule.

headline: 36 Hours in Boston
abstract: Whether you wish to tour by foot, boat or bike, Georges Island, the Rose Kennedy Greenway, the HarborWalk or the Freedom Trail are fine places to start.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the area’s 50-some colleges, Boston has a reputation for hitting the books first, goofing off second. To be sure, venerable institutions like Symphony Hall, the Museum of Fine Arts and Faneuil Hall still anchor the city’s hold on music, art and history. But in recent years, this little big town has emerged from its brainy, introverted shell to offer a livelier mix of cultural offerings, plus an exploding food scene. The Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy Greenway parkland extends from the North End to Chinatown, connecting a new frontier of glass and steel construction known as the Seaport District to downtown. Of course, this is also a sports- and craft beer-obsessed city, meaning you’re never far from a Celtics, Bruins, Patriots or Red Sox fan hoisting a pint for the home team in one of the Hub’s zillion pubs. Go Boston.

headline: Lyft Announces Deal With Didi Kuaidi, the Chinese Ride-Hailing Company
abstract: The partnership will allow Lyft, which is based in San Francisco, to operate in China for the first time.
lead_paragraph: The pink mustache is coming to China. And it will receive a warm welcome — not a snub — from its new hosts.

headline: Reliving the ’90s With Pauly Shore, Lisa Loeb and Naughty by Nature
abstract: 90s Fest in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was a boozy kitschy day where nostalgia reigned.
lead_paragraph: Wearing floral-print shorts and a matching shirt, Pauly Shore took to a stage along the Williamsburg, Brooklyn, waterfront last Saturday and surveyed the crowd. “How many of you remember the 1990s?” he asked.

headline: Can Young Picky Eaters Reform? 10 Rules, and a Plan
abstract: A family with two picky school-aged kids tries to help them change.
lead_paragraph: Can 10- and 7-year-old picky eaters, accustomed to being served the easy meals they prefer, change their ways?

headline: Russia Proposes Talks With U.S. Over Syria
abstract: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov made the proposal to Secretary of State John Kerry amid tensions over Moscow’s military buildup in Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry said on Wednesday that Moscow had proposed talks between the United States and Russian militaries on the situation in Syria and the buildup of Russian forces there.

headline: Obama Hints at Sanctions Against China Over Cyberattacks
abstract: Remarks by President Obama seemed to represent a ratcheting up of what has until now been a quiet effort to warn the Chinese that the United States will not tolerate recent breaches.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama warned on Wednesday that his administration was ready to take action against China over online attacks carried out by Beijing or its proxies, publicly raising the specter of sanctions a week before President Xi Jinping arrives in the United States for a state visit.

headline: Kanye West’s Second Collection Featured Monochromes, Kardashians
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2015)', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: He presented another season of his fashion line and premiered a new song alongside the clothes.
lead_paragraph: After months of anticipation and a few raised eyebrows about the ethics of its eleventh-hour scheduling, Kanye West’s second fashion collection, Yeezy Season 2, bowed this afternoon at Skylight Modern in Chelsea. In a presentation choreographed by the performance artist Vanessa Beecroft, models emerged in phalanxes, four to 12 at a time, directed by a drill sergeant. Each group was coordinated by color (or lack thereof: the collection, based in black and tan, was highly monochromatic). Kylie Jenner and Bella Hadid modeled; “King of the Youth” Ian Connor did, too — smoking, natch — and the front row was packed with a diverse array of pals, including the rest of the Kardashian girls (North included), Common, Lorde, Courtney Love, Drake, Riccardo Tisci, Michael Strahan and Seth Meyers. And who better to score the show than Kanye’s best friend, Kanye? He debuted a new song alongside the new collection, featuring Ty Dolla Sign and Post Malone.

headline: Student Contest | Make an Editorial Cartoon
abstract: In our first Student Editorial Cartoon Contest, we are asking teenagers to make an illustration providing commentary or criticism on an issue or event. Post yours here by Oct. 20.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Sept. 13, 2016 | We have now announced our 2016 Editorial Cartoon Contest. Your can see the winners from our 2015 contest here.

headline: ‘Disgraced’ Will Be Most-Produced Play This Season
abstract: Ayad Akhtar’s Pulitzer Prize-winning drama is at the top of a list that also includes “Outside Mullingar” by John Patrick Shanley.
lead_paragraph: “Disgraced,” a Pulitzer Prize-winning play about a New York lawyer whose life is jolted by tensions associated with his Muslim heritage, will be the most-produced play around the country this theatrical season, according to a survey by American Theater magazine.

headline: Copa América’s Fate Uncertain as U.S. Soccer Skips Meeting
abstract: After four months of doubt and speculation, the United States may withdraw as the host of the event in 2016 — and may not participate at all.
lead_paragraph: After four months of doubt and speculation, all signs now point to U.S. Soccer withdrawing as host of the 2016 Copa América Centenario tournament over unresolved concerns about legal liability that emerged after several top soccer and marketing officials connected to the tournament were arrested in May.

headline: Review: ‘Heroes Reborn’ Finds Its Superhumans Again Fighting to Save the World and Themselves

lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Tim Kring has only himself to blame. When he created “Heroes” for NBC in 2006, it was something new and fresh and, for a season or two, invigorating. It opened the doors of television to comics-style storytelling and superpowered saviors, and they’ve run rampant since.

headline: Moses Malone Was Easy to Overlook but Undeniably Great
abstract: After Malone died at age 60 over the weekend, it was persuasively argued that he was the most underappreciated great player in pro basketball history.
lead_paragraph: Buried on Page 178 of “The Breaks of the Game,” David Halberstam’s illuminating 1981 book about professional basketball, is a telling and amusing passage underscoring the dumbfounding disposability of Moses Malone early in his Hall of Fame career.

lead_paragraph: Like diet and exercise, sleep is a necessary ingredient for a healthy life. But keeping yourself rested is often easier said than done. Whether you seek 40 winks or a full night’s slumber, here are some noteworthy gadgets that may help you get more out of your sleep.

headline: From South Park to the Space Station, Randy Olson Sees an ‘And, But, Therefore’ Story Solution
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'News and News Media', 'Philosophy', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: A look at a new book by Randy Olson on a formula for telling the story of science in an engaging way.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve read Dot Earth a lot, you know I’m a fan of the ultimate science-as-story coach, Randy Olson, who left a tenured job teaching marine biology to make provocative films on science controversies and then write, and write, and write about connecting science to society through storytelling.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Debt Rescue Plan Called Into Question
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The planners appeared to have overstated Puerto Rico’s financial needs, so it is seeking twice what it actually needs in concessions from creditors, a credit analyst said.
lead_paragraph: A week after the governor of Puerto Rico laid out a plan for attacking the island’s heavy debt, analysts are beginning to publicly question the proposals and even the financial assumptions on which they are based.

headline: ‘This Is It’: The California Fire, Up Close
abstract: The reporter Jack Healy provides insight into his reporting on the raging California wildfire.
lead_paragraph: Lots of natural disasters keep journalists on their periphery. Police barricades go up, neighborhoods get cordoned off and telling the story of the lives affected by a tornado, flood or fire becomes immeasurably trickier.

keywords: ['Floods', 'Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints']
abstract: Three children survived, and one 6-year-old boy was still missing after two cars were swept off a bridge Monday; six hikers were also killed nearby, and one was missing.
lead_paragraph: HILDALE, Utah — When a flash flood turned the creek into a deadly torrent here on Monday night — carrying off two vehicles full of family members and killing at least 12 — residents quickly ran to help, shoveling through the muck and debris in search of survivors.

headline: Classical Playlist: Bach, Biber, Gottschalk and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: BACH: Keyboard Concertos No. 1 to 7 (BWV 1052-59) Andreas Staier, harpsichord; Freiburg Baroque Orchestra(Harmonia Mundi)Listening to Bach’s concertos in big gulps may not be the best way to savor their myriad delights, but unless you’re a stronger person than I, you’ll have a hard time turning off the first disc of this double set after the opening D-minor Concerto (BWV 1052), with the propulsive flights of its outer movements. Or the second disc, after the opening D-major Concerto (BWV 1054), with its all-too-brief, teeming finale. Better known these days as a fortepianist, Mr. Staier draws endlessly glinting, shifting colors from his harpsichord, a beautiful-sounding 2011 copy of a 17th-century Flemish original. He delineates structure and suggests mood subtly through embellishments, agogic (rhythmic) accents and in several instances an added cadenza. Brilliant and captivating. (James R. Oestreich)

headline: Car Repairs From Deer Collisions Will Cost More
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deer', 'Automobile Insurance and Liability']
abstract: Costs per claim have risen, and drivers without comprehensive coverage are more likely to have to pay out of pocket.
lead_paragraph: The latest insurance data show that the risk of hitting a deer with your car has not changed much from a year ago. But the cost of repairing your car if you’re unlucky enough to strike one is on the rise.

headline: Jade Helm Military Exercise Ends, With Little Fanfare and Less Paranoia
abstract: The military exercise in Texas and other states had fueled conspiracy theories of a plan to impose martial law, but self-appointed monitors found little to complain about.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In the end, the soldiers rumored to be going after people’s guns handed out plaques and offered handshakes. Conspiracy theories of a military invasion, with trains to transport shackled political prisoners and Blue Bell ice cream trucks doubling as portable refrigerated morgues, fizzled as the most controversial Special Forces activity eyewitnesses saw was some service members, on a lake, on Jet Skis.

headline: For Christopher Shinn, Confronting Death Brings a New Play to Life
abstract: After battling cancer, the playwright returns to the stage with a play he thought would be his last.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — Christopher Shinn tilts back in a metal folding chair until it reaches a precarious, 45-degree angle against a wall of the Hartford Stage rehearsal room. He watches silently as the first scene of his new play, “An Opening in Time,” begins with a bam. A baseball hits the house of the main character, Anne, who steps outside, startled. She regards the ball intently. And so does Mr. Shinn. His chair looks like it may slip and crash at any moment, but he never loses focus and never goes down.

headline: Public Library Hires Dutch Firm for Renovations
abstract: The New York Public Library moves forward with a $300 million renovation project that was abandoned a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: One year after abandoning its much-disputed Norman Foster-designed renovation, the New York Public Library has selected architects for the $300 million project, which will include creating a new interior for the Mid-Manhattan branch and opening more public space in its flagship Stephen A. Schwarzman Building on Fifth Avenue.

headline: Assembly in Nepal Approves New Constitution
abstract: The new charter was supported by 507 of 601 lawmakers in the country’s Constituent Assembly. It goes into effect Sunday.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU — Nepal’s Constituent Assembly overwhelmingly approved a new Constitution on Wednesday night after years of delay because of disagreements among major political parties.

headline: Trump’s Approach Is More Like Reagan’s Than You Might Think
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ronald Reagan wasn’t shy about attacking his opponents, although a big difference was “we” and “he.”
lead_paragraph: Wednesday night’s presidential debate is at the Reagan Presidential Library, which means that candidates are going to feel obliged to mention Ronald Reagan — a lot. In 2011, candidates running for the G.O.P. nomination gathered at the same library, in Simi Valley, Calif., for the fourth debate in that contest. The eight candidates mentioned Mr. Reagan 24 times — roughly once every five minutes over all.

headline: An Installation — and a Collaboration — for the Pattern-Obsessed
abstract: The design studio Patternity and the e-invitation company Paperless Post have worked together on a series of cards, as well as an immersive pop-up.
lead_paragraph: Patternity, the London design studio of Anna Murray and Grace Winteringham, has created eye-dazzling print designs for everyone from Apple to Oscar de la Renta; their online pattern-spotting research archive is a popular, Pinterest-worthy wonder of a blog. Now, the duo’s signature vibrant geometric shapes are available to anyone hosting a fall soirée, thanks to a new collaboration with the custom-card company Paperless Post. The 11 black-and-white card designs are both arrestingly graphic and “quite celebratory,” Murray says. In tandem with the launch and London Design Week, Paperless Post and Patternity have also created an immersive installation featuring versions of the patterns — made interactive through textures, mirrors and experiments with scale — on view next week at Somerset House in London.

headline: Through Music, Jen Shyu Explores the Unknown, Including Herself
abstract: This jazz artist sings original lyrics in several languages that incorporate descriptions of Buddhist religious ceremonies, poetry and dreams.
lead_paragraph: A lot of jazz musicians are concerned with output. They have a sound or a band; a way of composing, performing or recording; they use what they already know to stay on the scene.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening in New York
abstract: Tomorrowland and Slowear move into SoHo; the Indian jeweler Nirav Modi has opened a boutique; and more.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Tomorrowland, based in Tokyo, will open its first United States boutique in SoHo. There you’ll find minimalist bits from the men’s and women’s collections, along with a curated selection of niche apparel, accessories and lifestyle brands from Japan, including Kimoto Glass barware and sculptural jewelry from Shihari. At 476 Broome Street. … Many other imports cropped up during this New York Fashion Week. Slowear, a family-owned Venetian fashion group specializing in craft-minded luxury men’s wear, has opened a SoHo outpost where you can outfit yourself from head to toe with items from its four labels, Incotex trousers, Glanshirt shirting, Zanone knitwear and Montedoro outerwear and accessories. At 116 Prince Street. … Ports 1961 debuted its first stand-alone men’s wear store, in the meatpacking district, where you’ll find the new men’s wear creative director Milan Vukmirovic’s tweaked classics like a red peacoat ($1,895) and a star camo weekender ($1,595) from his first collection shown in Milan. At 3 Ninth Avenue. … The Neapolitan tailoring specialist Isaia has a new shop with an impressive range of 112 made-to-measure garments, including a camel overcoat ($4,405) and a double-breasted wool sports jacket ($3,000). At 819 Madison Avenue. … And the Indian jeweler Nirav Modi has opened a boutique where you’ll find stunners like a Mughal flower choker and bracelet that includes 54 carats of diamonds set in 18-karat white gold and can be worn on either the wrist or neck. (Price upon request.) At 727 Madison Avenue. … On the homegrown front, the Diamond District veterans Rob Ronen and Michael Herman have opened a concept store in SoHo called Material Good. There you’ll find pieces from buzzy fine-jewelry labels like a Spinelli Kilcollin set of three linked rings in 18-karat yellow and rose gold, and pavé cognac, champagne and white diamonds ($8,000) and a Hoorsenbuhs 18-karat rose gold phantom cuff ($23,500) alongside 20th-century design objects from the likes of Jean Prouvé and Charlotte Perriand. At 120 Wooster Street.

headline: Stephen Falk on ‘You’re the Worst’ and Why He Believes in Romantic Comedies
abstract: Mr. Falk speaks about how his characters are jerks and what he learned from his “Next Caller” experience.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Stephen Falk, a TV writer and producer, created a comedy called “Next Caller.” NBC picked up the show and ordered six episodes, but canceled it before it ever aired. When he got the word, Mr. Falk took to Tumblr and wrote that the sudden notice felt like “a 10.0 earthquake,” explaining that “there is a larger discussion that has to do with network expectations” versus “the Creative’s expectations; the wisdom of holding to what you deem good vs. What They Want; making yourself laugh first.”

headline: Matthew Barney’s Most Punishing Tour: ‘River of Fundament’
abstract: A new film, almost six hours long, and a body of sculpture inspired by the film are being exhibited at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: The studio of the artist Matthew Barney in Long Island City, Queens, sits amid a collection of cookie-cutter warehouses where the most infernal sight is usually a chained guard dog, no Cerberus he. But at various times over the last several years, the studio was transformed into a version of a netherworld so hellish that even Mr. Barney, who has a stomach for such things, approached his limits. There were, for example, the dead pigs being devoured by maggots. And the eviscerated cow carcass, lying in a shallow pool. “That water was really pretty nasty by the end,” Mr. Barney recalled recently.

keywords: ['ANTIDEPRESSANTS', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Academic and Scientific Journals', 'Research', 'Paxil (Drug)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Clinical Trials', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: The study reverses an earlier conclusion that caused a long-running dispute, and opens the way for journals to post multiple interpretations of the same experiment.

headline: California’s Upward-Mobility Machine
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Pell Grants', 'Graduation Rates', 'Tuition']
abstract: The University of California enrolls large numbers of talented students from all economic backgrounds. Many other colleges are decidedly affluent.
lead_paragraph: The University of California is struggling with budget woes that have deeply affected campus life. Yet the system’s nine colleges still lead the nation in providing top-flight college education to the masses.

headline: Tory Burch: In the Studio
abstract: The designer reveals how her father influenced her collections, how personal her office is and how she balances parenthood and work.
lead_paragraph: In the second episode of our video series that goes behind closed doors and into the usually unseen working lives of designers, Tory Burch reveals the secret behind her desk, why she struggles with asymmetry and how her father influenced her collections. And those are just the conversational bits left on the cutting-room floor. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Mets’ Offense Is Silent, and East Lead Shrinks
abstract: The Marlins knocked around Bartolo Colon and Tyler Clippard, and the rookie Adam Conley helped keep the Mets scoreless as they lost a game off their division lead over the Nationals.
lead_paragraph: Yoenis Cespedes dug into the box in the sixth inning facing the type of situation he had thrived in over the previous six weeks: a 3-2 count against a rookie pitcher with a runner on base. Adam Conley, the Miami Marlins’ starter, fired a slider, and Cespedes took a big swing — and missed badly.

headline: Review: Ashley Bathgate Wraps Kate Moore’s Music Around Noguchi’s Stone
abstract: Ms. Bathgate, a cellist, played pieces including the wistful, earthy “Stories for Ocean Shells” at the Noguchi Museum in Queens.
lead_paragraph: The sculptures by the Japanese-American artist Isamu Noguchi on display at the Noguchi Museum in Queens, which he designed, highlight his interest in textural contrast. Polished surfaces and shapes chiseled in stone are juxtaposed with rough, uneven elements, these asymmetrical parts creating a balanced whole.

headline: Review: Brian Stokes Mitchell Blends Songs and Theater in ‘Plays With Music’
abstract: This theatrically far-reaching show at Café Carlyle has Mr. Mitchell playing a different role in almost every song.
lead_paragraph: In “Plays With Music,” the title of Brian Stokes Mitchell’s theatrically far-reaching show at Café Carlyle in Manhattan, the operative word is “plays.” When not inhabiting a role onstage, this most traditionally heroic of Broadway leading men reimagines songs as one-act plays performed with a childlike enthusiasm.

lead_paragraph: Audra McDonald, the star of one of this theatrical season’s most-anticipated musicals, will miss three of the first six months of performances, the production said this week.

abstract: Ben Carson, surging in the polls, was asked about topics ranging from his position in the Republican presidential race, how he would handle Donald Trump and his thoughts on climate change.
lead_paragraph: Ben Carson, surging in the polls, was asked about topics ranging from his position in the Republican presidential race, how he would handle Donald Trump and his thoughts on climate change.

headline: U.S. Said to Have Settled With G.M. Over Deadly Defect
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The deal would be in the form of a deferred-prosecution agreement, and include a penalty just under $1 billion. But no G.M. employees are expected to be indicted.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are poised to settle a criminal investigation into General Motors, according to people briefed on the matter, accusing the automaker of failing to disclose a safety defect tied to at least 124 deaths. The case, which the prosecutors plan to unveil on Thursday, would cap a wide-ranging investigation that tainted the automaker’s reputation for quality and safety and damaged its bottom line.

headline: Meeting of Anglican Leaders Could Lead to a Looser Federation
keywords: ['ANGLICAN CHURCHES', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Episcopal Church']
abstract: The Most Rev. Justin Welby, the spiritual leader of the Anglican Church, invited 37 primates to meet in Britain next January to “discuss key issues face to face.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sharply divided over issues including same-sex marriage, Anglican leaders from around the world were called on Wednesday to a meeting, planned for next year, that could lead to the transformation of the fractious global church into a much looser grouping.

headline: Dr. Deborah Asnis, Who Sounded Alert on West Nile Virus Outbreak, Dies at 59
abstract: Dr. Asnis was credited with limiting the spread of the Western Hemisphere’s first outbreak of the virus by promptly reporting puzzling symptoms in two Queens patients.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Deborah Asnis, whose suspicions about two Queens hospital patients suffering from sudden paralysis led to the discovery of the first outbreak of West Nile virus in the Western Hemisphere, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 59.

headline: Altice in Deal to Take Over Cablevision
abstract: The transaction would further realign an industry already in upheaval as cable and telecom companies seek greater scale and negotiating power with content providers.
lead_paragraph: Cablevision has agreed to sell itself to Altice, an acquisitive European telecommunications giant, for about $17.7 billion, including debt, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday. It is the latest deal to reshape the broadband and cable television landscape.

headline: A Meditation on Race, in Shades of White
abstract: Marion Palfi set out to document racism and segregation in Georgia in the 1940s. Her unpublished manuscript that followed reveals racial attitudes that were neither uniform nor without ambivalence.
lead_paragraph: Marion Palfi set out to document racism and segregation in Georgia in the 1940s. Her unpublished manuscript that followed reveals racial attitudes that were neither uniform nor without ambivalence.

headline: Antitrust Nod for Expedia to Buy Orbitz
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The Justice Department will not block Expedia’s $1.3 billion purchase of Orbitz, another travel-booking site.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department will not try to block the acquisition of the travel booking site Orbitz by its larger rival Expedia, clearing the way for the companies to complete the $1.3 billion merger announced earlier this year.

headline: Yankees Earn Tense Win After Sending Nova to Bullpen
abstract: After Manager Joe Girardi announced that Ivan Nova would be sent to the bullpen, the Yankees beat Tampa Bay behind a strong outing from Luis Severino and a home run by the rookie Greg Bird.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — In the heat of a playoff chase, the Yankees are finding that victories come as easily these days as running the bases does for 38-year-old Carlos Beltran, as lunging to catch a pop-up does for the not-quite-svelte Brian McCann and as managing another high-tension escape of his own mess does for Dellin Betances.

lead_paragraph: This season add textures and bold colors to your look with fur-trimmed bombers, comfortable cozy shoes, and beautifully understated bags.

headline: Chat Between Elton John and Vladimir Putin Was a Hoax
abstract: Two Russian pranksters took credit, and a spokesman for the Russian president said they owed the singer an apology.
lead_paragraph: When word emerged this week — via Elton John on Instagram — that Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, had called Mr. John to discuss gay rights, the possibility of some sort of accord between a leader who has gained a reputation for supporting anti-gay policies and the singer, a strong supporter of gay rights, seemed to some too good to be true.

headline: Broadway’s ‘Amazing Grace’ Will Close in October
abstract: The musical about an early abolitionist opened to weak reviews and performed poorly at the box office.
lead_paragraph: “Amazing Grace,” the first musical to open on Broadway this season, will also be the first to close: its producers announced Wednesday night that they would shutter the production next month.

headline: Syrian Refugee Tripped in Hungary Is Welcomed in Spain
abstract: The Syrian man who was tripped last week by a Hungarian camerawoman arrived in Spain, where he has been offered a job by a soccer school.
lead_paragraph: A Syrian refugee who was tripped last week by a Hungarian journalist, prompting a wave of outrage at the reporter, arrived late Wednesday in Spain, where he has been offered accommodations and a job by a soccer school in Madrid.

headline: Anti-Union Bill Fails in Missouri as G.O.P. Loses Override Vote
abstract: In a major victory for organized labor in Missouri, Republicans in the state legislature failed Wednesday to override the Democratic governor’s veto of a so-called right to work bill.
lead_paragraph: In a major victory for organized labor in Missouri, Republicans failed Wednesday to override the Democratic governor’s veto of a bill that would have allowed workers who chose not to join unions to avoid paying fees.

headline: Dewey & LeBoeuf Accounting Fraud Case Goes to Jury
abstract: The trial of three former executives of the once-prominent law firm is headed to a verdict — but jurors had plenty of questions for the judge.
lead_paragraph: The jury deliberating whether three former executives of Dewey & LeBoeuf schemed to manipulate the finances of the once-prominent law firm to defraud investors and bank lenders did not take long getting down to work.

keywords: ['Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Boards of Directors']

headline: Special Zones Proposed to Limit Toplessness in Times Square
abstract: A coalition of elected officials, property owners and business leaders have proposed setting aside areas in Times Square for cash solicitors.
lead_paragraph: The City of New York should set aside areas in Times Square exclusively for the topless painted women, costumed characters and other cash solicitors who have proliferated among the hundreds of thousands of tourists and office workers who ply the neighborhood every day, according to a report by a coalition of elected officials, property owners and business leaders.

headline: Guards Seize Interim Leaders of Burkina Faso, and Gunfire Is Heard
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: Guards held the president, prime minister and two Cabinet members hostage, less than a year since the last abrupt power grab in the African country.
lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Guards seized Burkina Faso’s interim president, prime minister and two cabinet ministers Wednesday, in what appeared to be a military coup attempt less than a year after the last abrupt power shift in this poor African country.

abstract: The high-profile sports columnist, who has frequently written about politics, has spent most of his career at the tabloid.
lead_paragraph: Mike Lupica’s future as the high-profile sports columnist of The Daily News was in doubt Wednesday when the tabloid laid off several sportswriters and its managing editor for sports.

headline: Putin Sees Path to Diplomacy Through Syria
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Russian president unleashed a diplomatic offensive this week, pushing to meet with President Obama, and planning a big rollout for a Syrian peace plan at the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — To much of the world, Syria is a scene of unending tragedy, but to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia it is a golden opportunity, a way out of the isolation he and Russia have endured since the West imposed sanctions over Ukraine — with the added bonus of wagging an “I told you so” finger at the White House.

headline: Al Bagnoli Is Building From the Bottom at Columbia
abstract: After 23 years as the football coach at Penn, Al Bagnoli is trying to turn around the program at an Ivy League rival.

A confidant told him of a rumor, down in Philadelphia, that a just-retired football coach was already getting restless. So Pilling made a phone call.

headline: New York Will Trim Common Core Exams After Many Students Skipped Them
abstract: The State Education Department said that the tests for third through eighth graders would be shortened next spring, and that they would be trimmed further in 2017.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s standardized tests for third through eighth graders will be shortened this year, the education commissioner said on Wednesday, the latest retooling of a group of exams that have grown so unpopular that 20 percent of eligible children sat them out this past spring.

headline: Review: ICE Features Levy Lorenzo on Teacups and Rebekah Heller on Bassoon
abstract: New sound possibilities were the focus of the International Contemporary Ensemble’s first concert of the new season.
lead_paragraph: The hall dims, leaving a small table bathed in the glare of a desk lamp. On the table is a black box. A pair of teacups sit, upside down, on top of it. The performer, with sincere ceremony, takes a cup in each hand. Bending his wrists, he tilts the cups on their rims, allowing light into the shadows beneath. As it strikes the lid of the box, it turns into sounds.

headline: De Blasio’s Plan to Lift Poor Schools Comes With High Costs and Big Political Risks
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio framed his $186 million commitment to help struggling schools as a way to address income inequality, but questions remain about how these programs will work.
lead_paragraph: There was $75 million a year for second-grade reading specialists. Advanced Placement classes got $51 million. Every eighth grader can take algebra thanks to $19 million. And $15 million was proposed to provide more than 16,000 students with dedicated counselors from sixth through 12th grade.

headline: After Trade, Sylvia Fowles Helps Lynx Flourish
abstract: After forcing a trade from the Chicago Sky, Sylvia Fowles is with the Minnesota Lynx, a team chasing its third title in five years.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The Minnesota Lynx traditionally break out brightly colored sneakers for the W.N.B.A. playoffs, picked by the six-time All-Star Seimone Augustus. Sylvia Fowles, who joined the Lynx in midseason, was delighted to find a royal blue pair when she arrived at practice this week.

Trump loomed large over parts of the so-called undercard debate on Wednesday when four candidates appeared at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, Calif., and moderators asked if Mr. Trump should be exempt from Reagan’s “11th commandment” not to criticize fellow Republicans.

keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Speeches and Statements']

lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Secretary General Ban Ki-moon sharply rebuked Hungary for what he called its unacceptable treatment of people fleeing war and said Russia’s stepped-up military support for the Syrian government would only make the devastating conflict worse.

headline: Giants’ Victor Cruz Misses Practice, Making Status Doubtful
abstract: Cruz, who injured his left calf in mid-August, missed the season-opening game with Dallas, and the Giants must now be weighing the option of holding Cruz out of the first three games of the season.
lead_paragraph: Victor Cruz, who has not practiced for weeks with a calf strain, remained out of practice Wednesday, which casts more doubt on whether Cruz will be ready for Sunday’s game against the Atlanta Falcons, or play this month at all.

headline: Carnegie’s Board Chairman Challenges Hall’s Artistic Director

lead_paragraph: Behind-the-scenes tensions at Carnegie Hall erupted into public view on Wednesday after Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire businessman who became chairman of the Carnegie board this year, sent an email to his fellow trustees accusing the organization’s executive and artistic director, Clive Gillinson, of a “troubling lack of transparency” and criticizing the board for failing to provide “appropriate oversight.”

lead_paragraph: Lawrence S. Phillips, a longtime executive with Phillips-Van Heusen, his family’s clothing company, and a founder of the American Jewish World Service, an aid organization dedicated to ending poverty and promoting human rights in developing countries, died on Friday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 88.

headline: Einar Ingman, Soldier Lauded for Valor in Korean War, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Ingman destroyed two machine gun nests in South Korea in 1951 despite suffering severe injuries, leading to the loss of an eye and hearing in one ear.
lead_paragraph: Einar H. Ingman, who was awarded the Medal of Honor for destroying two machine gun nests in Korea in 1951 despite suffering grievous injuries, died on Sept. 9 in Tomahawk, Wis. He was 85.

lead_paragraph: The City of New York has agreed to pay $1.25 million to settle a sexual harassment lawsuit filed by three female police officers against a lieutenant in the 44th Precinct in the Bronx, the officers’ lawyers said on Wednesday.

headline: In Chile, Earthquake Forces One Million to Evacuate
abstract: The 8.3-magnitude temblor struck off the coast, shaking buildings in cities around the country and killing at least eight people.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — A strong 8.3-magnitude earthquake struck off Chile’s coast on Wednesday, shaking buildings in cities around the country and forcing the authorities to evacuate residents along the 2,690-mile coast after tsunami warnings were issued. At least eight deaths were reported.

headline: Mexico: 2nd Missing Student Identified
abstract: The government has said that the students were hauled off buses by corrupt local police officers in the southern city of Iguala and handed over to a drug gang.
lead_paragraph: Experts have identified a bone fragment from the second of 43 missing students from a rural teachers’ college who disappeared almost a year ago in a case that has rocked Mexico. The government has said that the students were hauled off buses by corrupt local police officers in the southern city of Iguala and handed over to a drug gang, which killed them and cremated the bodies at a nearby dump. But the students have never been found, and only one, Alexander Mora, had been identified from a bone fragment that the authorities said was recovered near the dump. Attorney General Arely Gómez said Wednesday that advanced testing at the Medical University of Innsbruck in Austria had determined that another bone fragment from the site belonged to Jhosivani Guerrero de la Cruz, who was 20 when he disappeared. An outside panel of the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights said recently that the physical evidence at the dump did not support the hypothesis that the students were cremated there.

Trump on Wednesday night, seeking to elevate themselves as leaders of substance and shake up a race that Mr. Trump has dominated all summer.

headline: Max Beauvoir, Who Gave Up Science to Be High Priest of Voodoo, Dies at 79
abstract: American-educated, Mr. Beauvoir was planning a career in biochemistry when his dying grandfather anointed him a houngan.
lead_paragraph: Max Beauvoir, a former City College of New York chemistry major who gave up hard science for magic spirits, spell-casting and ritual animal sacrifices vital to becoming Haiti’s high priest of voodoo, died on Saturday in Port-au-Prince, the capital. He was 79.

abstract: The second meeting of Republican candidates often revolved around the supposedly entertaining billionaire, and that isn’t amusing.

abstract: As the Republicans prepared to take the debate stage, Mrs. Clinton took the stage in New York to tape the “Tonight Show With Jimmy Fallon” and took a phone call from Mr. Trump, as portrayed by Mr. Fallon wearing a blonde wig.

headline: G.O.P. Focus on World Affairs Reveals a Divide Among the Contenders
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'Debates (Political)', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Candidates could not agree on whether the way to deal with America’s adversaries was to engage them, or issue ultimatums and tear up the nuclear accord with Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican presidential candidates vying for attention and debating points on Wednesday night focused more intently than in their first debate on the dangers facing the United States from a violent and chaotic world. But they could not agree on whether the way to deal with America’s adversaries was to engage them, or issue ultimatums to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and tear up the nuclear accord with Iran.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9:40 A.M. (Starz Cinema) THE PATIENCE STONE (2013) In this film directed by Atiq Rahimi and adapted from his 2008 novel, a beautiful young Afghan woman (Golshifteh Farahani) confesses her fears, resentments and dreams to her comatose older husband (Hamidrez Javdan), a guerrilla fighter with a bullet in his neck. The film mirrors an Afghan myth that “had been told by women ‘as a healthy expression of their stifled feelings in a male-dominated world,’ ” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, quoting the folklorist Richard M. Dorson. Mr. Rahimi uses “universals (Man and Woman) as proxies in a battle that, as the story progresses, takes on an abstract quality,” Ms. Dargis wrote. “Yet while there may be truths in some universals, it’s hard to forget that this tale has its roots in a bitterly real world.” (Image: Ms. Farahani and Mr. Javdan.)

abstract: CNN seemed determined to get the 11 presidential candidates to spar with one another, even if it had to drag them by the wrists and tie on the gloves itself.

headline: The Elusive Truth About War on ISIS

abstract: The war against the Islamic State is being waged largely out of sight, which makes reports of manipulated intelligence particularly disturbing.
lead_paragraph: During the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, American military officials often provided misleadingly upbeat assessments of battlefield efforts and belittled reporting that contradicted their narrative. Their take on the progress of the troops was frequently at odds with the conclusions of civilian intelligence analysts and reporting by journalists in the field. The opposing views were important because they sometimes forced the Pentagon to face unpleasant truths and change course.

Dwight does it, and the audience gives a standing ovation to a manic tirade.

headline: Review: ‘Everest’ Revisits a Fateful Adventure in 3-D
abstract: Baltasar Kormakur’s film is a breathless, large-scale 3-D action spectacle about an ill-starred attempt to scale the planet’s highest peak.
lead_paragraph: “Because it’s there” is a perfectly valid justification for climbing an enormous mountain — a famous one, at any rate — but maybe not a good enough reason to see a movie. Or to make a movie, for that matter. Technically, of course, a film isn’t really “there” until someone makes it, and “Everest,” a breathless, large-scale 3-D action spectacle (directed by Baltasar Kormakur) about an ill-starred attempt to scale the planet’s highest peak, was called into being with impressive star power and technical bravura. It definitely exists. But it never seems to get anywhere, taking up space and time without managing to be especially memorable or imposing.

headline: Patrick deWitt’s ‘Undermajordomo Minor’
abstract: A tale of mystery, adventure, romance and quest, with an oddball detour.
lead_paragraph: What does it mean to say that a writer has a “take” on a genre? This question has been popping around my mind since I read Patrick deWitt’s new novel, “Undermajordomo Minor,” which is, let’s just say this straight out, quick and funny and thoughtful and moving and super. But what else is it? The book feels like a take on a certain genre — and let’s figure out what the genre is in a minute — but I’m suspicious of that phrasing, a take, which is often used to draw a divisive line. It is said, for instance, that Margaret Atwood does a take on science fiction and therefore is a literary writer instead of a science fiction writer, and then we wonder why there are so few science fiction writers who write as well as Margaret Atwood, while the science fiction writers glare at us and order another round. This is bad. “The Handmaid’s Tale” is science fiction and should not be disqualified as such on the grounds that it has good sentences and makes you think, as does the work of Patrick deWitt. Therefore, “Undermajordomo Minor” is a terrific piece of genre writing, and that’s that.

headline: What the World Got Wrong About Kareem Abdul-Jabbar
keywords: ['Basketball', 'Books and Literature', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: A long, strange day with the least understood basketball star of all time.
lead_paragraph: In the sleek, cold lobby of the Langham Place hotel in Midtown Manhattan, one of those thoroughly designed spaces in which one cannot find a right angle, much less a comfortable chair, the 68-year-old, 7-foot-2 former basketball star Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was sitting on a leather bench with his arms draped around his protruding knees. It was a melancholy pose, best suited for the solitude of a beach at night or a rocky summit after a long hike. A U.C.L.A. T-shirt and a pair of jeans hung loosely off his narrow frame. Despite having had quadruple-bypass surgery just a few months earlier, Abdul-Jabbar didn’t look all that different than he did during his last days on the Los Angeles Lakers in the late 1980s. The only evidence, really, that he had passed retirement age was a dash of white in his goatee.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: The Thorne Miniature Rooms
abstract: Model rooms at the Art Institute of Chicago can make an adult feel like a child again.
lead_paragraph: Down a center flight of marble stairs in the front entrance hall of the Art Institute of Chicago, there is a real-life time machine. It bears no resemblance, however, to any such devices from fiction. There are no displacement spheres, quantum-leap accelerators or flux capacitors; it looks nothing like H.G. Wells’s gilded time-sleigh with its gleaming dinner platter, crystal-knobbed control lever and plush velvet driver’s seat. Indeed, this particular time machine doesn’t even have space for passengers, a fact that becomes immediately apparent upon approaching it. There is only a roomful of wide-eyed drifters trying to project themselves, via intensely prolonged gazes, through a series of glass-paned portals, tilting their torsos and craning their necks as if trying to inhabit the miniature worlds beyond.

headline: 1890: Bottle Is Linked to Epidemic
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A bottle of cholera is linked to a Spanish epidemic in 1890.
lead_paragraph: The practice of leaving bottled cholera where it may fall into the hands of careless servants cannot be too strongly reprobated. It appears that the present epidemic in Spain is due to bottled cholera. A servant girl found a bottle of cholera, of vintage 1885, and carelessly emptied it into the gutter, with the result that in a short time the whole town swarmed with cholera microbes. At least this is the story told by a Spanish doctor, and it is not absolutely impossible that it may be true. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 18, 1890

headline: European Lowflation
abstract: Not looking good.
lead_paragraph: There is good reason to believe that the conventional 2 percent inflation target is too low, even for the United States; the risks of hitting the zero lower bound are clearly much higher than people believed when 2 percent became orthodoxy. But whatever the case for a higher US target, the case is much, much stronger for Europe, which combines Japan-style demography — a shrinking working-age population, making secular stagnation more likely — with adjustment problems that get much harder when inflation is low. It’s important to realize that it matters not at all whether the overall rate is slightly positive or slightly negative; as the IMF says, “lowflation” creates all the problems we associate with deflation, even if the headline number is greater than zero.

headline: Lucy’s Vietnamese Kitchen Stays Close to Its Roots
abstract: The restaurant in Bushwick, Brooklyn, a block away from the apartment where the chef grew up and still lives, is named for his grandmother.
lead_paragraph: Lucky cats beckon from storefronts across East and Southeast Asia, petal-eyed in porcelain, one paw curling up. But I’d never seen one as brazen as this tom wearing shades and cruising on a lotus blossom toward the Williamsburg Bridge. It’s a red swirl of a scene, spray-painted on the wall of Lucy’s Vietnamese Kitchen, which opened in March in northeastern Bushwick in Brooklyn.

headline: Norway Again Embraces the Vikings, Minus the Violence
abstract: “Rape and pillage are not part of the curriculum,” said the director of a government-funded course on how to live like a Norse warrior, though image redemption is.
lead_paragraph: SELJORD, Norway — Jeppe Nordmann Garly has for years been a “recreational Viking,” a keen member of a fringe fraternity of would-be Norse warriors who dress up in 10th-century clothing, attend weekend craft fairs and trade tips over the Internet on where to pick up an authentic helmet or sword.

lead_paragraph: When Dr. William Schaffner, an infectious disease specialist in Tennessee, flicked on the television last night to catch the end of the Republican debate, he watched a scene that felt unsettlingly familiar: A candidate was talking about vaccines and autism.

headline: Bigger Plates and Servings Mean People Eat More
abstract: A review of studies has found that adults consistently consume more food when given larger portions, plates or silverware.
lead_paragraph: Adults consistently consume more food when given larger portions, plates or silverware, a large review of studies has found.

headline: $900 Million Penalty for G.M.’s Deadly Defect Leaves Many Cold
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Fines (Penalties)']

lead_paragraph: As the number of deaths linked to defective cars made by General Motors has steadily risen to 124, victims’ families have waited for the answer to a burning question: How will federal prosecutors hold the automaker accountable for its decade-long failure to disclose the defect?

headline: Facts & Figures: Measuring the Debate’s Trump Factor
abstract: Other candidates mentioned Donald Trump a lot more in the second Republican debate than in the first.
lead_paragraph: It’s perhaps not surprising that Wednesday night’s second Republican presidential debate was more Trump-centric than the first. But The Washington Post has quantified exactly how much more. According to their analysis, other candidates mentioned Mr. Trump 5 times during the first debate. In the second debate, they mentioned him 27 times.

lead_paragraph: For the first time, a widely used modern diabetes drug has been shown to reduce deaths from cardiovascular disease, a long-sought goal of treatment, researchers announced on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: The death toll from California’s devastating wildfires rose to five on Thursday as officials investigated whether one of the fatal blazes had been started by a power line making contact with a tree.

headline: An Atheist Group Asks, Should New York Be in the Pope Business?
abstract: The Freedom From Religion Foundation believes the city has shown favoritism to Catholicism and has ignored the importance of separation of church and state.
lead_paragraph: When you call the Freedom From Religion Foundation in Madison, Wis., and you are put on hold, a recording of a song written by one of its founders, Dan Barker, performed to the melody of the “Battle of Jericho,” begins to play. (“I’ve heard about your hero Joshua who’s not so great/But there’s none like Thomas Jefferson and his battle between church and state.”) For 37 years, the organization has espoused the causes of atheists, agnostics and skeptics fighting laws that make days of religious observance state holidays, practices that leave public schools with pictures of Christ hanging on their walls and town councils that appropriate public money for, to cite one example, the repair of church steeples. In many instances the foundation’s work has been successful.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The head of Britain’s domestic intelligence agency, MI5, appealed on Thursday for broader legal powers to deal with advances in technologies and what he described as a more diffuse and serious terrorist threat.

headline: Daily Report: The Giant Target on Tech’s Back

lead_paragraph: The arrows are coming at American tech companies from many directions.

headline: When BFFs Are Quick to Criticize
abstract: What to do when your roommate and longtime friend just needs a hug.
lead_paragraph: My best friend and I are going through a rough patch, but I’m pretty sure she’s not even aware of it. We moved to New York after college 10 years ago and still live together. Work is going well for us; we both date. But she has been getting more and more critical of friends, potential boyfriends and co-workers every day. I hate to use the word “toxic,” but that’s what it feels like. She never stops judging. Should I extricate myself or what?

headline: 1915: Dog Knows Enemy Shell Fire
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A letter describes the curious behavior of a dog in the trenches in 1915.
lead_paragraph: A French student of physiology in a letter from the front has described the remarkable behavior of a dog which is his companion in the trenches. ‘‘We have,’’ he writes, ‘‘a sheepdog to which we are very much attached. … His affection for us is touching, and the expression in his eyes when he looks at us is indescribable. But what is most surprising is his conduct under fire. Yesterday I took him some bread. … Shells were raining all round us. One projectile shrieked by overhead. The dog retired almost shamefacedly into his kennel. … Curiously enough, when our guns fire he remains indifferent, and he appears able to distinguish between the noise made by shells fired at us and those we fire at the enemy.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 18, 1915

headline: Fact Check: Republicans Run Afoul of Medical Thinking With Autism Assertions
abstract: During Wednesday’s Republican presidential debate, Donald J. Trump said that he believes vaccines can cause autism in children, but the evidence disputes this notion.

headline: Living With Cancer: Teal Ribbons
abstract: Although progress has been made to improve treatments for ovarian cancer, it’s not nearly enough to combat a disease that often goes undetected until it is in the late stages.
lead_paragraph: “Does anyone know that September is Ovarian Cancer Month?” Antoinette Gallelli asks in “Ovarian Cancer, My Walk With It,” a memoir self-published two years ago. A banner in an infusion room reminded her of the commemoration. “The saddest thing was that I didn’t hear it on the television; in fact, I personally didn’t hear it anywhere. I would hope that in time this will change.”

headline: Printed Matter’s Shiny New Shop
abstract: This year, the storied nonprofit will move from its cramped Chelsea storefront to a larger space farther west.
lead_paragraph: For decades, one of New York’s most beloved bookshops has provided a trove of inspiration for in-the-know artists and graphic designers by selling and exhibiting rare artists’ books and rarer zines, the likes of which you’d never find at most other bookstores or even on Amazon. This year, the storied nonprofit will both turn 40 and move from its cramped Chelsea storefront to a larger space farther west. Nostalgists will miss the old sticker-plastered headquarters, but Printed Matter is dedicated to remaining as unconventional as ever, as witnessed by this month’s raucous edition of their NY Art Book Fair, a lively marketplace where bookmongers from around the globe packed into MoMA PS1 for what felt more like a music festival than a convention for bibliophiles.

headline: The Haas Brothers’ African Adventure
abstract: The furniture-designing Texan twins teamed with Monkeybiz, a collective of women from a local township called Khayelitsha.
lead_paragraph: On a trip to Cape Town in 2013, the furniture-designing Texan twins Simon and Nikolai Haas, known professionally as the Haas Brothers, were browsing the stalls at a craft bazaar when they came across toy rhinos and baboons made by Monkeybiz, a collective of women from a local township called Khayelitsha. The brothers — who make weird, stoner-chic items such as ceramics that look like toxic coral or a furry daybed named for Anna Nicole Smith — collaborated with the Monkeybiz artisans, masters of beading, to produce creatures straight out of a Maurice Sendak story. The resulting collection, Afreaks, which includes a bench with an upright tail and an 8-foot-tall sculpture of a mushroom, will make its American debut at Design Miami in December and show again at Cooper Hewitt’s Design Triennial next year. And the women of Monkeybiz? They’ve started calling themselves the Haas Sisters.

headline: Historic San Francisco Theater Getting a Makeover, New Programming
abstract: The Curran Theater is due to reopen in 2017 with an emphasis on international programming.
lead_paragraph: A California real estate heiress who has backed multiple Broadway shows is renovating a historic San Francisco theater and pledging to bring new theatrical programming to that city.

headline: Ryan Adams Confirms Release of Taylor Swift Cover Album
abstract: Ryan Adams has confirmed that his Taylor Swift cover project — a song-for-song homage to the pop star’s smash “1989” — will be released digitally on Sept. 21.
lead_paragraph: For anyone who acknowledged that Taylor Swift’s “1989” was a master class in pop songwriting but thought the album could stand to be a bit more dour and guitar-driven, there is Ryan Adams. After weeks of teasing on social media, Mr. Adams announced Thursday that his song-for-song “1989” cover album — “as played by the Smiths” — would be released digitally on Sept. 21, via his label PAX-AM.

headline: Why Chile’s Latest Big Earthquake Has a Smaller Death Toll
abstract: Though the earthquake that hit on Wednesday was strong, the reported death toll has been much lower than a 2010 earthquake and tsunami that killed hundreds.
lead_paragraph: Chile, one of the most seismically active countries in the world, has been struck by three major earthquakes of magnitude 8 or greater in the past five years. The first, in February 2010, killed 525 people, including those who died in the tsunami it spawned. But only 11 people have so far been reported killed in the latest, which struck on Wednesday.

keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States International Relations', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: President Xi Jinping will arrive on Tuesday, with meetings with tech leaders in Seattle, with President Obama in Washington, and an address to the United Nations in New York.
lead_paragraph: Xi Jinping, China’s president and Communist Party chief, arrives in the United States on Tuesday for his first state visit. For China, a priority will be bolstering Mr. Xi’s stature at home, and the events planned should play well on Chinese television. These include meetings in Seattle with American business executives, a 21-gun salute on the White House lawn and a state dinner, followed by Mr. Xi’s first speech before the United Nations in New York.

headline: Inside Zandra Rhodes’s Kaleidoscopic London Home
abstract: The British designer, known for her pink bob, returns tomorrow to London Fashion Week for the first time since 2007.
lead_paragraph: Zandra Rhodes is dressed casually for our interview — but “casual is always with jewelry and makeup,” she says. “Always.” Her makeup consists of a thick circle of blue eye shadow paired with a dark red lipstick — the same every day, because she has no time for trial and error. She wears it all night, removes it each morning and applies a new layer in its place: “I only look at myself once a day,” she says.

headline: Constance Wu Is Making Her Way in Hollywood
abstract: The actress talks about how she “Yoda’ed” her way into television and why she’s determined to bring more Asian-Americans with her.
lead_paragraph: When “Fresh Off the Boat” had its premiere in February, some viewers were nearly as anxious as they were exhilarated by the prospect of seeing the first Asian-American family sitcom in 20 years. The questions were many: Would the writers play to stereotypes about Asian-Americans or flout them? Would the show’s punch lines land at the expense of the immigrants and their experiences? And if the show flopped, would we have to wait another two decades for a show about Asian-Americans? Eddie Huang, on whose memoir the show is based, had his own concerns about the story being repackaged as “pasteurized network television.”

lead_paragraph: As the Inuit people spread across the Arctic, they developed one of the most extreme diets on Earth. They didn’t farm fruits, vegetables or grains. There weren’t many wild plants to forage, aside from the occasional patch of berries on the tundra.

abstract: The state’s two Republican majority leaders have accused 18 lawmakers of disloyalty for their votes on issues like health care.
lead_paragraph: When can democracy become a bit too much for working politicians? In Montana politics, it seems, when leaders of the state’s solid Republican legislature go to court to complain that party orthodoxy is being unfairly compromised by non-conformist and moderate G.O.P. lawmakers daring to vote for such measures as expanded government health care, greater financial disclosure in elections, and a settlement with native Americans over water rights.

headline: ‘Quirkyalone’ Is Still Alone
abstract: Singlehood is now being celebrated as a legitimate lifestyle choice, but what if you just can’t find a way to be in a serious relationship?

headline: Lawmakers Press Railroad Nominee on Safety Deadline
abstract: Sarah Feinberg, President Obama’s pick to lead the Federal Railroad Administration, faced tough questions from senators considering her nomination.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s nominee to lead the Federal Railroad Administration faced tough questioning by lawmakers on Thursday about the rail industry’s contention that it cannot meet a year-end deadline to install a safety technology meant to keep trains from derailing.

headline: ‘London Fields’ Pulled From Toronto Film Festival Over Dispute
abstract: A suit filed by the director claims the producers committed fraud by substantially changing the film without his consent and not paying him.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Toronto International Film Festival officials on Thursday said they had withdrawn the film “London Fields” from their lineup because of a lawsuit filed on Tuesday by the film’s director, Mathew Cullen, against some of its producers, including Chris Hanley and his Muse Productions company.

headline: 25 Charged in Heroin Trafficking Ring in Brooklyn
abstract: Prosecutors said the suspects, who include the leader of the group’s mother, brother and sister, also sold the drug in Queens and on Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: In South Williamsburg, not far from the popular restaurants and gleaming new condominiums that dot the fast-changing stretch of Brooklyn, the authorities said a disheveled apartment on Driggs Avenue was the hub for a heroin-trafficking operation that served the neighborhood and beyond.

headline: Contrasting Art and Creating Dialogue at Yale University Gallery
abstract: An exhibition challenges the idea that artists who work in clay are somehow working in a lesser medium.
lead_paragraph: In one area of the Yale University Art Gallery’s expansive exhibition “The Ceramic Presence in Modern Art: Selections from the Linda Leonard Schlenger Collection and the Yale University Art Gallery,” three earth-toned ceramic spheres by Toshiko Takaezu are huddled together on the floor. “New Black Moon” has daubs of black, white and green, with streaks of amber clay visible at the top. A band of muted greens, grays and oranges bisects “Small Moon #36” like an unruly equator, while a meandering crack pierces the surface of “White Moon Ball #2 (Exploded Moon).”

headline: Restaurant Review: Serving Up Conversation Starters at Le Fat Poodle
abstract: The Old Greenwich restaurant is a more elegant and expensive occupant of the space vacated by Arcadia.
lead_paragraph: People who frequently dine out are often drawn to a new restaurant because it occupies an old haunt. Le Fat Poodle, which opened in December in Old Greenwich, has replaced the former coffee bar Arcadia. But oh my, has the interior ever changed: It’s much expanded and more elegant (with higher prices, too).
