headline: A Major Exhibition for an Architect on the Rise
abstract: “Making Place: The Architecture of David Adjaye” will open at the Art Institute of Chicago on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: This Saturday, the Art Institute of Chicago will open “Making Place: The Architecture of David Adjaye,” the largest comprehensive survey of the work of the OBE-awarded British architect on the rise, which originated earlier this year at the Haus der Kunst in Munich. Culling from among over 50 projects Adjaye has built around the world, from libraries to private residences, museums, retail spaces and master city plans, “Making Place” highlights the threads and ideas that lead from one project to the next. “David is a fearless architect, an unconventional thinker, and he is committed to rethinking the possibilities of architecture,” says Zoe Ryan of the Art Institute, who co-curated the show alongside Okwui Enwezor, the Haus der Kunst’s director. It was a fruitful collaboration: “Okwui shows us the work through the lens of contemporary art and I am looking at things through the lens of design and architecture,” she explains. The exhibition aims to bring Adjaye’s projects to life through drawings, sketches, models and a film by Oliver Hardt.

headline: Top FIFA Executive Jérôme Valcke Placed on Leave Amid Corruption Investigation
abstract: FIFA announced that it would begin an ethics investigation of Valcke related to allegations of improper ticket sales. He was released from his duties “effective immediately."
lead_paragraph: Jérôme Valcke, the second-ranking official at FIFA, was placed on immediate leave and will be investigated for allegations of corruption involving the black-market sale of World Cup tickets, the association announced Thursday.

headline: The Lesson of the General Motors Settlement
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Congress needs to make it easier to bring criminal cases against people who knowingly withhold information about dangerous car defects.
lead_paragraph: General Motors has agreed to pay the government $900 million for failing to disclose a defective ignition switch that led to numerous deaths and injuries, the United States attorney for the southern district of New York, Preet Bharara, announced on Thursday. While large, the settlement cannot be satisfying to many victims and their families because it does not include charges against any G.M. engineers or executives who withheld the life-saving information from the government and the public in the first place.

headline: Why Yellen Blinked on Interest Rates
abstract: The decision to hold off suggests the Fed wants a little more evidence that the economy is truly on the mend.
lead_paragraph: It has been seven years of zero percent interest rates. What’s another two or three months among friends?

headline: Romanian Prime Minister to Face Corruption Trial
abstract: Prime Minister Victor Ponta is accused of forgery, money laundering and being an accessory to tax evasion, and will face charges in Romania’s top court.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — Prime Minister Victor Ponta of Romania was formally indicted Thursday, a first for a sitting prime minister here, and will face corruption charges in Romania’s top court.

headline: White House Warns of Traffic ‘Mess’ During Pope’s Visit to Washington
abstract: The White House expected 15,000 people to gather on its South Lawn and the nearby grassy Ellipse next week to welcome Pope Francis to Washington.
lead_paragraph: The White House said Thursday that it was expecting 15,000 people to gather on its South Lawn and the nearby grassy Ellipse to greet Pope Francis next week at an official welcoming ceremony with President Obama.

lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who faces a possible life sentence for endangering the soldiers who searched for him after he left his Afghanistan base in 2009, had a “severe mental disease or defect” at the time, one of his lawyers said Thursday.

headline: Martin O’Malley Connects With Pro-Marijuana Activists
abstract: Martin O’Malley, the Democratic presidential hopeful and former Maryland governor, sat down for a marijuana round table in Denver to discuss Colorado’s experiment with legalization.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — When Colorado voters cast their ballots in November 2012, a proposal to legalize recreational marijuana won by a larger margin than President Obama achieved in winning the state. Since then, it has become one of the hottest political and social issues in this swing state, becoming a new source of jobs and millions in tax dollars, but bringing along with it worries about stoned drivers and teenagers’ abusing the drug.

headline: Review: ‘Songs From the North’ Works to Understand a People and Their Country
abstract: The director Soon-Mi Yoo looks to penetrate presumptions of North Korea in this film, a personal essay built on three trips she took to the nation.
lead_paragraph: To the outside world, North Korea is unknowable, a nation reduced to caricature by its own isolation and by cartoonish satires like last year’s James Franco-Seth Rogen comedy “The Interview.” The director Soon-Mi Yoo hopes to penetrate such presumptions in “Songs From the North,” an essay built on three trips she took to the country and fortified by extensive use of archival material.

headline: Restaurant Review: At Acuario, Sharing in Peru’s Bounty
abstract: At Acuario, the dishes are modestly priced and generously portioned, and diners should be prepared to do a lot of sharing.
lead_paragraph: Acuario has been bringing a taste of Peru to Port Chester’s Main Street for more than eight years and at dinner the crowds pack in soon after the doors open. Families especially enjoy the huge portions and modest prices; moreover, almost every dish is plentiful enough to be shared. Seasoning and preparation could use more consistency, but this places majors in abbondanza, so plan on doing a lot of sharing or taking home a lot of leftover food.

headline: Chile Sees Extensive Damage After Earthquake and Tsunami
abstract: The magnitude 8.3 quake and ensuing tsunami left at least 11 people dead, wrecked houses and business and cut electricity for about 100,000 families.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Coastal cities in north-central Chile suffered extensive damage from the powerful earthquake that struck the region Wednesday night, according to aerial images released on Thursday by the police.

headline: The Forefather of Cat Pics
abstract: The photographer Walter Chandoha has been documenting feline antics for over 70 years.
lead_paragraph: Walter Chandoha is definitely a cat person. After photographing cats for over 70 years, he says, “Their potential for photography is unlimited. I still come up with a cat picture that is unlike any cat picture ever made — mine or any other photographer’s.” This fall, Aperture will release “Walter Chandoha: The Cat Photographer,” a collection of his cat career highlights. Chandoha’s photographs have appeared in ads for everything from cat food to shoes, in Ladies’ Home Journal and Life magazine. He opted against glamorous cat casting calls, sourcing most of his models from his own family. “The first was Loco, a kitten I picked up in the snow one night coming home from classes at NYU. He ultimately was responsible for my becoming a freelance photographer specializing in cats,” Chandoha says.

keywords: ['Detainees', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Yunis Abdurrahman Shokuri’s transfer was a small sign that the Obama administration is still trying to close the prison, despite opposition from Congress and bureaucratic turbulence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday announced the repatriation of a Moroccan man who had been held without trial at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, for more than 13 years. The transfer reduced the detainee population at the prison, which President Obama still wants to close before he leaves office, to 115 men.

headline: Review: ‘Kongo: Power and Majesty’ at the Metropolitan Museum of Art
abstract: This tight, idea-filled and troubling show offers a rare view of surviving works from the Kongo civilization on the coast of Central Africa.
lead_paragraph: Much art is made for pleasure or profit. Some is made to save lives and souls. The 15 sensational carved wood figures, standing like thorny trees in a grove, at the end of “Kongo: Power and Majesty” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, are examples of art of the rescuing kind. They are sculptural responses to a slow-motion emergency, one that shaped the history of the African continent and continues to resonate there today.

headline: Ex-Officials Urge White House to Accept More Syrian Refugees
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: The officials, some of whom served under President Obama, urged the U.S. to accept 100,000 Syrian refugees, a tenfold increase over the current commitment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 20 former senior officials, including some who served in prominent positions in the Obama administration, urged the White House on Thursday to accept 100,000 Syrian refugees, a tenfold increase over an American commitment made last week.

headline: Review: ‘Sicario’ Digs Into the Depths of Drug Cartel Violence
abstract: Denis Villeneuve’s new movie, which stars Emily Blunt and Josh Brolin, tries to paint a morally complicated picture instead of restaging a morality play.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of directors make violent movies. Denis Villeneuve makes movies about violence, which is not quite the same thing. A Canadian filmmaker equally comfortable in French and English, he is especially interested in preludes and aftermaths, in the tense moments before the eruption of violence and in the shock and confusion that follow. His framing, cutting and sound design evoke the feelings that motivate and arise from the shedding of blood: rage, grief, steely resolve and wild panic.

headline: Opening Night for ‘Arsenic and Old Lace’
abstract: The play delighted many when it opened on Broadway and was soon produced as a film, but not everyone roared.
lead_paragraph: Amy Archer-Gilligan had a habit of doing away with the residents of the Connecticut nursing home she ran early in the 20th century. She was found guilty of fatally poisoning one man but was suspected of killing many more. She was sent to live out her days in a hospital for the criminally insane, where she died in 1962. A Connecticut writer has been trying to gain access to hundreds of pages of her medical documents so he can write a book about her, but the State Supreme Court quashed his hopes this week when it ruled that the papers were not public records.

abstract: This year’s host discussed the advice he received from his former “Saturday Night Live” colleagues about the tricky task of hosting a major awards show.
lead_paragraph: This year’s Emmy Awards host, Andy Samberg, has no shortage of people to turn to for advice. A small army of his former colleagues at “Saturday Night Live,” including Tina Fey, Amy Poehler and Seth Meyers, has taken on the tricky and somewhat thankless task of hosting a major awards show.

headline: Review: ‘Prophet’s Prey,’ a Documentary About Mormon Fundamentalists
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Polygamy', 'Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints']
abstract: Amy Berg’s film chronicles the rise and fall of Warren Jeffs, the leader of the Fundamentalist Church of Latter-day Saints.
lead_paragraph: The chief attraction of Colorado City, or so it would seem from the brief entry on the website of the Arizona Office of Tourism, isn’t Colorado City but the “nearby scenic attractions” that include the Vermilion and Shinarump Cliffs. Set at the base of ravishing red cliff mountains, the city and its twin, Hildale, Utah, look straight out of Canaan. To watch “Prophet’s Prey,” Amy Berg’s tough and disturbing documentary about a secretive, polygamous Mormon fundamentalist sect with unsettling roots in the region, is to grasp, perhaps, the unspoken reason the Arizona tourism office seems to be suggesting that visitors drive right on by.

headline: Review: Wadsworth Atheneum, a Masterpiece of Renovation
abstract: After a five-year renovation, the museum is reopening the Morgan Memorial building and its European galleries.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — Hurrah. Another American museum has gotten it right, bracing against the tide of disastrous new buildings and additions that ruin and sometimes cripple so many of these institutions.

headline: ‘Girl Waits With Gun’ Tells Tale of the Charlie’s Angels of a Bygone Era
abstract: The latest book by Amy Stewart, author of “The Drunken Botanist,” is a historical novel based on the real-life story of New Jersey’s Kopp sisters.
lead_paragraph: When Amy Stewart visited the Bergen County Justice Center in July in Hackensack, N.J., she rattled off facts about the building’s old, abandoned jail that amazed even her tour guide, a police officer.

lead_paragraph: The eight small dishes and condiments served at the beginning of each meal at Seoulite’s are so full of interesting textures and flavors that they are reason enough to eat at this Korean restaurant in Berkeley Heights, one of the few in the area.

headline: Review: In ‘The New Girlfriend,’ a Widower’s Secret Life Is Revealed
abstract: The director François Ozon offers a serio-comic exploration of cross-dressing, gender fluidity and desire in his adaptation of a dark story by Ruth Rendell.
lead_paragraph: The close-up shot that opens “The New Girlfriend” evokes a glamorous church wedding, as lipstick is carefully applied to the impassive face of a beautiful woman while an organ plays a triumphal “Here Comes the Bride.” But it takes only a moment before you realize that the ceremony is really a funeral.

headline: Review: Blacka Di Danca Shakes His Way Through Borough Hall
abstract: BEAT Festival brought dancehall to office workers with a lunchtime show and class.
lead_paragraph: Employees of Brooklyn Borough Hall emerged from their offices on Wednesday afternoon to the unlikely sounds of dancehall music pulsing through the building. Down in the light-filled lobby, the dancer and choreographer Blacka Di Danca was leading a free demonstration and class in that Jamaican-born style. “I’m going to put you all in my next music video,” he shouted in time with a step called the Willie Bounce, addressing a few especially lively onlookers in the balcony.

headline: Review: Mark Grotjahn’s ‘Painted Sculpture’ Offers the Gorgeously Preposterous
abstract: The artist, who began painting on bronze casts of cardboard boxes a few years ago, goes bigger with this show at the Anton Kern Gallery.
lead_paragraph: Mark Grotjahn’s paintings have long pitted two important strands of early modernism — abstraction and masklike Expressionist faces — against each other and also against African art, to which both are so indebted. A few years ago, to his benefit, he started painting on bronze casts of cardboard boxes as well as canvas. His latest efforts, which he collectively calls “Painted Sculpture,” are gorgeously preposterous.

headline: Review: Renée Fleming, Up Close, at SubCulture
abstract: In a brief appearance with the Emerson String Quartet, Ms. Fleming sang a few of the intriguing selections from the album they made together.
lead_paragraph: Renée Fleming, when she sings, usually seems to be a football field away from her audiences at the Metropolitan Opera or Carnegie Hall. So it was a charming revelation to hear her so close up on Wednesday at SubCulture, the cozy, struggling basement space in the East Village.

headline: Review: Will Swenson Brings His Broadway Voice to 54 Below
abstract: At his New York cabaret debut, Mr. Swenson was joined for one number by his wife, Audra McDonald.
lead_paragraph: The New York cabaret debut of Will Swenson at 54 Below on Wednesday evening had one unforgettable moment. Who should join the 41-year-old Broadway singer (“Les Misérables,” “Lestat,” “Priscilla Queen of the Desert,” “110 in the Shade”) onstage but his wife, Audra McDonald? Together they delivered a tough, combative rendition of “You Don’t Bring Me Flowers,” devoid of the usual sadder-but-wiser sentimentality. As they faced one another and hurled accusations, Ms. McDonald’s eyes flashed with mock fury, and the fight culminated with her slapping him across in the face. The audience erupted with delight.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Prophet’s Prey’
abstract: The Times critic Mahohla Dargis reviews “Prophet’s Prey.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Mahohla Dargis reviews “Prophet’s Prey.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Black Mass’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Black Mass.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Black Mass.”

headline: After 22 Years of Work, Mozambique Is Free of Land Mine Peril
keywords: ['Mines, Explosive', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: At one time experts expected that it might take centuries to clear the war-scarred countryside of these deadly remnants of years of combat.
lead_paragraph: Once contaminated with tens of thousands of land mines from a legacy of war, Mozambique was officially declared cleansed of those weapons on Thursday after 22 years of work.

headline: Crazy Talk at the Republican Debate
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: It felt at times as if the candidates were no longer living in a fact-based world.
lead_paragraph: Eleven presidential candidates had three prime-time hours on the national stage on Wednesday to tell the American people why they should lead the country.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Sicario’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Sicario.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Sicario.”

headline: J Mendel’s Flowing Dresses and Geometric Prints
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2015)', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: The designer showed a spring/summer 2016 collection filled with romantic looks and bold abstractions.
lead_paragraph: The designer showed a spring/summer 2016 collection filled with romantic looks and bold abstractions.

headline: Review: ‘Swedish Wooden Toys’ Mix Ingenuity and Education
abstract: This exhibition of playthings from the 1600s to today shows off Sweden’s woodworking prowess.

headline: Steve Rannazzisi, Comedian Who Lied About 9/11, Loses Wild Wings Ad Campaign
abstract: Buffalo Wild Wings announced Thursday it was pulling an ad campaign that featured the comedian who lied about narrowly escaping from the World Trade Center.
lead_paragraph: Buffalo Wild Wings said Thursday it was pulling its TV commercials featuring comedian Steve Rannazzisi after he acknowledged this week that he had lied about narrowly escaping the 54th floor of the south tower of the World Trade Center during the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Hummingbirds Are Lovely Loners, Drawn to New York City’s Parks in Fall
abstract: The city’s most commonly seen species, the ruby-throated hummingbird (Archilochus colubris), is a tiny bird; insect-like and intricate. It is also asocial.
lead_paragraph: Hummingbirds have an ancient charisma that borders on the mythological. Humble in size, they are endowed with miraculous flying abilities vastly disproportionate to their three-inch wingspans. The birds shimmer like airborne emeralds, and with wings rendered nearly invisible at more than 70 strokes per second, they seem suspended in midair by otherworldly forces. Like fireflies, foxes, bats and toads, they inhabit both the corners of our gardens and our imaginations.

headline: Review: ‘Uncle John’ Is Steeped in Secrets
abstract: The first feature from Steven Piet unfolds with murkiness and ambiguity.
lead_paragraph: The simmering mystery “Uncle John” is so subtle, so exquisitely paced and so determined not to go in any of the obvious directions that it’s hard to believe the film is Steven Piet’s first feature. Mr. Piet, who with Erik Crary also wrote the script, sketches some memorable characters while keeping his two-pronged story sparse, ominous and deliciously ambiguous.

headline: Review: Keltie Ferris, Woman Warrior
abstract: While Ms. Ferris shows strength and aggression in her artwork, she manages to conjure the ethereal at the same time.
lead_paragraph: This has been a summer of women warriors: Serena Williams, Angela Merkel, Charlize Theron’s character in “Max Max: Fury Road,” and Shaye Haver and Kristen Griest, the first women to earn the United States Army’s elite Ranger designation. Now, in the final days of summer, painting’s warrior women are advancing, and Keltie Ferris is among them.

headline: Review: Illustrated Kimonos Celebrate Japan’s Once Mighty Military
abstract: An exhibition at Edward Thorp Gallery includes more than 30 kimonos, most from the 1930s and early 1940s.

headline: Review: ‘September Spring,’ a Multimedia Memorial
abstract: Sam Falls has created a performance installation at the Kitchen, featuring dancers on paint-smeared canvases, to honor his collaborator Jamie Kanzler.
lead_paragraph: The Kitchen is in the business of cooking up complicated multimedia work, as it does in the performance installation “September Spring.” Conceived by the Los Angeles-based artist Sam Falls, it’s a memorial to the poet and musician Jamie Kanzler, who died at the age of 24 in 2013, and whom Mr. Falls refers to as his godbrother. The two collaborated on music and book projects — as a poet, Mr. Kanzler used the nom de plume September Spring; as a musician he called himself Oldd News — and the collaboration continues in this show, organized by Lumi Tan.

headline: Review: Miguel Gutierrez’s Deep Questions in ‘Age & Beauty Part 3’
abstract: A trilogy at the Crossing the Line festival works its way backward.
lead_paragraph: This week, the 2015 Crossing the Line festival hosts a trilogy by a celebrated contemporary choreographer, which oddly works its way backward. The third installment of Miguel Gutierrez’s “Age & Beauty,” a series looking at the life of an aging gay choreographer — Mr. Gutierrez is 44 — explores the emotional toll that dance inflicts on the body and the mind.

headline: Review: ‘Captive,’ Based on a Hostage Crisis With a Spiritual Twist
abstract: This drama re-enacts killings by a prisoner at an Atlanta courthouse in 2005, culminating in a hostage-taking in which he ultimately bonded with his captive.
lead_paragraph: Why choose between product placement and plot point when you can have both at once? Based on actual 2005 events, the inspirational thriller “Captive” recounts how a fugitive, Brian Nichols (David Oyelowo), and his captive, Ashley Smith (Kate Mara), are affected at a crucial moment by Rick Warren’s best seller “The Purpose Driven Life.” The magic happens toward the end of the film, when she reads aloud to him from the book and something clicks inside his head.

headline: At Marc Jacobs, Beauty Inspired by the Morning After
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'September Fashion Week (2015)', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Beauty for the designer’s spring/summer 2016 show was made to look like models had been out all night partying.
lead_paragraph: The idea for the beauty in Marc Jacobs’s spring/summer 2016 show — from the hair and makeup right down to the sixth layer of glitter nail polish — was a fully conceived one: a girl who’s been out all night partying. She’s still glammed up — and ready to throw on her platforms and do it again. “We’re breaking all the cosmetic rules,” said lead makeup artist Francois Nars. “It’s a look you get from being out all night, sweating — without looking too undone.”

headline: The Bronx for $500,000 or Less
abstract: A sampler of available Bronx properties.

headline: On the South Bronx Bandwagon
abstract: New Yorkers looking for reasonably priced housing have set their sights on the city’s northernmost borough, particularly its southern tier.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers looking for reasonably priced housing have set their sights on the city’s northernmost borough, particularly its southern tier.

headline: The South Bronx Beckons
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Gentrification', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: The Bronx, particularly the South Bronx, has assumed the mantle of next frontier for renters, buyers and developers.
lead_paragraph: In the eight years that Anne Stewart lived in the East Village, she rarely ventured north of 23rd Street, let alone to the Bronx. But in late 2013, when a friend began apartment-hunting in an industrial section of the South Bronx, Ms. Stewart paid the area a visit. To her surprise, she found a sleepy enclave just steps from the Harlem River, with rents low enough that she and Katie Rubright could afford to move in together.

headline: Film and TV Industry Is Giving the Bronx More Screen Time
abstract: The borough, long overlooked in favor of Manhattan, has become the latest frontier for the growing presence of the film and television business in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The rat-a-tat of gunfire broke up the news conference on the steps of the Bronx County Courthouse as the crowd dived for cover.

headline: Books on Life as a Muslim in America and Urban Transportation
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Muslim Americans', 'Terrorism', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Sam Roberts describes a book about living as a Muslim in America and another about the decline of automobiles in cities.
lead_paragraph: If Moustafa Bayoumi’s “This Muslim American Life: Dispatches From the War on Terror” (New York University Press) can be sporadically preachy and sometimes hyperbolic, his essays also provide an engaging and refreshingly insightful window on the world from the perspective of an English professor of Egyptian origin at Brooklyn College.

headline: Review: In ‘Office’ by Johnnie To, Ups and Downs of Business
abstract: Set after Lehman Brothers’ collapse, Mr. To’s film, starring Chow Yun Fat and Sylvia Chang, looks at the clash between public lies and private lives.
lead_paragraph: One of the best-directed movies that you can see in New York right now isn’t playing in an art cinema but in a multiplex slab, where a pleasurably different entertainment has been slipped in among the familiar offerings. “Office” is the latest from the Hong Kong auteur Johnnie To, who, at 60, has directed more than 50 features. If you’ve heard of him, it may be because of thrillers like “PTU” and “Triad Election,” in which his peerless technique, eye for beauty and grasp of darkness flow as fluidly as his prowling cameras. If Mr. To were an American, his name would fall from lips as easily as Martin Scorsese’s, another artist alive to cinema’s past as well as its present.

headline: Theater Listings for Sept. 18-24
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Trove of ‘Letterlocking,’ or Vintage Strategies to Deter Snoops
abstract: An M.I.T. conservator has turned up ingenious examples of ways that people folded, slit or glued pages to prevent people from illicitly reading their letters.
lead_paragraph: Jana Dambrogio, the Thomas F. Peterson conservator at M.I.T. Libraries, is analyzing how letter writers have tried through the ages to keep their correspondence sealed and unread until it reached the intended recipients. She has coined the word “letterlocking” to describe methods of folding and gluing pages to deter snooping.

headline: Timex Museum Prepares to Shut Its Doors
abstract: After 14 years, Timexpo in Waterbury, Conn., dedicated to the history of the company and its clocks and watches, plans to disperse its colorful collection.
lead_paragraph: The imminent closing of Timexpo: The Timex Group Museum in Waterbury, Conn., has inspired its share of puns about doomsdays and time running out. The museum, devoted to the history of Timex and its clocks and watches, will close on Sept. 30, just 14 years after it was founded.

headline: James Lecesne, at One With the Audience and the Universe
abstract: For actor, writer and activist James Lecesne, Sundays are for chanting, riding his Schwinn along the Hudson River and performing in his one-man show.
lead_paragraph: The key to James Lecesne’s Sunday, or any day, is chanting. Mr. Lecesne, an actor, writer and activist, has been doing it twice a day since 1993, and he attributes “a certain level of happiness and determination no matter what’s going on” to it. Soon after he started, in an attempt to “make a difference” during the AIDS crisis, he said, he was offered a job at a nonprofit. This led to his meeting the director Mike Nichols, who was instrumental in producing his first show. “I got on track,” Mr. Lecesne said. He is the founder of the Trevor Project, a suicide prevention network for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender young people, and the star of a one-man play, “The Absolute Brightness of Leonard Pelkey,” which he wrote. Mr. Lecesne, 60, who is “between dogs,” lives alone in a fourth-floor walk-up in the West Village of Manhattan.

headline: Review: ‘Maze Runner: The Scorch Trials’ Pits Hardy Teenagers Against a Mysterious Organization
abstract: In the second installment in this film series, the heroes find themselves in a desolate landscape where humans have been ravaged by a deadly virus.
lead_paragraph: Science doesn’t yet know how many movies it will take to answer this century’s most pressing question: How will attractive teenagers survive the apocalypse?

headline: Letter From Ex-Officials on Syrian Refugees
abstract: The letter from ex-officials urges the White House to allocate up to $2 billion to pay for resettling Syrian refugees and help support international refugee efforts.
lead_paragraph: The letter from ex-officials urges the White House to allocate up to $2 billion to pay for resettling Syrian refugees and help support international refugee efforts.

headline: Review: In ‘Veteran,’ an ’80s Cop Comedy Vibe From South Korea
abstract: The film follows an honest detective taking on the pampered, sociopathic heir to a family-owned business conglomerate.
lead_paragraph: Ryoo Seung-wan’s “Veteran,” in which an honest detective takes on the pampered, sociopathic heir to a family-owned business conglomerate, must have had plenty of resonance in South Korea. Released in August, nine months after the daughter of the chairman of Korean Air threw a fit over a bag of nuts and blew up her career, it is already one of the 10 highest-grossing domestic films in that country’s history.

headline: Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami, Names Ellen Salpeter as Director
abstract: Ellen Salpeter of the Jewish Museum starts in Miami on Dec. 1. Sandy Skoglund’s show at Ryan Lee Gallery will bring a 1979 photograph to life.
lead_paragraph: The offices of Miami’s newest art museum are about to become more crowded: The Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami, has just appointed a new director, Ellen Salpeter, and added two junior curators.

headline: A Brooklyn Grocer’s Ripe Years
abstract: John Cortese, 91, has worked in Golden Gate Fancy Fruits and Vegetables since his father opened it in 1939, his only sojourn away to fight in World War II.
lead_paragraph: John Cortese wiped his hands on his white apron and paused over the purchase of a half-dozen zucchinis.

headline: Review: In ‘A Trick of the Light,’ the German Answer to the Lumière Brothers
abstract: Wim Wenders’s fiction-documentary hybrid introduces the Skladanowsky brothers, who shot playful scenes with a hand-cranked camera they invented in the 1890s.
lead_paragraph: France has the aptly named Lumière brothers and their Cinématographe. America has Thomas Edison and his Kinetoscope. And Germany has the Skladanowsky brothers and their Bioskop.

headline: Review: ‘Racing Extinction’ Charts the Slaughter of Vital Species
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: From the makers of “The Cove,” this documentary centers on the slaughter of creatures for profit without regard for the environmental consequences.
lead_paragraph: If you can watch “Racing Extinction” without bawling at least once, then its director, Louie Psihoyos, suggests you consider that all the tenderly photographed endangered species that flood its frames are only signposts to the disappearance of our own.

headline: From the Vault of the Roosevelt House Institute: F.D.R.’s Rarely Seen Family Photos
abstract: A copy of family photographs taken by Franklin D. Roosevelt’s oldest daughter, Anna, is at the Roosevelt House Public Policy Institute at Hunter College.
lead_paragraph: Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt’s Hyde Park home may get more press, but their double townhouse on East 65th Street was the scene of quite a lot of family drama in its own right. In 1905, Franklin’s mother, Sara Delano Roosevelt, gave the joined houses to her only child, Franklin, and his distant cousin and new wife, Eleanor, for Christmas. The recently widowed Sara Roosevelt continued to live at the Neo-Georgian-style edifice at No. 47 while the couple moved into the adjacent No. 49. Mrs. Roosevelt senior also asked the buildings’ architect, Charles E. Platt, to add several doors for easy access into the future president and first lady’s marital confines.

headline: Review: ‘Cooties,’ Back to School With Zombies and Gore
abstract: Tainted chicken nuggets in the cafeteria lead to a blood bath as teachers battle an undead uprising.
lead_paragraph: Is “Cooties” funny enough or scary enough or both to override its distastefulness? Tough call. Depends, really, on how you feel about a blood bath set in a school, a teacher beating a zombified student to death and name actors romping through the groves of gross-out humor.

headline: At DKNY, Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren, Coming Full Circle
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2015)']
abstract: A missed opportunity at DKNY; Proenza Schouler wins the day; and Calvin Klein offers intelligent glamour.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a slow ride on the fashion merry-go-round this week.

headline: Her New York, Unembellished
abstract: Jill Freedman captured overlooked subjects in black and white.
lead_paragraph: Jill Freedman captured overlooked subjects in black and white.

headline: For a Street Photographer, ‘The Weirder, the Better’
abstract: Jill Freedman photographed the hidden New York: “beggars, panhandlers, people sleeping on the street.”
lead_paragraph: Jill Freedman’s New York was invisible to most people even when she shot it. Now it is invisible even to her.

headline: Review: ‘Bonobos: Back to the Wild,’ a Sanctuary’s Rehab Mission
abstract: This docudrama looks at the efforts of a conservationist named Claudine André, who runs a bonobo sanctuary in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
lead_paragraph: “Bonobos: Back to the Wild” is an uncomfortable mix of fictionalized account and nature film, but you have to admire the work it documents.

headline: Off The Runway: Final Day
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2015)']
abstract: Scenes from the final day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the final day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Street Style: The Home Stretch
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2015)', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: New York Fashion Week is almost done, but the style on the streets stays strong.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week is almost done, but the style on the streets stays strong.

headline: Review: ‘The Cut’ Depicts the Armenian Diaspora Through a Searching Father
abstract: In Fatih Akin’s epic feature, a man survives a Turkish genocidal campaign to travel from country to country, hoping to find his daughters.

headline: Voters See Lack of Fire as Problem for Ben Carson
abstract: A number of active but uncommitted Republicans interviewed after the debate criticized Ben Carson’s performance as too passive.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Carly Fiorina hit a walk-off homer, helium is leaking from Ben Carson’s balloon and Scott Walker’s candidacy is on life support, according to the Republicans in Iowa who will cast the first votes of the nominating contest in less than five months.

headline: Review: ‘Some Kind of Hate,’ a Bullying-Revenge Slasher Tale
abstract: The blood flows and flows in this horror thriller, featuring Ronen Rubinstein and Sierra McCormick as two kids — one of them’s dead — trying to get back at their tormentors.
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Taggert, a human target and luckless hero, lives with his abusive, alcoholic biker father. His mom survives only in Lincoln’s sketches, crowned by a penciled-in halo. His school is no escape.

headline: Review: ‘Olvidados’ Revisits Rightist Terror in South America
abstract: This Bolivian film depicts a retired general who is haunted by his past role in the torture and deaths of leftist activists.
lead_paragraph: “It’s men like these that will keep the backbones of our countries straight.” In the director Carlos Bolado’s “Olvidados” (“Forgotten”), those words, a vote of confidence in two Bolivian generals, are more ominous than noble. These men are soon rolling up their sleeves to terrorize activists and anyone else considered a threat to their government.

headline: Review: ‘Hellions’ Reminds Us That Halloween Isn’t About the Candy
abstract: Demonic trick-or-treaters, spooky noises and a nod to “Rosemary’s Baby” create a fun, yet somewhat disappointing thriller.
lead_paragraph: Dora, a young woman terrorized by demonic trick-or-treaters in “Hellions,” has bigger worries than running out of candy.

headline: A Computer Problem Delays American Airlines Flights
abstract: The airline said it was investigating the cause of the problem, which grounded flights for nearly two hours, but ruled out a breach of its systems.
lead_paragraph: American Airlines flights were delayed for several hours on Thursday because of an unidentified computer problem, just weeks before the company completes its move to a single reservation system after its merger with US Airways.

headline: Madonna Returns to the Garden, Unapologetic and Playful
abstract: This singer was provocative as she performed her hits and songs from her latest album, “Rebel Heart.”
lead_paragraph: Madonna let fans see her sweat when her “Rebel Heart” tour started its two nights at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday. She belted “HeartBreakCity,” a bitter, accusatory breakup song, from a staircase as she battled the embraces of an acrobatic dancer. Then she tossed off a jacket to reveal a sweat-soaked blouse, and traded heartache for triumph with the first words — “I made it through the wilderness” — of “Like a Virgin.” She pranced and strutted through it with some moves from her 1980s videos and opened the blouse to reveal lingerie and cleavage. The lesson: Madonna the indomitable sexpot would prevail.

headline: Review: ‘The Man Who Saved the World’ Recounts a Cold War Near Miss
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Cold War Era']
abstract: This hybrid documentary centers on the life of Lt. Col. Stanislav Petrov, who was in charge of the Soviet early warning systems overnight on Sept. 26, 1983.
lead_paragraph: Accidental nuclear attacks have been the stuff of high-tech thrillers for a half-century, at least since “Fail-Safe” (1964). But this apocalyptic fiction almost became fact in 1983, averted only by the doubts of a single Soviet Union officer.

headline: Review: ‘Beauty Is a Wound,’ an Indonesian Blend of History, Myth and Magic
abstract: Eka Kurniawan’s latest novel can be read as a tale of the supernatural or a critique of a nation’s fraught colonial legacy.
lead_paragraph: If Pippi Longstocking were an Indonesian prostitute instead of a Swedish tomboy, she would be something like Dewi Ayu, who demonstrates her own can-do spirit by successfully returning from the dead in the first sentence of Eka Kurniawan’s novel “Beauty Is a Wound.”

headline: 7 Lives Intersecting With Pope Francis’
abstract: A tow-truck driver, an Argentine priest, a Super Bowl planner — all of their paths will cross with the pope’s during his visit to New York.
lead_paragraph: For the Archdiocese of New York, planning for a visit from the pope is a lot like staging a Super Bowl. And that is where Alfred F. Kelly Jr. comes in.

headline: For Pope Francis’ Mass at Madison Square Garden, God Is in the Details
abstract: Even with a directive to keep it simple, preparations for the papal visit are complex
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be Billy Joel’s 67th moment in the spotlight at Madison Square Garden. Instead, it will be Pope Francis’ first. On Friday, Sept. 25, the pope will celebrate a 90-minute Mass in the same space where Joe Frazier triumphed over Muhammad Ali during the “Fight of the Century” in 1971.

headline: Abortion Bills Advance, Setting Up a Showdown
abstract: The Senate planned to take up a ban while the House pushed ahead on stripping funds from Planned Parenthood, renewing a fight that could shut down the government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans said on Thursday that they would take up legislation outlawing all abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy, and the House voted to move forward with a bill that would end government financing for Planned Parenthood, intensifying a fight over abortion that threatened to paralyze budget talks and force a government shutdown at the end of the month.

headline: How the Lucky Few (Thousand) Got Tickets to See Pope Francis
abstract: With the pope’s arrival just days away, and the demand to see him far outstripping capacity, there have been a lot of lotteries in the New York area to fill the coveted slots.
lead_paragraph: The lottery began with a roll of dice in a conference room steps away from the pastor’s office.

headline: Carl E. Schorske, 100, Dies; Pulitzer-Winning Historian Saw Vienna as Pivotal
abstract: For Professor Schorske, a revered teacher at Princeton, the modern cultural age began in turn-of-the-century Vienna.
lead_paragraph: Carl E. Schorske, a professor and scholar whose collection of essays fixing turn-of-the-century Vienna as the radiating source of modernist thinking won a Pulitzer Prize in 1981 and remains an exemplar of cultural history, died on Sunday in East Windsor, N.J. He was 100.

headline: Suit Alleges ‘Scheme’ in Criminal Costs Borne by New Orleans’s Poor
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Local Government', 'Poverty', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A class-action lawsuit says fines and assessments are applied without regard for ability to pay — to the benefit of judges, prosecutors and public defenders.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Late at night, after the lawyers had gone home, Alana Cain washed the floors at a downtown firm. One morning, a ring disappeared; Ms. Cain, 26, was charged and eventually pleaded guilty. The judge ordered her to pay $1,800 in restitution. He also imposed roughly $950 on top of that in court fines and fees.

headline: Marc Jacobs: Spring 2016 RTW
abstract: See Mr. Jacobs’s spring 2016 collection, the last show of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: See Mr. Jacobs’s spring 2016 collection, the last show of New York Fashion Week.

headline: The Fed Gives Growth a Chance
abstract: By holding steady on interest rates, the Federal Reserve is acknowledging, correctly, that the economy shows no signs of overheating.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve did the right thing on Thursday when it opted not to begin raising interest rates. By holding steady, the Fed is acknowledging, correctly, that the economy shows no signs of overheating. Price inflation, for example, has been below the Fed’s 2 percent target for years and shows no signs of accelerating.

headline: Carlos Beltran, Once Central to Mets, Is Now a Key Figure for Yankees
abstract: Carlos Beltran, who was a central figure for the Mets the last time they carried playoff aspirations, is helping the Yankees with a second-half surge as they battle for the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: For anyone who was unaware that the Yankees are locked in a playoff race at a point in the season when each pitch carries added gravity, there were a couple of unmistakable signs on Wednesday at Tropicana Field.

headline: Meeting the Pope After a Fight for Better Pay
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Day Laborers', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Organized Labor', 'Car Washes']
abstract: A carwash worker in Queens got higher wages after a labor battle that began more than three years ago. He will be part of a group meeting with Pope Francis next week.
lead_paragraph: The modern carwash is a minor marvel. A car sits on a track and is pulled past purifying machinery: A grid of pipes shoots high-pressure streams of water, then soap; flapping, jiggling cloths lower from tracks to slather every inch of the car body; spinning brushes rise along the sides, to begin the drying, and then a wide vacuum rides just over the hood and roof to suck the water away.

headline: Finger-Pointing, but Few Answers, After a Syria Solution Fails
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The White House distanced itself from a fruitless effort to train a Syrian opposition army to fight ISIS, but critics maintained the plan had been implemented poorly and too late.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By any measure, President Obama’s effort to train a Syrian opposition army to fight the Islamic State on the ground has been an abysmal failure. The military acknowledged this week that just four or five American-trained fighters are actually fighting.

headline: Verbatim: Hillary Clinton Suggests White House Moving Too Slowly on Keystone
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has declined to take a position on the Keystone XL pipeline until the Obama administration decided whether to back it, told a voter in New Hampshire that she would not wait forever.
lead_paragraph: — Hillary Rodham Clinton, seeming exhausted at the end of a long day of campaigning in New Hampshire, responding to a voter who asked about the Keystone XL pipeline project (“My favorite topic!” she said), which she has previously declined to take a position on until the Obama administration decided whether to back it.

lead_paragraph: Sunny Mehta has been a musician, a professional poker player and an author, and he has worked in finance. He has lived in New Orleans, Chicago, Miami and Las Vegas.

headline: U.N.: Boko Haram Mayhem Has Displaced 1.4 Million Children
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Fear of attacks by the extremist group of northern Nigeria has uprooted a half-million children in the past five months, Unicef said in a report released Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Fear of attacks by Boko Haram, the Islamist extremist group of northern Nigeria known for its deadly marauding and kidnappings, has uprooted a half-million children in the past five months, Unicef said in a report released Thursday.

headline: Iran Released Top Members of Al Qaeda in a Trade
abstract: Five men were released as part of a prisoner swap in March with Al Qaeda’s branch in Yemen. Iran denied that the men had been freed.
lead_paragraph: The government of Iran released five senior members of Al Qaeda earlier this year, including the man who stepped in to serve as the terrorist group’s interim leader immediately after Osama bin Laden’s death, and who is the subject of a $5 million bounty, according to an American official who had been briefed on the matter.

headline: Trial for Robert Menendez, New Jersey Senator, Is Delayed
abstract: Mr. Menendez’s lawyers vowed to go to the Supreme Court to have the charges dismissed, arguing that the federal case was tainted from the beginning.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — A federal judge delayed the trial of Senator Robert Menendez on corruption charges on Thursday as the senator’s lawyers vowed to go to the Supreme Court in their bid to dismiss the charges against him, potentially pushing the trial back a year.

headline: The Dolans, the Clan That Built the Cablevision Empire, Say Goodbye
abstract: The fractious family that has loomed large over New York City is bidding goodbye to the company that caused so much angst, and made them rich.
lead_paragraph: Starting with 1,500 subscribers on Long Island more than 40 years ago, the Dolan family built one of America’s cable fortunes.

headline: Milo Hamilton, 88, Dies; Brought Baseball, Including Aaron’s Homer, to Life
abstract: Hamilton called baseball for seven major league teams over 60 years and was best known for calling Henry Aaron’s 715th home run.
lead_paragraph: Milo Hamilton, who called baseball for seven major league teams over 60 years and was best known for calling Henry Aaron’s 715th home run, died on Thursday in Houston. He was 88.

headline: A Hero’s Welcome at the White House
abstract: Alek Skarlatos, Spencer Stone and Anthony Sadler received official thanks at the White House and the Pentagon for their role in foiling a terrorist attack in France last month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fresh from foiling a terrorist attack, receiving the French Legion of Honor and fox-trotting on “Dancing With the Stars,” Alek Skarlatos, a specialist in the Oregon National Guard, was celebrated at the White House and Pentagon on Thursday with two boyhood friends and fellow heroes.

lead_paragraph: Since regular-season interleague baseball made its debut in 1997, the Mets and the Yankees have played each other every season.

headline: Liberty Relying on Epiphanny Prince to Return to Her Old Ways
abstract: After arriving in an off-season trade, Epiphanny Prince helped the Liberty to the top seed in the Eastern Conference, but the team’s coach expects more from Prince, who once scored 113 points in high school.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a lifetime ago, Epiphanny Prince scored 113 points in a high school basketball game. Her phenomenal performance in 2006 broke a record set by Cheryl Miller, who had scored 105 points.

headline: After Debate, Republicans Try to Alter Perceptions of Their Performance
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin and Jeb Bush were among those working to shine up their images in appearances and calls with supporters on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, N.H. — As Republican presidential candidates tried to put their best spin on Wednesday night’s debate, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, who has faltered in the polls, went to extra lengths on Thursday to cast his mixed performance in a positive light, urging donors to buttress an all-out push to win the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Warren Murphy, Writer and Creator of Remo Williams, Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Murphy, who co-authored the gritty thriller “Created the Destroyer” with Dick Sapir in 1963, wrote many more novels and had credits for movies like “Lethal Weapon 2.”
lead_paragraph: “Everyone knew why Remo Williams was going to die,” was how Warren Murphy and Dick Sapir began “Created, the Destroyer,” their first gritty thriller, in 1963.

headline: Review: A Modern Makeover for ‘Iphigenia in Aulis’
abstract: A humorously made-over Greek chorus is one of the twists in Anne Washburn and Rachel Chavkin’s version of Euripides’ play.
lead_paragraph: Enter flouncing, the ladies of the chorus. They are wearing flower-festooned headgear that Carmen Miranda might have thought appropriate for an Easter parade, with festive smiles to match. Granting that a few of these women are men in skirts, they otherwise would have fit right into a Broadway musical frolic of the 1930s, harmonizing and hoofing cheerfully behind a star like Ethel Merman.

headline: Review: ‘Hamlet in Bed’ Is Michael Laurence’s Shakespearean Take
abstract: Michael Laurence wrote and stars in this play, in which his character is a Hamlet-obsessed actor who wants to find his birth mother.
lead_paragraph: A former actor with a bleeding passion to play Shakespeare’s Danish prince — and to find his mother, who gave him up for adoption — leads us on his peculiar personal odyssey in “Hamlet in Bed,” a two-character play written by and starring Michael Laurence at the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater.

headline: Review: In ‘The Christians,’ a Schism Over Fire and Brimstone
abstract: Lucas Hnath’s depiction of a conservative congregation wrestling with radical new ideas mirrors what’s happening now in churches across the country.
lead_paragraph: Religious beliefs evolve, just as people do, in ways good and bad. But they rarely change quite as suddenly as in “The Christians,” Lucas Hnath’s softly mesmerizing drama about a schism that arises in an evangelical megachurch. In this terrific play about the mystery of faith, and how religion can tear people apart just as it can bring them together, a revelation experienced by the pastor causes a potentially disastrous rupture in the congregation.

lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — How many times has this happened to you?

headline: 2 Rikers Guards Set Up Attack on Inmate, Officials Say
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Assaults', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The charges against Officers Nakia Gales, 39, and Herman Jiminian, 41, include assault, falsifying records and official misconduct for their suspected role in the January 2014 attack.
lead_paragraph: Two Rikers Island correction officers face charges that they settled a personal score against an inmate by orchestrating an assault on him by a group of four other inmates and falsifying paperwork to cover up their role in the attack, officials said on Thursday. The four inmates were also charged.

headline: Judge’s Ruling Awards $600,000 to Exploited Workers
keywords: ['Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Abuse of the Disabled', 'Courts and the Judiciary']

lead_paragraph: More than six years after their rescue from virtual servitude, in which they worked for little pay in a turkey processing plant while living in a decrepit Iowa schoolhouse, more than two dozen men with intellectual disabilities will share nearly $600,000 owed to them, after a federal court order issued Thursday in Dallas.

headline: Woman Testifies That Manhattan Prosecutor Choked Her at Bar
abstract: The woman said that an assistant district attorney, Eli Cherkasky, assaulted her at a pub last Halloween after she yelled at him for touching her belongings.
lead_paragraph: The quarrel came in a long night of drinking and carousing at an Irish pub in Manhattan last Halloween, and as is often the case, the cause was trivial. An assistant district attorney, dressed as Clark Kent, was searching fruitlessly for his coat after hours of partying with friends and he picked up a woman’s purse and scarf.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Global markets were largely down on Friday after the United States Federal Reserve signaled fresh concerns over slowing growth in China and other emerging markets.

headline: Bridgeport Mayor Vows to ‘Fight Like Heck’ After Losing Primary Election
abstract: Mayor Bill Finch said he wouldn’t easily give up control to Joseph P. Ganim, a former mayor who shocked political watchers by winning the Democratic nomination even though he had been convicted of taking kickbacks.
lead_paragraph: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — The day after Democratic voters propelled Joseph P. Ganim one big step closer to joining the ranks of comeback mayors, this city’s incumbent mayor, Bill Finch, said he would not easily give up control to Mr. Ganim.

headline: Lana Del Rey: She’d Be Sad, if She Cared (Which She Doesn’t)
abstract: On her new album, “Honeymoon,” Ms. Del Rey strikes a pose of cool so refined, she’s frosty.
lead_paragraph: Lana Del Rey looks out into the world and all she sees are stares. Cold faces, eyes hard with judgment. And lights, too — sharp beams that poke like needles and cut like lasers. For years, she has been scrutinized as intently as she’s been listened to. You would not blame her even a bit for wilting.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) FURY (2014) An American tank crew — its leader, Sgt. Don Collier (Brad Pitt), a.k.a. Wardaddy, and his motley crew (Michael Peña, Jon Bernthal, Shia LaBeouf and Logan Lerman) — fights its way across Germany in the spring of 1945 as the Nazis retreat toward Berlin in Hitler’s suicidal last stand. Children are conscripted and uncooperative parents murdered. And while the Allies may have momentum, the Germans still have plenty of tanks, many superior to the Americans’. David Ayer, whose drama is less an epic than a series of tense episodes, “has a way of filming violence that is both intense and matter-of-fact,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Like many other post-‘Saving Private Ryan’ combat movies, this one emphasizes the chaotic immediacy of battle, staking its claim to authenticity on the unflinching depiction of bloodshed: Heads are vaporized by mortar rounds. Limbs are severed by bursts of automatic-rifle fire. Human flesh is charred by flames and shredded by shrapnel. But within this gore-spattered, superficially nihilistic carapace is an old-fashioned platoon picture, a sensitive and superbly acted tale of male bonding under duress.” (Image: Mr. Lerman, left, and Mr. Pitt.)

abstract: After witnessing the dangerous journey of migrants traveling from the Arab Spring to Italy in 2011, the photographer Guilio Piscitelli spent the next four years chronicling the refugee crisis.

Behind them were wars and revolutions. Ahead was the Italian island of Lampedusa, and the promise of a safer life in Europe.

headline: Mexico’s Fruitless Hunt for Justice
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Missing Persons', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Drug Cartels', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: The investigation into the disappearance of 43 students last year shows deep flaws in the system.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Sept. 26 will mark a year since one of the most heinous crimes in modern Mexico, when police officers and drug cartel hit men are believed to have abducted 43 students and killed another six students or passers-by in the town of Iguala. There have been even bigger mass killings by cartels in the past, also involving the security forces who are supposed to be fighting them. But the Iguala attacks caused far more outrage because they targeted students, the police were on the front line, and they were close to the capital.

headline: The G.O.P. Plays Loser’s Poker
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Fiorina will not wear well; she’s a terrible candidate in the age of income inequality and a battered middle class.
lead_paragraph: You can’t out-crazy Donald Trump. You can’t best him in half-truths that sound plausible just because you say them with forceful bluster. You can’t be scarier to Latinos than the man who threatens to round them up like stray cattle. And you can’t offend half the population more than the puffer-fish-faced plutocrat who dismisses less-attractive females as “fat pigs,” while bragging that he used to sleep with “the top women in the world.”

The good-humored social worker makes his way through hundreds of lanky construction workers clustered around a chai peddler as they wait for contractors to ride up on motorcycles and hire them for the day.

We were only a mile outside Edinburgh, but thanks to David, my Norwegian-American boyfriend, and Jurgen, the Norwegian speaker on David’s GPS, I already felt deep into Viking territory.

headline: My Crush on Pope Francis
abstract: A writer describes how His Holiness stole her heart.
lead_paragraph: The unusually broad appeal of the charismatic 266th pontiff, a.k.a. the Francis Effect, is well documented. Sparking new hope for the Roman Catholic Church through a more forgiving stance and a genial, media-friendly persona, Pope Francis has inspired lapsed parishioners to return, while extending, for lack of a better term, the fan base to those who aren’t Roman Catholic, Christian or even particularly religious.

headline: Europe’s Dangerous Ambivalence
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: It’s election time again in Greece, where the continuing economic crisis and the influx of refugees reflect the same fundamental structural paradox.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — FOR the first time in years, Greece’s debt problem and the challenge this poses to the eurozone’s integrity have been upstaged — pushed aside by the surge of refugees entering the European Union, most of them through Greek islands just off the Turkish coast. For us Greeks, however, as we prepare to vote on Sunday in our second national election this year, the prospect of our political impasse continuing makes us almost oblivious to the human river flowing northward through our country.

headline: How to Draw Like a Police Sketch Artist
abstract: Start with the shape of the head. Be open to changes.
lead_paragraph: Sketching a likeness for a wanted poster is the easy part, according to Stephen Mancusi, a detective who worked as a forensic artist for the New York Police Department for almost 27 years. Getting a witness to describe the face of a perpetrator is the more difficult and nuanced skill. Start by taking five or six minutes to pencil in the shape of a head of average proportions. A face tends to equal five eye-lengths across, while the width of a mouth is about the distance between pupils. Draw quickly: The movement of graphite on paper can be hypnotic. ‘‘People lose themselves watching,’’ Mancusi says. As they do, they relax and remember.

headline: ‘Fish in the Sky’

headline: A Stout for All Seasons
abstract: At the right temperature, this dark beer can be as refreshing as it is cozy.
lead_paragraph: Even in my long-­ago earliest drinking days, I had a hunch that porter was the drink for me. It seemed like the liquid equivalent of how I liked to see myself: earthy and reliable, but also undeniably dark.

headline: Life on the Papal Beat
abstract: A journalist reflects on covering the Vatican over the years, and how Pope Francis has, and has not, changed the institution.
lead_paragraph: In the two short years since his election, Pope Francis has managed an unusual feat: He has become as beloved by the international news media and the secular intelligentsia as by his own flock of 1.2 billion. I got a taste of what has been called ‘‘the Francis effect’’ when, on a sweltering July day, I watched dozens of mayors from around the world gather at the Vatican for a two-day conference on climate change.

headline: When Is a Lease Not a Lease? When It’s an iPhone
abstract: Apple’s new “financing” plan — a lease in all but name — makes available for phones a payment structure that is more familiar in the auto market.
lead_paragraph: APPLE is offering a new way for consumers to purchase iPhones, and while the company is calling the new system a “financing” plan, it is essentially a lease. The idea is to get people to constantly trade in their one- or two-year-old phones for the newest models. And Apple is employing a tactic similar to one that luxury carmakers use to get more people driving Mercedes-Benzes, BMWs, Audis and Lexuses that they could otherwise not afford to buy: creating a monthly payment that is appealingly low.

lead_paragraph: KENEMA, Sierra Leone — Under the hot midday sun, Erison Turay was lecturing his teammates before their first game. “Do not look happy,” he told them, as they stood there in their matching black T-shirts with the words “I Survived Ebola” in large white and red letters. “We must be serious. We must play as a remembrance for those that aren’t here.”

headline: 1890: Actor Dion Boucicault Dies
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The actor and author, Dion Boucicault dies in 1890.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Mr. Dion Boucicault, the well known actor and dramatic author, died of pneumonia to-night [Sept. 18] at his residence in this city. He had for many years dwelt among us and his genial face and flowing white locks were a familiar feature at every first night. For some time past Mr. Boucicault had conducted a school of dramatic art from which he turned out some of our most promising young actors and actresses. It had been noted within the last two or three years that the veteran was getting a little stiff in his movements, but the cheery voice and jaunty Irish manner never left him to the last. His death will prove a severe shock to the profession, of which during a lifetime he was a leading ornament. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 19, 1890

headline: Steve Paxton to Receive Bessie Award for Lifetime Achievement

lead_paragraph: For many years, “Eugene M. Jewell” was just a name inscribed on a metal bracelet that I, like so many others, wore in the 1970s.

headline: Popcast: Jen Shyu Explores the Unknown
abstract: Times critics discuss the jazz artist whose music incorporates poetry and dreams.
lead_paragraph: Times critics discuss the jazz artist whose music incorporates poetry and dreams.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Chrissie Hynde, whose rock ’n’ roll memoir, “Reckless,” is No. 7 on the hardcover nonfiction list, recently said she is not very gender-driven: “A good book is a good book. A good song is a good song.”
lead_paragraph: Female Acts: Chrissie Hynde’s rock ’n’ roll memoir, “Reckless,” about life as the lead singer of the Pretenders, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 7, taking its place in a wave of recent titles from the women of rock: Patti Smith’s “Just Kids,” which won the 2010 National Book Award, spent 46 weeks on the hardcover and paperback lists; Kim Gordon’s “Girl in a Band” logged a month this year; and Jewel’s “Never Broken” has just been released. Books are also on the way from Carrie Brownstein, Sinead O’Connor and others. “This is the era of the female act,” the former Rolling Stone editor (and current president of Blue Rider Press) David Rosenthal told The Washington Post this month. “Maybe that has caused overall a hunger for reading about female artists.” Maybe it has. But Hynde told The Post that gender isn’t a big part of the equation for her. “A good book is a good book. A good song is a good song,” she said. “Let me hear it, let me read it. I’m not very gender-driven.” Hynde grew up in a fairly conservative family in Akron, Ohio, and managed, apparently, to hide the more lurid elements of her rock ’n’ roll lifestyle from her mother and father. “I couldn’t have told this when my parents were alive,” she writes in a brief prologue to the memoir. “I would have had to leave out the bad language and tell a lot of lies about what I’d been doing all that time I was gone.”

headline: Burkina Faso Military Says Ousted Leaders Have Been Released
abstract: The president and interim prime minister have been released from detention after a coup put Gen. Gilbert Diendéré in charge.
lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Burkina Faso’s interim president, Michel Kafando, and prime minister, Isaac Zida, who were ousted in a coup this week, have been released from detention, a military spokesman said on Friday. Protests continued in the capital, Ouagadougou.

headline: Popcast: Jen Shyu and Musical Inspiration
abstract: Times music critics discuss the jazz artist, who sings original lyrics in several languages that incorporate descriptions of Buddhist religious ceremonies, poetry and dreams.
lead_paragraph: Jen Shyu, whose new album “Songs and Cries of the World” comes out this week, is an improvising singer of great accomplishment who leads a band including some of the best improvising musicians in the United States: the trumpeter Ambrose Akinmusire, the violist Mat Maneri, the bassist Thomas Morgan, the drummer Dan Weiss. But she gets much of her inspiration and source material from far outside jazz. Not from pop or classical music or avant-garde traditions. But from music that she has to travel great distances to learn about, like Southern Taiwanese folk songs; or pansori, the South Korean musical storytelling tradition; or sindhenan, the improvisational singing of Javanese gamelan music. (A lot of the music she’s looking for has something to do with her own background: raised in Illinois, her parents are from Taiwan and East Timor.) She achieves fluency in new languages in order to improvise within them; she studies their narrative traditions in order to write within them.

headline: The College Access Index: A Promise to Critics
abstract: Some university administrators say the available data on economic diversity is too imperfect to be meaningful. The Upshot’s editor responds.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Coming-of-Age Novels
abstract: New books by Naomi Jackson, Emma Jane Unsworth and Sara Jaffe.
lead_paragraph: THE STAR SIDE OF BIRD HILL By Naomi Jackson 298 pp. Penguin Press, $25.95.

headline: ‘The Social Sex: A History of Female Friendship’
abstract: A historical look at women’s friendships and the social forces that have shaped them.
lead_paragraph: Friendship is a bond that is uniquely defined by the people who exist within it. Unlike relationships such as marriage or parenthood, which have clear timelines and boundaries, friendships have no ceremonial beginning or end, no biological definition. They are not sanctioned by any church, nor recognized officially by any state. This is perhaps why women, historically diminished by the government and burdened by the family, find such fulfillment and power among friends.

headline: Friends of Long Standing
abstract: Several women at The Times recommend their favorite fiction on the theme of female friendship.
lead_paragraph: With Ann Friedman taking on friendship in nonfiction (in her review of Marilyn Yalom’s “The Social Sex: A History of Female Friendship”), I thought I’d ask several women at The Times to recommend their favorite fiction on the same theme.

headline: Friend of Dylann Roof Pleads Not Guilty to Charges in Charleston Shooting
abstract: A federal grand jury accused Joseph C. Meek Jr. of withholding information in the investigation of Mr. Roof, who has been charged with killing nine inside a church.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — A friend of Dylann S. Roof, the man charged in the June 17 massacre at an African-American church in Charleston, S.C., entered a plea of not guilty on Friday to charges of lying to investigators and concealing information about the attack, which killed nine people.

headline: Alison Light’s ‘Common People: In Pursuit of My Ancestors’
abstract: Alison Light’s family research illuminates a swath of British working-class history.
lead_paragraph: This is a richly peopled book. Alison Light prefaces it with nine family trees, and these include some 200 names — the host of Georges and Arthurs and Walters and Alberts, as well as the Mary Anns and the Sarahs and the Elizas that we shall find traced and placed, saved from anonymity, identified, set in the context of their times.

headline: ‘The Lost Landscape,’ by Joyce Carol Oates
abstract: Joyce Carol Oates looks to her childhood and beyond in tracing the roots of her vocation.
lead_paragraph: Joyce Carol Oates is an ambivalent memoirist. In “The Lost Landscape: A Writer’s Coming of Age,” she repeatedly ex­presses her doubts about first-person autobio­graphical writing. For one thing, she’s deeply wary of the confessional voice. For another, she has little faith in the reliability of memory. While she can vouch for the accuracy of “A Widow’s Story,” her 2011 account of the aftermath of her first husband’s death, which she based on contemporaneous journals, she can hardly back up this latest memoir with documentation. No small child, not even a Joyce Carol Oates, could be expected to take notes all day. Yet another problem: The memoirist is obliged to leave things out. “To charges of distortion,” she writes, “I can only say — mea culpa.”

headline: ‘Succession,’ by Livi Michael
abstract: A novel of the women in the wings of the Wars of the Roses.
lead_paragraph: The Wars of the Roses might be having a moment. George R.R. Martin cheerfully admits to tailoring his “Game of Thrones” novels after the events of the 30-year conflict between the House of York and the House of Lancaster, whose “sigils,” as Martin would have it, were the white rose and the red. The United States could be heading for a dynastic collision, Clinton versus Bush. And the full-pomp reinterment last March of Richard III’s remains, discovered in 2012 beneath a parking lot in Leicester, placed a sad punctuation mark on a saga that’s now more than half a millennium old.

headline: A Song for Naldo
abstract: A song from Jen Shyu courtesy of Pi Recordings.
lead_paragraph: A song from Jen Shyu courtesy of Pi Recordings.

headline: Ceridwen Dovey’s ‘Only the Animals’
abstract: These stories are narrated by the spirits of animals.
lead_paragraph: Ceridwen Dovey studied social anthropology at Harvard before writing her debut novel, the celebrated “Blood Kin” (2007). She continued her studies at New York University afterward, and has now brought an anthropologist’s eye to her second book, the story collection “Only the Animals.” Her subject is not human societies, however, but the relationship between humans and other species. And why not? As J.M. Coetzee says in one of Dovey’s epigraphs, “Each creature is key to all other creatures.”

headline: ‘Sweet Caress,’ by William Boyd
abstract: An Englishwoman forges her way as a professional photographer in William Boyd’s latest novel.
lead_paragraph: It’s always interesting to see an author write against his or her own experience — an Asian writing as a European, a civilian woman writing as a male Marine or, really, any writer suddenly adopting a distinctly different voice. So it’s very interesting to read William Boyd’s “Sweet Caress,” written not only in the voice of a woman but of a woman born more than four decades before the author.

headline: Matt Bell’s ‘Scrapper’
abstract: In Detroit, a salvager seeks vengeance against a boy’s kidnapper.
lead_paragraph: The haunting jacket of Matt Bell’s memorable second novel, “Scrapper,” features the skeletal silos and shafts of a factory through the broken windows of the Fisher Body Plant No. 21, not far from the cloverleaf interchange of I-75 and I-94 in Detroit. Like many locations in the city, this decaying site contains a multitude of histories: Built in 1919, it originally manufactured Buick and Cadillac bodies; during World War II, it produced parts for bombers, tanks and other military equipment; at one point, the factory held a soup kitchen and homeless shelter. Today it stands vacant, most of its metal innards stripped by scrappers, and the monolithic structure is deemed contaminated by the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: Kyung-sook Shin’s ‘The Girl Who Wrote Loneliness’
abstract: A novel’s narrator pries open her shuttered, traumatic past.
lead_paragraph: Kyung-sook Shin’s “The Girl Who Wrote Loneliness” begins with an unnamed novelist writing in isolation on Korea’s Jeju Island. She informs us of a recent call from an old friend, someone who has read her work and says, “You don’t write about us. . . . You seem to write quite a lot about your childhood, and also about college, and about love, but there was nothing about us.” Rattled, the novelist looks back on her teenage years. Why indeed hasn’t she written about her classmates and friends from that time?

headline: School for Slaughter
abstract: Saul Black’s new thriller is about an interstate manhunt for a killer whose modus operandi is so bizarre even his own accomplice can’t figure it out.
lead_paragraph: Cover your eyes — this one’s really nasty. Not even cookie-­baking moms and their innocent children are spared in THE KILLING LESSONS (St. Martin’s, $25.99), Saul Black’s thriller about an interstate manhunt for a killer whose modus operandi is so bizarre even his own accomplice can’t figure it out.

headline: ‘Daddy Long Legs’ at the Davenport
abstract: Megan McGinnis and Paul Alexander Nolan star in a musical about pen pals from Jean Webster’s 1912 novel best known as a 1955 movie with Leslie Caron and Fred Astaire.
lead_paragraph: Arachnophobes have no reason to fear “Daddy Long Legs,” the small and by most accounts quite cuddly production that opens at the Davenport Theater on Sept. 28. Staged by the British director John Caird (“Les Misérables,” “Nicholas Nickleby”), this two-character chamber musical concerns not a creepy-crawly but a plucky orphan girl and her anonymous, avuncular benefactor.

lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — The golden hour on this late September afternoon was anything but. The air was hot and hazy, the sky the color of the industrial concrete buildings doubling as the set of the F.B.I. Academy.

headline: Eerily Similar Dresses From Different New York Designers
abstract: During fashion week, three looks from various collections seemed related — but weren’t.
lead_paragraph: During New York Fashion week, which wrapped up last night, three very different designers showed three very similar dresses. White as canvases and printed with colorful, watercolor-like designs, Adam Selman’s slip dress, Adam Lippes’s elegant silhouette and Marc Jacobs’s long-sleeved sheath suggest that come spring/summer 2016 the worlds of art and fashion will continue, as they’re wont to do, to collide.
