headline: The Met, the Myth: Searching for Noah Syndergaard’s Viking Roots in Denmark
abstract: In Haderslev, where few people follow baseball, some historians said it was possible that Syndergaard, nicknamed Thor, could trace his lineage to Vikings.
lead_paragraph: HADERSLEV, Denmark — More than 120 years ago, Simon Hansen Sondergaard left this town in southwest Denmark for the United States. He settled in Iowa, along with four of his five siblings, where he farmed and raised a family.

headline: A Junkyard in the Adirondacks
keywords: ['Explosions (Accidental)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: One company has a terrible idea for disposing of old oil tank cars: Dump them in the Adirondack Park.
lead_paragraph: After deadly and destructive explosions of oil tank cars in recent years, the federal government began requiring new, somewhat safer tankers to carry the explosive Bakken crude oil across the country.  Let’s hope that this is progress.  The problem now for those who transport this highly-combustible oil is what to do with the big outdated tankers.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Court and the World’
abstract: This week, John Fabian Witt talks about Stephen Breyer’s new book; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Mira Jacob discusses three new coming-of-age novels; Sam Tanenhaus reminisces about the podcast; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

abstract: A decision on separating top roles at the bank is less about who is chairman and more about how shareholders’ decisions are valued.
lead_paragraph: It’s Corporate Governance 101: Company directors are supposed to respect the wishes of the shareholders they are duty bound to serve. And if the directors defy them, those shareholders are supposed to hold the directors accountable.

headline: VW Is Said to Cheat on Diesel Emissions; U.S. to Order Big Recall
keywords: ['Diesel Power', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Frauds and Swindling']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday directed Volkswagen to recall nearly a half-million cars, saying the automaker illegally installed software in its diesel-power cars to evade standards for reducing smog.

headline: 1965: Kosygin Offers To Mediate
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Soviet Premier Alexei N. Kosygin offers to mediate in India-Pakistan war, 1965
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Soviet Premier Alexei N. Kosygin has proposed that Indian Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri and Pakistani President Mohammed Ayub Khan come to the Soviet Union to try to settle the undeclared war between their two countries, the news agency Tass announced tonight. Tass said Mr. Kosygin ‘‘could take part in such a meeting if India and Pakistan wished this.’’

lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Zoran Milanovic said Croatia was showing its neighbors it has a heart, but must also show it has a brain in dealing with the recent influx of Syrian migrants.

headline: With ‘The Intern,’ Nancy Meyers Keeps Exploring Women’s Relationships
abstract: Over a 35-year career in Hollywood, Ms. Meyers has told the stories of men and women at work and in love.
lead_paragraph: It was a line of dialogue that provoked volcanic laughter, echoed through bedrooms for a decade or two, and announced a distinctive comic voice.

headline: From EyeEm, Technology to See and Tag Photos
abstract: As large tech giants look for ways to make it easier to find photos online, the Berlin-based start-up has released technology that uses a sophisticated algorithm and machine learning to help people find images online by analyzing the details of each photo.
lead_paragraph: A little-known German start-up may have just made it a lot easier to search for photos online.

headline: Roland Emmerich’s ‘Stonewall’ Finds Controversy
abstract: The film’s trailer was immediately met with backlash from those who say the movie misrepresents who was actually at the riots in 1969.
lead_paragraph: The trailer for the drama “Stonewall,” due in theaters on Friday, Sept. 25, focuses on a fictional young, blond, white gay Midwesterner named Danny who arrives in New York City and soon becomes a leader in the historic uprising by lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender patrons of the West Village bar the Stonewall Inn in response to a police raid on June 28, 1969. During the roughly two-minute trailer, the tag line “inspired by the incredible true story of the unsung heroes whose courage broke down walls” scrolls dramatically across the screen.

headline: ‘The Walk’ Replays Philippe Petit’s High-Wire Act — but Was It Art?
abstract: The new movie with Joseph Gordon-Levitt reopens the debate about what Mr. Petit’s famous 1974 walk between World Trade Center towers meant.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Gordon-Levitt still has his ticket stub from a visit to the World Trade Center in July 2001. He was 20 years old and a fresh transplant from Southern California, doing what millions of tourists had done before him but few would do after. “I remember being up there,” he said recently. “There were clouds below you.” He likened it to being “halfway to the cosmos, not in a building that’s rooted on earth.”

headline: Garlic Soup That’s in a Rush
abstract: Based on a Provençal recipe, this meal requires a minimal number of staples and can be on the table in 30 minutes.
lead_paragraph: When the day gets away from me and I’m hungry but (uncharacteristically) haven’t given dinner a thought, I turn to garlic soup. Its very existence makes me feel secure. I know that a delicious dinner can be on the table in 30 minutes.

headline: With Help From Kickstarter, Chicago Gets a Museum That Relishes the Hot Dog
abstract: The Foodseum in Chicago will showcase encased meats in a new exhibit. Other museums in the city will have special programs and deals in October.
lead_paragraph: Foodseum opens its first exhibition, “The Hot Dog and Encased Meat of the World,” on Saturday at Block 37 in Chicago’s Loop; it runs through Dec. 20.

headline: ‘Finders Keepers,’ the Story of a Gnarled Leg and the Lives It Altered
abstract: The documentary “Finders Keepers” analyzes two North Carolina men who wrangled over an amputated limb.
lead_paragraph: The 911 call was unlike anything ever heard in Maiden, N.C., or probably anywhere else.

headline: A Fresh Look at ‘Daniel,’ ‘The Confession’ and the Trials of the Cold War
abstract: Sidney Lumet’s “Daniel” and Costa-Gavras’s “The Confession,” new on Blu-ray and DVD, are similar movies in many ways.
lead_paragraph: Sidney Lumet’s “Daniel” (1983) and Costa-Gavras’s “The Confession” (1970), new on Blu-ray and DVD from Olive and Criterion, are in some ways mirror images of each other — each has each been accused of distorting its subject.

headline: A Toxic Work World
keywords: ['Work-Life Balance', 'Women and Girls', 'Parenting', 'Paid Time Off', 'Family Leaves']
abstract: Only the young and childless can keep up.
lead_paragraph: FOR many Americans, life has become all competition all the time. Workers across the socioeconomic spectrum, from hotel housekeepers to surgeons, have stories about toiling 12- to 16-hour days (often without overtime pay) and experiencing anxiety attacks and exhaustion. Public health experts have begun talking about stress as an epidemic.

lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Receding NAIRU
abstract: Always a bit lower than where we are.
lead_paragraph: I began my apprenticeship in economics as a research assistant to Bill Nordhaus, who was working on energy at the time (check the acknowledgments), and one thing I remember was the continual frustration over the failure of alternatives to conventional crude oil to materialize. That’s all changed now, of course; but at the time people used to cite “Weitzmann’s Law”, which said that the cost of alternatives to oil was 40 percent above the current price — whatever the current price happened to be.

lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The Malaysian authorities on Friday prevented a member of the governing party from traveling to New York, where he had planned to urge American law enforcement officials to investigate a sovereign wealth fund headed by Malaysia’s prime minister.

lead_paragraph: Lela Moore is a news assistant and comment moderator.

lead_paragraph: For her first show in London in seven years, the fashion designer worked with traditional Malaysian fabrics in a plethora of prints.

headline: Humanity as a Competitive Advantage
abstract: As technology advances, people will need qualities such as empathy, care, attunement, self-awareness and generosity to get ahead.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, I flew from New York to Boston and took off a full day to see a doctor about a medical condition I have. I went to these lengths because I understood him to be perhaps the world’s expert in this particular syndrome.

headline: Irving Police Chief Defends Response to Ahmed Mohamed’s Clock
abstract: The father of Ahmed, 14, said his son would withdraw from MacArthur High School in Texas, where his homemade clock was mistaken for an imitation bomb.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Ahmed Mohamed, the 14-year-old high school student who was detained and handcuffed for bringing to school a homemade clock that was thought to be a fake bomb, was “overwhelmed” and is now “a little fatigued” from an eventful week, his father said on Friday.

headline: Donald Trump Cancels Appearance at Conservative Forum
abstract: Donald J. Trump said a pending business transaction caused him to cancel a planned appearance at a presidential candidate forum being held by the conservative group Heritage Action in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump canceled a planned appearance at a South Carolina presidential candidate forum being held Friday by a conservative group, citing a business transaction he had pending.

headline: Remembering a Force for Transformation in Hartford
abstract: Nick Carbone, who died this week, had a talent for forging diverse coalitions and a passionate determination to revive his hometown.
lead_paragraph: A call came out of the blue this week from a man I haven’t spoken to in 30 years. After the pleasantries, Dick Suisman delivered the sad news: Nick Carbone, the legendary politician from Hartford, Conn., had died of leukemia at the age of 78.

headline: Georgia Tech’s Odd Problem: Its Defense Needs a Tight End
abstract: The defense has to be creative when preparing for opponents, like Notre Dame this weekend, because it does not have a conventional college offense to practice against.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — There is an ample collection of running backs at Georgia Tech — 22 of them to be precise. There are also 13 former high school quarterbacks, many of them recruited because they were usually the best athletes at their high schools and capable of playing multiple positions.

headline: A Condo Near MoMA for $23 Million
abstract: A full-floor sponsor apartment at the Baccarat Hotel and Residences was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A full-floor aerie near the top of the Baccarat Hotel and Residences, a new glass tower in Midtown by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill that sits opposite the Museum of Modern Art, sold to an unidentified buyer for $23,289,760.64 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: An Oboist and Administrator Changes Orchestras
abstract: The president of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra announced he was leaving to run the Orchestra of St. Luke’s. He has played as an oboist in both ensembles.
lead_paragraph: James Roe was an oboist in the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra before he became its president and chief executive in 2013. Now he is moving on to lead another ensemble with which he once performed as a player: the Orchestra of St. Luke’s, which announced on Friday that Mr. Roe would become its president and executive director on Dec. 1.

headline: New Ecotourism Tours in Sarasota
abstract: The debut tour, “Inspired Sarasota Bay,” departs Oct. 25 and will take guests to bays, islands and beaches, showcasing the environmental heritage of Sarasota Bay.
lead_paragraph: Bays and Birds Ecko, a new ecotourism nonprofit program based in Sarasota, Fla., is offering a series of outdoor tours to highlight the Gulf Coast’s natural and cultural diversity. The debut tour, “Inspired Sarasota Bay,” departs Oct. 25 and will take guests to bays, islands and beaches, showcasing the environmental heritage of Sarasota Bay. Additional trips this year include the Manatee River area; the Myakka River, including portions that are not generally open to the public; Gulf Coast birding; and urban wildlife viewing by bike.

headline: Family Pond Boils at Center of a ‘Regulatory War’ in Wyoming
keywords: ['Clean Water Act', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Land Use Policies', 'Environment', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: Andy Johnson’s watering hole has become an emblem for conservatives and local governments fighting the reach of the federal government.
lead_paragraph: FORT BRIDGER, Wyo. — The sun was sinking and the brook trout were biting, so Andy Johnson and his daughter Aspen, 6, stepped onto their sun-bleached pier, hooked some mealworms and cast their lines into the most infamous pond in the West.

headline: Everett C. Parker, Who Won Landmark Fight Over Media Race Bias, Dies at 102
abstract: Dr. Parker won a landmark broadcasting case and led a civil rights crusade to hold stations accountable for presenting racially biased programming.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Everett C. Parker, who won a landmark broadcasting case and led a civil rights crusade to hold television and radio stations accountable for presenting racially biased programming and for failing to hire blacks and other minorities, died on Thursday in White Plains. He was 102.

headline: Watching the Fed, and Remembering the Tequila Crisis
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Twenty years ago, a series of rate increases by the Federal Reserve put pressure on emerging markets like Mexico, which had to be bailed out by the United States and the I.M.F. Could it happen again?
lead_paragraph: Lots of buzz concerning the impact of higher interest rates in the United States. A major trading partner creating shock waves in the global economy. Stock market volatility spreading around the world.

headline: Marie Kondo on the Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up — With Kids
abstract: How do you work the “life-changing magic of tidying up” when you’re surrounded by un-tidiers?
lead_paragraph: About a year ago, I came across “The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up” by Marie Kondo on a bookstore table, and because I like to read about organization (more than I like to get organized, really) I bought it, only to toss is aside in frustration a few pages in. I was supposed to clean up all at once, not one room at a time? Pull out every article of clothing, even my carefully stored summer things? And focus on my own mess, not my messy family? This was not helpful. It was impossible, and it made me feel almost as bad as the clutter that still surrounded us.

headline: Denzel Washington Says He Will Bring 10 August Wilson Plays to HBO
abstract: Denzel Washington says 10 August Wilson plays will be on HBO.
lead_paragraph: During an interview at the Wallis Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Thursday night Denzel Washington said that he would produce adaptations of all 10 plays in August Wilson’s cycle about African-American life in the 20th century for HBO.

lead_paragraph: The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit — which includes Delaware, home to many large American companies – has issued an opinion that will have a significant impact on Chapter 11 bankruptcy practice.

headline: House Republicans Vote to Stop Funding Planned Parenthood
abstract: The lawmakers voted to stop funding the group, but the bill has no chance of becoming law, and it was unclear if it would avert a government shutdown.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans vented their rage against Planned Parenthood on Friday, voting to block all federal financing for the organization, which they accused of profiting from the sale of aborted fetuses for medical research. It was unclear, however, if the vote would mollify conservative lawmakers who have threatened to force a government shutdown over the abortion issue.

headline: How Cablevision Shareholders Have Fared
abstract: Since James Dolan took over in 1995, the total return on a share of the cable company, including distributions from spin-offs, is about 654 percent.
lead_paragraph: The Dolan family, who have agreed to sell Cablevision to Altice of France for some $17 billion, including debt, have been a lightning rod for many in New York City and Long Island. There is its management of the New York Knicks and Rangers, as well as its stewardship of the cable company.

headline: Caroline de Maigret, a Model and Parisian Muse
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2015)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The music producer and writer hobnobs with some of fashion’s biggest names but has moved beyond the runway.
lead_paragraph: An ambassador of Parisian cool was in town, and she wanted a burrito. “Super-vegetarian,” said Caroline de Maigret, the model, music producer and co-author of “How to Be Parisian Wherever You Are,” pointing at the laminated menu at Lupe’s, a Mexican diner in TriBeCa. “It’s rice, beans, salad, guacamole. And no, it’s not very healthy.”

headline: Bank of America Merrill Lynch Hires a Senior Banker
abstract: John Utendahl, who was most recently a vice chairman at Deutsche Bank, will join in October as an executive vice chairman of global and investment banking.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has hired a long-time deal maker from Deutsche Bank to serve as a senior banker, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Friday.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Raymond Pettibon
abstract: The artist shares the titles he’d most want with him on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from the artist Raymond Pettibon — who in November will release a tote-bag collaboration with MZ Wallace to benefit the New York Public Library. He shares his picks exclusively with T.

headline: Abstract Artworks with a Hint of Danger
abstract: Alex Hubbard’s new show “Basic Perversions” inaugurates the West Coast outpost of Maccarone, a major New York gallery, and incorporates toxic material.
lead_paragraph: “Everything I do is toxic,” jokes the artist Alex Hubbard, as lacquer fumes waft through the vast expanses of his downtown Los Angeles studio. A layer of gloss adds the finishing touches to the pieces in his latest show, “Basic Perversions,” paintings formed from pigmented industrial synthetics — urethane, resin and fiberglass — “all of which,” Hubbard notes, “are hazardous to my health.”

headline: Kerry on Military Talks With Russia
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']

lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry, during an appearance with the foreign minister of the United Arab Emirates in London on Friday, said he hoped military talks with Russia on Syria would take place soon.

headline: Op-Photo: Protests on Two Continents
abstract: On the same day, demonstrators in Finland and Japan voice their opposition to their governments’ decisions.
lead_paragraph: On the left, demonstrators in Helsinki, Finland on Friday protest against cuts to overtime pay and holidays. And on the right, also on Friday, protesters outside Japan’s parliament building in Tokyo oppose legislation that would let the country’s military play a bigger part in conflicts abroad.

headline: Willing to Spend $100 Million, Donald Trump Has So Far Reveled in Free Publicity
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance', 'Debates (Political)', 'Political Advertising', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: In an interview, the Republican presidential hopeful said his wealth and celebrity would matter more to his political fate than debate performances.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, N.H. — Expressing confidence that American voters do not care if he lacks specifics, Donald J. Trump says he has yet to fully exploit his personal advantages over his Republican presidential rivals — chiefly his enormous wealth and celebrity — and that both will matter more to his political fate than debate performances like his shaky one this week.

headline: Lady Gaga’s New Video Is a PSA About Campus Sexual Assault
abstract: Lady Gaga is addressing campus rape in a raw new music video for “Til It Happens to You.”
lead_paragraph: Lady Gaga is addressing campus rape in a raw new music video for “Til It Happens to You,” a song from the documentary “The Hunting Ground,” which examines the issue of sexual assault among college students.

keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Elections', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: Ahead of Sunday’s election, the former prime minister is campaigning to be returned to power after bruising bailout negotiations that split his party.
lead_paragraph: PATRAS, Greece — Alexis Tsipras, Greece’s prime minister until he resigned last month to call new elections, was campaigning in this port city recently, in many ways looking like the same charismatic young politician who swept into office only eight months ago.

headline: Suspect in 2 Deaths at Brooklyn and Manhattan Hotels Is Arrested
abstract: Joseph Danclair, 36, of Brooklyn was charged with second-degree murder in one case; the authorities said charges were also expected soon in the other.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Danclair had a way with women, the police said. The Brooklyn man could easily strike up a conversation, they said, and in some cases, persuade them to go along with him.

headline: White House Faults Donald Trump for Not Rebuking Obama Muslim Assertion
abstract: Donald J. Trump was pandering for votes when he failed to correct a rally attendee who said President Obama was Muslim and not American, Josh Earnest, the White House’s press secretary, said Friday.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was pandering for votes when he failed to correct a rally attendee who said President Obama was Muslim and not American, Josh Earnest, the White House’s press secretary, said Friday. He called the lapse part of a “cynical strategy” used by many Republicans.

abstract: The market values of Anheuser-Busch InBev and SABMiller have increased by $30 billion in the wake of a takeover approach.
lead_paragraph: Anheuser-Busch InBev, brewer of Budweiser, has yet to make a firm offer for a rival brewer, SABMiller, but the market is already tipsy on the potential for value creation.

headline: Refugees in Calais, Reading and Waiting

abstract: The makeshift library is a place for reading, but also for digesting what has happened, and to figure out what comes next.
lead_paragraph: Calais, France — “YOU like the place?”

headline: Review: Attacca Quartet Continues Its Haydn Project
abstract: The troupe is on a six-season quest to play the composer’s 68 string quartets.
lead_paragraph: Completism is a curse on classical music. Our urge to present and to hear everything that a composer wrote in a genre, usually in a compressed period, can sometimes be productive. Mostly, though, the endless flood of Bach, Beethoven and Mahler cycles let loose by our major soloists, chamber ensembles and orchestras stifles the genuinely creative thinking that our art needs. Bankable though the idea may be, it tends to be boring.

headline: Review: ‘Nufonia Must Fall’ Shares the Heart of Kid Koala’s Robot Tale
abstract: This Next Wave Festival show mixes puppet theater, video and music to translate a nearly wordless graphic novel published in 2003.
lead_paragraph: “Nufonia Must Fall,” a Next Wave Festival show at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater through Sunday, might be called modern primitive multimedia. It mixes puppet theater, video, a string quartet and a nest of electric instruments.

headline: Jon Irabagon Paints Tradition in New Hues
abstract: The saxophonist Jon Irabagon shows his range on the two very different albums he is releasing on his label Irrabagast.
lead_paragraph: The saxophonist Jon Irabagon closed a recent set at the Jazz Standard with “The Original J,” a brisk new tune in a willful state of flux. His quartet made it feel plunging and precarious, charged with fervor. Only gradually, during a piano solo by Matt Mitchell, did it become obvious that the tune’s chord progression had been borrowed from the standard songbook: specifically, Cole Porter’s “So in Love.”

headline: Pat Haden’s Joyous Nights at U.S.C. Outweigh the Sleepless Ones
abstract: After five years as athletic director, Haden is still trying to return U.S.C. to football greatness, but he has had other victories, including securing a long-term lease of L.A. Coliseum.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Pat Haden stood on the field at Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum on a hot afternoon in May and pointed to a spot in the stands dozens of rows above the west end zone. His father’s season tickets to Southern California football games were there, in Row 90.

lead_paragraph: Soldiers and officials from the Pakistani military recounted the Taliban attack on an air force base mosque.

headline: U.A.W. Contract With Fiat Chrysler Would Give 2nd-Tier Workers Big Raise
abstract: The proposed contract would substantially narrow the pay gap between entry-level workers, who now earn as little as $16 an hour, and veteran workers, who get $28.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The proposed contract between Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and the United Automobile Workers union includes wage increases that significantly close the gap in pay between veteran workers and entry-level employees.

headline: Bernie Sanders Bashes Billionaires at a Manhattan Fund-Raiser
abstract: A Manhattan event on Friday for Bernie Sanders was anything but a traditional fund-raiser: hundreds of supporters in a sweaty concert hall cheering a stem-winder from the candidate about the evils of fund-raising in a post-Citizens United world.
lead_paragraph: The traditional campaign fund-raiser: a few dozen deep-pocketed donors in a quiet room, a trimmed-down stump speech from the candidate, a pantomime of intimacy.

headline: More Protection for a Nest Egg Has Some Brokers Upset
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Consumer Protection', 'Personal Finances', 'Financial Brokers', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A rule in development for five years is meant to make sure financial professionals act in a client’s best interest on retirement accounts, which could prevent many abuses.
lead_paragraph: A DOZEN or so new victims file into Joseph Peiffer’s law offices each month.

headline: With Kelsey Grammer Still Away, ‘Neverland’ Finds a New Hook
abstract: Terrence Mann will assume the role in the Broadway musical at the end of September.
lead_paragraph: Kelsey Grammer’s summer vacation has gotten longer.

headline: The Rationality of Rage
abstract: Sometimes it’s smart to get angry.
lead_paragraph: ANGER is a primal and destructive emotion, disrupting rational discourse and inflaming illogical passions — or so it often seems. Then again, anger also has its upsides. Expressing anger, for example, is known to be a useful tool in negotiations. Indeed, in the past few years, researchers have been learning more about when and how to deploy anger productively.

headline: Eric Fanning, Civilian Adviser, Named Secretary of the Army
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: The nomination of Mr. Fanning, the current acting under secretary, would make him the first openly gay secretary of a military branch.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is nominating Eric K. Fanning, a close civilian adviser to Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter, to be the secretary of the Army, an appointment that would make him the first openly gay secretary of a military branch.

lead_paragraph: Turkey and More — Pictures of the Day

abstract: Photos from Turkey, Croatia, Sri Lanka and Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, Croatia, Sri Lanka and Saudi Arabia.

headline: Robert Johnson, Bronx District Attorney, Says He Wants to Become a State Judge
abstract: The decision by Mr. Johnson to seek a nomination to serve on the New York State Supreme Court sets in motion his likely resignation.
lead_paragraph: The longtime Bronx district attorney, Robert T. Johnson, said on Friday that he intended to seek a nomination to be a State Supreme Court justice, setting in motion his likely resignation and paving the way for Democratic Party officials in the borough to name his replacement.

headline: Amid Jerusalem Clashes, Israeli and Palestinian Leaders Try to Make Their Case
abstract: The leaders of Israel and the Palestinians spoke against the backdrop of this week’s violent clashes at Al Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, called Pope Francis to brief him on the “ongoing Israeli aggression in occupied East Jerusalem, and particularly against Al Aqsa Mosque.”

headline: Europe Should See Refugees as a Boon, Not a Burden
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Foreign Workers', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Immigrants generally pay more in taxes than they claim in government benefits.
lead_paragraph: Many European leaders have described the refugees who are risking their lives to get to the Continent as a burden. But there is good reason to believe that these immigrants will contribute more to Europe economically than they will take from it.

headline: Understanding Insurance Policies for Homes in Wildfire-Prone Areas
abstract: Many residents in drought-stricken California are being forced from their houses by fires. Here’s advice about preemptive measures you can take to understand, and possibly adjust, your policy.
lead_paragraph: THE worst wildfire season in years is forcing many Californians from their homes and has caused the destruction of hundreds of houses, cars and other property.

headline: In Its 13th Year, the London Design Festival Spreads Out
abstract: The event, which in previous years has mostly been confined to venues in the east and west, grows this year to encompass projects all over the city.
lead_paragraph: As the London Design Festival prepares for its 13th year, the city is gearing up to host a range of activities including five major design shows and hundreds of installations and pop-ups across seven “design districts.” The festival, which runs from Sept. 19 to 27, has outgrown its original geographical confines: luxury design and large-scale installations in west London, and edgier work on view in the east. This year, LDF spans the whole city, with venues reaching into the north and south — including a number of independent shops, galleries and cafes that will be hosting their own events and exhibitions.

headline: The De-Reaganization of the Republican Party
abstract: Wednesday’s debate marked the latest break from the legacy of the president whose library hosted the event.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 9, 1986, Air Force One delivered President Ronald Reagan to Iceland, where he met with President Mikhail Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. The Reykjavik summit, as it was known, marked the beginning of the end of the Cold War.

headline: College Football Games to Watch This Weekend
abstract: Ole Miss at Alabama, Georgia Tech at Notre Dame and Auburn at Louisiana State are among some of the best games.
lead_paragraph: No. 15 Mississippi at No. 2 Alabama

headline: An Aboriginal Artist’s Dizzying New York Moment
abstract: Traveling from the remote Australian desert to the United States for his first solo show here, Warlimpirrnga Tjapaltjarri has had much to adjust to.
lead_paragraph: For at least the last century, it has always been a momentous occasion: An artist from the hinterlands arrives in New York for the first time, hoping for what the writer Willie Morris called “the tender security of fulfillment.” But for the painter Warlimpirrnga Tjapaltjarri, things were a little different.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 8
abstract: Calvin Klein, RuPaul and others attended Susanne Bartsch’s “Fashion Underground” show at the Museum at F.I.T.
lead_paragraph: Calvin Klein, RuPaul and others attended Susanne Bartsch’s “Fashion Underground” show at the Museum at F.I.T.

headline: Port Antonio: Jamaica Unplugged
abstract: These days, the way to encounter the Caribbean mainstay has nothing to do with big resorts — and everything to do with having as local an experience as possible.
lead_paragraph: FOR MANY YEARS, Port Antonio, a junglehemmed town on Jamaica’s northeast coast, was synonymous with a specific kind of languorous glamour, best illustrated by a 1955 photograph of Patrice Flynn, a movie actress and wife of Errol. In it, she is riding on horseback along a sandy track as he walks beside her, his white shirt unbuttoned. Everything about it suggests a near future of Dark and Stormies at sundown on a veranda somewhere. This was the beginning of the town’s glory years, when it was the retreat of choice for Grace Kelly and Elizabeth Taylor, who used to arrive by yacht with Richard Burton.

headline: 5 Stand-Out Male Models at New York Fashion Week
abstract: Several spring/summer 2016 runways featured new (and newish) men’s faces. Here, a handful that caught T’s eye.
lead_paragraph: Several spring/summer 2016 runways featured new (and newish) men’s faces. Here, a handful that caught T’s eye.

headline: Back to School — on the Runways
abstract: Designers nodded to academia in their spring 2016 collections.
lead_paragraph: Each September, New York Fashion Week and back-to-school converge — sometimes even on the runway, where this season three designers nodded to the academic uniform. At Hood by Air, detention-bound models wore cropped white oxford shirts (buttoned all the way up to the neck, in accordance with dress code) and black leather skirts with zippered slits. In tailored jackets, knee socks and button-down shirts, Thom Browne’s schoolgirls were much more prim — though with a wacky twist — as they filed into a schoolhouse before their headmistress. And at DKNY, which debuted its first collection under new creative direction from Dao-Yi Chow and Maxwell Osborne of Public School, pleats and blazers came together for a more of-the-moment, urban feel.

headline: Mexican Tourists Wounded in Egyptian Air Attack Return Home
abstract: The circumstances of the attack in Egypt’s Western Desert that killed 12 people remain murky as officials called for an investigation and compensation for the victims.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The six Mexican survivors of an air attack by Egyptian security forces on a group of Mexican tourists and their Egyptian guides returned to their country on Friday as the Mexican government said it would seek compensation on their behalf from Egypt.

headline: Toronto Film Festival: Separating Contenders From Pretenders
abstract: Major festivals like Toronto’s are a launching pad to the Oscars, and some noteworthy films will trickle into the slipstream.
lead_paragraph: The first time that a red carpet was rolled out may have been in “The Oresteia” when Clytemnestra orders her handmaidens to lay down crimson tapestries for the return of her long-absent husband, Agamemnon. The color evokes the blood that was spilled at Troy and signals the blood that will pour from Agamemnon when he’s killed by Clytemnestra, who holds him responsible the death of their daughter, Iphigenia. The red carpet has long held significantly different meanings, although given its grip on the movie world I have started to see it too as a river of blood, cascading from all the footsore celebrities, anxious festival programmers and weary journalists now on that death march called the awards season.

headline: The New Mods
abstract: This season, the prevailing archetype is the Pop dollybird clad in psychedelic geometrics.
lead_paragraph: This season, the prevailing archetype is the Pop dollybird clad in psychedelic geometrics.

headline: What’s Showing at the Toronto Film Festival? TV
abstract: This year, Toronto became the third major film festival to include a slate of television series, recognizing that the medium now produces significant work.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — “Have you heard of this movie?” a young woman asks her companion as they settle into their seats for something called “The Returned.” A man sitting in front of them turns and tells them they’ve fought their way through the crowds at the Toronto International Film Festival to see … a television show.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Backstage at Molly Goddard’s Sandwich Factory
abstract: A look at the designer’s spring/summer collection at London Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: A look at the designer’s spring/summer collection at London Fashion Week.

headline: The Power of Grace Jones
abstract: The style icon and provocateur, who says, “I’m 5,000 years old,” discusses her memoir and today’s pop stars. She’s not impressed.
lead_paragraph: “I am so terribly sorry,” said the woman in a black blazer and leopard-print heels, hovering over Grace Jones. “There’s no way that I can have you keep doing this interview here.”

headline: The Mod Look of the ’60s, Revisited
abstract: This season, the prevailing archetype is the Pop dollybird clad in psychedelic geometrics.
lead_paragraph: THE IMAGE of the carefree 1960s girl is never far from designers’ minds, from the era’s innocent flower children to such sexy sophisticates as Bardot and Birkin. This season, the prevailing archetype is the Pop dollybird clad in psychedelic geometrics. Donatella Versace’s color-block dresses in acid-bright shades were shown with color-coordinated thigh-high boots: very Modesty Blaise. Louis Vuitton and Calvin Klein showed minis with keyhole cutouts, as Jonathan Saunders and Jeremy Scott reverted to trippy retro patterns. Valentino conjured the Vienna Secessionists, whose graphic sensibility had a big impact on the 1960s Op Art giants Bridget Riley and Victor Vasarely.

headline: Making New Memories in the Aftermath of a Quebec Train Disaster
abstract: Michel Huneault photographed the train explosion in Lac-Mégantic and then returned to document how the small village coped. He has received the Lange-Taylor Prize from Duke University’s Center for Documentary Studies for the project.
lead_paragraph: Michel Huneault photographed the train explosion in Lac-Mégantic and then returned to document how the small village coped. He has received the Lange-Taylor Prize from Duke University’s Center for Documentary Studies for the project.

headline: Japan’s Parliament Approves Overseas Combat Role for Military
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe succeeded in his effort to move beyond the postwar pacifism that has kept his country out of conflicts.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In a middle-of-the night vote that capped a tumultuous struggle with opposition parties in Parliament, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan secured final passage of legislation on Saturday authorizing overseas combat missions for his country’s military, overturning a decades-old policy of reserving the use of force for self-defense.

headline: Review: Joanna Kotze’s High-Speed Chase at Baryshnikov Arts Center
abstract: For “Find Yourself Here,” three dancers and three visual artists blur the lines between movement and sound.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, Joanna Kotze won the Bessie Award for Outstanding Emerging Choreographer for her dense and stately evening-length “It happened it had happened it is happening it will happen.” Now in her follow-up, “Find Yourself Here,” choppier in tone, she places three dancers and three visual artists in the same space to blur the lines between task and choreography, movement and sound.

headline: Review: ‘Rice,’ by Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan, Honors a Crop and a People
abstract: This production at the Brooklyn Academy of Music uses movement and song to illustrate the life cycle of a grain the country depends on.
lead_paragraph: Sex! Fire! Combat with sticks! The production by Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan that opened on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music has all of those things. And yet, somehow, it is about as exciting as the life cycle of rice.

headline: Staten Island Museum Is Reopening in Snug Harbor Complex
abstract: Moving to a cultural hub and a vastly expanded space, the museum hopes to transcend its “outpost” identity and let its eclectic collection breathe.
lead_paragraph: Sure, the Staten Island Museum has long owned a variety of treasures: a 16th-century suit of armor, a wooden statue from the 12th dynasty of ancient Egypt, a collection of portraits of prominent people from the borough.

headline: Review: The JACK Quartet, With Instruments of Destruction
abstract: The group plays more than strings in this evening of music with the Danish composer Simon Steen-Andersen at the Miller Theater.
lead_paragraph: The Miller Theater at Columbia University is known for its forward-thinking programming, but it opened its season Thursday with something truly wild: the JACK Quartet playing Schumann. Imperfectly.

headline: The Flea’s New Artistic Director Is Dreaming Big
abstract: Niegel Smith, who has a broad and varied background, is looking forward to the last seasons in one space and all the new possibilities of the new theater.
lead_paragraph: When Niegel Smith got messages from three friends on a single day last winter, urging him to apply to succeed Jim Simpson, the founding artistic director of the Flea Theater, it didn’t seem to him like an obvious fit.

headline: ‘The Mikado’ Is Beheaded in New York
abstract: The cancellation of a production brings up complicated questions about race and racism in theater.
lead_paragraph: This is startling: The New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players, a small company dedicated to keeping those warhorse Victorian operettas alive and kicking, has just canceled its winter production of “The Mikado.”

headline: In London, a Fashion Show Becomes a Sandwich Factory
abstract: The young designer Molly Goddard turns her presentation into a (particularly delicious) assembly line.
lead_paragraph: In a presentation space at London’s Institute of Contemporary Arts, the designer Molly Goddard is turning a group of models in party dresses into a no-nonsense sandwich-production line. A series of white tables fill the space, each with its own prop: a tub of chopped tomatoes; a foil tray of lettuce leaves; a platter of cheese slices — and, of course, piles upon piles of white bread. “It’s OK to look a bit bored,” she directs the models, arranging them in pairs. She herself looks entirely relaxed. There are seven minutes until show time.

headline: Friday Night Music: I’m Still Here
abstract: When you’ve been through Herbert and J. Edgar Hoover …
lead_paragraph: I was looking for something else, but this Elaine Stritch performance is so good I had to share:

headline: Bill Cunningham | Pant Shapes Expand
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2015)']
abstract: At New York Fashion Week, pants had a fresh proportion: the width of skirts and cut off at the calf. Other times they covered the shoe.
lead_paragraph: At New York Fashion Week, pants had a fresh proportion: the width of skirts and cut off at the calf. Other times they covered the shoe.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Pant Shapes Expand at New York Fashion Week
abstract: Pants have a fresh proportion: the width of skirts and cut off at the calf.
lead_paragraph: Pants have a fresh proportion: the width of skirts and cut off at the calf. Other times they cover the shoe. It was a look that many of the people attending New York Fashion Week wore. The idea was first seen at Céline in Paris over a year ago In New York, the idea was developed at J. Crew. Many of the long trousers suggest palazzo pajamas worn in Rome in the 1960s for informal evenings. A buyer from Saudi Arabia wore versions of this skirt pants every day last week.. Among the many pant shapes being worn is another attempt at the one-piece jumpsuit, which has always been difficult for women to handle in bathroom stalls.

headline: Photographing Marine Veterans on the Home Front
abstract: Todd Heisler photographed several Marine veterans of the Afghan war. Many of their comrades had died in combat; others killed themselves at home or attempted suicide.
lead_paragraph: Todd Heisler photographed several Marine veterans of the Afghan war. Many of their comrades had died in combat; others killed themselves at home or attempted suicide.

headline: Review: In ‘How to Live on Earth,’ a Way Off the Planet
abstract: MJ Kaufman’s play looks at four would-be astronauts applying for a one-way trip to Mars.
lead_paragraph: Mars is not especially hospitable to human life. It has minimal oxygen, a temperature of 200 degrees below at the poles and low gravity that can burst internal organs within minutes. To say nothing of the dust.

headline: Evening Hours | New York Fashion Week
abstract: Industry parties and the season’s kickoff gala.
lead_paragraph: Industry parties and the season’s kickoff gala.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The Court and the World’
abstract: John Fabian Witt talks about Stephen Breyer’s new book, and Mira Jacob discusses three coming-of-age novels.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, John Fabian Witt reviews the Supreme Court Justice Stephen Breyer’s “The Court and the World,” which considers whether foreign law should have a place in interpreting the American Constitution. Mr. Witt writes:

headline: Israeli Settlers Publish Their Reality, with Palestine as Fiction
abstract: Apparently worried that their view was not reaching other Israelis, settlers explained their view in a Hebrew publication resembling a comic book.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli settlers have long asserted that the Palestinians are an invented people, that the West Bank’s real name is Judea and Samaria, and that it was liberated by Israeli soldiers in 1967. Now the settlers, apparently worried that their version of history is not reaching other Israelis, are promoting it in a Hebrew-language publication that resembles a comic book.

headline: A Murder at a Bronx Motel Lingers, Three Years Later
abstract: An investigation into a 2012 fatal stabbing eventually led to a man from Boston and a file that reads like the playbook of the modern pimp.
lead_paragraph: Michael Rocco arrived at home that morning shaken, and he was not easily shaken.

headline: A Humble Pope, Challenging the World
abstract: Francis, the first Latin American pope, has drawn from his life in Argentina to try to create a humbler papacy, albeit one with lofty ambitions. His push for change has stirred hope and anxiety.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Days after the election of Pope Francis, word reached the Vatican press office that the new pontiff was unexpectedly celebrating morning Mass. Other popes had presided over morning services, too, but as the world (and the Vatican press office) would soon realize, Francis did things his own way.

headline: Judge Rules That a Dog Visiting a Bronx Apartment Is Not an Illegal Tenant
keywords: ['Dogs', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Landlords']
abstract: The case of a Pomeranian dropped off at a family member’s apartment highlighted the long-running battle between tenants and landlords over lease stipulations regarding pets.
lead_paragraph: The Pomeranian was dropped off at the Bronx apartment in the morning, snuggled there with a 17-year-old girl who had depression and a spine condition, and then returned at night to its owner’s home in New Jersey.

headline: ISIS Group Attacks Prison in Libya
abstract: Four militants loyal to the Islamic State attacked a prison on Friday inside the air base that serves as the only working airport for Tripoli.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Four militants loyal to the Islamic State attacked a prison on Friday inside the air base that serves as the only working airport for Tripoli, the Libyan capital, according to statements by the group and by the political faction that controls the city. It was one of the group’s most aggressive forays into the capital.

headline: Mark Fuller, Former Federal District Court Judge, Could Be Impeached
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Impeachment', 'Domestic Violence', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A judicial panel’s suggestion that Judge Fuller, who resigned after an arrest, could still be impeached was seen as a broader message that the judiciary was embracing a harder line.
lead_paragraph: A high-level committee of federal judges told Congress this month that lawmakers had reason to consider impeaching Mark E. Fuller, a former Federal District Court judge in Alabama, even though he had already resigned after being arrested and accused of striking his wife.

headline: Brazil to Keep Allowances for the Poor
abstract: Despite Brazil’s budget problems, there will be no cuts in a pioneering and widely admired program of monthly cash allowances to the poor.
lead_paragraph: Despite Brazil’s deepening economic travails and budget problems, there will be no cuts in a pioneering and widely admired program of monthly cash allowances to the poor, the official in charge of the effort said Friday.

headline: Roger Adelman, Prosecutor in Reagan Attacker’s Insanity Trial, Dies at 74
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Mr. Adelman’s unsuccessful prosecution of John W. Hinckley Jr. in the shooting of President Ronald Reagan and his press secretary led to a new law governing the insanity defense in criminal trials.
lead_paragraph: Roger M. Adelman, a government lawyer whose unsuccessful prosecution of John W. Hinckley Jr. in the 1981 shooting of President Ronald Reagan and his press secretary, James S. Brady, led to significant changes in the law governing the insanity defense in criminal trials, died on Sept. 12 at his home in Washington. He was 74.

headline: A Wet Winter Won’t Save California
keywords: ['Drought', 'Weather', 'Global Warming', 'Conservation of Resources', 'El Nino Southern Oscillation']
abstract: A new climate reality makes extreme drought more likely.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — As wildfires rage, crops are abandoned, wells run dry and cities work to meet mandatory water cuts, drought-weary Californians are counting on a savior in the tropical ocean: El Niño.

headline: Nail Salon Owners Sue Cuomo and New York State Over Wage Bond Requirement
keywords: ['Beauty Salons', 'Nails (Body Part)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The lawsuit said that a rule requiring owners to buy a form of insurance meant to prevent wage theft placed too great a burden on them.
lead_paragraph: Two groups representing nail salon owners sued Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the State of New York this week over a new requirement that says salons must obtain wage bonds, a form of insurance meant to protect workers from wage theft.

headline: Room in Catholic School for Gay-Straight Alliance
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Education (K-12)', 'Organizations, Societies and Clubs']
abstract: The Gay-Straight Alliance at Xavier High School in Manhattan reflects shifts in public opinion and in the tone of the church.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon during the first week of classes this week at Xavier High School in Manhattan, as the various student clubs reconvened, Joseph Papeo walked into Alexander Lavy’s physics classroom. On the walls hung a crucifix and posters of Einstein and Homer Simpson. Two flags flanked the door. One was the American standard, while the other was the rainbow banner of gay pride.

headline: Deputy Clerk Questions Alterations to Kentucky Marriage Licenses
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A deputy clerk in Rowan County raised questions about whether changes to marriage licenses, as ordered by the county’s clerk, complied with a federal judge’s orders.
lead_paragraph: A deputy clerk in Rowan County, Ky., raised questions on Friday about whether a slapdash solution to a legal standoff about same-sex marriage licenses complied with the order of the federal judge who this month jailed the county’s clerk, Kim Davis.

headline: Jordan Spieth Breaks Par, but Jason Day Breaks Away
abstract: Aided by a birdie an eagle on the last two holes, Spieth shot a 65 at the BMW Championship but was seven shots behind Day, who shot 63.
lead_paragraph: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — For five straight holes Friday afternoon, Jordan Spieth completely lost confidence in his putter, making the task of keeping pace with Jason Day, the world’s top golfer, even more daunting than normal.

headline: How the Pope Might Renew the Church
abstract: The Catholic Church needs to reconsider its policies on celibacy, women priests, and divorce.
lead_paragraph: Sacramento — I AM a Catholic, born in 1921 of Italian and Irish families and raised in California seminaries. After decades of work as a priest, I was astonished that Pope Paul VI appointed me a bishop in San Francisco. I love my church, and every night I pray that I might die in her warm, loving arms.

headline: Enabling of Ad Blocking in Apple’s iOS 9 Prompts Backlash
abstract: Apps that block all ads are threatening some web publishers’ livelihoods, which in turn could threaten some content on the web.
lead_paragraph: For years, people have longed for ways to stop advertising from popping up on their iPhones and iPads. Now, software to block ads on these gadgets has arrived — and the harsh realities of the practice are causing second thoughts.

headline: Varied Pleas as Candidates Press Cases at Conservative Forum
abstract: Most of the Republican presidential field appeared at the Heritage Action for America conference, though their tones and pleas differed.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Gov. Scott Walker, eager to jump-start a flagging campaign, expressed support for a government shutdown over Planned Parenthood funding and likened his fights with lawmakers in Wisconsin to the movie “Braveheart.”

headline: The Fight for Unplanned Parenthood
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'ABORTION', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Republicans’ new push against Planned Parenthood isn’t just about abortion.
lead_paragraph: Planned Parenthood! Government shutdown!

headline: Mets Test Yankees’ Ace, and Ace a Critical Test
abstract: Preparing for the season’s stretch run, the Mets broke through against Masahiro Tanaka and defeated the Yankees, 5-1, at Citi Field.
lead_paragraph: The presence of the Yankees at Citi Field, this late in the season, is a mild novelty. Much more notable, for the Mets, is the fact that they are playing a competitive team at all.

headline: Gender Integration of Marines Brings Out Unusually Public Discord
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The Marine Corps and its civilian leaders at the Pentagon are squaring off over whether integrating women into all-male combat units will undermine the units’ lethality.
lead_paragraph: The Marine Corps and its civilian leadership at the Pentagon are squaring off in an unusually public dispute over whether integrating women into the corps’s all-male combat units will undermine the units’ effectiveness, or whether the male-dominated Marine leadership is cherry-picking justifications to keep women out.

headline: Tourists Thwart Turtles from Nesting in Costa Rica
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Turtles and Tortoises', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Rain']
abstract: During the first weekend in September, day-trippers swarmed the beach in Costa Rica that serves as a nesting ground for olive ridley sea turtles, becoming a cautionary tale for conservationists, not to mention a social media sensation.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The day-trippers swarmed onto the beach to watch one of nature’s most extraordinary sights, hundreds of thousands of olive ridley sea turtles crawling out of the ocean to lay their eggs in the sand.

headline: Impose Price Controls on Drugs?
abstract: Readers explain why they disagree with Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel’s proposed solutions for rising drugs costs.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: United Nations Peacekeeping
abstract: The under secretary general for peacekeeping operations writes that his operation doesn’t have an “identity crisis.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Washington to Come to a Halt for Pope, Willingly or Not
abstract: The nation’s capital has been mired in gridlock for years, but next week’s snarls could be the worst ever as Pope Francis arrives on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s capital has been mired in gridlock for years, but next week’s snarls could be the worst ever — and this time it has nothing to do with politics.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s School Agenda
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Education (K-12)', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Ambitious initiatives will fail or fall short if the quality of reading instruction is not significantly improved.
lead_paragraph: The education initiatives that Mayor Bill de Blasio outlined in a long-awaited speech earlier this week, though modest in scope, address some serious challenges facing the largest school system in the country. Collectively, they call for $186 million in new city investment, and in the abstract they appear wholly worthy. But the city has yet to provide details on how the initiatives will be rolled out or the benchmarks against which they will be judged. And for the reforms to fully realize their potential, some failing schools may have to be shut down and completely restaffed and restructured.

headline: Turn the Ferguson Moment Into Lasting Change
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Minimum Wage', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A commission’s worthy recommendations will need strong support lest they slip into the sorry archive of might-have-beens.
lead_paragraph: The track record of “riot commissions” convened after major public disturbances is that they gather dust once they assure the public that something vaguely positive seems to be happening. To its credit, the commission of community leaders appointed to look into the volatile racial protests that rocked Ferguson, Mo., last year did not make that mistake. The 198-page report issued by the Ferguson Commission this week warns from its very first pages that palliatives won’t do this time: Leaders must enact a raft of urgently needed changes, or St. Louis and its ring of disjointed suburbs will never get beyond the deeply troubling mix of racial prejudices and government abuses laid bare in Ferguson.

She was acquitted, however, of the more serious charge of obstruction of justice.

headline: Mets Get a Taste of the Postseason, and Savor It, Against the Yankees
abstract: A strong start by Steven Matz and three home runs by Mets hitters helped the team preserve its eight-game lead in the National League East.
lead_paragraph: Juan Uribe dropped his bat and charged out of the box, waiting, watching like everyone else as his fly ball headed toward the right-field wall. Then thousands of Mets fans shot out of their seats in unison, holding their arms high, cheering wildly, waving towels and flags, shouting into the air and hugging the people next to them as Uribe rounded the bases with a skip in his step. He clapped his hands and let out a shout as he crossed home plate.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (AMC) THE GREAT GATSBY (2013) Leonardo DiCaprio stars as the enigmatic millionaire Jay Gatsby, and Carey Mulligan portrays Daisy Buchanan, the object of his obsession, in Baz Luhrmann’s stylized musical take on the F. Scott Fitzgerald novel. Tobey Maguire is Nick Carraway, the Yale graduate — and, conveniently, Daisy’s cousin — renting the cottage next to Gatsby’s colossal Long Island mansion. “Despite what you may have heard, it is an eminently enjoyable movie,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film, which won Oscars for best costume and production design. Still, is the tale “a credible love story?” he asked. “Fitzgerald himself was not sure, but Mr. Luhrmann, Mr. DiCaprio and Ms. Mulligan make it an effective one.”

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a DoubleTree Hotel in Durham, N.C., in May 2014, Dr. Robert M. Califf gave a presentation to a group of biomedical researchers, lawyers and industry experts. He spoke about ways to quicken the pace of biomedical innovation by transforming research. Toward the end he showed a slide that noted one barrier: regulation.

headline: After the Grateful Dead, Phil Lesh Shows He Has a Head for Business
abstract: Phil Lesh has gone from selling out shows as the bassist for the Grateful Dead to running a space of his own, a combination music hall and restaurant.
lead_paragraph: A few times a month, Sam Satenstein lines up outside Terrapin Crossroads, a music hall and restaurant in San Rafael, Calif., for performances by the band Phil Lesh and Friends. The hall is owned by Mr. Lesh, the 75-year-old Grateful Dead bassist, and his wife, Jill. Mr. Satenstein is almost always first in line; when the doors open he rushes in to secure a spot on the side of the stage favored by Mr. Lesh. He plops down on the floor to protect the space.

You are most likely to remember her as Jerry Seinfeld’s girlfriend on the “Schmoopie”/Soup Nazi episode, but she’s come a long way since then. abstract: The countries are discussing what could be the first arms control accord for cyberspace, and an agreement could be announced as soon as Thursday, according to officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and China are negotiating what could become the first arms control accord for cyberspace, embracing a commitment by each country that it will not be the first to use cyberweapons to cripple the other’s critical infrastructure during peacetime, according to officials involved in the talks.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When gloomy Republican Party leaders regrouped after President Obama’s 2012 re-election, they were intent on enhancing the party’s chances of winning back the White House. The result: new rules to head off a prolonged and divisive nomination fight, and to make certain the Republican standard-bearer is not pulled too far to the right before Election Day.

headline: Going Gaga for Ohad Naharin
abstract: To get dancers to move through space in an entirely new way, the Israeli choreographer first had to invent a lexicon of words to inspire them.
lead_paragraph: DANCE, ESPECIALLY BALLET, is often seen as a quest for perfection in human form. Not so for Ohad Naharin, the artistic director of the Tel Aviv-based Batsheva Dance Company. Rather than watch an hour of accomplished performance, Naharin would prefer to see five seconds of something sublime — that indefinable quality described by the thinker Edmund Burke as ‘‘delightful horror.’’ ‘‘This is where I wish to be, as a spectator and a creator,’’ Naharin says — and, judging from his inimitable oeuvre from the past 35 years, the choreographer, widely hailed as one of the most influential luminaries of contemporary dance, has succeeded in this desire.

lead_paragraph: OK, I should have seen that one coming, but didn’t: the banking industry has responded to the Fed’s decision not to hike rates with a primal cry of rage. And that, I think, tells us what we need to know about the political economy of permahawkery.

headline: Pope Francis Departs Rome for Cuba
abstract: Pope Francis boarded a flight at Rome’s Fiumicino airport on his way to Cuba, where he is expected on Saturday evening.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis boarded a flight at Rome’s Fiumicino airport on his way to Cuba, where he is expected on Saturday evening.

headline: Warily Eyeing China, Philippines May Invite U.S. Back to Subic Bay
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: With China pressing its claim to a vast expanse of sea west of Subic Bay, the Philippines is debating whether to welcome the United States Navy back to its old base.
lead_paragraph: SUBIC BAY, Philippines — In a flash of anticolonialist fervor nearly a quarter-century ago, lawmakers in the Philippines expelled the United States from an enormous naval base here, then the largest overseas outpost of the American military. Promising to break free from the “shackles of dictatorship,” they declared that foreign troops would never return.

headline: A Hockey Life Full of Turns in the Minors
abstract: Roy Sommer, 58, who is 20 victories from becoming the American Hockey League’s career coaching leader, is a blue-collar teacher most comfortable in flip-flops and straight talk.
lead_paragraph: TROUT CREEK, Mont. — There are several ways to get to Trout Creek. Roy Sommer, a hockey coach who knows the back ways of the professional game as well as anyone, likes the dirt road.

headline: When Purloined Letters Make News
abstract: A Times article about the movie “Concussion” based on hacked Sony emails raises broader ethical questions.
lead_paragraph: With the pro football season in full swing, the discussion of Sony Pictures’ coming film, “Concussion,” could hardly be timelier.

headline: How Federer Thrives in an Age of Disruption
keywords: ['Tennis', 'Wimbledon Tennis Tournament', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment', 'Athletics and Sports', 'United States Open (Tennis)']
abstract: At the U.S. Open, Federer showed that innovation isn’t a game just for the young.
lead_paragraph: SUPPORT for Roger Federer out in Flushing last week at the United States Open’s men’s final was mob-loud and unruly. There was raucous cheering every time Novak Djokovic netted a first serve, and calculated yelling when he was in his service motion. This owed something to the three-hour rain delay, which, to judge from the lines snaking from the alcohol concessions at Arthur Ashe Stadium, led many fans to tailgate, albeit with pink drinks.

headline: The (Fake) Meat Revolution
abstract: Researchers are getting closer to providing us with cheap alternatives to meat that even carnivores will enjoy.
lead_paragraph: IF only meat weren’t so delicious!

headline: Justice Falls Short in G.M. Case
abstract: The Justice Department has lost its way in prosecuting corporate crime.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — WITH tough talk that its actions belie, the Justice Department announced last week that it was bringing criminal charges against General Motors for “concealing a potentially deadly safety defect” from regulators and “misleading consumers regarding the safety” of G.M. vehicles, which caused or contributed to at least 124 deaths in accidents when airbags failed to deploy.

headline: Evangelicals and the Carson Illusion
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Evangelical Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: Why Ben Carson’s personal appeal to the religious right might be a greater folly than Trumpmania.

headline: How to Close Guantánamo
abstract: President Obama has just over a year to deliver on his promise to shut down the prison, a goal that is hard but not hopeless.
lead_paragraph: For almost 14 years, the United States’ military prison camp in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, has sat festering on the edge of the Caribbean and the Constitution. Opened by President George W. Bush in the panicky months after the Sept. 11 attacks, the detention center has had a powerful radicalizing effect, has severely tarnished America’s standing as a nation of laws and has cost taxpayers more than $5.2 billion.

headline: Making Government Logical
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research']
abstract: Obama is requiring government to use behavioral insights to simplify forms and reduce burdens.
lead_paragraph: THERE wasn’t a lot of fanfare, but last week may turn out to be among the most consequential of President Obama’s second term. By executive order, Mr. Obama directed federal agencies to incorporate behavioral science — insights into how people actually make decisions — into their programs.

headline: Grading More Fairly
abstract: Readers discuss a letter by Elizabeth Wissner-Gross asserting that some college students who excel are not being given the A’s they deserve to avoid charges of grade inflation.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss a letter by Elizabeth Wissner-Gross asserting that some college students who excel are not being given the A’s they deserve to avoid charges of grade inflation.

headline: Googling for God
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Celebrities', 'Search Engines', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: We wonder why he made us who we are, but also who made him.
lead_paragraph: IT has been a bad decade for God, at least so far. Despite the rising popularity of Pope Francis, who was elected in 2013, Google searches for churches are 15 percent lower in the first half of this decade than they were during the last half of the previous one. Searches questioning God’s existence are up. Many behaviors that he supposedly abhors have skyrocketed. Porn searches are up 83 percent. For heroin, it’s 32 percent.

headline: My Father, the Priest
abstract: It works fine to be both a priest and a family man. I’ve seen it in action.
lead_paragraph: WHEN anyone asks what my father does, I say he’s a retired teacher. He did, after all, teach high school science and Latin, so I’m not lying. I’m just not telling the whole story: My father, married to my mother for 45 years, is a Catholic priest. Not a former priest, but a member of the clergy in good standing in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport, Conn. Especially on a date, that’s a conversation stopper.

headline: Why I Use Trigger Warnings
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: They don’t coddle. They help create a better environment for learning.
lead_paragraph: TRIGGER warnings have been getting a lot of pushback lately. Professors who have adopted the practice of alerting their students to potentially disturbing content in a text or class are being accused of coddling millennials. And the students who request them are being called “infantile,” or worse. In a recent story in The Atlantic, the authors Greg Lukianoff and Jonathan Haidt describe them as part of a movement, “undirected and driven largely by students, to scrub campuses clean of words, ideas, and subjects that might cause discomfort or give offense.”

headline: Elizabeth Engelhardt
abstract: A professor of Southern studies on boardinghouse history, the Steep Canyon Rangers and Nascar.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Engelhardt is a professor of Southern studies at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill. Her research focuses on the interplay of food, race, gender, sports, ecology and culture in the South.

headline: Arab Coalition Bombs Yemen’s Capital, Killing Dozens
abstract: Saudi-led airstrikes targeted government buildings and residential neighborhoods in Sana overnight on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — A Saudi-led military coalition bombarded government buildings and residential neighborhoods in Sana, the Yemeni capital, overnight on Saturday, killing more than two dozen people, officials and witnesses said, and destroying homes in Sana’s Old City, a Unesco World Heritage site.

headline: Facebook Group’s Push for Safe Land Passage for Migrants Founders
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Social Media']
abstract: The effort showed the determination of asylum seekers to gain a coherent policy that will help them make their journeys and save lives.
lead_paragraph: EDIRNE, Turkey — Doaa, a 25-year old Syrian, was lying in the shade one day last week, trying to shelter herself from the scorching sun in a makeshift camp near this northwestern border city. A pile of blankets next to her quivered, and a tiny hand emerged. Her son, Nassim, was just a week old.

headline: Cubans Have Mixed Opinions on Effect of Visit by Pope Francis
abstract: As Pope Francis arrives for a four-day stay in Cuba, residents wonder if he will speak publicly about political freedom and what change, if any, his visit will bring to the nation.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — In a dilapidated eatery in Old Havana, Josef Fonseca, 92, sat in a worn plastic chair Saturday evening watching the arrival of Pope Francis in Cuba on a television with a snowy screen.

headline: In Long Run, Cardinals Hope That a Breather Helps
abstract: While the Mets try to carefully plot their young pitchers’ workload down the stretch, the Cardinals, who on Tuesday became the first team to reach 90 victories, are doing the same thing.
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis Cardinals, to nobody’s surprise, became the first team to reach 90 victories when they won in Milwaukee on Tuesday. The Cardinals could climb to 100 wins in the regular season, a feat unmatched since the Philadelphia Phillies did it in 2011. Naturally, the Cardinals beat those Phillies in the playoffs and went on to win the World Series.

headline: The Latest Jewels: Like Found Family Heirlooms
abstract: Warm metals, intricate designs and colored stones mimic make new designs seem timeless.
lead_paragraph: Warm metals, intricate designs and colored stones mimic make new designs seem timeless.

abstract: Simone Rocha presents her spring collection.
lead_paragraph: Simone Rocha presents her spring collection.

headline: Giants’ Defense Off to a Slow Start in Steve Spagnuolo’s Return Engagement
abstract: Although the defensive coordinator’s second stint with the team cannot be assessed so soon, it is fraught with problems as the Giants face the explosive Atlanta Falcons on Sunday at MetLife Stadium.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Coach Tom Coughlin, trying to address failures that contributed to his team’s missing the playoffs each of the last three seasons, returned to a glorious chapter in the franchise’s past when he hired Steve Spagnuolo as defensive coordinator in January.

headline: Pope Francis, Arriving in Cuba, Seeks to Revive Church
abstract: Francis arrived in Havana on Saturday for the first stop of a nine-day papal trip that includes the United States. The first Latin American pope must now try to open up Cuba to the Roman Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — In brokering the historic thaw between Cuba and the United States, Pope Francis stepped squarely into the thorny realm of geopolitics, sending letters to the presidents of both nations, playing host to secret meetings in the halls of the Vatican and nudging the Cold War enemies to put a half-century of vitriol and mistrust behind them.

headline: This Rugby Player Creates Rhymes and Rhythm
abstract: Mike Petri, a teacher who wrote a children’s book about rugby, is a key cog of the United States team that begins play in the Rugby World Cup on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: BRIGHTON AND HOVE, England — Just before Thanksgiving in 2013, Mike Petri and his wife, Lauren, were browsing in a bookstore in Bethlehem, Pa. Lauren was due to give birth to the couple’s first child in a few weeks, and so the couple were looking to fill out their collection of children’s books. They grabbed plenty of standards — “The Very Hungry Caterpillar,” some Dr. Seuss titles — but Petri was looking for something specific.

headline: J.W. Anderson’s Spring 2016 Space Adventure
abstract: The designer described his inspiration as a “women’s odyssey.”
lead_paragraph: The designer described his inspiration as a “women’s odyssey.”

headline: For a Day, the Yankees Do All the Right Things and Throttle the Mets
abstract: Despite having just three wins in their last 10 games, the Yankees, who still have a division title in play, looked almost flawless in a victory over the Mets on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The division title is still possible for the Yankees, who played almost flawlessly in a 5-0 victory against the Mets on Saturday, but a wild-card berth would not be an embarrassment. The Yankees always have grander hopes, anyway.
