keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The migrants poured into Austria on Saturday after being bounced around the Balkans, as Hungary grudgingly allowed at least 11,000 to enter from Croatia.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Thousands of migrants poured into Austria on Saturday after being bounced around countries overwhelmed by their arrival and insistent that they keep moving.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, in Own Ways, Show Pull at New Hampshire Convention
abstract: Mrs. Clinton turned to New Hampshire Democratic officials for help in fighting the surging campaign of Mr. Sanders for the presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Hillary Rodham Clinton turned to New Hampshire Democratic officials and county leaders on Saturday for help in fighting the surging campaign of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, who holds a steady lead over her in state opinion polls in the 2016 presidential primary race.

headline: Carly Fiorina Draws Notice as Republicans, Hoping to Stand Out, Visit Michigan
abstract: At the Mackinac Republican Leadership Conference in Michigan on Saturday, Republican hopefuls looked to escape the shadow of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich. — Emboldened by a heralded debate performance, Carly Fiorina brought an air of political star power to this Michigan resort island in Lake Huron on Saturday, captivating a gathering of party activists with her toughness and vision for Republican leadership.

headline: With Chelsea and Arsenal, a Chilly Handshake Kicks Off a Heated Afternoon
abstract: As with their teams and their teams’ fans, there isn’t a lot of love lost between Chelsea Manager José Mourinho and Arsenal Manager Arsène Wenger.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — So, let’s begin with the important stuff: José Mourinho, the brilliant (and occasionally belligerent) manager of Chelsea, did, in fact, shake hands on Saturday with Arsène Wenger, the professorial (and occasionally petty) manager of Arsenal. Their palms touched!

headline: Assistant Coach With Potential Bides Time on Liberty
abstract: The Liberty finished with the best record in the W.N.B.A. and Katie Smith, a former player in her second season as an assistant, was the architect of the team’s defensive schemes.
lead_paragraph: The first player Bill Laimbeer signed after becoming coach of the Liberty was Katie Smith, then a 14-year veteran. At 38, she was past her prime and an incongruous on-court addition for a team looking to rebuild around youth after a disappointing 15-19 season in 2012.

headline: Falcons (1-0) at Giants (0-1) Matchup
abstract: With Victor Cruz still sidelined by a calf injury, the Giants are looking for a big game from Odell Beckham Jr. , last season’s offensive rookie of the year.
lead_paragraph: 1 p.m., Fox

headline: Put a Lid on It!
abstract: A Sunday puzzle debut by Jason Mueller, ably assisted by Jeff Chen, that’s just the tops.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today we welcome a new constructor. Jason Mueller, ably assisted by Jeff Chen, makes his New York Times debut with a theme that is absolutely charming. It’s the TOPS, in fact.

headline: At 88, Tom Benson Conducts Business as Usual for New Orleans Teams
abstract: The threat that his teams might be taken away is fading, and Benson has gone back to work, not slipped into an emeritus role, the way owners his age might be expected to do.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — In his three decades as owner of the Saints, Tom Benson has had his share of off-season drama. In 2005, he temporarily moved the team to Texas after Hurricane Katrina swamped New Orleans. Five years later, the Saints basked in the glow of their only Super Bowl victory. Then, in 2012, the N.F.L. penalized the team for rewarding players who hurt opponents.

headline: Latino Catholics See Reflection in a Friar Set for Sainthood
abstract: When Pope Francis canonizes him on Wednesday, Junípero Serra, a Spanish friar who founded nine Catholic missions in California, will become the first Hispanic saint from the United States.
lead_paragraph: VENTURA, Calif. — On his way to Mass every morning at Mission San Buenaventura, Miguel Olivas drives past the bronze statue of the Catholic mission’s founder, Junípero Serra, a Spanish Franciscan friar, and murmurs a plea: “Pray for me, Father Serra. Watch over me.”

lead_paragraph: A number of nongovernmental organizations have contributed aid to Syrian refugees in Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey, but not enough to keep them from fleeing to Europe, according to the United Nations.

headline: U.N. Funding Shortfalls and Cuts in Refugee Aid Fuel Exodus to Europe
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Refugees who cannot get assistance where they are will risk travel, aid officials say, especially when Europe seems to beckon.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of the prime reasons for the wave of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers washing into Europe is the deterioration of the conditions that Syrians face in Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey, a worsening largely caused by sharp falls in international funding from United Nations countries, officials and analysts say.

headline: Islamic Militants Kill 56 Captive Syrian Soldiers
abstract: The Nusra Front, an affiliate of Al Qaeda, killed dozens of Syrian government soldiers who had been taken prisoner when a northern air base was captured this month.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Islamic militants led by an affiliate of Al Qaeda gunned down dozens of Syrian government soldiers taken prisoner during the takeover of a military air base this month, antigovernment activists said Saturday.

headline: Score Is Lopsided in 22nd Straight Loss, but Columbia Finds Room for Optimism
abstract: To start Coach Al Bagnoli’s tenure, Columbia unveiled a team long on spirit and determination, one that may rise or at least free itself of a burdensome losing streak that punctuates decades of failure.
lead_paragraph: As Columbia Coach Al Bagnoli led his team back to the visitors’ locker room after a 44-24 loss to Fordham on Saturday at Jack Coffey Field, excited fans who gathered along the pathway cheered even though the Lions had absorbed their 22nd consecutive defeat. But this loss was a hopeful one. It did not feel like so many others.

headline: Haunted by Memories for 100 Years
abstract: In 1915, Mamie Kirkland and her family fled Ellisville, Miss., in fear that her father would be lynched. She swore she would never return. But at age 107, she made the journey.
lead_paragraph: In 1915, Mamie Kirkland and her family fled Ellisville, Miss., in fear that her father would be lynched. She swore she would never return. But at age 107, she made the journey.

abstract: Noah Syndergaard delivered missiles that hit 98, 97, 99 miles per hour on Saturday. But the Yankees set upon him like wolves on carrion, going on to win the game, 5-0.
lead_paragraph: Wham! Wham! Whack. Wham! Whack.

headline: Jackie Collins, Best-Selling Novelist of Hollywood, Dies at 77
abstract: Ms. Collins’s sex-filled, escapist (and even once banned) fiction was devoured by tens of millions of readers.
lead_paragraph: Jackie Collins, who wrote the kind of novels that tweedy English professors typically ignore or sniff at — sex-filled, escapist, utterly unpretentious — but that millions of readers devour and teenagers used to read by flashlight under the covers at night, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. She was 77.

headline: Horror Drove Her From South. 100 Years Later, She Returned.
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Lynching', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Vigilantes']
abstract: After decades of saying she didn’t even want to see the state on a map, Mamie Lang Kirkland returned to Ellisville, Miss., 100 years after her family fled a lynch mob.
lead_paragraph: ELLISVILLE, Miss. — The dark S.U.V. rented for the occasion stopped outside the one-story City Hall. A wheelchair was rolled up to receive a petite passenger wearing a baseball cap dappled with sparkles, her hair gray-white, her skin mocha brown, her socks hot pink.

headline: As Some Veteran Yankees Wear Down, Rested Ones Contribute to Victory
abstract: The Yankees are benefiting from the production of the veteran Carlos Beltran, 38, who led the team to a 5-0 victory over the Mets on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The way Carlos Beltran, 38, moves and carries himself these days — it’s a wonder he’s not sipping prune juice in the dugout — Noah Syndergaard, brash and blessed with one of baseball’s best arms, was surely thinking what other pitchers have thought this season: No way can he touch my best fastball.

lead_paragraph: Noël Verset, whose perseverance laboring in the steep, granite vineyards of Cornas, in the Rhône Valley of France, helped the Cornas appellation survive to be discovered by a new generation of wine lovers, died on Sept. 11 in Guilherand-Granges, France. He was 95.

headline: I Said We’d Never Hire a College Admissions Adviser. Then We Did.
abstract: We thought we could help our son through the college application process. We were wrong.
lead_paragraph: As I watched my friends with teenagers begin the college search process, I quietly judged those who hired a college admissions adviser. Certainly the admissions process is hard, but hiring someone to help your kid through the process? That’s something that “those” parents do, and we were not going to be those parents.

headline: 1915: German Armies Occupy Vilna
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The capital of Lithuania is taken by the German army in 1915.
lead_paragraph: Vilna, capital of the Government of that name and the biggest city of Lithuania, has been occupied by the Germans. Details of the city’s fall have not yet been made known, but there is every reason to suppose that the Russian army of occupation has withdrawn intact. For the last few days, as the HERALD indicated yesterday, the fate of Vilna had been in the balance. The enemy occupying Molodetchno and Vidsy, Vilna was practically cut off from all railway communication, and its evacuation, generally regarded as imminent, had doubtless been fully prepared for by the Russian high command. The fall of Vilna, says the “Times” Petrograd correspondent, will facilitate a further German advance along the northern routes and will increase Russia’s difficulties in the matter of transport, both of men and munitions. No official Russian statement has yet been issued, but even the German newspapers do not suggest that the army defending Vilna has been captured. Its escape may therefore be taken for granted, but its position is still a somewhat dangerous one, for an important enemy force threatens its flank from the east. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 21, 1915

headline: The Science Behind ‘They All Look Alike to Me’
abstract: Was the mistaken arrest of James Blake a case of racism, pure and simple, or a product of a real cognitive phenomenon that makes it hard for people of one race to distinguish among those of another?
lead_paragraph: The outcry was immediate and ferocious when a white New York City police officer tackled James Blake, the retired biracial tennis star, while arresting him this month in a case of mistaken identity. The officer mistook Mr. Blake for a black man suspected of credit card fraud, according to the police.

headline: 1940: Rumania Wants Axis’ Help to Gain Province
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Romanian leaders look for help in regaining a partitioned province in 1940.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST — One week after the formation of a National Legionary (Iron Guard) state, political order and totalitarian unity have been achieved in Rumania, and the government of Premier Gen. Ion Antonescu is ready to face the tremendous task of adjusting the country’s strained economic condition. The future of the regime and of Rumania depends upon the success of this effort, which also will determine the aid that Rumania can give Germany in its war effort. The Rumanian leaders hope to obtain axis help in re-creating a greater Rumania, which was partitioned this summer after the Nazis had said that the changes were necessary for peace in southeastern Europe. — New York Herald Tribune, September 21, 1940

headline: At Versus Versace, Long Live No-Makeup Makeup
abstract: The makeup artist Tom Pecheaux discussed backstage the importance of good skin — and letting go.
lead_paragraph: “There’s no better way to create dewy skin without any product,” said the makeup artist Tom Pecheaux backstage, as he languorously massaged the familiar contours of the model Erin Wasson’s face. “It’s not only about the physical benefits for the girl’s skin — reducing puffiness and promoting radiance — it’s a moment to let go.” This product-less, skin-on-skin procedure was the building block for the luminous beauty look at the Versus Versace spring/summer 2016 show, where nude tones (and undone, tousled hair) softened the black and navy tailoring that was the mainstay of the collection.

headline: Drug Goes From $13.50 a Tablet to $750, Overnight

headline: U.S. Soldiers Told to Ignore Sexual Abuse of Boys by Afghan Allies
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The American military’s policy has been to look the other way on “boy play” by Afghan commanders. One Marine’s father believes it was a factor in his son’s death.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In his last phone call home, Lance Cpl. Gregory Buckley Jr. told his father what was troubling him: From his bunk in southern Afghanistan, he could hear Afghan police officers sexually abusing boys they had brought to the base.

headline: Metropolitan Opera Showcases Portraits for ‘Otello’ Opening
abstract: The show, in the opera house’s south lobby, is keyed to a new production of Verdi’s opera and the opening of a new season.
lead_paragraph: “These are portents; but yet I hope, I hope/They do not point on me,” says Desdemona in Shakespeare’s “Othello,” before her voice is stifled forever. The drawings and paintings of the British artist Celia Paul — dark, caustic self-portraits and portraits of women in her family — are nothing if not portentous. And 14 of her works will help kick off the Metropolitan Opera’s new season, in “Desdemona for Celia by Hilton,” a collaborative exhibition by Ms. Paul and the critic Hilton Als at Gallery Met, in conjunction with the opera’s new production of Verdi’s “Otello,” which opens Monday.

headline: 2 Americans Among 6 Hostages Freed in Yemen After Months of Captivity
abstract: The White House announced that the two men were freed along with a British citizen and three Saudis, all of whom had been held by Houthi rebels.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two Americans held hostage for months by rebels in Yemen were freed on Sunday and quickly flown to safety in nearby Oman, which helped the United States secure the release of the men, American officials said.

headline: Drunk Girl Pretty at Topshop Unique
abstract: Backstage at the spring 2016 show, the makeup artist said the look is Princess Margaret meets Courtney Love — “at a really debauched garden party.”
lead_paragraph: “It’s Princess Margaret meets Courtney Love, and they’re at a really debauched garden party,” is how the makeup artist Hannah Murray explained the irreverent beauty look backstage at Topshop Unique’s spring 2016 show today. Leaving the skin super fresh, Murray worked with Topshop’s Kohl Pencil to loosely frame the upper and lower lids, adding Glow Pot gloss over the top to create a wet, petrol-hued finish. “This girl cares, but not too much,” she added.

headline: A Fancy Melon Set, Reissued
abstract: Made of radiant silver with a softly hammered surface, it’s part graceful scalpel, part elegant spork.
lead_paragraph: A wedge of cantaloupe, its sweetness intensified by savory paper-thin prosciutto, is a sophisticated dish worthy of its own superlative utensils. The legendary Danish design house Georg Jensen rises to the challenge with this exquisite melon set made of radiant silver with a softly hammered surface — part graceful scalpel, part elegant spork. With furled leaves, tapered endpoints and handles like Ionic columns, the pattern represents the bridge between the house’s Art Nouveau roots and its embrace of Modernism. Out of production for decades, this set is part of a limited edition of reissued pieces, each crafted for luxuriously specialized tasks, from the Acorn collection created in 1915 by the designer Johan Rohde. Also on offer are a dainty grapefruit spoon and a new champagne saber, a Napoleonic-era tool that opens a bottle with one sharp blow to the neck.

headline: Republicans Ensnared in Questions of Identity Politics
abstract: Several presidential candidates took to the Sunday talk shows to clarify points and weigh in on new controversies.
lead_paragraph: As presidential candidates wrapped up busy weekends in South Carolina, Michigan, Iowa and other states, several took to the Sunday talk shows to clarify points and weigh in on new controversies. Identity politics have resurfaced on the Republican side and a new CNN/ORC poll shows that less than a week after the party’s second debate Donald J. Trump is clinging to his lead, while Carly Fiorina has surged into second place ahead of Ben Carson. Senator Marco Rubio of Florida is also showing signs of gaining traction, while Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has fallen to the back of the pack. Here are the highlights.

headline: More On The Political Economy Of Permahawkery
abstract: Lessons from trade policy.
lead_paragraph: To be honest, I’m feeling rather stupid about not understanding until now how to make sense of the ever-changing rationales for the ever-changing demand for higher interest rates. As someone who started in international trade, I more than anyone should have known that specific factors, not Stolper-Samuelson, is usually the way to go.

headline: Software Is Smart Enough for SAT, but Still Far From Intelligent
abstract: In a first, an artificial intelligence program answered math questions on the SAT by understanding diagrams and sentences, but scientists say machine thinking is still a long way off.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — An artificial intelligence software program capable of seeing and reading has for the first time answered geometry questions from the SAT at the level of an average 11th grader.

headline: Mary Katrantzou: Spring 2016 RTW
abstract: Mary Katrantzou’s latest collection.
lead_paragraph: Mary Katrantzou’s latest collection.

headline: Review: From Twyla Tharp, 2 New Pieces for Her Anniversary Tour
abstract: Ms. Tharp’s tour, a summation of her career, opened at the Winspear Opera House in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — After making dances for half a century, Twyla Tharp could have celebrated with a victory lap, assembling an elite crew of dancers to tour a greatest-hits program sampling some of the dazzling works that long ago earned her a ranking among the greatest and most influential of American choreographers. Instead, for the 50th-anniversary tour that opened at the Winspear Opera House here on Friday and will conclude in New York in November, Ms. Tharp has fashioned a pair of new pieces: “Preludes and Fugues” and “Yowzie.”

headline: Giants Collapse Again, This Time at Home Against the Atlanta Falcons
abstract: After leading for most of the game, the Giants let Matt Ryan and Julio Jones beat them late.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For a second straight week, the Giants were storming toward an opponent’s goal line, yards from taking a commanding second-half lead. After a sluggish start, the Giants had turned dominant, and all the momentum was theirs.

headline: Xi Jinping’s U.S. Visit
abstract: Re-inflating the Chinese economy.
lead_paragraph: Re-inflating the Chinese economy.

headline: Apollo Announces Season Lineup, Starts Comedy Club
abstract: The Apollo Theater will host music, dance and a new comedy series this fall and winter.
lead_paragraph: The Apollo Theater has hosted plenty of notable comedians over the years, including Richard Pryor and Redd Foxx. Now, it is starting the Apollo Comedy Club as part of its fall-winter lineup.

headline: Patriots’ Brady Passes and Passes and Passes, and the Bills Are Thrown
abstract: Tom Brady had 466 passing yards, the second-highest total of his career, and New England won for the 11th time in its past 12 games at Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — With the Bills relying on a new coach, Rex Ryan, and a new quarterback, Tyrod Taylor, there were some expectations that this meeting between Buffalo and the New England Patriots might finally have a different result.

headline: ‘Maze Runner’ Sequel Races to No. 1 at Box Office
abstract: “Maze Runner: Scorch Trials” fell short of its predecessor’s ticket totals, but still hit No. 1.
lead_paragraph: Although “Maze Runner: Scorch Trials” easily topped the weekend box office in its debut, selling a sturdy $30.3 million in tickets, that total fell short of the take for “The Maze Runner” last fall, reinforcing a movie business axiom: Sequels do best when filmmakers don’t fiddle too much with the formula.

headline: Boat on East River Capsizes; Fire Department Rescues 19
keywords: ['Boats and Boating', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The Fire Department said no one in the large rowboat, which left from a Queens marina and whose passengers included a man who proposed to his girlfriend, had been injured.
lead_paragraph: It was a seemingly lovely afternoon to go out on the East River and do something memorable. For the group that left the marina in College Point, Queens, on Sunday in a dragon boat, the authorities said, that was exactly the plan.

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic Accompanies ‘On the Waterfront’ and ‘The Godfather’
abstract: The “Art of the Score” series demonstrates the challenges of retaining the dialogue from an original soundtrack while cutting out the music that originally played in the background.
lead_paragraph: The idea behind the Art of the Score series, one of the most popular innovations of the New York Philharmonic in recent years, could not be simpler: classic films are screened at Avery Fisher Hall with the Philharmonic playing the score live. But the execution of these projects is anything but simple.

headline: Review: Scott Shane’s ‘Objective Troy,’ on Killing the American Jihadist Anwar al-Awlaki
abstract: Mr. Shane, a reporter for The New York Times, calls Mr. Awlaki’s deliberate killing by his government, without a trial or court order, an example of the “dirty hands” concept in ethics.
lead_paragraph: In September 2011, in northern Yemen, C.I.A. Predator drones killed Anwar al-Awlaki, an American citizen who was then 40 years old. He was a skinny, charismatic preacher educated at Colorado State University. As a younger man he had displayed a weakness for prostitutes and had devoured books about leadership like “The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People,” by Stephen R. Covey. At the time of his death, Mr. Awlaki advocated killing fellow Americans in the name of jihad. He had embraced Al Qaeda’s branch in Yemen and had participated in plots to blow up American airplanes.

headline: Review: A ‘Resurrection’ in Tune With the Atlanta Symphony’s Renewal
abstract: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra opened its 71st season — a year after its 70th was delayed and then shortened — with Mahler’s symphony and a full chorus.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Prescient as Mahlerians like to think their hero was, Mahler could not have imagined how useful his “Resurrection” Symphony would become in 21st-century America, with orchestra after orchestra emerging from a near-death crisis of one sort or another.

headline: Review: ‘Whistleblower,’ a Dance-Theater Take on Chelsea Manning
abstract: This Mark Dendy cabaret explores the story of Ms. Manning, formerly Bradley Manning, who is serving a prison term for leaking documents.
lead_paragraph: When the Army private Chelsea Manning, known at the time as Bradley Manning, leaked more than 700,000 sensitive documents, the possibility of a trial and sentence in a military prison may have been foreseeable. Less easy to predict was that the private’s situation would inspire “Whistleblower,” a piece of dance theater by the writer, director and choreographer Mark Dendy.

headline: Review: Banda de los Muertos Brings the Party for Its Album Debut
abstract: A cross-cultural experiment under the cover of staunch traditionalism, the ensemble addresses the Mexican brass band music as a literature and a style.
lead_paragraph: Banda de los Muertos locked into a boisterous churn almost from the start of its show on Friday night at Pioneer Works in Red Hook, Brooklyn. Playing “El Sinaloense,” a Mexican brass band standard, the group sputtered and blared, rolling hard with tumbling polyrhythm, filling the room with sound. As if on cue, dancing broke out in the audience, starting with a handful of couples near the foot of the stage.

headline: Review: In ‘Blindspot,’ an Amnesiac’s Tattoos Are the Clues
abstract: An unattended duffel bag in Times Square contains a big surprise for the F.B.I.: a naked woman covered with tattoos who has no idea who she is.
lead_paragraph: From its opening scene, a spine-tingling if-you-see-something-say-something moment, NBC’s “Blindspot” is an attention getter. Who knows whether its somewhat lurid central gimmick is sturdy enough to carry it for the long haul, but the show, which has its premiere Monday night, certainly gets off to an intriguing start.

headline: Review: In ‘Age & Beauty,’ Miguel Gutierrez Ponders the Personal and the Professional
abstract: This three-part choreographic series delves into queerness and how it relates to issues like aging, emotions and legacy.
lead_paragraph: If part of watching dance is piecing together afterimages, what is the effect of seeing a trilogy out of order? Enlightening. Miguel Gutierrez’s “Age & Beauty,” Parts 1 and 2, were reprised over the weekend in a co-presentation of New York Live Arts, where the works were performed, and Crossing the Line 2015.

headline: Review: Traditional Dance From Okinawa at Japan Society
abstract: A rare program showcased centuries-old court dances and more recent popular folk dances from that island chain.
lead_paragraph: For a dancegoer in New York, fall can feel like an onrush of the new, of premieres and untested experiments, by turns exciting and overwhelming. In the midst of all that, it was refreshing to spend time with something ancient on Friday, when the Japan Society offered “Traditional Dance From Okinawa With Live Music,” a rare and exquisite program showcasing the performing arts of Japan’s southwestern islands.

headline: Review: ‘Life in Pieces,’ a CBS Comedy, Told in Vignettes
abstract: In this new show, whose cast includes James Brolin and Dianne Wiest, a family’s identity is conveyed in six-minute-long stories.
lead_paragraph: “Life in Pieces,” which begins Monday on CBS, may be the ultimate antidote for those who find the supposed new golden age of television to be exhausting and time-eating. If that golden age is characterized by intricate, character-rich dramas that have to be watched from Season 1, Episode 1, here’s a half-hour comedy you can consume in six-minute bites, as many or as few as you want.

headline: ‘Masaan’ and Other Indian Films Steer Away From Bollywood Escapism
abstract: “Masaan” is the surest sign yet that a fresh crop of filmmakers are ushering Indian movies toward a new direction.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — At the beginning of “Masaan,” the most acclaimed Indian movie of the year, two lovers meet at a ramshackle motel in the holy northern city of Varanasi. In the middle of their clandestine sexual encounter, police officers barge into the room and threaten the couple, setting off a chain of events with devastating consequences. Composed of parallel yet interconnected tales, “Masaan” explores India’s forces of caste and social conservatism, which continue to hold sway as the country makes a dizzying passage into the modern world.

headline: Mary Katrantzou’s Cosmic Chaos
abstract: The designer focused on the theme of exploration for her spring/summer 2016 collection.
lead_paragraph: The designer focused on the theme of exploration for her spring/summer 2016 collection.

headline: Review: Argento Chamber Ensemble’s ‘Scelsi Rediscovered’
abstract: The concert, part of the Austrian Cultural Forum’s Moving Sounds festival, also featured an American premiere by the composer Georg Friedrich Haas.
lead_paragraph: “Scelsi Rediscovered” was the title given to the Argento Chamber Ensemble’s simmering concert Friday evening at the Czech Center New York. But it hasn’t been all that long since this enigmatic, reclusive Italian master was discovered in the first place. Not until the years before Scelsi’s death in 1988 did his works — some more than 50 years old at that point — become widely known.

headline: Here Comes Trouble
abstract: The return of Bruce Haight.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — A succinct scrutiny of the puzzle today: This one by Bruce Haight looks relatively non-challenging on the surface, but offers a “one-two punch” when you realize that, yes, this theme is merely a bunch of two-word “S-S” phrases, but they’re all either abutting each other or — even better — interlocking. That’s a neat surprise on a Monday.

headline: Alabama Church Shooting Wounds Infant and 2 Adults
abstract: The police said they had arrested a suspect, the father of the wounded infant. The child’s mother and the church’s pastor were also wounded.
lead_paragraph: A man walked into a church service in East Selma, Ala., on Sunday morning and opened fire with a handgun, shooting his 24-year-old girlfriend and their infant son and then the pastor before being disarmed by congregants, according to the police.

headline: Bipartisan Effort Fights Health Law Rule That Could Raise Premiums
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Small Business', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Some lawmakers want to head off changes to the Affordable Care Act that could subject more small companies to greater insurance requirements.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress from both parties, as well as some employers, insurers and state insurance commissioners, are calling for changes in the Affordable Care Act to prevent premium increases that are expected to affect workers at many small and midsize companies next year.

headline: Cowboys Search for Answers After Tony Romo Injury
abstract: Romo, who made the Pro Bowl last season, broke the same clavicle in a loss to the Giants in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Dealing a major blow to the Dallas Cowboys, their star quarterback Tony Romo left Sunday’s 20-10 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles with a broken left clavicle. He did not return and may be out for an extended amount of time.

headline: Clever, a Software Service, Gives Schools a Way to Manage Data Flow to Apps
abstract: A new company, Clever, is addressing questions raised by politicians and parents about the data on students, and how it is secured and used.
lead_paragraph: For years, Mark Racine, the technology director of the Boston Public Schools, and his team plodded through a cumbersome exercise at the start of each school year: transferring student roster information from school databases to the various learning apps that teachers wanted to use in the classroom.

headline: Emmy Red Carpet Fashion
abstract: Looks from Taraji P. Henson, Kerry Washington, Laverne Cox and more at the 67th Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: Looks from Taraji P. Henson, Kerry Washington, Laverne Cox and more at the 67th Emmy Awards.

headline: President ‘Heartbroken’ Over Death of Adviser
abstract: Jake Brewer, who worked in the office of the chief technology officer at the White House, was taking part in a charity bike ride when he was killed in an accident.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said on Sunday that he was “heartbroken” at the death of a technology policy adviser, Jake Brewer, who was killed in a cycling accident on Saturday while participating in a charity ride to raise money for cancer research.

headline: ISIS Defectors Reveal Disillusionment
abstract: A small but growing number of those who have left the Islamic State are risking reprisals and imprisonment to speak out.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A small but growing number of defectors from the Islamic State are risking reprisals and imprisonment to speak out about their disillusionment with the extremist group, according to a research organization that tracks former and current militants.

headline: Amid Protests, Nepal Adopts Constitution
abstract: After nearly a decade of delay, the Himalayan nation formally adopted a constitution, though some object to provincial boundaries.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — After nearly a decade of delay marked by haggling and political infighting, Nepal formally adopted a constitution on Sunday, with President Ram Baran Yadav calling the moment a realization of “the continuous democratic movements initiated by Nepalese people” after he signed the document.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 21
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: A Rookie Brings Her Skills to the ‘Super Bowl’ of Social Planning
abstract: Deesha Dyer, the new White House social secretary, will have her skills tested with visits from the pope and China’s president and a United Nations conclave.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Imagine a week in which you arrange the halftime show for the Super Bowl, organize the trophy ceremony for the World Cup and then, for good measure, plan your daughter’s wedding.

headline: C. K. Williams, Poet, Dies at 78; Pulitzer Winner Tackled Politics and Morality
abstract: Mr. Williams poems dealt with war, poverty and climate change, winning him a Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award.
lead_paragraph: C. K. Williams, whose morally impassioned poems addressing war, poverty and climate change, as well as the imponderable mysteries of the psyche, won him a Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award, died on Sunday at his home in Hopewell. N.J. He was 78.

headline: G.O.P. Field Wrestles With Questions on Islam and the Presidency
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Muslim Americans', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s handling of a question about President Obama’s faith last week rippled through the Sunday talk shows, where his rivals often offered halting responses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Faith and politics intersected on Sunday when discussions of how Donald J. Trump handled a question about President Obama’s religion evolved into an awkward debate over whether a Muslim could ever be commander in chief.

headline: Lawmakers Seek National Park in Honor of Stonewall
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Stonewall Riots (1969)']
abstract: Federal lawmakers announced a campaign urging the president to honor a historic site in gay rights history.
lead_paragraph: Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York and Representative Jerrold Nadler of Manhattan unveiled a campaign on Sunday to create a national park honoring the Stonewall uprising, vowing that they would mount a petition drive urging President Obama to grant protected status to the site of a pivotal early clash in the movement for gay equality.

headline: In Courting Chinese Companies, Britain to Help Fund Planned Nuclear Plant
abstract: Britain said it would provide £2 billion as the government looks to China to help finance the new Hinkley Point station, which will cost at least £16 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government said on Monday that it would provide 2 billion pounds, or about $3.1 billion, in state aid for a nuclear power station planned for Hinkley Point in southwest England.

headline: Running Afoul of the Thai Monarchy
abstract: Thailand’s strict lèse-majesté laws make it a crime to insult the monarchy, an offense that includes a surprising number of activities.
lead_paragraph: Thailand’s strict lèse-majesté laws make it a crime to insult the monarchy, an offense that includes a surprising number of activities.

headline: With King in Declining Health, Future of Monarchy in Thailand Is Uncertain
keywords: ['Royal Family', 'Libel and Slander', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Worries over the transition have accelerated an extremely delicate debate over what kind of monarchy Thailand should have.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — After nearly seven decades on the throne, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, 87, the keystone of Thailand’s identity and a major unifying force for the country, is in declining health. With increasing frequency, the palace has issued medical bulletins detailing his ailments, and in recent days his youngest daughter has led prayer sessions following a Buddhist rite normally used for terminally ill patients.

headline: Kickstarter Focuses Its Mission on Altruism Over Profit
abstract: Yancey Strickler and Perry Chen, the crowdfunding site’s co-founders, announce that their company is reincorporating as a “public benefit corporation.”
lead_paragraph: Many technology start-ups aim to become “unicorns,” the companies that get valued at $1 billion or more on their way to probable vast riches. Yancey Strickler and Perry Chen have no interest in that.

headline: Russian Project Honors Stalin’s Victims and Stirs Talk on Brutal Past
abstract: Memorializing victims at their last known homes, the Last Address project hopes to start conversations among neighbors to help process a brutal period in Soviet history.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — In a society stewing in nationalist sentiment, a little project called Last Address seems almost seditious.

headline: Tireless Star and Unorthodox Coach Help Lead Britain to Davis Cup Final
abstract: Leon Smith had no experience of competing professionally when he was appointed captain of Britain’s Davis Cup team in April 2010. Now he has helped execute one of the most drastic reversals in the competition’s history.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — Leon Smith was a curious choice when he was appointed captain of Britain’s Davis Cup team in April 2010. The team was on the verge of being relegated to the lowest levels of the competition, a tennis underworld populated by nations like San Marino and Liechtenstein and their squads of part-timers.

headline: Emmy Awards Red Carpet Fashion
abstract: Looks from Taraji P. Henson, Laverne Cox and more at the 67th Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: The 67th prime time Emmy Awards on Sunday night in Los Angeles, brought television’s top performers, technicians and creators together for a night of self-congratulation and ceremony.

headline: Only Thing in Leonard Fournette’s Way: N.F.L. Rule Book
abstract: Louisiana State’s Leonard Fournette is not eligible for the N.F.L., but some argue that he is ready to play in the league.
lead_paragraph: There was a rare moment of stillness at the beginning of Louisiana State’s 45-21 rout of visiting Auburn on Saturday. The Tigers — purple version — handed off to Leonard Fournette, and he stalled with some careful stutter-steps, letting L.S.U.’s offensive linemen clear his path.

headline: New York Military Academy’s Sudden Closing, After 126 Years
abstract: The academy, which counts Donald J. Trump, Stephen Sondheim and John A. Gotti among its alumni, is set to be auctioned after struggling financially for years.
lead_paragraph: CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — Among its thousands of alumni, the 126-year-old New York Military Academy counts the unlikely grouping of Donald J. Trump, Stephen Sondheim and John A. Gotti. Yet all three have this in common: They remember their time at the prep school with deep affection.

headline: Apple Confirms Discovery of Malicious Code in Some App Store Products
abstract: Security researchers said hackers took advantage of the fact that many Chinese developers use copies of code that are held on Chinese servers, resulting in a malicious version of Xcode.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hackers have found their way into Apple’s App Store.

headline: Mediators in Burkino Faso Issue Proposals to End Strife
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Hours after they were interrupted by supporters of the military, the mediators presented proposals to resolve the political crisis created by last week’s coup.
lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Mediators proposed ways to end a political crisis stemming from last week’s coup in Burkina Faso, just hours after the hotel where they were meeting on Sunday was stormed by supporters of the military.

headline: After Battling Safety Agency, Recaro Changes Course on Car Seat Recall
keywords: ['Child Car Seats', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The recall of 173,000 Recaro Performance Ride and ProRide seats comes after a fraught 18-month process in which the company clashed with regulators.
lead_paragraph: The recall seemed to be straightforward enough: Recaro Child Safety needed to fix some of its car seats so that they would not break free during a crash.

headline: The Refugee Crisis Has Produced One Winner: Organized Crime
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Organized Crime', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Smuggling people is now as profitable, if not more so, than the trade in illegal narcotics.
lead_paragraph: IN the midst of the refugee crisis, the European Union has for the first time ever been considering deploying naval assets against organized crime. People smuggling, chiefly from Syria and the Horn of Africa, is now a multibillion-dollar business that is as profitable, if not more so, than the trade in illegal narcotics.

headline: Oregon’s Legal Sale of Marijuana Comes With Reprieve
abstract: In preparation for retail marijuana sales on Oct. 1, the state is making it possible for people to have past marijuana convictions removed from their criminal record.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — About 15 years ago, when she was in her 20s, Erika Walton handed a bong to someone who turned out be a police officer, and was cited for marijuana possession. She paid the fine, she said, but the violation lingered on, haunting her record.

headline: On Instagram and Other Social Media, Redefining ‘User Engagement’
abstract: The intersection between brands trying to capitalize on social media activity and people’s expectation of privacy has become murky.
lead_paragraph: Shereen Way did not think twice about posting a photo on Instagram of her 4-year-old daughter wearing a green dress and pink Crocs sandals.

headline: Muscle Strain Will Keep Masahiro Tanaka From Making a Key Start in Toronto
abstract: Tanaka, the Yankees’ best pitcher, has a Grade 1 strain of his right hamstring and will miss his next start — which is Wednesday against the Blue Jays, a team the Yankees are chasing for the American League East title.
lead_paragraph: Yankees Manager Joe Girardi opened his pregame news conference Sunday afternoon by saying he would start the proceedings. Normally, Girardi begins by fielding questions from reporters, so it was clear some kind of announcement was coming, and very likely it was bad news.

headline: A Game Changer for the Giants, for Better or Worse
abstract: On Sunday, the Giants became the first team in N.F.L. history to blow two double-digit leads in two games to open the season. And quarterback Eli Manning played a prominent role in giving away the game.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Fans tend to treat the N.F.L. season like an H. G. Wells science fiction story: Every week is Armageddon.

headline: Farewell to a Street Tree
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: The life of a Brooklyn family’s crabapple, from its purchase in a Vermont nursery to its youth, its blossoms, its harvests and the happiness it produced.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A Firing at The Los Angeles Times Focuses Discontent
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Austin Beutner’s departure as publisher, a position he had held only a year, widened a divide between The Los Angeles Times and its corporate parent in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In January, Jack Griffin, the chief executive of Tribune Publishing Company, took his senior management team to visit The Los Angeles Times, the jewel in his company’s portfolio of newspapers.

headline: Talented Pass Catcher Plays Defense for Jets
abstract: Cornerback Marcus Williams, a defensive specialist on his high school basketball team, was not invited to the N.F.L. scouting combine after college but impressed the Jets with his hands and work ethic.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Four of the five starters on the 2008-9 Hopkins High School boys’ basketball team, that season’s Minnesota state champion, received Division I scholarships. The exception was the 5-foot-11 point guard, who shot a little, passed a lot and relished his responsibility as a defensive stopper.

headline: Pope Francis Visits: Day 2 in Cuba
abstract: The latest from Pope Francis’ visit to Cuba and the United States.
lead_paragraph: The latest from Pope Francis’ visit to Cuba and the United States.

headline: New York City to Add Housing for Domestic Violence Victims
keywords: ['Domestic Violence', 'Homeless Persons', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The city wants to provide emergency shelter for as many as 13,300 adults and children, up from the 8,880 served now by city-funded programs.
lead_paragraph: New York City is planning to add more housing for homeless adults and children fleeing domestic violence, the latest effort by Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration to deal with a homelessness problem that has persisted as housing costs in the city have continued to soar.

headline: Jason Day Holds On to Win, and Grabs Top Ranking
abstract: Protecting a four-shot lead in Sunday’s final round of the BMW Championship, Day had set his sights on overtaking Rory McIlroy as the top-ranked player in the world golf rankings.
lead_paragraph: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — Jason Day stood behind his second shot on the 465-yard 16th hole and took a moment to close his eyes to visualize his third.

headline: And the Emmy Goes to ...
abstract: Viola Davis made history as best lead actress in a drama series at Sunday night’s ceremony in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Viola Davis made history as best lead actress in a drama series at Sunday night’s ceremony in Los Angeles.

headline: Government Declassifies Additional Portions of Once-Secret Report on Post-9/11 Surveillance
abstract: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the government has declassified additional portions of a 2009 report by five agencies’ inspectors general about the Stellarwind program, the group of N.S.A. warrantless wiretapping and bulk phone and e-mail records collection activities initiated by President George W. Bush after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. In 2009, the government released a 43-page unclassified version which omitted discussion of many key facts that then remained secret. In April, the government released an earlier version of this report. The newly declassified portions largely consist of references to and descriptions of the text of Mr. Bush’s periodic authorizations to the N.S.A, which evolved over time — especially after a March 2004 confrontation with the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the government has declassified additional portions of a 2009 report by five agencies’ inspectors general about the Stellarwind program, the group of N.S.A. warrantless wiretapping and bulk phone and e-mail records collection activities initiated by President George W. Bush after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. In 2009, the government released a 43-page unclassified version which omitted discussion of many key facts that then remained secret. In April, the government released an earlier version of this report. The newly declassified portions largely consist of references to and descriptions of the text of Mr. Bush’s periodic authorizations to the N.S.A, which evolved over time — especially after a March 2004 confrontation with the Justice Department.

headline: Charter and Time Warner Vote, and Chinese Tech Meeting in Seattle
abstract: This week, shareholders of Charter Communications and Time Warner Cable vote on the proposed merger, the Chinese president visits the United States, and Janet Yellen delivers a speech about inflation.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders of both Charter Communications and Time Warner Cable will vote on Monday on their proposed $56.7 billion merger. Announced in May, Charter’s takeover of Time Warner Cable, along with a deal for Bright House Networks, would create the country’s second-largest broadband Internet provider and third-largest video provider.

headline: Review: ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’ Tailored for Multitaskers
abstract: A cast of five plays all the roles in Shakespeare’s uproarious comedy of romantic confusions.
lead_paragraph: Everybody’s a Bottom in Eric Tucker’s riotous production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” in which a cast of five divides and multiplies like a troupe of stage-struck amoebas. Bottom the Weaver, you may recall, is the overeager amateur actor in this Shakespeare comedy of crazy mixed-up love — the one who wants to play all the parts, be they heroes, lions or ladies.

headline: George W. Bush Made Retroactive N.S.A. ‘Fix’ After Hospital Room Showdown
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Newly disclosed information sheds light on a Bush administration fight in March 2004 about the post-9/11 surveillance and data-collection program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President George W. Bush sought to retroactively authorize portions of the National Security Agency’s post-9/11 surveillance and data collection program after a now-famous incident in 2004 in which his attorney general refused to certify the program as lawful from his hospital bed, according to newly declassified portions of a government investigation.

headline: Years Ago, Mets Had Starters Who Finished With a Flourish
abstract: The apparent weariness of the Mets’ staff this season contrasts with the endurance of Tom Seaver and Jerry Koosman, who combined for 11 complete-game victories in the final month of the 1969 regular season.
lead_paragraph: As the Mets try to win their first division title since 2006, their pitchers appear to be struggling physically down the stretch. A starting rotation that once seemed overpowering is looking a little gassed.

headline: Bike-Sharing Programs Gain a Toehold in New Jersey
abstract: In traffic-packed New Jersey, urban bike-share projects are beginning to take hold following the success of programs in New York.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Last Wednesday, Steven M. Fulop, the mayor of Jersey City, got ready for one of his regular morning bike rides. He had his helmet on, but rather than his usual spandex jersey, he wore khakis, an oxford shirt and a light down vest. And instead of his $3,000 Kuota carbon-fiber racing bike, which Mr. Fulop, a former Marine, rides in triathlons, he mounted a hefty, bright blue Citi Bike.

headline: Mamdouha Bobst, Philanthropist and Public Health Advocate, Dies at 90
abstract: Mrs. Bobst donated to institutions like N.Y.U., the American Cancer Society and the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, and served as the Lebanese delegate to the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: Mamdouha Bobst, a philanthropist and public health advocate whose donations benefited universities, hospitals and clinics for animals, died on Sept. 10 in Manhattan. She was 90.

headline: Red Carpet Trend at the 2015 Emmys? Trying to Stay Cool
abstract: No single theme emerged from the red carpet this year. Only a simple message: It’s brutal out here.
lead_paragraph: It was hot, about 100 degrees hot, on some of the processional stops on the Emmys red carpet. To watch the two hours of coverage on E! — as grueling to observe as it must have been to sweat through — was to come away not with any single trend or theme, no runaway winner of the red-carpet lottery, but one simple message: It’s brutal out here.

headline: Jack Larson, a TV Jimmy Olsen Turned Playwright, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Larson, who went on to write plays and librettos, predicted that he would be best remembered as the eager cub reporter for The Daily Planet on ‘Superman.’
lead_paragraph: Jack Larson, the playwright and librettist who, as he often predicted with good-natured resignation, will be remembered best as the actor who played the cub reporter Jimmy Olsen on the television series “Adventures of Superman,” died on Sunday at his home in the Brentwood neighborhood of Los Angeles.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Fox) MINORITY REPORT This new series, based on the 2002 Steven Spielberg film starring Tom Cruise, travels ahead to 2065, by which time Pre-Crime — the ability to know in advance that a crime will be committed through foreknowledge gathered by psychics — has long been abolished and a young “precog” named Dash (Stark Sands) is trying to lead a civilian life despite continuing visions of bloodshed. Meanwhile in Washington, a police detective (Meagan Good) and a mayoral candidate (Peter Van Eyck) are struggling with the return of murder. “ ‘Minority Report,’ the TV series, appears to come from an alternative universe: one in which ‘Minority Report,’ the movie, was never made,” James Poniewozik wrote in The New York Times. “Taken on its own terms, then, ‘Minority Report’ is ... still not good,” he added. Though the future promises holographic phone calls, subway advertisements for marijuana goodies and the 75th season of “The Simpsons,” he wrote, “psychic powers make for dull detective work.” Season 2 of “Gotham,” which finds Detective Gordon (Ben McKenzie) seeking help from the Penguin after a shift in power at the Gotham City Police Department, leads in at 8. (Image: from left, Wilmer Valderrama, Li Jun Li and Ms. Good.)

headline: A Limit on Matt Harvey’s Innings Has New Fans: The Yankees
abstract: Harvey pitched well, allowing one hit in five innings, but the Mets continued to stick to their plan to limit his workload, and the Yankees pounded the bullpen to coast to another win.
lead_paragraph: Matt Harvey walked into the dugout after the fifth inning, his head down, his face flushed from a hard day’s work. His teammates greeted him with high-fives and pats on the back for his performance. He stopped and chatted with Manager Terry Collins, found a water bottle and then found a seat where he could watch the rest of the game, because his day was evidently done.

headline: Aaron Rodgers and Packers Take Advantage of Seahawks Turnovers
abstract: Green Bay linebacker Jayrone Elliott intercepted Seattle quarterback Russell Wilson in the fourth quarter of the Packers’ 27-17 victory.
lead_paragraph: For the second straight week, the Seattle Seahawks were left wondering what went wrong. The two-time defending N.F.C. champions lost to the Green Bay Packers, 27-17, on Sunday night, dropping to 0-2 for the season.

lead_paragraph: Coming off a game in which he turned two touches into 98 yards, the rookie David Johnson continued to shine for the Cardinals, returning the opening kickoff a club-record 108 yards for a touchdown to start a victory over the Bears. Johnson also ran for 42 yards on five carries with a touchdown. The rushing attack opened up things for Carson Palmer, who threw for four touchdowns.

headline: Making New Memories in the Aftermath of a Quebec Train Disaster
abstract: Michel Huneault photographed the train explosion in Lac-Mégantic and then returned to document how the small village coped. He has received the Lange-Taylor Prize from Duke University’s Center for Documentary Studies for the project.
lead_paragraph: Early in the morning of July 6, 2013, when most of the inhabitants of the small Quebec town of Lac-Mégantic were asleep in their beds, a train transporting crude oil derailed and engulfed the town in flames.

lead_paragraph: The GIF, or Graphics Interchange Format, was invented in 1987, honored as a “word of the year” in 2012 and has brought its creator a lifetime achievement award at the Webby Awards.

headline: OxyContin Is Not for Kids
abstract: The F.D.A.’s misguided approval of a powerful opiate for young people will make the fight against painkiller addiction even harder.
lead_paragraph: Montpelier, Vt. — A YEAR and a half ago, I stood up before Vermonters and devoted my State of the State address to speaking about the opiate and heroin crisis affecting my state. Despite our best efforts since, this is not a battle we are winning. Now the Food and Drug Administration is recklessly making the problem worse with its decision to approve OxyContin for use by children as young as 11 years old.

headline: Let’s Not Move to Mars
abstract: Recent plans to colonize the red planet are excessively optimistic. It is a veritable hell for living things.
lead_paragraph: IN the early years of the 20th century, zeppelins filled with flammable and explosive hydrogen were all the rage in Germany, a reckless infatuation that ended with the eruption and crash of the Hindenburg in 1937. Sometimes, technology is a triumph of wild-eyed enthusiasm over the unpleasant facts of the real world.

headline: The Pope and the Birth Control Ban
abstract: Pope Francis needs to listen to laypeople about how the church’s rules affect their lives.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis has taken a softer line than some of his predecessors on sexual and reproductive issues. He has said that the church should concentrate less on same-sex marriage, contraception and abortion, and this month he announced that during the church’s coming Holy Year of Mercy, all priests would be able to grant absolution for abortion.

headline: Mr. Putin’s Mixed Messages on Syria
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: Although the Russian leader is trying to save President Assad’s regime, President Obama must try to engage with him on the civil war and fighting ISIS.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir Putin of Russia is trying to have it both ways in Syria. He is dangerously building up Russia’s military presence there, while positioning himself as the world’s savior against Islamic extremists and holding high-level military-to-military talks with the United States. President Obama should go one step further and be prepared to meet Mr. Putin later this month when the two are at the United Nations. If there is to be a solution to the Islamic State’s advance and to Syria’s war, both Russia and America will have to be involved.

headline: The Rage of the Bankers
abstract: The truth about low interest rates, and why the arguments against leaving them alone seem to keep changing.
lead_paragraph: Last week the Federal Reserve chose not to raise interest rates. It was the right decision. In fact, I’m among the economists wondering why we’re even thinking about raising rates right now.

headline: Don’t Coronate Carly Fiorina Just Yet
abstract: The candidate is weak on facts and on her understanding of the challenges less fortunate women face.
lead_paragraph: The media has a new darling in the Republican presidential disaster pageant: Carly Fiorina.

headline: Use Medicare’s Muscle to Lower Drug Prices
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: Medicaid has ways to get big rebates from drug manufacturers; Medicare should be given similar powers.
lead_paragraph: A poll last month by Consumer Reports found that a third of the patients who take prescription drugs are paying significantly more this year, forcing many to cut back on other necessities or load up on credit card debt. Another poll in August by the Kaiser Family Foundation found that about a quarter of those surveyed said they had trouble paying for prescription drugs.

lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Martin Winterkorn was uncharacteristically subdued last week when, on the eve of the Frankfurt auto show, he stepped into a beam of blue light to show off the latest products from the Volkswagen empire.

headline: Pope Francis’ U.S. Visit Could Benefit Both Left and Right
abstract: If the pope’s visit seems likely to bolster President Obama on some of his top priorities, it also comes at a moment of sharp focus on moral questions where the two differ.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pope Francis will arrive at a military base outside the capital on Tuesday afternoon to open his first visit to the United States, and President Obama will be there to welcome him. It is a gesture the president has extended to virtually no other foreign visitor.

abstract: Can Russia be an ally in stabilizing Syria and fighting ISIS or is it too closely tied to the Assad regime?

abstract: The insurer also said it was reviewing its general operations and expected losses of about $275 million on claims related to explosions in China.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Zurich Insurance Group said on Monday that it was abandoning its pursuit of RSA Insurance Group, a smaller British rival, after a deterioration in its business performance, particularly in Zurich’s general insurance unit.

headline: Xi Jinping of China Arriving in U.S. at Moment of Vulnerability
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'International Relations']
abstract: The chill on the Chinese economy has eroded some of the sheen attached to Mr. Xi, and some analysts say he may want to project an especially strong image when holding talks in the United States.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping of China looked regal as he stood in a limousine moving past Tiananmen Square this month, wearing a traditional suit of the kind favored by Mao and waving at parade troops assembled at attention. But the luster of Mr. Xi’s imperial presidency has dulled lately.

headline: Trading Meat for Tires as Bartering Economy Grows in Greece
keywords: ['Barter', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Euro (Currency)']
abstract: As Greece grapples with a continued downturn, bartering is gaining traction at the margins of the economy, a worrisome sign for Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras who was re-elected on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Thodoris Roussos stood in his butcher’s shop and pointed to a large white delivery truck at the curb. For months, he had put off replacing the tires, because Greece’s financial crisis had cut into business. But recently, he upgraded the van with a set of good wheels at a price that could not be beat.

headline: France Rejects Google’s Efforts to Limit Application of Privacy Ruling
abstract: Several European privacy regulators, particularly in France, have urged that the so-called right to be forgotten be applied to all of Google’s search domains.
lead_paragraph: France’s privacy watchdog just will not take no for an answer.

headline: Foster Parenting: When to Explain, When to Let It Pass
abstract: In casual conversation about my sons, one foster, one biological, it can be hard to know how much to say.
lead_paragraph: “Is this your son’s first year of preschool?”

headline: David Brock’s ‘Killing the Messenger’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A renowned veteran of the Republican propaganda machine tells how he came to help Democrats.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always wondered about the details of the reconciliation between Hillary Clinton and David Brock. As an investigative reporter for The American Spectator in the 1990s, Brock published whatever the Arkansas state troopers told him about Bill Clinton and his women and put the rumor about Vince Foster and Hillary into print. His tone and loose reporting ethics arguably unleashed two decades of cheap tabloid right-wing best sellers that still dog Hillary and Bill today. Is that really something the Clintons ever got past?

headline: ‘Black Silent Majority,’ by Michael Javen Fortner
abstract: The effort to combat crime with stricter laws has long been a priority among African-Americans, a professor writes.
lead_paragraph: For as long as I can remember, certain relatives of mine were always dismayed and often enraged by the daily headlines and nightly news stories of crime. As a kid I heard countless tales of the terrible outrages visited on black people by other black people: burglarizing homes, pulling guns and shooting at one another, too often claiming innocent bystanders in the crossfire. Some of these stories were personal testimonies of victimization. In my ’70s childhood on Chicago’s South Side, I was taught that some black people behaved despicably.

headline: Hillary Clinton Rates Unfavorably in New York State Poll
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton was viewed unfavorably by 51 percent of the voters polled in a new Siena College survey, a low mark in the state she represented as a senator for eight years.
lead_paragraph: A rough political summer has left Hillary Rodham Clinton with negative favorability ratings in a New York State poll for the first time, a low mark in the state she represented as a senator for eight years.

Many of them said he had fought hard to get a better deal for the country and deserved a second chance.

headline: A Quarter of the Country’s Green Sea Turtles Call Florida Refuge Home
abstract: A threatened species is starting to grow again, helped by a record year at the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Green sea turtles have had their ups and downs. They were so plentiful that they were commercially harvested for hundreds of years in the Atlantic, but are now listed as threatened or endangered under the Endangered Species Act, depending on the location.

headline: Indonesia’s ‘Mud Volcano’ and Nine Years of Debate About Its Muck
abstract: New evidence suggests a damaging, continuing mud volcano was started by drilling. But many researchers still blame an earthquake.
lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, a rice paddy in eastern Java suddenly cleaved open and began spewing steaming mud. Before long, it covered an area twice the size of Central Park; roads, factories and homes disappeared under a tide of reeking muck. Twenty lives were lost and nearly 40,000 people displaced, with damages topping $2.7 billion.

headline: As Fires Grow, a New Landscape Appears in the West
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Wildfires', 'Global Warming', 'Drought', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Trees and Shrubs']
abstract: A natural cycle of fire and forest renewal has been broken in the West, some scientists believe. Millions of trees may never return.
lead_paragraph: NEAR COCHITI CANYON, N.M. — The hills here are beautiful, a rolling, green landscape of grasses and shrubs under a late-summer sky. But it is starkly different from what was here before: vast forests of ponderosa pine. The repeated blazes that devastated the trees were caused by simple things: an improperly extinguished campfire in 1996, a tree falling on a power line in 2011.

headline: A Saudi-American Reset
abstract: After a period of estrangement, King Salman’s visit to Washington was a sign of renewed cooperation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After more than two years of perceived slights and supposed snubs, the new contours of a revitalized but evolving partnership between the United States and Saudi Arabia are beginning to take shape. This month’s visit to Washington by King Salman solidified the defense and security aspects of this new version of an old relationship. The Saudis are also strongly pushing an economic agenda as the centerpiece of what King Salman identified as a “new strategic alliance for the 21st century.”

headline: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love A.I.
abstract: We should acknowledge what computers do better than we do, and get on with the business of being human.
lead_paragraph: The distinction between man and machine is under siege. The technology wizard Ray Kurzweil speaks with casual confidence of achieving electromagnetic immortality with our once-human selves eternally etched onto universal servers. For me, the possibility that machines will acquire the equivalent of human feelings and emotions is pure fantasy. And yet, as a neurologist, I cannot ignore advancing machine intelligence’s implications about the human mind.

headline: Trapped in the System: A Sick Doctor’s Story
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Colitis']
abstract: If this is how much trouble I have navigating a simple refilling of my medication, I don’t know how the rest of America does it.
lead_paragraph: We spend a lot of time talking about various metrics of quality or access in the American health care system. The problem with many of them is that they rarely seem to capture the issues that people face in dealing with care. Although many metrics are improving, problems remain that still seem insurmountable.

abstract: The pope, whom American Catholics overwhelmingly support, arrives in the United States as Republicans wrestle with these issues and with perceptions of intolerance.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning. Pope Francis has delivered an encyclical calling for increased action against climate change, denounced the role of global capitalism in increasing poverty, and enthusiastically supported the new nuclear accord with Iran, positions that have caused tensions in the Republican Party. Now the pope, whom American Catholics overwhelmingly support, arrives in the United States as Republicans wrestle with these issues and with perceptions of intolerance.

headline: Explaining the Flight News and Rules on Travel to Cuba
abstract: The United States has further loosened travel regulations for Americans visiting the island. Here is what you need to know before you go.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after the United States announced it would be loosening travel restrictions to Cuba, the two countries have reached an agreement on regularly scheduled commercial flights to the island, the Associated Press has reported. Coupled with the previous rule changes for travelers, commercial flights to the island from the United States would make it possible for practically anyone who wishes to visit Cuba to do so. Here is what you need to know before you go:

abstract: The standards editor responds to a reader’s complaint about a racial slur in an article on Kareem Abdul-Jabbar.
lead_paragraph: A reader, Adam Lawrence, of New York City, said he was “thrilled and engrossed” as he read the magazine piece this past weekend on the former basketball star, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, until he encountered a racial slur in the text. To his dismay, the word was repeated twice more as he kept reading.

headline: Esmail Kiram II, Self-Proclaimed Sultan of Sulu, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Kiram, whose title several others claim as well, encouraged a violent effort to regain part of the island Borneo for the Philippines in 2013.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Esmail Kiram II, the self-proclaimed sultan of Sulu who in 2013 encouraged a last-ditch, violent effort to regain what is now the Malaysian state of Sabah on the island of Borneo for the Philippines, died on Saturday at a hospital in Zamboanga City in the southern Philippines. He was 75.

headline: Alexis Tsipras’s Election Victory, and Greece’s Looming Challenges
abstract: Though he succeeded in ridding his party of radicals, he still faces stiff opposition from an austerity-weary country.
lead_paragraph: Alexis Tsipras won an unexpectedly decisive victory in elections in Greece on Sunday, renewing his mandate to lead the austerity-weary nation, this time as a prime minister committed to supporting a bailout rather than to fighting one. Defying many experts’ predictions of a tight race, his leftist party, Syriza, received just over 35 percent of the vote, beating the main right-leaning opposition party by more than seven percentage points.

headline: A Simpler Financial-Aid Calculator Spreads
abstract: The University of Virginia and Williams College have adopted a tool that is simpler to use than the typical federally mandated tuition calculator.
lead_paragraph: A simplified financial-aid calculator — much easier to use than the federally mandated calculators that most colleges create — has begun spreading beyond Wellesley College, where it began two years ago.

headline: Daily Report: Kickstarter Becomes a ‘Public Benefit Corporation’
abstract: You won’t find many tech companies worried about the corrupting influence of money. But Kickstarter, the company that has helped finance many a novel idea, is making moves to ensure it doesn’t stray from its original purpose.
lead_paragraph: It is a common criticism of tech companies these days: They say they want to change the world, but what they really want to change is how much money they have in the bank. Or the horsepower of the car in the driveway. Or maybe the exotic locale of the third vacation home.

headline: 1940: Legionnaires Take Over Fair
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The American Legion dominates World’s Fair in 1940.
lead_paragraph: With 75,000 members of the American Legion and their families attending, the New York World’s Fair had its biggest Saturday of 1940 yesterday, the paid admissions total mounting to 234,121 at midnight. The Legionnaires attended the fair as a prelude to the national convention which opens in Boston tomorrow. Congregated in the huge court were 15,000 legionnaires and members of their auxiliary organizations, most of them in uniform. There were so many flags in the parade that Legion members in uniform stood at attention and saluted for nearly an hour. — New York Herald Tribune, September 22, 1940

headline: Skype Service Problems for Some Users Worldwide
abstract: Microsoft’s Internet calling unit did not specify how many of its roughly 300 million global users were affected.
lead_paragraph: Users of Skype, Microsoft’s Internet calling unit, faced a lengthy blackout on Monday after people worldwide were not able to make calls or sign into the service.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Ruffles
abstract: Folds of fabric spruce up neutral colors and conservative silhouettes.
lead_paragraph: Ladylike ruffles have spruced up neutral colors and conservative silhouettes in designers’ spring/summer 2016 collections. At Proenza Schouler, architectural bends grounded a light, gauzy layer that swished and swayed as the model walked. And Simone Rocha’s asymmetrical and artfully arranged ruffles defined womanly curves while the voluminous folds on a J. W. Anderson dress were just sweet — as a peach.

lead_paragraph: If the Internet is the Wild West, you could call 4chan “The Good, the Bad and the Ugly.”

abstract: The vaunted defense of Seattle, the reigning N.F.C. champion, is struggling against the pass as the All-Pro safety Kam Chancellor sits at home amid a contract dispute..
lead_paragraph: The Seattle Seahawks, the N.F.L.’s reigning N.F.C. champions, have started the season 0-2, and their vaunted defense is struggling, especially against the pass. An All-Pro strong safety who would help them a lot is sitting at home, embroiled in a contract dispute.

headline: Parents, Not Schools, Should Decide What to Pack for Lunch
abstract: Some school wellness policies enable or require school staff to hover, judge, and even confiscate food.
lead_paragraph: Last year, when a teacher confiscated Oreos from a Colorado preschooler’s lunch, both The Daily News in New York and USA Today covered the story that set the Internet buzzing. The teacher’s note, sent home with the preschooler, asserted that Oreos were not “healthy” — those same Oreos that many of us enjoyed with a glass of milk in the 1970s and ’80s.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Bobby Jindal, looking for traction in the Republican presidential nomination contest, is welcoming Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday to his home state of Louisiana, where she plans to hold an event stressing the positive effects of President Obama’s health care law.

headline: When Dinner Proves Divisive: One Strategy, Many Dishes
abstract: Directions that can be configured to produce many different options at one meal is the workaround solution.
lead_paragraph: Back when I cooked only to please myself and one or two other consenting adults, choosing recipes was a breeze. Nothing was off limits. Dishes with olives, stinky cheeses, bitter greens and mushrooms — sometimes all of the above — were on regular rotation. Then I began cooking for kids (picky, omnivorous and otherwise). With them came their nut-allergic friends, vegan guitar teachers and chile-fearing in-laws. Forced to adapt my NC-17 cooking style to a G-rated audience, I paged through cookbooks in search of “crowd pleasers” that proved elusive.

headline: A Beneficial Evolutionary Step for Chameleons
abstract: The lizard has five digits, but in each hand and foot, these digits are split into two “bundles” that makes living in trees easier for them.
lead_paragraph: Chameleons have five digits, but in each hand and foot, these digits are split into two “bundles.” The arrangement permits them to grasp branches and climb with ease, excellent adaptations for life in the trees. A new study reports that the angle between the “bundles” in the tree-dwelling species depends on a large number of previously unknown skeletal elements in the wrist and ankle that fuse together as the embryonic chameleon develops. The fusion produces a ball-and-socket joint that chameleons can use to rotate their bodies while reaching for branches. The study appears in the journal BMC Evolutionary Biology.

headline: Earth Blamed for Cracks in Moon
abstract: According to a new study, images taken by NASA’s lunar orbiter showed more than 3,200 ridges in the moon, which was found to be 50 yards thinner.
lead_paragraph: The moon is shrinking, and Earth is to blame for how the moon’s crust has cracked.
