headline: VW’s Recall Troubles May Have Little Effect on China, Its Largest Market
abstract: The automaker sells almost no diesel cars in the country: fewer than 1,000 of the three million or so the company sells there each year.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China is Volkswagen’s single-largest market, and the company vies with General Motors as the country’s biggest automaker. But Volkswagen’s diesel scandal is unlikely to have many repercussions in China.

headline: A Magna Carta Exhibition at New-York Historical Society
abstract: A 1217 version of the Magna Carta, along with the only known surviving copy of the King’s Writ of 1215, the instructions that King John issued at Runnymede on how to carry out the charter, will be at the New-York Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: A 1217 version of the Magna Carta, on loan from Hereford Cathedral in England, will be exhibited for the first time at the New-York Historical Society for one week, from Sept. 23 to 30. The show will include the only known surviving copy of the King’s Writ of 1215, the instructions that King John issued at Runnymede to local sheriffs on how to carry out the new charter.

headline: Atomic Agency Defends How Iran Collected Evidence at Secret Base
abstract: In the absence of outside inspectors, surveillance devices watched at the Parchin military base, the International Atomic Energy Agency said.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency said Monday that Iran had turned over samples from a suspected site of nuclear experimentation, but confirmed that they had been collected by Iranians under the watchful eye of surveillance devices, rather than by outside nuclear inspectors.

The clean look — finished at times with a supermatte, gothic lip — complemented the heavily embellished, monochromatic mood of the collection (which by the way was debuted, before the show, on Snapchat).

headline: Many Messages in the G.M. Settlement
abstract: The Justice Department appears to want other companies under investigation to view the significant benefits realized by General Motors from its cooperation.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest product defects in recent American manufacturing history, linked to at least 124 deaths and numerous injuries, was traceable to a mundane automobile part, the ignition switch. For General Motors, the debacle over how it handled that defect scarred the organization as it had to admit to repeated failures in simply identifying the problem that reflected a corporate culture that seemed to prize inaction and deflection.

headline: 1965: Thant Urges an Inclusive U.N.
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Secretary General Thant tells the United Nations that all countries need representation in 1965.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. — Secretary-General U Thant told the UN General Assembly as it opened its 20th session here today [Sept. 21] that the military conflicts in Asia and the disarmament deadlock have reinforced his view that all countries — including Communist China — should be represented at UN headquarters. In his annual report, Mr. Thant declared that the war in Vietnam had ‘‘cruelly set back’’ the trend toward East-West cooperation and revived the cold war. He added that the international situation ‘‘has again been disturbed’’ by the conflict between India and Pakistan. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 22, 1965

headline: Mets Math: The Six-Game Lead That Really Isn’t

lead_paragraph: With 13 games to go in the regular season, the Mets (84-65) hold a shrunken, but still sturdy, six-game lead over the Washington Nationals in the National League East. That would seem safe enough, except for one small problem: The Mets’ lead is, in some respects, just three games, not six.

headline: Details Emerge in Massachusetts ‘Baby Doe’ Case as Couple Are Arraigned
abstract: Rachelle Dee Bond and her companion, Michael Patrick McCarthy, pleaded not guilty Monday in the death of Ms. Bond’s daughter, Bella, whose body was found in June.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — For months, a computer-generated image of a toddler’s face, with big eyes, long hair and chubby cheeks, appeared on billboards and fliers here and beyond. Her body had been found, clad in black and white leggings, in a trash bag on a rocky beach on Deer Island, along Boston Harbor. But for almost three months, despite an exhaustive search, investigators knew little more than that until last week.

headline: Facts & Figures: American Republicans May Be Alone on Climate Change
abstract: The Republican Party is the only one of nine conservative parties around the world to deny human-caused climate change, according to a recent study.
lead_paragraph: A study has found that the Republican Party in the United States lags behind conservative parties worldwide when it comes to accepting the reality of climate change, Tom Jacobs of Pacific Standard reports. The study’s author examined the platforms of the top conservative parties in each of nine countries — the United States, United Kingdom, Australia, Germany, Spain, Sweden, Norway, Canada and New Zealand — and found that the Republican Party here was the only one to deny the existence of human-caused climate change.

headline: Matzo Fried Chicken Served to Go
abstract: Plus: preserving quality aged beef; sampling ethnic foods in Astoria; Early Girl tomatoes; and an Edible Schoolyard anniversary celebration.
lead_paragraph: Become a restaurant known for your matzo-meal fried chicken, and people will want to take some home. So, Richard Kimmel is opening a food shop, Kitty’s-a-Go-Go, next door to Kitty’s Canteen, his red-curtained boîte that serves the chicken. Jewish food with a Southern drawl is the specialty, inspired by the recipes of Kitty Kimmel, Mr. Kimmel’s grandmother who worked for a talent agency in New York. Jazz musicians taught her how to cook soul food. Kathy Johannes and Stephanie Teekaram, the chefs at Kitty’s, now make the chicken, hush kitties (hush puppies filled with pastrami), matzo-ball soup with mustard greens, and biscuits shaped like bagels, which are called bisgels, a name trademarked by Mr. Kimmel, whose business partner is Snoop Dogg: 11 Stanton Street (Chrystie Street), 212-477-7047, kittysagogo.com.

headline: A New Design Shop That Aims to Elevate the Smoke-Filled Room
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Marijuana', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Tetra, a lifestyle brand dreamed up by three friends and T contributors, sources and sells unique objects created to heighten the aesthetics of smoking.
lead_paragraph: Tetra, a new online shop and lifestyle brand “dedicated to elevating the aesthetics of the smoking experience,” was first dreamed up by three friends at El Matador beach in Los Angeles. The project, launching today, was co-created by Monica Khemsurov, a design curator and writer and cofounder of the Sight Unseen design blog; Su Wu, an arts writer and founder of the inspiration blog I’m Revolting; and Eviana Hartman, a style and design writer and founder of the fashion line Bodkin. (All three happen to be regular T contributors, too.) It was born of the realization, Khemsurov explains, that even as a particular form of recreational smoking has rapidly gained mainstream acceptance (cough), there hasn’t been “a store dedicated to selling beautifully designed objects for smokers.”

headline: Apple Improves the Watch, Slightly
abstract: The company has made some small and useful improvements, but this is still a product of limited use for most people.
lead_paragraph: The Apple Watch has been on sale since the spring, and like all Apple products, it has been the subject of intense speculation, criticism, fawning and doomsaying. Expect all of it to accelerate, because on Monday Apple is releasing the first major upgrade of the watch’s operating system. The new software had been scheduled for release last week, but Apple postponed the rollout at the last minute because of an unspecified bug. That bug has now been fixed.

headline: Young Quarterbacks Produce Rare Win-Win-Win-Win Situation
abstract: Jameis Winston (Buccaneers), Johnny Manziel (Browns), Blake Bortles (Jaguars) and Derek Carr (Raiders) helped their long-suffering teams prevail in the same week for the first time since 2007.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 25, 2007, the Cleveland Browns, the Jacksonville Jaguars, the Oakland Raiders and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers all won. They were quarterbacked by Derek Anderson, David Garrard, Daunte Culpepper and Jeff Garcia. Until Sunday, that was the last time those four teams all won in the same week.

abstract: This revival doesn’t quite dynamite the franchise, but every so often, it tosses a tiny stick of TNT into your fondest memories.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, when Paul Lee, the president of ABC Entertainment, announced that the network’s new version of the Muppet franchise would be “more adult,” my inner Statler and Waldorf stirred in the balcony. There are certain things I don’t want to know, and where Muppet babies come from is among them.

headline: Trump’s Minor Fall, Fiorina’s Major Lift
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Elections, Governors', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Notes on the state of the Republican race.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t have time to comment on the Republican debate last week, but in a way it’s better to offer an assessment a few days later, since we now have polls that help confirm the commentariat’s basic reaction: It was a great night for Carly Fiorina, a good night for Marco Rubio, a not-so-great night for the Donald, a meh night for most of the pack, and another lost evening for the plummeting Scott Walker. And now, a few observations on what it all might mean:

headline: Don Henley and Billy Joel, at 92nd Street Y, Trade Stories About a Lifetime of Songwriting
abstract: Billy Joel and Don Henley shared behind-the-scenes stories for over an hour and a half.
lead_paragraph: Billy Joel first met Don Henley in the early 1970s, when the two men were rising musicians based in Southern California. “I opened up for Don at the University of California at Berkeley,” Mr. Joel told the crowd Sunday night at the 92nd Street Y. “These were the days when the Eagles were all wearing Hawaiian shirts.”

lead_paragraph: At the San Diego Senior Olympics on Sunday, Don Pellmann broke five records for men in the 100-and-over age group and tried to become the oldest man to record a height in the pole vault.

headline: 100 Years Old. 5 World Records.
abstract: The most senior athlete at the San Diego Senior Olympics, Don Pellmann, became the first centenarian to break 27 seconds in the 100 meters on the way to five age-group records.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Don Pellmann had been at the San Diego Mesa College track for less than an hour Sunday morning and had already moved his lawn chair twice to remain in the shade, which was receding fast. By the time Pellmann set his fifth age-group world record, in the early afternoon, the temperature on the track was creeping toward 100, which also happens to be the birthday Pellmann recently celebrated.

headline: Condiments as Weapon Against Malnutrition
abstract: Efforts to add iron to fish sauce in Vietnam and bouillon cubes in West Africa are examples of a new trend in fortification of food.

lead_paragraph: How would you help the homeless? What would you do about student debt? And how good of a quarterback is Joe Flacco?

headline: Should You Watch NBC’s ‘Blindspot’?
abstract: Assessing the pros and cons of the new drama, premiering Monday.
lead_paragraph: SERIES: “Blindspot,” which premieres Monday on NBC. It was created by the writer Martin Gero of “The L.A. Complex” and produced by Greg Berlanti of “Arrow” and “The Flash” fame. (It’s a busy fall for the uber producer — his “Supergirl” lands on CBS next month and the superhero spinoff series “Legends of Tomorrow” is a midseason premiere.)

headline: Michel Faulkner, Harlem Minister, Announces G.O.P. Bid to Unseat Mayor de Blasio
abstract: Mr. Faulkner, who once played for the New York Jets, criticized Bill de Blasio’s leadership style and management of the city’s Police Department.
lead_paragraph: With Mayor Bill de Blasio’s poll numbers in a prolonged slump, Republican leaders have vowed to put up a strong challenger in 2017. But to compete in strongly liberal New York City, Republicans would most likely need either a candidate of some political celebrity to challenge the Democratic mayor, or at least someone with vast personal wealth to spend on a campaign.

headline: Prescription Drug Costs Are Rising as a Campaign Issue
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Per capita spending on medicines is up sharply, and even people with health insurance are finding themselves paying more.
lead_paragraph: Both Bernie Sanders and Hillary Rodham Clinton are trying to make the rising cost of prescription drugs an issue in the presidential campaign.

headline: Oldest Find of Salmon Remains in North America
abstract: The 11,500-year-old remains were found in Alaska, a study says, confirming that salmon fishing in North America dates from the end of the last ice age.
lead_paragraph: Salmon fishing in North America dates from the end of the last ice age, a new study reports.

headline: Getty Museum and Armenian Church Reach Agreement Over 13th-Century Manuscript
abstract: The museum and church leaders have settled a dispute over an illustrated Armenian manuscript that the Getty bought in 1994 for $1 million.
lead_paragraph: The J. Paul Getty Museum, after years of legal wrangling over eight pieces of colorful medieval parchment in its collection, announced on Monday that it has recognized a different rightful owner: the Western Prelacy of the Armenian Apostolic Church of America. The pages, which the illuminator T’oros Roslin painted in the 13th century, were somehow separated a century ago from the rest of a religious manuscript, the Zeyt’un Gospels, which has been preserved at the Matenadaran institute in Armenia.

headline: Emmy Awards Audience Drops to New Low
abstract: Just 11.9 million viewers tuned in to Fox Sunday night as the Emmy Awards went up against the Green Bay Packers and Seattle Seahawks on NBC.
lead_paragraph: This year’s Emmy Awards were the least-watched in the show’s history, drawing just 11.9 million viewers on Sunday night, according to Nielsen.

headline: Albert Maysles Will Get a Tribute at the New York Film Festival
abstract: The documentary filmmaker will be honored in a tribute with free tickets for the general public.
lead_paragraph: Albert Maysles, the pioneering documentary filmmaker who died in March, will receive a tribute hosted by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Maysles family, organizers announced Monday.

headline: How Much Junk Food Do Teenagers Eat?
keywords: ['Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Food', 'Calories']
abstract: Just what percentage of calories do American teenagers get from fast food, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention?
lead_paragraph: American teenagers receive 16.9 percent of their calories from fast food, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported last week.

headline: Greece’s Leader Starts Big Economic Overhaul
abstract: After his convincing victory in the national election, Alexis Tsipras will need to move quickly to keep the country’s creditors happy and aid flowing.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Alexis Tsipras moved swiftly to form a new Greek government on Monday after his convincing victory in the national election a day earlier, with some officials close to him suggesting that he would create a new ministry solely dedicated to carrying out the tough bailout package he reluctantly agreed to last summer.

headline: Kathleen Kane, Pennsylvania Attorney General, Is Suspended From Practicing Law
abstract: Ms. Kane remains in office as she confronts criminal charges related to a leak of secret investigative information.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The ability of Pennsylvania’s embattled attorney general to carry out her job was thrown into question Monday as the State Supreme Court issued a temporary suspension of her law license.

headline: Big Price Increase for Tuberculosis Drug Is Rescinded
abstract: Rodelis, which acquired cycloserine and promptly raised its price more than twentyfold, returned it to the foundation that had previously owned the drug.
lead_paragraph: A huge overnight price increase for an important tuberculosis drug has been rescinded after the company that acquired the drug gave it back to its previous owner under pressure, it was announced on Monday.

headline: Thousands Ricochet Across Europe: Inside the Migrant Crisis
abstract: Mary Ann Giordano provides an inside look at the nuts and bolts involved in covering a story breaking across the globe.

headline: Letters to the Editor
keywords: ['Heimlich Maneuver', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'First Aid']
abstract: Readers respond to articles in Science Times.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: The London Design Medal’s Winners on Their Working Philosophy
abstract: The British duo Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby won this year’s award, one of the industry’s highest accolades, 20 years into their innovative career.
lead_paragraph: The British design duo Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby have won this year’s Panerai London Design Medal. The award, now in its 10th year, is one of the design industry’s highest accolades and celebrates excellence in design, plus contribution to the industry and to London. “We weren’t expecting it at all,” Barber says. “It’s not something that you ever anticipate.”

headline: Ignoring Sexual Abuse in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: The American military cannot allow sexual assault of children on its bases or give the impression that it is condoned.
lead_paragraph: The incidents of sexual assault on children described by American service members who served in Afghanistan are sickening. Boys screaming in the night as Afghan police officers attacked them. Three or four Afghan men found lying on the floor of a room at a military base with children between them, presumably for sex play.

headline: More than 100 Killed by Boko Haram Bombings in Nigeria
abstract: The blasts appeared to be carefully coordinated and countered assertions by Nigerian officials that Boko Haram had been severely weakened.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — More than 100 people were killed Sunday evening in northern Nigeria in a quick succession of what appeared to be carefully coordinated bombings by Boko Haram, the Islamist extremist group.

headline: Readers React to Afghan Allies’ Sexual Abuse of Boys
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Commenters expressed outrage at the perpetrators and at the American officers who instructed subordinates to ignore the abuse they witnessed.
lead_paragraph: Again and again, American soldiers discovered that their Afghan counterparts were sexually abusing boys, sometimes on American military bases. But after reporting the crimes, they were told by their superiors to ignore them or punished for taking matters into their own hands.

headline: Ben Carson’s Comments Stir Anger Among Muslims
abstract: Muslim advocates called for Ben Carson to leave the presidential race after saying that he was opposed to a Muslim being president.
lead_paragraph: Emotions in the Muslim community remained roiled on Monday by Ben Carson’s assertion that followers of Islam are not fit to serve as president of the United States.

headline: The Pop-Up Pope
abstract: A self-styled “joyful band of Catholics” took a life-size likeness of Pope Francis to Philadelphia to promote Catholicism and the real pontiff’s United States’ visit.
lead_paragraph: A self-styled “joyful band of Catholics” took a life-size likeness of Pope Francis to Philadelphia to promote Catholicism and the real pontiff’s United States’ visit.

headline: Scott Walker Ends His 2016 Presidential Run
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin quit the race for the Republican presidential nomination and urged some of his 15 rivals to do the same in hopes of uniting the party around an alternative to Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, whose early glow as a Republican presidential contender was snuffed out with the rise of anti-establishment rivals, announced Monday that he was quitting the race and urged some of his 15 rivals to do the same so the party could unite against the leading candidate, Donald J. Trump.

headline: Let the Voters Decide? Nah, Not in the Bronx
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'District Attorneys', 'Elections, District Attorneys', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: The Democratic Party in the borough is getting ready to hand-pick its next district attorney, normally an elected position.
lead_paragraph: In one of the sleaziest maneuvers in a notoriously sleazy political world, the Democratic Party cabal in the Bronx is ready to hand-pick the borough’s next district attorney.  Normally, that would be an elected position, but the party bigwigs do their best to keep voters in their borough from getting overly involved. As a result, as Dick Dadey of Citizens Union told The Times, “Corruption will continue in the Bronx.”

headline: A Discussion of E.L. Doctorow’s ‘Homer & Langley’
abstract: In honor of E. L. Doctorow, who died on July 21, the Big City Book Club will discuss his 2009 novel, “Homer & Langley,” tonight at 6:30 Eastern.
lead_paragraph: The Collyer Brothers, American history’s best known hoarders and the subject of E.L. Doctorow’s 2009 novel, “Homer & Langley,” lived and died surrounded by more than 120 tons of rubbish and memorabilia in a Harlem brownstone at 128th Street and Fifth Avenue. The site is now empty, a pocket park where New Yorkers might sit and think on the horrors of overeager acquisition.

headline: When Radiation Isn’t the Real Risk
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Radiation', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: Four years after the nuclear accident at Fukushima, no one has been killed or sickened by radioactivity. But 1,600 died fleeing the disaster.
lead_paragraph: This spring, four years after the nuclear accident at Fukushima, a small group of scientists met in Tokyo to evaluate the deadly aftermath.

headline: Should You Watch Fox’s ‘Minority Report’?
abstract: The sci-fi crime drama, based on the 2002 film, premieres Monday.
lead_paragraph: SERIES: “Minority Report,” a crime drama premiering Monday on Fox. It was written and developed by Max Borenstein, who wrote the latest “Godzilla” movie.

headline: The Weeknd Dominates Billboard Chart, and Streaming Is Surging
abstract: The Weeknd’s “Beauty Behind the Madness” spends a third week at No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart as industry data for the first half of 2015 indicates streaming is surging while CD sales are plunging.
lead_paragraph: This week on the music charts, the Weeknd’s “Beauty Behind the Madness” (XO/Republic) is taking a third victory lap at No. 1, and new industry statistics show that streaming now contributes about one-third of the revenue for the American record business.

headline: Not-So-Simple Shapes at Peter Pilotto
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2015)', 'London Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: For spring/summer 2016, Pilotto and Christopher de Vos mixed zigzag lines, circles and triangles with mesh.
lead_paragraph: For spring/summer 2016, Pilotto and Christopher de Vos mixed zigzag lines, circles and triangles with mesh.

headline: A Little Floral, a Little Military at Burberry
abstract: Christopher Bailey’s spring/summer collection mixed hard-edged pieces with fluid silhouettes.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Bailey’s spring/summer collection mixed hard-edged pieces with fluid silhouettes.

headline: New York City’s Cultural Affairs Commissioner Takes Leave Because of Illness
abstract: New York City Cultural Affairs Commissioner Thomas Finkelpearl says he has lymphoma.
lead_paragraph: Tom Finkelpearl, the city’s Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, will take a leave of absence to treat a health issue, the de Blasio administration announced on Monday. In his absence, Mr. Finkelpearl’s deputy, Edwin Torres, will serve as acting commissioner.

headline: 1 in 4 Women Experience Sex Assault on Campus
abstract: The study, one of the largest studies of its kind, was conducted by the American Association of Universities.
lead_paragraph: In four years of college, more than one-fourth of undergraduate women at a large group of leading universities said they had been sexually assaulted by force or when they were incapacitated, according to one of the largest studies of its kind, released Monday.

headline: Cori Bargmann Puts Her Mind to How the Brain Works
abstract: For a neurobiologist at Rockefeller University, a mission to help lead a president’s initiative starts with a search for the needed tools.
lead_paragraph: Cornelia Bargmann, a neurobiologist at Rockefeller University in New York, studies how genes interact with neurons to create behavior. Two years ago, President Obama named Dr. Bargmann, who is known as Cori, a co-chairwoman of the advisory commission for the Brain Initiative, which he has described as “giving scientists the tools they need to get a dynamic picture of the brain in action.”

headline: Heidi Julavits at Home
abstract: In her Morningside Heights apartment, the writer and antiques lover shares some of her favorite secondhand objects.
lead_paragraph: In her Morningside Heights apartment, the writer and antiques lover shares some of her favorite secondhand objects.

headline: Review: ‘Sex of the Baby,’ a Tale of Desire and Betrayal
abstract: Matthew-Lee Erlbach’s play centers on two gay men seeking to have a child, and a prospective birth mother who ends up having an affair with one of them.
lead_paragraph: In Matthew-Lee Erlbach’s farcical ”Sex of the Baby,” boy meets girl at a job interview. Daniel, a sculptor, is screening prospective birth mothers for the child that he and his partner, Michael, want to have. Bekah, a bubbly honey-blond teacher with flawless skin and a sterling résumé, seems ideal.

headline: At Home — and on the Hunt for Antiques — With Heidi Julavits
abstract: “It’s the unnecessariness of the objects that I like the most,” says the writer. “‘What I’m going to do with it,’ is never criteria.”
lead_paragraph: The first item that the writer Heidi Julavits bought at a yard sale was a black, rayon dress — in Los Angeles, on a college cross-country road trip. The acquisition, she remembers, felt more than a commodity exchange; in a still unknown city, she says, “it felt like purchasing citizenship.”

headline: Russia Expands Fleet in Syria With Jets That Can Attack Targets on Ground
keywords: ['Military Aircraft', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Two dozen new planes are part of an arms buildup at the base, appearing to leave little doubt about Moscow’s goal of establishing a Middle Eastern military outpost.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia has sharply increased the number of combat aircraft at an air base near Latakia, Syria, giving its forces a new ability to strike targets on the ground in the war-stricken country.

headline: Bird Flu Vaccine Conditionally Approved, but Still Can’t Be Sold
abstract: The Agriculture Department gave Harrisvaccines a conditional license for a drug to protect chickens from a flu that killed 48 million birds this year.
lead_paragraph: A vaccine to help protect the nation’s chickens from avian influenza after more than 48 million birds died during an outbreak this year has cleared a first hurdle, with the Agriculture Department granting its maker a “conditional” license.

headline: Pretty in Pink Men’s Wear
abstract: Masculine tailoring in the dandiest color.
lead_paragraph: Masculine tailoring in the dandiest color.

headline: Review: Christopher Houlihan Adds Shine to a Restored Organ at Co-Cathedral of St. Joseph
abstract: Mr. Houlihan’s concert was part of a rededication of the organ.
lead_paragraph: For a Roman Catholic church, an organ is much more than an instrument. It has an almost sacramental power, resounding for godly glory. It sings hymns as another member of the congregation, a part of the community. It breathes new life as its community does.

headline: Two Finalists Shine, but Davis Cup Is Still in Need of Polish
abstract: As Britain and Belgium prepare to make a rare appearance in the Davis Cup final, the International Tennis Federation is electing a new president, and the winner could push the event to evolve.
lead_paragraph: It is a big week for Davis Cup tennis, and not only because Britain is back in the final for the first time in 37 years and Belgium for the first time in 111 years.

headline: Review: ‘Scream Queens’ Spoofs Horror Spoofs
abstract: This Fox series features Emma Roberts as the president of a sorority house where evil deeds occurred 20 years earlier.
lead_paragraph: If any of the fall’s new shows works harder to win us over than “Scream Queens,” I don’t want to hear about it — I’m exhausted just from watching Tuesday night’s two-hour premiere. The industriousness of this Fox horror spoof is reflected in the game performance of its lead, Emma Roberts, who marches through her role as a sorority-house storm trooper with a slightly grim determination, hunting down laughs that aren’t always there.

headline: Malaysia’s Leader, Najib Razak, Faces U.S. Corruption Inquiry
keywords: ['Sovereign Wealth Funds', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'United States International Relations', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: The prime minister, already involved in several other investigations, is being examined by a federal grand jury on charges of corruption related to questions about real estate deals in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The embattled prime minister of Malaysia, facing mounting political turmoil and a parade of inquiries at home and abroad into a sovereign wealth fund that he oversees, is now coming under the scrutiny of American investigators as well.

headline: Airlines Find Travelers Accept Fees Wrapped Up in Bundles
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Business Travel']
abstract: After meeting resistance to add-on fees, carriers are grouping benefits like added legroom and free Wi-Fi into fare packages.
lead_paragraph: As add-on fees make up a growing percentage of airlines’ profits, more carriers are introducing bundles of features on top of their base fares — and travelers are embracing them.

headline: Timeline of Scott Walker’s Presidential Campaign
abstract: Two months after announcing a presidential bid in which he promised to “wreak havoc” upon Washington, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is ending his run.
lead_paragraph: Two months after announcing a presidential bid in which he promised to “wreak havoc” upon Washington, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is ending his run. After a promising start in Iowa, the Harley-Davidson-riding candidate failed to gain traction nationally with his promises of repealing the Affordable Care Act and taking the fight to unions. As happened with former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, the first Republican to drop out of a crowded field, Mr. Walker was overshadowed by the emergence of Donald J. Trump, making it difficult for his message to break through the political noise.

headline: Robert E. Simon Jr., Who Created a Town, Reston, Va., Dies at 101
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Suburbs', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Mr. Simon, a New York real estate developer, planned the town in the 1960s as an alternative to postwar commuter towns with cookie-cutter homes.
lead_paragraph: Robert E. Simon Jr., a New York real estate developer who founded Reston, Va., in the early 1960s as America’s first planned alternative to the postwar suburban sprawl of commuter towns with cookie-cutter houses on look-alike streets, died on Monday at his home in Reston. He was 101.

headline: Suspects Arraigned in ‘Baby Doe’ Case
abstract: Michael Patrick McCarthy and Rachelle Dee Bond both plead not guilty to charges in the death of  3-year-old Bella Bond, whose body was found on a Boston Harbor shoreline in June.
lead_paragraph: Michael Patrick McCarthy and Rachelle Dee Bond both plead not guilty to charges in the death of  3-year-old Bella Bond, whose body was found on a Boston Harbor shoreline in June.

headline: Summer in Salento
abstract: The slow-paced, isolated villages that make up this region of southern Italy boast a stunning landscape, deep-blue seas and centuries of history.
lead_paragraph: The slow-paced, isolated villages that make up this region of southern Italy boast a stunning landscape, deep-blue seas and centuries of history.

headline: The Ancient Allure of Puglia
abstract: The slow-paced villages that make up Salento boast a stunning landscape, deep-blue seas, centuries of history — and are blissfully isolated from the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: The slow-paced villages that make up Salento boast a stunning landscape, deep-blue seas, centuries of history — and are blissfully isolated from the 21st century.

headline: Review: ‘Paradise of the Pacific,’ the Hard Truths of Hawaii’s History
abstract: Susanna Moore provides a fascinating history of that Pacific archipelago before it was transformed by the arrival of foreigners.
lead_paragraph: In Susanna Moore’s fiercely observed early novels “My Old Sweetheart,” “The Whiteness of Bones,” and “Sleeping Beauties,” Hawaii emerges as a damaged paradise — a place of violent, magical beauty, and its own social rules and hierarchies; a land haunted by its past and isolated from the real world beyond the waves.

headline: Review: ‘Limitless’ on CBS Stars Jake McDorman as a Brainiac
abstract: In this new series, Mr. McDorman becomes supernaturally smart after taking a pill.
lead_paragraph: “Limitless,” which starts Tuesday night on CBS, traffics in two trends that television has already worked pretty hard: characters with heightened observational powers and shows based on movies. But it manages to feel reasonably fresh anyway, thanks to dashes of cheekiness and of Bradley Cooper.

headline: Tatars, Foes of Russia in Crimea, Block Shipments of Food
abstract: A Tatar leader said no trucks had been allowed in since Sunday, and Germany warned Russia to avert elections planned by separatists.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Crimean Tatars, angered by Russia’s annexation of the Black Sea peninsula, said Monday that a blockade of food deliveries to Crimea from Ukraine would continue indefinitely.

headline: S.E.C. and First Eagle Investment Reach $40 Million Settlement
abstract: The case was the first brought against an asset manager under the S.E.C.’s Distribution-in-Guise Initiative, which aims to protect mutual fund shareholders.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Monday that it had reached a $40 million settlement with a New York-based investment adviser over charges that it had improperly used mutual fund assets to pay brokerage firms for the marketing and distribution of its funds.

headline: Rashaad Newsome’s King of Arms Ball
abstract: The artist brought the third iteration of his King of Arms Ball, a vogueing competition, to Brooklyn last night.
lead_paragraph: The artist brought the third iteration of his King of Arms Ball, a vogueing competition, to Brooklyn last night.

headline: When Contemporary Art Meets Ballroom Culture
abstract: The artist Rashaad Newsome brought the third iteration of his King of Arms Ball, a vogueing competition, to Brooklyn last night.
lead_paragraph: Last night in Bushwick, the artist Rashaad Newsome staged the third annual edition of his King of Arms Ball — a proper “Paris Is Burning”-style vogueing ball, complete with acrobatic and athletic runway walks, plenty of accessories and exactly one peacock perched atop a contestant’s head.

headline: Mating Penguins Take Over Punta Tombo
abstract: Over a million Magellanic penguins are expected to arrive on the Argentine peninsula of Punta Tombo for their annual breeding season, and for some, it’s an opportunity to find a new mate.
lead_paragraph: Over a million Magellanic penguins are expected to arrive on the Argentine peninsula of Punta Tombo for their annual breeding season, and for some, it’s an opportunity to find a new mate.

headline: ‘Wicked’ Reclaims Its Spot as No. 2 on Broadway, Overtaking ‘Hamilton’
abstract: Three shows still in previews — “Spring Awakening,” “Old Times” and “Fool for Love” — had soft starts.
lead_paragraph: “Wicked” reclaimed its spot as the second-highest-grossing show on Broadway last week, passing “Hamilton” during a generally up week for the commercial theater business.

headline: Vatican, in Switch, Will Join Palestine in Flying Flag at U.N.
abstract: The Holy See’s ambassador to the United Nations said the Vatican flag will fly, after all, when Pope Francis visits on Friday.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In a policy reversal that hints at the delicate diplomacy ahead of the visit by Pope Francis, the Vatican’s envoy to the United Nations said on Monday that the flag of the Holy See would be hoisted at the gates here for the first time, just before the pope addresses world leaders.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: ‘Splendor and Misery: Images of Prostitution,’ Captures a Profession in Paris Through Artists’ Eyes
abstract: The Musée d’Orsay is touting this show as the first major exhibition on the artistic representation of prostitution in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A skirt lifted above her ankle. A beauty mark painted on her cheek. A direct gaze. Sitting alone over a drink in a cafe.

lead_paragraph: Cuba and More — Pictures of the Day

abstract: Photos from Cuba, Croatia, India and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Cuba, Croatia, India and Spain.

headline: Pope Francis to Find a Church in Upheaval
abstract: Some U.S. churches are bursting with immigrant parishioners, while others struggle to stay open.
lead_paragraph: MERCED, Calif. — More than 5,000 parishioners packed the pews, the choir loft and the vestibule on a recent weekend at Sacred Heart Church here in California’s Central Valley for five Masses — four of them in Spanish. Young Hispanic families spilled outside onto the steps, straining to hear the homily over the roar of an elevated freeway across the street.

headline: Pope Francis on Abortion and Other Issues
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Women and Girls', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Environment']

lead_paragraph: A look at where Pope Francis stands on issues of particular importance to Americans.

headline: Rembrandt Portraits May Come Home, for Record Price, With Government Help
abstract: The government will underwrite the purchase of the portraits of Marten Soolmans and his wife-to-be, Oopjen Coppit, from Éric de Rothschild.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — The Dutch government on Monday pledged 80 million euros toward the purchase of a pair of Rembrandt portraits, half of the €160 million ($180.6 million) needed to buy the works from the French businessman Éric de Rothschild.

headline: Daniel Thompson, Whose Bagel Machine Altered the American Diet, Dies at 94
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Bagels', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Bound up in the Thompson bagel machine is the story of Jewish assimilation, gastronomic homogenization, the decline of trade unionism and the rise of franchise retailing.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Thompson, who five decades ago automated the arcane art of bagel making, a development — seen variously as saving grace and sacrilege — that has sent billions of mass-produced bagels raining down on the American heartland, died on Sept. 3 in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 94.

headline: Newest Immigrants Assimilating as Fast as Previous Ones, Report Says
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'English Language', 'Education', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine says immigrants are eager to learn English and are not burdening the health care system.
lead_paragraph: The newest generations of immigrants are assimilating into American society as fast and broadly as the previous ones, with their integration increasing over time “across all measurable outcomes,” according to a report published on Monday by the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine.

headline: Partisan Divides In Everything
abstract: Hell toupee.
lead_paragraph: Source.

headline: Deadly Car Bombing at Somalia’s Presidential Palace Is Claimed by Shabab
abstract: The Shabab, a militant Islamist group affiliated with Al Qaeda, said the attack had targeted senior Somali and foreign officials.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A car loaded with explosives was detonated Monday at the gate of the presidential palace in Mogadishu, killing at least four people and wounding a dozen others, witnesses and officials said.

headline: Nutcases and Knut Cases
abstract: A century of analysis forgotten.
lead_paragraph: Monetary permahawkery takes two forms. One is obviously ridiculous, but nonetheless has a lot of influence on right-wing politicians. The other can sound serious and judicious, which makes it dangerous, because it might gain real traction with policymakers.

headline: Rugby World Cup: Japan’s Shocking Upset Commands Attention
abstract: Japan beat South Africa in a Rugby World Cup match Saturday that many have heralded as the greatest upset ever, and now it hopes to establish itself after years of dismal results.
lead_paragraph: When Japan beat South Africa over the weekend, there was no question that it was the biggest upset at a Rugby World Cup. Rather, the debate was whether it was the most shocking result in rugby history, or even in all of sports.

headline: Lessons From Scott Walker’s Early Exit
abstract: Navigating the competing pressures of appealing to the Republican Party’s establishment and its base was too much for him.
lead_paragraph: What’s so striking about this year’s huge field of Republican candidates is that so few of them appear to be plausible nominees, broadly acceptable across the party. With Scott Walker now out of the race, the short list of such candidates got even shorter.

headline: Scott Walker Drops Out
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin withdrew from the 2016 Republican presidential race on Monday, citing a need to “clear the field” for a “positive conservative message.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin withdrew from the 2016 Republican presidential race on Monday, citing a need to “clear the field” for a “positive conservative message.”

headline: Surge in Homelessness Tests Wisconsin Capital’s Welcoming Spirit
abstract: A ban on sleeping outside City Hall at night reflects the city’s divided response to a problem that its mayor blames partly on its reputation for hospitality.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — As darkness fell on a humid Wisconsin night, some of the several dozen homeless people who sleep outside City Hall began to unfurl their sleeping bags and settle in. But Nancy Griswold, 49, was restless: She sat on a concrete bench next to a black roller bag full of her belongings and surveyed the scene with the crisp confidence of a docent at the state Capitol, only a block away.

headline: France Opens Trade Office in Iran
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The opening leads the charge of European countries angling for a share of the Iranian market since the July nuclear agreement.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — France opened a trade office in Tehran on Monday, leading the charge of European countries angling for a share of the Iranian market after the July nuclear agreement.

headline: In Pelosi, Strong Catholic Faith and Abortion Rights Coexist
abstract: Nancy Pelosi, the House minority leader with a lifetime of memories of meeting popes, says Republicans are mistaken to mix politics with Francis’s visit.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, the issue of abortion rights has always been ancillary to her unwavering faith and deep approbation for generations of popes. “I actually agree with the pope on more issues than many Catholics who agree with him on one issue,” Ms. Pelosi said in an interview in her office at the Capitol last week.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: Banks have eliminated over 20 percent of the front-office head count from their Wall Street operations since 2011, according to the industry data and analytics firm Coalition.
lead_paragraph: When Goldman Sachs moved into its new tower near the Hudson River in 2009, the sprawling trading desks on the fourth, fifth and sixth floors were some of the most active and lucrative in the world.

headline: Brooklyn Cherry Business to Plead Guilty Over Pollution and Marijuana
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: With the owner of Dell’s Maraschino Cherries dead, investigators have not yet unraveled a marijuana operation’s inner workings or identified the others they believe must be involved.
lead_paragraph: Seven months after its owner committed suicide as investigators closed in on the secret marijuana farm he had kept in the basement of his factory, a company based in Brooklyn will plead guilty on Tuesday to possessing marijuana and illegally dumping acidic wastewater into the sewer system, prosecutors said on Monday.

headline: Austria Takes Role of Distribution Center for Germany-Bound Migrants
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Since the start of the weekend, about 27,000 migrants have entered reception centers and camps where they have received food, housing and health care before they move on to Germany.
lead_paragraph: NICKELSDORF, Austria — In the absence of a unified plan by the European Union, consistent national policies or any consensus on the best way to end the worst humanitarian crisis on the Continent since World War II, Austria is stepping up to house thousands of migrants from the Middle East and Asia, fast becoming Europe’s distribution center of people seeking safety and a better life.

headline: Carmen Balcells, Agent to Latin America’s Literary Lions, Dies at 85
abstract: Nicknamed “La Mamá Grande” after a story by Gabriel García Márquez, Ms. Balcells rewrote the rules of Spanish-language publishing.
lead_paragraph: Carmen Balcells, the formidable literary agent who shepherded a generation of Latin American writers, including Gabriel García Márquez and Mario Vargas Llosa, to international prominence, died on Sunday at her home in Barcelona. She was 85.

headline: Pope Lures Exiles Back to Cuba, Where a Lifetime Ago Is Yesterday
abstract: It was a long-resisted journey — spiritual, emotional, physical — decades in the making, with Pope Francis’ visit offering the final, irresistible impetus.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Gloria Arazoza, her step crimped just a touch by age, walked into what was once Cuba’s most formidable and ornate yacht club on Saturday afternoon and headed straight for the beach. Suddenly, a lifetime ago felt like yesterday.

And in a back room, more of them packed in around Kadiatou Jolloh, her face damp with tears, as she lay on a bed, grappling with the loss of her husband.

headline: Georgia: 28-Year Sentence in Tainted Peanut Case
abstract: The former president of a peanut company was sentenced to 28 years in prison for his role in a salmonella outbreak that killed nine people.
lead_paragraph: The former president of a peanut company was sentenced Monday to 28 years in prison for his role in a salmonella outbreak that killed nine people and sickened more than 700 others. The executive, Stewart Parnell, 61, was sentenced about a year after a Federal District Court jury in Albany convicted him of dozens of counts, including introduction of adulterated food into interstate commerce with intent to defraud or mislead. Prosecutors said Mr. Parnell’s company, Peanut Corporation of America, repeatedly sold contaminated peanut products and misled customers about test results. They also said the company, which was headquartered in Virginia but also had facilities in Texas and Georgia, sometimes shipped products that Mr. Parnell knew were tainted. The company filed for bankruptcy and no longer operates. The prison term fell far short of the 803 years that Mr. Parnell faced under sentencing guidelines. He plans to appeal his convictions.

headline: The Wrath of Volkswagen’s Drivers
keywords: ['Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Diesel Power', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: With its admission of fraud in its diesel emissions testing, Volkswagen stands to lose drivers’ trust and the sales comeback it has sought in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen’s stunning admission that it sold diesel-powered cars that intentionally faked emissions testing results has left many of their owners — who thought they were buying fuel-efficient and environmentally friendly vehicles — angry and feeling betrayed.

lead_paragraph: There were not many overarching positive vibes coming from the Giants’ training complex Monday, the day after a second consecutive late-game collapse dropped the team’s record to 0-2. Wide receiver Victor Cruz, who has been sidelined by a calf injury since mid-August, did not practice, making him doubtful for Thursday’s game against the Washington Redskins at MetLife Stadium.

keywords: ['Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Automobiles', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Diesel Power', 'Clean Air Act', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: Volkswagen executives told environmental regulators repeatedly that discrepancies on pollution tests were not a deliberate attempt to deceive Washington officials.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen executives told environmental regulators for more than a year that discrepancies between pollution tests on its diesel cars and the starkly higher levels out on the road were a technical error, not a deliberate attempt to deceive Washington officials.

headline: The Influence of Fiorina at Lucent, in Hindsight
abstract: Carly Fiorina’s tenure as chief of Hewlett-Packard has drawn some criticism during her presidential campaign. But her career at Lucent is worth a look as well.
lead_paragraph: As Carly Fiorina has risen in the polls over the last week, there is renewed focus on her controversial tenure as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard. Yet her career at Lucent Technologies has been treated as little more than a footnote. It shouldn’t be.

headline: Review: Thomas Bradshaw’s ‘Fulfillment,’ on One Man’s Ceiling, and His Frustrations
abstract: This deadpan drama by the shock artist Thomas Bradshaw is more of a slice-of-life narrative than his previous ventures into new frontiers of outrage.
lead_paragraph: Being a shock artist like Thomas Bradshaw carries its own exacting burden. The knowing theatergoer attends this prolific playwright’s work in a state of anxious anticipation, fearing and hoping to be rattled by some fresh violation of the traditionally taboo.

headline: Wild and Wonderful
abstract: Victor Barocas and Tom Pepper pull a fast one on me.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — At first, I thought the theme of Victor Barocas’s and Tom Pepper’s puzzle was going to be “occupations that end in -IST.” Since I generally solve from top to bottom, themes like this one hit me in waves, with the final revealer acting like a tidal wave, providing the crucial “Aha!” moment.

headline: Mets Recall How to Win After a Night to Forget
abstract: The Mets, who had lost four of their last five, earned an impressive victory that also served as a reminder that their next nine games will be against teams out of the playoff race.
lead_paragraph: Manager Terry Collins walked into the Mets’ clubhouse late Sunday and found his players sitting quietly at their lockers. The Mets had pulled their ace, Matt Harvey, from the game early, on purpose, as part of a plan to keep him healthy in his first season back after Tommy John surgery. The team fell apart from there and lost by nine runs.

headline: Philippines: Gunmen Abduct Foreigners
abstract: Four people — two Canadian men, a Norwegian man and a Filipino woman — were abducted on Monday night from a resort on the southern Philippine island of Mindanao.
lead_paragraph: Four people — two Canadian men, a Norwegian man and a Filipino woman — were abducted on Monday night from a resort on the southern Philippine island of Mindanao, the police said Tuesday. The victims were identified as John Ridsdel and Robert Hall, both of Canada, and Kjartan Sekkingstad of Norway. The identity of the Filipino woman has not yet been confirmed. The four were taken from the Oceanview Resort on Samal island, off the southern coast of Mindanao, about 11:40 p.m. Mindanao has been a frequent site of kidnappings and violence between government troops and several rebel groups, including Muslim extremists that have pledged allegiance to the Islamic State. But Monday’s kidnapping is the first abduction of foreign tourists in Mindanao in more than two years. In 2012, a Swiss national, Lorenzo Vinciguerra, and Ewold Horn, from the Netherlands, were abducted while bird watching off the coast of Mindanao. Mr. Vinciguerra escaped last December. Mr. Horn is still being held.

headline: Egypt Destroying Far More Homes Than Buffer-Zone Plan Called For, Report Says
keywords: ['Demolition', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In clearing a buffer zone to crack down on Islamic insurgents, Egypt has destroyed 3,255 homes — four times the number it said would be, according to Human Rights Watch.
lead_paragraph: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt announced a sweeping plan last fall to tighten his crackdown on Islamist insurgents in the North Sinai: clearing a half-kilometer buffer zone along the length of the border with the Gaza Strip, to block any weapons or support from coming through tunnels from Hamas militants on the other side. The government said it would demolish 800 homes and displace as many as 10,000 people in the process.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1:35 P.M. (Starz) THE HOLIDAY (2006) A British wedding columnist (Kate Winslet) swaps places with a Los Angeles movie-trailer producer (Cameron Diaz) after guy troubles leave them in a tizzy in this romantic comedy about love — for men, for the movies — directed by Nancy Meyers. “There is something touching if willfully naïve about Ms. Meyers’s nostalgia for Hollywood’s golden age, when Louis B. Mayer ruled the very lot on which she shot part of this film,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “An old-studio producer would have recognized that there are several films jammed into this one and maybe called in Ben Hecht for a polish, even as he recognized that Ms. Meyers always has something to give.” (Image: Ms. Winslet and Jack Black.)

headline: Pope Francis, the Prince of the Personal
abstract: On Francis’ visit, he will offer a model on listening and learning, and upholding moral standards while remaining loving and merciful.
lead_paragraph: One of Pope Francis’ favorite novels is “The Betrothed” by Alessandro Manzoni. It is about two lovers whose longing to marry is thwarted by a cowardly and morally mediocre priest and a grasping nobleman. A good simple friar shelters the suffering couple. Then a plague hits the country, reminding everyone of their mortality and vulnerability, and also bringing about a moral reckoning.

headline: How the U.S. Can Welcome Refugees
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Resettling those who flee persecution is an American success story.
lead_paragraph: THE evidence from Europe in recent weeks is that many citizens are ahead of their governments when it comes to responding to the tide of human misery coming from the Middle East. Soccer clubs in Germany are setting up training academies. Austrians have turned out at railway stations. In Iceland, more than 15,000 people joined the “Syria is calling” Facebook page, many of whom apparently offered to house a refugee.

headline: California’s Right-to-Die Bill
abstract: The governor should sign into law a bill that would allow some terminally ill patients to hasten their death.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jerry Brown of California is hearing plenty from opponents and supporters of a bill state lawmakers passed earlier this month that would allow some terminally ill patients to hasten their death. Modeled after the pioneering right-to-die bill Oregon put into effect in 1997, California’s End of Life Option Act would allow people in the advanced stages of a terminal illness to obtain a lethal dose of painkillers from a physician.

headline: ‘Bible Belt Atheist’
abstract: In this short documentary, a former Pentecostal preacher starts a secular church in the South.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Los Angeles and Paris, we both were raised secular and embraced atheism early and easily. It’s not that we didn’t ponder life’s mysteries; it’s just that after we reasoned away our religious questions, we stopped worrying about them and moved on. When we learned about the former pastor Jerry DeWitt’s struggles with being an “outed” atheist in rural Louisiana, we realized for the first time just how difficult being an atheist can be in some communities, where religion is woven deeply into the social fabric.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — After weeks of indecision, the European Union voted on Tuesday to distribute 120,000 asylum seekers among member states, a plan meant to display unity in the face of the largest movement of refugees on the Continent since World War II.

headline: What Happened to South African Democracy

As a new visitor myself last month, I was captivated by both. But what has lodged most in my memory is something very different.

headline: ‘The Visiting Privilege,’ by Joy Williams
abstract: Stories spanning nearly 50 years are marked by queasy humor and a wry nihilism.
lead_paragraph: If the human race were ever put on trial — for crimes against the planet, animals and one another — it would be hard to think of a more ferocious prosecutor than Joy Williams. Is there a writer whose condemnations are more convincing, whose vision is more godless and bleak? And in case this all sounds too punishing for you, is there a funnier nihilist in the ranks of American writers?

headline: ‘Selfish,’ by Kim Kardashian West, and More
abstract: The narcissism typified in one book is seen as either useful or dangerous in two others.
lead_paragraph: During her reign, Kim Kardashian has proved herself to be a person of towering if brittle self-regard. The brittleness is revealed in the floods of tears that attend even minor affronts to her sense of self: if a family member gently teases her; if she feels in any way misunderstood; if she realizes she may give birth to her third fiancé’s child before her second divorce is final. But the true nature of her self-­regard — river deep and mountain high — is revealed in just about all of her other actions, and particularly in her recently published collection of self-portraits, “Selfish.”

For now, though, I found a less novel, but far handier feature in the new iPhone — one that has long been the butt of jokes but is now becoming a necessary part of modern computing.

headline: Rate Rage in 1932
abstract: Bankers for depression.
lead_paragraph: Both Rob Johnson and Peter Temin direct me to a paper by Gerald Epstein and Thomas Ferguson on the Fed’s strange, destructive turn away from expansionary policy in 1932. They look carefully at the archival evidence, and find that a key factor was the complaints of commercial banks that low interest rates on government securities were squeezing their profits. That is, the turn to tight money in the face of deflation and a collapsing real economy was driven by the same narrow banker interests I have suggested explain current demands for higher rates despite low inflation.

lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth I was the regal template for the irregular braids backstage at the Giles spring/summer 2016 runway: The Toni&Guy team recreated the slightly shiny (ahem, sweaty) hair revealed once all those grand Tudor ladies took off their towering wigs. “Even though they’re braids, we didn’t want it to get too pretty,” said the hairstylist Indira Schauwecker, emphasizing the thinned-out quality of this anti-volume look. “It’s a lived-in and wet look with a masculine edge. The idea is that these braids have been destroyed by the wigs.”

headline: 1940: Nazis Torpedo Refugee Liner
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Torpedoes', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Over eighty children die after a British vessel was torpedoed, in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In one of the most tragic sea disasters of the war, 293 persons, including eighty-three children evacuated from England to escape Nazi bombs, lost their lives when a liner bound for Canada was torpedoed by a German submarine last Tuesday night 600 miles at sea, it was officially announced tonight [Sept. 22]. Only 113 persons out of a total complement of 406 aboard the vessel — which sailed Friday, the 13th — were rescued by British warships and landed last Friday at a northern British port. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 23, 1940

headline: 1890: The War on Slavery
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: European governments are called upon to diminish the slave trade in 1890.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The meeting of the anti-slavery congress in this city, convoked by Cardinal Lavigerie, will give a new impulse to the crusade against the African slave trade. The Powers that have divided Africa between them are now responsible. Now that the countries from which the slaves are brought are English, French, German, Belgian, Italian and Portuguese territories the European Governments are compelled to exercise a more active and extensive hostility to the trade. Fully 80,000 slaves are annually exported from Africa and as it is estimated that four-fifths of those brought down to the coast perish on the way, at least 400,000 negroes are annually torn from their homes. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 23, 1890

headline: De Blasio Says James Blake Has Handled Mistaken Arrest With ‘Selflessness’
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio praised the retired tennis star after meeting with him to discuss reforms the city could undertake to curb the kind of rough treatment Mr. Blake faced.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who the retired tennis star James Blake said had been cooperative and sympathetic to his calls for police reform during their meeting on Monday, returned the compliment on Tuesday, praising Mr. Blake for looking to spur change in the aftermath of his mistaken arrest.

headline: Exit Walker
abstract: The Wisconsin union-slayer drops out early.
lead_paragraph: About four hours passed yesterday between my hitting “publish” on a post suggesting that Scott Walker’s donors and supporters shouldn’t bail on him just yet and Walker surprising many of those same donors and supporters, as well as the political press, by deciding to drop out of the presidential race entirely. I was obviously among the surprised, and the sheer speed of Walker’s exit makes me think that all the savvy post-mortems might end up missing a key truth: Running for president is hard, unpleasant work, Walker had fought three intense campaigns in just four years, and it’s possible that he simply burned out on running for office sometime in the last two months.

headline: The Understated Elegance of the Airline Scarf
abstract: The last glamorous thing about flying commercial.
lead_paragraph: In an airport, there is not much to do but wait, and watch. Our fellow passengers tend to dress as if planning to attend a pajama party at 35,000 feet, of course, while the professionals dress professionally. Amid the terminal boredom, we find ourselves comforted by a pilot’s winged badge, oddly transfixed by a gate agent’s epaulets and charmed by what may be the last remaining glamorous thing about flying commercial, which is the scarf worn by the woman pleading for laggards to fold up their tray tables. While not all female flight attendants wear scarves, the attitude exemplified by Air Canada’s uniform guide — ”Wear your scarf at all times!” — is common enough to keep the item tightly knotted to the iconography of the job. In a traveler’s wishful moments, the panache of the scarf can perk up a slog of a trip with the hint of a colorful jaunt.

headline: David Petraeus Urges Stronger U.S. Military Effort in Syria
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In his first testimony since resigning as director of the C.I.A., Mr. Petraeus told Congress that the United States should act to stop the Syrian government’s barrel-bomb attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s Syria policy came under sharp criticism Tuesday from one of its own former top military commanders and C.I.A. directors —David H. Petraeus — even as the White House is weighing new options for fighting the Islamic State in Syria.

headline: Gabriel Kreuther
abstract: European technique with a purpose at the chef’s new restaurant near Bryant Park.
lead_paragraph: European technique with a purpose at the chef’s new restaurant near Bryant Park.

headline: Restaurant Review: Gabriel Kreuther in Midtown
abstract: Gabriel Kreuther has brought his winning formulas from the Modern to his own restaurant near Bryant Park.
lead_paragraph: When the chef Gabriel Kreuther left the Modern in 2014, he seems to have packed up virtually everything except Picasso’s goat in the sculpture garden. He named the place he opened in June, across 42nd Street from Bryant Park, after himself, but it could just as easily be called the Modern in Exile.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – Glenn Close, who portrayed Norma Desmond, the fictional faded film star, in Andrew Lloyd Webber’s musical adaptation of “Sunset Boulevard” in Los Angeles and Broadway more than 20 years ago, will reprise the role for a semi-staged production at the London Coliseum in April.

headline: Inside a Jordanian Refugee Camp: Reporter’s Notebook
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Jerusalem bureau chief Jodi Rudoren describes her experience in the Zaatari Refugee Camp in Jordan
lead_paragraph: ZAATARI REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan — When I first visited Zaatari a few months after it opened in 2012, I wrote about the emerging marketplace: a couple dozen kiosks where people hawk used clothes, snacks, SIM cards and perfume. It was one of several signs of Syrians settling in, I said then; of realizing that they would “likely live in this camp for months, not days or weeks.”

headline: As London Fashion Week Ends, a Burberry Concert and Anya Hindmarch’s Fun House
keywords: ['London Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2015)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The final shows included Peter Pilotto and Christopher Kane.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — To paraphrase the Edwardian satirist H.H. Munro (better known as Saki, in one of English literature’s early feats of branding): They were good fashion shows, as fashion shows go, and as fashion shows go, they went.

headline: Volkswagen Debacle on Financial Par With BP Oil Spill
abstract: The final bill under the Clean Water Act for BP’s Gulf of Mexico oil spill was $5.5 billion; for Volkswagen, it could be as much as $18 billion.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen’s cheating on clean air rules in the United States has driven investors into a deep funk.

lead_paragraph: The Transportation Security Administration defended its officers’ treatment of a transgender woman on Tuesday, a day after she says she was harassed and held for 40 minutes while passing through security in Orlando, Fla., causing her to miss a flight.

headline: Culture Project Cancels Play Directed by Cynthia Nixon
abstract: The play, “MotherStruck,” written and performed by Staceyann Chin, is an autobiographical solo show about Ms. Chin’s effort, as a single gay woman without health insurance, to have a child.
lead_paragraph: Citing serious financial trouble, the Culture Project on Tuesday abruptly canceled the premiere of a new play, backed by Rosie O’Donnell and directed by Cynthia Nixon, that was to have begun performances on Thursday.

abstract: Ms. Sainte-Marie was honored for “Power in the Blood,” which was released in May.
lead_paragraph: The veteran folk singer Buffy Sainte-Marie was awarded the 2015 Polaris Prize for Canadian album of the year at a ceremony in Toronto on Monday night. Ms. Sainte-Marie was honored for “Power in the Blood,” which was released in May, and will receive a prize of 50,000 Canadian dollars.

headline: Ben Carson Can’t Change Subject After Contentious Muslim Remark
abstract: “I would not advocate that we put a Muslim in charge of this nation,” Ben Carson said on “Meet the Press” on Sunday. The Republican candidate for president has had a hard time discussing anything else since.
lead_paragraph: Ben Carson, the retired neurosurgeon who is running for president, has seen his campaign’s first firestorm after remarks over the weekend in which he said that a Muslim should not be president of the United States.

abstract: Mr. Coates will write a yearlong series about the superhero that is to begin next spring.
lead_paragraph: Ta-Nehisi Coates can be identified in many ways: as a national correspondent for The Atlantic, as an author and, as of this month, as a nominee for the National Book Award’s nonfiction prize. But Mr. Coates also has a not-so-secret identity, as evidenced by some of his Atlantic blog posts and his Twitter feed: Marvel Comics superfan.

headline: Cardinals Are a Different Team When Carson Palmer Is Healthy
abstract: Arizona has a 14-2 record and has outscored its opponents by 160 points in its last 16 games started by Palmer.
lead_paragraph: Over the final 10 weeks of the 2013 season, the Arizona Cardinals posted the second best record in the N.F.L. at 7-2. Then, over the first 11 weeks of the 2014 season, the Cardinals sat atop the N.F.L. standings with an 8-1 record. But quarterback injuries doomed the team, and Arizona lost its final three games of the season playing with a third-string quarterback, Ryan Lindley.

headline: Panda Express Takes a Second Run at New York
abstract: The buffet-style chain is returning to a market saturated with traditional Chinese restaurants.
lead_paragraph: ROSEMEAD, Calif. — You tend to hear two prevailing views of Panda Express, a buffet-style chain that spoons up populist Chinese-American dishes at more than 1,800 locations around the world — and that plans on planting flags in New York City this year.

headline: An Emphasis on Lace and Organza at Marques’Almeida
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2015)', 'London Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']

lead_paragraph: The designers decided to play up textures in their spring/summer 2016 collection at London Fashion Week.

headline: Three’s a Trend: All-Over Cutouts
abstract: In New York and London, labels have shown looks in black — with strategically placed holes.
lead_paragraph: We’ve already discovered that spring/summer 2016 may well be the Season of the Shoulder. But shoulders aren’t the only body part that have been exposed on runways over the last few weeks — we’ve seen cutouts all over garments, particularly black ones, in New York and London. At Proenza Schouler, flamenco-inspired dresses included tidy cutouts at the waist (and shoulders, too). Across the pond, Anthony Vaccarello, the connoisseur of sporty-yet-sexy silhouettes, sent down a black tank with cutout detailing atop oversize, billowy black pants for Versus Versace. And a cutout form-fitting dress (in, you guessed it, black) showed up at Christopher Kane, whose collection was inspired by John Chamberlain’s “car crash” sculptures.

headline: San Francisco Opera Picks Matthew Shilvock, an Insider, to Be Its Leader
abstract: The appointment suggests that the company homed in on the practicalities of running an ambitious house.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco Opera mounted a 10-month international search to find a general director to succeed David Gockley when he steps down after this season. But in the end it decided that the best candidate was closer to home: On Tuesday the company announced that it would promote Matthew Shilvock, its associate general director, to the top job in August.

headline: ‘Lord of the Dance’ Creator Michael Flatley Announces His Farewell
abstract: “Lord of the Dance: Dangerous Games” will mark the end of his role onstage, but Mr. Flatley will still be directing and producing.
lead_paragraph: Michael Flatley’s starring role in “Lord of the Dance: Dangerous Games” will mark more than one milestone for the 57-year-old who founded two major Irish dance franchises. It will be his Broadway debut — and his farewell.

headline: ConAgra Reports $1.2 Billion Quarterly Loss as Overhaul Continues
abstract: The company lost $1.2 billion, or $2.88 a share, compared with profits of $482.3 million, or $1.14 a share, in the period last year..
lead_paragraph: ConAgra Foods, which owns brands like Marie Callender’s, Reddi-wip and Chef Boyardee, reported a steep loss in its first quarter on Tuesday after knocking down the value of its beleaguered private label business.

lead_paragraph: Martin Winterkorn, the chief executive of Volkswagen, apologizes for the company’s diesel emissions deception but calls it “the mistakes of a few people.”
