keywords: ['Nine-One-One (911) (Emergency Phone Number)', 'Drownings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The caller told an emergency dispatcher in North Carolina that he had sought help for “sexual desires” and that his children would be taken away from him.
lead_paragraph: The crime started in a dark North Carolina neighborhood and ended when two children were pulled alive from a nearby lake by an off-duty deputy, and the police said their father had tried to kill them.

headline: One Direction Announces November Album, Setting Up Battle With Bieber
abstract: One Direction has announced a Nov. 13 release date for its new album, “Made in the A.M.,” setting up a head-to-head pop battle with Justin Bieber, who is also to release his new album that day.
lead_paragraph: Two of the biggest teen-pop acts in recent memory have picked the same day to grow up.

headline: Black Barn Takes Its Inspiration From the Farm
abstract: The restaurant in the former SD26 space offers seasonal, rustic fare; Amy’s Bread opens a cafe in the library; Danny Brown Wine Bar to close.
lead_paragraph: Black Barn Whitewashed barn board walls, steel paneling and an elaborate overhead maze of raw crisscrossed beams give new personality to the space that was the restaurant SD26. “Can you believe it?” asked the chef and owner John Doherty, pointing out the dramatic ceiling. The design, by Mark Zeff, who is also a partner, includes tables for larger parties in roomy alcoves and a chef’s table stationed to one side of the bright open kitchen. The resolutely farm-to-table menu executed by the chef, Matteo Bergamini, who was at SD26, only hints at Italy with an array of charcuterie, a black fig pizza, and porchetta with broccoli rabe. Mushroom toast, lobster salad and grilled corn salad are on the savory side of the menu. Sweets include an apple pudding with buckwheat croutons. There’s a long list of sparkling wines and Champagnes, some served at the compact oyster bar near the entrance: 19 East 26th Street, 212-265-5959, blackbarnrestaurant.com.

headline: Newfest Lineup Includes  Peter Greenaway and Todd Haynes Films
abstract: The lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender film festival runs from Oct. 22-27.
lead_paragraph: Films from seasoned directors join the work of newcomers in the lineup for Newfest, New York’s lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender film festival. Organizers announced Monday that the festival would open Oct. 22 with “Eisenstein in Guanajuato,” from Peter Greenaway, about the Russian director Sergei Eisenstein’s pivotal months  in Mexico in the 1930s. The film received a warm reception when it played in Berlin earlier this year.

headline: Palestinian Woman Is First to Oversee Muslim Wedding Vows
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Palestinians', 'Marriages', 'Muslims and Islam', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Tahrir Hammad, 36, is conducting Palestinian weddings traditionally overseen by men as some jurists there try to get more women working in the legal system.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Tahrir Hammad thinks women, including herself, are too emotional to serve as judges, and accepts without question an Islamic legal dictate that sees two women as equivalent to one male witness for official ceremonies.

headline: Bernie Sanders Joins Rally of Striking Federal Workers to Call for Wage Increase
abstract: Bernie Sanders used the pope’s visit to amplify his call for a wage increase for federal workers by joining a rally of striking government workers at a Washington church.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders, the Democratic presidential candidate, is using the pope’s visit to Washington to amplify his call for a wage increase for federal workers.

headline: Video Review: The Ford Edge Adds a Touch of Luxury
abstract: The midsize crossover category has gotten smaller with the discontinuation of the Honda Crosstour and Toyota Venza, but the new Edge remains a strong entry.
lead_paragraph: ONE glance at your neighbor’s Chevrolet Suburban will confirm that Americans prefer roomier vehicles, so the dwindling number of midsize crossovers is puzzling. Honda Crosstour and Toyota Venza have been discontinued for lack of interest. That leaves the second-generation Ford Edge to do battle with the Sorento, Santa Fe, Murano and perhaps the raised wagon that is Outback.

headline: Driven | 2015 Ford Edge
abstract: The number of midsize crossover choices may be shrinking, but Ford has produced a new Edge and given it a premium feel and a sharp design.
lead_paragraph: The number of midsize crossover choices may be shrinking, but Ford has produced a new Edge and given it a premium feel and a sharp design.

headline: Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, Deposed President, Returns to Yemen
abstract: It was unclear how long Mr. Hadi, who was pushed out by Houthi rebels, intended to stay in Aden, where he arrived on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi of Yemen flew back to his war-ravaged country on Tuesday for the first time since he was forced into exile six months ago, according to a senior Yemeni security official and a statement by his exiled government.

headline: Los Angeles Puts $100 Million Into Helping Homeless
abstract: The city’s plan will focus on housing and service programs to get an estimated 26,000 homeless people off the streets.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Flooded with homeless encampments from its freeway underpasses to the chic sidewalks of Venice Beach, municipal officials here declared a public emergency on Tuesday, making Los Angeles the first city in the nation to take such a drastic step in response to its mounting problem with street dwellers.

headline: Donald Trump Threatens to Sue Club for Growth Over Ad Campaign
abstract: Donald J. Trump is threatening to sue the conservative Club for Growth unless it stops running advertisements asserting that he wants to raise taxes if elected president.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is hitting back at the Club for Growth, threatening to sue the conservative organization unless it stops running advertisements asserting that he wants to raise taxes.

headline: Should You Watch CBS’s ‘Limitless’?

headline: Three’s a Trend: Asymmetrical Harnesses
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2015)', 'London Fashion Week']
abstract: Looks from Simone Rocha, Joseph and Phoebe English included strips of fabric crisscrossing models’ bodies in unexpected ways.
lead_paragraph: We’ve seen plenty of unexpected skin in London this week, by way of creative cutouts. Another sexy trend that popped up this week: inventive, asymmetrical new plays on the harness. First, Simone Rocha sent innocent, girlie dresses down the runway bound with fabric or plastic harnesses. At Joseph, creative director Louise Trotter added a provocative touch — a double fabric harness, arcing over one shoulder and across the waist — to a simple ensemble comprised of a white top and black trousers. And true to form, Phoebe English delivered another collection filled with textures and layers, including a choppy cream skirt with suspenders that bound the arms.

headline: Is Bridge a Sport? The High Court Will Decide
abstract: When Sport England, which promotes and finances sports in the country, ruled that bridge was an activity, not a sport, the English Bridge Union sued.
lead_paragraph: Bridge, the trick-taking card game, has complex rules, prestigious international tournaments and a century of history.

headline: Petraeus Warns of Danger in Syria
abstract: Retired Gen. David H. Petraeus told the Senate Armed Services Committee that the effort to thwart the Islamic State and bring peace to Syria has been inadequate and lacked resources.
lead_paragraph: Retired Gen. David H. Petraeus told the Senate Armed Services Committee that the effort to thwart the Islamic State and bring peace to Syria has been inadequate and lacked resources.

headline: French Law That Banned UberPop Service Survives Legal Challenge
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: The Constitutional Council upheld a law that banned Uber’s low-cost ride-hailing service, which the company has suspended in France.
lead_paragraph: The Constitutional Council in France upheld on Tuesday a law that banned Uber’s low-cost ride-hailing service, a much-awaited decision that underscores how national courts are enforcing limits on the company’s expansion into new markets.

headline: In Detroit, a 100-Foot Graphic Mural That Distills the Urban Experience
abstract: The artist Andrew Kuo has created a new work for the city’s Museum of Contemporary Art — with a little help from Art Basel and Kickstarter.
lead_paragraph: When Elysia Borowy-Reeder, the executive director of the Museum of Contemporary Art Detroit (MOCAD), first glimpsed the graphic geometric shapes and the vivid hues in the New York artist Andrew Kuo’s work, she immediately thought it would be perfect for MOCAD’s Woodward Avenue facade, a space previously covered with murals by the San Francisco artist Barry McGee and by Detroit’s Seventh Letter Crew.

headline: Why Some Policy Experts Question Clinton’s Plan to Contain Drug Costs
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Hillary Clinton wants a set amount of drug company revenue to go to research for new therapies, an approach some critics call unrealistic.
lead_paragraph: When critics complain about the high cost of a prescription drug, drug makers tend to have two main defenses. One is that developing drugs is an expensive, risky endeavor, and so companies need high prices to cover the cost of medical research. The second is that their products bring value by improving health and wellness, and the companies should be rewarded for those public benefits.

headline: 5 Easy Meals for the Distracted Cook
abstract: Basic techniques and simple recipes let you turn your attention to little things like life.
lead_paragraph: How many dishes can you cook on autopilot?

headline: Why Everything Is Bad for You
abstract: Might as well eat bologna. Because you just can’t win.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up in the same New Jersey suburbs so expertly described in Todd Solondz movies and Tom Perrotta novels, the usual lunch for me was a sandwich consisting of Wonder Bread spread thick with Land O’ Lakes butter, a wad of Oscar Mayer bologna and a slice of American cheese.

headline: A Religious Museum Expands in Amsterdam
abstract: The reconfigured Our Lord in the Attic Museum in Amsterdam, with exhibits that cover the theme of religious freedom, will open this week.
lead_paragraph: The restored and expanded Our Lord in the Attic Museum (Museum Ons’ Lieve Heer op Solder) in Amsterdam makes its debut on Sept. 23, when visitors will enter the museum through a new entrance building connected by underground passage to the 17th-century house. The six-year, $12 million project adds a museum shop and cafe as well as more exhibit space to cover themes such as religious freedom historically through modern times. In its new layout, the museum also focuses on the stories of the various people who lived in the house.

lead_paragraph: The wounds of segregation were still raw in the 1970s. With only rare exceptions, African-American children had nowhere near the same educational opportunities as whites.

headline: Robert Lewandowski Scores Five Goals in Nine Minutes for Bayern Munich

lead_paragraph: The goals came so quickly from Robert Lewandowski that it was hard to keep track of them.

headline: India Retracts Proposal on Encryption for Social Media Data After Outcry
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Privacy']
abstract: A policy requiring that plain-text versions of messages be saved for 90 days for possible police inspection was condemned as draconian and impractical.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Responding to a chorus of criticism, Indian officials on Tuesday hastily withdrew a draft policy on encryption that would have required users of social media and messaging applications to save plain-text versions of their messages for 90 days so that they could be shared with the police.

headline: Samu-Jussi Koski in Greece
abstract: The designer’s photographs from Athens, Serifos and the North Aegean Islands.
lead_paragraph: The designer’s photographs from Athens, Serifos and the North Aegean Islands.

headline: A Finnish Designer Finds Inspiration — Truly — in the Greek Islands
abstract: Samu-Jussi Koski shares photographs from his recent travels with T.
lead_paragraph: Samu-Jussi Koski, the founder and head designer of the Helsinki-based fashion brand Samuji and its housewares line, Samuji Koti, cites nature as “a huge inspiration.” Hearing him describe the Greek landscape, it’s clear that phrase isn’t just a Q&A cop-out — he finds real motivation in, as he puts it, “the colors of the plants, the hills, the strange flowers, the ever-changing tone of the sky.” On the island Serifos, which he and his husband have visited each summer for the last decade or so, Koski likes to climb to the top of the highest hill at the edge of Chora, reaching a small church at either sunrise or sunset. “The sky that drops to the calm Mediterranean Sea at those times is something so beautiful,” he says. “One cannot find those colors anywhere else.”

headline: Should You Watch ABC’s ‘The Muppets’?
abstract: Weighing the pros and cons of the new sitcom, which premieres Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: SERIES: “The Muppets,” the latest gig for Jim Henson’s menagerie, premieres Tuesday on ABC. It was created by Bill Prady, an executive producer of “The Big Bang Theory.”

headline: In Interview, Donald Trump Denies Report of Father’s Arrest in 1927
abstract: Donald J. Trump responds to questions about a 1927 report in The New York Times that listed his father as among those arrested in response to a Ku Klux Klan rally that had turned violent in Queens
lead_paragraph: For a story about Donald J. Trump’s childhood home of Jamaica Estates, Queens, I talked to the presidential candidate about the role his father, Fred C. Trump, played in developing the neighborhood. I also asked him about a 1927 report in The New York Times, unearthed by the website Boing Boing, that listed Fred Trump as being among a group of people arrested, and then discharged, by the police in response to a Ku Klux Klan rally that had turned violent in Queens. The question, essentially, was, “Did you ever hear of this?”

headline: Should You Watch Fox’s ‘Scream Queens’?
abstract: Weighing the pros and cons of the new horror comedy, premiering Tuesday on Fox.

headline: Saudi Held at Guantánamo Is Repatriated, Reducing Number of Detainees to 114
keywords: ['Detainees', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The United States held the man as a wartime prisoner for more than 13 years, government files show. President Obama seeks to close the wartime prison by the time he leaves office.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon announced on Tuesday that it had repatriated a Guantánamo Bay detainee who intelligence analysts had concluded was probably once a bodyguard for Osama bin Laden. The United States held the man as a wartime prisoner for more than 13 years, government files show.

abstract: When you leave a company, you can roll over pretax contributions to a 401(k) into a traditional I.R.A. and after-tax contributions into a Roth I.R.A.
lead_paragraph: Making pretax contributions to your 401(k) retirement plan is a no-brainer. But recent changes in federal tax rules may make it more attractive for serious savers to increase after-tax contributions, as well.

headline: Weeknight Recipes and Cooking Strategies
abstract: A home-cooked midweek meal is easily had, once you’ve honed the most basic kitchen skills.
lead_paragraph: Cooking is a joy, a balm for mind and spirit. At its best it is a kind of magic, the transformation of groceries into art. But midweek cooking? Midweek cooking is a drag.

abstract: Harvard’s endowment, academia’s largest, performed slightly better than average but still trailed performance at some colleges.
lead_paragraph: The Harvard University Management Company, which oversees an endowment of $37.6 billion, the academic world’s largest, generated a 5.8 percent return for its most recent fiscal year, significantly lower than several of its rivals.

headline: Why Scott Walker’s Campaign Failed
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Governors (US)', 'Organized Labor', 'Political Action Committees', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The problem with the campaign was Scott Walker himself.
lead_paragraph: When a political campaign teeters on the edge of failure, the candidate and the campaign staff start to look for explanations. They blame the staff. They blame the press. They blame the weather. They blame everyone except the candidate.

headline: U.S. Targets Four States in Effort to Enroll the Uninsured
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Efforts to expand health coverage will focus on Dallas, Houston, northern New Jersey, Chicago and Miami, the health and human services secretary said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the third open enrollment season under the Affordable Care Act beginning in about six weeks, Obama administration officials said Tuesday that they would focus efforts to expand health coverage to the uninsured in Dallas, Houston, northern New Jersey, Chicago and Miami.

headline: Review: In Fox’s ‘Rosewood,’ a Cocky Crime Pathologist in Sultry Miami
abstract: Morris Chestnut stars in this new series, which extends a TV tradition of assuming that something very dark lies beneath Miami’s sunny surface.
lead_paragraph: Miami occupies a special place among TV locations. “Dexter,” “Miami Vice,” “Nip/Tuck,” “CSI: Miami,” “Magic City,” HBO’s new “Ballers”: show after show is built on the idea that this city’s sun-drenched, hard-bodied exterior must hide corruption. No place, the implication is, can be that beautiful without being sick underneath.

headline: Hillary Clinton Says She Opposes Keystone Pipeline
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton, who had said that she was waiting for the Obama administration to take a position on the pipeline, told an audience in Iowa that it was not “in the best interests of what we need to do to combat climate change.”
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton said on Tuesday that she opposed building the Keystone XL oil pipeline, revealing her position on an issue that divides two Democratic constituencies, organized labor and environmentalists, and that she has long declined to address.

headline: Believing in Magic

lead_paragraph: A magician and his assistant, who travel the world performing, decide to tie the knot.

lead_paragraph: Mr. Moghadam, 59, is the chairman and chief executive of Prologis, a publicly traded real estate investment trust, or REIT, based in San Francisco, that develops and owns about 700 million square feet of industrial property worldwide, including many sites in New Jersey.

headline: Xi Jinping Pledges to Work With U.S. to Stop Cybercrimes
abstract: The president faced a crowd concerned over China’s barriers to market access, rampant commercial cybertheft and the imposition of intrusive security measures.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — President Xi Jinping pledged in a speech here on Tuesday night to work with the United States on fighting cybercrime, saying that the Chinese government was a staunch defender of cybersecurity.

abstract: Cookie’s got clout, and she shows it in the season opener of this nighttime soap opera, Wednesday on Fox.
lead_paragraph: “Empire” returns for its second season on Fox with a show of power. Several, actually.

lead_paragraph: It looks as if the Tonys are hitting the road again.

headline: Making Times Square’s Pedestrian Plazas Work
abstract: City Hall’s plan focuses on better policing, but better management and a clear cultural vision may be just as important.
lead_paragraph: So the pedestrian plazas in Times Square aren’t going away. Last month’s tabloid flap over topless women and costumed panhandlers prompted William J. Bratton, the city’s police commissioner, to say he’d like to rip the plazas up. The mayor, Bill de Blasio, didn’t disagree, calling for a task force to study ways to improve the square.

headline: Review: ‘Baby Doll,’ a Child-Woman at the Center of a Moral Sinkhole
abstract: The McCarter Theater’s production doesn’t stray far from the indelible 1956 movie, but the sexuality feels toned down.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — Everyone onstage looks a little clammy at times in the enjoyable if slightly tame new stage adaptation of “Baby Doll” at the McCarter Theater Center here. The once-grand but now visibly crumbling mansion in which much of the action takes place looks as if it would give scant protection from the fierce Mississippi Delta sun. But the tensions that inflame its inhabitants are the primary cause of any excessive perspiration.

headline: Joshua Jay and Anna Kloots: A Magician Marries His Assistant
abstract: They knew it had to be permanent if they would be traveling the world together performing magic.
lead_paragraph: The groom? The magician Joshua Jay. The bride? Anna Kloots, his magician’s assistant. When Mr. Jay, 33, appears in a straitjacket, Ms. Kloots, 26, pulls in people from the audience to check the integrity of his bonds and his blindfold.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: What Scott Walker Could Have Learned From George W. Bush
abstract: The Wisconsin governor understood the importance of a campaign message, but underestimated the importance of everything else.
lead_paragraph: The Internet is not wanting for explanations of the flameout of Gov. Scott Walker’s short and surprisingly anemic presidential campaign. Walker couldn’t lock down the Republican Party’s conservative base. His average-Joe persona was no match for the scene-stealing Donald Trump. He didn’t understand foreign policy. He didn’t understand domestic policy. He flip-flopped. He was too timid in the first debate. He was too gimmicky in the second debate. Above all, the Wisconsin governor’s downfall illustrates yet again how difficult and unforgiving the business of presidential campaigning is, even for a career politician like Walker.

headline: New York City Police Officer Pleads Guilty to Attempted Murder in Drunken Shooting
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Officer Brendan Cronin, who had been drinking for several hours before the attack on a vehicle in Westchester County last year, will be sentenced to nine years in prison.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer pleaded guilty to attempted murder on Tuesday for firing a barrage of bullets at a car in Westchester County last year, an unprompted, drunken attack that seriously injured a 47-year-old passenger.

headline: Teaming Up, Together (Drake and Future) or Apart (Ryan Adams and Taylor Swift)
abstract: The idea of a partnership of equals is, at best, fallacy, and at worst, fantasy. A look at the album “What a Time to Be Alive” and Mr. Adams’s take on “1989.”
lead_paragraph: The idea of a partnership of equals is, at best, fallacy, and at worst, fantasy. Never is that more clear than when one-half of the team-up is Drake or Taylor Swift, the anchors of contemporary pop music.

headline: ‘Pizza Rat’ Prompts a Collective ‘Ew’ and Debate on Cleaning New York Subway
abstract: Thomas P. DiNapoli, the state comptroller, questioned a pilot program that removed trash cans from 39 train stations, saying it has shown little evidence of reducing rodents or litter.
lead_paragraph: Even in a subway system often cluttered with trash, it stood out: a whole slice of pizza left carelessly on the floor.

headline: Giants Cut Receiver Preston Parker; Victor Cruz Runs in Practice
abstract: Parker’s release was perceived as a threatening message from Coach Tom Coughlin to the rest of the roster.
lead_paragraph: Preston Parker, the wide receiver who dropped several passes in the Giants’ first two games, was released by the team Tuesday. Just a few hours later, Victor Cruz, who has not played since early last season because of two leg injuries, was running in practice for the first time since mid-August.

headline: Quirky, an Invention Start-Up, Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: The crowdsourced company, which raised $185 million from investors, said it was arranging a sale of “substantially all its assets.”
lead_paragraph: Quirky, an ambitious crowdsourced invention start-up, which raised $185 million from investors that included General Electric and leading venture capital firms, filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday.

abstract: Melissa Clark makes a simple roast chicken.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes a simple roast chicken.

headline: Review: ‘Pondling’ Looks Deep Into the Heart of a Disturbed Child
abstract: Genevieve Hulme-Beaman’s solo play, in which she stars, is part of the Origin Theater Company’s 1st Irish festival at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: The rhyme about sugar and spice and everything nice has always been absurd. Anyone who’s ever been a little girl can tell you that much. But Madeleine, the faintly disheveled menace at the center of Genevieve Hulme-Beaman’s poignant and engrossing solo play, “Pondling,” is in particularly misleading disguise as a darling moppet.

headline: Review: In ‘Deep South,’ Paul Theroux Takes an Eye-Opening Road Trip
abstract: Mr. Theroux’s book touches on many corners of the South, including its food, language and gun shows.
lead_paragraph: Paul Theroux is in a suspiciously good mood in “Deep South,” his 10th travel book. You begin to wonder if, in his relative old age — Mr. Theroux is 74 — this inimitably caustic novelist and nonfiction writer is mellowing.

headline: As Frustrations Build in Libya, So Do Calls for Help
abstract: Many Libyans doubt that the country’s warring factions will end their power struggle, even if a United Nations-sponsored peace agreement is signed soon.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — For more than a year, Libyans have been watching their politicians shuttle between foreign capitals on rounds of peace talks, workshops and conferences in search of a solution to the worsening chaos at home. At one recent event in the Tunisian capital, frustrations at the slow progress were evident in the heartfelt questions and statements from the Libyan refugees in the audience.

headline: Scott Walker’s Dismal Finish Is a Fitting Result, Old Foes Say
abstract: Old adversaries said that Mr. Walker began and furthered his Wisconsin career on a divisive style with roots in a 1990 legislative campaign.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — For the last 25 years, Representative Gwen Moore has sought to relinquish her claim to being the only politician ever to defeat Scott Walker.

headline: Late Rally for Doc Adams, a Jeter Before There Were Mitts
abstract: Amid baseball fever in New York, descendants of the long-ago player who created the position of shortstop hope to see him elected to the Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: Before Derek Jeter made his mark as New York’s most illustrious shortstop, there was another player, popularly known as Doc Adams, who in the mid-1800s invented the position while playing for a different local powerhouse, the Knickerbocker Base Ball Club.

headline: Documenting Ukraine with a Different Visual Approach
abstract: Thomas de Wouters’s square, black-and white images of Ukraine look as if they were made by a 1960s-era New York street photographer set loose on the modern-day front between Russia and Ukraine.

lead_paragraph: On his first day back at work after Halloween last year, Eli Cherkasky, a prosecutor, told his co-workers at the Manhattan district attorney’s office that his bruised eye had been caused by the glasses he had worn as part of his Clark Kent costume.

keywords: ['Television', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'News and News Media']

lead_paragraph: With little fanfare, Brian Williams returned to television Tuesday afternoon in his new position as a breaking-news anchor at MSNBC with coverage of Pope Francis’s arrival in the United States.

headline: Martin Shkreli, the Mercurial Man Behind the Drug Price Increase That Went Viral
abstract: After raising the cost for a drug used to treat serious parasitic infections to $750 a tablet, from $13.50, Martin Shkreli of Turing Pharmaceuticals says he will sell it for less to ease public anger.
lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli is either the boy genius or the bad boy of pharmaceuticals, depending on one’s point of view.

headline: Judge Strikes Down New York City’s Ban on Foam Food Containers
keywords: ['Plastics', 'Containers and Packaging', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Foam', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Decisions and Verdicts']

lead_paragraph: New York City’s ban on plastic-foam food containers, the once-ubiquitous vessels for Chinese takeout and curbside halal food, has been overturned, rejecting a signature environmental initiative of two mayors and clearing the way for an industry-backed plan to buy and recycle the items.

lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola, the world’s largest maker of sugary beverages, has spent almost $120 million in the past five years to pay for academic health research, partnerships with major medical groups and community fitness programs aimed at curbing the obesity epidemic.

abstract: Tribune Publishing lowered its revenue and earnings guidance for the year, based on a review of its holdings in Southern California. The company recently fired the publisher of The Los Angeles Times.
lead_paragraph: Tribune Publishing executives said in a conference call to investors on Tuesday that the company had reduced its guidance for the year based on what was described as a review of its holdings in Southern California.

headline: Alexis Tsipras Appoints New Greek Cabinet Much Like the Old
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Mr. Tsipras, under pressure from the country’s bailout partners to begin work on economic reforms, kept his core economic team nearly intact.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greece’s newly re-elected prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, decided on Tuesday on a new cabinet with few new faces and returned the critical job of finance minister to Euclid Tsakalotos, the low-key economist who made headway with his eurozone peers in bailout negotiations.

headline: Pope Francis, in New York, Will Live Like a Diplomat
abstract: The pontiff known for simple tastes will stay in a five-story, 11,000-square-foot townhouse on the Upper East Side with a bit of municipal history.
lead_paragraph: The signs of his arrival in the neighborhood will be less than subtle: a battalion of police officers, Secret Service agents and assorted security personnel monitoring every manhole and sidewalk crack; snipers on the rooftops; bomb-sniffing dogs at the ready.

headline: Volkswagen’s Diesel Fraud Makes Critic of Secret Code a Prophet
keywords: ['Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Software', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Automobiles', 'Air Pollution', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The automaker’s admission that it used proprietary software code to cheat emissions tests shows why Eben Moglen, a Columbia University law professor, has long argued for making such code transparent.
lead_paragraph: A Columbia University law professor stood in a hotel lobby one morning and noticed a sign apologizing for an elevator that was out of order. It had dropped unexpectedly three stories a few days earlier. The professor, Eben Moglen, tried to imagine what the world would be like if elevators were not built so that people could inspect them.

headline: The Republican Attack on Muslims
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Muslim Americans', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The presidential candidates’ demagogy panders to a disaffected base and ignores American values.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson is drawing criticism over the bigoted comments he has been making recently about Muslims. It is well deserved, and is not a matter of “P.C. culture,” as Mr. Carson has claimed. Nor does Mr. Carson represent some minor fringe element in the Republican Party.

abstract: Mr. Emanuel told the City Council that unless taxes and fees were increased, there would be cuts to trash collection, the police force and at fire stations.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Faced with a toxic combination of mounting pension payments and plunging credit ratings, Mayor Rahm Emanuel on Tuesday called for tax and fee increases unprecedented in this city’s modern history, including a “last resort” property tax increase of more than $500 million to be put in place over four years.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the past two years, the critical question confronting the Obama administration about Xi Jinping, the Chinese president who defied American predictions by challenging the United States’ superpower status early and directly, has been how forcefully to respond.

headline: Two Activists Visiting U.S. Call for Rights in Hong Kong
abstract: Joshua Wong, 18, and Martin Lee, 77, said in an interview that President Obama should press their cause when meeting his Chinese counterpart this week.
lead_paragraph: Two Hong Kong democracy activists — one young enough to be the other’s grandson — expressed deep distrust on Tuesday over China’s intentions and urged President Obama to press their cause when meeting his Chinese counterpart this week.

headline: Hillary Clinton Proposes Cap on Patients’ Drug Costs as Bernie Sanders Pushes His Plan
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination competed fiercely on plans to rein in pharmaceutical companies as Republicans generally opposed interference.
lead_paragraph: With voter fury rising over the high cost of prescription drugs, Hillary Rodham Clinton proposed capping out-of-pocket drug expenses at $250 a month on Tuesday while a rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, extolled his own plan and long record for pushing to lower drug costs.

headline: Iraq: Airstrike Kills an ISIS Leader
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: A Pentagon spokesman, Peter Cook, described Abu Bakr al-Turkmani as an “administrative emir” of the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon said Tuesday that coalition forces killed a senior leader of the Islamic State, Abu Bakr al-Turkmani, in an airstrike two weeks ago in northern Iraq. A Pentagon spokesman, Peter Cook, described Mr. Turkmani as an “administrative emir” of the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL, and a close associate of the group’s leaders. Mr. Cook also confirmed the death of a French jihadist, David Drugeon, in an airstrike in July in Syria. Mr. Drugeon was a member of the Khorasan Group, an offshoot of Al Qaeda, and an explosives expert, Mr. Cook said. Mr. Drugeon “trained other extremists in Syria and sought to plan other attacks against Western targets,” Mr. Cook said.

headline: Liberty Advance to Conference Finals
abstract: The reserves Sugar Rodgers and Candice Wiggins spurred a 15-0 second-quarter run to lead the Liberty past the Washington Mystics.
lead_paragraph: Epiphanny Prince missed 10 of her first 11 attempts from the field in Tuesday night’s decisive Game 3 Eastern Conference semifinal against the Washington Mystics at Madison Square Garden. With the Liberty’s franchise record for wins and best regular-season record in the W.N.B.A. this year withering away in the fourth quarter, Prince had passed up open looks, her confidence nearly shot.

headline: Sir David Willcocks, Conductor Who Influenced British Choral Music, Dies at 95
abstract: Long considered Britain’s most esteemed choir director, Mr. Willcocks also led ensembles in the United States and even worked with the Rolling Stones.
lead_paragraph: Sir David Willcocks, long considered Britain’s most esteemed choir director, who also led ensembles in the United States and even worked with the Rolling Stones, died on Thursday at his home in Cambridge, England. He was 95.

headline: Gov. Scott Walker Goes Back to His Day Job
abstract: His presidential campaign over, Mr. Walker has relations to soothe in Wisconsin, a state that feels a bit forgotten, some political operatives say.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — Gov. Scott Walker went back to his regular job on Tuesday, and it sounded like just another day. The governor was at work in the Capitol, his aides said, holding private meetings and receiving briefings from his executive staff.

keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Car-Pooling and Ride-Sharing', 'Commuting', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Software']
abstract: Uber is aiming to push deeper into China, launching a new commuter-oriented ride service on Wednesday in Chengdu, China.
lead_paragraph: Uber is growing like a weed in China, spending millions of dollars to push into the country. And it’s just getting started.

headline: Race and Class Collide in a Plan for Two Brooklyn Schools

abstract: A proposal to rezone students from the predominantly white P.S. 8 to the mostly black P.S. 307 has drawn intense opposition from families at both.
lead_paragraph: At Public School 8 in Brooklyn Heights, the auditorium’s stage is crowded with music stands that were stored there when the music room had to be turned into a first-grade classroom.

headline: Park Built Around 4 Mounds on Governors Island Will Offer New Views
abstract: Work has begun on 10 acres of land with four hills ranging from 25 to 70 feet that will offer panoramic views of New York Harbor. It is scheduled to be completed by spring 2017.
lead_paragraph: Adriaan Geuze, the landscape architect who is designing the parkland on Governors Island, had two incentives for raising the elevation of the 40 acres on his drawing board. The first was resiliency. His firm, West 8, knows a thing or two about flooding, given its headquarters in the Netherlands.

headline: Mets Fall to the Braves, but Manage to Gain Ground With Outside Help
abstract: The Mets stumbled closer to their first National League East title since 2006 because the Washington Nationals also lost, to the Baltimore Orioles.
lead_paragraph: With a successful road trip and an eight-game winning streak, the Mets built their lead in the National League East to nine and a half games with only 17 to play. Even for a team with a recent history of shocking collapses, that should have been enough allow the Mets to glide joyfully into their first division title since 2006.

headline: American Is Extradited to South Korea for Trial in 1997 Murder
abstract: Arthur John Patterson, 35, denied killing a 22-year-old South Korean college student, a crime that a friend of his had been convicted and then acquitted of.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — An American man arrived here in handcuffs on Wednesday as South Korea prepared to revisit a notorious murder case from 1997.

headline: Investigators Find Emails Hillary Clinton Said Were Erased
abstract: The F.B.I. recovered work-related and personal emails from the server Hillary Rodham Clinton used as secretary of state, two officials said, but it was not clear if all 60,000 emails were found.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. investigators have recovered work-related and personal emails that Hillary Rodham Clinton said had been deleted from the server that housed the personal account she used exclusively when she was secretary of state, according to two government officials.

headline: ‘Happy Birthday’ Copyright Invalidated by Judge
abstract: The decision is a blow to the music publisher Warner/Chappell and its parent, the Warner Music Group, which reportedly still collect some $2 million annually in licensing fees.
lead_paragraph: A judge ruled on Tuesday that the long-claimed copyright on “Happy Birthday to You,” the most popular tune in the English language, is not valid.

headline: Georges de Paris, Tailor to Nine Presidents, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. de Paris had made suits for every American leader since Lyndon B. Johnson, and he crafted his own life story, as well.
lead_paragraph: Georges de Paris, a Washington tailor who hand-stitched suits for every American president from Lyndon B. Johnson through Barack Obama (and who may have embroidered his own profile), died on Sept. 13 in Arlington, Va. He was 80.

headline: Dr. William E. Paul, Who Helped AIDS Research Save Millions of Lives, Dies at 79
abstract: As the director of the Office of AIDS Research at the National Institute of Health, Dr. Paul focused the government’s research programs to develop innovative therapies.
lead_paragraph: Dr. William E. Paul, an immunologist who was credited with focusing the federal government’s disparate AIDS research programs in the 1990s on developing innovative therapies that saved millions of lives, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 79.

headline: Dr. Leon Root, Orthopedic Surgeon Who Wrote Advice Books, Dies at 86
abstract: Dr. Root was chief of pediatric orthopedics for 27 years at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan, and he created a program to screen New York City children for disorders of the bones and joints.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Leon Root, a widely known orthopedic surgeon whose advice books on back pain and osteoporosis reached a broad public, and who created an ambitious program to screen children in Manhattan and the Bronx for disorders of the bones and joints, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Greg Bird’s Home Run in 10th Lifts Yankees Over Blue Jays
abstract: The victory allowed the Yankees to close to two and a half games behind the Blue Jays and keep their hopes of a division title alive.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — No matter the moment in his nascent major league career, Greg Bird has been unflustered by whatever has been thrown at him, good or bad. It was a sign to many of his teammates that Bird, 22, has maturity uncommon in a player his age, a trait that is sure to serve him well.

headline: Yogi Berra, Yankee Who Built His Stardom 90 Percent on Skill and Half on Wit, Dies at 90
abstract: A mainstay player on 10 Yankee championship teams who as a manager led the Yankees and Mets to the World Series, Berra may have been better known for his bumbling yet wise way with words.
lead_paragraph: Yogi Berra, one of baseball’s greatest catchers and characters, who as a player was a mainstay of 10 Yankees championship teams and as a manager led both the Yankees and the Mets to the World Series — but who may be more widely known as an ungainly but lovable cultural figure, inspiring a cartoon character and issuing a seemingly limitless supply of unwittingly witty epigrams known as Yogi-isms — died on Tuesday. He was 90.

It’s about what can happen in a democratic society when politicians go too far, when they not only stand mute when hateful words that cross civilized redlines suddenly become part of the public discourse, but, worse, start to wink at and dabble in this hate speech for their advantage.

headline: Anne-Marie Slaughter’s ‘Unfinished Business’
abstract: “Unfinished Business” is the outgrowth of a much-discussed article for The Atlantic about the difficulty of career advancement for professional women with children.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Anne-Marie Slaughter wrote an article for The Atlantic about the difficulty of career advancement for professional women with children. “Why Women Still Can’t Have It All,” which has now grown into “Unfinished Business,” electrified readers. Slaughter’s criticisms of workplace policies and attitudes were not new, but her article had the force of her own belated awakening to the problem. A law professor, author and ­Princeton University dean (now president of the nonpartisan think tank New America), Slaughter had just spent two years as director of policy planning in the State Department under Hillary Clinton — a “dream job” that she initially hoped would lead to further advancement within the agency. But after two years of punishing work hours and a weekly commute between Washington and Princeton, where her husband was taking care of their two sons, Slaughter was surprised to find herself declining more State Department stints. Sometimes a job just couldn’t be squared with family responsibilities, she concluded. She returned to her full-time academic post at Princeton, which offered flexible hours more conducive to family life, and was more or less satisfied with her decision.

headline: Starbucks Falls Short After Pledging Better Labor Practices
abstract: Barista interviews and a nonprofit’s report find continuing issues with erratic and short-notice scheduling, suggesting the difficulty of taking the high road.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Starbucks  vowed to provide store employees with more consistent schedules from week to week, and to post their schedules at least 10 days in advance. The company said it would stop asking workers to endure the sleep-depriving ritual known as a “clopening,” which requires them to shut down a store at night only to return early the next morning to help open it.

headline: Consumers Are Embracing Full-Fat Foods
abstract: A new report on dietary fat consumption suggests that the public is increasingly consuming more, not less, of foods high in saturated fat like butter, meat and whole milk.
lead_paragraph: Public health authorities have long urged Americans to cut back on foods high in saturated fat like butter, meat and whole milk. But a new report on dietary-fat consumption suggests that the public is increasingly eating more, not less, of these foods.

headline: Margaret Atwood’s ‘The Heart Goes Last’
abstract: With nothing left to lose, or so they think, a couple move into a suburban dream home.
lead_paragraph: The world of “The Heart Goes Last” starts out feeling familiarly post-­apocalyptic: a destitute married couple, Charmaine and Stan, drift across a devastated landscape, forced to sleep in their car as roving bandits threaten attack each night. As the story expands, we see the novel’s reality is even more disturbing: This is not a different universe, just a slightly exaggerated version of our own. A world where the working class has been pushed off the edge of the economic cliff, and the middle-class dream is alive only as a living nightmare. One of the last sustainable industries is the prison system. “Prisons used to be about punishment, and then reform and penitence, and then keeping dangerous offenders inside. Then, for quite a few decades, they were about crowd control — penning up the young, aggressive, marginalized guys to keep them off the streets. And then, when they started to be run as private businesses, they were about the profit margins for the prepackaged jail-meal suppliers and the hired guards and so forth.”

headline: Trevor Noah on ‘The Daily Show’ and His ‘Jewish Yoda,’ Jon Stewart
abstract: The new host of Comedy Central’s marquee news-satire series discusses his preparations, his controversial tweets and the challenges that the program will face.
lead_paragraph: Like the mostly vacant canvas that once hung outside the Midtown Manhattan studios of “The Daily Show,” advertising his Sept. 28 debut date and not much else, the office that Trevor Noah works from was nearly barren on a recent visit. The walls were unadorned, and the bookshelves were unfilled, except for a sound system that Mr. Noah was setting up so he could listen to jazz while he worked on his material. Perhaps the room’s only other distinguishing feature was a row of three TV sets, tuned to the NY1, CNN and BBC news channels, inundating Mr. Noah, 31, with a stream of information from around the world.

Leaders argued bitterly for weeks before the European Union could adopt a plan on Tuesday to share the burden among its members.

headline: Today in Politics: A First-Time Visitor to Washington Plans to Hit All the Sights

On the day the pope came to Washington and drew nearly all the nation’s cameras with him, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont did their best to stay in view, covering the high costs of prescription drugs, the Keystone XL oil pipeline, and low-wage workers. But, on Wednesday, all eyes, including President Obama’s and those of the gathering thousands, will be on the man in white.

headline: In Europe’s Top Destinations, Hotels to Suit Your Wallet
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Budget Travel']
abstract: Hotel pairs in six popular European cities, including Paris and Barcelona, offer alternatives at the high or low end of the budget spectrum.
lead_paragraph: A testament to the adage, “You get what you pay for,” high-end hotels lavishly indulge guests in everything from personal butlers to full-service spas, swimming pools and enough restaurants to take the guilt out of staying in. But luxury isn’t limited to pampering hotels with bank-bleeding prices. Sometimes the extras — a bountiful breakfast buffet, historic settings or personal services like walking tours and hiking directions — provide equivalent value at cheaper lodgings. The following hotel pairs in six European destinations offer intriguing alternatives at either end of the budget spectrum.

headline: Peer Pressure (not Parent Pressure) Helps Picky Eaters Try New Foods
abstract: The parents of picky eaters are surprised by what they’ll try with their peers.
lead_paragraph: Many parents struggle to persuade their school-aged children to take to heart the value of eating a healthy, varied diet, one that is colorful, full of vegetables and fruits and light on the bland, refined white grains like bread, pasta and pizza that go down so easily with children. Marlo and Corey, parents of Brooke, 10, and Hunter, 7, want the whole family to sit down to eat one, balanced meal together, but Brooke refuses to eat many foods, preferring pasta with butter and cheese or ramen noodles. Her younger brother almost always follows her lead, and Marlo and Corey have been willing to prepare something different for each child just to be sure that they eat enough.

He is the subject of a new exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the recipient of this year’s J. Paul Getty Medal for artistic achievement from the trust that operates the Getty Museum.

headline: 1915: Nurse Risks Gangrene Test
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A vaccine against gangrene is tested on a heroic nurse in 1915
lead_paragraph: The most infectious, rapid and fatal of all diseases of the battlefield — gas gangrene — has probably been vanquished by science at the American Hospital at Neuilly. Through the heroism of a nurse, Miss Mary Davies, who inoculated herself with the bacilli, Dr. Kenneth Taylor, who recently announced in the ‘‘Lancet’’ successful experiments on guinea pigs with a new vaccine, was able to test the remedy for the first time on a human being. Although virulent gangrene symptoms rapidly developed in the young woman, Dr. Taylor has announced that she is now out of danger. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 24, 1915

headline: Chinese Spillovers
abstract: How much should we worry?
lead_paragraph: China is clearly in economic trouble. But how worried should we be about spillovers from China’s woes to the rest of the world economy? I have in general been telling people “not very”, although it’s a bigger issue for Japan and Korea. But Citi’s Willem Buiter suggests that it could be a quite big deal, leading to a global recession. And Willem is a very smart guy; read his “Alice in Euroland“, from 1998 (!), warning of the dangers of EMU’s “lender of last resort vacuum.” So could he be right?

headline: Coming Soon to Checkouts: Microchip-Card Payment Systems
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Credit Cards', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Small Business']
abstract: Retailers are racing to meet an Oct. 1 deadline set by credit card networks to switch to the more secure payment technology that is common in most of the world except the United States.
lead_paragraph: LEE PADGETT, the owner of Busted, a lingerie shop in Detroit, has spent the last two weeks wrestling with three different payment software systems and a pile of new hardware. She is determined that by Oct. 1, her store will be one of the first in the area to begin moving from the familiar swiping technology for processing credit and debit cards to the chip-card system that card networks are pressing retailers to adopt.

headline: 1965: French Reds Back Mitterrand
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: With Communist support, Mitterrand could win up to 6 million votes in 1965.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French Communist Party ended 17 years of political isolation today [Sept. 23] by endorsing the leftist presidential candidacy of François Mitterrand. The choice was necessary because a purely Communist candidacy against President Charles de Gaulle might have produced as little as half of its traditional 20 percent of the vote. With Communist, Socialist, and other leftist backing, Mr. Mitterrand can expect 5 to 6 million votes from an electorate of nearly 28 million. He has a good chance of getting more votes than any other candidate except Gen. de Gaulle in the Dec. 5 election. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 24, 1965

An apartment would be provided, and a stipend. I didn’t think about it for very long. I wrote back: Yes.

headline: A Summer of Treasure-Filled Balloons
abstract: Sleepy Jones launched pajamas, cash and good vibes into the summer air.
lead_paragraph: On this first official day of fall, we celebrate summer’s end with a look back at one particularly seasonal, cross-country road trip. Last month, Sleepy Jones — the brand known for pajamas that look as appropriate on the street as they do at the breakfast table — released big red balloons at some of the nation’s most breathtaking environs: from the beaches of Montauk and the dunes of White Sands National Monument in New Mexico to the rocky shores of Malibu and the lush vineyards of Napa. It was a treasure hunt of sorts, and the locations were announced on Instagram. Each one was filled with Sleepy Jones pieces, money for the lucky finder’s troubles and, in one case, a party invitation from Miranda July.

abstract: Milan Fashion Week, which begins today, has made changes to be more welcoming to new designers — along with the opening of several new restaurants and cultural institutions.
lead_paragraph: Milan has, as far as reputations go, long been considered staid and provincial — a business town that empties on weekends. Apart from the influxes for fashion week and April’s Salone del Mobile design fair, visitors passed it by. But now, the city is on the edge of something of a renaissance, with new designers taking over at leading fashion houses, independent designers gaining more recognition and a host of new restaurants, bars and cultural activities on offer.

headline: New York City Ballet Gambles on Unknown Choreographers
abstract: New works by Robert Binet and Myles Thatcher will be part of the troupe’s fall gala.
lead_paragraph: Sara Mearns, balanced on one square inch of a pointe shoe, her other leg bent in front of her, swiveled under Tyler Angle’s outstretched arm, ducking her head. “I can’t get through!” she shrieked as her neck caught under his elbow. Then both dancers fell out of the position, collapsing with laugher. Robert Binet, 24, smiled. “Let’s try a different way,” he said.

headline: A Yankee’s Forgiveness Won’t Be Forgotten

lead_paragraph: The overdue and gloriously unscripted sequel to Yogi Berra’s wonderful Yankees life began on a cold Tuesday evening in January 1999, when Berra, a Hall of Fame catcher, stood slightly hunched at the back-entrance doorstep of a recently opened museum named for him. He awaited the arrival of the man whose impulsive behavioral and operational tendencies had sent Berra into a 14-year self-imposed exile from his most cherished workplace, in the South Bronx.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 3: Waiver Wire Picks
abstract: Whether your team’s record is 2-0 or 0-2, the waiver wire can be a path to fantasy gold.
lead_paragraph: The injuries did not stop in Week 2 of the N.F.L. season. Eddie Lacy exited with a high ankle sprain, Tony Romo fractured his collarbone and important players like Lamar Miller, Carlos Hyde and Davante Adams also left the field early with injuries. With some of these fantasy football starters potentially sidelined, that opens the door for other players to make an impact. Week 2 also proved that all of those overreactions from Week 1 were just that — overreactions. Adrian Peterson totaled nearly 200 all-purpose yards, Odell Beckham Jr. had nearly 150 yards and a touchdown, and Calvin Johnson and A.J. Green returned to pay dirt. Whether your team’s record is 2-0 or 0-2, the waiver wire can be a path to fantasy gold.

headline: 36 Hours in Paris, Right Bank
abstract: Discover the multiple personalities of the Right Bank, from its most intimate streets to its monumental boulevards and open spaces.
lead_paragraph: Think Left Bank, and the Latin Quarter and the Eiffel Tower spring to mind. The Right Bank, which is twice the size, has no clear identity. There are, in fact, many Right Banks. There is the Old Regime Right Bank, both monumental and orderly, with some of the city’s best-known sites — the Louvre, the Tuileries Gardens and the Palais Royal. There is the intimate, disorderly Marais, and the elegant open spaces of the revolutionary Right Bank (with the Bastille and Place de la Concorde, where Louis XVI, Marie Antoinette and Robespierre were guillotined). And there is the 19th-century financial Right Bank with its grand boulevards, covered arcades and department stores. Meanwhile, Right Bank villages like Montmartre, Passy and Belleville that were added to the city only in 1860 have struggled ever since to hold on to their local identities. Below is a selection of places that will let you discover the Right Bank’s multiple personalities.

headline: Yannick Noah Once Again Answers France’s Call
abstract: Noah was named coach of France’s Davis Cup team by officials eager to replicate his past triumphs.
lead_paragraph: Yannick Noah is back for another run as French Davis Cup captain. It will not be dull. It never is where Noah and tennis are concerned.

headline: Jumpsuits, 7 Days a Week at Totokaelo’s SoHo Store
abstract: For men and women, clothing to prove that the unencumbered life is worth living.
lead_paragraph: There’s something deplorably corny about referring to a website as a “destination.” It’s like calling an advertisement “branded content” or referring to a person — any person — as a “thought leader.” But in the case of Totokaelo, the term actually makes sense. For the last five years or so, the website of this retailer really has provided a vantage point for surveying a certain fashion landscape.

headline: The Prime Minister Did What With a Pig’s Head?
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'High Society and Socialites']
abstract: A scurrilous story about David Cameron’s student days reveals much about Britain’s prurient fascination with privilege.
lead_paragraph: IN Oxford in the 1980s, the covered market in the town center was a warren of small shops, selling everything from antiques to fruit and vegetables. There was an upstairs cafe and a butcher shop that displayed its wares in traditional fashion: Rows of carcasses hung above the entrance and across the front, so that in season it was almost comically festooned with dead game birds. Trays of trotters, liver and other kinds of offal completed the carnivorous tableau, usually arranged artfully around an obscenely grinning pig’s head.

headline: The Montreal Brothers Behind a Jet Set Leather Brand
abstract: Byron and Dexter Peart, identical twins, have devoted their lives to making hyper-functional, discreetly luxurious leather bags — priced about a third less than comparable designer bags.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — This is not a typical city to start a global luxury brand, but then again Want Les Essentiels de La Vie specializes in being atypical, beginning with that mouthful of a name and the company’s identical twin founders, Byron and Dexter Peart.

headline: Ashraf Ghani, Afghan President, Vows to Crack Down on Abuse of Boys
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mr. Ghani said the authorities would prosecute pedophiles no matter who they were, but many are Afghan commanders or powerful backers of the government.
lead_paragraph: Addressing revulsion at the widespread sexual abuse of boys by powerful Afghan commanders, President Ashraf Ghani pledged on Wednesday that his government would do what it could to stamp out a practice that is pervasive among many wealthy and prominent men in his country.

headline: Egypt Buys Two French Warships Originally Built for Russia
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Military Vehicles', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Defense and Military Forces']

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Two French warships originally built for Russia, but not delivered because of the crisis in Ukraine, will be sold to Egypt instead, the French government announced Wednesday.

headline: How Brian Regan, Connoisseur of Clean Jokes, Became a Comic’s Comic
abstract: Mr. Regan has been uncool so long that he’s become kind of cool. Now he’s performing in Comedy Central’s first live special on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Brian Regan is a throwback, and not just because he is one of the last headlining comics who refuse to curse onstage.

headline: The Art, Drinks, Roads and Poems that Inspire Julia Holter
abstract: The experimental pop artist recommends “Andrei Rublev,” Route 395, Frank O’Hara and more.
lead_paragraph: On paper, one could be forgiven for mistaking the music of the experimental pop singer Julia Holter for a particularly eclectic college syllabus. Over the course of Holter’s four albums, she’s taken inspiration from Euripides’s “Hippolytus” (her album “Tragedy”) and Frank O’Hara’s “Having a Coke With You” (her song “Moni Mon Ami”). On her last album, “Loud City Song,” Holter filtered contemporary celebrity through the lens of “Gigi,” a 1958 musical set in turn-of-the-century Paris, based on a novella by Colette. On her new record, “Have You in My Wilderness” (out Sept. 25 on Domino), however, Holter’s inspirations are less thematically unified — more free form — than in the past. “This record is less identifiable with influences,” she says. “It’s not that I don’t use a bit from books or legends or whatever, but each song is different; it’s not like I had loosely based the album on some kind of narrative.”

headline: The Instantly Gratifying Facial
abstract: Beauty brands and aestheticians help massage faces into shape.
lead_paragraph: Defining the contours of the face was once as easy as applying a bit of blush. Then bronzer became a (really big) thing. Then the duck face came along — as a not so discreet attempt to create the illusion of concave cheeks in selfies. Ultimately, a cheekbone-defining makeup technique called contouring took YouTube tutorials by storm, followed not too distantly by the Kardashian-approved highlighting method called strobing (on Instagram). Aestheticians and skin care companies get it: We will go to great lengths to mask a puffy face. So recently, they’ve taken to toning and depuffing skin — for real.

headline: Restoring Public Confidence in Government Isn’t Getting Any Easier in Ferguson, Mo.
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Local Government', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Supreme Courts (State)']
abstract: Those who say they can fix the court system in and around Ferguson without a total overhaul didn’t help their case by keeping a recent meeting closed to the public.
lead_paragraph: In the tumultuous year after the police shooting of an unarmed black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., the exploitative court system serving the suburban municipalities that ring St. Louis has faced growing public outrage. The Department of Justice has found that this system abuses the rights of citizens — especially African Americans — in scheming to raise revenue.  And a recent tone-deaf response from the courts to calls for reform has only worsened the public’s fury.

headline: Classical Playlist: Gabrieli, Bach, ‘Distant Voices’ and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: ‘GABRIELI’ National Brass Ensemble(Oberlin Music)Giovanni Gabrieli’s writing for brass brilliantly captured Renaissance Venice in all its glittering pomp and elegance. Here, the National Brass Ensemble, made up of some of the country’s finest players, does splendid work with selections from Gabrieli’s Sacrae Symphoniae in an arrangement by Tim Higgins. John Williams’s breathless “Music for Brass,” a new work with more than a hint of “Star Wars” steel and sparkle, rounds out the program. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

A former Eagle scout, partner at CollegeHumor, and founder of Vimeo, the elegant online video platform, he was in between ventures, teaching entrepreneurship at the School of Visual Arts and spinning cycles, as he put it, while looking for land to buy — a lot of land — upon which he hoped to spend time building things and reconnecting to the scouting skills of his childhood.

At 450 West 14th Street. … The socially conscious jewelry brand AUrate New York is having a pop-up starting on Friday. For each piece of jewelry you buy, like a collar necklace in 18-karat gold over sterling silver ($550) and a diamond ear cuff in 18k gold and diamonds ($750), a book will be donated to an economically underprivileged child. At 154 Spring Spring.

headline: Review: ‘Finale’ by Thomas Mallon Moves Past ‘Watergate’ and Into the Reagan Era
abstract: The novel picks up in 1976, after Nixon’s long nightmare is over and Ronald Reagan is losing the Republican nomination to Gerald Ford.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Mallon’s latest historical novel, “Finale,” picks up effortlessly from his last. And “Watergate” (2012) is a tough act to follow. It’s a shockingly glamorous immersion in the Washington of the Nixon years, with a vast array of characters and a beautifully oblique way of maneuvering them. It makes no difference what knowledge of the Nixon presidency you bring to this marvel of a book. Mr. Mallon has found surprising perspectives from which to look at it and a way of siphoning emphasis away from the turf already trampled by historians. Only its deftly manipulative style keeps “Watergate” from being mistaken for nonfiction.

headline: Review: ‘Swan Lake’ Features an Authoritative Sara Mearns
abstract: This Peter Martins production of the Tchaikovsky ballet opened New York City Ballet’s fall season.
lead_paragraph: Sara Mearns, leading the first of four casts of “Swan Lake” and opening New York City Ballet’s four-week fall season at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday, has moved light years beyond the melodramatic clichés with which this ballet is usually saddled. The foolish “Black Swan” notion of this ballet makes Odette the good, passive victim and Odile the actively evil demon, while Prince Siegfried looks like a moron for thinking one could be the other. Ms. Mearns, however, interpreting the double role with completely authoritative individuality, makes both heroines arrestingly multilayered. Her Odette reveals a capacity for voluptuous passion within doomed captivity; her Odile is extraordinarily cool, enigmatic, even poignant, notwithstanding sweeping brilliance.

headline: Viola Davis Speaks About Her Emmy, Diversity and Women on TV
keywords: ['Emmy Awards', 'Women and Girls', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Television']
abstract: Ms. Davis talks about becoming the first African-American woman to win the leading dramatic actress category.
lead_paragraph: When Viola Davis accepted her Emmy Award for best actress in a drama on Sunday night, she was the first African-American woman to ever do so. Feeling the weight of that moment, Ms. Davis quoted Harriet Tubman (“But I can’t seem to get there no how. I can’t seem to get over that line”) and put it plainly to the television industry about the lack of opportunities for black women. “You cannot win an Emmy for roles that are simply not there,” she said.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Chinese fighter jet performed an unsafe maneuver last week while close to a United States spy plane, Defense Department officials said Wednesday. It is the second time in just over a year that the Pentagon has accused Chinese pilots of inflaming tensions.

headline: Review: In a New Work, Camille A. Brown Plays With Empowerment
abstract: Ms. Brown explores the roots of the black female identity by transporting her dancers and audience to the playground.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Camille A. Brown may be tiny, but her latest dance isn’t the least bit diminutive. In “Black Girl: Linguistic Play,” which opened the Joyce Theater’s fall season on a high note Tuesday, Ms. Brown explores black female identity by transporting her dancers and audience to the playground. On a multilevel stage of platforms and mirrors, she uses the games of childhood as a source of empowerment.

headline: Memories of Berra Well Up for Yankees Young and Old

lead_paragraph: TORONTO — One day in spring training about a decade ago, the Yankees’ clubhouse manager, Rob Cucuzza, came across Yogi Berra, who had plopped down in a chair. Cucuzza finally mustered the gumption to ask him a question.

keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Social Media', 'Kurds', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']

headline: Canada: Two Men Get Life Sentences in Plot to Derail Train From New York
abstract: Chiheb Esseghaier, 33, and Raed Jaser, 37, were convicted this year largely on the strength of secret recordings made by an F.B.I. agent.
lead_paragraph: Two men were sentenced Wednesday in Toronto to life in prison for plotting to derail a passenger train traveling from New York to Toronto and other terrorism-related charges. Chiheb Esseghaier, 33, and Raed Jaser, 37, were convicted this year largely on the strength of secret recordings made by an F.B.I. agent who posed as an Egyptian-American real estate developer with radical Islamist views. Mr. Esseghaier, who is from Montreal, had repeatedly said he would not participate in the trial because he recognized only the laws of the Quran. Two psychiatrists concluded that Mr. Esseghaier probably has schizophrenia but differed on whether he was fit to stand trial. But Justice Michael Code of the Ontario Superior Court found that the man was not delusional at the time of the plotting. The judge also rejected Mr. Jaser’s defense that he had been entrapped and played along with the agent only to get money to feed his drug addiction.

headline: Pilgrims Gather in Washington to See Pope Francis Canonize Junípero Serra

keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: A reporter and a photographer for The New York Times chronicle how volunteers in Dortmund cope with a torrent of asylum seekers arriving around the clock.
lead_paragraph: DORTMUND, Germany — The ramps and slopes of the skateboard hall are stacked with thousands of donated garments, all sorted into boxes by type and size. The bowling lanes are dormant. The concerts and dance classes are postponed. Nothing ordinary has been happening at the Dietrich Keuning Haus, a community center behind the main railway station, since Sept. 6.

headline: Discovery of Evidence Bag Adds Twist to Kane Case
abstract: A lawyer for the woman who has accused the Chicago Blackhawks star Patrick Kane of rape said the bag had been left on a doorstep, but the police said it wasn’t missing.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — A lawyer for the woman who has accused the Chicago Blackhawks star Patrick Kane of rape announced at a news conference Wednesday that a rape-kit evidence bag was left on the doorstep of the accuser’s mother Tuesday afternoon. But police officials quickly dismissed the claim as untrue, even as it raised new questions about the investigation in the increasingly bizarre case.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the war in Iraq deteriorated, a senior American intelligence analyst went public in 2005 and criticized President George W. Bush’s administration for pushing “amateurish and unrealistic” plans for the invasion two years before.

headline: North Carolina: 3-year-old Thrown Into Pond Dies
abstract: A 3-year-old girl who was thrown into a pond at an apartment complex by her father late Sunday died on Wednesday, the police in Durham, N.C., said.
lead_paragraph: A 3-year-old girl who was thrown into a pond at an apartment complex by her father late Sunday died on Wednesday, the police in Durham, N.C., said. The girl and two siblings were thrown into the pond by Alan Lassiter, 29, of Raleigh, the police said. The girl and her 5-year-old sister were pulled out alive. Their 7-year-old brother escaped on his own and sought help, the police said. The older girl was released from a hospital. Mr. Lassiter is being held in the Durham County jail on three charges of attempted murder, although one of the counts is expected to be upgraded to murder. He told a 911 dispatcher that he tried to drown his children because the child protection authorities were trying to take them away as he was seeking help for sexual feelings toward children, the police said.

lead_paragraph: Three police officers who fatally shot a rock-throwing Hispanic man in Pasco, Wash., did not violate department policies or procedures in the February encounter, according to the findings of an internal investigation released Wednesday.

headline: Player of the Year? Someone With the Initial ‘J.’
abstract: Golf’s equivalent of baseball’s Most Valuable Player Award is destined to go to Jordan Spieth or Jason Day. How much the FedEx Cup playoffs will factor in the voting remains to be seen.

headline: A Car Scandal Shoves Berlin Off High Ground
abstract: Germany, known as obedient to rules, finds its identity shaken as its claim to moral leadership of Europe has been tarnished after repeatedly urging other nations to welcome migrants.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As Germany has emerged as the dominant actor in Europe, it has lectured Greece and other debtor nations on the virtues of thrift and lately wagged its finger at countries that balk at receiving a share of refugees from the killing fields of Syria. Its right to lead, based on a narrative of self-sacrifice and obedience to rules, was generally acknowledged.

headline: As Europe Wrangles Over Migrant Relocation, Reality Moves Faster
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The situation on the ground is often very different from what is discussed in the conference rooms of Brussels as the tide of desperate people keeps flowing into Europe.
lead_paragraph: PIRAEUS, Greece — Amid the rancorous bickering this week by European leaders over a relocation plan to spread asylum seekers around the Continent, a Coast Guard officer stood on the dock here at Greece’s main port screaming a blunt command at a throng of rain-soaked new arrivals: Hurry up and relocate yourselves.

headline: New York’s Transportation Command Prepares for the Papal Disruptions
abstract: The officials at New York’s Joint Traffic Management Center have two messages about Pope Francis’ 36-hour whirlwind visit: Take mass transit, and they’re ready for anything.
lead_paragraph: Inside New York City’s bustling traffic command center in Queens, a mosaic of screens fills a long wall, broadcasting dozens of live feeds of vehicles moving about the city. Operators sit at monitors, scrolling through incident reports and updating electronic road signs to alert drivers to accidents.

He knew that figure because he keeps a running tally on his event memos, the inevitable conclusion informing every policy decision, adding a sense of urgency to every goal.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (ABC) GREY’S ANATOMY In this season premiere, the doctors confront their pasts while trying to save the lives of two girls who are victims of bullying. Meredith (Ellen Pompeo), meanwhile, adjusts to living with new roommates, and Bailey (Chandra Wilson) fights to become the chief of surgery. In “Scandal,” at 9, Olivia (Kerry Washington) and Fitz (Tony Goldwyn) revel in their relationship until a royal visit turns tragic. And in “How to Get Away With Murder,” at 10, Annalise (Viola Davis, fresh off an Emmy win for best lead actress in a drama series) and her students must move on as though nothing has happened in the wake of Rebecca’s disappearance. But only Annalise and Frank know that she was murdered, and they’re going to find out who did it. (Image: Ms. Pompeo)

headline: Young, Black, Female and Envisioning Corporate Life
abstract: In her series “Am I What You’re Looking For?,” Endia Beal questions what it means to be a young minority woman in the workplace.
lead_paragraph: Endia Beal is a North Carolina-based artist who uses photography and video to explore conversations about race and diversity in the corporate setting. Ms. Beal, 30, received her M.F.A. in photography from Yale Art School and currently works as an associate professor of photography at Winston-Salem State University and as director of the university’s Diggs Gallery. Her most notable portrait series, “Can I Touch It,” presents white women in corporate attire wearing traditionally black hairstyles. Earlier this year, Ms. Beal was one of 11 photographers to present their work at the National Geographic Photography Seminar.

headline: A Modest Step for the Refugees
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: A decision to distribute 120,000 asylum seekers has finally been made, but Europe’s unity is being sorely tested.
lead_paragraph: The European Union finally did the very least it could do on Tuesday and voted to distribute 120,000 asylum seekers among member nations. That will relieve some of the pressure on the frontline countries flooded by the unending flow of refugees from the Middle East and North Africa. But the long delay in taking even this modest step, and the bitter resistance of four Central European states, offer a graphic display of the grave threat posed by the crisis to the fundamental principles of the union.

I had no idea that anybody in Ohio outside my immediate neighborhood knew who he was.
