headline: Who Are Your Sports Heroes?

headline: Review: In ‘The Intern,’ She’s the Boss, but He’s the Star
abstract: Robert De Niro plays Ben, a gentle father figure who comes equipped with a laundered handkerchief, in Nancy Meyers’s latest film.
lead_paragraph: The director Nancy Meyers doesn’t just make movies, she makes the kind of lifestyle fantasies you sink into like eiderdown. Her movies are frothy, playful, homogeneous, routinely maddening and generally pretty irresistible even when they’re not all that good. Her most notable visual signature is the immaculate, luxuriously appointed interiors she’s known to fuss over personally — they inevitably feature throw pillows that look as if they’ve been arranged with a measuring tape. These interiors are fetishized by moviegoers and Architectural Digest alike, ready-made for Pinterest and comment threads peppered with questions like, “Where do I get that hat?”

headline: After Volkswagen Revelation, Auto Emissions Tests Come Under Global Scrutiny
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Air Pollution', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Questions are increasing about the wisdom of allowing carmakers to have so much influence on how air pollution standards are enforced.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, automakers conduct their own emissions tests and submit the results to the government. In Europe, automakers pick who conducts the tests and where they are done. And these two regulatory systems are considered the world’s gold standards.

headline: Combination Drug May Ease the Agitation of Alzheimer’s
abstract: A combination drug may be a safer way to treat agitation and aggression in people with Alzheimer’s.
lead_paragraph: Agitation and aggression are common in Alzheimer’s patients, and there is no known safe and effective treatment. Now researchers report that a combination drug already in use for treating certain neurological problems may be a better remedy.

abstract: The region in New York, a top destination for wine lovers, is home to 70 breweries, and 12 more are scheduled to open in the next few months.
lead_paragraph: The Finger Lakes in western New York State have long been a top destination for wine lovers, but the region is quickly becoming a haven for beer drinkers as well. It is home to 70 breweries, according to Finger Lakes Beer Trail, a local trade group, up from just 24 in 2011. Twelve more are scheduled to open in the next few months.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Secret Power
abstract: The justices should tell us more about why they pick the cases they choose to hear.
lead_paragraph: Stanford, Calif. — ON Monday, the Supreme Court will meet in private to perform one of its most consequential — yet least appreciated — functions: choosing the cases it will hear. The court’s nine justices hold regular conferences from late September to late June to perform this task. From the roughly 8,000 petitions that arrive at the court each year, the justices select about 75 cases. If four or more justices vote to take a case, it is added to the docket; otherwise, review is denied. Either way, an explanation for the court’s decision is almost never given, nor is it customary to indicate how the individual justices voted.

headline: A Husband’s Serious Illness Strengthens a Marriage

headline: ‘Empire’ and ‘black-ish’ Show Why Diversity Needs to Be Deep, Not Just Broad
abstract: Several of last season’s best new network shows featured minority lead characters. The change was long overdue, and just in time.
lead_paragraph: Last fall’s TV diversity revolution, in which several of the broadcast networks’ best new shows featured minority lead characters, was long overdue. It was also just in time. With racial controversies, especially those involving African-Americans, increasingly making headlines over the past year, it would have been that much more glaring if there were only lily-white TV families to answer back.

But in his main event, he will try to speak across the widening gap between party lines.

Often, the police say, the immigrants, many of whom have crossed the border illegally, try to make a run for it when the vehicle is stopped.

headline: 1940: Sipping Aperitif From a Teacup
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Partial prohibition forces France to get creative in 1940.
lead_paragraph: PARIS (via Berlin) — A bootleg and speakeasy industry that flourished in the United States during the dry era has made its appearance in France with the enforcement of partial prohibition. The new law throws a dry blanket on one of the gayest French customs — the aperitif hour. It fixes the alcoholic content of all drinks classed as aperitifs at not more than 16 per cent. The favourite dodge to get a drink of barred liquor is to enter a bar or cafe where you are known and order an ‘‘infusion,’’ which is the French word for herb tea. The bootleg drink is then served in a teacup. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 25, 1940

headline: Pulling Off Fendi’s Improperly Placed Eyeliner
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2015)', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Backstage, the makeup artist Peter Philips created a solid, clean foundation to allow one floating black streak to pop.
lead_paragraph: For Fendi’s spring/summer 2016 collection — inspired as much by the military as by romance — the makeup artist Peter Philips drafted a look based on notes from Karl Lagerfeld: purity, the sunlit branches of a tree, “a runaway Mormon girl.” Using Dior Star foundation, he evened the models’ skin tone and left the face mostly clean — no mascara or lipstick, and just a touch of pink blush — so that a graphic line above the eye, centered between the lashes and the eyebrow, stood out. The effect is especially dramatic when it catches the light, like the tree in Lagerfeld’s vision.

headline: 1965: Russia Proposes Treaty to U.N.
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Russia proposes a nonproliferation draft treaty to the United Nations in 1965.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. — Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko proposed to the UN General Assembly a draft treaty on the nonproliferation of nuclear weapons. If accepted, the treaty would block plans for a NATO multilateral nuclear force. The Russians rejected a similar treaty put forward by the United States and its allies at the recent unsuccessful session of the 17-nation Geneva disarmament talks. The Western proposal allowed for the formation of an allied multinuclear force that would have included West Germany and other nations that do not have nuclear weapons. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 25, 1965

Rich with familiar voices, it further cements their reputation as eager and willing collaborators. Here, they reflect on what it was like to record with a few famous friends.

headline: A Gay Muslim Filmmaker Goes Inside the Hajj
abstract: The filmmaker Parvez Sharma hopes that his new documentary, “A Sinner in Mecca,” will inspire questions among Muslims around the world. “Islam’s reformation is long overdue,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Arranging to meet the filmmaker Parvez Sharma is a little like setting up an appointment with an extremely polite spy. He asks to rendezvous in a public place — a Starbucks in SoHo where the noise level is high, the tables distant and the volume of customers great. His boundaries are clearly drawn: no discussion of his husband, his friends, his Manhattan neighborhood or his family. He arrives a half-hour early.

headline: Stephen Karam’s Plays Treat Anguish as a Laughing Matter
abstract: Mr. Karam, who specializes in agonizing comedies that are funnier than their subjects would indicate, has a new play, “The Humans,” that can also be viewed as a horror story.
lead_paragraph: The playwright Stephen Karam has short dark hair, bright dark eyes and a wide smile that occasionally overpowers the rest of his face like some sudden, bloodless coup. On a recent morning at a cafe near his Chinatown apartment in New York, he was eating a red pepper and spinach omelet, a brave attempt to add more vegetables to his diet. At 35, he still looks boyish, and when he talks about being a grown-up, it takes a few seconds to realize that he is actually talking about himself.

headline: Daily Fantasy Sports and the Hidden Cost of America’s Weird Gambling Laws
keywords: ['Fantasy Sports', 'Gambling', 'Contests and Prizes', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The same complexity and opacity that make daily fantasy sports legal also make it more likely that the casual fan will lose money.
lead_paragraph: Sports leagues in the United States, and the networks that broadcast their games, prefer to pretend that everyone watching their games does so for the pure love of competition, the occasional nonchalant reference to the gambling point spread by a football announcer notwithstanding.

headline: Sharing With Thy Restaurant Neighbor
abstract: Questions about when to share with a pushy dinner companion, autism, divulging guest lists and surly servers.
lead_paragraph: At the end of lunch at a nice restaurant, one of the two friends I was dining with noticed that the couple at the next table was leaving behind three-quarters of a yummy-looking dessert. She asked them for it, and they gladly handed it over. I laughed. Our other friend told me later that she was appalled. She said it reflected poorly on us, and was angry that I had laughed. I told her if it had been a nice bottle of wine, I may have asked myself. What’s your opinion?

headline: From Divorce, a Fractured Beauty (Updated With Podcast)
abstract: A recently divorced couple manages to have a happy family vacation.
lead_paragraph: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by the actress Molly Ringwald in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the “play” button below or subscribe on iTunes or Google Play Music.

headline: Sviatoslav Richter, Enigmatic Pianist, Playing With Contradictions
abstract: An 18-disc collection of his work, released on the centennial of his birth, offers a rich, exciting portrait of the Russian pianist.
lead_paragraph: After Stalin’s death in 1953, the Soviet Union lifted a bit of the Iron Curtain to allow some major midcareer Russian artists to make debuts in America. Among them were the violinist David Oistrakh and the pianist Emil Gilels, both in 1955. Notably missing was the towering pianist Sviatoslav Richter, an artist of, in the best sense, demonic powers, whose performances combined stunning technique, myriad colorings and fierce integrity. Every time Gilels was lavished with praise by musicians in America, he would offer thanks, then add, “Wait until you hear Richter!”

headline: A Cult Streetwear Brand Gets a Sleek Update
abstract: This week, the California brand Stüssy releases a special collaboration with the Swedish shop Très Bien.
lead_paragraph: For most kids growing up in the 1980s and ’90s, Stüssy was a beloved skater brand — the epitome of California cool. “For our generation, Stüssy, together with other U.S. brands like Nike, Levi’s and Champion, was the uniform at a certain age,” says Hannes Hogeman, who, along with his brother Simon, runs Très Bien, a Swedish store that sells men’s high fashion and streetwear. This Friday, the retailer will launch the Stüssy Très Bien collection, a special collaboration that offers, in the words of Hannes, a more “minimalistic take on street- and sportswear.” There are boxy T-shirts, oversize shorts and a coach jacket with the towns “Laguna” and “Malmö” written on the back (the hometowns of Shawn Stüssy and the Hogeman brothers in California and Sweden, respectively). The collection feels like Stüssy at heart — it features skater-inspired styles with a tinge of Scandinavian refinement thrown in. “The designs came effortlessly, to be honest,” Hannes says. “It was more about removing details, changing the cuts and adding some fabrics that you may not usually get from Stüssy.”

headline: Motherhood, Screened Off
abstract: The problem with smartphones isn’t their ubiquity. It’s their opacity.
lead_paragraph: My mother’s address book is one of the small visual details of my childhood that I can perfectly conjure, although I am sure no photograph of it exists. Fake-leather-bound, filled with her formal, spidery script, it was, to me, barely legible, with addresses crossed out and replaced with new ones as friends’ lives shifted. I often was dispatched to grab it for her from a kitchen drawer. I knew when she was looking for someone’s phone number, which seems unremarkable, except that my own children do not know when I am searching for a phone number, because all they see is me, on my iPhone, intently focused on something mysterious and decidedly not them.

Five years later, the network is premiering a sequel series, titled “Heroes Reborn.” While it’s possible to watch the series without having ever seen any episodes from its forerunner, “Heroes Reborn” assumes that viewers have some familiarity with a number of characters and concepts. abstract: These bottles convey the elemental aromas, flavors and emotions of appellations like Côte-Rôtie, Hermitage and Cornas, but in a more open, easier-going manner.
lead_paragraph: Some of the world’s greatest wines come from the northern Rhône Valley of France, from appellations like Côte-Rôtie, Hermitage and Cornas. These are wines that tell stories of devotion and arduous labor, and of the intimate human relationship over 2,000 years with grapevines and precipitous rocky hillsides, all brought to life with an almost savage expressiveness by the syrah grape.

headline: The Art Insider’s Guide to Stockholm
abstract: Saskia Neuman, Absolut’s global art manager, shares her favorite galleries, restaurants and bars in the up-and-coming art town.
lead_paragraph: “Stockholm, and what is typically Swedish, is changing,” says Saskia Neuman, a native of the city that’s lately seemed to churn out even more cultural heavyweights than it does tall, beautiful people. Before her days as Absolut’s global art manager, Neuman lived in London, Venice and Berlin — adding to her résumé stints as Hans Ulrich Obrist’s Girl Friday and Daniel Birnbaum’s exhibition coordinator for his Venice Biennale run — only to return home, where she’s now responsible for scouting worthy talent for the vodka label’s own art award. (This year’s winners, Frances Stark for artwork and Mark Godfrey for art writing, were feted this week.)

headline: In a New Group Show, Artists Look to the Sky
abstract: “Space Age,” at Galerie Thaddaeus Ropac Pantin, collects 30 works, some newly commissioned, on the topic spanning five decades.
lead_paragraph: Since space exploration has only existed for some 60 years, any artist working before 1950 would be unfamiliar with the visual vocabulary of rockets, shuttles and astronauts. So it follows that “Space Age,” the latest group show at Galerie Thaddaeus Ropac in Pantin, northeast of central Paris, is resolutely contemporary. The show’s 30 works, some newly commissioned, span five decades and offer a vast range of depictions, from a standing diptych by Robert Longo in which the Russian astronaut Valentina Tereshkova (the first woman in space) faces a starry abyss, to a duo of James Rosenquist canvases covered in galactic brightly colored geometries. The newer of his fractal works features a rotating mirror bordered with the words “an intrinsic existence”: selfie or self-reflection, take your pick. Whereas Not Vital’s stainless steel moon sucks viewers into its cratered, spherical surface, Lee Bull engulfs her suspended debris in fog.

headline: Review: Martha Armstrong’s Nature Scenes at Bowery Gallery
abstract: A plein-air painter in her mid-70s who trained at Smith College and the Rhode Island School of Design, she has worked for years in relative obscurity.
lead_paragraph: Painting from nature is nearly as old as the hills. For years, Alex Katz was the most prominent keeper of its flame, but other devotees have lately come into clearer view — Mr. Katz’s contemporary, the great Lois Dodd, for one. In addition, younger painters like Maureen Gallace and the even younger Daniel Heidkamp and Aliza Nisenbaum have wholeheartedly or partly followed suit. Painting from various forms of life has become a thing — as they say — in the hipper reaches of the contemporary art world.

headline: Review: In ‘Early Soviet Photography, Early Soviet Film,’ Artists Edit Reality to Fit an Ideal
abstract: The exhibition at the Jewish Museum demonstrates how avant-garde art was officially embraced as a natural complement to progressive politics.
lead_paragraph: Revolutions sell utopias; that’s their job. Art, if it behaves itself and sticks to the right script, can be an important part of the promotional package. This is the basic tale told by “The Power of Pictures: Early Soviet Photography, Early Soviet Film” at the Jewish Museum, but with a question added: What happens to art and its makers when the script is drastically revised?

headline: Arriving in Manhattan, Pope Tells Clergy to Serve Humbly
abstract: Francis spoke to hundreds of clergy at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in Manhattan on Thursday evening, after delivering a call to action in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In his first visit to New York City, the center of global finance and capitalism, Pope Francis used his remarks on Thursday evening to encourage the hundreds of clergy members, brothers and nuns gathered in St. Patrick’s Cathedral to live humbly and resist the temptation to treat their ministries as businesses, with success measured strictly by the bottom line.

headline: In ‘99 Homes,’ a Man Buffeted and Then Manipulated in Florida’s Foreclosure Disaster
abstract: Ramin Bahrani’s tale is on one level a fable about how impersonal economic forces shape individual destinies.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t get emotional about real estate.” That bit of wisdom — among the mantras shared by a predatory broker named Rick Carver — is both upheld and defied by “99 Homes,” Ramin Bahrani’s stunningly effective melodrama of flipped houses and mortgaged souls. While the film hardly endorses Rick’s coldblooded, dog-eat-dog view of the world, it is too cleareyed to oppose his ruthlessness with soft, easy appeals to sentiment. The foreclosed properties Rick acquires and resells may be repositories of hopes, dreams and family memories, but they’re also economic units, “boxes” to be emptied out, refilled and written down on a balance sheet. That’s a fact of life, and also a tragic contradiction.

abstract: This show at Asia Society showcases the astoundingly skillful work of goldsmiths in the Philippines hundreds of years before the Spanish colonizers arrived.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New York Students Prepare for a Special Visitor: Pope Francis
abstract: Tens of thousands of New Yorkers will try to glimpse the pope, but a select group of children from four Catholic schools will get their own private audience.
lead_paragraph: Essa Nahshal is a 7-year-old from Harlem with a neatly combed side part and a Pokemon obsession, but this week video games have to compete for his attention with an unlikely visitor: the pope.

headline: Excerpt: ‘The Player’
abstract: The new NBC show stars Wesley Snipes and Philip Winchester.
lead_paragraph: The new NBC show stars Wesley Snipes and Philip Winchester.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WELCOME TO BRAGGSVILLE, by T. Geronimo Johnson. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $14.99.) This biting satire, which our reviewer, Rich Benjamin, called “the funniest sendup of identity politics, the academy and white racial anxiety to hit the scene in years,” follows a callow white teenager who leaves small-town Georgia for college at Berkeley. Newly steeped in academic political correctness, he and his new friends travel back to his hometown to stage a “performative intervention” — a mock lynching — with calamitous results.

headline: A Sea of Geometric Patterns and Stripes at Prada
abstract: Scenes from backstage at the spring/summer collection.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from backstage at the spring/summer collection.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Heroes Reborn’
abstract: The new NBC series is a sequel to “Heroes,” which ran from 2006-2010.
lead_paragraph: The new NBC series is a sequel to “Heroes,” which ran from 2006-2010.

headline: Roland Emmerich on ‘Stonewall’
abstract: The director of “Stonewall” discusses his film.
lead_paragraph: The director of “Stonewall” discusses his film.

headline: Theater Listings for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Theater

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE COURT AND THE WORLD: American Law and the New Global Realities, by Stephen Breyer. (Knopf, $27.95.) The Supreme Court justice argues that American judges must increasingly understand and engage with foreign and international law.

headline: A Francis Effect for a Broken System
abstract: At its core, the pope’s message in Congress was how to live a life and share a planet. Simple. He didn’t scold, and he didn’t lecture.
lead_paragraph: The petty, the partisan, the hateful fell away — most of it. The bickering, the backbiting, the treachery was tamed — for now. No one shouted “You lie!” The powerful were made to look powerless. Words were used to uplift instead of to wound.

headline: Queer Tango Brings Its Liberated Style to New York
abstract: Tango has evolved: Men are dancing with men, women with women; women are leading and men are learning to follow.

headline: New Books Analyze the Photographs of Frederick Douglass and Sojourner Truth
abstract: Douglass and Truth, two of the most famous 19th-century African-Americans, commissioned formal works of themselves as part of their public relations strategies.

headline: Review: ‘Strangers Drowning’ Examines Extreme Do-Gooders
abstract: Larissa MacFarquhar profiles people whose self-sacrifice makes people uneasy and considers the issues surrounding deep ethical commitment.
lead_paragraph: In the introduction to his book “Class: A Guide Through the American Status System” (1983), Paul Fussell noted that he’d had trouble telling others what he was working on. Social class is a touchy subject. At parties, people edged away from him.

headline: Review: In ‘Tape,’ Performers Move Fluidly and Whimsically About a Grid
abstract: This work choreographed by Kenneth Kvarnstrom is set on a stage lined with duct tape and performed to live music played by Jonas Nordberg.
lead_paragraph: In craft circles, duct tape — in an array of patterns and colors — is all the rage. Slap it on a Ziploc bag and you have a dazzling neon zebra pouch. In “Tape” by Kenneth Kvarnstrom, a Finnish choreographer based in Sweden, the dancers use duct tape to create a grid of lines and squares on the stage. Alas, it’s just boring black, but Mr. Kvarnstrom’s idea of tape extends beyond the sticky stuff in this production.

headline: Moschino Goes to the Carwash
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2015)', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The house introduced a kitschy, upbeat spring collection — filled with thick-cut fringe and reflective detailing.
lead_paragraph: The house introduced a kitschy, upbeat spring collection — filled with thick-cut fringe and reflective detailing.

headline: Review: Adrián Villar Rojas Explores Space in New Show
abstract: The Argentine artist focuses more on sites than objects in “Two Suns,” his exhibition at the Marian Goodman Gallery.
lead_paragraph: Adrián Villar Rojas excels at site-specific works that oscillate among historical, symbolic and spatial effects. One brought him wide attention when he represented Argentina at the 2011 Venice Biennale. Since then, he has become a staple at these large international exhibitions. Working mostly in situ in cast concrete with a team of assistants, he may have single-handedly made a complement of “festivalist art,” originally a pejorative coined for the grandiose installations of such shows.

headline: David Nelson Exhibition Illuminates Evolution of His Work
abstract: Mr. Nelson’s art began to change, moving from painting to distinctive forms of sculpture and photography after his partner died in the early 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Biography isn’t necessarily destiny, but it seems to have played a role in the work of the wonderful artist David Nelson (1960-2013), as this show attests. He studied art in New York in the late 1970s and ’80s and began primarily as a painter. In 1990, he and his longtime partner, David Knudsvig, also an artist, tested positive for H.I.V. Mr. Knudsvig died of AIDS three years later, and Mr. Nelson’s art began to change, moving from painting to distinctive forms of sculpture and photography.

headline: Review: ‘Stonewall’ Doesn’t Distinguish Between Facts and Fiction
abstract: Roland Emmerich’s film wants to be as specific as possible in reconstructing the Stonewall riots, but it also wants to be sweeping social allegory.
lead_paragraph: “Stonewall,” Roland Emmerich’s would-be epic film about a turning point in the gay liberation movement in 1969, is far from the first historical movie to choke on its own noble intentions. For its two-hour-plus duration, the movie struggles to fuse incompatible concepts.

headline: Review: Trisha Baga Mixes Orlando, Fla., With ‘Orlando’
abstract: In her show at Greene Naftali, Ms. Baga presents ceramics, videos and portraits made from quinoa.
lead_paragraph: In her second solo show at this gallery, Trisha Baga cultivates the ambitious sprawl of media and narratives prominent in her double New York debut here and at the Whitney Museum in 2012. Her previous efforts coalesced into disorienting surrounds of video projections on walls and nearby objects, whose patchwork of subjects included the popular artsplainer Sister Wendy and Plymouth Rock. Her latest works keep the media more distinct, though not the themes.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Stonewall’
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Stonewall.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Stonewall.”

headline: Review: ‘The New Morality,’ a Vintage Play at the Mint
abstract: Harold Chapin’s work, directed by Jonathan Bank, is a comedy of marital ethics set in England.
lead_paragraph: In the third act of Harold Chapin’s “The New Morality,” a prewar artifact excavated by the Mint Theater Company, our heroine, Betty, prepares a late summer cocktail called a hock cup: She mixes white wine with maraschino liqueur, Cointreau, brandy and a whisper of soda water, muddling the lot with strawberries and cucumber. It’s a wonder audiences don’t rush the stage for a glass.

headline: Richard Prince Takes a New Approach to Cowboys
abstract: Richard Prince’s child cowboy is at Barbara Gladstone, and artists from McKee find new homes.
lead_paragraph: Richard Prince is circling back to familiar ground, on two counts, with the latest iteration of his cowboy theme, going on view on Saturday at the West 21st Street Chelsea gallery of Barbara Gladstone, who represented him from 1987 to 2008, when he left for Gagosian Gallery. This appears to be a rapprochement.

headline: Best of France (Ooh-La-La!) and Brooklyn’s Atlantic Antic
abstract: Best of France in Times Square offers a bit of everything for Francophiles. And the Atlantic Antic street festival shows off Brooklyn’s diversity.
lead_paragraph: France and Brooklyn, two capitals of culture revered for their gastronomy, ability to set trends and distinctive facial hair, will be on display this weekend at festivals around New York.

headline: Review: Met Opera’s ‘Turandot’ Reveals Layers of Humanity
abstract: Franco Zeffirelli’s production of “Turandot,” the Met’s gaudiest, shiniest comfort blanket, opened on Wednesday evening.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since the 2012–13 season, Franco Zeffirelli’s production of “Turandot” has been buffed up and sent out to draw the crowds at the Metropolitan Opera. Crowned by a thoughtful assumption of the title role by the soprano Christine Goerke, it opened with a solid performance and to a satisfied reception on Wednesday evening.

headline: When Shakespeare Is the Subject, Not the Scribe
abstract: In “Equivocation,” Shakespeare, called Shag here, faces a conundrum when King James I asks for him to write a play.
lead_paragraph: Shakespeare in love? How about Shakespeare in a jam?

headline: New York Film Festival Walks the Tightrope Between Art and Commerce
abstract: The selection committee seems to be promoting the idea that entries should be good cinema above all else, whether indies or from a big studio.
lead_paragraph: This year’s New York Film Festival opens with a couple of virtuosic balancing acts. One, “The Walk,” the latest from Robert Zemeckis, features Philippe Petit’s nosebleed stroll from one World Trade Center tower to its twin on Aug. 7, 1974. The other high-wire act is far less dangerous, but comes with its own hazards because it means pleasing constituencies as different as film society patrons and everyday cinephiles, critics who complain that it’s too elitist and those who sniff at the very idea of pleasurable, old-fashioned entertainment. It’s a tough trick, one the festival pulls off by putting a crowd-pleaser like Mr. Zemeckis alongside the rarefied likes of Chantal Akerman.

headline: Deutsche Bank Picks Goldman Executive as Bank and Insurance Adviser
abstract: Celeste Guth will co-head of the global financial institutions group beside Tadhg Flood.
lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank said on Thursday that it had hired a senior banker from Goldman Sachs to serve as one of its top advisers for banks and insurance companies.

headline: Pope Francis Arrives in New York
abstract: Francis arrived at Kennedy International Airport, where he was greeted by Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan.
lead_paragraph: Francis arrived at Kennedy International Airport, where he was greeted by Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan.

headline: Op-Photo: Making Way for Pope Francis
abstract: In advance of the pope’s visit to New York City, a truck blocked a street near St. Patrick’s Cathedral.
lead_paragraph: A truck filled with ballast blocked a street near St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York City on Thursday, in advance of Pope Francis’s visit.

headline: Jamie Barton, Opera’s Nose-Studded Rock Star, Returns to the Met
abstract: A leader of a new generation of opera stars, Ms. Barton caused a sensation two years ago at her last Metropolitan Opera appearance, and she returns in “Anna Bolena.”
lead_paragraph: Traditionalists don’t have to worry: Jamie Barton, the galvanizing young mezzo-soprano, will take out her silver nose stud before she takes the Metropolitan Opera stage on Saturday in Donizetti’s “Anna Bolena.” After all, it doesn’t exactly match the sumptuous Tudor costume she wears as the disloyal Jane Seymour in David McVicar’s moody production.

headline: Review: ‘Quantico’ Flips Between Jousting F.B.I. Recruits and a Terrorist Attack
abstract: With its roller-coaster plot reversals and amorous characters, this ABC drama evokes signature elements of Shonda Rhimes’s series even though it isn’t one.
lead_paragraph: Successful producers shape the TV business through the shows that they make. Monumental producers shape the TV business even through the shows that they don’t.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Intern’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Intern.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Intern.”

headline: José James Celebrates Billie Holiday at the Blue Note
abstract: José James pays tribute to Holiday in a celebration for what would have been her 100th birthday, at the Blue Note.
lead_paragraph: When a youngish jazz singer pays homage to a major precursor, you can usually brace yourself for a particular sort of pageantry: a dutiful nod to the time period, a guided tour of the repertory and especially a demonstration of influence, which often boils down to mannerism. José James is finding intriguing ways to tweak this formula in his tribute to Billie Holiday, which runs at the Blue Note through Sunday.

headline: Postal Service Failed to Protect Personal Data in Mail Surveillance, Report Says
keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Crime and Criminals', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Inspectors General']
abstract: Documents including names, addresses and financial information could have been compromised by the Postal Service’s mail cover surveillance program, an investigation found.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Employees of the United States Postal Service failed to properly safeguard documents that included the names, addresses and financial information used by its law enforcement arm to monitor the mail of people suspected of criminal activities or for national security purposes, an internal investigation found.

headline: Movie Review: ‘99 Homes’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “99 Homes.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “99 Homes.”

headline: With Ultrasound as Backdrop, Carly Fiorina Presses Attack on Planned Parenthood
abstract: In visiting a Christian pregnancy center, where she chatted with a woman having an ultrasound, Carly Fiorina was taking aim at Planned Parenthood, a favorite target of Republicans.
lead_paragraph: SPARTANBURG, S.C. — As the sound of a fetal heartbeat filled the ultrasound room at a Christian pregnancy center here, Carly Fiorina grasped the elbow of the young woman on the table.

headline: Robert Zemeckis, Master of Illusion, Returns
abstract: The director of “Forrest Gump” and “Back to the Future” is the subject of a MoMA retrospective, and his new movie plays the New York Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: This fall is the season of Robert Zemeckis, the 63-year-old Chicago-born writer-director who began making movies in the 1970s and changed American history, at least metaphorically, with his two huge hits “Back to the Future” (1985) and “Forrest Gump” (1994).

headline: Review: Trinity Restaurant, Italian Fare With Family’s Touch
abstract: Low-key fine dining has settled into the locale once home to Timothy’s, a campus legend at Trinity College in Hartford, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Some restaurants labor in the footsteps of legends. For decades, Timothy’s, just off the Trinity College campus in Hartford, served comfort food at bargain prices, winning a cadre of fiercely loyal customers. And while I still think of its successor, Trinity Restaurant, as a newcomer, it has been around for almost seven years now, offering the college and its mythical-sounding “Behind the Rocks” neighborhood a low-key, fine-dining option.

headline: For Nathaniel Dorsky and Jerome Hiler, Film Is the Star
abstract: Two filmmakers who long shunned publicity get a retrospective at the New York Film Festival titled “Luminous Intimacy.”
lead_paragraph: Every so often while watching the work of Nathaniel Dorsky, I let out a yelp of joy. Mr. Dorsky makes blissfully beautiful films that don’t tell stories but instead explore the world, the medium and our relationship with each. They’re short, averaging around 20 minutes, and visually dense, with layers of pulsing color, churning film grain, shifting light and mutating form. Their actors, as it were, are the objects, the flowers, trees, animals, people and cars that slip in and out of the frame, although it is film – fragile, alchemical, magical, lush and luminous – that is the star. Like the gold and silver used in illuminated manuscripts, film creates a radiant glow that suggests why Mr. Dorsky calls his art devotional cinema.

headline: Restaurant Review: Artaux Fine Foods Mixes Elegant and Homey
abstract: Diners at the Sea Cliff restaurant can eat in a shiny main room or a more intimate chef’s table in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Artaux Fine Foods in Sea Cliff offers creative and delicious food in two equally entertaining yet diverse settings.

headline: Volunteers, Many Once Refugees Themselves, Help as Guides in Vienna
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of', 'ARABIC LANGUAGE']
abstract: Dozens of Arabic-speaking Muslims are among the 2,000 or so volunteers in the Austrian capital helping migrants adjust to new lives.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — At the migration center in the east wing of the main train station here, Ragad al-Rachid, a petite 19-year-old psychology student and a Syrian Muslim, is immersed in the logistical details of helping dozens of people a day adjust to new lives in her adopted country.

headline: Pope Francis Visits: Day 6
abstract: Pope Francis traveled from Washington to New York. Here’s a roundup of the highlights on the sixth day of his trip to the United States and Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis traveled from Washington to New York. Here’s a roundup of the highlights on the sixth day of his trip to the United States and Cuba.

headline: Jafar Panahi, Iranian Filmmaker, Persists Despite a Ban
abstract: Mr. Panahi has made three movies since the government told him to stop. His latest, “Taxi,” is opening in New York after winning the top prize at Berlin.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — There’s a memorable scene in “Taxi,” the latest film by the Iranian dissident director Jafar Panahi, in which his vivacious, now 11-year-old niece recites the rules for making a movie in Iran. They include: Respect Islamic headscarves, avoid contact between men and women, avoid violence, avoid discussing political or economic issues, avoid “sordid realism.”

headline: Brian De Palma Explains Himself in ‘De Palma’
abstract: “De Palma,” a documentary by Jake Paltrow and Noah Baumbach at the New York Film Festival, lets Brian De Palma look back on his filmmaking career.
lead_paragraph: In the documentary “De Palma,” a special event of the New York Film Festival on Wednesday, Sept. 30, the 75-year-old director who is its subject gives a film-by-film account of a career that includes such box-office triumphs as “Carrie” and “The Untouchables,” as well as a disastrous screen adaptation of Tom Wolfe’s “The Bonfire of the Vanities.” The film, by Noah Baumbach and Jake Paltrow, covers Brian De Palma’s evolution from a high school science nerd to a Young Turk of Hollywood to a patriarch of sorts.

headline: Terror and Corruption Prosecutor Leaves for Private Sector
abstract: Jason P.W. Halperin, who won all of his 13 cases as an assistant United States attorney in the Southern District of New York, is joining a law firm.
lead_paragraph: For much of his 11-year career as an assistant United States attorney in the Southern District of New York, Jason P.W. Halperin straddled two worlds: public corruption and terrorism. He took 13 cases to trial and never lost one.

headline: Bridge Turkish & Mediterranean Grill Offers Reasons to Take Your Time
abstract: The Highland Park, N.J., restaurant excels at traditional Middle Eastern appetizers, with a special emphasis on treats from the owner’s native Turkey.
lead_paragraph: The usual array of Middle Eastern kebabs and falafel was being offered at Bridge Turkish & Mediterranean Grill in Highland Park, N.J., but I was looking for the Turkish stuff.

headline: 12 Indicted in Georgia in Crime Rings Run With Cellphones From Prisons
abstract: The indictments described cellphone smuggling operations that allowed inmates to conduct illegal business beyond the walls of state penitentiaries.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Twelve people were indicted this week on suspicion of having roles in crime rings that the authorities said relied on cellphones that were smuggled into Georgia prisons and allowed inmates to order killings, sell drugs to customers hundreds of miles away and try to steal identities.

headline: Central Park Fence for Pope Gets Strong Reactions
keywords: ['Security and Warning Systems', 'Fences and Property Barriers']
abstract: A few residents in the area said an eight-foot-tall temporary fence from West 59th Street to 81st Street was overkill for a brief papal visit on Friday.
lead_paragraph: For days Upper West Siders saw signs of the impending visit to Central Park by the pope. There were the vendors hawking I ♥ Pope Francis T-shirts at Columbus Circle, a parking ban along the lower half of Central Park West, the removal of Citi Bike rentals. But nothing prepared them for the fence.

headline: President Xi’s Double Talk on Doing Business in China
abstract: The Xi government has a long way to go in protecting the rights of foreign companies and fighting cybercrime.
lead_paragraph: At the start of his visit to the United States, President Xi Jinping of China sought to reassure American companies that his government was committed to protecting the interests of foreign companies and fighting cybercrime.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Saudi Arabia and Elsewhere
abstract: Pictures of the Day — Saudi Arabia and More
lead_paragraph: Pictures of the Day — Saudi Arabia and More

headline: Restaurant Review: Coming Home to Kelly’s Sea Level
abstract: You tend to want to linger in this establishment, which has been family-run for generations.
lead_paragraph: Jerry McGuire, the co-owner of Kelly’s Sea Level in Rye, says that one of the reasons people enjoy the place so much is that it’s “homey.”

headline: September 24, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Saudi Arabia, Greece, India and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Saudi Arabia, Greece, India and the United States.

headline: For the Philharmonic’s Opening Night, a New Name and a Big Gift
abstract: As the New York Philharmonic’s season began, the orchestra’s home was formally renamed David Geffen Hall and its chairman made a $25 million donation.
lead_paragraph: The opening of the New York Philharmonic’s 174th season on Thursday felt like the start of a new chapter, as the orchestra played for the first time in the newly rechristened David Geffen Hall and announced that it was getting the largest individual donation in its history: a $25 million gift from Oscar S. Schafer, the chairman of its board, and his wife, Didi.

headline: Review: The Good Old Tasteless Days in ‘Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead’
abstract: Douglas Tirola’s documentary about The National Lampoon brings back the 1970s, when “We’ll kill this dog” was an acceptable magazine cover line.
lead_paragraph: “Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of The National Lampoon” looks longingly back at the 1970s when a smart, tasteless joke could make you laugh out loud without worrying about hurting someone’s feelings or being attacked on social media. Hedonism was in full sway and political correctness in its infancy.

headline: In the Bronx, Photographing a Church for the Poor
abstract: For Ángel Franco, photographing religious experience in New York allows him to set aside his own beliefs as he immerses himself in rituals and relationships that sustain communities of faith.
lead_paragraph: For Ángel Franco, photographing religious experience in New York allows him to set aside his own beliefs as he immerses himself in rituals and relationships that sustain communities of faith.

headline: Pope Francis’ Homily at St. Patrick’s Cathedral
abstract: The English translation of Pope Francis’ homily during vespers at St. Patrick’s Cathedral, as released by the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: Following is the English translation of Pope Francis’ homily during vespers at St. Patrick’s Cathedral on Wednesday evening. His speech, delivered in Spanish, was prepared for delivery and released by the Vatican:

headline: Review: ‘Mississippi Grind’ Keeps Its Cards Close
abstract: Ryan Reynolds and Ben Mendelsohn star in this gambling movie from Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck, who refuse to chain themselves to the machinery of plot.
lead_paragraph: Even if you are not a sucker, as I am, for any movie about gambling with an American geographical reference in the title — “California Split,” “The Cincinnati Kid,” “Atlantic City” — you will find a lot to like about “Mississippi Grind,” a low-key road movie written and directed by Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck. Who can resist a soundtrack full of well-chosen blues and country-and-western songs, many of which offer further testimony to the place of cards, poker chips, dice and racehorses in our national mythology? There is also a cameo from James Toback, screenwriter of “The Gambler” (the good one, from 1974, with James Caan), and as such a kind of tutelary deity of long odds and risky bets.

headline: Review: ‘Finders Keepers’ Finds Humor and Humanity in the Bizarre
abstract: This custody battle between an amputee and the man who unwittingly bought his leg is as authentic as the North Carolina vernacular in which it unfolds.
lead_paragraph: An amputated leg leads everyone in a merry dance in “Finders Keepers,” the kind of documentary that makes you suspect that Christopher Guest is hiding behind the curtain. But this shockingly funny, weirdly touching custody battle between John Wood, the aggrieved amputee, and Shannon Whisnant, the fast-talking entrepreneur who unwittingly bought the appendage in a storage-unit auction, is as authentic as the North Carolina vernacular in which it unfolds.

headline: Elizabeth M. Fink, a Lawyer for Attica Inmates and Radicals, Dies at 70
abstract: Ms. Fink, a self-described revolutionary, represented criminals and radicals pro bono for more than four decades.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth M. Fink, a fiery advocate for society’s outcasts who devoted much of her law career to vindicating and compensating inmate victims of the 1971 Attica prison uprising, died on Tuesday in Brooklyn. She was 70.

headline: Israel Acts to Combat Violence in Jerusalem
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Rock and Stone', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Law and Legislation', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The security cabinet will ease some rules on police shooting and is proposing harsher sentences as it clamps down on Palestinians throwing rocks, firebombs and fireworks at Israeli citizens and soldiers.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s security cabinet approved a series of measures on Thursday as part of a crackdown on rock throwing and firebombing by Palestinians in Jerusalem, including minimum sentences and greater leeway for the police to open fire — steps that opponents say contravene basic legal principles and may only escalate the violence.

headline: Police Program Aims to Pinpoint Those Most Likely to Commit Crimes
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Police', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Racial Profiling']
abstract: As Kansas City, Mo., and other cities turn to “predictive policing” to prevent violent offenses, civil rights advocates worry about profiling abuses.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — At the request of his probation officer, Tyrone C. Brown came to a community auditorium here in June and sat alongside about 30 other mostly young black men with criminal records — men who were being watched closely by the police, just as he was.

headline: Review: ‘Mission to Lars’ Follows Siblings’ Quest to Fulfill Their Disabled Brother’s Dream
abstract: This documentary focuses on a man with fragile X syndrome whose lifelong wish has been to meet Lars Ulrich, the drummer for Metallica.
lead_paragraph: Documentaries about disabilities don’t come any smarter or more touching than “Mission to Lars,” a beautiful sibling road trip tale with a heavy-metal flourish.

headline: Saudis Seek to Fend Off U.N. Inquiry on Yemen
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations']
abstract: The Netherlands and some Western countries want the United Nations high commissioner for human rights to investigate abuses in the Yemeni war.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — As Saudi Arabia and its Arab allies pressed their military offensive against Houthi rebels in Yemen, Saudi diplomats were waging their own battle to fend off calls in the United Nations Human Rights Council for an international inquiry into abuses by all parties to the Yemeni conflict.

headline: Review: ‘A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story,’ One Woman’s Push for Acceptance
abstract: Sara Hirsh Bordo, directing her first feature, keeps the scenes bright and fast-moving, but several important topics about Ms. Velasquez are are barely addressed.
lead_paragraph: The makers of “A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story” leave a few too many questions unanswered, but their subject’s immense optimism steamrolls through the documentary’s shortcomings. Indeed, there seems to be little this woman can’t vanquish.

headline: Review: ‘Western’ Chronicles Borderland Traditions, Both Charming and Violent
abstract: The documentary by Bill and Turner Ross is a vivid ground-level tour of the reality unfolding on the border between the United States and Mexico.
lead_paragraph: As TV and movies make abundantly clear, the western has evolved, the genre now updated as a setting for wars among murderous drug cartels and police agencies (the latest exhibit: “Sicario”).

headline: Aide Recants Ordering Attack on Texas Referee
abstract: Officials from a San Antonio high school said an assistant football coach admitted ordering what became an infamous attack but then denied it, saying he had been trying to protect players.
lead_paragraph: A high school football assistant coach told his supervisors that he had ordered the attack on a Texas referee that has been seen by millions, but later recanted, saying that he had taken the blame to protect the players who delivered the blows, school officials said Thursday.

headline: A Confluence of Big Events for 3 Faiths
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Holy days for Jews and Muslims and the arrival of Pope Francis have brought an opportunity to showcase another side of New York City.
lead_paragraph: For Tony Carnes, editor and publisher of the web magazine A Journey Through NYC Religions, this week is like a “World Series,” he said. Or, offering another metaphor, he said, “It’s like the sun and the moon creating a high tide.”

headline: Iraq: Yazidis Turn to International Court
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The court’s current chief prosecutor said because those countries have not joined the court, it has no jurisdiction over matters that take place in Syria or Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Members of Iraq’s Yazidi minority on Thursday urged the International Criminal Court to investigate accusations of atrocities committed by militants of the Islamic State, which they said constituted genocide against their people. Murad Ismael, a member of the delegation, said the Free Yezidi Foundation and the Yazda group handed court prosecutors a report with accounts of killings, abductions of women and children, sexual enslavement and the destruction of religious sites. Luis Moreno Ocampo, the court’s former chief prosecutor, served as the group’s “legal and strategic adviser,” Mr. Ismael said. Fatou Bensouda, the court’s current chief prosecutor, has condemned crimes by Islamic State militants in Syria and Iraq, but she has said that because those countries have not joined the court, it has no jurisdiction over matters that take place in Syria or Iraq. But Mr. Ismael said the involvement of Islamic State militants from countries that are court members, including Tunisia, Georgia and Australia, in such critical roles as training, fund-raising or organizing crimes against Yazidi women and girls might allow the court to proceed with an investigation.

headline: Review: ‘Wildlike’ Pits a Teenage Girl Against the Alaskan Wilderness
abstract: Frank Hall Green’s film stars Ella Purnell as a 14-year-old escaping a sexually abusive uncle, and Bruce Greenwood as a backpacker who helps.
lead_paragraph: In “Wildlike,” Mackenzie (Ella Purnell), a 14-year-old from Seattle whose father has died and whose mother is in rehab, is sent to live with her uncle in Alaska for the summer. But when the creep starts molesting her, she runs away, alone and desperate in strange if beautiful country. Scrambling to stay ahead of her uncle, Mackenzie eventually attaches to Bartlett (Bruce Greenwood), a middle-aged backpacker headed to Denali National Park, in the unspoken hope that he’ll help her get home.

headline: Antiquities Still at Risk, Experts Warn
abstract: All six Unesco World Heritage sites in Syria had been damaged in that country’s war, including the most recent destruction in the ancient city of Palmyra.
lead_paragraph: The pillaging of antiquities by Islamic State militants is thriving in Syria and Iraq despite efforts to counter it, Middle East officials and archaeological experts  said Thursday at a conference on the illicit trafficking of artifacts. Irina Bokova, the director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, said all six Unesco World Heritage sites in Syria had been damaged in that country’s war, including the most recent destruction in the ancient city of Palmyra. “Culture has always been a victim of war, but what we’re seeing today is new,” Ms. Bokova said at the Asia Society in New York.

headline: Review: In ‘The Green Inferno,’ Eli Roth Turns Collegians Into Prey
abstract: This film, set in the Peruvian Amazon, revisits the cannibal subgenre whose heyday was in the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: It’s a homage written in blood. It’s an excursion into the forbidden land of unpalatable ideas, with the severed limbs and disemboweled bodies of idealistic young college students serving as signposts.

headline: Review: ‘Lost in Hong Kong’ Is Part Music Video, Part Buddy Film
abstract: Xu Zheng directs and stars in this comedy about a former art student who seeks to shed his brother-in-law so he can reunite with a woman from his past.
lead_paragraph: “Lost in Hong Kong” is a very, very, very, long-feeling movie with identity problems: At times it seems like an extended, sappy pop-music video; at others, a buddy film, with no love lost between the buddies. An unresolved love lies at the center, and a tacked-on homicide unreels into an irrelevant side plot. Perhaps because it tries too hard to be too many things, the movie loses its punch.

headline: Alabama Vote Is Rare Win in the South for the U.A.W.
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Automobiles', 'Income Inequality', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Employees cited low wages, worsening benefits and the growing use of temporary workers as reasons they voted to join the United Automobile Workers union.
lead_paragraph: When the results of a vote to join the United Automobile Workers union was announced late Wednesday at the Commercial Vehicle Group (C.V.G.) in Piedmont, Ala., the “hollering and whooping” echoed throughout the plant, said Alan Amos, a welder there.

headline: Review: In ‘Misunderstood,’ a Girl Seeks Relief From a Turbulent Household
abstract: Asia Argento’s somewhat autobiographical film wavers between realism and surrealism.
lead_paragraph: “Misunderstood,” a buoyantly funny, sometimes desperately sad film about a child searching for love and home, could easily be titled “The Girl, Her Bag and Her Beautiful Cat.” These three are the film’s holy trinity and its defining image, one that is almost Chaplinesque in its graphic clarity and emotional punch. The director, Asia Argento, has a finely tuned sense of the absurd, but isn’t afraid of tears. This may be because she once shared the name of the 9-year-old girl, Aria, who observes this turbulent world as if it were a drama she might one day stage.

headline: Sharp Drop in Currency Adds to Growing List of Woes in Brazil
keywords: ['Currency', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Foreign Investments', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'US Dollar (Currency)']
abstract: The weakness in the real is causing companies to delay plans, and the market for initial public offerings has been effectively frozen.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Since it was created in 1994, the Brazilian currency, the real, has been synonymous with the country’s return to financial stability and its subsequent ascent as an economic power.

headline: Pomp and Prayers in New York
abstract: After arriving from Washington in the middle of his six-day trip to the United States, Pope Francis attended a prayer service at St. Patrick’s Cathedral.
lead_paragraph: After arriving from Washington in the middle of his six-day trip to the United States, Pope Francis attended a prayer service at St. Patrick’s Cathedral.

headline: Bernie Sanders Eclipses Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire Poll
abstract: The new poll found that even if Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. entered the race, he would not garner nearly enough support to win or change the dynamic of the race
lead_paragraph: As summer turned to fall, a chilly wind was blowing in New Hampshire for Hillary Rodham Clinton: A new poll on Thursday showed Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont surging ahead of Mrs. Clinton with 46 percent of the vote to 30 percent for her.

headline: Port Authority Remains Divided on Plan to Replace Manhattan Bus Terminal
abstract: The agency agreed that the worn-down, 65-year-old depot in Midtown Manhattan must be replaced, but there was a lack of consensus on how to do it.
lead_paragraph: Two years after starting to plan for the replacement of the main bus terminal in Manhattan, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey still does not have a plan, its appointed leaders admitted on Thursday.

headline: In Lunch for the Homeless, a Sacred Mission for Pope Francis
abstract: Francis is using his celebrity to compel the cameras to show Americans a picture some might rather ignore: In Washington, he met the homeless.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The residents of the Harriet Tubman Women’s Shelter rose at 3 a.m. on Thursday to give everyone time to shower, fix their hair and get dressed in the best clothes they had after years on and off the streets, coping with evictions, abuse and jobs that disappeared.

headline: Tensions Build as M.T.A. Chief Keeps Pressing New York City for More Money
abstract: Thomas F. Prendergast, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has repeatedly called on the city to increase its contribution toward capital projects by more than $2 billion.
lead_paragraph: A year after the Metropolitan Transportation Authority unveiled a capital plan to address the system’s deteriorating infrastructure and increasing ridership, the chairman of the agency has grown increasingly combative toward New York City, faulting the mayor for not assuming more of the $29 billion proposal’s costs.

headline: Review: At Hartford Stage, Expectations of Love and the Weight of Memory in ‘An Opening in Time’
abstract: Two people who almost had an affair 20 years ago have another chance in Christopher Shinn’s play at Hartford Stage.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — Though fall has only just begun according to the calendar, it is nearing its end at Hartford Stage, and winter is coming on fast. The mortal chill of waning days and lengthening nights pervades “An Opening in Time,” the anxiously wistful new play by Christopher Shinn that runs here through Oct. 11.

headline: Darrelle Revis and Two Other Top Jets May Miss Game Against Eagles
abstract: As the Jets try to defeat the Philadelphia Eagles for the first time in franchise history on Sunday, they may be without some prominent players, including cornerback Darrelle Revis.
lead_paragraph: The Jets could be without some prominent players Sunday when they try to defeat the Philadelphia Eagles for the first time in franchise history.

headline: Review: In ‘Sleepless in New York,’ the Misery of the Lovelorn
abstract: This documentary introduces three city dwellers who are reeling from breakups, with general commentary on lovesickness from a biological anthropologist.
lead_paragraph: Cinema may be fluent in the language of romance, but breakups are another, excruciating story, and Christian Frei is happy to chronicle them in “Sleepless in New York.” Following three lovelorn city dwellers over an extended period, Mr. Frei’s raw documentary plumbs the soul-searching, pain and dark, obsessive thoughts that afflict these victims of lost love.

headline: Review: In ‘Hotel Transylvania 2,’ Dracula Yearns for a Little Monster of a Grandson
abstract: In this sequel, Dracula’s daughter has married a human and begotten a son, and her father worries that the boy may not be vampirish enough.
lead_paragraph: In the 2012 animated picture “Hotel Transylvania,” the comedy stalwart Adam Sandler voiced a Dracula who juggled concerns over his troubled spooky-lodging business with concerns over losing his vampire daughter, Mavis, to the outside world. Mr. Sandler’s cronies and frequent co-stars in live-action movies voiced Dracula’s classic-monster cohort. As a homage to beloved old-movie myths, it fell into the “each man kills the thing he loves” category of tribute, setting a level of sacrilege so high that its sequel, “Hotel Transylvania 2,” directed by the returning Genndy Tartakovsky, is more tolerable simply by dint of inoculation.

headline: Robert Streb, Tortoise Among Hares, Stands Out as PGA Tour Finale Begins
abstract: At a time when headliners are wunderkinds like Jordan Spieth and Rory McIlroy, Streb stands out for spending two years on the mini-tours and another on the Web.com Tour before reaching golf’s main stage.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Two players from a youth traveling hockey team in Oklahoma in the late 1990s grew up to be professional athletes. Even more mind-boggling, the first one to grace the playoffs in his sport was not Sam Bradford, the Philadelphia Eagles quarterback drafted by the St. Louis Rams with the No. 1 pick in 2010.

headline: Review: In ‘The Keeping Room,’ 3 Women Under Siege in the Civil War
abstract: The British director Daniel Barber labors to impress in this Southern period thriller with two Union soldiers preying on two sisters and a slave.
lead_paragraph: The ravages of the Civil War shouldn’t require much jazzing up for the movies, but the British director Daniel Barber labors to impress with his Southern period thriller “The Keeping Room.”

headline: Daniel Levins, Dancer in Classical Ballet and Films, Dies at 61
abstract: Mr. Levins joined Eliot Feld’s American Ballet Company as a teenager, was a principal at American Ballet Theater and had a memorable role in ‘The Turning Point.’
lead_paragraph: Daniel Levins, a dancer sometimes known professionally as Daniel Levans, who gained notice as a teenager in Eliot Feld’s acclaimed American Ballet Company and as a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater in the 1970s, died on Sept. 15 in Brooklyn. He was 61.

headline: Document Signed by Hillary Clinton in 2012 Regarding Huma Abedin’s New Job
abstract: The document, part of a process by which Huma Abedin, an aide to Hillary Rodham Clinton, became a special government employee at the State Department, describes Ms. Abedin’s new title as “senior advisor.”
lead_paragraph: The document, part of a process by which Huma Abedin, an aide to Hillary Rodham Clinton, became a special government employee at the State Department, describes Ms. Abedin’s new title as “senior advisor.”

headline: Where Hercules Slew the Lion
abstract: Friday fun with James Mulhern.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I was of two minds about this puzzle.

headline: Hillary Clinton Personally Signed Off on Job Change for Huma Abedin
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton was directly involved in arranging a new government position for a top aide that allowed the aide to begin working for a private consulting firm while remaining at the State Department, according to documents released on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Update: According to a document obtained by The New York Times, the certification of a new employment position for one of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s senior aides at the State Department was signed by Mrs. Clinton’s then chief of staff, Cheryl D. Mills, who was authorized to sign such documents for Mrs. Clinton.

headline: Review: In ‘Pay the Ghost,’ Nicolas Cage Is on a Mission
abstract: In this film, Mr. Cage’s character searches for his son after the boy is abducted at a Halloween carnival.
lead_paragraph: Good actors making poor choices — especially when the actor is Nicolas Cage — is nothing new, but I worry that the dross in his career ledger is rapidly outpacing the gold. A compellingly idiosyncratic performer, he has languished too long in movies unworthy of his commitment and with no room for the seat-of-the-pants improvisations that make him so riveting.

headline: Review: ‘Becoming Bulletproof’ Follows a Group of Disabled Adults in a Film Within a Film
abstract: Besides the usual ordeals of moviemaking — missed lines, bad cues — Michael Barnett, the documentary’s director, looked at the cast and crew’s friendships and struggles.
lead_paragraph: The film inside the film seems a bit slapdash. But that’s the only false note in “Becoming Bulletproof,” a wonderful documentary that follows a group of disabled adults who work together to make a movie.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Sept. 25
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include Pope Francis, the New York Military Academy and filming of “Gotham” in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include Pope Francis, the New York Military Academy and filming of “Gotham” in the Bronx.

headline: Review: ‘Ashby’ Pairs a Retired C.I.A. Killer With a High School Nerd
abstract: Mickey Rourke stars as the former assassin and Nat Wolff as the student who wants to hear his life story in this semicomic film from Tony McNamara.
lead_paragraph: Mickey Rourke, who plays the title character in “Ashby,” is a bizarre sight in this overstuffed semicomedy, which has no idea what it wants to say. In his towering gray pompadour, Ashby suggests a vain, surgically altered Mafioso relocated to Virginia through the witness protection program. In fact, Ashby is something even more exotic: a retired C.I.A. assassin who by his own account killed 93 people in the line of duty. Is he a heroic patriot or a sociopath? The movie doesn’t dare ask, but Mr. Rourke’s gruff, sentimental performance suggests a little of both, tilting toward patriot.

headline: An Email on Libya Sent to Hillary Clinton
abstract: This April 2011 email is among those that are being reviewed by F.B.I investigators to determine if aides of Hillary Rodham Clinton mishandled sensitive national security information when communicating with her via email while she was secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: This April 2011 email is among those that are being reviewed by F.B.I investigators to determine if aides of Hillary Rodham Clinton mishandled sensitive national security information when communicating with her via email while she was secretary of state.

headline: Hillary Clinton Email Inquiry Weighs if Aides Erred at ‘Send’
abstract: An investigation raises complex questions about whether State Department officials broke laws or rules by sending information to Mrs. Clinton’s personal email account.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The email described a deteriorating situation in Libya, with snipers shooting people in the streets as rebels tried to unseat President Muammar el-Qaddafi and worried American diplomats in the midst of a “phased checkout” from Benghazi. It arrived in the private email account of Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, one Sunday morning in April 2011, with unforeseen consequences.

headline: Jazz Listings for Sept. 25-Oct. 1
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.★ Barry Altschul and the 3dom Factor (Saturday) Mr. Altschul, a drummer of deep experience in the post-1960s avant-garde, has a new album, “Tales of the Unforeseen,” with the excellent trio he calls 3dom Factor. Featuring the saxophonist Jon Irabagon and the bassist Joe Fonda, it’s a tough, elastic band that moves in and out of phase. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, Greenwich Village; 212-989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com. (Nate Chinen)

headline: Bronx District Attorney and Judge May Trade Roles
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Elections, District Attorneys']
abstract: Delegates at a judicial nominating convention voted unanimously to give Robert T. Johnson the nod for an open Supreme Court position.
lead_paragraph: Bronx Democratic power brokers executed a series of political moves on Thursday night, nominating District Attorney Robert T. Johnson for a judgeship and giving his spot on the November ballot to Justice Darcel D. Clark of the state appellate court.

headline: Teaser Trailer: ‘Freedom for the Wolf’
abstract: “Freedom for the Wolf” is a new documentary directed by Rupert Russell about the rise of “illiberal democracy.”
lead_paragraph: “Freedom for the Wolf” is a new documentary directed by Rupert Russell about the rise of “illiberal democracy.”

headline: Hitting the Road, the Mets Regain Their Focus and Widen Their Lead
abstract: The Mets’ offense pounded the Reds for 12 hits and six runs, and overcame a so-so start from Steven Matz to win, 6-4, on Thursday and take another step toward clinching the National League East.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — In the third inning, Daniel Murphy was racing toward home plate so fast and with such determination that when he slid in safely, his foot clipped the Reds’ catcher, and Murphy spun several feet past the base. Through all the commotion, Murphy missed the umpire’s call. When he looked up, a bit disoriented, he flung himself back toward the plate to make sure he had scored.

headline: With One Swing, Yankees Solve Left-Handed Riddle of Chris Sale
abstract: Thanks to Carlos Beltran’s three-run homer, the Yankees inflicted enough damage against the White Sox ace Sale, a dominant left-hander, to defeat the team, 3-2.
lead_paragraph: On the strength of Carlos Beltran’s three-run homer, the Yankees kept alive their hopes of winning the American League East as they defeated the Chicago White Sox, 3-2, at Yankee Stadium on Thursday.

headline: Bill Proposed to Give Regulatory Protection to Puerto Rico Mutual Fund Investors
abstract: Nydia M. Velázquez, Democrat of New York, is expected to introduce an amendment to the Investment Company Act of 1940.
lead_paragraph: Seventy-five years ago, when the federal government set out to regulate mutual funds, investment firms in Puerto Rico were deemed too far off the beaten track to merit scrutiny. So mutual funds on the island, and other United States territories, were excluded from regulation under the Investment Company Act of 1940.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | ragamuffin
abstract: This word has appeared in eight New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: ragamuffin • \ˈra-gə-ˌmə-fən\ • noun

headline: Giants Build a Fourth-Quarter Lead, and Win Nonetheless
abstract: The Giants, who squandered big leads in losing their first two games, pulled away from the Redskins with a late 30-yard touchdown catch by Odell Beckham Jr.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Entering the fourth quarter Thursday night, the Giants led the Washington Redskins by 12 points. The home crowd at MetLife Stadium would have been forgiven for feeling a sense of dread.

headline: What’s on Television Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 3 P.M. (FXX) FLIGHT (2012) It’s hard to take your eyes off Denzel Washington as Whip Whitaker, a crack airline pilot who manages to land a plane — at one point flying it upside down — after catastrophe strikes during a storm in this thriller from Robert Zemeckis. But Whip’s life takes a nose dive when an inquiry reveals his lust for drinking and drugs, and suggests that he may not have been sober during his heroic feat. “He’s high as a kite, and you may be, too, lifted by the contact high that great filmmaking gives you,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. She added: “It’s no surprise that ‘Flight’ has salvation in mind. The shock is how deep Mr. Zemeckis and Mr. Washington journey into the abyss and how long they stay there. It can be tough for stars to play such unrepentantly compromised characters, as Mr. Washington does brilliantly here.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for September 25, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “I ask you all, please, to pray for me, and if there are among you any who do not believe or cannot pray, I ask you please to send good wishes my way.”

headline: Corrections: September 25, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, September 25, 2015.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Jeb Bush Says Hope, Not ‘Free Stuff,’ Will Draw Black Voters
abstract: A message of “aspiration and hope” will attract more African-American support than offers of “free stuff,” Jeb Bush said in South Carolina, echoing a contentious phrase from Mitt Romney’s 2012 campaign.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush told a crowd in South Carolina on Thursday that Republicans could attract more African-Americans with a message of “hope and aspiration,” and not with promises of “free stuff” — a phrase that echoed comments made by Mitt Romney during and after his 2012 bid for president.
