headline: Dewey, Cheatem & Howe
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Consumer Protection', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Recent cases of disturbing business practices underscore the need for good regulation, which is at stake in next year’s election.
lead_paragraph: Item: The C.E.O. of Volkswagen has resigned after revelations that his company committed fraud on an epic scale, installing software on its diesel cars that detected when their emissions were being tested, and produced deceptively low results.

headline: Fairness for Franchise Businesses and Workers
abstract: Franchise owners have lost ground in dealing with their businesses’ corporate parents, which in turn makes it harder to raise worker pay.
lead_paragraph: In California today, nearly 83,000 fast-food restaurants, convenience stores and other franchise businesses generate $94 billion in annual revenue and employ almost one million people.

headline: Even in Jail, I Will Fight for a Free Venezuela
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Politics and Government', 'Elections']
abstract: International observers must ensure fair elections in December.
lead_paragraph: RAMO VERDE PRISON, Venezuela — ON Feb. 12, 2014, the repressive and inept elite that governs Venezuela ordered my arrest on charges of conspiracy, arson, inciting violence, damage to public property and other crimes. Later that week, after two surprise visits from the president of the National Assembly to my family’s home, it was suggested to me that I should seek refuge in a foreign embassy.

headline: The American Idea and Today’s G.O.P.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: American exceptionalism is built on immigration, not threatened by it, as most Republicans believe.
lead_paragraph: America was settled, founded and built by people who believed they were doing something exceptional. Other nations were defined by their history, but America was defined by its future, by the people who weren’t yet here and by the greatness that hadn’t yet been achieved.

headline: Opening City Hall’s Wallets to Innovation
abstract: Cities are challenging a wide range of companies to imagine new ways to solve local problems, rather than just inviting familiar contractors to bid on brain-dead repair jobs.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, the city of San Francisco decided to upgrade its streetlights.

headline: Pope Francis to Address U.N.’s Largest Gathering of World Leaders
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Global Warming', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Pope Francis may give world leaders a moral flogging at the United Nations General Assembly before a global summit meeting on Syria, climate change and refugees.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — It will be the largest gathering of presidents and prime ministers ever at the United Nations. Some of them will assemble here under one roof for the first time in years, and their job will be to wrestle with global crises that they stubbornly disagree on, including climate change, the war in Syria, and a historic exodus of people fleeing conflict and hunger.

headline: News Q’s | Hajj Stampede Near Mecca Leaves Over 700 Dead
abstract: Why are some critical of the Saudi government for the way it has developed Mecca and managed the hajj?
lead_paragraph: Before Reading ‘Hajj Stampede Near Mecca Leaves Over 700 Dead’

headline: Hong Kong’s Umbrella Revolution: One Year Later
abstract: A year later, the people of Hong Kong are still debating the pro-democracy demonstrations that roiled the city for weeks.
lead_paragraph: Read in Chinese | 点击查看本文中文版

headline: The Stress of New Construction
abstract: As hammers clang and views vanish, not everybody is embracing development.
lead_paragraph: A block without construction seems to be the exception rather than the rule these days, as scaffolding, sidewalk sheds and tall cranes have become almost as common a sight as pigeons on the streets of New York.

headline: S.E.C. Turns Its Eye to Hidden Fees in Mutual Funds
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Financial Planners', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: First Eagle Investment Management reached an agreement with the S.E.C., and it might just be the start of the commission’s crackdown on fund companies’ hidden fees.
lead_paragraph: As regulators have ramped up their scrutiny of private equity practices in recent years, investors have learned a lot about hidden — and dubious — fees they are paying.

headline: How to Ask for Forgiveness, in Four Steps
abstract: Every week, our news feeds fill with someone or other asking for forgiveness. Here is how to do it.
lead_paragraph: On a weekday evening in early September, more than 400 people, from their late teens to their early 80s, crowded into a standing-room-only event on Manhattan’s Upper West Side. The topic was not politics, film, fashion, celebrity or any other subject that could be expected to draw such a crowd. The topic was forgiveness. Sitting in the audience, I was wondering why so many people had turned out, when suddenly: an electrifying moment.

headline: Pope Francis, in New York, Takes On Extremism and Inequality
abstract: The pope, who was met by adoring crowds at every stop in New York, capped his electric visit by celebrating a Mass at Madison Square Garden on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: By motorcade and popemobile and simple shoe leather, in a daylong tour up and down Manhattan that found pockets of joy and pain, wealth and want, Pope Francis on Friday called for social justice and peace in addresses to world leaders and workaday New Yorkers alike. He ended with a stirring homily that was both an ode to the city and a reminder to watch for glimpses of the presence of God among the poorest of the poor.

headline: Are Paper Books Better Than E-Books?
abstract: Do paper books offer a richer, more satisfying reading experience because you can physically hold them and turn the pages?
lead_paragraph: Analysts once predicted that e-books would overtake print by 2015. After all, they’re lighter to pack on a trip; they don’t clutter shelves; they don’t weigh down backpacks. Yet, e-book sales have slipped lately, and there are signs that even e-book adopters are returning to print.

headline: A Million Thanks: Pro Athletes Share the Wealth With Their Colleges
abstract: The N.B.A. star Draymond Green, who recently announced a $3.1 million donation to Michigan State, is part of a growing trend of philanthropy in sports.
lead_paragraph: Universities have long turned to wealthy alumni to help finance their athletic departments. The Nike founder Phil Knight fueled Oregon’s rise to prominence, for example, and the oil tycoon T. Boone Pickens subsidized a building boom at Oklahoma State.

headline: In the Bronx, ‘Poor Church’ Is More Than a Papal Phrase
abstract: Efforts to hold together a merged congregation raise the question of whether the Roman Catholic Church can minister to New York City’s poor in an era of diminishing resources.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Nelson A. Belizario walked gingerly through the quiet sanctuary of St. Joseph’s Church in the Bronx, with its rich-hued stained glass windows and soaring ceiling dotted with golden stars. He stopped at one window depicting its patron on his deathbed, flanked by Mary and Jesus. The scene reassures the faithful that death should not be a time of sadness.

headline: In the Bronx, Photographing a Church for the Poor
abstract: For Ángel Franco, photographing religious experience in New York gives him a chance to set aside his own beliefs as he immerses himself in rituals and relationships that sustain communities of faith.
lead_paragraph: For the last half of the summer, and in anticipation of Pope Francis’ visit to New York, Ángel Franco, a New York Times staff photographer, and David Gonzalez, a New York Times columnist and co-editor of the Lens blog, have been reporting “In the Bronx, ‘Poor Church’ Is More Than a Papal Phrase,” a story that looks at the life of a merged Roman Catholic parish in the Bronx.

headline: Xi Jinping’s Inner Circle Offers Cold Shoulder to Western Officials
abstract: The Chinese president keeps advisers at more of a distance than did his predecessors, and those officials refuse to develop ties with their Western counterparts.

headline: Review: ‘Ron Nagle: Five O’Clock Shadow,’ Delicacy and Tension on a Small Scale
abstract: The bonsai-size art of Mr. Nagle, whose chief medium is glazd clay, is gaining wider appreciation. His new show is at the Matthew Marks Gallery in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: The bonsai-size art of Ron Nagle, whose chief medium is glazed clay, has been cherished in certain quarters of the art world for over 40 years. But lately the admiration has been spreading. In 2012, he was drafted into the American Academy of Arts and Letters; in 2013, 30 of his objects appeared in the Venice Biennale, prominently displayed with 36 anonymous Tantric paintings, also small, in a perfect harmony of intuitive shape and saturated color.

headline: The Breast Cancer Gene and Me
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Breast Cancer', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Mastectomy']
abstract: It’s simple: All Ashkenazi Jewish women should have the BRCA test.

I caught it fast and I acted fast, but I must have looked away: By the time of my double mastectomy, the cancer had spread to five lymph nodes.

It is also reported that the Roumanian grand manoeuvres which were to have been held about this time have been countermanded at the last moment owing to the foreign situation, which renders any movement of troops undesirable.

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — People with foreign language skills were, by necessity, among the first emergency workers to respond to a horrific bus accident on Thursday that killed four international college students and sent nearly 50 other people to hospitals. But even as the trauma teams scrambled to treat, identify and communicate with the victims, many of whom spoke little or no English and had just arrived in America this week, there was a terrible hole in the response: No speaker of German could be found, and a 15-year-old boy had to be told that his mother was dead.

headline: Owing to the Greeks
abstract: The economic imbroglio between Germany and Greece perfectly corresponds with literary history.
lead_paragraph: It is rare that a contemporary political state of affairs perfectly corresponds with a classical literary one — when the contours of the two align so entirely that not only does the latter help explain the former, but the new situation, with all its messy contingencies, seems to follow the carefully wrought logic of its aesthetic predecessor with such precision as to appear like a manifestation, or symptom, of it. Yet this is the case (I would argue) with the economic imbroglio between Germany and Greece.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Lauren Groff, whose “Fates and Furies” is No. 7 on the hardcover fiction list, says she relates to both of the book’s main characters: “I wobble between action and somewhat optimistic fatalism.”
lead_paragraph: His and Hers, Part I: You could think of Lauren Groff’s third novel, “Fates and ­Furies” — new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 7 — as a sort of “Gone Girl” minus the murderous psychopathology. Both tell the story of a marriage first from the husband’s somewhat complacent perspective, then change course midway to reveal a wife far more active and vengeful than expected. But “Fates and Furies” is also, as the title suggests, a meditation on classical ideas of destiny and human agency, with the golden boy Lotto (short for Lancelot) representing submission to the Fates while his wife, Mathilde, rides with the Furies and shapes reality to her liking. I asked Groff which view she endorses, if either. “I wobble between action and somewhat optimistic fatalism,” she replied by email. “In the middle of the night, I side more with Ma­thilde’s pragmatic anxiety; during the slow, hot Florida daylight hours, I’m a little sunnier, a little more like Lotto. I thought, going into the book, that I was 89 percent Lotto, and this book is in some ways an elaborate apologia to my husband for often being wrapped up in my writing to the exclusion of actual life. But Mathilde is a terrifying sister of my heart, and I find myself in her in equal measure. It’s not exactly Flaubert’s ‘Madame Bovary, c’est moi.’ In truth both Lotto and Mathilde, c’est moi. I am both of them and neither of them in equal measure, and their lives and ambivalence and desires have elements of mine, all snarled up in this one big wild knot.”

headline: ‘The Invention of Nature,’ by Andrea Wulf
abstract: Before Darwin, a strange, genius scientist sparked understanding of ecosystems, and of their endangerment.
lead_paragraph: Alexander von Humboldt was the pre-eminent scientist of his time. Contemporaries spoke of him as second in fame only to Napoleon. All over the Americas and the English-speaking world, towns and rivers are still named after him, along with mountain ranges, bays, waterfalls, 300 plants and more than 100 animals. There is a Humboldt glacier, a Humboldt asteroid, a Humboldt hog-nosed skunk. Off the coast of Peru and Chile, the giant Humboldt squid swims in the Humboldt Current, and even on the moon there is an area called Mare Humboldtianum. Darwin called him the “greatest scientific traveler who ever lived.”

headline: The Contenders
abstract: A look at the recently announced longlists of nominees for the National Book Awards.
lead_paragraph: With the advent of fall, publishing dusts off its red carpets, welcoming big new titles and honoring the best of the past year.

headline: ‘This Is Your Life, Harriet Chance!’ by Jonathan Evison
abstract: In Evison’s fourth novel, a 78-year-old widow finds out she’s won a free cruise.
lead_paragraph: It’s been more than 50 years since “This Is Your Life,” the early reality show after which Jonathan Evison’s new novel is named, aired the final episode of its initial television run. The concept of the program might seem quaint to the generation that grew up on the Internet — the host, Ralph Edwards, would surprise his guests (some celebrities, some not) with a retrospective of their lives, accompanied by special appearances from friends and family members out of their pasts.

headline: John Banville’s ‘The Blue Guitar’
abstract: A formerly famous painter returns to his hometown and takes up with a friend’s wife.
lead_paragraph: Here is “rufous-headed, roly-poly” Oliver Orme, “the hypochondriacs’ hypochondriac,” a man with “no fortitude, no sticking power; no grit,” but inexplicable charisma. “I’m pushing 50,” John ­Banville’s latest narrator announces, “and feel a hundred.” His heart is still beating, though: “A thief’s heart is an impetuous organ,” and Orme is compulsive. He’s been stealing since he pocketed a tube of zinc white paint as a child. Even though he is married to the youthful Gloria, he cannot keep his hands off the wife of his friend Marcus, the local watch repairman. “I pinched Polly,” he boasts. “Polly I ­purloined.”

headline: David Maraniss’s ‘Once in a Great City: A Detroit Story’
abstract: An expansive look at Detroit in 1963 captures its greatness on the cusp of its decline.
lead_paragraph: David Maraniss’s “Once in a Great City” concerns Detroit in 1963 — a crucial year, this book asserts, in the city’s history, marking the end of its boom times and the beginning of its end times. Though my Detroit birth and upbringing were still a decade off, 1963 was a big year for me, too. My dad graduated from high school in the city that spring, and my mom would begin her senior year that fall. For their first date, they went to see “It’s a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World.” The ingredients for the city’s apocalypse would seem to have come together along with those of my ­existence.

headline: In Milan, a Designer Aims for ‘The Edge of Good Taste’
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2015)']
abstract: The designer Arthur Arbesser shows his debut collection for Iceberg in Milan today.
lead_paragraph: “This place is very Milan,” said the designer Arthur Arbesser as he slid into a wooden chair at Bottiglieria Bulloni, a wine shop and bar established in 1933. It’s a place so truly Milanese that it closes immediately after aperitivo at 9 p.m. Arbesser — the newly appointed creative director of Iceberg — was taking a break from preparing for his first collection for the house, which debuts today. It will be followed by the first runway presentation of his namesake line a few days later. Having already skipped lunch, it seemed that a glass of Franciacorta (Italian sparkling wine that has been called the official drink of Milan Fashion Week) and aperitivo snacks would constitute his dinner before returning to the studio.

headline: Me and My Jetta: How VW Broke My Heart
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Diesel Power', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: The company purposely duped those of us who cared most about the Earth.
lead_paragraph: THE day I went to pick up my new Volkswagen Jetta TDI in March 2009, the salesman had me sit in the driver’s seat while he introduced the car’s various features. The engine was softly idling, and as I reached to shut it off, he told me not to bother. The minimal amount of fuel this car burned — sipped, in the automotive argot — was its great selling point. That, and the almost complete removal of hazardous exhaust that had made earlier diesel vehicles notorious.

headline: Eighty Years of Penguin Books
abstract: A cover-to-cover look at the iconic publisher’s ongoing legacy.
lead_paragraph: Before Allen Lane began his publishing house in 1935, good books were the purview of the privileged, costing more than many Londoners spent on a week’s rent. But that all changed when Lane, then managing director of the Bodley Head, bought the rights to 10 already popular hardcovers (including Ernest Hemingway’s “A Farewell to Arms” and Agatha Christie’s “The Mysterious Affair at Styles”), redesigning each with a uniform set of specs so simple that even small, inexperienced print shops could mass-produce them on the cheap. The color-coded, pocket-size paperbacks — numbered in the order of their release — were a hit, and Lane’s house, Penguin, eventually became a favorite of collectors eager to snap up everything from coffee mugs to deck chairs bearing its logo. Eighty years on, a cover-to-cover look at the iconic publisher’s ongoing legacy.

The next installment in the series comes from the writer and T contributor Edmund White, who shares his picks exclusively with T.

headline: Review: ‘West Side Story’ at the John W. Engeman Theater in Northport
abstract: From the first finger snaps, the production at the John W. Engeman Theater in Northport, tailored to a non-Broadway stage, retains the show’s emotional urgency.
lead_paragraph: From the first sinewy notes of Leonard Bernstein’s music and the first hard-edged finger snaps of glowering young men prowling across the stage, it’s clear that the production of “West Side Story” at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport is on the right track.

headline: A Composer Opens Up Her Creative Process, Online
abstract: As Hannah Lash, the New Haven Symphony Orchestra’s new composer-in-residence, writes her first symphony, she will be shining a light on the work in progress, inviting comment on social media and in live forums.
lead_paragraph: As a professor at the Yale School of Music and a working harpist, Hannah Lash enjoys plenty of interaction with students, colleagues and the public. But when it comes time to compose, she typically holes up in her New Haven home late at night and keeps to herself.

keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Up to 7,000 people are expected to meet the 85 writers and illustrators and buy their works at the Chappaqua Children’s Book Festival, now in its second year.
lead_paragraph: The children’s book author and illustrator Peter Sis’ love of ice cream is no secret: The title of his most recent book is “Ice Cream Summer.” But as Mr. Sis mentioned before signing books for children at the Hall of Scoops ice cream shop here, Purple Pig Tales, a custom flavor being offered that combined the taste of cotton candy with swirls of vanilla and rainbow confetti, might not be his first choice.

headline: Best Arms in Baseball Have No Bargaining Power
abstract: As David Cone points out, the Matt Harvey situation highlights a flaw in the arbitration system: It may be in a team’s best interests to maximize a pitcher’s production in his first six contract years without regard for his long-term health.
lead_paragraph: No one ever accused David Cone of being an innings-addled wimp.

lead_paragraph: The use of cellphones, the rustling of candy wrappers, and audible murmuring are some of the worst transgressions audience members can make during live theater performances in New York City.

headline: Jami Floyd, WNYC Host, on the Upper West Side
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The New York host of the National Public Radio radio show “All Things Considered,” lives with her family on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: Deadlines are sacrosanct to Jami Floyd, the new local host of the National Public Radio show “All Things Considered” on WNYC, a job she started last month. So when Ms. Floyd and her husband, Kurt Flehinger, a lawyer, bought a four-bedroom prewar apartment near Riverside Park a decade ago, they gave their contractor a strict six-week deadline to finish renovating it. They had to move in no later than Labor Day, they told him, so that their son and daughter would feel settled when they started school.

lead_paragraph: A sleek glass penthouse perched atop a warehouse-turned-boutique condominium in TriBeCa, with an immense landscaped terrace and reflecting pool that provide a verdant urban oasis on the roof, sold for $18,574,000 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Jorge Ramos’s Long Game
keywords: ['Television', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'News and News Media', 'Spanish Language', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: As the Republican Party veers right on immigration, the Univision anchorman is making sure the cameras keep rolling.
lead_paragraph: On a Tuesday morning earlier this month, Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, Ariz., waited near a side entrance of the Tent City Jail, the open-air compound he operates in Phoenix. Several female inmates were lined up before him, hands behind their backs, ankles linked by chains. The women wore black-and-white-striped prison uniforms — the kind of throwbacks tourists don for photographs near Alcatraz — with the words “Sheriff’s Inmate” on their backs. Arpaio wore a black suit, black shoes and a white shirt. He looked as if he had raided Johnny Cash’s closet.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Under the Sea
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2015)', 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: Emilio Pucci, Fausto Puglisi and Max Mara all played with underwater creatures.
lead_paragraph: In Milan, maritime looks have skewed more scuba than sailor. For his first Emilio Pucci collection, Massimo Giorgetti affixed sea creatures to mesh and other sheer fabrics; Fausto Puglisi created seashell-encrusted separates; and the Max Mara team paired midi skirts with lighthouse-print T-shirts — all taking the nautical theme a step further than the usual navy stripes.

headline: John Boehner Fades Away
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Economy', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)']
abstract: Republicans liked him, but that didn’t help him rally the troops — or keep them from stabbing him in the back.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly after the 2010 election, I encountered Representative John A. Boehner in the Capitol Building. His party had just won a majority in the House, which meant he would soon become speaker. Though he’s a Republican and I was a longtime Democratic staff member, we got along well. “Just wait,” he told me. “In six months, I’ll be more popular in your caucus than in mine.”

headline: A Black-Tie Ball Fit for a Knight
abstract: The Order of Malta, a sovereign entity with diplomatic relations in 105 countries, edges into the New York social fund-raising circuit.
lead_paragraph: The Order of Malta is more than nine centuries old, but that doesn’t mean it can’t try something new. Last Saturday at the Metropolitan Club, the organization, whose mission is to serve “the poor and the sick,” held its first White Cross Ball in New York, where it has some 150 knights and dames.

lead_paragraph: Economists always warn, correctly, not to make too much of any single economic report, but rather to analyze new information in terms of longer-term trends.

lead_paragraph: After hours of anticipation, the procession Pope Francis made through Central Park on Friday was a blur: Just as soon as it started, it was over. And officials took a bow, estimating that nearly everyone with a ticket had made it inside.

lead_paragraph: A prosecutor in the Manhattan district attorney’s office was found guilty on Friday of charges he assaulted a woman during a drunken argument at a bar on Halloween night last year.

headline: All in the Family
abstract: This especially large edition of T required a fairly heroic effort on the part of the staff.
lead_paragraph: BECAUSE THIS IS an especially large edition of T, requiring fairly heroic effort on the part of the staff, I’d like to share a bit of the behind-the-scenes action here at The New York Times. The size of any magazine is generally a function of how many advertisers have bought space in it: the more ad pages, the more editorial stories. A couple of weeks before this issue was due to head off to the printer, ad-sales figures spiked 75 percent above what was expected — a fantastic boon in the beleaguered world of print journalism. Of course, we were excited by the news, but whereas we normally have several months to conceive, plan and execute ideas, we now had two weeks to make 40 additional pages.

abstract: A gala concert on Thursday night featured the pianist Lang Lang and conducting by Alan Gilbert, after the hall was renamed for David Geffen.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic opened its season on Thursday with a gala concert featuring the superstar pianist Lang Lang, in a flashy account of Grieg’s Piano Concerto, and Alan Gilbert, the orchestra’s music director, conducting an energetic, if not especially inspired, performance of Beethoven’s Seventh Symphony. This program of staples, which lasted less than 90 minutes (with no intermission), seemed calculated to go over easily and leave plenty of time for the many patrons attending to enjoy a post-concert dinner.

abstract: Too tired for nonfiction? Too late for a whole chapter of a novel? Try a poem. Or two.
lead_paragraph: Does fall mark a transition for you in what and how you read? The publishing world thinks it does; now is the time for big releases and more serious fiction. I’ve got a bit of a stack of new books, and there are even more tempting me on the front tables at my local bookstores.

headline: Reviving a Traditional Irish Women’s Sport in New York
abstract: The Hoboken Guards are the first women’s camogie team in New York in nearly 20 years. The photographer Jessica Bal spent a season with the team documenting the bond they found in the traditional Irish sport.
lead_paragraph: The Hoboken Guards are the first women’s camogie team in New York in nearly 20 years. The photographer Jessica Bal spent a season with the team documenting the bond they found in the traditional Irish sport.

headline: Citi Bike App Gets an Upgrade
abstract: Citi Bike’s updated app allows riders to track mileage and customize their maps to include information about local businesses.
lead_paragraph: When I last looked at the Citi Bike app, in June 2013, New York’s bike-sharing program had just started. The app was rudimentary, consisting almost entirely of data about nearby docking stations and the availability of bicycles, information that was sometimes inaccurate. It was fitting for a program that quickly became notorious for faulty software and subpar customer service.

headline: Preparing Pinstripes for New Players
abstract: New or old, the preparation and maintenance of a Yankee uniform leaves little to chance.
lead_paragraph: Q. The Yankees often notify their principal farm team that a player must report to Yankee Stadium “tonight or tomorrow” for possible duty in the next game. How does the club outfit a player with a properly fitting uniform with his number on it so quickly?

abstract: The new goals are meant to apply to every country, giving them a broader reach than a set of goals adopted in 2000, which were aimed mainly at developing countries.
lead_paragraph: The Sustainable Development Goals adopted by the United Nations at a summit meeting in New York on Friday lay out a sweeping vision for improving the lives of people all over the world over the next 15 years.

headline: U.N. Adopts Ambitious Global Goals After Years of Negotiations
abstract: The goals come with 169 specific targets for action meant to aid the planet and its most vulnerable people, a task few people think will be easy to achieve.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The last time Amina J. Mohammed went home to see her extended family in northern Nigeria, her cousins asked her to skip her usual gifts of clothes and sweets and bring them something that they really needed: body scanners for the gates of the local mosque, to guard against suicide bombers sent by Boko Haram.

headline: No End in Sight to Tide of Migrants Entering Europe, U.N. Says
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: As officials warned that conditions in Iraq could send waves of displaced people to Europe, anti-migrant demonstrations erupted in Finland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The flood of Syrian refugees pouring into the heart of Europe is unlikely to ease anytime soon, and worsening conditions in Iraq could send new waves of displaced people onto the Continent, United Nations officials warned on Friday.

headline: Major Changes Under Rhode Island Pension Overhaul
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Government Employees', 'Taxation', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'State Legislatures', 'Retirement']
abstract: Benefits were reduced and workers’ contributions were increased to put the pension plan on a sound footing.
lead_paragraph: As states and municipalities struggle with rising pension costs, the governor, legislature and labor organizations in Rhode Island were able to agree on reductions to pension obligations and avoid tax increases or other financial burdens. Here are some of the most significant changes.

headline: Rhode Island Averts Pension Disaster Without Raising Taxes
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Government Employees', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Gov. Gina M. Raimondo has finished a pension overhaul that reduces benefits, but does not raise taxes or issue risky pension-obligation bonds.
lead_paragraph: Chicago is facing its biggest tax increase in memory, to raise money for pension payments. Illinois is stymied by a $110 billion pension shortfall. In New Jersey, public workers are in court over a failed pension deal. From Pennsylvania to California, pensions costs are crowding out aid for public education.

headline: Ruffles, Lace and Crochet at Philosophy
abstract: For spring/summer 2016, Lorenzo Seraphini opted for a dreamy collection of flowing silhouettes.
lead_paragraph: For spring/summer 2016, Lorenzo Seraphini opted for a dreamy collection of flowing silhouettes.

headline: Review: ‘Zero One’ Plays With Difference at Danspace
abstract: Yasuko Yokoshi’s piece, a dance of alternating worlds, has opened Danspace Project’s fall season.
lead_paragraph: Yasuko Yokoshi’s “Zero One” is a dance of twos: two alternating worlds, on screen and onstage; two performers at the center of each; two dance cultures mingling. This haunting new work, which opened Danspace Project’s fall season on Thursday at St. Mark’s Church, layers a live duet by the identical twins Manami and Sawami Fukuoka with excerpts from Ms. Yokoshi’s film “Hangman Takuzo,” named for a 67-year-old Japanese performance artist who hangs himself — safely — each day in his garden.

headline: For ‘Dr. Ken,’ a Comic Returns to Medicine
abstract: On Oct. 2, ABC unveils “Dr. Ken,” starring Ken Jeong, who was a doctor before he became a comic.
lead_paragraph: Apparently the way to get a TV show these days is to be a stand-up comic and pitch a series about your life before you started telling jokes for a living. In recent weeks, NBC offered both “Mr. Robinson,” featuring Craig Robinson, and “The Carmichael Show,” with Jerrod Carmichael, and on Friday, Oct. 2, ABC unveils “Dr. Ken,” starring Ken Jeong, who was a doctor before he became a comic.

headline: Review: In ‘Indian Summers,’ British Expatriates Misbehave
abstract: A new series on PBS “Masterpiece,” set in India in 1932, puts a full deck of sahib stereotypes into play against lush jungle and forest backdrops.
lead_paragraph: With the end of “Downton Abbey” in sight — only nine more episodes, already being shown in Britain! — the search for a reasonable substitute takes on new urgency. PBS makes a major play to keep the “Downton” audience with the premiere of “Indian Summers” on Sunday night on “Masterpiece.” It’s a different animal — leaning more toward sex-charged melodrama than genteel parlor comedy — but if you have a taste for good-looking British people misbehaving in beautiful surroundings, it may do just fine.

headline: Review: ABC’s ‘Blood & Oil,’ Washing Away the Past
abstract: In this new drama, a couple head to North Dakota to start a laundry and are met instead with boomtown prices and politics.
lead_paragraph: Petroleum, land, money, bravado, ego and intrafamily tensions, but about 1,200 miles north of Dallas. It’s the new ABC drama “Blood & Oil,” which gets off to a tolerable start on Sunday, though, of course, drawing attention on television’s most jam-packed night is always tough.

headline: Review: ‘Disclosures,’ Bruno Isakovic’s Show and Tell
abstract: The performers share their intimate life stories, their fears and fantasies, while disrobing in this program at Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: For about an hour on Wednesday night, six performers undressed and confessed in the Underground Theater at Abrons Arts Center. They talked about their relationships to their bodies, revealing everything from circumcisions and mastectomies to sexual fantasies and ruminations on gender. By the end, we knew all about them, their genitals and their lives, in selective but intimate detail.

headline: How Lee Child, Author of the Jack Reacher Novels, Spends His Sundays
abstract: The author of the thrilling series spends his Sundays eating French food, walking through the park and perusing museums.
lead_paragraph: Lee Child, the author of the Jack Reacher crime novels, starts a new book each September and finishes sometime in spring, 20 books in 20 years. The most recent, “Make Me,” just took over the No. 1 spot on the New York Times best-seller list. He spends Sundays the way many writers do, in his own bubble. “It’s hard for others to understand, because you’re living in this made-up zone of fantasy, where that seems real to you, and the real real stuff seems odd,” he said. Mr. Child, 60, whose real name is Jim Grant, lives on the Upper West Side with his wife, Jane Grant.

headline: ‘Up and Away,’ for Young Audiences Who Don’t Want Surprises
abstract: Trusty Sidekick’s new theater production, about a family’s hot-air balloon ride, was created for children with autism.
lead_paragraph: You arrive and are assigned your own cast member, who will escort you to the performance space — where five colorful life-size replicas of hot-air balloons fill the room — and sit right next to you throughout the show. Your personal attaché will even walk you to the elevator and wave goodbye at the end.

headline: At Ali Baba’s Terrace, Frequent Fliers With Gridlock in Mind
abstract: Street congestion from visiting dignitaries, including Pope Francis, was a hot topic at a business lunch at Ali Baba’s Terrace, near the United Nations in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Midtown East is already a busy part of town, but on Tuesday, the neighborhood was especially abuzz. It was the first day of the United Nations General Assembly session, and representatives from around the world had descended on the area in droves. Traffic was at a standstill, helicopters hovered overhead and talk of Pope Francis’ arrival in two days was everywhere, including at Ali Baba’s Terrace, a Turkish restaurant just down the street from the United Nations headquarters.

headline: Browsing to the Beat at Maison Kitsuné
abstract: At the Manhattan boutique next to the NoMad Hotel, customers nod to the relentless sound of electronic music while considering clothing influenced by the popular cultures of France and Japan.
lead_paragraph: Maison Kitsuné does not merely hang its clothes on pedestrian racks. Rather, its latest collection is carefully arranged on sparely populated rails. The boutique (1170 Broadway, at 28th Street) is an oasis of moneyed calm in a bustling and quickly gentrifying neighborhood, and its offerings manage to be eclectic, youthful and sporty, while at the same time intimidatingly priced pieces of high fashion.

headline: Ukraine to Ban Flights by Major Russian Airlines
abstract: The ban, which would take effect next month, is part of a set of trade sanctions imposed on Russia for supporting a separatist revolt inside Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine will ban major Russian airlines including Aeroflot, the Russian national airline, from flying to its airports starting next month as part of a broad set of trade sanctions imposed on Russia for supporting a separatist revolt in Ukraine.

lead_paragraph: So a few things happened today, not including House Speaker John Boehner announcing he was stepping down and Volkswagen and the Environmental Protection Agency trying to bolster pollution controls.

lead_paragraph: After seeing the film “Bring It On,” the photographer Brian Finke began a project on cheerleading and football, two historically related, but increasingly independent, competitive sports.

headline: Wolfgang Tillmans Takes Pictures of Modern Life, Backlit by the Past
abstract: In exhibitions at the David Zwirner Gallery in Chelsea and at the Met, Mr. Tillmans displays the bewitching and stupefying contemporary world.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Wolfgang Tillmans is a material guy. He has always embraced the physicality of photos. As a boy in Remscheid, a small city in western Germany, he photocopied printed images and bought his first camera so he could obtain more material for the copy machine. Achieving prominence in the early 1990s, when his pictures of Hamburg night life were published in i-D, a British periodical known for its cutting-edge design, he prized his work not as it existed in its original form but as it appeared laid out in the magazine.

headline: Prosecutors Struggling to Keep Up With Cases of Violence From Rikers
keywords: ['District Attorneys', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Prisons and Prisoners']

lead_paragraph: Already struggling to contain surging violence at Rikers Island, New York City officials are now facing further hurdles as they try to prosecute the inmates they say are responsible for it.

headline: Kevin McCarthy Expected to Seek Speaker John Boehner’s Post in House
abstract: In the wake of John Boehner’s resignation announcement, speculation has centered on Mr. McCarthy, the No. 2 House Republican, who has risen rapidly through the ranks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When John A. Boehner announced his retirement on Friday, speculation about who would succeed him as speaker immediately centered on the No. 2 House Republican: Kevin McCarthy, a 50-year-old Californian who has had a rapid rise through the party ranks.

headline: Patricia Hoffbauer Takes Dance in a Wry, Irreverent Direction
abstract: In “Dances for Intimate Spaces and Friendly People,” 14 performers from many backgrounds and generations take over at Gibney Dance.
lead_paragraph: Dancing about making dances is nothing new, but Patricia Hoffbauer’s approach may be singular. In “Dances for Intimate Spaces and Friendly People,” 14 dancers from many backgrounds and generations take over the studios at Gibney Dance’s Lower Manhattan outpost, including the postmodern luminaries Yvonne Rainer and Sara Rudner. Isolated duets, trios and quartets, converging at the end, carry the audience from space to space, while a video exhibition in the lobby documents the process of the work’s creation.

abstract: This Belgian songwriter with a Rwandan father has emerged as a million-selling combination of Michael Jackson and Jacques Brel.
lead_paragraph: Can a European superstar conquer Madison Square Garden?

headline: Truce Struck in 2 Areas of Syria
abstract: Supporters and opponents of President Bashar al-Assad will trade territory in two parts of the country and pledge to observe a six-month cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — In one of the most ambitious deals yet struck between combatants in the multisided war in Syria, supporters and opponents of President Bashar al-Assad will essentially trade territory in two different parts of the country, stop bombing and besieging one another’s civilians and pledge to observe a six-month cease-fire.

headline: Harlem Kids Thrilled After Meeting Pope
abstract: New York City students said that meeting the pope on Friday was a life-changing experience.

headline: National Sawdust, a New-Music Space, Opens in Brooklyn
abstract: The space, built from the shell of a former sawdust factory, will host performances and stage recordings.
lead_paragraph: An experimental venture could bring a jolt to the new-music scene in New York: the opening of National Sawdust, a nonprofit performance space and recording facility in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The building’s intimate, adaptable main hall has been built from the shell of an old sawdust factory. The goal is to foster the creation of original works. It opens on Thursday, Oct. 1, with a program titled “Discover the Space” Vol. 1 and Vol. 2, (nationalsawdust.org).

headline: Francisco Oller Exhibition Explores Impressionism and the Caribbean
abstract: An exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum surrounds Oller’s pictures with work by both earlier Puerto Rican artists and his famed French contemporaries.
lead_paragraph: In the 19th century, Modernism traveled the world, and one of the places it flourished was in Puerto Rico, where the painter Francisco Oller was born in 1833. He had his initial art training in San Juan, then went abroad for further study in Spain and France. In Paris, he fell in with avant-garde artists who favored Courbet-inspired realism and a brand-new style, Impressionism. He painted side by side with Claude Monet and introduced Camille Pissarro, another Caribbean native, to Paul Cézanne. Unlike Pissarro, though, Oller didn’t stay in Europe. He returned to Puerto Rico, then still a Spanish colony, and made life there the theme of his art in landscape paintings of sugar plantations and still-lifes of tropical fruit.

headline: Costa Rica to Shield Sea Turtles
abstract: Weeks after tourists disrupted the nesting of thousands of olive ridley sea turtles, the government said it would enforce stricter security measures.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after an onslaught of tourists disrupted thousands of olive ridley sea turtles nesting on a Costa Rican beach, the turtles have arrived again to lay their eggs. Absent this time were the selfie-taking tourists who had wandered among them, causing international outrage on social media and leading to stricter security measures.

lead_paragraph: The pope toured Manhattan beginning with an address at the the United Nations General Assembly and ending with an evening mass at Madison Square Garden.

Patriotic songs played on the stereo, a man in a blue blazer from the John Birch Society hovered by a well-stocked literature table, and Lauren L. Martel, a lawyer from Hilton Head, told the crowd that 25 Syrian refugees were already living among them.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, seeking to expand the state’s relationship with Cuba, met on Friday with its president, Raúl Castro, for the first time, the governor’s office said.

lead_paragraph: Pope Francis stood flanked by an imam in a skullcap and a rabbi in a prayer shawl on what amounts to hallowed ground: an underground chamber where the victims of the attacks on the World Trade Center are memorialized.

headline: Nigeria: Polio Contained, W.H.O. Says
abstract: Polio remains endemic in just two countries, Pakistan and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Polio is no longer endemic in Nigeria, which means that it has conquered the disease, the World Health Organization declared Friday. Polio remains endemic in just two countries, Pakistan and Afghanistan, which have never eliminated the virus. As of last month, all of Africa had gone a full year without a case of polio paralysis. The last case anywhere in Africa was detected in Somalia on Aug. 11, 2014; it was caused by a strain of the virus that had originated in Nigeria. The last case in Nigeria was recorded on July 24, 2014. Despite Friday’s announcement, Nigeria cannot be declared “polio free” until two more years have passed with no paralysis cases and no virus detected in sewage. As recently as 2012, Nigeria accounted for more than half of all the world’s polio cases.

headline: String of Emails Raises Questions About When Hillary Clinton Began Using Personal Account

headline: John McNeill, Priest Who Pushed Catholic Church to Welcome Gays, Dies at 90
abstract: Father McNeill was a champion of gay rights long before the Catholic church opened the issue to debate, and he was expelled from his order as a result.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. John McNeill, an openly gay Roman Catholic priest who, from the 1970s onward, publicly pressed the church to welcome gay men and lesbians — and who was expelled from his order as a result — died on Tuesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 90.

headline: No. 1 Ranking Remains a Slippery Spot for Day, Spieth and McIlroy
abstract: If Rory McIlroy or Jordan Spieth overtakes Jason Day after this week’s Tour Championship, it will be the first time since 1997 that there has been a different No. 1 in five consecutive weeks.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Jason Day followed Rory McIlroy to the interview room Wednesday at the Tour Championship and, after taking his seat, smiled and slyly observed, “Rory warmed the seat for me.” Day’s playful aside summed up the variability at the top in men’s golf.

headline: Eric Cantor: The G.O.P., After John Boehner
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: The former majority leader says many people in the Republican party don’t understand the smart way to fight.
lead_paragraph: Richmond, Va. — LIKE so many others, I was stunned by Speaker John A. Boehner’s announcement on Friday that he would step down at the end of October. For nearly six years — first as Republican whip and then as majority leader — I met with John on a daily, sometimes hourly, basis as we worked to lead the House Republican Conference. It is no secret that we had different styles and personalities, but he was always selfless, a man who put the nation, his constituents, the House of Representatives and the party before himself.

headline: A Day Laborer, on His Way to See Pope Francis

It brought Juan Tapia to a house outside Yonkers, where he spent days painting the living room blue — “the color of the sky today,” he said on Thursday.

headline: The Prospect of Peace in Colombia
abstract: It is astonishing that a war that has been so deadly, so cruel, could end through diplomacy.
lead_paragraph: BARICHARA, Colombia — It was not a heartfelt handshake. It was tentative and awkward. And yet, I watched in stunned silence as President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia shook hands with Rodrigo Londoño (no relation), the leader of the country’s largest guerrilla group, on Wednesday night after the two announced a major breakthrough in peace talks.

headline: Beijing Puts Ball Back in Washington’s Court on Climate Change
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Global Warming', 'Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs']
abstract: President Xi Jinping’s plan for China to implement a cap-and-trade system recalled President Obama’s failure to overcome Republican opposition to a similar policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama tried to tackle climate change in his first term, he pushed Congress to limit and put a price on carbon pollution, but the so-called cap-and-trade bill died in the Senate in 2010. Among the chief reasons: Lawmakers from both parties feared that any law to cut greenhouse gas emissions would harm the nation’s competitiveness compared with China, which was then emerging as the world’s largest polluter.

headline: How Surgery Can Fight Global Poverty
keywords: ['Surgery and Surgeons', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Poverty', 'International Relations']
abstract: The United Nations has developed admirable goals to end global poverty and hunger, but they can’t succeed without expanding access to surgery.
lead_paragraph: EARLIER this year in Madagascar, a man in his 60s named Sambany made international news after volunteer surgeons from Mercy Ships removed a 16-pound tumor from his face. For decades, he had sought treatment at 10 hospitals, most of which lacked surgeons. He was ostracized, then physically unable to work. His family had to sell a rice field just to pay for the cost of getting to the hospital (the surgery itself was provided free).

headline: Colombia’s President Says Peace Talks Overcame Late Surprise
abstract: At the last minute, he said, a rebel leader tried to back out of a crucial part of the deal, a deadline to sign a final accord.
lead_paragraph: When President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia met with the leader of his country’s largest guerrilla group this week to seal the outline of a deal to end more than five decades of war, he received an unsettling shock. At the last minute, he said, the rebel leader, Rodrigo Londoño, tried to back out of a crucial part of the newly negotiated framework.

lead_paragraph: The New Brunswick Faculty Council, a group of Rutgers professors, said on Friday that punishing Kyle Flood, the head football coach, with a three-game suspension and a $50,000 fine for contacting a player’s professor to try to make the player eligible was too lenient a penalty.

headline: Malawi: U.N. Warns of a Food Crisis
abstract: More than 2.8 million people will not have enough to eat over the next several months because of floods and drought.
lead_paragraph: The World Food Program, the hunger-fighting agency of the United Nations, warned Friday of an impending crisis in the southeastern African nation of Malawi, saying that more than 2.8 million people there will lack enough to eat over the next several months because of severe floods and a drought that ruined the 2015 harvest. The agency said the floods this year in Malawi were “the worst in living memory,” flushing away stockpiles of food and ruining fertile land. Crops that survived the floods, the agency said, succumbed later to “intense dry spells.” The agency, which is financed by voluntary contributions, said its Malawi relief operation was less than 25 percent funded and required more than $80 million.

keywords: ['Liability for Products', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Salmonella (Bacteria)', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Law and Legislation']

lead_paragraph: Salmonella poisoning is an awful affliction. It is marked by diarrhea, abdominal cramps, dehydration and fever that can last as long as a week. Many people wind up in the hospital. Others develop something called reactive arthritis. And in a small number of cases, the victims die.

In the 557 days since, the Knicks have won 27 games — including 17 games last season, when they steamrollered franchise records for futility.

They will remove the furniture from the visiting team’s clubhouse, cover the room in plastic, and stock tubs with ice, beer and champagne.

headline: Yankees Get Mixed News on Tanaka and Bad News on the Field

Earlier in the afternoon, Tanaka threw off a mound for the first time since straining a hamstring against the Mets, a noteworthy milepost in the high-pressure stretch run of September.

lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Mats Zuccarello missed the Rangers’ last 14 playoff games and their first two preseason contests, but he returned to the ice with a flourish Thursday against the Boston Bruins.

headline: The Giants’ Wait for Victor Cruz Could Be Nearing an End
abstract: The star receiver has not played in roughly a year while recovering from a strained calf muscle and major knee surgery.

Coach Tom Coughlin indicated on Friday that wide receiver Victor Cruz, who has not played in roughly a year, should resume practicing next week, which would put him on schedule to rejoin the team on Oct. 4 for its next game, against the Buffalo Bills.

headline: Met Opera Crowd Cheers Ailing Russian Baritone
abstract: The Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky, being treated for a brain tumor, received a tumultuous ovation at his return to the Metropolitan Opera Friday evening in Verdi’s “Il Trovatore.”
lead_paragraph: Three months after announcing he had a brain tumor, and still in the midst of treatment, the cherished Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday evening as the Count di Luna in Verdi’s “Il Trovatore.”

headline: Don Francisco Walks Us Through His Final Day on ‘Sábado Gigante’
abstract: For the host of the highly popular Spanish-language variety show, the day began with a dental emergency and ended with Champagne.
lead_paragraph: This will be Mario Kreutzberger’s first free Saturday in 41 years. The host of “Sábado Gigante,” which ended its 53-year run last Saturday, he took his last day off in 1974, after the death of his mother. Since then Mr. Kreutzberger, more commonly known by his stage name, Don Francisco, has appeared on that Spanish-language variety show, which aired on Univision in the United States, every weekend without fail. Mr. Kreutzberger recalled his final day on “Sábado Gigante” in this account, which has been condensed and edited for clarity.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) UNBROKEN (2014) Angelina Jolie descends from the heavens into hell in this tale about Louis Zamperini (Jack O’Connell), the Olympic track star turned World War II hero, who survived a plane crash in the Pacific in 1943 and drifted for nearly seven weeks on a life raft before being imprisoned and tortured by the Japanese for two years. Joel Coen, Ethan Coen, Richard LaGravenese and William Nicholson condensed Laura Hillenbrand’s 2010 best seller, “Unbroken: A World War II Story of Survival, Resilience, and Redemption,” which covers the first 25 years or so of Mr. Zamperini’s life, into a 2-hour-17-minute screenplay. That’s still hardly enough time to cover each chapter in his life, and though Ms. Jolie does fine work throughout, the strain shows. Her “tendency to go David Lean in this material works against her,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “What the movie ends up in desperate need of is a sense of life made real and palpable through dreadful, transporting details, not a life embalmed in hagiographic awe.”

headline: Quotation of the Day

headline: New Yorkers Fast, Jostle, Wait and Cook as Pope Visits

headline: Review: ‘The Awful Truth,’ Modern Woman and Not-So-Modern Men
abstract: This 1922 comedy by Arthur Richman, the basis of several movies, gets a revival by the Metropolitan Playhouse.
lead_paragraph: The acting isn’t great, but the Metropolitan Playhouse production of “The Awful Truth” provides a rewarding sense of rediscovery, even for those unfamiliar with the work. It’s the rediscovery of the truth that our forebears weren’t as quaint and pristine as we might have thought.

headline: Reviving a Traditional Irish Women’s Sport in New York
abstract: The Hoboken Guards are the first women’s camogie team in New York in nearly 20 years. The photographer Jessica Bal spent a season with the team documenting the bond they found in the traditional Irish sport.
lead_paragraph: When Aisling Daly moved to New York two years ago, she knew she would miss two things from her native Ireland: family and camogie.

headline: At Independence Hall, Pope Offers a Broad Vision of Religious Freedom
abstract: Religious freedom means the right to worship God, “as our consciences dictate,” Francis said, but he also warned about its perversion “as a pretext for hatred and brutality.”
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Standing near Independence Hall, where America’s founding documents were signed, Pope Francis on Saturday called religious freedom a “fundamental right” and laid out a broad and tolerant vision of what it should be, but also warned about its perversion “as a pretext for hatred and brutality.”

lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Sarah Daniels stood at the front of an auditorium on the University of Michigan campus and looked out at the 120 or so students before her on an unseasonably cool day in late August.

headline: Empty Promises and Broken Surfboards

lead_paragraph: In the years that the Haggler has been fighting on behalf of aggrieved consumers, he has compiled a win-loss record exceeded only by Floyd Mayweather, the boxer whose undefeated professional career now stands at 49 wins. But this greatly oversells the Haggler’s achievements — he has lost far more bouts than readers know. It’s just that he rarely writes about the losses.

headline: Long Hidden Away, Columbia’s Football Program Is Put on Display
abstract: New Coach Al Bagnoli has players go through Friday walk-throughs on the campus’s South Lawn, reconnecting a team whose stadium is about 100 blocks away to its fan base.
lead_paragraph: It was just after 3 p.m. Friday when scores of curious onlookers, mostly wearing backpacks, began to line the yew hedges around Columbia’s South Lawn, snapping pictures of a sight unfamiliar to these grounds for decades. Before them, only a few feet away, was the football team, long a source of considerable embarrassment for a proud Ivy League fan base. But the team was out in the warm sunshine on this September afternoon.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword Puzzle

lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — So you’ve made some considerable progress in your solving, you’re regularly solving the late-week, trickier puzzles, and you feel ready to climb some new mountains. Why not try a cryptic crossword, like this terrific one by Daniel Raymon?

headline: John Boehner Exits, Donald Trump Storms On

headline: Review: ‘The Walk’ Captures High-Wire Bravado at World Trade Center
abstract: Robert Zemeckis restages the tightrope journey that Philippe Petit (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) took between the twin towers in 1974.
lead_paragraph: “Now I’ve seen everything,” an anonymous New Yorker remarks, marveling at the spectacle unfolding more than a hundred stories above street level. It’s the morning of Aug. 7, 1974, and Philippe Petit is walking across a steel cable strung between the towers of the World Trade Center. Amid the gasps and murmurs, that line stands out, and invites a bit of pondering. It’s an expression of wonder, for sure, but it also carries an implication of jadedness, especially for moviegoers. All the surround-sound bells and whistles and digitally enhanced fireworks in the world can’t quite shake us out of the feeling that we’ve seen it all before.

headline: To Get a Job in Your 50s, Maintain Friendships in Your 40s
abstract: People over 50 have more difficulty landing a job than their younger counterparts, but they can improve their chances by keeping a strong social network.

Connie Wanberg, a professor at the Carlson School of Management at the University of Minnesota, had long heard gloom-and-doom stories to that effect, but she wondered how strong the data was to support them.

lead_paragraph: Martin Winterkorn, Volkswagen’s chief executive, took the stage four years ago at the automaker’s new plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., and outlined a bold strategy. The company, he said, was in the midst of a plan to more than triple its sales in the United States in just a decade — setting it on a course to sweep by Toyota to become the world’s largest automaker.

headline: ­Protecting Apes Could Backfire
keywords: ['Monkeys and Apes', 'Research', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: A new rule to protect laboratory chimpanzees could hurt research on vaccines for their wild brethren.
lead_paragraph: Cambridge, England — A NEW listing under the Endangered Species Act effectively bans the use of captive chimpanzees in human biomedical research. This might seem like good news. But this action to protect the welfare of captive chimpanzees by classifying them as endangered could unintentionally deliver a serious blow to wild apes. Efforts to develop and deploy vaccines against Ebola and other infectious diseases ravaging these animals could grind to a halt.

headline: Donald Trump, Our Reality TV Candidate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Television', 'Reality Television', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: I’ve been working in reality television for 10 years, and the Republican hopeful is exactly what we look for in our casting process.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles — THE first time I met Delores Hughes, known as Mema, she was dressed in a purple muumuu, searching her kitchen for her false teeth. She warned me not to let her dog Tigger inside, because it would attack me. Dogfights were common at Mema’s house; her daughter had the stitches to prove it. By the end of the day, Mema was leading dozens of moonshine-drunk neighbors in a round of “Happy Birthday” — it was my birthday — and I thought to myself, not only have I just met my new favorite person, but this person is reality TV gold.

headline: The Soaring Price of Political Access
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Action Committees', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The traditional party machines are now making bids to hold their own in money and influence.
lead_paragraph: Politicians busy soliciting ever-larger donations from eager millionaires epitomize the truth of a 12-year-old Supreme Court ruling on contribution limits: “Money, like water, will always find an outlet.”

headline: Francis, the Perfect 19th-Century Pope
abstract: He’s really cool, but a lot of his thinking doesn’t work today.
lead_paragraph: Washington — AFTER attending a canonization Mass at Catholic University with the pope who rails against the excesses of capitalism, I walked off campus to a festival of capitalism.

headline: A Special Education
abstract: The question of whether my schooling hurt me or helped me has haunted me my whole life.
lead_paragraph: THE famous little yellow bus stopped at the bottom of my driveway at 8:30 a.m. on the first day of fourth grade. I was the only passenger at first, but we zigzagged here and there, picking up children I had never seen before. We finally stopped at an office building, in a city eight miles from our rural upstate New York town, where a room had been rented for the class. We were “special ed.”

headline: Why Students Hate School Lunches
abstract: Kids are turning their noses up at — and filling trash cans with — unappetizing fare.
lead_paragraph: MORE than 30 million children trundle through school cafeteria lines every day in the United States and thanks to the Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act, which took effect in 2012, they are no longer served greasy pizza, salty French fries and sauced up chicken wings. Meals must now be lower in fat, calories and sodium and contain lean proteins, more fruits and vegetables and whole grains. And kids from coast to coast are wrinkling their noses.

headline: Cassian Folsom
abstract: A monk on the beauty of chanting, the burden of email and the luxury of getting to sleep late once a month — until 5:30 instead of 3:30.
lead_paragraph: Father Cassian Folsom is the prior of the Monastery of St. Benedict in Norcia, Italy, where the monks are known both for brewing the beer that was served to the conclave that elected Pope Francis and a chart-topping album of Marian chant, which was released in June.

headline: Putin’s Credo: Never Let Them See You Sweat
abstract: To the Russian president, any display of weakness is a fatal flaw.
lead_paragraph: LONG ago, at the inception of his rise to power, Vladimir V. Putin recounted a memory of growing up in the late 1950s in a Soviet communal apartment in Leningrad, as St. Petersburg was then known. For kicks, he and his friends would chase rats in the building’s dismal hallways. It was what passed for a game until the time a cornered rat hurled himself at a surprised and frightened young Vladimir, who turned and ran away.

headline: Donald Trump and the Rise of the Moral Minority
abstract: The success of his campaign so far exposes a rift within the evangelical movement.
lead_paragraph: DONALD TRUMP’S high poll numbers among evangelicals have preoccupied the media for months. But the most interesting thing about his Christian fans is not their willingness to overlook the sins of a casino playboy. Evangelicals happily voted for a divorced man of uncertain faith once before: Ronald Reagan. What is most striking is that Mr. Trump’s campaign has exposed a rift within evangelicalism — a split between those calling for culture war as usual and those who say Christians must adjust to life as a minority in American Babylon.

headline: The Curious Politics of the ‘Nudge’
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Research']
abstract: Conservatives like this policy tool. Except when liberals do. And vice versa.
lead_paragraph: HOW do we really feel about policy “nudges”?

headline: Stop Googling. Let’s Talk.
keywords: ['Text Messaging', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Youth', 'Children and Childhood', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Empathy', 'Research']
abstract: What have we done to face-to-face conversation?
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE students tell me they know how to look someone in the eye and type on their phones at the same time, their split attention undetected. They say it’s a skill they mastered in middle school when they wanted to text in class without getting caught. Now they use it when they want to be both with their friends and, as some put it, “elsewhere.”

lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — The Denver Broncos and quarterback Peyton Manning are winning, a fall tradition in Colorado as expected as the changing aspen leaves. It is the way they are winning under their new coach, Gary Kubiak, that has agitated their perpetually fevered fan base.

headline: Terry Rosenbaum, Teacher Who Was Fired After Defying McCarthy, Dies at 97
abstract: Mr. Rosenbaum’s career in education was cut short after he helped in an attempt to indict a police officer in 1951 and attracted Senator Joseph R. McCarthy’s attention.

headline: As Young Players Surge, Birdie Becomes the New Par
abstract: The Gym Rat Pack, a group of top golfers in their 20s, has taken Tiger Woods’s athleticism and raised the competition a notch.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Since the United States Open in mid-June, Jason Day’s cumulative score in PGA Tour events is 101 under par. With a 61 here and a couple of 63s there, Day has turned what used to be regarded as a four-day marathon into a four-round sprint.

headline: Court Conundrum: Offenders Who Can’t Pay, or Won’t
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: A surreptitious recording made in a Georgia courtroom touches on a relatively unexamined question in the legal system, at a time when fine-collection strategies are under increasing scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: BOWDON, Ga. — A few weeks ago, a courtroom cellphone video came to light in which Richard A. Diment, the longtime Municipal Court judge here, threatened to jail traffic offenders who failed to come up with enough money to apply to their fines. “Until you get $300 here tonight, you won’t be able to leave,” he told one defendant.

headline: Hospitals Devastated in Syria, War-Wounded Seek Treatment in Jordan
abstract: More people injured in the Syrian war are seeking treatment in Jordan, where health care facilities are more secure and a new reconstructive surgery hospital opened this month.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Mohammad Smarat sat gazing at the few plants sprouting outside the entrance of the white stone hospital here, recalling how he had collapsed in a sea of green fields after getting shot.

headline: Bill Clinton Blames G.O.P. and Press for Wife’s Email Woes
abstract: In a CNN interview, President Bill Clinton said of the furor over Hillary Rodham Clinton’s emails, “I have never seen so much expended on so little.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton blamed Republicans who hope to undercut his wife’s presidential chances and a voracious political news media uninterested in substance for the furor surrounding Hillary Rodham Clinton’s use of a private email account and server while she was secretary of state.

headline: FIFA’s Captain Clings to the Helm of His Sinking Ship
abstract: FIFA president Sepp Blatter has hinted he might try to extend his reign, even as a corruption scandal engulfs the organization, which apparently lacks an internal candidate free of controversy to replace him.
lead_paragraph: When Sepp Blatter was re-elected president of FIFA this spring, he trotted out one of his favorite metaphors. In his 17th year in charge of the organization, and brushing aside a raging corruption scandal, Mr. Blatter boasted that he would navigate FIFA’s rocky waters and guide world soccer’s governing body safely to the shore.
