lead_paragraph: At the Cathedral Basilica of SS. Peter and Paul in Philadelphia, Pope Francis offered solutions for the problems facing the church in a rapidly changing society.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Announces Project to Connect Refugee Camps to the Internet
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The connectivity ambitions are at the center of Mr. Zuckerberg’s advocacy effort, Internet.org, whose principal goal is to offer Internet access to about four billion people who cannot afford it.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive of Facebook, promoted access to the Internet as “an enabler of human rights” and a “force for peace” on Saturday, as he announced that his company would help the United Nations bring Internet connections to refugee camps.

headline: Thousands Enter Syria to Join ISIS Despite Global Efforts
abstract: Nearly 30,000 foreign recruits have now poured into Syria to join the civil war, stark evidence that an international effort to enforce antiterrorism laws is not diminishing the militants’ ranks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly 30,000 foreign recruits have now poured into Syria, many to join the Islamic State, a doubling of volunteers in just the past 12 months and stark evidence that an international effort to tighten borders, share intelligence and enforce antiterrorism laws is not diminishing the ranks of new militant fighters.

headline: As Indonesia Prospers, Air Pollution Takes Toll
abstract: Years of robust economic growth have put more vehicles in reach and on roadways, and more hazardous pollutants in the air.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The young woman sat on a bench at a bus terminal here one recent morning, listening to her iPod beneath a bright blue sky. But despite the sunshine and a light breeze, the woman, Fety Dwiyanti, wore a face mask. She did not have the flu or a cold, though, she was just worried about what was getting into her lungs.

headline: Pope Francis’ Remarks at Independence Hall
keywords: ['Freedom of Religion', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: The English translation of Pope Francis’ speech at Independence Hall on Saturday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: The following is the English translation of Pope Francis’ remarks at Independence Hall on Saturday afternoon. His homily was prepared for delivery and released by the Vatican:

headline: As the Astros’ Season Wilts, a Texas Rivalry Blooms
abstract: Houston started September with a four-game lead on the Rangers in the American League West. By the end of play on Saturday, Texas led by three and a half.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As a quarterback and linebacker for his high school football team in LaMarque, Tex., Jeff Banister sometimes played at the Astrodome. His team would enter through the loading dock, and Banister figured he could sneak in the same way to watch baseball. He would pay to park in the stadium lot, and then make his move.

headline: A Goal of Opportunity
abstract: Hilary Knight, a top star, will be playing in the National Women’s Hockey League, the first major professional women’s hockey league to offer salaries.
lead_paragraph: Hilary Knight, a top star, will be playing in the National Women’s Hockey League, the first major professional women’s hockey league to offer salaries.

headline: Carrying the Puck, and a Fight for Recognition in the National Women’s Hockey League
abstract: Hilary Knight, 26, one of the world’s best players, is leading the charge toward mainstream visibility for women’s hockey.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Hilary Knight pulled her car into a grocery store parking lot in 2012, called home and began crying. After leading Wisconsin to two national titles in women’s hockey, she had packed her belongings and driven to Boston to train full time with the United States national team. But after watching a young employee collecting shopping carts, she felt almost envious — and lost.

headline: Money Flows With Refugees, and Life Jackets Fill the Shops
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Smuggling', 'Human Trafficking', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A multimillion-dollar shadow economy has developed in Turkey to profit from the massive human tide rushing toward Europe.
lead_paragraph: IZMIR, Turkey — For months, Ahmed Abdul-Hamid, a Palestinian from the Syrian city of Aleppo, tried and failed to cross the sea to start a new life in Europe. The Turkish police detained him. Smugglers tricked him. Once, his boat stalled and he had to swim back to shore, leaving him stranded and broke.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: Berra’s Cultural Impact: It Ain’t Over

headline: Brewers’ New G.M. Looks to Change Story Line
abstract: David Stearns, who at 30 is the majors’ youngest general manager, has a wealth of varied experiences in baseball since his early foray into writing.
lead_paragraph: David Stearns was 16 years old in the summer of 2001, which he spent with his father in Arizona. He loved sports and was already considering his career options. Journalism, perhaps, was worth a try.

headline: The Only Similarity Between Yogi Berra and Hitters Today: Doing What Works
abstract: Finding a current hitter in the mold of Berra, a free-swinger who rarely struck out, is no small task.
lead_paragraph: As the Yankees reminisced about Yogi Berra, a story from the clubhouse manager Rob Cucuzza resonated — not just because it displayed Berra’s wit.

headline: Reacting to Videos, Planned Parenthood Fights to Regain Initiative
abstract: The women’s reproductive health care provider has countered videos claiming it was “profiteering in baby parts” by gathering information from affiliates, hiring lawyers, crisis managers and video experts, and solidifying support.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The undercover videos were made over more than two years, yet Planned Parenthood was taken by surprise when the first one was posted online in July. Now one of the biggest crises in the 99-year history of the organization, the nation’s largest provider of women’s reproductive health care, could reach a climax this week as conservatives want to shut down the government rather than help fund the group.

headline: Mark My Words
abstract: Tom McCoy has a lot to say in this Sunday crossword.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — An unusual and intriguing idea by Tom McCoy, well carried out for the most part. We have 12 quotation marks in our grid surrounding famous quotes when going Across that double as ditto marks for the Down entries.

headline: 4 Youths Held in Death of Israeli Man Whose Car Was Hit by Rocks
abstract: According to Israeli police, the Palestinian youths confessed to throwing rocks at vehicles on the road in East Jerusalem where the man had driven into a light pole.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Four Palestinian youths have been detained in the death of an Israeli man who drove his vehicle into a light pole in East Jerusalem two weeks ago after it was hit by rocks, the Israeli police said Saturday.

headline: Jets’ Tight Ends Have a Job to Do, but Few Passes to Catch
abstract: Kellen Davis and Jeff Cumberland, primarily blockers in the new offensive coordinator Chan Gailey’s system, are prepared to capitalize when their numbers are finally called.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Aside from his Jets teammates and coaches, Kellen Davis said, the only person he talks football with is his wife, Jillian. She loves the sport, knows the sport, and so she has noticed that her husband has been targeted only one time during the first two games. Which is one more than the Jets’ other tight end, Jeff Cumberland.

headline: Eagles at Jets Matchup
abstract: As soon as the Eagles’ Darren Sproles, listed at 5 feet 6 inches and 190 pounds, enters the game, he becomes the smallest player on the field. And the most dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Eagles (0-2) at Jets (2-0)

headline: Politics and Philosophy Clash Where the Pope Urges an Embrace of Refugees
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: While Pope Francis, visiting the United States, challenged Americans to embrace a more open mind-set toward newcomers, some of the candidates for president are viewing the issue of resettling refugees here with indifference, concern and resistance.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis challenged Americans last week to accept “the stranger in our midst” and reject a “mind-set of hostility” toward newcomers. But his invocation of the millions of Syrian and other Middle East refugees, a relatively small number of whom have been resettled in the United States, has been met with indifference or resistance by many in the 2016 presidential field.

headline: Shifting Direction, Kerry Aims to Include Iran in Efforts to End the Conflict in Syria
abstract: The secretary of State reached out to the Iranians at the United Nations on Saturday despite concerns about the country’s support for the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Secretary of State John Kerry sought on Saturday to draw Iran into the search for a political solution to the Syrian conflict as he began a week of diplomacy over the brutal fighting there.

headline: U.S. Is Struggling in Its Effort to Build an Afghan Air Force
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft']
abstract: Efforts to build an effective air force began late, and, in the view of some Afghan officials, have gone nowhere, even as the Afghans fight the Taliban mostly alone.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Col. Qalandar Shah Qalandari, Afghanistan’s most decorated pilot, recently took command of what was meant to be the building blocks of his country’s new air force: a squadron of shiny American-made attack helicopters, intended to solve the chronic lack of close air support for Afghan troops.

headline: Canada Revokes Citizenship of Bomb Plot Organizer
abstract: A controversial new law was used to strip the citizenship of Zakaria Amara, who is serving a life sentence for his role in a failed 2006 bombing plot in Toronto.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The government of Canada used a controversial new law to revoke the citizenship of one of the organizers of a failed 2006 Toronto bombing plot. The National Post, a Toronto newspaper, reported on Saturday that the man, Zakaria Amara, had received a letter telling him about the decision at the prison where he is serving a life term.

headline: After Nine-Year Wait, the Mets Are Returning to the Postseason
abstract: Eight years after an epic collapse that scarred the team and its fans, the Mets put at least a few of their demons to rest by winning the National League East title.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Between pitches in the ninth inning, David Wright kept turning and looking around Great American Ball Park, trying to soak up as much as he could. His team had not made the playoffs in nine years, and the last time, he was so young that he had taken it for granted. He wanted to remember the celebration vividly this time.

headline: Russia and Estonia Swap Prisoners Accused of Spying
abstract: Russia’s Federal Security Service said it handed over an Estonian security officer detained by Russia last year in exchange for a former Estonian official who was arrested in 2012.
lead_paragraph: TALLINN, Estonia — Russia and Estonia on Saturday exchanged two prisoners who had been convicted of espionage, carrying out the swap on a bridge at a border post between the countries.

headline: Yankees Get Just Enough Offense to Beat the White Sox
abstract: Starter Adam Warren had a strong outing, but the Yankees’ batters continued to struggle with the regular season winding down.
lead_paragraph: As Alex Rodriguez was standing on first base in the fourth inning Saturday, Chicago White Sox first baseman Jose Abreu stood next to him laughing. Perhaps Abreu was in on the joke.

headline: Streets Closed to Cars for Pope Francis’ Visit Transform Philadelphia
abstract: Security measures have effectively turned the urban core of one of America’s biggest cities into a peaceful, pedestrian-only village.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The group from Iglesia Católico de San Jose in Asheboro, N.C., began its trip to Philadelphia at about 8 p.m. on Friday. Riding in a convoy of vans and a bus, the worshipers — about 180 people in all, most of them Mexican immigrants — drove through the night.

headline: Review: Kanye West Shines Light on His Darkest Hour
abstract: The rapper revisited the album that reshaped the sound of contemporary hip-hop, “808s & Heartbreak,” with two shows at the Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — We are living in an age of Kanye West’s bliss. It wasn’t always clear that we’d get here.

headline: First Ladies Reveal Name of ‘Precious’ Panda Cub
abstract: Michelle Obama and Peng Liyuan of China revealed the National Zoo’s youngest panda would be called Bei Bei.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While the presidents of China and the United States held closed-door talks, the first ladies of both nations dealt with another international matter: announcing the National Zoo’s month-old giant panda cub — Bei Bei.

headline: Pope Francis Visits: Day 8
abstract: On the final leg of his first trip to the United States, Pope Francis called religious freedom a “fundamental right” and laid out a broad and tolerant vision of what it should be.
lead_paragraph: On the final leg of his first trip to the United States, Pope Francis called religious freedom a “fundamental right” and laid out a broad and tolerant vision of what it should be.

headline: In Case You Missed It: Top Articles of the Week
abstract: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from Sept. 18 to 24.
lead_paragraph: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from Sept. 18 to 24.

headline: Cuomo, Eulogizing Slain Aide, Deplores Violence and Urges Tough Gun Laws
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Gun Control', 'West Indian-American Day', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Mr. Cuomo gave an impassioned speech at the funeral of Carey W. Gabay, a lawyer in his administration who died after being shot during a burst of gunfire between rival gangs in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, during a fiery eulogy on Saturday for a lawyer in his administration who died after being shot in the head, implored New Yorkers to carry on the slain man’s mission by reforming schools, fixing public housing and, above all, demanding stronger federal gun laws.

headline: Jordan Spieth Is a Round Away From a Fantastic Finish
abstract: Spieth’s eight-under-par 202 through 54 holes left him with a one-stroke lead over Henrik Stenson in the Tour Championship.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — On one of Jordan Spieth’s shoulders rests an imaginary people pleaser, whispering into his ear to stay humble, be polite and do right by his team and his burgeoning group of supporters. It is counterbalanced by the fiery competitor that rests on Spieth’s other shoulder, exhorting him to never back off or down, to go for the jugular.

headline: Mets Live Down a Tortured September History
abstract: They have rarely succeeded when a division title or a playoff berth has been decided in the final games of the regular season.
lead_paragraph: On the afternoon of Sept. 23, 1998, with the bases loaded and two outs in the bottom of the ninth inning, a Chicago Cubs outfielder named Brant Brown settled under a lazy fly ball hit by Geoff Jenkins of the Milwaukee Brewers.

headline: Partnership Aims to Bolster Local Health Care Providers
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Ebola Virus', 'Philanthropy', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A collaboration of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the World Bank and the World Health Organization will focus on medical care in poor and middle-income countries.
lead_paragraph: Supported by one of the world’s leading philanthropies, a new partnership was announced Saturday during a United Nations development meeting aimed at improving health in poor and middle-income countries by helping to strengthen their primary care providers.

headline: President Xi Jinping of China Pledges $2 Billion to Fight Poverty
abstract: Mr. Xi told the United Nations that China would pledge $2 billion as an initial investment for development assistance to the poorest countries.
lead_paragraph: President Xi Jinping told the United Nations on Saturday that China would pledge $2 billion as an initial investment for development assistance to the poorest countries.

headline: Mets Go From Doldrums of Summer to Dreams of Fall
abstract: To sit in the stands at Citi Field in the listless days of July was to watch the Mets’ offense flat-line. Credit for a turnaround goes to the players, and to four impossibly young and strong starting arms.
lead_paragraph: On the 14th pitch of the ninth inning, the Mets’ closer, Jeurys Familia, dropped a nasty, skidding, mid-90s tailing pitch of that sort that makes mature professional hitters look like helpless Little Leaguers.

headline: The Best Moments in College Football This Week
abstract: A look at some of the top story lines from the fourth week of the 2015 college football season.
lead_paragraph: DREW BROWN Nebraska’s sophomore kicker tied an N.C.A.A. record for field goals in a half, with five, as the host Huskers defeated Southern Mississippi, 36-28. Brown’s first-half kicks came from 29, 27, 40, 22 and 50 yards.

headline: 1915: Russian Cavalry Entraps Enemy
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Fighting of extraordinary violence continues in Russia in 1915.
lead_paragraph: PETROGRAD — Fighting of extraordinary violence continues in the neighborhood of Dvinsk, where the Russian cavalry has just gained an important success, involving the destruction of a strong enemy column which was advancing near Lake Tchighvi. The Germans, who were numerically superior and supported by powerful artillery, were pressing hotly, and the Russians cleverly retreated into the lake region, a veritable labyrinth, with which they alone were familiar.

headline: In Vicious Fire Season, an Endurance Test for California Crews
abstract: Thousands of firefighters have worked around the clock, battling exhaustion, to try to contain flames that have swept through vast acreage.

After they spend days hacking dead brush and setting defensive fires across flaming mountains, their 24-hour rest breaks are cut short when a new fire rears up.

headline: 1965: Jesuit’s Chief Says Atheism Invades Church
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archive: The head of the Jesuists warns against a “new godless society.”
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — The head of the Jesuits, the most powerful order in the Roman Catholic Church, today [Sept. 27] said that a ‘‘new godless society’’ now holds ‘‘almost complete sway in international organizations, in financial circles and in the field of mass communications: press, cinema, radio, and television.’’ Father Pedro Arrupe, known as the ‘‘black pope’’ after his black robes and considerable power as the order’s superior-general, said that the ‘‘hidden poison’’ of atheism was operating inside the Catholic Church itself. His remarks, made to the Vatican Ecumenical Council during a debate on atheism, touched off an immediate controversy among his listeners, many of whom said he had gone too far.

lead_paragraph: Tom Brady joined an exclusive club when he threw his 400th career touchdown pass during the Patriots’ game against the Jaguars on Sunday. headline: Next Up From Pope Francis? An Album, of Course
abstract: After his whirlwind United States tour, Pope Francis will release a Vatican-approved album, which features his speeches set to rock and sacred music.
lead_paragraph: Usually the tour comes after the album. For Pope Francis, however, it’s the other way around: He is scheduled to release an album, “Wake Up!,” on Nov. 27, following his whirlwind United States trip, during which he has been greeted by hundreds of thousands of well-wishers. The album features the pope’s speeches set to rock, pop, and Gregorian chants, and will raise money for a support fund for refugees.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (ABC) QUANTICO The Bollywood superstar Priyanka Chopra subdues her glamour to play Alex Parrish, an F.B.I. trainee suspected of masterminding the biggest attack on New York since Sept. 11, in this thriller from Josh Safran, an executive producer of CW’s “Gossip Girl” and NBC’s “Smash.” Like those shows, “Quantico” features an attractive cast with a bit of something for everyone: a tough Southern belle (Johanna Braddy), a compromised Mormon (Brian J. Smith), a complex Muslim (Yasmine Al Massri) and a conservative gay recruit (Tate Ellington). Then there’s the no-nonsense mentor (Aunjanue Ellis), who immediately gives them a test: Find out a dark secret about a classmate within 24 hours or get sent packing. With its plot twists, flashbacks and Olivia Pope-like back story, “Quantico” feels like a Shonda Rhimes creation (“Grey’s Anatomy,” “Scandal”). “If great TV takes many hands to make, competently O.K. TV like ‘Quantico’ takes even more — it doesn’t do much to hide its borrowings,” James Poniewozik wrote in The New York Times. “What remains to be seen is if ‘Quantico’ is no more than what it appears to be or if there’s a distinctive terror story underneath, like a mole with an exceptionally pretty disguise.” (Image: Ms. Chopra.)

headline: Review: ‘Il Trovatore’ and ‘Anna Bolena’ Showcase Courage and Command at the Met
abstract: Dmitri Hovorostovsky, the Russian baritone with a brain tumor, is appearing in “Il Trovatore,” and Sondra Radvanovsky displays power in “Anna Bolena.”
lead_paragraph: Opera thrives on passion. Fans cherish singers who give their all, those artists who of course understand the techniques and styles of the genre, yet, when it counts, seem to put their lives on the line in their performances.

headline: Review: ‘Animals’ Asks When, and If, the Party Has to End
abstract: Emma Jane Unsworth’s novel, about friends whose life of drinking and doing drugs is threatened by maturity’s on-set, is much more than it initially seems.
lead_paragraph: For a moment in Emma Jane Unsworth’s new book, “Animals,” it appears we’ve unwittingly blundered into some sort of millennial version of “Bright Lights, Big City.” Here is the narrator, using the second person in the first sentence, addressing us as co-conspirators from the depths of an epic hangover.

headline: Review: Global Citizen Festival, Including Beyoncé and Pearl Jam, Mixes Music and Activism
abstract: Global Citizen works with governments and nongovernmental organizations toward the 17 “Sustainable Development Goals” just adopted by the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: A lot of sensitive-guy earnestness surrounding a burst of female pop precision and dazzle — that was this year’s Global Citizen Festival on Saturday on the Great Lawn of Central Park. The pop came from Beyoncé: singing, dancing, beaming and ending up just as hardheaded and socially conscious as the festival’s other headliners — Pearl Jam, Ed Sheeran and Coldplay.

headline: Some Players Relax After Mets’ Party, but Manager Ponders Playoff Strategy
abstract: Manager Terry Collins allowed several veterans to sit out a victory over the Reds as he focused on the Mets’ postseason rotation and the possibility of gaining home-field advantage.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — When the Mets arrived at the visitors’ clubhouse Sunday morning, the scent of champagne still hung in the air and the carpet was still wet from their celebration the night before, after they had clinched their first postseason berth since 2006. Many players trudged in just after 11 a.m., with bags under their eyes and iced coffees in their hands.

headline: Margaret Atwood, Digital Deep-Diver, Writes ‘The Heart Goes Last’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Ms. Atwood’s latest novel, “The Heart Goes Last,” grew out of an e-book series and revisits her signature themes.
lead_paragraph: Like a mad scientist from one of her futuristic novels, Margaret Atwood is an avid tinkerer who seems willing to experiment with almost any digital technology.

headline: Luis Severino Pitches Yankees a Step Closer to a Playoff Berth
abstract: Over nine of his 10 starts, the Yankees’ 21-year-old rookie right-hander has an earned run average of 1.87.
lead_paragraph: As Dustin Ackley recently contemplated his future with the Yankees, he did not need to examine any tea leaves. Outfielders Brett Gardner, Jacoby Ellsbury and Carlos Beltran are all signed for next season, to the tune of $49.6 million. If Mark Teixeira, who is owed $23.1 million next year, cannot stay healthy at first base, Greg Bird has proved to be a capable replacement.

headline: Xi Jinping Vows to ‘Reaffirm’ China’s Commitment to Women’s Rights
abstract: The Chinese president’s remarks came at a United Nations conference Sunday where world leaders promised to change their laws and practices to advance gender equality.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Xi Jinping of China, under pressure over the jailing of women’s rights activists, promised on Sunday to “reaffirm our commitment to gender equality and women’s development,” as Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations gently reminded world leaders to protect “human rights defenders.”

headline: “Toy Story” Boy
abstract: Dan Bischof, ably assisted by — wait for it — Jeff Chen, makes his New York Times crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — I first heard the term “supervocalics” in a Facebook group for word lovers, and have been fascinated by the concept ever since. A supervocalic is a word or phrase that uses all of the vowels — A, E, I, O, and U but not Y — exactly once (note that “supervocalic” itself is one such word). A eurysupervocalic, as proposed by writer Eric Chaikin, is a word or phrase that uses all of the vowels, including Y, exactly once (although the word “eurysupervocalic” itself fails the test because of the repeated ‘u’).

headline: Documentary to Feature Hong Kong Democracy Protests
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: “Freedom for the Wolf,” set for release next year, features the demonstrations as an essential part of a global struggle against the rise of “illiberal democracy” — what the director calls “voting without rights.”
lead_paragraph: Read in Chinese | 点击查看本文中文版

headline: Victory for Catalan Separatists
abstract: On the evening of an election in Catalonia, separatists celebrated as exit polls gave them a majority of seats in the region’s Parliament.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of an election in Catalonia, separatists celebrated as exit polls gave them a majority of seats in the region’s Parliament.

headline: The Migrant Crisis in Europe: Readers’ Questions Answered
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: New York Times correspondents and editors answer readers questions about the European migrant crisis. Submit your questions.
lead_paragraph: As thousands of migrants seek refuge in Europe, and governments continue to struggle with how to receive them, The New York Times asked readers for their questions on the crisis. Here are some answers, and a way for you to submit your questions.

headline: Questions Around Michel Platini Keep FIFA’s Future Murky
abstract: Although Mr. Platini, widely considered Sepp Blatter’s likely successor, was not implicated by Swiss investigators, that he was interviewed could complicate FIFA’s presidential race.
lead_paragraph: ZURICH — Even as Swiss investigators were interviewing Sepp Blatter on Friday afternoon, the discussion among some top soccer officials turned from the past to the future. What happens to Mr. Blatter is, of course, a significant story — the two criminal charges he may face carry the potential for jail time — but his ultimate fate with regard to FIFA is largely unchanged.

headline: A Ferry to the Immigrant Wall of Honor
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Museums', 'Statue of Liberty']
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A woman took her sons to see her father’s name engraved on a memorial at Ellis Island, and recounted his family’s difficult voyage from Italy.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2015)', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: For spring/summer 2016, the fashion house paired its usual motif with friendly footwear.
lead_paragraph: For spring/summer 2016, the fashion house paired its usual motif with friendly footwear.

headline: Clues to U.S. Relationships Can Be Seen in U.N. Body Language
abstract: At the United Nations on Monday, President Obama will navigate a sea of world leaders with whom he has varying levels of rapport, including President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
lead_paragraph: As President Obama makes his way through the halls and chamber of the United Nations with all the other world leaders attending the General Assembly this week, it will be a little like a high school reunion with motorcades.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Sept. 28
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Jonathan Papelbon Attacks Bryce Harper, and Nationals Manager Fails to Send Signal
abstract: Closer Jonathan Papelbon lunged at the Nationals star Bryce Harper in the dugout, then Manager Matt Williams allowed Papelbon to go back out and pitch.
lead_paragraph: We have a winner for the most ridiculous decision in the major leagues this season, and nothing else is close.

headline: Monday’s Matchup: Chiefs at Packers
abstract: The Packers’ offense should be as close to full strength as it will get this season, and that will be too much for the Chiefs to handle.
lead_paragraph: Chiefs (1-1) at Packers (2-0)

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic Performs Esa-Pekka Salonen’s ‘L.A. Variations’
abstract: The Philharmonic’s subscription season finally began with Mr. Salonen’s 1996 showpiece, part of a brief program conducted by Alan Gilbert at David Geffen Hall.
lead_paragraph: Esa-Pekka Salonen has started seeing a new orchestra, but on his first dates he’s still talking about an old flame. After three film screenings and a gala, the New York Philharmonic’s subscription season finally began on Friday with Mr. Salonen’s “L.A. Variations,” part of a brief and underwhelming program conducted by Alan Gilbert at David Geffen Hall.

headline: Obama Tackles Poverty and Sexism in U.N. Speech
abstract: Calling for better treatment of women around the world as he addressed the General Assembly, President Obama said he had no patience for excuses about discrimination.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Obama told a conclave of world leaders here on Sunday that millions of people should be saved through collective action to end extreme poverty and deadly infections, but he did not announce new initiatives to achieve those ends.

headline: Arizona Cardinals Embarrass Colin Kaepernick and the 49ers
abstract: Kaepernick has two interceptions returned for touchdowns in the first half of a 47-7 loss.
lead_paragraph: If there was any doubt that the Arizona Cardinals had passed the San Francisco 49ers for superiority in the N.F.C. West, it was erased when two of Colin Kaepernick’s first four passes were intercepted and returned for touchdowns.

headline: Data on Spending, Trevor Noah Starts and Tesla Unveils an S.U.V.
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: This week, consumer spending and personal income for August will be reported, Trevor Noah will take over “The Daily Show,” and Tesla will unveil an S.U.V.
lead_paragraph: On Monday morning, the Commerce Department will report the latest data on consumer spending and personal income in August. Wall Street is looking for healthy gains for consumers, with income up 0.4 percent and consumption rising 0.3 percent.

headline: At U.N., Obama Focuses on Corruption, Inequality and Other Roadblocks to Sustainable Development
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Global Warming', 'Income Inequality', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Poverty', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: President Obama pinpoints bad governance and gender inequality as big barriers to achieving 17 U.N. sustainable development goals.
lead_paragraph: President Obama today joined the parade of leaders addressing a United Nations session hailing the adoption of 17 Sustainable Development Goals for 2030, which range from extremely lofty (“end poverty in all its forms everywhere”) to doable but difficult (“sustainably manage forests, combat desertification, halt and reverse land degradation, halt biodiversity loss”). Explore all of the goals here.

headline: Silicon Valley Lawyer, Gary Reback, Takes Antitrust Fight to Europe
abstract: Gary Reback, who persuaded the federal government to bring a case against Microsoft in the 1990s, is now pursuing a case against Google.
lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — In the 1990s, Gary Reback was known as Silicon Valley’s dragon slayer, a lawyer who persuaded the Justice Department to sue Microsoft, accusing it of abusing its dominant position in desktop computers. Newspapers and magazines called him an “instigator” who was “Bill Gates’s worst nightmare.”

headline: Marla Krolikowski, Transgender Teacher Fired for Insubordination, Dies at 62
abstract: In a well-publicized lawsuit, Ms. Krolikowski sued St. Francis Preparatory School in Queens for dismissing her over her appearance.
lead_paragraph: Marla Krolikowski, who was fired from her job as a teacher at a Roman Catholic high school in Queens for insubordination after acknowledging in 2011 that she was transgender, died on Sept. 20 in Oceanside, N.Y. She was 62.

headline: VW’s Pitch to Americans Relied on Fun and Fantasy
abstract: The disgraced German automaker’s commercials, long known for their humor, promised diesel cars that were fun, quiet, efficient and, critically, clean.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen’s big push in the United States revolved around making Americans love driving a diesel car again — a challenging task given the poor image diesel had endured since the 1980s.

headline: A Smile Came Back to Prince Fielder, and an Award May Follow
abstract: Known for his joyous approach to baseball, Fielder has returned from injury to become a force in the Rangers lineup and a leading contender for the A.L. Comeback Player of the Year Award.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A veteran American League slugger was gone from the scene last season. His return, as a force at designated hitter in the middle of his lineup, has lifted his team into playoff position. He is enjoying the game again and has even been a clubhouse leader. He is the best choice for the A.L. Comeback Player of the Year Award.

headline: Oregon’s Loss to Utah Heralds Changing of the Pac-12 Guard
abstract: The Ducks, the conference’s resident power, sustained their second loss of the season, and some wonder if the program is fading.
lead_paragraph: It was a classic Saturday night at Oregon’s home field, Autzen Stadium. The game started slow, then exploded into a rout in the second and third quarters. There was a streak of six unanswered scores, all touchdowns. The victor dominated with more than 500 total yards in a 62-20 thrashing.

headline: Brands Woo Millennials With a Wink, an Emoji or Whatever It Takes
abstract: Marketers are resorting to emojis, outrageous stunts and elaborate events to reach a demographic that has little tolerance for traditional advertising.
lead_paragraph: David Perel spends at least an hour a day on his iPhone 6. He watches live sports on television and tries to catch “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” on CBS, but he rarely tunes in to prime-time shows. He does not have a Netflix subscription, but he is thinking hard about getting one.

headline: Haunted by Columbine
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Violence (Media and Entertainment)', 'Gun Control']
abstract: The killing of 12 students and a teacher at Columbine High School in 1999 continues to shape how we view and understand school shootings today.
lead_paragraph: The killing of 12 students and a teacher at Columbine High School in 1999 continues to shape how we view and understand school shootings today.

headline: When Columbine Is Invoked, Fears Tend to Overshadow Facts
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Many people assume school shootings have been happening ever more frequently, but the reality is not simple, and evidence can be murky.
lead_paragraph: It takes neither a clairvoyant nor a morbid personality to sense that, in time, the nightmare will return. We have already seen it often enough: Someone goes berserk and shoots up a school — typically a young man who turns a gun on himself after taking children’s lives, shattering families and leaving a tormented country to ponder how things went terribly wrong. Once again.

headline: The Daily News Layoffs and Digital Shift May Signal the Tabloid Era’s End
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Newspapers', 'News and News Media']
abstract: To veteran media watchers, the layoffs mean that the recent attrition at newspapers across the country has finally arrived in force in the nation’s media capital.
lead_paragraph: When it was over and the feature page was gone, dozens of reporters had been fired and the morning assignment editor was shown the door only minutes after handing out the morning’s first assignments, The Daily News — or what was left of it — was in a state of shock.

headline: David Wright, Aching for Glory, Is Finally Returning to the Playoffs
abstract: For Wright, who missed most of the season rehabilitating his back and now spends hours stretching and exercising before games, a return to the postseason is worth all the work.
lead_paragraph: When David Wright wakes up, his back usually feels stiff. Cranky, as he says. Just walking around his house or down the street, he feels the crankiness, and the only way to help soothe it, Wright has found, is his elaborate pregame routine.

headline: Chinese President Pushes Gender Equality
abstract: At a United Nations conference of global leaders, President Xi Jinping of China proposed a plan to support women’s development worldwide.
lead_paragraph: At a United Nations conference of global leaders, President Xi Jinping of China proposed a plan to support women’s development worldwide.

headline: U.S. Investigating Contract Awards in Buffalo Turnaround Project
abstract: Prosecutors are said to be scrutinizing a request for proposals that would have favored a company whose chief executive had made big donations to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors investigating Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s marquee program to revitalize Buffalo’s economy have been examining how the government-funded projects were awarded, and whether state elected officials played a role in choosing who would benefit from the major infusion of funds.

headline: Jeb Bush Readies Fund-Raising Push Ahead of Deadline
abstract: Mr. Bush’s campaign has invited leading donors to its Miami headquarters on Monday for a fundraising call-a-thon, part of an effort to maximize their haul for this quarter.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush’s campaign has invited leading donors to its Miamiheadquarters on Monday for a fundraising call-a-thon, part of a finalpush to maximize their haul for this quarter ahead of the end-of-month finance deadline.

headline: Katy Perry Steps Up Fight to Buy Los Angeles Convent
abstract: Ms. Perry last week sued Dana Hollister, a developer and rival would-be purchaser, whom she accused of interfering with her contractual and other rights.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Stepping up her fight to buy an eight-acre convent and retreat house here, the singer Katy Perry last week sued a rival would-be purchaser, whom she accused of interfering with her contractual and other rights.

headline: Marshawn Lynch Injury Forces New Seattle Seahawks to Step Up
abstract: Rookie Tyler Lockett returned a kickoff 105 yards, and tight end Jimmy Graham scored a touchdown as the Seahawks beat the Bears.
lead_paragraph: Marshawn Lynch did not appear on the Seattle Seahawks’ sideline until midway through the first quarter, and he could not remain healthy enough to stay in the entire game. But his teammates stepped up, helping ease the creeping fears caused by an 0-2 start for the two-time defending N.F.C. champions.

headline: Pope Departs, After Showing a Deft Touch
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: Francis demonstrated a nuanced political dexterity, effectively sidestepping the familiar framework of American debate while charting his own broader path.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Six days ago, Pope Francis landed in Washington for his first visit to the United States — a country that he did not know and that did not know him. He flew out Sunday night, having wowed Washington and New York, while leaving behind a downtown Philadelphia transformed into a “Francisville” of pilgrims, families and hawkers selling Francis swag.

headline: No Histrionics From Todd Bowles, Just an Even Keel After a Jets Loss
abstract: Todd Bowles, the Jets’ first-year head coach, handled Sunday’s 24-17 loss to Philadelphia in the same manner he handled an earlier victory: low-key, reminding fans that the season is a marathon.
lead_paragraph: After two impressive victories to start the season, I wondered how Todd Bowles, the Jets’ first-year head coach, would handle his team’s first loss of the season.

headline: Jordan Spieth Claims It All: Tournament, Cup, $10 Million and Top Ranking
abstract: Spieth completed a dream season by winning the Tour Championship and the FedEx Cup title to collect a $1.485 million check for the tournament and a $10 million bonus for the Cup victory.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The value of money was driven home to Jordan Spieth at a young age by his parents, who sent him off by himself to play in junior golf tournaments to foster his independence but also as a cost-saving measure. If he returned without his phone charger, as happened multiple times, or lost another item he could not do without, he had to dip into his savings to buy a replacement.

headline: ‘Spring Awakening’ Returns
abstract: Scenes from Deaf West Theater’s Broadway production.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from Deaf West Theater’s Broadway production.

headline: Review: In ‘Antigone’ at BAM, Agony and Despair in Inexorable Motion
abstract: Ivo van Hove’s doom-steeped production stars Juliette Binoche as the fatally rebellious daughter of the house of Oedipus.
lead_paragraph: A merciless sun blazes over Thebes in Ivo van Hove’s doom-steeped production of Sophocles’ “Antigone,” which opened on Sunday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with a highly distraught Juliette Binoche in the title role. As conceived by the set and lighting designer Jan Versweyveld, this ferocious orb dominates the back wall of the stage at the Harvey Theater like an all-seeing eye of fire, one that judges and withers everything it surveys.

headline: Review: ‘Spring Awakening’ by Deaf West Theater Brings a New Sensation to Broadway
abstract: Any qualms anyone might have about this being a premature revival will vanish when the cast of both hearing and deaf actors floods the stage.
lead_paragraph: One of the great musicals of the last decade was born anew on Sunday, when the thrillingly inventive Deaf West Theater production of “Spring Awakening” opened on Broadway at the Brooks Atkinson Theater. Any qualms theater-lovers might have about this being a premature, whiplash-inducing revival — the original  closed in 2009, after all — will vanish like frost in strong sunlight when the young cast of both hearing and deaf actors floods the stage.

headline: ‘Fear the Walking Dead’ Recap: I Saw the Devil’s Face
abstract: On Sunday, the last semblance of order began to splinter and people took matters into their own hands.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 5, “Cobalt”

headline: Giving Up the Bench in Hopes of Bringing Justice to the Bronx
abstract: Justice Darcel D. Clark of the State Supreme Court was nominated for district attorney in her native borough, decades after leaving the housing project she grew up in.
lead_paragraph: When Darcel D. Clark left a Bronx housing project for Boston College, and later Howard University School of Law, she did not forget the struggles of those she grew up with. She once told her college roommate that if she could do something about the drug deals and the crimes in the Bronx, she would.

headline: A Columbine Student Recalls the Attack
abstract: Retro Report Voices: Sean Graves was told he would never walk again after being shot during the attack at Columbine High School. This is what happened next.
lead_paragraph: Retro Report Voices: Sean Graves was told he would never walk again after being shot during the attack at Columbine High School. This is what happened next.

headline: ‘Masters of Sex’ Recap: A Finale That Tries, Vainly, for the Big Moment
abstract: A series in search of character consistency.
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 12: “Full Ten Count”

headline: Pope Francis Visits: Day 9
abstract: Pope Francis wrapped up his two-day visit to Philadelphia, where he spoke on the matter of sexual abuse in the Roman Catholic Church before he flew back to Rome.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis wrapped up his two-day visit to Philadelphia, where he spoke on the matter of sexual abuse in the Roman Catholic Church before he flew back to Rome.

headline: Review: LoftOpera, Finding Glamour Amid the Gritty, Performs Verdi
abstract: The company offered five selections from Verdi operas, contrasting the rough-edged surroundings with vocal beauty and visual style.
lead_paragraph: Fresh from attending Verdi’s “Otello” at the glittering opening night gala of the Metropolitan Opera last week, the contrasts between that event and a production by an adventurous young company in Brooklyn seemed particularly striking. Indeed, as I walked down a desolate street in Bushwick trying to find the Muse, a warehouse where LoftOpera was presenting an evening of Verdi, I thought perhaps I had taken a wrong turn. But I soon arrived at the graffiti-covered exterior of the building, a circus training school that has become yet another unlikely space for opera in New York.

headline: The Best of Week 3 in the N.F.L.
abstract: The top performers and key injuries in the league this week.
lead_paragraph: Devonta Freeman had the unenviable task of filling in at running back against the Cowboys, who had allowed an N.F.L.-low 106 rushing yards. The test turned out to be not so tough, however: He ran for 141 yards and three scores in place of Tevin Coleman, helping the Falcons overcome three two-touchdown deficits. His final score, in the fourth quarter, gave Atlanta its first lead.

headline: In Quest for Global Presence, Netflix Acquires Rights to 3 More Shows
abstract: The streaming service plans to announce licensing deals for the CW telenovela “Jane the Virgin,” the CBS thriller “Zoo” and the USA drama “Colony.”
lead_paragraph: Netflix is trying to persuade TV companies that it’s a friend, not a foe.

headline: Limited Progress Seen Even as More Nations Step Up on Climate
abstract: The pledges to battle climate change would still allow the world to heat up to a level that is likely to produce catastrophes, scientists say.
lead_paragraph: The pledges that countries are making to battle climate change would still allow the world to heat up by more than 6 degrees Fahrenheit, a new analysis shows, a level that scientists say is likely to produce catastrophes ranging from food shortages to widespread extinctions of plant and animal life.

headline: Richard E. Rainwater, Billionaire Texas Dealmaker, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Rainwater made lucrative deals in real estate, entertainment and oil and was a family friend to the Bushes who helped George W. Bush make a modest fortune.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Richard E. Rainwater, a Texas billionaire who had a Midas touch for real estate, entertainment and oil and owned a piece of the Texas Rangers baseball team with George W. Bush, died on Sunday in Fort Worth. He was 71.

headline: Immigration’s Impact on U.S. Demographics
abstract: The changing face of immigration into the United States.
lead_paragraph: The changing face of immigration into the United States.

headline: Share of Immigrants in U.S. Nears Highs of Early 20th Century, Report Finds
abstract: A Pew Research Center report revealed major shifts in immigration to the United States since Congress passed the Immigration and Nationality Act a half-century ago.
lead_paragraph: In the 50 years since Congress broadly reconfigured immigration to open the country to newcomers from around the world, 59 million foreign-born people have come to the United States, more than quadrupling the number of immigrants who were in the country in 1965 and bringing their share of the population close to the peak of another great influx a century ago, according to a report published Monday by the Pew Research Center.

headline: What’s on TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6 P.M. (LMN) WINTER’S BONE (2010) Jennifer Lawrence, in the breakthrough role that earned her an Oscar nomination, portrays Ree Dolly, a teenager in the Ozarks of Missouri who goes in search of her meth-cooking father after he puts up the family home to cover his bail and disappears. But her efforts to find him place her in a terrible dilemma: either betray the code of silence that keeps her clan proudly on the wrong side of the law or face destitution. The harshness in Debra Granik’s “regional-realist morality tale,” based on Daniel Woodrell’s novel, “is not there to illuminate a sociological condition,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Something more primal, almost Greek in its archaic power, is at stake in ‘Winter’s Bone,’ and its visual and emotional starkness do not feel like simple badges of authenticity.” (Image: Ms. Lawrence.)

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, September 28, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “I deeply regret that some bishops failed in their responsibility to protect children. It is very disturbing to know that in some cases bishops even were abusers. I pledge to you that we will follow the path of truth wherever it may lead.”

headline: Corrections: September 28, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Monday, September 28, 2015.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Football, Cheerleading and Hometown Glory
abstract: After seeing the film “Bring It On,” the photographer Brian Finke began a project on cheerleading and football, two historically related, but increasingly independent, competitive sports.
lead_paragraph: In Texas, where football is an unofficial religion, a photography project documenting the sideline drama and athleticism of football and cheerleading would not be unwelcome.

headline: Taiwan Braces for Arrival of Powerful Typhoon Dujuan
abstract: The storm, which is bringing heavy rains and strong winds, is the second major typhoon to hit the region in less than two months.
lead_paragraph: Less than two months after Taiwan and eastern China were battered by Typhoon Soudelor, another strong storm is nearing the region, bringing powerful winds and heavy rains. Typhoon Dujuan  is expected to make landfall Monday evening in Taiwan, then head west toward the Chinese province of Fujian before weakening and moving inland.

headline: ‘Don’t Prolong the Pain and Confusion’: Readers Respond to an Unusual Divorce
abstract: A Modern Love column inspired a conversation among readers about the effects of divorce.
lead_paragraph: A Modern Love column inspired a conversation among readers about the effects of divorce.

headline: Congress Should Give the Government More Money for Wildfires
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Wildfires', 'Global Warming', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Forest fires need to be treated more like other natural disasters rather than as a continuing expense.
lead_paragraph: Wildfires that have burned more than eight million acres and are still raging in the West are draining the budgets of federal agencies and forcing them to divert money from essential environmental and land conservation programs to fight the fires. That is why Congress needs to start budgeting for forest fires in a different way, treating them more like natural disasters rather than a continuing expense. The Agriculture and Interior Departments have been making this case for some time, and it’s a good one.

headline: Close Formula One Cockpits, Save Lives
abstract: A certain romance in Formula One racing is no reason for our friends and colleagues to die.
lead_paragraph: JUSTIN WILSON, my friend, my colleague, the man with whom I first stood on top of an IndyCar podium, is dead. His death last month was preventable. We in the racing industry had the technology and ability to prevent his death and we chose not to.

headline: An Ambitious Development Agenda From the U.N.
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Poverty', 'Global Warming', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Millennium Development Goals', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Meeting the United Nations’ lofty goals will be tough in a weakened world economy. Still, much can be done with support from industrialized nations.
lead_paragraph: In the last 15 years, the world has made great progress in reducing poverty, in part because of eight targets known as Millennium Development Goals that the United Nations committed to in 2000. Each carried a 2015 deadline. One goal — of cutting extreme poverty by half as measured by the proportion of people living on less than $1.25 a day — was in fact met five years ahead of schedule. Maternal mortality was not cut by three-fourths, as the U.N. wanted, but it was cut nearly in half, no small achievement.

headline: The Need for an Accountable Border Patrol
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A number of cases raise questions about agents’ use of violence, and justify renewed calls for greater transparency from the agency.
lead_paragraph: José Antonio Elena Rodríguez was 16 when he was gunned down on a street in Nogales, Mexico, in October 2012. He was shot several times in the back by a United States Border Patrol agent, firing through the fence from Nogales, Ariz. The boy was unarmed; his family said he had been walking home from a basketball game.

headline: The Real Roots of ’70s Drug Laws
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Black anti-crime activism in the ’60s and ’70s helped pave the way for our current system of draconian drug laws and mass incarceration.
lead_paragraph: THE number of black males killed by police officers continues to rise: Michael Brown, Eric Garner, John Crawford III, Ezell Ford, Akai Gurley, Tamir Rice. But many more still die at the hands of black neighbors instead of the police. Yet today we rarely ask politicians to speak their names or recognize their dignity and worth.

headline: The Blackmail Caucus, a.k.a. the Republican Party

lead_paragraph: John Boehner was a terrible, very bad, no good speaker of the House. Under his leadership, Republicans pursued an unprecedented strategy of scorched-earth obstructionism, which did immense damage to the economy and undermined America’s credibility around the world.

headline: Pascal’s Wager 2.0
abstract: Pascal’s famous wager requires a choice between believing and not believing in God. But there’s more than one way not to believe.
lead_paragraph: One benefit of teaching introductory philosophy to undergraduates is that it lets you talk about philosophy with eager and intelligent people who do not come with predispositions formed by years of technical study. This semester, preparing for a philosophy seminar with first-year honors students at Notre Dame, I reread with fresh eyes one of philosophy’s best-known arguments for belief in God — Pascal’s wager.

headline: ‘Changing the Subject,’ by Sven Birkerts
abstract: In these impassioned essays, Birkerts warns that the power of language and literature to sustain the self is under threat from “the tidal inrush of digitized living.”
lead_paragraph: Sven Birkerts is an anxious man. By turns he is frightened, terrified, alarmed, filled with dread. On one occasion he shudders in his core; mostly he is just plain worried. What concerns him, a concern he is eager to transmit to us, is the rapid spread of computer, Internet and telephone technologies and more specifically what those technologies are doing to our minds. Forever glued to screens of one kind or another, clicking compulsively on the links others provide for us, we are losing the ability to concentrate, growing more itchy and agitated by the day, allowing our consciousness to be fragmented and dispersed. Our very selfhood is under threat as we are invited to think of achievement as a collective, rather than individual goal, a contribution to Wikipedia rather than a distinctive personal statement. At every step the Internet or GPS navigator puts us at a remove from the world and from our fellow human beings, deprives us of the agency we enjoyed when we had to go out and find things for ourselves rather than have them suggested to us. “Rewired,” as neuroscientists have now demonstrated, to adapt to the fitful back and forth of the web, our brains are no longer fit for the sustained attention that literature requires. Fewer young people are choosing to study the humanities. Fewer great works of art are being produced. There is a real risk of individuality being submerged in system. To make matters worse, a vast majority of people seem entirely happy with this state of affairs, to the point that anyone questioning the value of the new technologies is immediately deemed a Luddite if not a dinosaur.

headline: Sherry Turkle’s ‘Reclaiming Conversation’
abstract: Jonathan Franzen reviews a new book based on interviews with people who say they feel controlled by new technologies.
lead_paragraph: Sherry Turkle is a singular voice in the discourse about technology. She’s a skeptic who was once a believer, a clinical psychologist among the industry shills and the literary hand-wringers, an empiricist among the cherry-picking anecdotalists, a moderate among the extremists, a realist among the fantasists, a humanist but not a Luddite: a grown-up. She holds an endowed chair at M.I.T. and is on close collegial terms with the roboticists and affective-computing engineers who work there. Unlike Jaron Lanier, who bears the stodgy weight of being a Microsoft guy, or Evgeny Morozov, whose perspective is Belarussian, Turkle is a trusted and respected insider. As such, she serves as a kind of conscience for the tech world.

headline: Photos of the Super Blood Moon’s Rare Appearance
abstract: A rare astronomical phenomenon produced a moon that appeared slightly bigger than usual and had a reddish hue.
lead_paragraph: In a rare astronomical phenomenon Sunday night, people around the world witnessed a so-called supermoon, which occurs when the moon is closest to Earth in its orbit. The event coincided with a lunar eclipse, leaving the moon in Earth’s shadow. The combination hadn’t occurred since 1982 and won’t happen again until 2033.

headline: Testing Neurons With Ultrasound
keywords: ['Worms', 'Ultrasonic Imaging and Sonograms', 'Brain', 'Fiber Optics', 'Nerves and Nervous System']
abstract: If the technique works in more complex animals, it would mean a noninvasive way to do basic research, and perhaps even treat brain circuits.
lead_paragraph: Turning certain brain cells on and off with light — a technique called optogenetics — is one of the most important tools in neuroscience. It allows scientists to test basic ideas about how brains work. But because waves of visible light don’t penetrate living tissue well, the technique requires the insertion of a conduit for the light into the brain — a very thin fiber optic cable.

headline: 1915: Allies Stand Behind Balkans
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain refuses to tolerate Bulgarian force in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sir Edward Grey made an important statement in the House of Commons this afternoon [Sept. 28] on the Balkan situation. He declared, replying to Sir P. Magnus, that Great Britain had no hostility toward the Bulgarian people, but, on the contrary, entertained a feeling of warm sympathy toward their aspirations. If, however, the mobilization in Bulgaria was not for defensive purposes and if Bulgaria assumed an aggressive attitude on the side of the enemy, Great Britain was prepared to give its Balkan friends all the support in its power, in concert with Britain’s Allies. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 29, 1915

headline: A Very British Tea Party at the Spotted Pig
abstract: At her friend April Bloomfield’s New York City restaurant, Claire Ptak celebrates the stateside launch of her Violet Cakes cookbook.
lead_paragraph: Though she’s American, Claire Ptak loves a good British tea service. “The entire ritual is greater than the sum of its parts,” explains Ptak, the owner and chef behind London’s popular Violet Cakes bakery and cafe, before listing her favorite components: “the scones with cream and jam, and of course the dainty little sandwiches. The top plate of perfect cake is exciting too.” It’s rather fitting then that tomorrow, to celebrate the stateside debut of Ptak’s “The Violet Bakery Cookbook” ($30, Ten Speed Press), the California-born baker will import a touch of that Brit tradition to New York, with a tea party at the Spotted Pig.

headline: Joyce Mitchell, Ex-Prison Employee, Is Sentenced
abstract: Ms. Mitchell, who had pleaded guilty to helping two inmates escape from the Clinton Correctional Facility in upstate New York, was sentenced Monday to at least two years and four months in prison.
lead_paragraph: A former prison employee who admitted to helping two convicted killers escape from a maximum-security prison in northern New York, leading to one of the largest manhunts in the state’s history, was sentenced on Monday to at least two years and four months in prison.

headline: 1965: Wilson Warns on Race Issue
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Prime Minister Harold Wilson wants to cut non-white immigration in 1965.
lead_paragraph: Blackpool, England — Prime Minister Harold Wilson warned today [Sept. 28] that ‘‘a social explosion of the kind we have seen abroad’’ might soon burst in Britain unless the government acts swiftly to curb the illegal flow of non-white immigrants. Addressing the annual convention of the Labour party, Mr. Wilson rejected charges that his policy is based on racial prejudice. In August, the government issued an executive order cutting Commonwealth immigration from 20,300 a year to 8,500. The restriction had its heaviest effect on immigration from the West Indies, India and Pakistan. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 29, 1965

headline: Warburg Pincus to Invest Up to $60 Million in Civitas Learning
abstract: Civitas specializes in using cloud-based computing to help schools examine which students are struggling and why.
lead_paragraph: With sophisticated data analysis seeping into nearly every industry, a start-up focused on higher education has drawn the big private equity firm Warburg Pincus as its latest investor.

headline: Decades-Old Questions Over Trump’s Wealth and Education
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Libel and Slander', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Donald Trump has boasted about being rich and smart, but he has not released data to back up his claims.

Geist — not to be confused with his son Willie, of “Morning Joe” and “Today” show fame — spent a day or so following Donald Trump around New York and wrote about it in a memorable New York Times Magazine cover story. Mr. Geist’s tale has a certain familiar quality to it. “Spending a day with Donald Trump is like driving a Ferrari without the windshield,” he wrote. “It’s exhilarating; he gets a few bugs in his teeth.”

headline: Airstrikes in Yemen Hit Wedding Party, Killing Dozens

lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Warplanes with the Saudi Arabia-led military coalition bombed a wedding party on Yemen’s Red Sea coast on Monday, killing at least 70 civilians, according to two local officials and a relative of one of the victims.

headline: A New View of a Nebula Full of Newborn Stars
abstract: A dazzling image of Messier 17, a reddish nebula 5,500 light-years from Earth, provides a detailed view of its newborn stars, gas clouds and dust.
lead_paragraph: A dazzling image of Messier 17, a reddish nebula 5,500 light-years from Earth, provides a detailed view of its newborn stars, gas clouds and dust. The gas in the nebula has a mass about 30,000 times that of the sun, astronomers estimate. The center of the nebula is home to more than 800 stars, and more are forming in the outer regions. The nebula is near the plane of the Milky Way, in the constellation Sagittarius, and is named after Charles Messier, who discovered it in 1764. The image was captured by a telescope at La Silla Observatory in Chile.

headline: London Cafe’s Cereal, at $5 a Bowl, Sets Off Wrath

lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Coming soon … Dismaland Calais.” The graffiti artist Banksy announced on his website on Sunday that timber and other materials from his glum parody theme park Dismaland would be sent to the “jungle” — a camp for migrants and refugees in Calais, France.

headline: Review: For DanceNow’s 20th Anniversary, an Encore at Joe’s Pub

lead_paragraph: At Joe’s Pub on Thursday, a woman at one table was salting her food heavily. In a thick New York accent, she complained about her husband. She tossed salt over her shoulder in great arcs, but no one was hit because she had a tiny bit more space around her than everyone else. She was onstage.

headline: Donald Trump Unveils Plan to Overhaul Tax Code With Broad Cuts

Trump laid out a plan on Monday to revamp the tax code, seeking to reduce taxes for people at most income levels with simplification and by reducing rates, while also eliminating deductions and certain breaks that allow the wealthy and corporations to avoid paying extra.

headline: Maxwell Anderson Resigns as Director of Dallas Museum of Art
abstract: After four years at the helm of the Dallas Museum of Art, Maxwell L. Anderson moves on to a new position in New York.
lead_paragraph: The Dallas Museum of Art announced on Monday that Maxwell L. Anderson — who has served as its director for almost four years and helped increase attendance while expanding the museum’s scope into areas like Islamic art — had resigned. A statement from the museum did not explain Mr. Anderson’s unexpected departure, except to say that he had accepted a position as director of grant programs at the New Cities Foundation in New York.

headline: Nation’s Rail Service Is Threatened as Deadline for Safety System Looms
abstract: The safety technology is required on 60,000 miles of railroad tracks by Dec. 31, and if it is not put in place, rail service could be disrupted nationally.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even after spending nearly $6 billion, the rail industry says it will not be able to meet its year-end government-imposed deadline to install a system known as positive train control, which is intended to prevent collisions or derailments caused by excessive speed.

headline: Children With H.I.V. More Likely to Die of Malaria
keywords: ['Malaria', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Children and Childhood', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The research, which looked at 3,000 Malawian children, partially resolves a question that has long puzzled H.I.V. specialists.
lead_paragraph: Children infected with H.I.V. appear much more likely than those who are not to die with severe malaria, a new study has found. It may make sense to give these children malaria drugs protectively, the authors said.

headline: Espelette Pepper Expands Reach to Butter
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Restaurants', 'Butter', 'Photography', 'Seafood']
abstract: Plus: a notable chocolate drink; a feast for your eyes; Peruvian-approved ceviche; a keyboard waffle iron; and a new Gourmet Garage in TriBeCa.
lead_paragraph: Lately, it seems as though the French will dust almost anything, even ice cream, with Espelette pepper, which is made from chiles grown in a designated area of the Basque Country. Now, imported Espelette butter has hit the American market, joining mustards, oils, mayonnaise and other items fueled with the ruddy spice. Slice the ingots of cultured, hand-churned, forcefully seasoned butter into pats to top a steak or fish. Or simply spread the butter on toast or crackers for canapés, perhaps crowned with a patch of cured ham: Beurre des Aldudes with Espelette pepper, $6 for 5.3 ounces at Le District, 225 Liberty Street (West Street), 212-981-8588, ledistrict.com.

headline: Is It Old Age, or A.D.H.D.?
keywords: ["Alzheimer's Disease", 'Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'Elderly', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Once seen as a disorder affecting mainly children and young adults, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder is increasingly understood to last throughout one’s lifetime.
lead_paragraph: The 73-year-old widow came to see Dr. David Goodman, an assistant professor in the psychiatry and behavioral sciences department at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, after her daughter had urged her to “see somebody” for her increasing forgetfulness. She was often losing her pocketbook and keys and had trouble following conversations, and 15 minutes later couldn’t remember much of what was said.

headline: As Banks Retreat, Private Equity Rushes to Buy Troubled Home Mortgages
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Foreclosures', 'Private Equity', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: With banks less willing to tackle distressed home loans, private equity and hedge funds have surged into the market. Critics say the new players are too quick to foreclose.
lead_paragraph: Private equity and hedge fund firms have bought more than 100,000 troubled mortgages at a discount from banks and federal housing agencies, emerging as aggressive liquidators for the remains of the mortgage crisis that erupted nearly a decade ago.

headline: Lies, Carly Fiorina and Abortion
abstract: Did the Republican presidential candidate invent a story about fetal brain harvesting at Planned Parenthood?
lead_paragraph: There has been an impressive amount of angry liberal commentary, which has spilled over into the mainstream press coverage (or do I repeat myself?) of the issue, about how in the last Republican presidential debate Carly Fiorina allegedly cited an entirely imaginary video in order to make a crazy claim about Planned Parenthood’s brain-harvesting ghoulishness that’s totally unsupported by the facts. Here’s Slate’s Dahlia Lithwick, in a representative rant, attacking Fiorina’s “big fib,” the sheer “enormity” of which has shaken Lithwick’s faith in honesty in politics and journalism:

headline: Many Conservative Republicans Believe Climate Change Is a Real Threat
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Research']
abstract: Echoing a number of other recent surveys, a significant number of Republicans believe the climate is changing and mankind plays a role in that change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A majority of Republicans — including 54 percent of self-described conservative Republicans — believe the world’s climate is changing and that mankind plays some role in the change, according to a new survey conducted by three prominent Republican pollsters.

lead_paragraph: Yes, there are Champions League games this week, and yes, you should probably take a peek at Bayer Leverkusen at Barcelona on Tuesday (2:45 p.m., Eastern time, Fox Sports 1), if only to see how Barça functions without a certain Argentine who will be out the next two months. headline: Toledo Museum to Return Four Antiquities Bought From Dealer Now Accused of Smuggling
abstract: The Toledo Museum of Art has decided to return four artworks that it had bought from an antiquities dealer now charged in India with smuggling and theft.
lead_paragraph: The Toledo Museum of Art has decided to return four pieces of rare Indian artwork on display there to India after concluding that their provenance had been falsified or could not be verified. All four of the ancient objects had been purchased from Subhash Kapoor, a former New York art dealer who is awaiting trial in India on charges of theft and smuggling.

headline: Giants’ Victor Cruz Returns to Practice
abstract: Cruz, a wide receiver, ran about 20 pass routes without discomfort in either his surgically rebuilt right knee or his strained left calf muscle. “Everything feels good; everything is starting to click,” he said.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants wide receiver Victor Cruz returned to practice Monday for the first time in more than a month and ran about 20 pass routes without discomfort in either his surgically rebuilt right knee or his strained left calf muscle. Cruz said after the hourlong workout that he was convinced that he would play when the Giants visit the surging Buffalo Bills on Sunday.

headline: Burkina Faso Coup Plotters Refuse to Give Up Arms, Imperiling Deal
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Kidnapping and Hostages']

lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — The troops who staged a failed coup in Burkina Faso have refused to give up their weapons under a political deal negotiated last week by West African leaders, the country’s transitional government said on Monday.

headline: Plea Deal for Dennis Hastert Is Being Discussed, Lawyers Say

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Lawyers for J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House of Representatives, have been discussing a possible plea agreement with prosecutors to resolve charges that Mr. Hastert lied to F.B.I. agents and illegally structured bank withdrawals, a federal court hearing revealed on Monday.

headline: Who Should Have Access to DNA Evidence?
keywords: ['Forensic Science', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Confessions', 'Sex Crimes', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Joseph Buffey pleaded guilty to rape, even though there was forensic evidence showing he didn’t commit the crime. Should prosecutors have been required to share it with him?
lead_paragraph: Next week, the West Virginia Supreme Court will hear a case in which 30 former prosecutors from around the country have taken the unusual step of siding with the defense. It’s a battle over a DNA test, and whether prosecutors must turn the results over to a defendant when they point to his innocence — even if he has made the decision to plead guilty.

headline: 7 New Legionnaires’ Cases in Bronx Prompt Investigation

headline: Taliban Pose for Victory Selfies in Afghan City

lead_paragraph: As some veteran foreign correspondents pointed out, watching Taliban insurgents storm into the northern Afghan city of Kunduz on Monday and declare their intention to govern according to Islamic law seemed to echo the way the city was taken by Western-backed, Islamist mujahedeen in 1988, just days after the withdrawal of Soviet troops.

headline: Silent Barn, a Brooklyn Arts Space, Is Damaged in a Fire
abstract: The Bushwick space, known for its sweaty punk shows, is rescheduling three weeks of events after a fire in the building’s residential area.
lead_paragraph: Silent Barn, the D.I.Y. arts space in Bushwick, Brooklyn, known for its sweaty punk shows and its strong support for performers, is in rebuilding mode after a fire on Friday in its residential area led to significant damage.

headline: Planned Parenthood to Offer Free S.T.D. Testing on National Pink Out Day
abstract: Fighting back against Republican attacks, Planned Parenthood is offering free testing for sexually transmitted diseases in 28 cities on Tuesday, “National Pink Out Day.”
lead_paragraph: It’s not unusual for contenders in political battles to try to win support with giveaways, a candidate offering tax cuts, for instance, or a labor union giving out free coffee and donuts at a rally. But Planned Parenthood, now embroiled in a fierce fight with Congressional Republicans, is taking the concept to a whole new level: free testing for sexually transmitted diseases.

headline: Drake and Future Lead a Billboard Chart Featuring Two Versions of ‘1989’

lead_paragraph: Nine years after he played the same role Off Broadway, the actor Jeff Daniels will star in a Broadway production of “Blackbird” as a man who sexually abused a young girl.

headline: A New Effort Has Doctors Turn Patients Into Donors

lead_paragraph: A well-to-do cancer patient is nearing the end of her treatments. During an office visit, she says to her doctor, “I can’t thank you enough for the care you provided.”

headline: British Labour Party, Wary of Old Image, Puts Its Focus on Prudence
keywords: ['Speeches and Statements', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']

headline: A Small Step in Changing S.E.C. Administrative Proceedings
abstract: The agency’s changes to how these proceedings will proceed are unlikely to blunt the criticism of them.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission has been pestered with complaints over its move to file more administrative proceedings before in-house judges, including proceedings involving complex matters like insider trading and accounting fraud that used to be brought in federal district courts.

headline: Broadway Takes a Hit as a Pope and a Holiday Distract New York
