headline: Recent History
abstract: A graphic novel set in the 1970s shows a kind of childhood long gone, but not so long ago.
lead_paragraph: Middle-grade readers today are part of what’s becoming known as Generation Z, born between 1996 and 2011 (give or take a year or so on either end). As this newspaper has noted, they have by now their own generational sensibility: more Lorde than Lady Gaga, more Snapchat than Facebook. Growing up entirely in a digital era, they are more private, sensible and cautious than their Millennial elders. Perhaps that’s because they are being raised not by high-flying boomers but by Generation X, which one Times article calls “a relatively small, jaded generation that came of age in the post-Watergate, post-Vietnam funk of the 1970s, when horizons seemed limited.” Much of the current helicopter-parenting phenomenon, it has been speculated, is a result of these Gen-Xers overcorrecting with their offspring for the strange and often jarring empty spaces that characterized their own 1970s childhoods. Back then, I think it is safe to say, “parenting” as a verb — a life-defining, life-consuming activity — had not been invented, even as the world had become more treacherous for children to navigate. It seems appropriate, then, that one of the best books I have yet read about growing up in the 1970s is a graphic novel for middle-grade readers: “Sunny Side Up,” by Jennifer L. Holm and Matthew Holm.

headline: The Essence of New Hampshire, Distilled
abstract: At Tamworth Distilling & Mercantile, bottling general-store-like spirits is a study in circumventing the law.
lead_paragraph: At Tamworth Distilling & Mercantile, which opened earlier this year on the grounds of a dilapidated New Hampshire inn, high-proof grain alcohol embodies the anachronistic, utilitarian charm of something you might have once found at a general store — or today, at the Vermont Country Store. According to its label — printed with, according to the product’s illustrator and namesake, Reverend Michael Alan, “a mixture of English and Latin, the Theban, and Adamic alphabets, and various magickal sigils for peace and love and prosperity” — the potent stuff can wipe away mascara and refresh stained furniture. The Alcohol, Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau has deemed it the most complicated label they have ever approved.

headline: At Rochas, Natural Beauty With a ’90s Touch
abstract: The show’s makeup artist Lucia Pieroni described the look as “you had mascara on a few days ago and forgot to take it off.”
lead_paragraph: “Nineties fresh-faced gorgeous cool girl,” was how the makeup artist Lucia Pieroni described the pared-back look at the Rochas show today — a nice balance with the designer Alessandro Dell’Acqua’s exquisitely detailed designs. “We used a very light foundation and lots of highlighters from Clé de Peau to get that really radiant skin,” Pieroni said backstage before the show. Next, a light eyeshadow was applied to the eyelid followed by eyeliner, just along the waterline — “like you had mascara on a few days ago and forgot to take it off,” she said. Lips were merely a shade of the softest pink, smudged on just so with the fingertips.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — France has opened the world’s first criminal inquiry into torture under President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, officials and rights advocates said Wednesday, an indirect rebuke to Russia and its efforts to rehabilitate Mr. Assad as part of an international anti-Islamist coalition.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Hinduism']

headline: A Lifesaving Smartphone App Inspired by a Brush With Tragedy
abstract: His father’s fall from a snowy rooftop spurred Michael Martin to help found a start-up whose mission is to better connect smartphones and 911 centers.
lead_paragraph: During a 2014 winter storm, Charles Martin climbed onto the roof of his rural Rockport, Ind., home to clear off a foot of heavy, wet snow. With his wife at work, Mr. Martin, a family counselor, slipped and fell off the roof, breaking his wrist and shattering his hip. Lying on his icy driveway in severe pain, he tried to call 911 on his cellphone, but the call would not go through. He lay in 20-degree cold for two hours until his wife arrived and dialed the emergency number from the landline inside the house.

headline: U.S. Base Seen as Monument to Futility as Afghans Watch Kunduz Fall
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: An American base in Kunduz has become a refuge for hundreds of Afghan soldiers and civilians besieged by the Taliban forces that now control the city.
lead_paragraph: The base was not much to behold when the American soldiers arrived in Kunduz in 2010. Nestled atop a vast plateau, it was little more than a collection of stucco buildings with chipping paint, a small airstrip on one side, a graveyard of rusting Soviet vehicles on the other. And everywhere was the Afghan dust, so fine it would puff like dry mountain snow with every step.

headline: Limón Dance Thrives, Decades After Its Founder’s Death
abstract: The troupe will celebrate its 70th season with a two-week festival.
lead_paragraph: The future of American modern dance — and the issue of who will carry on the torch — is very much an open question, particularly since the death of Merce Cunningham in 2009 and the closing of his company. What happens when the founding genius, the original voice, is gone? Martha Graham died in 1991, but her troupe survives, thanks to “contextual” presentations and new works by living choreographers; Paul Taylor, still actively producing work, is 85. His company, too, is making moves to widen its repertory.

headline: Refugee Crisis in Europe Prompts Western Engagement in Syria

abstract: The rush of refugees into Europe has stirred new urgency among Western leaders to address the war in Syria and push harder for an end to it.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Over the last four years, as four million Syrian refugees poured into neighboring countries and slipped inexorably into poverty, António Guterres, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, said he had pleaded in vain with world leaders to take their plight more seriously.

headline: Classical Duets of a Singular Nature
abstract: The double concerto, a relative compositional rarity that includes two soloists, will be featured in separate performances in October.
lead_paragraph: “To him for whom it was written” Johannes Brahms inscribed on the manuscript of his 1887 Double Concerto for violin, cello and orchestra. At first, the gesture appears perfunctory: concertos are often dedicated to their performers. But why, for a work for two soloists, “him” and not “them”?

lead_paragraph: Like many art stories, this one begins not with a birth but a death — that of Robert Loughlin, whose demise was wild enough to give Vincent van Gogh a run for his money.

headline: A Not-So-Stealthy Leopard

headline: The Great Outdoors Begins in Brooklyn Heights
keywords: ['Camps and Camping', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: A few words on camping, staying warm in winter and “the lumberjack thing” from Jed Lubin of Hatchet Outdoor Supply Company.
lead_paragraph: “I’m not in love with the lumberjack thing,” said Jed Lubin, the 29-year-old manager of Hatchet Outdoor Supply Company, a store in Brooklyn Heights. The “lumberjack thing” Mr. Lubin referred to is a certain look common to the city streets (Iron Ranger boots, neoprene shell jackets) sometimes favored by those whose idea of adventure may be an Uber ride to Greenpoint. But Hatchet caters to those who immerse themselves in the great outdoors. In addition to classic clothing brands like Filson, the store stocks portable stoves, backpack tents and, yes, hatchets.

headline: 36 Hours in Bologna

headline: Effectiveness of Talk Therapy Is Overstated, a Study Says
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Research']
abstract: A new analysis found that talk therapy is effective for treating depression, but about 25 percent less effective than previously thought.
lead_paragraph: Medical literature has overstated the benefits of talk therapy for depression, in part because studies with poor results have rarely made it into journals, researchers reported Wednesday.

headline: Vittorio De Sica Retrospective at Film Forum Will End on a High
abstract: The festival will conclude with a week of De Sica’s best work, including “A Farewell to Arms,” “Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow” and “The Garden of the Finzi-Continis.”
lead_paragraph: Film Forum concludes its monthlong retrospective of Vittorio De Sica (1901-1974) with a week of high points. On Monday, Oct. 5, there’s “A Farewell to Arms,” David O. Selznick’s 1957 production of Ernest Hemingway’s World War I novel. Much panned, it still earned De Sica, playing Major Rinaldi, his only Oscar nomination for acting.

headline: For VW, Costs of Emissions-Test Cheating Will Outweigh Gains
abstract: Skimping on emissions technology probably saved VW a measly $4.8 billion, less than it has so far set aside to meet recall costs.
lead_paragraph: Cheating on emissions tests has left Volkswagen with criminal investigations, potentially enormous fines and a corporate governance crisis. One might think the rewards for behaving badly must have been high indeed. Not so.

headline: End Boxing at West Point, a Former Army Secretary Says
abstract: A former Army secretary writes, “To be willing to die for your country in battle is one thing; to be permanently scarred for the sake of tradition is another.”

headline: Loan Servicers Faulted for Some Student Loan Problems

headline: France and the Netherlands Chip In to Buy Rembrandt Portraits
abstract: Two Rembrandts will stay in Europe and go on public display for the first time in centuries in an agreement between the French and Dutch governments.
lead_paragraph: France and the Netherlands have agreed to jointly buy two Rembrandt portraits from the French executive Eric de Rothschild for 160 million euros, or $179 million, the culture ministries of both countries said on Wednesday.

headline: 36 Hours in Bologna, Italy
abstract: This food-loving city has a wide array of bistros, cafes and markets, along with museums devoted to its history, and, yes, gelato.
lead_paragraph: Scrappy, scruffy Bologna could easily coast on its history, if not just on its culinary history. Home to one of the world’s oldest universities, this northern Italian city has contributed dozens of classic recipes and foods to the repertory of Italian cooking, including tortellini, tagliatelle and mortadella — the cold cut whose imitation is known as “Bologna” — as well as ragù Bolognese. As the capital of the region of Emilia-Romagna, Bologna is one of the best places to sample the cheeses, cured hams and vinegars that originate in the area, many of which have been famous for centuries. But modern Bologna is not just about the past. Dozens of cool new attractions have changed the face of the city, from new ways of eating to new museums and new bars. And although several of the city’s brightest attractions have appeared only within the last two or three years, many more are yet to come, including Eataly World, a huge culinary theme park scheduled to open here sometime in the next few months.

headline: Melania Trump, the Silent Partner
abstract: The spouse of Donald J. Trump is little seen and less often heard.
lead_paragraph: Lying prone on a rug adorned with the Great Seal of the United States, the woman who might someday be first lady is wearing high-heeled sandals and a crimson bikini.

headline: Republican Hypocrisy on Planned Parenthood
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Executive Compensation', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Republicans have never subjected big companies that actually break the law to the kind of scrutiny they’re giving Planned Parenthood.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans called for an investigation of Planned Parenthood this summer, after a series of deceptively edited videos issued by an anti-abortion group, the Center for Medical Progress, alleged that Planned Parenthood profits from the sale of tissue from fetuses. But at a hearing on Tuesday, members of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee deluged Cecile Richards, Planned Parenthood’s president, with a variety of questions entirely unrelated to that issue.

lead_paragraph: The Apple Watch that I wear generates a constant stream of questions from friends and strangers alike. One thing they always ask is whether the device is actually useful. I always answer yes — and that’s even more so now that Apple has released the first major upgrade of the watch’s operating system.

headline: 3 Hillary Clinton Emails Deemed ‘Secret’ in State Dept. Review of 6,300 Pages
abstract: The State Department is releasing the emails in batches, subject to a court order after revelations that Mrs. Clinton had used a private email system while she was the secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three emails sent to Hillary Rodham Clinton in 2011 when she was secretary of state contained information that should have been considered “secret,” the government’s second-highest classification, according to a State Department review of about 6,300 pages of her emails made public on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Rothschild & Sons,’ a Reimagined Show From a Beloved Songwriting Team
abstract: This musical from the songwriters Jerry Bock and Sheldon Harnick is being described as an “intimate one-act reimagining” of “The Rothschilds,” the 1970 musical.
lead_paragraph: What’s this? A new musical from the beloved songwriting team of Jerry Bock and Sheldon Harnick, whose “Fiddler on the Roof” returns to Broadway this fall? Mr. Harnick is still with us (huzzah!), but Mr. Bock died in 2010. Strictly speaking, “Rothschild & Sons,” which begins performances on Tuesday, Oct. 6, at the York Theater Company, is not a thoroughly new show. It’s being described as an “intimate one-act reimagining” of “The Rothschilds,” the 1970 musical, with a book by Sherman Yellen, about the Jewish dynasty that rose from obscurity and oppression in late 18th-century Germany and became a banking powerhouse. Mr. Yellen is also, happily, still with us. He has restructured his book to focus on the relationships among the patriarch, Mayer Rothschild, played by Robert Cuccioli, his wife and their five sons. The score will include some previously unheard Bock-Harnick songs and others revised by Mr. Harnick. For musical theater lovers, this makes for a must-have ticket. (yorktheatre.org.)

headline: Three’s a Trend: Slouchy White T-Shirts
abstract: Designers in Paris and Milan are teaming the wardrobe staple with long skirts.
lead_paragraph: The best part, perhaps, of one trend popping up on the spring/summer 2016 runways: It can already be found in your closet. A number of designers have show plain — and a little oversized — white T-shirts. Anthony Vaccarello and Tod’s both styled off-the-shoulder versions with black skirts (the former, slit up to there, and the latter, in embellished and perforated leather). The brand Off-White went for an all-white look, using a neckline cutout, ruffles and frayed edges to break up the monochromatic look.

headline: Who Is Fighting Whom in Syria
abstract: The Syrian civil war involves multiple countries with overlapping and at times conflicting agendas. Here is where some of the main foreign actors stand.
lead_paragraph: The Syrian civil war, now in its fifth year, involves multiple countries with overlapping and at times conflicting agendas. Competing visions of how to manage the conflict, which has led to a major global refugee crisis as well as the rise of the Islamic State, dominated discussions at the United Nations General Assembly last month. But despite days of meetings and diplomatic maneuvering, the crisis only intensified. Here is where some of the main foreign actors stand.

lead_paragraph: “The Gray Man” is so ambitious that its faults are worth overlooking. Indeed, for every nit to pick here, there’s a moment to admire.

lead_paragraph: In January, when he was appointed creative director of Gucci, Alessandro Michele was barely known to fashion’s press corps and buying teams, let alone the wider world. After working quietly behind the scenes for years, he had succeeded his former boss, Frida Giannini, who had been ousted from the position. Few had ever heard his name.

headline: Una emergencia dental y, al final, champaña: Don Francisco relata su último ‘Sábado Gigante’
abstract: El 26 de septiembre fue el primer sábado libre de Mario Kreutzberger en 41 años.
lead_paragraph: El 26 de septiembre fue el primer sábado libre de Mario Kreutzberger en 41 años. El anfitrión de “Sábado Gigante” – programa que llegó a su fin el pasado 19 de septiembre después de 53 años al aire – tomó su ultimo día libre en 1974, después del fallecimiento de su madre. Desde entonces, Kreutzberger, mejor conocido como Don Francisco, se presentó sin excepción alguna cada fin de semana en el programa de variedades que transmitía la cadena Univisión en Estados Unidos. Kreutzberger recordó su último día en “Sábado Gigante” en esta nota.

headline: The Pope Sought Out Kim Davis for a Blessing
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Marriages', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The meeting suggests the Vatican may be willing to get more involved in the politics of same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: In an intriguing postscript to Pope Francis’s whirlwind visit to the United States, a private papal meeting with Kim Davis, the Kentucky county clerk who defied a court order to license the marriage of same-sex couples, remained a well-kept secret until he headed home. The meeting, which occurred last Thursday afternoon at the Vatican Embassy in Washington, was arranged at the behest of the Vatican and not through the American church hierarchy, according to Mathew Staver, the lawyer for Ms. Davis, who said Francis thanked her for her courage, promised to pray for her, and urged her to “stay strong.”

lead_paragraph: The star wide receiver Victor Cruz, who was expected to return to the Giants’ lineup on Sunday for the first time in nearly a year, aggravated a strained left calf muscle that had been bothering him since mid-August and left practice Wednesday.

headline: Text to Text | ‘The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks’ and ‘The Sequel’
abstract: We invite students to explore the science and ethics of using human cells and tissue for medical research through the lens of Rebecca Skloot’s 2010 book, “The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks,” and a related 2013 Op-Ed.
lead_paragraph: How private should your genetic information be? Can scientific researchers and pharmaceutical companies use your cells for the sake of scientific advancement? These are not just hypothetical questions. For the descendants of Henrietta Lacks, and for more and more patients and their families, these are pressing ethical questions that need answers and clear policies.

headline: Tulsa Sheriff to Resign Over Killing by Deputy
abstract: A lawyer for Sheriff Stanley Glanz said that he would step down, six months after a volunteer deputy accidentally killed an unarmed man during an arrest.
lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — A grand jury here indicted the sheriff of Tulsa County on misconduct charges on Wednesday, and the sheriff’s lawyer said he will step down, six months after a volunteer reserve deputy accidentally shot and killed an unarmed man during an arrest.

headline: 12 Sentenced in 2006 Bombings of Mumbai Commuter Trains
abstract: Five people were sentenced to death and seven to life in prison for their roles in the blasts, which killed at least 180 people and wounded 800 others.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — An Indian court has sentenced five people to death and seven to life imprisonment for their roles in a series of bombings of Mumbai’s commuter trains in 2006, which killed at least 180 people and wounded 800 others. The seven nearly simultaneous blasts took place during the evening rush hours.

headline: The Pre-Aged Genius of Bill Withers
abstract: Paying tribute to the master of well-seasoned soul.
lead_paragraph: “I’m not going to let anybody con me out of being an old guy,” Bill Withers told The Times in an interview earlier this month. Now 77, the recent Rock & Roll Hall of Fame inductee was referring to the fact that he didn’t feel under any pressure to make new music. But even at the peak of his career, Withers was, in a sense, old. He was already 33 when his first hit, “Ain’t No Sunshine,” quietly strode out of radios in the late summer of 1971, a time when 30 was still at least nominally the expiration date for the relevancy of anything pop-cultural.

headline: A New Track From a Saint Laurent and Alexander Wang-Approved Funk Rebel
abstract: The British disco-punk musician Ebony Bones shares “Under the Blood Red Moon,” an apocalyptic dance anthem from her upcoming EP.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by “those who don’t blend in,” the British disco-punk musician Ebony Bones has played musical muse to Saint Laurent, who chose her music for the “Guess We’ll Always Have NY” campaign, and Alexander Wang, who featured it on the New York Fashion Week runway for his spring 2014 collection. And sauntering through the lobby of Berlin’s Park Inn Hotel, it’s clear that Bones, born Ebony Thomas, has the personality to match her bona fides. “I’m going through a yeti stage,” she says of what she’s wearing — a synthetic hair outfit by Franziska Michael — as she sits down on a plush couch. “Fashion for me is something you read in a magazine, but style is always a reflection of personality.”

headline: Verbatim: Ben Carson on Avoiding the Police as a Child
abstract: Ben Carson describes how he would get away from the police as a child, then says he was kidding.
lead_paragraph: — Ben Carson, after describing how as a child he could hop fences to get away from police officers after playfully “throwing rocks at cars,” before quickly saying that he was kidding and that he had “a tremendous amount of respect for police because they put their lives on the line every day.” He made the remarks at an event in Durham, N.H.

headline: Classical Playlist: Ornstein, Foss, ‘Divine Redeemer’ and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: ORNSTEIN: Piano Quintet; String Quartet No. 2Marc-André Hamelin, piano; Pacifica Quartet(Hyperion)“So gorgeous I want to inject it into my veins.” Those were the words I blurted out to a fellow critic about the slow movement of Leo Ornstein’s stunning Piano Quintet after I first heard it performed by this first-rate group of musicians two years ago at Carnegie Hall. Here, finally, is a recording of this epically proportioned forgotten treasure, written in 1927 in Philadelphia by Ornstein, a Ukrainian-born piano virtuoso and composer who died in 2002 at the age of 108. Ornstein goes for the jugular in the febrile outer movements, shot through with Russian folk material and rhythmic fire, but offers respite in the achingly tender Andante Lamentoso. His nervous, simmering String Quartet No. 2, written around 1929, is another interesting document of Ornstein’s late Romantic style, but it’s the Quintet that now ought to be picked up by intrepid performers and presenters and given its due in the chamber music canon. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

headline: A Reason to Keep Coming Back to Tomorrowland
abstract: Even though the brand is well established, the store in SoHo has just opened.
lead_paragraph: The only thing sadder than an empty closet is a full one. The empty one symbolizes lack, but also potential: It is a space of one’s own, to be filled as circumstance, taste and resources allow. Look at it the right way, and an empty closet means hope, a platform for the life you may lead.

headline: Review: In ‘Dr. Ken’ on ABC, Ken Jeong Is a Physician With Jokes
abstract: Mr. Jeong uses some of his own experiences from medical school and residency as he plays an over-the-top character in this new sitcom.
lead_paragraph: It’s one thing to tempt fate. It was another order of hubris entirely to write this exchange into the first episode of the new ABC comedy “Dr. Ken”:

headline: Review: ‘Benders’ Features Hip Checks and Humiliations
abstract: This IFC sitcom, about friends who play in a hockey league, continues the comic themes found in other Denis Leary television series.
lead_paragraph: As a producer and writer, Denis Leary is steadily building a library of shows about 21st-century manhood, and they don’t present a pretty picture.

headline: The New York Film Festival Contrasts the Human Pulse and the Digital
keywords: ['New York Film Festival', 'Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: The festival juxtaposes portraits of clinical minds, like “Steve Jobs” and “Experimenter,” and compassionate films like the documentary “Where to Invade Next.”
lead_paragraph: Can a single movie haunt an entire film festival? “Steve Jobs,” Danny Boyle’s scathing, scary, biographical portrait starring Michael Fassbender, may leave you with the creepy sensation that its subject has crawled inside your head and hijacked your mind. As I watched the movie — the New York Film Festival’s centerpiece, to be shown Saturday at Lincoln Center — I thought of a cult leader wheedling his worshipful flock to follow him and drink the Kool-Aid. The alternative was expulsion from Jobs’s inner circle, which for those in his orbit was the equivalent of banishment to Siberia.

headline: Review: ‘A Little Life,’ Hanya Yanagihara’s Traumatic Tale of Male Friendship
abstract: This novel depicts a man whose mind and body are indelibly scarred by abuse, and the friends and professionals who struggle to help him.
lead_paragraph: Hanya Yanagihara’s “A Little Life,” published in March, turned out to be one of the most talked-about novels of the summer. It’s a big, emotional, trauma-packed read with a voluptuous prose style that wavers between the exquisite and the overdone. A potboiler about very intense male friendship, it’s a sui generis phenomenon that became a runaway hit. And it is now a shortlisted contender for the Man Booker Prize, which will be awarded on Oct. 13.

headline: All 15 Republican Candidates File for South Carolina Primary
abstract: All 15 Republican presidential candidates have paid the $40,000 required to run in the South Carolina Republican primary next year, the first ballot-access test in the G.O.P. race.
lead_paragraph: All 15 Republican presidential candidates have paid the $40,000 required to run in the South Carolina Republican primary next year, the first ballot-access test in the G.O.P. race.

headline: September 30, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Greece, Kenya, Germany and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Greece, Kenya, Germany and the United States.

headline: For Amy Schumer, Multimillion-Dollar Book Deal Is All in the Timing
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Celebrities', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Ms. Schumer’s agreement with Simon & Schuster to write a book of essays came after she canceled a much smaller deal with HarperCollins.
lead_paragraph: When news broke last week that the comedian Amy Schumer had sold a memoir  to Simon & Schuster in a high-seven-figure deal, some publishing executives experienced a sense of déjà vu. Hadn’t Ms. Schumer already sold a book of autobiographical essays for seven figures two years ago?

abstract: Humberto Leon and Carol Lim revamp the Kenzo store in the heart of a Milan.
lead_paragraph: Humberto Leon and Carol Lim revamp the Kenzo store in the heart of a Milan.

headline: Debating ‘Otello,’ Blackface and Casting Trends
abstract: Ben Brantley and Anthony Tommasini weigh in on the debate set off by the Metropolitan Opera’s decision to forgo darkening makeup in its latest production.
lead_paragraph: When the Metropolitan Opera announced it would forgo the traditional darkening makeup for the title character in its new production of Verdi’s “Otello,” it set off the latest in an ongoing series of debates about the depiction of race in theatrical settings. In an email exchange, two critics for The New York Times — Ben Brantley, whose specialty is theater, and Anthony Tommasini, whose area is classical music — discussed the “Otello” staging, the uses of blackface, casting trends and more. Here are excerpts from their conversation.

headline: Review: Janet Jackson’s ‘Unbreakable’ Focuses on Love Outside the Bedroom
abstract: The word “sex” never appears in the lyrics of this album, Ms. Jackson’s first in seven years; she instead plays someone who’s happily in love and wishing for a better world.
lead_paragraph: Meet a sweeter, more chaste Janet Jackson. “Unbreakable,” her first album in seven years, arrives after two major events: the 2009 death of her brother Michael and her 2012 marriage to a Qatari businessman, Wissam Al Mana. Through 17 songs, Ms. Jackson sings about love, loyalty and compassion, and about memories as well as anticipation. The word “sex” never appears in the lyrics.

headline: Review: Wavves Celebrates the Joys of Bad Decisions on ‘V’
abstract: The Los Angeles punk band releases its fifth album.
lead_paragraph: Wavves

headline: Kenzo’s Milan Store: Under New Management
abstract: The redesigned Kenzo store in the heart of a Milan reflects the vision of Humberto Leon and Carol Lim, the creative team freshening up the label.
lead_paragraph: For years, Kenzo has kept quarters on the Via Alessandro Manzoni, one of a cluster of several streets in the touristy thick of central Milan where fashion brands vie to set up shop. The location has not changed, but much else has.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: ‘Press Enter,’ From the Pianist and Composer Romain Collin
abstract: Mr. Collin’s new album shows off his lucid, flowing pianism and walks a fine line in terms of modishness.
lead_paragraph: Romain Collin

headline: Chvrches Offer Hymns From the Altar of ’80s New Wave at SummerStage
abstract: This Scottish band, touring behind its new album, “Every Open Eye (Glassnote), was accompanied by a neon light show suited to the synthesizer textures.
lead_paragraph: On its 2013 debut album, “The Bones of What You Believe,” the Scottish band Chvrches knelt at the altar of new wave romanticism. The singer Lauren Mayberry has an almost metallic voice, plaintive but precise, and she used it primarily to convey ache. Her band mates, Iain Cook and Martin Doherty, are adept multi-instrumentalists, fluent in the whole range of 1980s sparkle. The album was something of a revelation, a revisiting of a distant time that didn’t feel studied.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: Batsheva Dance Company’s Young Ensemble Embodies a Signature Litheness
abstract: Ohad Naharin, the Israeli choreographer, has brought the group to New York for “Decadance,” an 80-minute show at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: It helps to be young, or at least youthful in body, to perform the work of Ohad Naharin, the Israeli choreographer and artistic director of Batsheva Dance Company. His oozy style, grounded in Gaga, his trademarked and globally disseminated movement method, calls for a special litheness and resilience, the kind that facilitates, say, a precipitous backbend and its swift reversal, or a knock-kneed crumpling to the floor, or a deliberately high-impact collision with a partner.

headline: Review: Yarn/Wire Provides Two Flavors of Thrill
abstract: After performing Mark Fell’s “core, self, oscillation,” the four members of this ensemble listened along with the audience to an electronic version.
lead_paragraph: Yarn/Wire’s concert on Tuesday ended without Yarn/Wire. It speaks to this unusual, insightful ensemble’s self-effacing focus on composers and their music that after playing Mark Fell’s “core, self, oscillation,” the four members — two pianists and two percussionists, celebrating the start of their 10th season together — left the stage and listened along with the audience to an electronic version of the same piece.

headline: Toxic Algae Outbreak Overwhelms a Polluted Ohio River
abstract: Pads of toxic blue-green algae have speckled nearly two thirds of the river in the last five weeks, experts say, putting water utilities on alert.
lead_paragraph: The Ohio River, transformed by mining and industrial waste and sewage overflows into the nation’s most polluted major waterway, has a new and unexpected tormentor this fall: carpets of poisonous algae.

headline: Review: Ensemble Signal’s Musicians Do Solo Turns in ‘Theatricals’
abstract: This concert, the first in the season’s Pop-Up series at Miller Theater in Manhattan, included the trombonist Steven Parker’s rendition of Berio’s “Sequenza V.”
lead_paragraph: There was only one possible criticism of the trombonist Steven Parker’s wonderful performance of Luciano Berio’s “Sequenza V” (1966) on Tuesday evening, part of a Pop-Up concert at Miller Theater: a sorry lack of clown shoes.

headline: Carole Little, Fashion Designer for Working Women, Dies at 80
abstract: Ms. Little’s sportswear found an eager audience among working women who sought affordable style, and her clothing adorned stars like Lauren Hutton and Jane Fonda.
lead_paragraph: Carole Little, a Los Angeles fashion designer whose sportswear found an eager audience among working women looking for affordable style, died on Sept. 19 at her home in San Diego. She was 80.

headline: Microsoft and Google Call an End to Patent Battles
abstract: Peace has broken out between Google and Microsoft, which agreed to dismiss all of their pending patent lawsuits against each other.
lead_paragraph: Peace has broken out between Google and Microsoft, which agreed to dismiss all of their pending patent lawsuits against each other.

headline: Where Is the Vegan Julia Child? Readers React to ‘Vegan Glam’
abstract: Readers weigh in on Jeff Gordinier’s article about attempts by the vegan movement to be more inclusive.
lead_paragraph: Readers were quick to respond to Jeff Gordinier’s article about the movement to bring the vegan lifestyle to the masses. While many discussed the merits of a plant-based diet, others talked about the need to make vegan choices accessible to more than just the wealthy. Selections from those comments are below; some have been edited for space.

headline: Military Deaths in ISIS Operations
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified seven American service members who have died supporting the operation to eliminate the Islamic State militant group.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified seven American service members who have died supporting the operation to eliminate the Islamic State militant group. It confirmed the death of the following American recently.

headline: Syrian Rebels Say Russia Is Targeting Them Rather Than ISIS
abstract: The rebels were taken aback on Wednesday when Russia’s first airstrikes in Syria appeared to target areas where the Islamic State has no known presence.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — “They are the most violent strikes,” says a man filming the grim aftermath of what he asserts was a Russian air attack on the town of Talbiseh, in the Homs Province of Syria. “This is the Russian criminal regime.” The voice then trails off into laments and prayers: “Oh God, oh God, oh God. God is all we need.”

headline: Saudi Objections Halt U.N. Inquiry of Yemen War
abstract: The United States, Britain and France, bowing to pressure from Saudi Arabia, dropped plans for an international investigation into the war in Yemen, to the dismay of human rights groups.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — In a U-turn at the United Nations Human Rights Council, Western governments dropped plans Wednesday for an international inquiry into human rights violations by all parties in the war in Yemen that has killed thousands of civilians in the last six months.

headline: Fiat Chrysler Workers Appear to Reject Contract Proposal
abstract: The outcome, if confirmed, would be the first time in more than 20 years Chrysler workers have turned down a contract negotiated by their union.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Hourly workers at Fiat Chrysler Automobiles appear to have soundly rejected a proposed new union contract that set no limit on the number of lower-paid workers and that contained no mechanism to move them up to top-wage status.

headline: Hillary Clinton Calls Kevin McCarthy’s Remarks on Benghazi Inquiry ‘Deeply Distressing’
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton said in an interview that the Republican congressman’s remarks revealed that the House committee’s investigation into the 2012 attacks was “always meant to be a partisan political exercise.”
lead_paragraph: Remarks by Representative Kevin McCarthy linking Hillary Rodham Clinton’s sinking poll numbers to a House committee’s investigation into the 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya, were “deeply distressing,” Mrs. Clinton said in an interview to be shown this weekend.

headline: Judge Blocks Obama Administration Rules on Fracking
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: A federal judge in Wyoming issued a preliminary injunction against the rules, which applied only to oil and gas production on federal and tribal lands.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Wednesday blocked the Obama administration’s first major regulations on hydraulic fracturing, a technique for oil and gas drilling that has led to a boom in American energy production but has also raised concerns about health and safety risks.

headline: Parsing YouTube Evidence of Russian Strikes in Syria
abstract: Video of Russian airstrikes on Syrian rebels, recorded from the air and the ground, raised questions about who, exactly, the bombardment was aimed at.
lead_paragraph: The start of the Russian air campaign against Syrian rebels on Wednesday unfolded in territory largely off limits to journalists, but at least some of the bombing runs appear to have been well documented on YouTube. Within hours of the first sorties, Russia’s Air Force released aerial views of some strikes, and footage recorded by militants and activists on the ground appeared to show the impact of the bombing.

headline: How to Wear Burgundy, the Hot Color for Fall
abstract: The color is everywhere and can be worn with much more than you think.
lead_paragraph: The color is everywhere and can be worn with much more than you think.

headline: How to Wear Burgundy, the Hot Color for Fall
abstract: The color is everywhere and can be worn with much more than you think.
lead_paragraph: If the front row at fashion week and the fall goods now arriving in stores are any indication, burgundy is officially the new navy. The shade, called oxblood in fall 2012 when it broke out as that season’s signature color, is everywhere, a moody tone signifying that summer has come to an end (although it’s showing on spring 2016 runways, too). The appeal is much like navy: It can be worn with much more than you would think. Here’s how.

headline: Rick Owens and the Leather Jacket That Changed His Career
keywords: ['Coats and Jackets', 'Leather and Leather Goods', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The designer on a widely imitated piece from one of his early collections, the foundation of everything he does.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, watching Rick Owens and his wife, Michele Lamy, beavering away in Los Angeles in a garret-like space at the Chateau Marmont, which was then crumbling, few fashion insiders would have bet on Mr. Owens’s staying power.

headline: Pioneering Female Photographers in Mexico
abstract: A new show in New York offers a 90-year survey of women who helped shape the visual narrative of Mexico starting in the decades after its revolution.
lead_paragraph: A new show in New York offers a 90-year survey of women who helped shape the visual narrative of Mexico starting in the decades after its revolution.

headline: Mets Must Deal With Injuries to Yoenis Cespedes, Steven Matz and Wilmer Flores
abstract: Two of Cespedes’s fingers were bruised by a pitch from the Phillies’ Justin De Fratus, and Matz, a potential starter in the postseason, continued to be bothered by a stiff upper back.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — During the third inning of a lazy game Wednesday, an 89-mile-per-hour fastball drifted high and tight toward Yoenis Cespedes and struck him on his left hand, pinching his middle finger between the ball and the bat.

headline: The SoHo Block Party and More Shopping Events and Sales Happening in New York
abstract: Mackage plans a pop-up; Rob Pruitt is having a green-screen runway; and more.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, the Canadian label Mackage is opening a pop-up shop where you’ll find cozy outerwear for the cooler months, like a pebble leather moto jacket ($1,050) and a wool coat with fur collar ($790). At 1122 Madison Avenue.

headline: Bernie Sanders Raises $26 Million, Powered by Online Donations Exceeding Obama’s 2008 Pace
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont raised $26 million for his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination in the last three months, a significant sum that was fueled by a torrid pace of online donations: more than a million so far.
lead_paragraph: Update: The campaign of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has since revised their numbers: It had raised about $26 million since July and has more than $26 million in cash on hand.

headline: Border Havoc as Nepalis Accuse India of Payback
abstract: Nepal said India imposed an economic blockade as retaliation for its adoption of a Constitution that had drawn Indian objections.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Days after Nepal adopted a constitution in a way that appeared to infuriate India, Kuldiep Singh, an official with India’s border security force, received his orders: Thoroughly search every single truck trying to cross into Nepal.
